HEADLINE: World Briefing

BYLINE: Compiled by Terence Neilan

 BODY:

THE AMERICAS
 
COLOMBIA: INDIAN TRIBE ASKS ASYLUM -- All 2,500 members of an Indian tribe have asked for political asylum in Spain, saying their community faces extermination at the hands of leftist guerrillas and right-wing death squads. The homeland of the Embera-Katio people in Cordoba Province has become a battleground for the groups. Larry Rohter (NYT) 

ECUADOR: WORLD BANK LOAN -- Barely a month after strikes and protests threatened to topple his Government, President Jamil Mahuad has obtained preliminary approval from the World Bank and other international lending agencies for a $900 million economic rescue package. The agreement is intended to lift Ecuador from its worst financial crisis since the Great Depression. Larry Rohter (NYT)
 
MEXICO: U.S. LIFTS TUNA BAN -- Over the objections of American environmentalists, the U.S. has lifted an embargo on Mexican canned tuna and authorized its sale carrying the label "dolphin safe." The U.S. imposed the embargo in 1987, saying dolphins were trapped in the large nets used by many Mexican fishermen. Julia Preston (NYT)
 
MEXICO: ELECTORAL REFORM BILL -- Opposition legislators in the lower house of Congress struck a blow to the governing party, known as the PRI, by approving a sweeping electoral reform law. The bill imposes new controls on government use of the news media during campaigns, permits the nine million Mexicans living abroad to vote, increases penalties for vote buying and election fraud and allows for party coalitions. The reform seems unlikely to pass the PRI-controlled Senate, however. Julia Preston (NYT)
 
EUROPE
 
ITALY: ANDREOTTI FACES LIFE TERM -- A public prosecutor in Perugia asked that former Prime Minister Giulio Andreotti be given a life sentence if convicted on charges he conspired in the 1982 murder of a journalist. Mr. Andreotti, 80, is also awaiting a verdict in Palermo, where he is on trial on separate charges that he was the Mafia's main protector in Rome. (NYT)
 
SPAIN: NEW PINOCHET CHARGES -- Judge Baltasar Garzon broadened the indictment against Gen. Augusto Pinochet, adding 12 charges of torture against the former Chilean dictator, making a total of 72 from the period beginning in 1988. The move came as General Pinochet's lawyers said they would appeal Britain's decision giving the go-ahead to extradition proceedings that could force him to stand trial in Spain. Al Goodman (NYT)
 
GREECE: MODERNIZING ITS FORCES -- Greece awarded Lockheed Martin a $2 billion contract for more than 50 F-16 jet fighters as part of a program to modernize its armed forces. Prime Minister Costas Simitis also announced that Dassault Aviation of France would be given a contract for 15 Mirage 2000-5's and an order to upgrade 10 others in Greece's fleet of about 60. (AP)
 
LITHUANIA: PREMIER STEPS DOWN -- Prime Minister Gediminas Vagnorius resigned, saying in a television address that his disagreements with President Valdas Adamkus were weakening the country. The two have been locked in a struggle over economic policy and have traded accusations of corruption. (Agence France-Presse)
 
ASIA
 
INDIA: PREMIER READY TO RUN -- Prime Minister Atal Behari Vajpayee, head of the coalition government that lost a confidence vote, said he would lead that same coalition into elections as its prime ministerial candidate. He also said in an interview with the magazine India Today that "it might be highly improper" for his caretaker government to sign the nuclear test ban treaty by the September deadline if the election is delayed until then. The date for new elections is not expected to be set until next week. Celia W. Dugger (NYT)
 
CAMBODIA: NEW ASEAN MEMBER -- The 32-year-old Association of Southeast Asian Nations achieved its dream of including all 10 countries in the region. At a ceremony in Hanoi, the association inducted the final member, Cambodia, after a two-year delay following a coup in that country. Seth Mydans (NYT)
 
MIDDLE EAST
 
ISRAEL: SHORTCUT TO PRISON -- An Israeli officer has been sentenced to 14 days in jail for mistakenly driving into a Palestinian self-rule area in an incident in which the Palestinian police opened fire and wounded an Israeli soldier, military officials said. The officer, a lieutenant in the paratroopers, was trying to take a shortcut to an Israeli Army base, the officials added. (Agence France-Presse)
 
IRAN: KHATAMI PLANS ARAB TOUR -- President Mohammad Khatami will visit Syria, Saudi Arabia and Qatar from May 10 to 20, signaling a marked improvement in ties between Iran and its Arab neighbors. Relations with the Arab world deteriorated after the Islamic revolution in 1979 and during the eight-year war with Iraq. (Agence France-Presse)
 
AFRICA
 
LESOTHO: SOUTH AFRICA PULLING OUT -- South Africa started withdrawing its troops from Lesotho, but South Africa and Botswana said they would set up a joint rapid reaction force that could deal with any further disturbances there. The two nations sent troops to Lesotho last September in an effort to restore order after months of political unrest. Donald G. McNeil Jr. (NYT)
 
RWANDA: EX-MAYOR GETS LIFE -- A military court in Switzerland sentenced a former Rwandan mayor to life in prison after finding him guilty of crimes committed during the 1994 genocide, including murder, attempted murder, incitement to murder and war crimes. The case against Fulgence Niyonteze, 35, was the first time a Rwandan suspected of war crimes had gone before a national court. Mr. Niyonteze was tried in Switzerland because he sought asylum there in 1994. (AP)

HEADLINE: Nafta vs. Mexico's Trees

 BODY:

To the Editor: 
 Re "All Across Mexico, a Chainsaw Massacre of Trees" (news article, April 28): When Mexico signed the North American Free Trade Agreement five years ago, it opened its forestry sector to increased trade and investment. At least a dozen United States logging companies went south, drawn by new access to vast forest reserves, few regulatory costs and a booming demand for wood-fiber packing by Mexico's export-driven manufacturing industry. Unable to compete against the flood of cheap American grain imports, Mexico's small farmers now cut trees to survive. These corporations now want to extend Nafta's forest-friendly rules to the rest of the globe through the World Trade Organization.
 
VICTOR MENOTTI
San Francisco, April 28, 1999
 
The writer is environment program director at the International Forum on Globalization. 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: Risk Takers' Safety Net

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY L. O'BRIEN

 BODY:
About two years ago, Matt Hazard and three of his buddies got together to form a new, hard-rock band in Minneapolis. At a loss for what to call themselves, they settled on Moral Hazard.
"The guitarist wanted to get my last name in the band because we thought it sounded cool, but every combination seemed kind of lame," recalls the 19-year-old Mr. Hazard. "But we were all in the same high school economics class, and one day our teacher began writing that term on the board and we said, 'That's it.' " 
 He adds, "It seems like a relevant term to society."
Indeed. Rarely do dreary economic abstractions become fodder for mainstream media accounts or occasional cocktail party chatter as the concept of moral hazard has.
Simply put, moral hazard describes any situation, though usually a financial one, in which risky behavior is encouraged because risk takers believe they will be bailed out of mistakes by a third party.
Think Asia and Russia here. The international financial crisis that erupted in Thailand and began tearing across the globe nearly two years ago left the policy wonks who had to deal with its consequences in a philosophic bind.
Many lenders and investors had plowed money into rapidly growing countries like Thailand, Indonesia and South Korea in the belief that governments there would always prop up certain key companies. But many of the corporations were so larded with bad debt that the governments couldn't keep them afloat forever. In Russia, feverish financial speculation was fueled in part by the belief that the Russian Government wouldn't default on its bonds and by the perception that Russia, with all its nuclear warheads, was too big for anyone to let it fail.
Investors badly misjudged the situation in all those countries, lost money when economic meltdowns occurred, then stampeded for the exits. That put all the countries in a squeeze. After all, it's hard to keep food stocked in stores and an economy moving ahead when nobody will lend you more money. So the International Monetary Fund and the United States Treasury Department both advocated lending fresh funds to these nations to get them over the hump and back onto the happy track of prosperity.
"No, no, no!" shouted critics of that idea. They said that if the I.M.F. and the Treasury Department gave more money to the countries, both the countries and speculators would feel safe to invest recklessly in the future because they knew they would be bailed out. Classic moral hazard.
"When individual behavior is random and the downside is bid up by implicit guarantees of being bailed out, you encourage risky behavior," observes William A. Niskanen, chairman of the Cato Institute, a libertarian think tank in Washington. Asia and Russia, of course, aren't the only arenas in which moral hazard has reared its ugly head.
Other well-known cases of moral hazard at work include the savings and loan debacle in the United States a decade ago, in which owners of old-fashioned mortgage banks felt safe taking fliers on dangerous real estate forays because the banks' deposits were insured by the Federal Government. The Government-led rescue of the once high-flying hedge fund Long Term Capital might also be morally hazardous if it encourages free-wheeling speculation disconnected from the threat of financial ruin.
Although no public money was used to keep the fund afloat, critics said the Federal Reserve's orchestration of the rescue sent a signal that some funds, no matter how much gambling they indulged in, were too important to fail.
Insurance underwriters and their customers regularly engage in morally hazardous transactions. Health insurers constantly weigh what medical treatments they will cover, trying to decide whether coverage will induce patients to pursue elaborate and expensive treatments that they don't necessarily need. The flip side of this is, of course, insurers or H.M.O.'s that become so tightfisted and risk averse that patients can't get treatments they surely need. Home ownership can also be a morally hazardous proposition. People who might otherwise avoid building homes in Malibu because of the risk of fire and mudslides or in hurricane-ravaged parts of the East Coast might do so anyway because their home insurer picks up the tab if their house is destroyed.
Morally hazardous situations may also crop up outside the narrow confines of the financial world. Take major league baseball, for instance. The American League, unlike the National League, has long had a designated hitter rule that allows a team to substitute a better batter each time their pitcher would normally step up to the plate. And where is the moral hazard in that? It turns out that American League pitchers tend to throw more bean balls at batters than do their counterparts in the National League because, some studies say, such risky -- even nasty -- behavior can't be punished. The designated hitter rule keeps the bean baller safely away from the plate, where an opposing hurler could otherwise launch fastballs at his head in retribution.
Spotting morally hazardous situations may be easy in retrospect, after the risk has surfaced, but it can be much harder to discern moral hazard -- or act on it -- in a crisis.
Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin, as canny an observer of financial markets as anyone in Washington, was attuned to the ambiguities of moral hazard when he defended the effort to pump fresh funds into South Korea in 1997 as that country edged toward economic collapse. "Look, I wouldn't spend a nickel to bail out investors or creditors," he said at the time. "The purpose of this is not to help creditors; the purpose is to help Korea." But he conceded that saving the country also meant saving investors who had placed errant bets there.
Others agree that sidestepping moral hazard can't be the sole goal. They say a more nuanced balancing act must be struck between not encouraging risky behavior and forestalling an economic crisis before it spins further out of control.
"Sometimes people just say, 'Oh, there's a moral hazard here,' and rule out a whole range of actions that might be taken," says Barry Bosworth, a senior economics fellow at the Brookings Institution in Washington. "I'm not saying we just disregard moral hazard and charge ahead, but it is often the case in financial crises that those who triggered the crisis don't pay at all; average citizens do."
One way to avoid moral hazard is to establish better frameworks for anticipating and reducing risks in a world where different countries hew to wildly different ethical and financial standards. Along these lines, Gordon Brown, Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer, has called for improved financial disclosure, better oversight and stronger ties between the public and private sectors to stave off financial disasters in various parts of the globe.
Big central banks, if they're honestly run and efficiently operated, can also be useful lenders of last resort when a crisis looms. Mr. Bosworth points out that the United States banking system operated for about 100 years without a central bank to act as a lender of last resort during financial crises. So before the creation of the Federal Reserve earlier this century, the country frequently lurched from financial crisis to financial crisis, a pattern that has largely disappeared here since the Depression.
For his part, Mr. Niskanen at the Cato Institute doesn't rule out lending during a crisis if all somebody needs are a few bucks to get them over the hump.
But if larger problems like corruption, cronyism or wasteful economic policies exist when a bailout is being considered, he is inclined to emphasize the downsides of bailing out shortsighted risktakers and creating moral hazard.
"I think we should respond in a crisis based on rules established before the crisis occurs and not based on rules negotiated during a crisis," he says.
But others demur from this point of view, noting that pulling the plug on a borrower -- even if it is the right thing to do in terms of avoiding moral hazard -- can often make a bad financial situation even worse.
"This is a game about getting the right balance between systemic risk and allowing markets to function," said Morris Goldstein, a former International Monetary Fund official and a senior fellow at the Institute for International Economics in Washington. "I lean more to the case by case approach than to the idea of laying out rules in advance. It's very difficult to lay out an either-or rule because systemic risk can sometimes be overwhelming."
There are some rock bands who share Mr. Goldstein's philosophy and extol the virtues of benevolence if the threat of moral hazard arises, especially when rules are not clear or maybe don't even exist, as in the notoriously fickle and unfettered music business.
"When we researched it on the Internet, moral hazard seemed to be people whining about the U.S. helping out other countries," says Mr. Hazard. "But in the music industry you just can't make it on your own, and you always need someone to bail you out if you're going to make it. So that side of moral hazard has a lot of meaning for me."

HEADLINE: Challenging Everyone's Conceptions About Blacks

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.

 BODY:
At times Orlando Patterson seems to be mouthing the arguments of racial neoconservatives. An African-American who teaches sociology at Harvard University, Mr. Patterson asserts that problems in many black neighborhoods stem less from white racism than from the breakdown of the black family and the behavior of black men who impregnate too many black women and marry too few.
In other moments, he sounds like a traditional liberal, insisting slavery and the Southern sharecropping system are to blame for such irresponsible behavior by breaking down the family structure. 
 Then again, his proposed solution -- that more black women should marry outside their race -- might take those on the left and right by surprise.
"Once they make that important decision to explore the broader marriage market, it may well put more pressure on Afro-American men to shape up," he said in a recent interview. "But the situation right now is that they've restricted their market to the men who have no incentive to change."
Such iconoclastic views have helped turn Mr. Patterson, 59, into one of the most provocative thinkers on the status of blacks today. Conservatives criticize him by saying he focuses too much on the debilitating effects of slavery and not enough on the impact of the welfare state. Black feminists chastise him for challenging the notion that black women suffer from double discrimination because of their race and sex. (He says they are getting more education and higher incomes than black men.)
Meanwhile, some blacks take him to task for publicly airing "dirty linen." Kenneth S. Tollett, a professor of sociology at Howard University, said: "I don't think he appreciates the consequences of his analysis. He is apparently blaming black males as the major source of difficulties in the black community. That's just fodder for racists and people who want to denigrate the black community."
Yet agitating people may be the point. "It's a cultivated style of his," said Glenn C. Loury, a professor of economics at Boston University and a friend of Mr. Patterson. "He means to be iconoclastic. He means to go against the grain. He takes relish in it."
Mr. Patterson has been challenging conventional ideas about race for years. He has written five weighty sociological treatises, including "The Ordeal of Integration" (Civitas/Counterpoint, 1997) and "Freedom in the Making of Western Civilization" (Basic Books, 1991), both of which won the National Book Award. He has also penned three works of fiction, including "The Children of Sisyphus," published in 1964 when Mr. Patterson was 23 years old. It was one of the first accounts detailing the life style and philosophy of Jamaica's Rastafarian cult.
"I was writing about the Rastas long before they became fashionable," he said in the lilting accent of his native Jamaica as he leaned back on a leather sofa in his fifth-floor office. Mr. Patterson's skin is deep bronze; his hairline is receding. A wispy goatee clings to his chin.
Now it is his latest book, "Rituals of Blood: Consequences of Slavery in Two American Centuries" (Civitas/Counterpoint), that is causing a stir by weighing in on the long-running debate over how much damage slavery did to the black family.
During the antebellum period, abolitionists emphasized the havoc slavery played on black family life. After the war, Southerners who dominated American history for decades flipped that argument upside down, calling slavery a stabilizing force on blacks whose family life deteriorated after emancipation.
Earlier in this century, sociologists like W. E. B. Du Bois and E. Franklin Frazier placed the spotlight once again on the debilitating aftereffects of slavery. As a young official in the Johnson Administration, Daniel Patrick Moynihan was influenced by their work as he grappled with the persistently high level of out-of-wedlock births among blacks.
In the 1970's, Mr. Moynihan's argument was countered by Herbert G. Gutman, a professor at City University of New York. In his classic book, "The Black Family in Slavery and Freedom," he tried to show the resilience of the black family and how through all of slavery's depredations, the family emerged relatively intact. Mr. Gutman's work was seized upon by many black intellectuals who were both troubled by Mr. Moynihan's depiction of black antisocial behavior and the implicit message of Mr. Gutman's work: If black families survived the ravages of slavery, then whatever problems that plague them today are the result of contemporary racism.
To Mr. Patterson, however, Mr. Gutman's theory is romantic nonsense.
"Look, how can you have 270 years of history in which the family was not recognized, women could be raped, beaten, stripped naked in the fields before their so-called husbands; where men were emasculated deliberately in the sense of having no authority, no say over their children, even though they are encouraged to reproduce; how can you have 270 years of that and claim that people came out with intact families with a two-parents, suburban-type family?" he asked. "It's just absurd on the face of it."
He scoffs at critics who say his forthright critique of black men and families hurts African-Americans. And he is impatient with the reluctance to discuss sexual relations between black men and women.
Mr. Patterson started writing about gender relations among African-Americans in 1991, when Anita Hill leveled her explosive charges of sexual harassment against Clarence Thomas after he was nominated for the Supreme Court. In an Op-Ed article for The New York Times, he dismissed the charges and Mr. Thomas's alleged "Rabelaisian humor" with Ms. Hill as merely examples of a "down-home style of courting."
Mr. Patterson was hissed at when he repeated his theory at a conference at Georgetown University a year later. After the experience, Mr. Patterson began to throw himself into the issue of why the relations between black men and black women were in such a sorry state.
His interest in the subject has a personal dimension as well, however.
His father was a police detective whose efforts to unionize police officers caused him to run afoul of the British colonial authorities in rural Jamaica, turning him into a bitter man who drank too much and abused his wife. The couple separated when Mr. Patterson was 2. They reunited when he was 11, but there was always tension in the marriage.
"I guess a lot of my attitudes toward gender and so on are formed by that experience, because I do think that I've always had difficulty relating to him," Mr. Patterson said of his father. "They came back together mainly for my benefit, but I'm not sure that was a great idea for them."
At college at the University of the West Indies and in graduate school at the London School of Economics, Mr. Patterson called himself a "radical nationalist." He demonstrated for an end to Jamaica's colonial status -- he was 22 when the country became independent in 1962 -- and for a federation of Caribbean nations. His left-wing politics led to a long friendship with Michael Manley, the late socialist Prime Minister of Jamaica, to whom Mr. Patterson was an unofficial adviser for many years.
In 1968 a crackdown by a conservative Jamaican Government against leftist student and faculty organizations at the University of the West Indies, where he was teaching, convinced Mr. Patterson that he should move to the United States, where he was eventually appointed to the Harvard faculty.
His background and interests have created an odd mixture in Mr. Patterson: a black student of the American racial dynamic who was born and raised in a foreign country with a black majority. It is a mixture he says allows him to view racial issues here with a fresh eye.
"Growing up in a society in which almost everybody -- my kinsmen anyway -- were people of color, you don't experience the kind of racial hurts which from what I read in autobiographies and accounts by sociologists are a very powerful shaper of attitudes," he said. "Race was something I discovered intellectually later on in college. But having a group of white people who were the majority around you and constantly giving off signals of their superiority and your inferiority was something I was spared the burden of having to put up with."

HEADLINE: Minnesota Mining Says Profit Declined

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: ST. PAUL, April 30

 BODY:
The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company, the maker of more than 50,000 industrial and consumer products, said today that its first-quarter profit fell 4 percent despite a rebound in sales in Asia.
Net income fell to $384 million, or 95 cents a share, from $400 million, or 98 cents, a year earlier. The per-share results were better than the average forecast of 91 cents of analysts polled by the First Call Corporation, which tracks corporate earnings. The company's shares rose $3.375, to $89. 
 Minnesota Mining, whose products range from Scotch tape to Nexcare bandages to industrial abrasives, said revenue rose 2.2 percent, to $3.78 billion from $3.7 billion. The company, which gets half its sales overseas, had its best performance in five quarters in the Asia Pacific region. Sales also rose in the United States, though just 2 percent at a time when the economy surged.
In Asia Pacific, sales volume rose 7 percent. Optimism for a turnaround in the region has fueled industrial stocks for the last two weeks.
The company's shares, which touched a two-year low of $65.625 on Sept. 1, have weakened in the last 18 months on concerns about Asia's economies and six straight quarters of year-to-year profit declines for the company.
But since the start of the year, its shares have risen 25 percent, helped by this month's gains by industrial stocks.

HEADLINE: Outgoing U.N. Development Chief Berates U.S.

BYLINE: By JUDITH MILLER

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, April 30

 BODY:
With American debt to the United Nations soaring and contributions to development aid plunging, the outgoing chief of the United Nations Development Program, the highest-ranking American in the United Nations system, has accused the United States of "tragic shortsightedness" in failing to support the world body.
The United States has consistently "undervalued, underutilized and underfunded" the United Nations and its agencies in recent years, said the development chief, James Gustave Speth, a soft-spoken environmentalist known to be close to Vice President Al Gore. 
 Mr. Speth, who will step down at the end of June as head of the United Nation's largest agency after six years, was interviewed on Wednesday in his spacious office with a panoramic view of the United Nations Secretariat and Manhattan's East Side. He is leaving to be dean of Yale University's School of Forestry and Environmental Studies.
In words laced with frustration, he deplored what he called American "ignorance" of the "extraordinary" role played by the United Nations in preventing and containing conflict, sustaining development and reducing poverty. He criticized not only the Republican-led Congress, which has been holding $1.6 billion in past dues hostage to anti-abortion and other domestic concerns, but also the Democratic Administration that had nominated him.
While "a lot more supportive" than Congress, the Clinton Administration has also given the United Nations too little priority, he said, often "going it alone" as a superpower and failing to press for the implementation of its pledge to reward the reforms it advocated.
A troubling indication that Washington had given up its leadership here, many United Nations officials said, was the Administration's decision to permit a non-American to replace Mr. Speth, who was the sixth American to hold that post.
Several diplomats and American officials said that Washington had given up the post in hopes of further reducing its contribution to United Nations development aid. Last week, the General Assembly confirmed Secretary General Kofi Annan's nomination of Mark Malloch Brown, the British-born World Bank vice president, as Mr. Speth's successor.
The U.N.D.P., the world body's main foreign-aid arm, has about 5,000 employees in 130 offices throughout the world and disburses about $1.9 billion of its $2.2 billion budget to fight poverty and underdevelopment. Europeans, resentful of the United States for failing to pay $1.6 billion in assessments, had campaigned for the U.N.D.P. slot.
Although the agency's budget comes from voluntary contributions, America's portion of the budget has been dropping. In the new issue of Foreign Affairs, Mr. Speth called Washington's aid budgets "particularly stingy." In the interview he noted that while Nordic countries contributed about $16 per capita to his agency, America's per capita contribution stood at 50 cents.
The drop comes at a time of growing poverty amid abundance. Almost three-fifths of the world's 4.4 billion people in developing countries live without basic sanitation; almost one-third are without safe drinking water; a quarter lack adequate housing, a fifth are malnourished and 1.3 billion live on less than $1 a day, he said.
"Most Americans have no sense of how desperate the lot of one half of humanity is," Mr. Speth said.
Mr. Speth said that although the United Nations had made "dramatic progress" in eliminating duplication and waste, and that his own agency had undergone "significant restructuring" -- spending nearly a fourth of its budget now on projects that promote better government, democracy and market forces -- the Administration's budget request of $80 million this year was still 20 percent less than what it requested and Congress approved.
He warned that a weakening of the United Nations' development efforts would undermine the organization's peacekeeping activities. "It is the hands-on work of helping people in 160 countries around the world that builds up the credibility of the United Nations and gives it access," he said.
John R. Bolton, senior vice president of the Washington-based American Enterprise Institute, disagreed with Mr. Speth's suggestion that failing to support the world body's development work was lessening its impact in world diplomacy. But he agreed with those who criticized the Administration for not fighting to keep an American in the agency's top job. It showed yet again that the Administration was "spineless" and "without vision," Mr. Bolton said.
Robert DeVecchi, a senior fellow at the Council on Foreign Relations and president emeritus of the International Rescue Committee, said that the nationality of the administrator mattered less than his competence. American relief workers were "delighted" with Mr. Malloch Brown's appointment, he said.

HEADLINE: U.S. Investigating Big Wall St. Investment Firms

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 30

 BODY:
The Federal Government has started an investigation into the way some of Wall Street's largest investment firms set the fees they charge companies to sell their stock to the public in initial offerings.
The Justice Department's antitrust division blanketed the financial community's most prestigious securities houses with subpoenas on Thursday for information about the fees for initial public offerings, the companies' lawyers said. 
 A Justice Department spokeswoman, Gina Talamona, said, "The antitrust division is looking at the possibility of anticompetitive practices in the underwriting services for initial public offerings."
The inquiry follows a wave of public offerings, particularly of high-technology and Internet companies. Last year 374 companies went public, raising nearly $37 billion, according to the Securities Data Company. By contrast, in 1990, 172 companies raised $4.5 billion when they went public.
The existence of the subpoenas was disclosed in documents filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission by Goldman, Sachs & Company, which is preparing to go public on Tuesday and raise more than $3 billion.
Goldman said it had received a subpoena from the Justice Department "requesting information with respect to its investigation of an alleged conspiracy among securities underwriters to fix underwriting fees."
Executives at Goldman said they did not expect that the subpoena would affect its plans to go public.
The breadth of the Justice Department inquiry was far broader than just Goldman. Lawyers and executives involved in the cases said the list of subpoena recipients included Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, Merrill Lynch & Company, Credit Suisse First Boston, Lehman Brothers, Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, and Salomon Smith Barney, a unit of Citigroup.
The inquiry, in its initial stages, surprised Wall Street executives who have already denied accusations in a related civil lawsuit that they conspired to set a standardized fee. Studies have shown that Wall Street firms typically charge about 7 percent for smaller public offerings of up to $80 million, and less for the larger ones.
"We were genuinely shocked that Justice took this on," said an executive at one of the larger firms that received a subpoena this week.
A lawyer for another firm said it was "a true mystery" why the Justice Department's antitrust division had felt compelled to get involved in a market that he said "remains very competitive."
The Justice Department inquiry follows a series of private class action lawsuits brought by shareholders against 25 of the nation's largest and smaller securities firms that were recently consolidated in Federal District Court in Manhattan.
That case, filed by the New York law firm of Kirby McInerney & Squire, accuses the underwriters of violating Section 1 of the Sherman Antitrust Act and various provisions of the Clayton Act by conspiring to keep the fee that underwriters charge companies issuing stock at a nearly uniform fee.
"The fee is a major source of underwriters' profits and has been called 'the last bastion of the clubby cigar-smoking world of investment banking,' " the law firm said in a civil complaint filed last month. "The underwriter fee for I.P.O. offerings in the United States is uniformly 7 percent. This uniformity cannot be justified on the basis of costs and risks and would not exist in a competitive market free of collusion."
The complaint also quotes from a 1997 article in The Wall Street Journal quoting the head of underwriting at one investment bank saying, "The fact is, we'd be cutting our own throats to compete on price." It notes that in foreign countries, where there is even greater risk to the underwriters, fees may be as low as 3 percent or 4 percent.
"The large numbers of underwriters competing for business in I.P.O. offerings, and the healthy economy and stock market of the last six years, should have resulted, in our highly developed and extraordinarily efficient securities markets, in lower and more competitively negotiated fees," the complaint said. "In fact, as the demand for I.P.O. securities has increased and underwriter risk has decreased, the percentage fees on I.P.O. securities have held constant."
Alice McInerney, a lawyer who helped draft the civil complaint, said the shareholders had been harmed by the collusive efforts of the underwriters because the value of their stock was diminished by the size of the fee.
But lawyers representing the underwriters have disputed that contention. Earlier this week, they moved to dismiss the case, partly on the theory that shareholders do not have standing to bring a lawsuit under Federal antitrust laws because they are neither competitors nor direct purchasers of underwriting services. In court papers, the defense lawyers noted that not a single company that has issued stock had joined the case.
The defense lawyers also argued that the mere existence of similar pricing by the underwriters did not prove any collusion to violate antitrust law.
"Plaintiffs have failed to allege any facts that, if proven, would be sufficient to establish concerted action," the defense lawyers wrote in their brief seeking to dismiss the case. "Plaintiffs, instead, rely on conclusory allegations that unspecified meetings were held through which prices were allegedly fixed and agreements enforced. But they do not allege a single fact that lends even an inference of concerted action or any overt act in furtherance of the conspiracy by any of the 25 named defendants, many of which were not even syndicate members in the offerings in which plaintiffs participated."

HEADLINE: CRISIS IN THE BALKANS: BELGRADE;
Bombs Pound Heart and Homes of Serbia's Capital

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER

DATELINE: BELGRADE, Serbia, April 30

 BODY:
When NATO bombed residential areas of Belgrade for the first time early this morning, two errant missiles, meant for military office buildings, hit houses instead.
Dejan Filipovic, 26, was in his upstairs bedroom on Miruliceva Street when a missile nearly blew him out of the window. 
 He scrambled out the rest of the way, over the wreckage of the Zlatni Ovan restaurant, the Golden Goat, breaking only his leg, his sister, Aleksandra, said.
"We were in the living room and Dejan was upstairs," Aleksandra said, pulling at the sleeves of her sweatshirt as she shifted through the rubble. "My mother went through the window and I followed her, but my father stayed because my brother was upstairs. When he realized Dejan was alive, he climbed out, too. And then it all collapsed, and we all thought we were very lucky to be alive."
Branko Filipovic, her uncle, said: "These are crazy people to do this -- monsters. There's no military building here."
Aleksandra, an economics student, laughed harshly. "This is one of the 'mistakes' of NATO," she said with all the venom she could muster. "It's just another of those 'mistakes.' "
On Thursday in Washington, Gen. Henry H. Shelton, the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, told reporters that the air war against Yugoslavia had entered the "domination phase."
General Shelton described improving weather and said NATO had planned 670 air sorties through the day and night. "So today's a big one," he said.
It certainly seemed that way in Belgrade, which had its worst night of bombing, coupled with a presumably unrelated earthquake about 5:30 A.M. People joked that "if NATO doesn't get you, an earthquake will."
After the earthquake, one shaken person interviewed on Studio B radio said: "Nothing can surprise us now. Only Armageddon, maybe."
But the deep percussion of high explosives lasted for hours, as NATO chose targets in the heart of Belgrade -- the massive paired 1970's-era buildings of the Defense Ministry and Army General Staff Headquarters, just across the street from the elegant Foreign Ministry, and the federal Interior Ministry, which had seemed to be pretty effectively destroyed earlier in the war.
Four people died, none of them in the houses that were destroyed in the Vracar district, near the Kalenic market, one of the city's largest. At least one police officer died; he had been doing guard duty by the Interior Ministry, officials said. At least 37 people were hurt; 13 of them seriously. But officials insisted that the Defense and Army buildings had been emptied of workers weeks ago.
In the morning, the scene around the buildings was somber and eerie, as shocked Belgraders picked their way over a carpet of broken glass and shattered masonry, as if Fifth Avenue had been hit by missiles and every window for a half-mile had shattered.
Some gathered on the corners to stare, speaking in hushed voices; others walked along fixedly. Some stopped to pick up a bit of shrapnel and put it in their pockets. Some diplomats, who had come to work to find their windows blown in all over their offices, milled around outside, staring at the shrapnel pockmarks gouged out of the sculpted stones of the facade.
Workmen with long straw brooms swept the sidewalks and streets, making little heaps of glistening, broken trash before shoveling them into trucks to cart away.
The oddest sight was of other city workers carefully pulling the weeds from the dirt around trees -- some of which had bent or broken in the blast -- as if a long-ordered city beautification project was being carried out on schedule amid the ruins.
"What really makes me angry is the Foreign Ministry," said a passer-by named Ilija. "It's one of the most beautiful buildings in the city, and it's like the old civic Belgrade is being destroyed."
The Foreign Ministry, begun in 1903 and finished in 1936, has lovely arches and windows, with a marble reception area now left open to the elements. Pretty iron bollards on the sidewalks had been broken off and elegant street lights bent or severed.
Diplomats had made nervous jokes in recent weeks about being across the street from such likely targets. The huge defense buildings, faced with pink stone, were known as Sutjeska, after a Bosnian mountain where Tito fought a grand battle in 1943 and was wounded.
But there was something shocking about the home of Yugoslav diplomacy being shattered in this remote-control war, an irony immediately seized upon by the ministry spokesman, Nebojsa Vujovic, who noted that the bombing occurred only hours before the arrival of the Russian special envoy for the Balkans, Viktor S. Chernomyrdin.
"NATO wants to bury under concrete and steel, under the debris, not only the civilian victims but the idea of a diplomatic settlement itself," Mr. Vujovic said. "This is an attack on diplomacy as a method to solve the crisis in Kosovo."
In the Vracar district, an end to the war seemed quite far away. The history of bombing cities in this century is a mixed one, but tends to reinforce patriotism and anger, not diminish it.
Branko Filipovic had nothing but imprecations for NATO. "This will go on until they have the mercy to stop it," he said. "If the international community does nothing, we won't exist. But we won't give up Kosovo."
Aleksandra said: "I think they cannot know our people and our life here. We're a small country but educated and proud. We're proud to live in this city and we're proud to be Serbs and we will stay proud."
Then she laughed, describing how her uncle often slept in their house, because he lives so close to the Defense Ministry. "He slept here for 10 days, thinking it was safer," she said. "And now they're both destroyed. Only five minutes before our street was hit, he called us and said everything is smoke and dust."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Dow Industrial Average Increased 10.2% in April
The Dow Jones industrial average gained 10.2 percent in April, the biggest monthly gain in more than a decade, and is up 17.51 percent so far this year. 
 But yesterday the Dow industrial average and Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell on fears that a bustling economy might produce a bout of inflation. The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 89.34 points, to 10,789.04, while the S.& P. 500-stock index fell 7.65 points, to 1,335.18. The Nasdaq composite index gained 14.41 points, to 2,542.85. Page C3.
 
The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond rose to 5.66 percent from 5.52 percent. C3.
 
U.S. Economy Grew 4.5% in Quarter
The economy grew at a surprisingly robust 4.5 percent annual rate during the first quarter of 1999. And America's economic boom -- already the second longest on record -- shows no signs of flagging. A1.
 
Milwaukee Bank to Buy Mercantile
Mercantile Bancorporation, a St. Louis bank that has been cutting jobs and expenses after a three-year acquisition binge, has agreed to be acquired by Firstar, a Milwaukee bank, in a stock swap valued at $10.6 billion. C3.
 
Shares of Repsol and YPF Surge
Shares of Repsol and YPF surged after Spain's largest oil company expressed confidence that its unsolicited $13.4 billion takeover offer for the Argentine rival would succeed. Alfonso Cortina, the chairman of Repsol, announced the bid late Thursday. If the merger occurs, it would create the world's eighth-largest oil business. The high price offered by Repsol for YPF and the support of the Argentine Government for the takeover made the deal look likely. C2.
 
I.B.M. Manager Agrees to Testify
A manager from I.B.M.'s personal computer business has agreed to testify in the rebuttal phase of the Government's antitrust case against Microsoft. C4.
 
Trade Group Fails to Select a Leader
The World Trade Organization became leaderless after efforts to appoint a New Zealander as new Director General were blocked by supporters of his Thai rival. C2.
 
Trading Ends on Tokyo Exchange
Japan bade farewell to an era as the closing bell rang on the trading floor of the Tokyo Stock Exchange for the last time. Computers and cost-cutting put an end to face-to-face trading on Asia's largest exchange. C2.
 
Suiza to Sell 57% of Packaging Unit
Suiza Foods has agreed to sell 57 percent of its domestic packaging operations to a joint venture led by Vestar Capital Partners for $367 million. Vestar, an investment firm, will own 51 percent of Suiza's plastics operations. C3.
 
Second Bid for Banca Commerciale
Banca Commerciale Italiana is discussing a merger with Banca Intesa in a move that could result in a better offer for Banca Commerciale shareholders than last month's $15.3 billion offer by Unicredito Italiano. Either transaction would create Italy's biggest bank. C2.
 
Clinton Approves Pollution Rules
President Clinton is expected to announce today that he has approved strict Federal rules to control pollution from automobiles and end the special treatment for most sport utility vehicles. The rules would force oil companies to make cleaner fuel and compel auto makers to redesign their engines and install larger catalytic converters. A11.
 
Communications Satellite Is Lost
A Milstar communications satellite worth $800 million and a Titan 4B rocket costing $433 million that was carrying the satellite were lost after a Florida launching. A16.

HEADLINE: CRISIS IN THE BALKANS;
From Milosevic, 6 Steps Toward Ending the War on the Serbs

BYLINE: UPI

DATELINE: BELGRADE, Serbia, April 30

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from an interview today with President Slobodan Milosevic:
 
PRESIDENT MILOSEVIC -- In Yugoslavia we have 26 different ethnic groups. Any one of them could cause trouble if agitated from the outside, which is what happened in Kosovo.
In Belgrade we have 100,000 Yugoslav Albanians, and never a problem with them. Walk from our Parliament building and you will see many shops with their Albanian names. Not one window smashed here in all those years of violence in Kosovo. Our people never considered them responsible for the behavior of the so-called Kosovo Liberation Army terrorists. . . . 
 Ethnically mixed states is the trend in the new global village. The Kosovar terrorists were trying to reverse a phenomenon.
 
Q. Which you then attempted to do in Kosovo after March 24?
 
A. Absolutely not. That is the big lie which, repeated often enough, becomes conventional wisdom.
 
Q. You are denying that your armed forces drove people out of their homes and torched entire villages?
 
A. We are not angels. Nor are we the devils you have made us out to be. Our regular forces are highly disciplined. The paramilitary irregular forces are a different story. Bad things happened, as they did with both sides during the Vietnam war. . . .
 
Q. Satellites show entire villages torched.
 
A.Individual houses, yes. But not whole villages, as we saw on TV in Vietnam when American forces torched villages. . . .
 NATO believes it can pick on a small nation and force us to surrender our independence. And that is where NATO miscalculated. You are not willing to sacrifice lives to achieve our surrender. But we are willing to die to defend our rights as a sovereign nation. . . .
 
Q. After you walked away from the Rambouillet accords on Kosovo, did you really expect more than a month of sustained bombing?
 
A. Rambouillet was not a negotiation; it was a Clinton Administration diktat. . . . Rambouillet was a recipe for the independence of Kosovo, which clearly we could not accept. . . .
 
Q. So how do we get out of this mess?
 
A. A political process, not by more bombing. . . . Please tell me why a U.N. protectorate is needed. That is not to say we are against a U.N. mission. . . . The U.N. can have a huge mission in Kosovo if it wishes. They can bear witness to the legal behavior of our law-enforcement agencies and to the fact that everything is now peaceful, that the K.L.A. has ceased to exist except for scattered small groups that can still stage ambushes.
We cannot accept an occupation force, whether it flies a NATO or U.N. flag.
 
Q. So you accept a U.N. peacekeeping force?
 
A. Yes, but no army.
 
Q. Without weapons?
 
A. Self-defense weapons are normal, but no offensive weapons. We cannot accept anything that looks like an occupation. . . .
The idea behind Rambouillet was 28,000 troops, including 4,000 Americans, who would be occupying Kosovo with tanks, armored personnel carriers and heavy weaponry.
 
Q. So in your judgment what is the nature of a compromise between NATO and Yugoslavia?
 
A. First of all, cessation of all military activities.
 Second, simultaneity between the withdrawal of NATO troops now concentrated on our borders in Albania and Macedonia, on the one hand, and the decrease of our own troops in Kosovo from their present level of 100,000 to the normal garrison strength of between 11,000 and 12,000, which was the regular Pristina Corps.
 
Q. You went from 40,000 to 100,000 troops in Kosovo since the bombing started?
 
A. Yes, because of the danger of aggression across our borders by NATO forces. . . . But if the danger of NATO aggression is over, we can send our troops back to Serbia.
 
Q. How long would such a simultaneous withdrawal take in your judgment?
 
A. We can do it in one week.
 
Q. And the third point?
 
A. The return of all refugees, regardless of their ethnic or religious affiliation.
 
Q. And when would the U.N. peacekeeping force go in? Before the refugees can return presumably.
 
A. I don't like the word "force." We would welcome U.N. mission, not what "force" implies. There is no job for forces. What would such forces do? Just ruin our roads with their tracked vehicles. . . .
My fourth point is the political process. We will continue direct negotiations with Mr. Rugova Ibrahim Rugova, a prominent Kosovo Albanian in the presence of the international community. They can listen to every single word that is spoken, but they cannot act as mediators. We want to achieve the widest possible autonomy for Kosovo within Serbia. . . .
My fifth point is free access for United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees and the International Red Cross.
Sixth, an economic recovery plan for the three Yugoslav federation states that have been heavily damaged by NATO aggression. . . .
 
Q. What would you say to European participation as the European Union, not as individual NATO countries?
 
A. There are European countries that are not members of NATO, like Ireland, that would be acceptable.
 
Q. Contingents from Russia, Ukraine and Belarus have also been mentioned.
 
A. They, too, would be acceptable.
 
Q. Surely you are not prepared to face several more weeks of NATO bombing as the diplomatic haggling continues?
 
A. One more day is too much. But what choice do we have if NATO insists on occupying Yugoslavia? To that we will never surrender.

HEADLINE: Economy's Growth Keeps to Fast Pace, Up 4.5% in Quarter

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
America's economic boom -- already the second longest on record -- shows no signs of flagging.
Despite a decline in auto production and another sharp deterioration in the trade balance, the United States economy grew at a surprisingly robust 4.5 percent annual rate during the first quarter of 1999, the Government reported yesterday. 
 That is the sort of heady pace usually associated with the first, not the ninth, year of an economic expansion. Moreover, most forecasters, including those at the Federal Reserve, had been expecting a visible slowdown from the previous quarter's frenetic 6 percent rate.
"This economy continues to defy the aging process," said Bill Cheney, chief economist at the John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company in Boston. "The only discernible weakness is the trade deficit. And this has merely slowed the economy from warp speed."
A burst of domestic spending fueled last quarter's gains. Consumers, who account for more than two-thirds of the nation's buying, spent at the fastest pace in more than a decade. Home purchases shot up at an annual rate above 15 percent. And business investment in new plant and equipment, which had faltered last summer, continued to rebound, advancing at a 7.6 percent rate.
Investors were stunned by the economy's momentum. Fears that the Federal Reserve might raise interest rates in the next few months to cool things off sent bond prices down sharply, and stocks tumbled, too. The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 89.34 points, to 10,789.04.
To William Dudley, chief economist at Goldman, Sachs, the latest report on the gross domestic product "in some ways was even stronger than the fourth quarter's."
Despite the virtual absence of inflation now, Mr. Dudley said, growth this fast always increases the risk that wages and prices will start to creep steadily upward.
But even though the so-called G.D.P. deflator -- which measures changes in the prices of domestically produced goods -- jumped to a 1.4 percent annual rate compared with eight-tenths of a percent in the fourth quarter, the increase appeared mostly to reflect a one-time pay increase for civil servants.
Steven Landefeld, director of the Bureau of Economic Analysis, pointed out that prices on everything that businesses and consumers buy, including cut-price imports, rose no faster last quarter than in the fall, at a 1.1 percent rate.
How long can the good times last? An economist who has spent the last 15 years studying American business cycles says the short answer is: pretty much as long as the Federal Reserve, committed to preventing an outbreak of inflation, remains convinced that the danger is minimal.
The economist, Christina D. Romer of the University of California at Berkeley, explains in a forthcoming article in The Journal of Economic Perspectives that long periods of uninterrupted growth are a post-World War II phenomenon. Between the early 19th century and the 1960's, the longest interval between recessions was half a dozen years or fewer. But the 1960's boom lasted nearly nine years, the 1980's growth cycle stretched for almost eight years, and the expansion of the 1990's has now passed its eighth birthday.
What changed? Professor Romer said: "We learned something from Keynes about how to prevent recessions, i.e. how to use monetary policy to counter economic shocks. But the new-found competence eventually turned into hubris."
During the Vietnam War and the years after the 1973 oil shock, she says, "we expanded too much and created a lot of inflation."
To undo its own mistakes, the Fed had to create some truly nasty recessions, including the severe recession of 1980-82 engineered by Paul A. Volcker, then the Fed's chairman. Ever since, central bankers have managed to avoid overexpansion, and the only recession, the one largely precipitated by a consumer pullback in response to the outbreak of the 1990-91 Persian Gulf war, was relatively short-lived and shallow.
With the Fed's having shown restraint in the past, Professor Romer said, "We don't have to create a recession to get inflation down."
Professor Romer says that Alan Greenspan, who has been in charge at the Fed since 1987, has been lucky as well as smart. Trouble in the rest of the world, paradoxically, turned out to be a boon for the American economy. Tough times abroad helped hold inflation down as the prices of raw materials and imports collapsed and foreigners poured their money into Wall Street.
As for American consumers, they are behaving as if bad times are far, far away. With unemployment at a 30-year low, inflation-adjusted take-home pay rising handily, and spirits about as high as they have ever been, consumers are spending all of their income -- and then some. In addition, the well heeled are cashing in some of their stock market gains while the less well-to-do are taking advantage of easy credit to borrow more.
After-tax personal income soared at a 4.6 percent annual rate this winter, but spending rose at an even headier 6.7 percent annual rate and the personal saving rate, already around zero, fell into negative territory to the lowest level, minus five-tenths of a percent, ever recorded. (The measure, while seriously flawed, nonetheless clearly shows that Americans are saving less than they were just a year or two ago.)
Business, which has been having trouble passing higher costs along, is spending freely once again as well to improve its efficiency. Although the growth of computer purchases slowed this winter, businesses invested heavily in low-technology gear, new office space and the like.
What could go wrong? A meltdown in the stock market could spook consumers into becoming born-again savers. Corporate America, facing heavy debts and mediocre profits, could suddenly slash its investment budget. Another deterioration in growth abroad -- at the moment things look a bit firmer -- could reverse the budding spring revival in manufacturing that seems to be under way. And inflation may start to simmer again. For now, however, these are just risks, not realities.

HEADLINE: As Deadline Closes In, Patriots Reject Lucrative Hartford Offer

BYLINE: By MIKE ALLEN

DATELINE: HARTFORD, April 30

 BODY:
Five months after the New England Patriots announced a startling plan to move to Connecticut, the football team said today it was walking away from the most lucrative stadium deal in professional sports now that Massachusetts is willing to pay to keep the team.
Patriots executives attributed their decision to problems with the site in downtown Hartford, which is now occupied by a steam plant and is contaminated with coal tar and other toxins. But the withdrawal came just three days after Massachusetts legislators, after years of bitter and unproductive negotiations with the team's owner, Robert K. Kraft, promised a subsidy of $70 million to help him build a new stadium next to his current one at Foxboro, south of Boston. 
 Mr. Kraft's decision turned what had seemed a stunning coup into an embarrassing and expensive fiasco for Connecticut officials, most critically Gov. John G. Rowland, who had brokered the deal that would have saddled taxpayers with the entire cost of the $375 million stadium.
The Patriots canceled the contract with a curt notice to the state at 4:30 P.M. today, just two days before a deadline that allowed the team to back out without any penalty. Lawyers for the Patriots had determined that if the team waited any longer, it could be liable to the state for damages of as much as $100 million, according to a National Football League executive.
Much about the team's future remains uncertain. An executive close to the Patriots expressed disgust with the current Massachusetts offer, which would require the team to finance the entire cost of the stadium, while the state paid for new parking lots, roads and other improvements. But clearly the team would like to work something out. "It's not an option -- it's our home," the executive said.
Patriots officials also said Mr. Kraft would consider selling the team, having grown weary of the frustrating stadium talks he has held with three states -- including a flirtation with Rhode Island -- ever since becoming the team's fourth owner in 1994.
Mr. Rowland at first had promised the stadium site in the Connecticut capital would be ready for play in 2001, but that target had slipped to 2002. Then, consultants to Mr. Kraft told him this week that there was a 50-50 chance the stadium would be delayed at least another year. Team officials said that report prompted their decision to cancel the contract.
An official who works closely with Mr. Kraft said the team had misgivings about the Hartford site as long ago as February, which is the reason the exit clauses like the one exercised today were built into the contract.
In a letter to Mr. Rowland, Mr. Kraft said: "The scope of this project was a mountainous undertaking and much more complex than anyone anticipated when our discussions originally began. We know that you have exhausted every effort to meet the deadlines that have been within your control, but it has become clear to us that the goal of playing in a new stadium in Hartford by the year 2002 has a significant degree of uncertainty."
Mr. Rowland, a second-term Republican angrily challenged the Patriots' explanation, saying he believed the state had been used as a pawn by Mr. Kraft to extract a deal from Massachusetts. "No one walks away from a year's planning and a $374 million package because of concerns of the schedule being a little bit longer than usual," he said.
Hartford officials had envisioned the stadium as the centerpiece of a revitalization project, Adriaen's Landing, which was to include a hotel and convention center, lifting a city that has suffered through years of economic decline as manufacturers left and insurance companies consolidated.
"I often said it's not just about football," Governor Rowland said at a somber news conference tonight. "It's about having pride, it's about creating community spirit. We tasted that, and I think that that taste is still with us. We're going to find and create other opportunities and chances for Hartford."
The team, which has played in the Boston area since its birth in 1959 as the American Football League's eighth franchise, now will be eagerly courted by Massachusetts officials. Gov. Paul Cellucci of Massachusetts said tonight, "The New England Patriots will be playing in Massachusetts, where they belong."
Ralph Nader, the consumer advocate who had led public opposition to the stadium, said other cities and states should learn a lesson from Connecticut's bitter experience. "A government needs to know what they're doing and who they're dealing with, and Connecticut showed it did not know either one," Mr. Nader said. "Bob Kraft was using Connecticut against Massachusetts and then when Massachusetts came around, he threw the deal into the river."
Andrew S. Zimbalist, an economics professor at Smith College who is a leading opponent of subsidized stadiums, said: "You have to be careful not to invest too much of your political and financial resources in one of these deals. Rowland took none of the necessary precautions to protect his state and his city."
Mr. Rowland showed his bitterness at his news conference, held in the same ornate room at the Capitol where legislators had donned Patriots hard hats for the jubilant announcement Nov. 19 that the team had agreed to move to Hartford.
"There was always that feeling that Mr. Kraft was always looking for a way out," he said. "Everything always had a very cautious tone. He was not doing somersaults and saying he can't wait to come to Hartford."
Stacey James, the Patriots' spokesman, said Mr. Kraft would not have exerted so much effort or energy on the Hartford deal if he had not been sincere. "We entered into this agreement in good faith to try to play in a new stadium in 2001," Mr. James said. "We signed it for 2002, but when you start talking about 2003, you're talking five football seasons from now, and there simply was no guarantee it wouldn't be longer."
The Governor promised lawsuits against the team and the N.F.L., which served as a midwife to the Massachusetts proposal. Although it initially had voiced little concern about the Connecticut deal, the league had grown worried in recent months that by moving from the 6th-largest television market to the 27th, the Patriots would hamper the league's negotiations with television networks.
Connecticut was most frustrated by the involvement of the N.F.L. Commissioner, Paul Tagliabue, who flew into Boston for a highly promoted round of visits to business and political leaders.
Mr. Rowland estimated the state had spent "a few million dollars" on consultants and site tests. "You can expect legal action, not only with regard to the Kraft family but presumably with the N.F.L. as well," he said. "I don't think we'll have any problem recovering any of these damages."
The State Attorney General, Richard Blumenthal, said he would be "moving aggressively and quickly to take any available action to assert the state's legal claims and rights." Mr. Blumenthal asserted that the N.F.L. has been "throwing its weight around in a way that restrains competition and injures consumers."
Connecticut politicians poured scorn on Mr. Kraft. The Speaker of the House of Representatives, Moira K. Lyons, a Democrat from Stamford, condemned what she called "the lack of good-faith principles shown by the Kraft family."
Mr. Rowland, though, can expect to be showered with blame in coming days, since he cut the deal in secret, then said that he would stake his legacy on its success. Edward Marcus, chairman of the Connecticut Democratic Party, said stadium preparations had cost the state millions of dollars but added, "What may be even more important is the loss to our reputation."
On the darkest day of his political life, Governor Rowland joked that he is now an official New York Jets fan, and indicated that he never gives up. When asked whether he plans to try to lure another team, he said, "I can assure you that I am not -- at this moment."
Massachusetts legislators have promised to enact their offer before May 25, when N.F.L. owners are scheduled to discuss the Patriots' stadium plans. Three-quarters of the owners must approve any relocation by a franchise. Supporters of the Massachusetts plan have said that if Mr. Kraft did not accept their proposal, they would make their case directly to the other owners.
Paul G. Kirk Jr., a Boston lawyer and former Democratic National Chairman who is leading the Massachusetts bid, had spent the week begging businesses to sign up for luxury suites to help make the deal more attractive to Mr. Kraft. Tonight, Mr. Kirk was so confident of the state's prospects that he said skyboxes now would be "first come, first served."
Mr. Kraft hinted at his future plans and galled Connecticut officials by using his termination letter to thank them for working "so hard in this effort to help the Patriots remain a competitive franchise in New England."

HEADLINE: Beliefs;
On generosity to the poor: three sociologists find some surprising results in a religious survey.

BYLINE: By Peter Steinfels

 BODY:
"Pie in the sky bye-and-bye" was the mocking refrain of political revolutionaries who accused religion of pacifying the poor with heavenly hopes instead of helping them with earthly goods. Yet compassion toward the poor, with here-and-now almsgiving as part of it, has been part of every major religious tradition. So it is not surprising that three sociologists recently set out to answer these questions:
Does religion really matter when it comes to giving money to help the poor? Are the Christian groups that are generally associated with concern for the poor, namely, serious Roman Catholics and liberal Protestants, the most generous in aiding the poor? Do the giving habits of political and theologically conservative Christians, especially those influenced by the religious right, show an anti-poor sentiment? 
 Mark D. Regnerus, Christian Smith and David Sikkink, all associated with the sociology department of the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, re-examined data gathered in the 1996 Religious Identity and Influence Survey that had been financed by the Pew Charitable Trusts. Among questions on ideas about morality, gender, education and civic activities, this national telephone survey asked respondents how much of their time or money they had spent in various social and political activities: "a lot," "some" or "none." One such activity was giving money to organizations that helped "the poor and needy."
Writing in last September's issue of the Journal for the Scientific Study of Religion, the sociologists make the data jump through all the usual hoops: race, gender, education, age, income, recent financial change, size of family, size of community, political affiliation. To the latter they add whether respondents had relied on the Christian Coalition or similar organizations in deciding how to vote.
The sociologists also analyzed the data according to church attendance and how important respondents said religion was in their lives. Respondents were divided into religious categories: fundamentalist, evangelical, mainline Protestant, liberal Protestant, low-attendance Protestant, high- and low-attendance Catholic, other religious (Jews, Hindus, Mormons, Jehovah's Witnesses and similar groups whose respondents in the sample were too few to analyze separately), and, finally, nonreligious.
And what did they find?
First, religion apparently matters. The nonreligious were far less likely to report giving "a lot" to groups aiding the poor than all the religious groups except low-attendance Catholics. Control for demographic factors, and the nonreligious are at the bottom of the giving hierarchy.
The degree of religiosity apparently matters, too. The more intensely religious the respondents, the more generous they were apt to be, regardless of their religious affiliation.
Second, "other religious," the residual category containing Jews, Hindus and similar groups, were considerably more likely to give than even the highest of the major Christian categories. Also, nonwhites and women reported giving "a lot" more often than whites and men, and college graduates a little more often than those without degrees. Democrats and Republicans finished nearly in a dead heat, with Republicans winning by a nose.
Third, liberal Protestants and practicing Catholics do not especially stand out in their generosity to the poor. Evangelical Protestants appear mildly more generous.
Fourth, there is no evidence of an anti-poor mentality, as measured by reported giving, among political and theological conservatives. "The conventional wisdom regarding the hostility of politically and theologically conservative Christians toward the poor appears incorrect, at least on this count," the authors write.
What surprised them even more, however, was that those who looked to religious-right organizations like the Christian Coalition for guidance in voting were more likely to report "significant 'pro-poor' giving habits." They were strikingly likely to report giving "a lot".
The limits of this analysis do not escape the authors. From the standpoint of the poor, attitudes toward government assistance, tax relief and health care, or attitudes toward unemployment, economic growth and unionization, may have far greater consequences for well-being than personal charity.
Then there are the inevitable shortcomings of survey data. What definitions exist in the respondents' mind of organizations that help "the poor and needy"? What do they have in mind by giving "a lot"? The random differences can be assumed to cancel one another out. But what if liberal Protestants or, for that matter, college-educated evangelicals consistently had a more stringent notion of what constitutes "a lot"? Systematic differences among religious, political or demographic categories in understanding those questions would skew the results.
Nonetheless, public debate about justice for the poor often slides from what means will best accomplish what goals to ad hominem judgments about the motives and attitudes of the debaters. Whether politically and theologically conservative Christians are right in their prescriptions for relieving poverty is a question distinct from whether they are anti-poor, a la Ebenezer Scrooge, in their personal outlook -- and, as with the transformed Scrooge, giving habits are a reasonable test of the latter.
"Fundamentally," the three sociologists say in their discipline's understated style, "making the jump from economic conservatism to declaring persons to be hostile toward the poor seems unwarranted, according to our research results."

INTERNATIONAL A3-10
 
Jackson Delegation Visits Captured G.I.'s in Serbia
The three American servicemen held by Yugoslavia described their days as lonely and monotonous, interrupted only by perfunctory daily visits from a Serbian army officer and solitary exercise in their cells. The three were visited by the Rev. Jesse L. Jackson and Representative Rod R. Blagojevich of Illinois. A1 

President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia said the Clinton Administration was not prepared to sacrifice American lives to achieve its goals, but that Yugoslavs were "willing to die" to defend their rights, according to the transcript of an interview with an American journalist. A1
 
NATO unleashed what officials described as the most aggressive bombing yet in the five-week air war, hitting tanks and armored vehicles in Kosovo and bridges in Serbia. Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright, noting the flood of refugees, said the Administration would expedite the transfer of refugees to the United States, beginning with about 400 to be taken to Fort Dix, N.J. A8
 
Two errant missiles hit houses instead of military buildings when NATO bombed residential areas of Belgrade for the first time. A8
 
Former Prime Minister Viktor S. Chernomyrdin of Russia said he made some progress toward a peace settlement during six hours of talks with President Milosevic, but NATO officials were dismissive. A9
 
Kosovo Update A9
 
Gay Pub Bombed in London
A nail bomb ripped through a gay bar in the Soho district of London, killing at least 2 people and injuring 73 and leaving the city on edge after two other bombings this month, in minority neighborhoods. A1
 
U.S. Takes Iran Off Terror List
The State Department dropped its designation of the Teheran Government as the world's leading state sponsor of terrorism, a move that American officials hope will ease relations with Iran. A4
 
Beijing Warning on Protests
China's leaders issued a warning to all Government officials and employees of state-run institutions not to take part in any demonstrations by the Buddhist Law movement. A5
 
Coup in the Comoro Islands
The Comoran military announced that it overthrew the Government of the Comoro islands on Thursday night. The streets there were quiet after the apparently bloodless coup, a local journalist said. A7
 
U.N. Official Criticizes U.S.
James Gustave Speth, the departing chief of the United Nations Development Program and the highest-ranking American in the United Nations system, accused the United States of "tragic shortsightedness" in failing to support the world body as American debt to the United Nations is soaring and contributions to development aid are plunging. A4
 
World Briefing A6
 
NATIONAL A11-13, 16
 
Little Action Was Taken On Complaint, Officials Say
Sheriff's officials in Littleton, Colo., acknowledged that they had done little to follow up a complaint that a neighbor made last year that Eric Harris, one of the teen-age gunmen at Columbine High School, "talks often of making pipe bombs and using them to kill numerous people." But at a news conference, the officials also defended themselves against mounting criticism that they had ignored signs that the two teen-agers were unstable and dangerous. The officials also released copies of Web pages posted by Mr. Harris. A1
 
Officials of the National Rifle Association, gathered in Denver for the organization's annual convention, rejected any suggestion that the gun lobby was responsible for the Littleton killings and asserted that they would stand fast against any new initiative on gun control. "Our mission is to remain a steady beacon of strength and support for the Second Amendment," said Charlton Heston, the N.R.A. president. "We cannot let tragedy lay waste to the most rare and hard-won human right in history." A12
 
President Clinton said he would convene a White House meeting on youth violence. The White House said educators, gun makers, sportsmen, entertainment industry representatives and Internet providers would be among those invited. A12
 
New U.S. Emissions Standards
President Clinton is to announce strict rules today to control automotive pollution and end special treatment for sport utility vehicles. A11
 
Satellite Launching Fails
A Titan 4B rocket failed to carry a military communications satellite into its intended orbit after launching from Cape Canaveral, Fla. The loss of the rocket and Milstar satellite, which together were worth more than $1 billion, was the third straight setback for the Air Force in a space mission. A16
 
Florida Passes Voucher Plan
The Florida Legislature gave final approval to a plan that would make Florida the only state to pay for vouchers for students to attend private schools, including religious schools. The plan passed the Senate by a vote of 25 to 15, and the House, 70 to 48. Gov. Jeb Bush advocated the plan during his campaign. Opponents of the measure have threatened to sue, saying it will destroy public education and violates the constitutional separation of church and state. (AP)
 
Alaskan Avalanche Kills Climber
A Canadian climber was killed in an avalanche in Wrangell-St. Elias National Park in Alaska, state troopers there said. The climber, Jim Haberle of Whistler, British Columbia, was killed on Thursday when he and two companions were caught in a snowslide on a moderately steep slope in the southeastern area of the park, the troopers said. Mr. Haberle, who was in his late 30's, was carried over a cliff and fell about 1,500 feet. He was the 12th person to die in Alaska avalanches since March. His companions were not injured. (Reuters)

Reaction to School Threat
Officials in Hillsborough Township, N.J., whose schools were closed because of an E-mail threat, said that nothing untoward had been found in searches. But they would not say when the schools would reopen. B5

BUSINESS DAY C1-16
 
U.S. Economy Steams Ahead
The United States economy grew at a surprisingly robust 4.5 percent annual rate during the first quarter of 1999, despite a decline in auto production and another sharp deterioration in the trade balance. Most forecasters, including those at the Federal Reserve, had been expecting a slowdown from the previous quarter's frenetic 6 percent rate. Fear that the Fed might raise interest rates in the next few months to cool things off sent bond prices down sharply, and the stock market slipped as well. A1
 
The Dow fell 89.34 points, to 10,789.04; the S.& P. 500 dropped 7.65 points, to 1,335.18, but the Nasdaq gained 14.41 points, to 2,542.85. C3
 
Stock Offerings Investigated
The Federal Government has started an investigation into the way some big Wall Street investment firms set the fees they charge companies to sell their stock to the public in initial offerings. A1
 
Effort on Securities Fraud
The S.E.C. has proposed that brokerage firms do more of the policing to combat securities fraud among small over-the-counter stocks. C1
 
Alliance Forming Against AT&T
America Online and Microsoft may back Comcast in its fight against AT&T to acquire Mediaone, the big cable television carrier. C1
 
Midwestern Bank Deal
Mercantile Bancorporation, a St. Louis bank that has been cutting jobs and expenses after a three-year acquisition binge, agreed to be acquired by Firstar, a Milwaukee bank, in a stock swap worth $10.6 billion. C3
