HEADLINE: Tennessee Talks of Paring Plan for 'Uninsurables'

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN

DATELINE: NASHVILLE

 BODY:
In one bold stroke, Tennessee converted its Medicaid health benefits to managed care five years ago and used the savings to cover hundreds of thousands of people who could not afford health insurance of their own or were too sick to qualify. With three million people enrolled, the program, called Tenncare, became the most ambitious and generous government health plan in the nation.
But with Tenncare's costs rising and Tennessee facing a budget deficit, the program is under fire and facing probable retrenchment under pressure from Gov. Don Sundquist. And the people most at risk are those who benefit most from the state's effort at providing nearly universal health insurance: those with chronic or even terminal diseases who have been rejected by private insurance. 
 To arrest a projected 12 percent increase in Tenncare spending for the year beginning in July, Governor Sundquist, a Republican elected to a second four-year term in November, has proposed a moratorium on new enrollments of those regarded as uninsurable, for six months or a year, while the state explores cutting benefits, raising premiums and tightening eligibility.
Meanwhile, the Tenncare director, Brian Lapps Sr., is suggesting that some beneficiaries of the program are exploiting it. The poorest recipients, Mr. Lapps says, could help pay for their care if they would only curb their use of cell phones and cigarettes.
"We have a spoiled population that wants everything for nothing," he said in an interview.
The program's advocates are troubled by the proposed curbs in the program.
"Tennessee did something ahead of the curve, and now it's back to the Okefenokee Swamp," said Dr. Stephen P. Raffanti, medical director of an outpatient AIDS clinic at the Vanderbilt University Medical Center that opened its doors when Tenncare began and now has 1,500 patients.
Tenncare is free for most of its beneficiaries, who are poor enough to qualify for Medicaid. The better off pay premiums, deductibles and fees based on their incomes. Applicants with debilitating pre-existing conditions, like AIDS or multiple sclerosis, qualify merely by presenting a letter from an insurance company denying them coverage.
Tenncare's impact has been greatest for that last group, which the program calls uninsurables, currently numbering 108,000 of the 1.3 million enrolled in Tenncare. But they are also by far the most expensive group -- a single patient's medication can cost tens of thousands of dollars a year -- and the cost of extending coverage to this group is at the root of Tenncare's problems.
Caught between rising prescription costs and growing numbers of these sickest patients, Tenncare has cut its payments to doctors and H.M.O.'s below what they need to break even, according to a state-financed analysis by PricewaterhouseCoopers, a consulting firm.
The program is struggling as the state seeks ways to balance its budget. Education is expected to be among the areas hardest hit.
One day this month, 52 of the uninsurable came to testify at a hearing the state called on the proposal to stop enrollments. The speakers and their advocates expressed resentment at what they called Mr. Lapps's stereotyping of the sick.
Wearing a sticker proclaiming, "We are not the problem," David Tignor, 24, said he has hemophilia. Mr. Tignor is hobbled by braces for ankles that internal bleeding has turned arthritic. He caught AIDS and hepatitis C from a blood transfusion. The state and Federal Government pay for his medicine, which costs more than $100,000 a year.
"This is my work cell phone," Mr. Tignor said, pulling one from his jeans and thrusting it at Mr. Lapps, who presided, taking notes. Mr. Tignor said he needed the phone to call for help when he fell, and added that his employer paid for it.
Louise McKown, 49, pulled herself up to the microphone on two canes that she had decorated with bouquets of violets and daisies. Ms. McKown has a degenerative brain disease that has slurred her speech and made noodles of her legs.
"The day may come when I can no longer speak, write or type," she said. She admonished Mr. Lapps, "This was most definitely not caused by smoking or drinking." And then she added, "I do not want your pity, but I do wish that you understand my reality."
In his one response to his petitioners' comments, Mr. Lapps promised that those who were already enrolled in Tenncare would not be disenrolled.
The Clinton Administration allows states to devise variations of the basic federally subsidized state Medicaid programs that for the most part cover parents and their children who are on welfare and, more recently, parents who are moving from welfare to work at low wages.
In developing Tennessee's variation in late 1993, Gov. Ned McWerter, a Democrat, and his commissioner for finance and administration then, David Manning, thought that by using managed care and health maintenance organizations to cover the state's 800,000 Medicaid recipients, they could both tame the inflation then raging in health care and generate savings to cover people who were uninsured, including the uninsurable.
To maneuver around a hostile physicians' lobby and a skeptical Legislature, which was then out of session and whose approval was not needed, Mr. McWerter and Mr. Manning opened the program overnight, as the new year began in 1994. Health care institutions and his own administration were ill-prepared, and abuses, fraud and foul-ups ensued.
"It was 'Who's on first? Where's second?,' " said Gordon Bonnyman, director of the Tennessee Justice Center, a public policy advocacy group. An influential lawyer and lobbyist, Mr. Bonnyman helped assure Tenncare's start by trading his support for the shift to H.M.O.'s for Mr. McWerter's promise to cover the uninsured.
In spite of the chaos, Governor McWerter, whose term expired in January 1995, had put the state on the road to the universal care that President Clinton proposed then and that Congress subsequently blocked.
"Tenncare showed that if there is a political will, it could be done," Mr. Bonnyman said. "Now that is being casually, cavalierly, thoughtlessly tossed aside.
For the moment, Tenncare is entrenched. It covers 24 percent of the population. Its enrollment includes 768,000 Medicaid recipients, whose coverage is not threatened, along with the 108,000 uninsurable and 411,000 of the previously uninsured, mostly workers and their families who either are not offered insurance through their jobs or cannot afford it if they are.
By some measures, the program is succeeding. A survey last year by the Center for Business and Economic Research at the University of Tennessee in Knoxville found that 81 percent of the enrollees were satisfied with Tenncare in 1997, compared with 61 percent in 1994.
Enrollees using hospital emergency rooms, the survey found, had fallen by half over the three years, suggesting that people are getting treated before crises strike.
Tenncare's advocates say the program has also succeeded in keeping many of the uninsured self-sufficient.
"I have patients at five and six years who are working," said Dr. Raffanti of the Comprehensive Care Clinic, the one specializing in AIDS. "A lot of these patients I'm going to keep from going to end-stage disease for a very long time."
Some officials and health care experts here trace the program's current financial travails to two miscalculations early on. One, they say, was the McWerter administration's high expectations for the impact of managed care in reducing costs. Another was a decision to limit coverage to 1.3 million enrollees.
So appealing was the promise of coverage that the uninsured, most of them healthy, rushed aboard. The limit was reached within months, and in late 1994, the state stopped enrolling them, though it later reopened coverage to uninsured children.
But under an agreement with the Federal Health Care Financing Administration, which regulates Medicaid and Medicare, it continued to enroll the uninsurable. And as their numbers grew, the state lost more and more of the contribution to the cost of their care that it had received from the largely healthy uninsured.
"Ideally, we should open enrollment to the uninsured, not wait for people to get sick," said John Ferguson, the state commissioner for finance and administration.
But there are other issues, too, said Mr. Lapps, the Tenncare director.
He knows his new terrain: for three years, until last October, he was an uninsurable Tenncare enrollee because of a condition he declines to disclose, and is now covered by the state employee health plan.
Mr. Lapps says that he wants to preserve the program and that "we are 60 to 65 percent of having it right." Problems he wants to tackle, he said, include insurance companies suspected of dumping patients on Tenncare, signs of illegal enrollments, excessively generous benefits and a failure to verify enrollees' incomes.
But enrollees are an issue, too, Mr. Lapps said. "There are a lot of responsible poor out there," he said. "But there's a portion who drive up to the doctor's in a BMW. The question has to be raised: What is their purchasing priority?"
Mr. Lapps has some support. The Tennessee Medical Association has fought Tenncare from the start, mostly because of cuts in doctors' fees, which Mr. Lapps would partly restore. "He's talking the talk that we've been talking for five years," said Russ Miller, the association's spokesman.
The Federal Health Care Financing Administration must approve the moratorium during which the state would look into revising Tenncare. Negotiations continue, and Federal officials in Washington declined to comment. But Commissioner Ferguson said, "The reading we're getting is, we could close enrollment."
Mr. Bonnyman, director of the justice center, said that would be the demise of Tenncare as it has been known.
"It's like the Governor woke up and said, 'Why are we covering all these people when other states aren't?' " he said. "It's a poignant testimony to our national incapacity to develop a rational and humane health policy."

CORRECTION-DATE: May 4, 1999, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about Tenncare, the Tennessee health care program for the uninsured, misstated the number of people enrolled. As noted elsewhere in the article, it is 1.3 million, not 3 million.
 The article also misspelled the surname of the governor who established the program. He is Ned McWherter, not McWerter.

And Bear in Mind
(Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)
 
ALEXANDER HAMILTON, AMERICAN, by Richard Brookhiser. (Free Press, $25.) A dramatic, compact biography that argues for virtues not always attributed to Hamilton, like intelligence, idealism, character and vision.
 
BONE BY BONE, by Peter Matthiessen. (Random House, $26.95.) The last of three novels inhabited and propelled by Edgar J. Watson, a cane planter, developer and murderer whose conquest of Florida's Gulf Coast marches with the imperialist impulses of the young United States.
 
COLERIDGE: Darker Reflections, 1804-1834, by Richard Holmes. (Pantheon, $32.) The fine second half of the author's life of Coleridge, during which the poet's immense powers of thinking and talking contend with his recurrent paralysis of will.
 
FOR THE RELIEF OF UNBearable Urges, by Nathan Englander. (Knopf, $22.) Ambitious short stories by a 29-year-old former yeshiva student from New York, now living in secular Israel; his characters are able to flourish in a borderland between the author's old world and that new one.
 
THE GROUND BENEATH HER FEET, by Salman Rushdie. (Holt, $27.50.) Gods, humans and rock performers mix and match conduct -- some horrific, some charming -- in a novel not of our world but of a dangerous, fragile world, riven with earthquakes and set at a refractive angle to ours.
 
THE LEXUS AND THE OLIVE TREE, by Thomas L. Friedman. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $27.50.) A columnist, formerly a correspondent, for The Times explains, with anecdotes as well as analyses, what the instant electronic global economy is and what it may take to live there.
 
THE MEME MACHINE, by Susan Blackmore. (Oxford University, $25.) An informed effort to popularize the theory that cultures are controlled by replicating units (memes) analogous to the genes of biological theory, and that their operations drive cultural evolution.
 
THE SEA CAME IN AT MIDNIGHT, by Steve Erickson. (Bard/Avon, $23.) Several stories mesh together, or fail to do so, at the level of echo and metaphor rather than plot in this firmly apocalyptic novel at whose center is a dislocated girl who sells memories in a Japanese brothel.
 
THE SOPRANOS, by Alan Warner. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $24.) A kind of gloomy farce by a young, talented Scottish novelist who has every sympathy with a pack of teen-age choirgirls down in the big city, where wishfully licentious outbreaks fill up, for a while, the vacancy of hope.
 
VERA: (Mrs. Vladimir Nabokov), by Stacy Schiff. (Random House, $27.95.) A thoughtful biography of Nabokov's wife, protector, dogsbody and perfect reader that opens up a 52-year marriage without pretending to explain every enigma.

SECTION: Section 6; Page 63; Column 1; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 659 words

HEADLINE: Style;
Zen and the Art of Fashion

BYLINE: By Bob Morris; Bob Morris is a frequent contributor to The New York Times Magazine.

 BODY:
Lee, a young man with good cheekbones from a poor family, grew up where there was no Banana Republic. He was not schooled in the subtle ways of J. Crew, either. He simply wore what was cheap and easy -- T-shirts, fleece, sneakers and sweats that did not ring of chic or knowingness. When he moved to Manhattan for college and settled into a stimulating new life of study and play, Lee remained badly dressed and adamantly unstylish.
One day in late October, while he was sitting in the park watching the leaves on the ground being styled for a photo shoot, a slender figure caught his eye. She was a young woman named Flo with pale hair that took the autumn light. Flo was the founder of a big, trendy mail-order company called Zen, which promoted spirituality through clothing, furniture and cosmetics and marketed itself by pushing purity, timelessness and harmony with nature. Although she was not a student of the discipline, Flo had the Zen thing down pat, and she felt totally one with it all. 
 Lee had never met anyone like Flo. She spoke in a hushed voice as if in a monastery. She called bubble baths aromatherapy, wore shoes that looked as humble as a monk's (but cost more than a personal computer) and paid thousands of dollars to go on retreats where she ate nothing and did not speak for days at a time. Everything about Flo -- from her imported jute headband to her ahimsa-silk skirt (made from silkworms that have died naturally) -- was complicated in its simplicity. Flo was a mystery with a really good body.
That winter, while snow from a movie shoot gently dusted the rooftops of Washington Square, Lee moved in with Flo. This was when his troubles began. It was not just that Flo's home, done in an intimidatingly monastic style, made him feel like a slob. Or that Flo's fastidious fervor for the purest of foods -- nondairy, gluten-free, organic -- made him feel like a reprobate every time his stomach growled. Rather, it was her gentle but constant concern about his bad haircut and careless wardrobe that made him feel as unworthy and anxious as a tourist in Paris.
One day in early spring, when troughs of hydroponic grass began gracing the tables of better dinner parties all over town, Lee visited the master of a SoHo zendo. The master, or sensei, agreed that, yes, it is a paradox that retailers use the language of Zen, which teaches the senselessness of attachment, to promote consumerism. But a Zen master, after all, is trained to accept the world as a paradox.
"What happens to my fist when I open my hand?" the sensei asked, posing a koan, a Zen riddle that can't be answered. It left Lee speechless.
"That is the point, exactly," the sensei said. "There is no answer. But now let me ask you this: Have you not noticed, since you came to this city from your small town, how muted and spare people can be? Have you not observed, as you go about your day, the attention others pay to subtlety? This nonlook of no-thought takes work. And even our monks cloak themselves in black and shave their heads with great intentionality because they know that when they finally achieve satori -- the great moment of enlightenment -- it's good to have just the right look."
The sensei fell silent as he glanced, with some distaste, at Lee's haphazard outfit.
"Birds put effort into building their nests just so," he said. "Poets write with a lyrical economy of style. This spring, you should find your way to a place of simple pale shades -- grays, blues, beiges -- that reflect the gentleness of clouds and sky. Learn from Zen, and I mean both the spiritual discipline and your girlfriend's mail-order company, and you will find a new way of being that is both flexible and fashionable. Clean your closet and open your mind."
Lee blushed with excitement. He was starting to understand the way. "How can I thank you?" he asked. "Just have Flo call me," the master replied, "the next time Zen is having a sale."

HEADLINE: WEEKEND GETAWAYS;
Beyond Charm in Charleston

BYLINE: By SUSAN JACOBY; SUSAN JACOBY is working on a four-generation history of her family.

 BODY:
EATING breakfast in the shade of a palm tree on a sun-drenched Easter morning in Charleston, surrounded by the sound of church bells pealing from every direction and azaleas in full bloom, I surrendered to pure pleasure. A first-time visitor is overpowered by the city's exquisite 18th- and 19th-century architecture, sensuous foliage, near-Mediterranean interplay of light and water and, last but not least, unimaginably good food.
Yet Charleston and its nearby low-country plantations are overwhelming in another, more sobering way. Touring the meticulously preserved historic center, one is reminded -- explicitly and implicitly -- that all of this beauty owes its existence to a system under which, for nearly 200 years, a few human beings owned, and profited from the labor of, a great many more human beings. 
 For every paean to the past during house and plantation tours (usually accompanied by assurances that this family never abused its slaves), I found black and white Charlestonians who encouraged me to look beneath the surface of their richly textured city.
A visitor cannot hope to see everything of historical interest in one weekend -- I immediately crossed Fort Sumter off my itinerary -- and the best way to begin an exploration of the many layers of Charleston is on foot. On my first day, I set out along Meeting Street after breakfast at Joseph's, an unpretentious, superb restaurant where I fortified myself with scrambled eggs, spicy sausage patties, home-fried potatoes, grits and muffins.
Meeting Street bisects Charleston's historic center, beginning at its southern tip with the Battery (so named because guns were mounted there to deter British ships during the War of 1812).
My first stop was the Circular Congregational Church, said (probably apocryphally) to have been constructed in the round to prevent the devil from hiding in corners. The congregation was founded in 1681 by dissenting Scotch and Irish Presbyterians, French Huguenots and English Congregationalists. Meeting Street took its name from the original church building, known in the 17th century as the White Meeting House.
From its founding in 1670, the Carolina colony was a haven for religious dissenters (though the Anglican Church would not lose its status as the state-established religion until 1778). By 1749, Charleston had attracted enough Jews to form Congregation Beth Elohim, which would later become the birthplace of Reform Judaism in America.
The original Circular Congregational, completed in 1806, was designed by Robert Mills, the pre-eminent Charleston architect of his day, whose later works included the Washington Monument. The Pantheon-style building, erected without a steeple, was mocked for years in a piece of local doggerel:
Charleston is a pious place
And full of pious people.
They built a church on Meeting Street
But could not raise a steeple.
That church was destroyed by fire in 1861; it is amazing, in view of Charleston's history of devastating fires, earthquakes and hurricanes, that so many colonial and early 19th-century structures have survived. In 1890, the present Romanesque building, also in a more or less circular form, was built on the same site.
Farther north on Meeting Street is a Mills building that survived the 1861 fire -- called, appropriately, the Fireproof Building. The graceful 1826 classical revival structure, which now houses the South Carolina Historical Society, was the first building in the United States specifically designed to protect public records from fire.
Charleston has retained its antebellum beauty, now fiercely protected by the secular religion of preservationism, because the town never experienced the post-Civil War economic boom that Victorianized the architecture of other, more prosperous Southern cities. As Charlestonians like to say, they were "too proud to whitewash and too poor to paint."
But Charleston is not a museum like Colonial Williamsburg, and many of its historic houses are privately owned and closed to the public. For a visitor, it is great fun to peer through iron gates into courtyard gardens (though it may not be as much fun for the residents) and imagine the private lives behind the lovingly preserved colonial, Federal and Greek Revival facades. On Meeting Street, I stopped for a tour of the 1808 Nathaniel Russell House, noted for its flying staircase that seems to spiral upward with no apparent support.
Meeting Street's restored glories end at the harborfront's White Point Gardens. From there, I turned left along the High Battery walkway, with an unsurpassed view of the harbor and the three-story houses with broad piazzas (the Charleston term for porches) introduced by early settlers from Barbados.
Heading back toward the center on Church Street, I paused at the small French Protestant Huguenot Church, also founded by dissenters, in 1681. It is the only church in America where the original Huguenot liturgy is still regularly used, with an annual service in French.
The 1845 building, supported by slender, fragile-appearing buttresses that rise over each pointed bay to a groined ceiling, stands out even in a city filled with architectural gems. Its unique visual impact derives from the combination of Gothic style and the plain esthetic of a low-church Protestant sanctuary.
Leaving the Huguenots behind, I circled back toward Meeting Street around the old city market and headed south toward Calhoun Street and its landmark Emanuel African Methodist Episcopal Church. Calhoun was long called Boundary Street (many older Charlestonians still use the term) to distinguish between the part of town where black activities were severely restricted and the area where blacks could live and worship more freely.
A plaque on the front of the white stucco church notes simply that Emanuel A.M.E. was "founded 1818, closed 1822, reopened 1865."
The congregation was founded by the Rev. Morris Brown, a free black minister who had been affiliated with a local white Methodist church. Before the Civil War, some free blacks, and many slaves, worshiped (always in the back pews or balconies) in Charleston's white churches. Mr. Brown started his black church after traveling secretly to Philadelphia in 1791 to be ordained by the newly formed Free African Society, established by blacks dissatisfied with second-class status in northern Methodist churches.
In 1822, the original church (not on its present site) was burned down by whites because the building had been used as a meeting place by Denmark Vesey, the free black carpenter who was executed for attempting to organize a slave rebellion. Emanuel reopened immediately after the Civil War, when the congregation bought the land where the present church, dedicated in 1891, stands. Approximately a century later, the church installed a monument to Vesey.
Frances T. Mack, 80, and Lee Bennett, 77, members of the church's history committee, explained that they grew up knowing nothing about Vesey. "I don't know whether our parents, or even our grandparents, knew who he was," said Mrs. Mack. ""But if they did, they were afraid to talk about it."
After leaving the church, I made a final stop at the nearby Avery Research Center for African-American History and Culture, originally a school for freed slaves, where I was looking for information on a black Charleston artist, Edwin A. Harleston (1882-1931).
The next morning, I rented a car for a drive to two plantations situated along the Ashley River about 30 minutes from Charleston's center.
The Magnolia Plantation and its gardens represent the best of English garden design, transplanted and transformed over a 300-year period into a subtropical kingdom of camellias and azaleas, laurels and live oaks draped in hanging moss. Originally laid out by the Rev. John Grimke Drayton, the plantation's owner for most of the 19th century, the gardens were subsequently enhanced by a series of lacy white wooden bridges that lend a Giverny-like feel to the ponds and waterways. The entire plantation is also a wildlife preserve, with a swamp garden that attracts ornithologists from around the world.
This "informal" arrangement, artfully designed to create the illusion of a seamless blending with nature, is the kind of garden I like best. But I was also drawn to Magnolia by an old, almost-forgotten interest in the art of Mr. Harleston, whose work I encountered many years ago when I stumbled across his portrait of the philanthropist Pierre S. duPont in a Delaware state building.
Until this year, when I spotted Mr. Harleston's name in Edwin Ball's book, "Slaves in the Family," I did not know he was an African-American.
In the 1920's, Mr. Harleston longed to paint landscapes at Magnolia but was denied permission, because, although the gardens had been open to the public since 1870, they were closed to blacks. He then dressed as a workman in order to sketch and photograph scenes he would later paint.
Even in such an enchanted landscape, the ironies of intertwining white and black history are everywhere. Mr. Drayton, the horticultural visionary, called slaves his "black roses." He was also the nephew of the famous (the official Magnolia guidebook calls them "notorious") abolitionists Angelina and Sarah Grimke. Yet Mr. Drayton must have been influenced by his aunts because he built a schoolhouse on the plantation and engaged in the then-forbidden activity of teaching slaves to read.
Just a few miles away, the more elaborate Middleton Place, believed to be the oldest formal landscape garden in America, evoked the heritage of slavery for me even more powerfully than Magnolia.
There is a great deal to see at Middleton, from stable yards with demonstrations of everyday antebellum plantation activities to a restored house with the books and artifacts of a family that produced a president of the First Continental Congress; a signer of the Declaration of Independence; one of America's first classical archeologists, and a United States Minister to Russia.
But the formal gardens, laid out in 1741 by Henry Middleton (the Continental Congress president) are the main attraction. It took 100 slaves almost a decade to complete the terraces, walkways, hedges, artificial lakes and plantings patterned after the work of Andre Le Notre, who designed the gardens at Versailles.
Working in the gardens must have been a more desirable job for a slave than wresting tar and turpentine from the forests or rice from swampland. Yet I was on the verge of heat exhaustion after two hours spent walking around the grounds on an 85-degree day.
AFTER returning to Charleston, I had just enough time to look up "Honey Man," the lone work by Mr. Harleston currently on display in the Gibbes Museum of Art -- which also has an outstanding collection of more than 500 miniature portraits -- on Meeting Street.
The painting confirmed my impression of Mr. Harleston as a major talent at a time when a black man could not support himself as an artist. Recalling an era (the period of the opera "Porgy and Bess") when Charleston's black vendors sold honey, shrimp and crabs door to door, "Honey Man" is a portrait of a tired wage-earner, his shoulders bent with the weight of his baskets. He might have been walking down one of the elegant streets I had admired the day before.
It felt good to get back to 1999. On my last night, I dined at Magnolias, recommended to me by a lifelong Charlestonian. It was my best meal in a city of great food: pan-seared chicken livers with a thin, crisp crust outside and melting softness inside; buttermilk mashed potatoes, and spicy tomato chutney that exploded in my mouth with the taste of summer. My dinner companion was equally enthusiastic about her seafood gumbo, a low-country specialty. Did I mention the currant bread pudding with rum sauce and homemade vanilla ice cream?
After dinner, I had enough energy -- New South cooking leaves out some of the traditional fat and flour -- for a stop at Atlantic Books on East Bay Street. Charleston is a great book town, especially for historical, rare and out-of-print works, and I found a volume on Renaissance Italian city-states that I had been trying to track down since 1990.
The next morning was Easter Sunday, and I ended my trip to Charleston as I began -- in the graveyard of the Circular Church. Children were hunting for Easter eggs in the city's oldest burial ground, with monuments dating from 1696. One girl, spotting me as an outsider (it wasn't hard, since my New York woman's standard black uniform stood out among the Charleston pastels) pointed out an inscription.
Under the slab lay the three sons of Richard and Mary Savage, who died within 10 days of one another -- of typhus, yellow fever, smallpox? -- in 1784. The boys were ages 3, 5 and 7. "It's much better to be growing up today, ma'am, wouldn't you say?" observed my young guide.
That was the message I took away from a city that makes the past impossible to forget.

LENGTH: 108 words

HEADLINE: The Real Divide

 BODY:
Missing from Berman's essay on the cultural war between insiders and outsiders was the real war: class war. Clinton's consistently high poll numbers during the Lewinsky fiasco were based not on some cosmic dominance of the hippie heathens over the Christians, but on the fact that the have-nots simply did not care. Could Clinton's impeachment help retrain formerly well-paid factory workers about to be dumped into the service industry? It meant absolutely nothing to so many people, and the indifference was so widespread that many in the G.O.P. mistook it for moral decay instead of distracted desperation.
 
Tim Fogle
Louisville, Ky.

SECTION: Section 6; Page 36; Column 2; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 995 words

HEADLINE: The Way We Live Now: 5-2-99: Word & Image;
Our Humanity Vs. Their Sovereignty

BYLINE: By Max Frankel 

 BODY:
Perhaps Bill Clinton really believed that he was going to war to crush the seeds of World War III in the Balkan morass. Or maybe he decided that NATO needed a new cause to refresh itself. Or he became convinced that saving Western Europe from a flood of Albanian refugees was a vital American interest. Maybe he was just furious at that man, Slobodan Milosevic, for refusing to let Kosovo move toward independence like the rest of the former Yugoslav federation.
Domino theories and subtle diplomatic strategies may have guided the White House, but they don't explain Americans' willingness to follow the President into this new war. The reason for that is obvious -- on every television screen. It's those pictures of almost unfathomable atrocity that once again drive our politics. 
 Those scenes of huddled masses burned out of their homes and driven into exile aroused our sympathy and overrode all obligations to respect Serbia's sovereignty. Once the cameras went into action, and the President promised only surgical, aerial combat, no U.N. treaties or Russian entreaties could keep us out. And once "in," as the slogan went, we had to "win," whatever that meant.
Brushed aside were the slogans of the former anti-war movements that America was not "the world's policeman," that we had no business interfering in other nations' civil wars. A few critics clucked about our inconsistency -- our failure to get similarly aroused about even worse barbarities in Cambodia, East Timor, Liberia, Sudan, Algeria, Rwanda. Did Asian and African slaughters not qualify for American response?
What those challenges fail to grasp is that our responses, or lack of responses, are not based on consistency of policy. They're based on the tube. Television drives the public temperature // and cameras were either barred or scared away from those other battlegrounds. Hence there were no bloodcurdling images, and words alone failed to move us.
Cameras also drive our choice of military tactics. President Clinton ruled out ground combat in Kosovo because he had seen how the sight of bloody battle scenes on TV forced our retreat from Vietnam. And he himself ordered us out of Somalia after a single American soldier was shown beaten to death and disgustingly dragged around by people that the troops had come to feed. Images seize our hearts.
But they also cloud our thoughts.
Long before television, or bombers or telephones, Americans questioned their purpose in the world. In every generation, one faction insisted that we fight only to defend the national interest, using power to guard our frontiers and to bargain for the economic and political welfare of our people. Another faction insisted that we had to fight also for our national beliefs, to promote our universal values of peace, freedom, justice and democracy.
Jefferson thought societies had the same obligations as individuals to advance moral values. Hamilton thought a nation had no right to indulge "emotions of generosity and benevolence" at the expense of its own interests. Madison struggled for a middle ground; he said nations must serve their interests, but thought these sometimes included the general interests of mankind.
In our century, we learned to devise different strokes for different folks. President Wilson came through World War I agitating for the "self-determination" of peoples held down by the enemy powers, Germany and Austria-Hungary. But he ignored the domination of other peoples by the United States and by allies like France and Britain.
We continue to be torn in that Wilsonian fashion. Like Hamilton, we worry about oil-supply lines more than about civil liberties in the Middle East. Heeding Jefferson, we wage economic warfare to promote human rights in South Africa or Cuba. And when it comes to China, like Madison, we recognize our national interest in a bountiful trade and our human interest in opposing tyranny. Even after a decade of profound transformation in China, we cannot erase the images of the tanks in Tiananmen Square.
China now opposes our attacks on Yugoslavia on behalf of dissident Kosovo because it fears our intervention would challenge its claim to Taiwan and its hold on Tibet. Yet the Chinese are eager to join the World Trade Organization, to which they would have to yield a large measure of sovereignty. In a similar ambiguity, the United States in recent years has sided with China to oppose the creation of an international court to prosecute war crimes. Yet when the cameras finally caught up with the skeletal remains of atrocity in Rwanda and Bosnia, Americans guiltily endorsed some ad hoc trials of a few captives for "crimes against humanity."
Milosevic remains a poor candidate for trial so long as we need to negotiate with him for an eventual deal for Kosovo. We want to preserve a sovereign Yugoslavia even as we bomb within its borders. The United Nations is no help; it forswears intervention in matters of "domestic jurisdiction" even as it sponsors a "universal declaration of human rights." So we let the cameras steer our course.
Someday in the next century we will acknowledge that there can be no global human rights without global laws and no way to write and enforce the laws without a global congress, courts and cops. The more our cameras intrude upon the world's terrain, the more of our sovereignty will we yield to our humanity.
As the lion in the jungle of nations, the United States is obviously not ready to yield to a higher authority. But in time we will realize, like the nations of Western Europe, that sovereignty has become the enemy of safety. The time will come when Americans recognize that anarchy among nations constitutes a threat to our interest and welfare. We would then take the lead in creating a canopy of law across the globe. Only under a regime of law can politics replace violence and allow the reason of words to take precedence over the passion of pictures.

HEADLINE: Franchise for Little Jobs Around the House

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER 

 BODY:
WHO among us has never had a leaky faucet, a door that won't close or a broken porch railing? Nagging small repairs, to be sure, yet for the unhandy, finding someone else willing to take on small jobs has become almost impossible.
Sensing an opportunity for a specialized business led to the formation of the Handyman Connection, a Cincinnati-based company, which recognized a need and turned it into a successful franchise operation. 
 Based on the concept that homeowners across the United States would welcome a helping hand for home repairs and small remodeling jobs, Handyman Connection franchisees supply retired craftsmen and experienced specialists to do things like carpentry work, minor plumbing and electrical repairs, painting, wallpapering, ceramic tiling and masonry work as well as deck construction and kitchen and bath remodeling. A little more than a year ago, Stephen White, 48, former chief executive officer of a 100-bed hospital in Lebanon, Ind., bought the Handyman Connection franchise for Westchester region and opened in Elmsford.
"The health field was becoming more difficult, and after 20 years I was ready for a change," Mr. White said. "I always dreamed of owning my own business, and I figured now was the time."
Mr. White and his wife, Dale, also wanted to return to the New York City area to be near relatives. "Once we settled on where we wanted to live, I started researching the possibilities," Mr. White said. "I could buy an existing business or buy a learning curve, which is what I call a franchise. I knew someone who had bought the Handyman Connection franchise so I met with him, and what he had to say convinced me that this was a very good franchise, especially for someone who is good with his hands. My dad, who was a steam fitter by trade, and the handiest guy I ever met, taught me a lot."
Before making a decision, Mr. White explored other franchise possibilities. "I looked at a few retail operations, 1-800-Flowers, for one, and some temporary personnel agencies, but Handyman was the best choice for me."
Mr. White said the price he paid for the Handyman franchise, $75,000, was based on demographics. "The more populated areas, those with a population over half a million, cost more," he said. "I have Westchester, Rockland, Dutchess, Orange, Putnam and Sullivan Counties, and in time, I expect to open offices in some of them. I'll probably start with Rockland. Close as it is, it has been hard for me to recruit people who live in Rockland. Timewise, they say it isn't worth it with the traffic on the bridge so heavy."
Besides the six-county territory, what did Mr. White get for his $75,000? "I bought a business system, group purchasing ability and advice," he said. "It cost me about $10,000 to $15,000 to open the office, but I'm very satisfied. Starting from scratch, I did $250,000 in the first year."
The biggest challenge facing Mr. White is getting good people. "I have plenty of business, and our work is guaranteed for a year," he said. "I only take people with at least 10 years' experience in their trades with three references that are checked. They're bonded and insured by us, but they work as independent contractors. We give them full office support and handle all the paperwork."
Retired craftsmen make up the biggest group. "They're bored staying home and glad of the opportunity to earn a little extra money," Mr. White said. "They can work as much or as little as they please. We also draw from a group of younger people, with full-time jobs, who work for us after hours."
The freedom and ease of being able to pick and choose jobs attracted Robert Herbst, a painter, to Handyman Connection.
"Some years back I had my own business, until the recession closed me down because my customers, who were building houses on spec, just couldn't pay me," Mr. Herbst said. "Then we moved upstate for a couple of years. But we wanted better schools for the kids, so we moved back down to Wacabuc."
Mr. Herbst, who has been doing a lot of jobs for Mr. White, said: "It's a good arrangement -- very flexible -- and it's hassle free, no paperwork, and that's a big thing. If I want to take the day off, no problem. If I want to work on my own, that's O.K. Being able to fill in when you want to or when you need extra money suits me."
Although Mr. Herbst is not paid for the time it takes him to give free estimates to potential customers, he said: "It's the way this business has always been run. Everyone gives free estimates."
Work is billed at between $35 and $50 an hour, Mr. White said. "But frequently we send out one person who can handle a variety of jobs such as fixing loose tile in the bathroom, caulking a bathtub or planing a door down," he added.
As the franchisee, Mr. White keeps half the money generated from a job. "The company was started seven years ago by two guys, Marvin Belkin and Arthur Neuman, who couldn't find anyone to make the small repairs needed for a condo they owned in Cincinnati," he said. "It's a natural for me because I've always been interested in repairing and remodeling, and I understand what good craftsmanship involves."
The Handyman Connection Web site is www.handymanconnection .com.

HEADLINE: WORKING;
At the Scene Of a Crime?

BYLINE: By MICHELLE COTTLE; Michelle Cottle is a Washington writer.

 BODY:

Q. I recently discovered that the corporate division in which I am a manager has been engaging in practices that are at least questionable and possibly illegal. With a few discreet questions, I have learned that the vice president in charge of the division sanctions the activities and that my peers don't share my qualms. Without disclosing my reason, I have lined up a transfer out of the division, but it won't take effect for several months. In the meantime, how can I protect myself if things blow up? Should I talk to a lawyer?
 
A. "Possibly illegal" is not the same as illegal -- or even unethical. At this stage, you need more facts about the issues involved. 
 "Try to determine whether you're calling the line too close" advised James Schrager, a business ethicist and professor of strategy at the University of Chicago's Graduate School of Business. Because you seem to be the only person who questions these activities, you may be overreacting.
To understand your company's actions -- and how or why it may be bending the rules -- talk to your peers, Mr. Schrager said. Someone may be able to explain the situation to your satisfaction. "But if you're hearing things like, 'everybody does it,' or 'they've never stopped us before,' or 'the law is poorly written,' there may be a real problem," he added.
Personally, there is good news: In most cases, you don't have much to worry about from a legal standpoint. "If an individual employee is not engaging in wrongful or criminal activity, then there isn't much likelihood of individual liability," said Philip M. Berkowitz, a management employment lawyer with Salans Hertzfeld Heilbronn Christy & Viener of New York.
But if you think you should distance yourself from your division's practices, get your objections on record, Mr. Schrager said.
Talk to your boss, but be sure to keep the conversation private and nonconfrontational. "If you make it a personal dispute between you and the boss, that doesn't do anybody any good," Mr. Berkowitz said.
As a last resort, consider talking to in-house counsel. The lawyer could not only clarify the law, but the conversation could also document your concerns. Be aware, though, that the lawyer will almost certainly tell your boss about the discussion. To avoid the appearance of going over your boss's head, you may want to ask him or her for clearance first. (Of course, even if nothing shady is going on, your boss may take offense, refuse your request or even blow up at you.)
Think twice about approaching an outside lawyer. Not only will it cost you serious money, but the lawyer also won't have a complete picture of your organization, Mr. Schrager said. And should anyone find out, your loyalty could be questioned. Besides, if the behavior you've uncovered is serious enough to merit your own legal representation, you may want to think less about protecting yourself until your transfer, and more about finding another employer altogether.
 
Michelle Cottle is a Washington writer. Each week, she responds to readers' questions about career and workplace issues. Send them by E-mail to working@nytimes.com or by mail to Working, Money & Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: In Chicago, Layers of History but Uncertain Future

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP 

DATELINE: CHICAGO

 BODY:
A TUMULTUOUS strike more than a century ago settled the question of whether the model town of Pullman -- built practically in a single stroke by George M. Pullman to house thousands of workers of the Pullman Palace Car Company -- was a new American utopia.
It wasn't. 
 Today, as a landmarked but beleaguered neighborhood on Chicago's far South Side, Pullman is struggling to define exactly what it is.
The question is more than an existential exercise, for it bears on a new effort to restore the remaining public buildings and attract the visitors -- and visitors' dollars -- needed to bolster its economy.
The critical state of affairs was underscored in December, when the main office building and an adjacent erecting shop, both abandoned, were set afire by an arsonist. The blaze ravaged the clock tower, a red-brick Victorian confection that marked Pullman's picturesque spot in an otherwise unforgiving industrial landscape along Lake Calumet, closer to Indiana than to the Loop.
Although Pullman was developed in 1880 as a self-sufficient community within the greater township of Hyde Park, it was long ago subsumed into the City of Chicago. It is now a neighborhood of roughly 35 blocks, with some 4,000 residents. Under court order, the Palace Car Company gave up its role as landlord by 1909, but its successor, Pullman-Standard, was building and refurbishing railroad cars here through the 60's.
Red-brick workers' cottages and two-story flats still line Pullman's verdant blocks in neat, tight arrays. The Hotel Florence, a rambling Queen Anne dowager, still greets visitors with a deep veranda and a tiny mountain range of gables, dormers and chimneys. The abandoned market hall is ringed by four curving colonnades that recall the loggias of Renaissance Italy.
Soaring over the town square is the steeple of the Greenstone Church, made of a stone that ranges in color from moss to lichen to jade, with stained-glass windows as delicate as doilies. The town stable, now an auto-repair shop, is still ornamented with two carved horse heads.
But the clock tower, Pullman's cynosure, is a tumbled and charred ruin whose arched windows are now empty portals to the sky.
"It's swaying in the breeze," said Keith Herron, the assistant superintendent of historic sites in the Illinois Historic Preservation Agency, which owns the clock tower. The state plans to spend $2.1 million to stabilize the structure by wrapping steel bands around it and filling in the windows with wood braces to increase lateral stability.
Preservationists in Pullman are encouraged by the renewed attention that has accompanied the catastrophe. After a long spell of what seemed like official indifference, the city and state are forming a task force to chart a fresh revitalization effort.
The panel is to be headed by James R. Thompson, a former Illinois Governor whose administration bought the clock tower and hotel 10 years ago to create what Mr. Thompson called "the greatest railroad museum in America."
Although nothing came of those plans, great fires seem to have a galvanizing effect on Chicagoans.
"Isn't it sad that it has to be something tragic like this that has to be a catalyst?" asked Deborah Bellamy-Jawor, executive director of the Historic Pullman Foundation, a nonprofit group concerned with preservation, restoration, education and research. "But from now on, it's a bright future."
The Florence (named for George Pullman's daughter) was already scheduled to undergo a $1.9 million stabilization later this year. And a $200,000 renovation is under way at the market hall.
Restoring the public structures, no easy task in itself, may be the most straightforward challenge facing the task force. More vexing -- and more interesting -- is how to interpret and convey these 19th-century buildings to a 21st-century audience.
Is Pullman a monument to transportation? Certainly, the name was once synonymous with travel, since the sleeping and dining cars that emerged from Pullman's factories made long-distance train trips "comfortable, inexpensive and safe enough for the middle class," Stanley Buder wrote in "Pullman: An Experiment in Industrial Order and Community Planning" (1967).
Is it instead a monument to city planning and that long tradition of American utopianism that spawned experimental communities like New Harmony, Ind.; Columbia, Md., and, more recently, the Florida towns of Seaside and Celebration?
IS it a monument to organized labor? The 1894 strike, which grew out of the Pullman company's refusal to abate rents even as it slashed wages and jobs, was a milestone in the union movement. It reverberated nationally when it was joined by the American Railway Union under Eugene V. Debs, which refused to move trains carrying Pullman cars, prompting the Government to use Federal troops as strike breakers.
Or is Pullman a monument to civil rights? The men who tended to Pullman cars were Pullman employees (the cars were leased, not sold, to railroads) and their union, the Brotherhood of Sleeping Car Porters, was one of the most potent advocates in the early 20th century for the equal treatment of African-American workers.
"It is some of the richest history that we have at any site," said Mr. Herron, whose agency owns about 60 properties throughout Illinois.
Added to the historic complexity is the complicated economic and racial reality of modern Pullman, which cleaves along 111th Street into a poorer north neighborhood, largely of renters, and a more affluent -- though scarcely wealthy -- south neighborhood, where many homeowners have fixed up their properties. The districts are separated by the old Pullman works, where some residents would like to see a shopping center, while others would prefer a more purely historic restoration.
Pullman said he built the town to "exclude all baneful influences" -- taverns, brothels and labor agitators chief among them -- and to provide homes "of such character and surroundings as would prove so attractive as to cause the best class of mechanic to seek that place for employment."
His architect was Solon S. Beman, who had worked under Richard M. Upjohn of New York on the Connecticut State Capitol in Hartford. The landscape designer was Nathan F. Barrett, who had laid out estates in the New York area.
"George Pullman understood the commercial value of beauty," said Michael Wolski, the foundation's tour coordinator. And properties in Pullman -- even the church, which was to be rented by different denominations -- were expected to earn a 6 percent return annually on investment.
To insure revenues, the company cut two checks for workers: one for the current amount of rent due, the other for whatever was left over in pay. Workers would endorse the rent checks back to the company at the Pullman bank.
"I have seen men with families of eight or nine children to support crying there because they only got three or four cents after paying their rent," said Thomas W. Heathcoate, a car builder, testifying in 1894 before the Federal commission investigating the strike. The United States Strike Commission concluded that "the esthetic features are admired by visitors, but have little money value to employees, especially when they lack bread."
In a blighted state by the 1960's, Pullman was relatively inexpensive. "A lot of people moved here because the housing was affordable," said John Cwenkala, who has lived in Pullman 16 years. "Pullman is one of the only communities that was really restored by blue-collar workers."
Like most of his neighbors, Mr. Cwenkala is eager to see action after decades of talk. "There has been no lack of studies," he said. "It would be nice to see something happen."

HEADLINE: Welcome to 'Stealth University';
SUNY at Farmingdale Remakes Itself and Hopes Someone Will Notice

BYLINE: By KAREN W. ARENSON 

DATELINE: FARMINGDALE

 BODY:
HAZEM TAWFIK nodded sorrowfully as he stood in the spacious white industrial laboratory he directs at the State University of New York campus at Farmingdale.
A big, genial man in love with manufacturing engineering, he has an array of high-tech toys: a laser cutting and welding machine, a stereolithography machine, even a 10-foot-high Cincinnati Milicron robot. And he has companies begging for his help in solving their manufacturing riddles. But he needs more students. 
 His program once drew 150 students a year, but now has only 25, most of them part-timers who come evenings after work. That is not enough to fill the lab or to take on all of industry's problems, so, he longs for more.
"Students in high school do not see engineering and technology as viable careers," he said. "They say: 'Why do I have to go through tough courses and study, instead of taking easy courses in business and becoming a banker and making lots of money?' "
That longing for more students is repeated across SUNY Farmingdale, a sprawling 380-acre campus on the Nassau-Suffolk border that has classrooms full of high-tech equipment and a variety of specialized laboratories but the air of a slightly scruffy, underused movie set.
The local economy is booming, and businesses, frantic for technically trained employees, are lining up to hire Farmingdale graduates. But many of the school's laboratories sit empty for much of the day. Its once-crowded parking lots are wide open. Its students occupy only four of its eight former residence halls.
On a recent afternoon, the college's state-of-the-art security imaging laboratory was empty. So were its elegant formal gardens, where purple rhododendrons and hearty yellow daffodils bloomed profusely in the chilly sunshine, and the greenhouse where banana trees were lined up waiting for balmier weather to be moved outdoors.
At the aviation center a few miles away, six or seven students huddled around a table receiving ground instruction in the late afternoon, while sleek Katana training airplanes sat lined up on the runway, their engines silent.
One exception was the dental hygiene clinic, where rows of students in blue lab coats leaned intently over real patients, picking at the tartar between their teeth. The program is the most competitive at Farmingdale; it receives around 200 applications for about 50 slots each year.
Farmingdale employees describe their college as a little-known treasure, but that has proved little consolation as they have watched enrollment slide. In the mid-1970's, Farmingdale's enrollment -- counted as the equivalent of full-time students -- was nearly 10,000. Today, it is under 4,000.
"We think we have a wonderful institution, but we are the best-kept secret on Long Island," said Tina Sneed, assistant dean for enrollment services, whose job it is to recruit more students.
She has a tough challenge. Many high school students see science and technology as too difficult. And the collapse of Long Island's defense industry that threw many engineers and technicians out of work left others skeptical that such careers are worth the effort.
"Everyone on Long Island knows an engineer who was laid off, so they are shying away from technology because they think it is cyclically unstable," said Pearl M. Kamer, chief economist for the Long Island Association. She emphatically rejects that belief. Defense is cyclical, she says, not technology.
Perhaps worse, though, is that Farmingdale itself has been through so many changes in recent years that high school students and their families and guidance counselors are confused about what it offers.
"Our students used to go to Farmingdale for air-conditioning, veterinary, pre-engineering and drafting," said Felice Solomon, director of guidance for the Plainview-Old Bethpage School District. "Then Farmingdale got out of a lot of those programs."
Asked about new programs, she said, "People don't know about them, and when people don't know, they don't go."
Even students at the college are sometimes not certain about what is there. Rich Marandino, a 21-year-old senior from Massapequa, said he and a classmate in visual communications had planned to transfer to another college after two years. It was only after an interviewer at another college expressed such admiration for their Farmingdale portfolios that they decided to stay two more years.
"They were like 'Wow,' " said Mr. Marandino, who aspires to be an art director and whose spiky black hair and silver earring would make him look at home at any art school in Manhattan. "Besides, the teachers here are well connected," he added.
Farmingdale's need to clarify its identity concerns Peter D. Salins, SUNY's provost, who says the former two-year agriculture and technical school has a way to go before it feels like a full four-year college.
"There is still a huge credibility gap," he said. "They have to convince the Long Island community -- students and their parents -- that they are a more advanced institution than they've been perceived as. For the perceptions to change, the substance has to change; it is a bit of the chicken and the egg."
Farmingdale officials are trying to burnish the college's image now that their decadelong struggle to transform the campus is finally falling into place.
"We're close," said Frank A. Cipriani, Farmingdale's president of 21 years, who is on administrative leave developing a fund-raising campaign. "The pieces are almost all in place. I can't produce enough graduates to satisfy the demand. What we have to do now is attract enough students who can benefit."
Although still not complete, changes are visible on several fronts:
* Farmingdale officials say their enrollment slide appears to have ended. Applications this spring have been relatively flat, a disappointment compared with the 15 percent surge at SUNY's Old Westbury campus and the 3 percent gain at Stony Brook, but a relief after the declines in recent years. And the college is beginning more aggressive recruiting efforts, including an open house this weekend -- its first in years.
* The college is accelerating its transformation into a four-year college. Although students have been able to transfer into its handful of bachelor's degree programs for several years, it accepting freshmen directly into four-year degree programs only last fall. So far this spring, 572 students have applied to its bachelor's degree programs, up from 298 at this time last year.
* SUNY has provided additional financing for some specialized programs like aviation, which allowed Farmingdale to lease new planes and provide more flying time for student pilots. A picture of the new planes in the SUNY admissions brochure helped draw more students and build its program. "Two years ago, we had no dispatcher and no mechanics and I was putting the oil in all the airplanes," said Stephen Campbell, the college's chief pilot. "Now we have two dispatchers and a mechanic and an assistant."
* The college is teaming up with Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory and SUNY Stony Brook to build a business incubator for biotechnology startup companies at one edge of Farmingdale's campus. New York State is putting up $15 million to finance the bioscience park, which is expected to provide research opportunities and jobs for Farmingdale students and faculty.
"We're making a lot of progress, but people don't know it yet," said Frank Pellegrini, chairman of Farmingdale's chemistry department and of its faculty and staff planning committee. "I've been here for 30 years, and the cows and pigs haven't been here for 20 of them," he added.
SUNY officials in Albany say they, too, are encouraged that Farmingdale appears to be heading in the right direction after years in limbo. As part of their new campus-by-campus "mission review" procedure, they recently examined the college's strategic plan and indicated their satisfaction, although they have not yet given their formal approval.
"Farmingdale has huge potential," Dr. Salins said. "Even though they are still predominantly a two-year institution, they've increasingly gotten four-year degrees, and that's the future."
But he is pressing for even greater change. He has asked Farmingdale to continue to raise its admissions requirements and to institute tougher hiring and promotion criteria for its faculty, many of whom do not have doctorates.
"If you are going to be a baccalaureate institution, you have to have commensurate faculty," he said.
Farmingdale has already come a long way from its creation in 1912 amid Long Island's potato farms as a four-year agricultural institute with a dual mission: to educate students and to support Long Island's economy.
For decades, it trained farmers and nurserymen and developed products like the Farmingdale grass seed, which was designed to withstand the fungus attacking Long Island's suburban lawns. In the 1940's, it began to train workers for Long Island's burgeoning defense industry.
At first it was free; now tuition is $3,200 a year for two-year degree students and $3,400 a year for bachelor's degree students.
Dr. Cipriani recalls that when he first arrived in 1964, a constant stream of yellow school buses brought 50,000 school children to see the college's cows and pigs.
But as the baby boom filled all available classrooms in the 1970's, Farmingdale departed from its traditional mission, offering more liberal arts programs.
"We were playing the role of a third community college," said Michael J. Vinciguerra, Farmingdale's provost and acting president. "We lost a little of our shape and focus."
It worked for a while. But when the baby boom ended, student enrollment slid. Then came the end of the Reagan defense buildup. That sent Long Island's economy reeling and, combined with the recession of the early 1990's, cut sharply into employment. The demand for Farmingdale's technical graduates fell and so did applications.
"The economy didn't turn up for a very long time," said Dr. Kamer. of the Long Island Association. "It was really a slow recovery until the last two years."
As Farmingdale tried to refocus, it decided that students needed broader training than was possible in four years. In 1985, it won permission to offer baccalaureate-level courses alongside its two-year associate's-degree programs, and added bachelor's-degree programs in electrical engineering technology and manufacturing enegineering technology. And in 1987, it graduated its last class of agriculture majors.
But as it gave up popular two-year programs like mortuary science and early childhood education in preparation for adding four-year programs, fewer and fewer students came. The campus struggled along, deferring maintenance and cutting faculty and staff to save money.
"Ten years ago, the faculty weren't sure where we were or where we were going," said Margaret Porciello, chairwoman of Farmingdale's business and computer systems department.
It was not until 1993 that the school won the Regents' permission to become a four-year college, and the shift to four-year status has not been entirely smooth. One problem, Farmingdale officials say, was that to become a four-year college, they had to promise not to add programs offered at nearby colleges.
That proved a high price, as Farmingdale found itself limited in what it could add. Although it introduced four-year degrees in areas like aviation administration and communications, other fields like business seemed to be out.
"We were Stealth University," said Dr. Vinciguerra. "Because of those restrictions, we were hiding programs and nobody could find them." With SUNY's top administrators supporting the college's expansion now, he said, "we don't have to hide it."
The transition is still under way. Farmingdale has plans to add nearly a dozen four-year degree programs in the next few years, including forensic science, environmental engineering technology and health information systems. Farmingdale officials believe they have the backing of SUNY administrators to add them, but each program has its own complications.
In dental hygiene, for example, Judith Friedman, the department's chairwoman, said a four-year program makes sense because it will prepare students for a wider range of jobs in research, industry and consulting.
"But four years would be a very big change for students to accept right now," she said, "so we will have to work our way in gradually."
The visual communications department is also edging toward a four-year program. Currently, students enroll in the two-year associate's degree program and then reapply for admission to the upper-class program or enter as transfer students.
"Two years is really not enough," said Wayne Krush, a professor in the art department. "Students need the four years to get experience."
The department provides that experience through an "in-house agency" class where seniors design ad campaigns, Web sites and other projects for real not-for-profit clients. Clients this year include the American Heart Association, the Heckscher Museum of Art and SUNY Farmingdale itself.
Offering four-year degree programs, however, will not necessarily bring in as many students as the college wants. So John I. Kostanoski, who directs a bachelor's-degree program in security systems "to train the new breed of security director who understands security technologies," put his program on the Internet. Although it was introduced only last year, it already has 48 full-time students on campus and another 11 on line.
Creating more four-year programs is not the only challenge. Dr. Cipriani, Farmingdale's president, said he is trying to design a fund-raising campaign because the college must raise more private money. Farmingdale's endowment is only about $500,000 and the college brings in less than $750,000 a year in private money.
"With the cutbacks in state support, it is incumbent on presidents to see if they can cushion that gap," he said.
The college is also trying to expand student recruitment, introducing techniques many other colleges already use. It is using Internet applications and has begun to have its students visit high schools. It has begun to offer on-site admissions at community colleges to draw more transfer students, and it is holding the open house this weekend. . Next year, admissions officers wants to meet earlier with high school counselors and to offer more on-campus activities to show off the college.
"We feel our students and their parents need to have a sense of what we really are all about," said Ms. Sneed, the assistant dean for enrollment services.
Farmingdale's changes are a central theme in its admissions video. "A Farmingdale education isn't the same as it was five years ago," it proclaims. "We've changed because the world has changed."
The college is also seeking outside advice. Last month, Dr. Vinciguerra huddled with a representative from Noel-Levitz, a consulting firm that advises colleges on student recruitment, to see what else Farmingdale might do. He said the consultant was "surprised at the clarity of our vision, but said we have to project it better.
"We have a super story to tell," Dr. Vinciguerra said. "I love this place; I really believe in this place. I think we have really found a good path to the future."
He predicts that Long Island's vigorous economy and population growth will also help.
Whether Farmingdale can finally complete its transition will become clear in the next few years. In Dr. Salins's view, the college is poised to make the jump.
"It's like a Nintendo game," he said. "They have to leap across a chasm. If they make it to the other side, they will be home free and everything will be great. If not, they will languish. But the leap is scary."

HEADLINE: Turning On the Lights Downtown;
More Cities Are Banking on Live Theater (and Places to Eat) Being the Switch

BYLINE: By LEONARD FELSON 

 BODY:
AS Connecticut's cities search for ways to recapture the luster they once possessed, theaters and performing arts centers are increasingly playing a supporting role in those urban revitalization dramas.
In June, The Bushnell in Hartford will break ground on an 88,000-square-foot $30 million addition, giving the 69-year-old 2,800-seat landmark a modern 950-seat auditorium for smaller productions. 
 In New Haven, an extensive renovation of the Shubert Performing Arts Center two years ago has allowed the 85-year-old theater to return to its roots as a showcase for pre-Broadway tryouts and other world premieres. And in Stamford, modernization of the Palace Theater, built in 1927 as a vaudeville and movie house, has already enabled the theater to bring major Broadway productions to the city.
In all three cities, the expansion and renovation work has been accomplished with financial help from private donors, corporations and the state, which has approved millions of dollars in aid. Beyond the obvious benefit to the theaters, city, state and corporate leaders have supported the projects because they believe the arts can serve as an economic catalyst to bring new life to urban centers.
"The arts enrich our communities, and they are helping to create tourism and entertainment districts in many of our urban areas," said Gov. John G. Rowland. "Community theaters, museums and galleries all help bring people downtown. And the arts are helping to spur economic development by enhancing the quality of life in cities and towns throughout Connecticut."
In return, theater operators say many restoration projects would not have occurred without support from Hartford. "We're delighted we have a governor and legislature who both recognize the value of cultural assets to economic development," said John Hiddlestone, operations director for the Stamford Center for the Arts, and the man in charge of the Palace Theater improvement project.
Indeed, other cities across the state also have theater renovation projects, most with state financial support. Among them are the following.
* The Garde Arts Center in New London is in the midst of a $15.7 million renovation that not only includes the former movie theater (built in 1926) but also two blocks on State Street, designed to redefine the downtown area and connect people to the heart of the city.
* The Warner Theater in Torrington is restoring the Art Deco theater (built in 1931). The $12 million public/private partnership aims to create an anchor downtown as well as a cultural and entertainment draw for northwestern Connecticut.
* In Bridgeport, the Polka Dot Playhouse, with a $2 million grant from the State Bond Commission, is converting a former bank building into its new home. The Klein Auditorium, also in Bridgeport, is using a $2.5 million grant to renovate.
* The former Colonial Theater in Hartford received $5 million in state aid to help redevelop the theater and create new retail space in the city's West End.
Though officials of most of the theaters being renovated say work needs to be done to modernize bathrooms, enlarge lobbies and update electrical, heating and cooling systems, the work will also open the theaters to many more groups, whether community companies or touring shows. That in turn translates into opportunities to draw more and varied audiences, which also means more activity on the streets of the state's cities.
"Just look at the newest performing arts center to come on line in Newark," said Arnold C. Greenberg, president of The Bushnell's board of directors. "It's created crowds and energy. It brings people downtown, which is good for the city's image and for restaurants."
Renovating or expanding performing arts centers is more than good for the arts organizations and theaters across the state, he said. Economically, for example, The Bushnell's addition will create 150 to 200 construction jobs, and once built, 100 new theater employees will be hired.
More importantly, said Mr. Greenberg, the sight of construction cranes ought to provide a psychological boost to Hartford, which for most of the 90's has seen few new construction projects get off the drawing boards. The new theater is scheduled to open in the fall of 2001.
When open, Mr. Greenberg said, he expects increased activity at restaurants near The Bushnell, including new ones that may open as a result of the added venue, and he said it is possible that a vibrant street life of eateries, cafes and boutiques could develop along Capitol Avenue between The Bushnell and downtown Main Street. In fact, with plans to create new housing developments on surface parking lots near The Bushnell, coupled with plans to create a $1.3 billion riverfront development known as Adriaen's Landing, Mr. Greenberg said, "it's not fanciful to imagine a marvelous boulevard from the State Capitol to the Connecticut River -- and The Bushnell will spark the new activity."
The renovation of the Shubert in New Haven, which helped turn it into a pre-Broadway house again, has similarly boosted economic activity in that city. The recent pre-Broadway production of "The Civil War," for example, brought 28,000 people downtown to see the show.
"For two months, 150 to 200 people from the show lived in our hotels, bought three meals a day, and left a lot of money in the city," said Caroline Werth, the Shubert's president and chief executive officer.
Besides attracting producers, actors and theatergoers from New York, the new Shubert is also drawing 30 percent of its audience from Fairfield County, Ms. Werth said, many of whom had never been to the theater before. "They're discovering that it's the same ride from Greenwich to New Haven as it is to Manhattan," she said, "except it's much less expensive."
At the Long Wharf Theater, not far away in New Haven, the managing director, Michael Ross, agreed that the theater could have a strong impact on a city's economic impact. "We've run the numbers on what we bring to the community," he said. "On any given night if both our venues at the Long Wharf are operating" -- a capacity of 700 people -- "63 percent of the people go to a restaurant in the area, and 89 percent go to a restaurant in New Haven. On average they spend $25 to $35 per person."
Though the Long Wharf, built in 1965, isn't being renovated, it expects to benefit from a proposed shopping mall next door, a 1.3-million square-foot complex called the New Haven Galleria at Long Wharf. The mall, which still has several legal and permit hurdles to overcome, is anticipated to draw one million shoppers a year. Mr. Ross said the mall developers have already agreed to work with the theater and the arts community to promote events.
Officials say the arts have played a key role in Stamford's effort to recapture a vibrancy downtown. Among the improvements to the 1,584-seat Palace, bought in 1989 by the Stamford Center of the Arts, was the enlargement of the stage and the addition of dressing rooms to accommodate large-scale productions. Improvements continue, including the construction of a new lobby and a 195-seat basement auditorium, but since the Palace reopened for large-scale musicals, Stamford has witnessed a burst of night life.
"This was a city in which the streets went totally dead at 6 o'clock," said Mr. Hiddlestone. "Gradually that's changed. Now there are nightclubs, bars and lots of restaurants, and though the theaters aren't the only cause of that change, they certainly help bring people out on the street," he added.
The ability to present Broadway productions in Connecticut theaters has also contributed to what economists call "reverse tourism," the environment that allows the state to keep residents' spending power within the state.
"A growing number of people can see entertainment in Stamford that they used to have to go to New York for," said Mr. Hiddlestone. "Obviously, it's a different experience than being in New York, but at least it's here on the doorstep," he said, noting the recent production of "Peter Pan" at the Palace, which went on to Broadway. "It was the same cast, the same production," he said.
Farther northeast along the shoreline, in New London, the Garde may be the model of how smaller cities can leverage the arts to rebuild a sense of community. "Our strategic vision is all about that reconnection," said Steve Segal, the theater's managing director.
"The programming is not necessarily about what happens on stage," he said. "In an urban setting, you have to also look outside the perimeters of the theater." Toward that goal, the Garde has bought key pieces of the State Street block to help lure people downtown and to ease their fears that the city is a dangerous place, Mr. Segal said.
"We like to think of ourselves as the grand lobby of the heart and soul of the city marketplace," Mr. Segal said. "Out of those interactions, other things happen. The waterfront gets developed. New restaurants open. And new partnerships -- educational, cultural or residential -- can start to bloom."
