SECTION: Section 11; Page 9; Column 1; Real Estate Desk 

LENGTH: 1635 words

HEADLINE: In the Region /Connecticut;
A $9-Million Expansion for Norwalk's Aquarium

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES 

 BODY:
A $9-MILLION expansion of the $30-million Maritime Aquarium now under way in South Norwalk is the most dramatic of a number of changes in progress or planned in a formerly rundown area that has sought a new identity in recent years.
Other developments include the purchase of a large amount of commercial and residential space along Washington and South Main Streets, the heart of the neighborhood, by a national developer that specializes in upscale urban areas.. 
 The aquarium expansion, which is scheduled to open in the summer of 2000 as an educational center, will be housed next door to the existing aquarium on North Water Street in the former Hatch & Bailey Lumber Company building. The 35,000-square-foot brick structure has been vacant since the aquarium opened in 1983.
Next month, workmen will begin shoring up the 19th-century structural members preparatory to renovating the interior and attaching the building to the aquarium.
Reconfigured out of a 100,000-square-foot 19th-century iron works on the west bank of the Norwalk River, the aquarium is considered a key element in the city's revival. Record crowds in the last three years, including more than 607,000 visitors paying $6.8 million in admission fees last year, made acquisition of more space crucial.
Almost all of the $9 million has been raised, according to David Sigworth, spokesman for the aquarium, "but some of it is in pledges coming to us over the next 10 years." To fill the gap, the aquarium has asked the city, which owns the land and buildings, to establish a $3.5 million line of credit.
Among the largest contributions to the project are $2.4 million from the state's Department of Economic and Community Development and $700,000 each from William Ziegler, an aquarium trustee; Newman's Own, Paul Newman's charitable foundation, and the Kresge Foundation, of Troy, Mich.
Coincident with the expansion of the aquarium, Starwood Investments L.L.C. of Washington, D.C., has begun cleaning up the exteriors of scattered properties that it acquired last November around the corner on Washington Street and South Main Street..
The company spent $7.5 million on 95,293 square feet spread through 31 ground-floor commercial condominium units in 16 buildings, and five entire buildings.
The shops, restaurants, offices and residential condominiums converted in the early 80's from dilapidated 19th-century buildings transformed the neighborhood from a slum into a stylish urban enclave now on the National Register of Historic Places. It was the first step in rescuing South Norwalk from oblivion.
Herbert Newman, head of Herbert Newman & Partners, New Haven architects, is the architect and planner for the aquarium's long-range expansion, which, he said, "could stretch over the next five to 15 years." Mr. Newman is a former professor at the Yale School of Architecture, where he is now critic of architectural design.
"The Hatch & Bailey building will retain its character," said Mr. Newman, "as an old building with interior walls of exposed brick and exposed wooden trusses, typical of mill buildings of the 1800s, juxtaposed with elevators, stairways, classrooms, conference rooms, research facilities, a kitchen, dining area and gift shop."
A new entrance will be installed on its north side, serving as a main entrance to the aquarium as well, until the existing main entrance on North Water Street is altered in the next expansion phase.
THE aquarium, the Hatch & Bailey Building and the land are part of a city-owned tract called Reed-Putnam, named for two nearby streets. It runs along the river from the aquarium to Interstate 95.
Plans approved by the city last year would join South Norwalk to downtown Norwalk by building a linear park along the river, enabling visitors to walk a half mile from the aquarium to the Lockwood-Mathews Mansion Museum on West Avenue.
A new Stepping Stones Museum for Children, which is under construction on the grounds of the mansion for a fall opening, will have one permanent exhibit and several changing exhibits year-round, as well as many hands-on activities.
Reed-Putnam plans also include a major hotel and residential project just north of the aquarium, an office complex near the highway and the demolition of the 100,000-square-foot Lock Building opposite the aquarium, to make way for a much needed 600-car parking garage.
Erected in sections from the 1870's to the 1940's and listed on the Connecticut Register of Historic Places, the building, where locks were once manufactured, "is full of asbestos and the soil is contaminated with arsenic," said Edward Musante, executive director of the Norwalk Redevelopment Agency. The building, owned by Michael di Scala, a local real estate developer and the Gardella family of Norwalk, is in Chapter 11 bankruptcy.
"The city has said it wanted to tear it down since 1983," said Mr. Gardella, "making it very difficult to rent." Only 25 percent is occupied by about 40 artists working in 16 leased spaces, and some warehousing and small manufacturing.
The city had named Clay Fowler, head of Spinnaker Management, a Stamford developer, to demolish the building, build the garage and develop a mixed-use residential/store complex on the aquarium's 126-space parking lot on North Water Street.
The artists responded by forming the Historic Lock Building Association, an advocacy group organized to save the building. Substantial public and some official support has persuaded the city to relent until appropriate studies can be produced.
"If it's feasible to provide parking for the aquarium without tearing down the Lock Building I would prefer it," said Peter Nolin, Common Council President.
C. William Kraus, vice president of the association, has been working with Artspace Projects, of Minneapolis, toward that end. "We want to develop the building as a regional attraction, with gallery space, sculpture gardens, artists' lofts and living space," he said.
Artspace, a nonprofit developer of space for artists, estimates that, at a cost of $13 million, the building would yield about 50 artists' live-work spaces of 1,000 to 2,000 square feet, with ground-floor parking in an existing garage on the ground floor.
"We work primarily in historic districts," said Chris Velasco, Artspace manager, "converting warehouses, hotels, schools that people don't know what to do with." Funded by the Ford Foundation, the MacArthur Foundation, corporate foundations, grants and Federal historic-preservation tax credits, Artspace has been buying and renovating disused buildings since 1979 and renting them out to artists at affordable rates. It administers a $60-million portfolio.
To satisfy the aquarium's need for parking, Artspace retained TAMS Consultants, of Boston, parking engineers who designed the new garage at Logan International Airport, to devise an alternative to the Lock Building. Later this month TAMS is expected to present to Norwalk officials a plan for a 600-space garage on the parking lot.
BUT according to Mr. Musante, whose agency must approve Reed-Putnam projects, the city already considered and rejected that idea. "The economics work out better if the land value of the surface lot could be used to subsidize the cost of public parking at the Lock Building site," he said, "by developing the surface lot for mixed use."
While the aquarium is just a few steps from Washington Street, the anticipated synergy between the two has not materialized. Most aquarium visitors are families with children who tend to bypass shopping and restaurant meals.
Another disappointment is the unsavory after-dark reputation that has settled on the street due to an inordinate number of bars and nightclubs that filled many recession-generated vacancies.
Complaints from visitors and apartment residents about drunk and disorderly bar patrons, panhandlers, and deafening rock music have reached a point where the Planning and Zoning Commission is expected to hold a public hearing at its May 19 meeting on modifying its regulations. A proposed amendment would prohibit new bars from opening on Washington Street and adjoining portions of South Main Street. Existing bars would not be affected, but those that convert to other uses would not be permitted to revert back to bars.
In spite of these concerns, the neighborhood is exactly what Starwood Urban looks for nationwide -- undervalued urban real estate, focusing on mixed-use holdings with a strong retail component.
"We like the eclectic nature of the place," said Robert S. Wennett, president of Starwood Urban. "Washington Street attracted us because it has more of an urban feel than the upscale villagey atmosphere of Westport or Greenwich." Among its acquisitions are spaces containing the Sassafras gift shop, Molly Brody's antiques, Beadworks, And & Company upscale clothing and household accessories, and several restaurants including Donovan's, Pasta Nostra, Amberjacks, Porterhouse, and Cote d'Azur.
Starwood Urban is a retail venture of Starwood Capital Group L.L.C. of Greenwich and Wennett Urban Retail of Washington D.C. Starwood Capital also controls Starwood Hotels & Resorts and Starwood Financial Trust. The South Norwalk acquisitions were purchased from numerous owners including Patriot Properties L.L.C. and Scirocco Partners, and from institutions that had foreclosed on some properties.
"There have been too many absentee landlords," said Mr. Wennett, "no single owner to control space and make a difference. Individual owners get whoever will pay the most rent, whereas we seek out tenants for a specific market. It is not our goal to fill up with national tenants. We plan to be very hands-on owners, working with tenants and shifting away from the overemphasis on nightclubs."

HEADLINE: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY;
I-95's Exit 8AIs a Magnet To High-Tech Warehouses

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA 

DATELINE: CRANBURY TOWNSHIP, N.J.

 BODY:
THE Graybar Electric company is starting up a distribution center here whose managers promise overnight delivery of electrical parts as far away as Boston or the suburbs of Washington. "If someone orders by 5 P.M., we'll have it on their loading dock before they open up the next morning," said Paul J. Milata, Graybar's regional manager here.
He can make that promise because he is managing a new building that is installing the latest equipment. But another important factor is the location of the building in Cranbury Business Park, about two miles from Exit 8A of the New Jersey Turnpike. 
 Not only is the site, about 60 miles southwest of New York City, midway between New York and Philadelphia, but it is almost equidistant from Boston and Washington. It is also an overnight ride west to important industrial centers in Pennsylvania and Ohio or east to the consumer markets of Long Island.
Because there is very little housing in the area, trucks have largely unimpeded access over local roads to the Turnpike, part of Interstate Route 95, which connects with the national highway system.
These are among the reasons that the area off Exit 8A has become one of the East Coast's prime centers for warehousing and distribution. Real estate executives estimate that there are 35 million square feet of industrial space within a few miles of the exit, most of it built over the last 10 years.
The area is so identified with warehousing and distribution that one developer, Kerzner Associates, named its project Eight A Corporate Park.
According to a year-end report by Cushman & Wakefield, the real estate services company, buildings in the 8A area accounted for 54 percent of the 2.6 million square feet of industrial construction in the northern and central parts of the state last year. Little building is going on now -- about 54,000 square feet -- but brokers and real estate executives say many applications are awaiting approvals and add that they expect further speculative construction to begin as the existing space fills up.
"This is a market that has always had speculative construction," said Michael Nachamkin, a vice president of Prologis Trust, a real estate investment trust that bills itself as as much an expert in global logistics as a real estate owner. "You need to have an inventory of space for your national customers," added Lisa R. Clark, a marketing executive with Prologis. She explained that companies operating on a national scale want distribution facilities ready when they decide to enter markets, without the delays involved in securing permits and construction.
A flurry of leasing in the first quarter of this year took 1.35 million square feet of space off the market in the 8A corridor, according to Cushman & Wakefield. In the largest single deal, Home Depot, a household products retailer, leased an entire 812,739-square-foot warehouse in Cranbury. Caliber Logistics took 150,000 square feet at 24 Charles Court in South Brunswick.
"This is an active market," said Paul D. Cohen, executive vice president of SBWE, a real estate services company based in New Jersey. "The inventory builds up for a while and then it gets leased."
"Exit 8A is the northernmost spot on the Turnpike with land available," said Jonathan B. Tesser, director of leasing for Matrix Development Group, one of the pioneer developers in the area. "Every time rents start to creep up, people start building on spec again."
Rents are modest compared to office space, but given the size of the buildings, can add up to a hefty annual total. For example, Building Two in Cranbury Business Park has 151,200 rentable square feet. Brokers say modern warehouse space typically rents for $4.25 to $4.75 a square foot annually, with older buildings ranging from $3.75 to $4.25 a square foot. But brokers reported that some owners have been bumping up asking rents for the most modern and best located buildings to the $5.10 to $5.25 a foot range in recent weeks.
Mr. Tesser estimated there is land near the exit for an additional 15 million to 20 million square feet of development. This land, which is, in effect, being warehoused for warehouses, has produced an interesting phenomenon: actively farmed fields running up to the edge of industrial parks. "I've got a spinach field on the east side of the plant, corn on the other and winter wheat in the back," said Mr. Milata of Graybar.
The continuing agricultural activity notwithstanding, real estate executives say almost all of the land is available for development when needed. "The owners keep it planted, but all of it is under contract or option for development," said Lou Belfer, a senior vice president of SBWE.
Real estate executives say the 8A market developed the way it did because the large blocks of land suddenly became easily accessible to the Turnpike when the exit was built in 1966. The highway was widened in the late 1980's, providing separate car and truck lanes down to 8A.
"Exit 8A was an afterthought," said Mr. Cohen, noting that it is almost midway in the 17 miles between Exits 8 and 9, which were part of the original layout of the highway, which was built in the early 1950's.
"Development started here around 1982, but there really wasn't mass development until 1985," Mr. Cohen said. He said development continued actively until 1991, when a recession in the real estate business brought everything to a halt. Activity resumed in 1995, he said, with existing property being absorbed, and then new construction began.
Most of the early building in the area was done by local developers such as Matrix, Frank A. Greek and Son and I. Heller. But in recent years, the real estate investment trusts have become a factor, with Prologis and Trammell Crow entering the market and Reckson Associates Realty Corporation combining with the local Morris Companies.
Matrix took over the old Phelps Dodgebuilding, a dark, brooding structure long familiar to motorists on the Turnpike. It changed the appearance of the 650,000-square-foot structure by lightening the color of the walls. Matrix added 550,000 square feet of space to what is now called 200 Docks Corner Road and recently finished leasing it all to tenants that include Barnes & Noble and Cooper Tire.
The Graybar operation is in a building built and owned by Prologis Trust, formerly Security Capital Industrial Trust, which claims to be the largest owner of warehouse-distribution space in the country, with 166 million square feet. Like the other buildings in Cranbury Business Park, this one is tall enough so goods can be stacked 32 feet high, and it has an advanced fire suppression system, an ultraflat floor and broad areas outside the building for trucks to maneuver.
Brokers and other real estate executives say a building of this sort represents the current state of the art and renders obsolete buildings put into operation less than a decade ago. Advances in forklift truck technology have allowed goods to be stacked higher in the steel racks that fill most warehouses.
Higher stacking is more economical for distributors because it allows more goods to be stored on the same piece of land. "Ten years ago 24-foot clear was state of the art," said Mr. Nachamkin, referring to the vertical distance between the floor and the trusses that support the roof. "Today 32 feet is standard," he said, noting that some buildings have 36 feet of stacking space.
"You can get one-third to one-half more product in a building with 36-foot clear height than 24 feet," said Benjamin Katz, a senior managing director of Insignia/ESG, the real-estate services company.
"There is a trend toward fewer but bigger boxes in the warehouse business," said Stanley Danzig, a senior director at Cushman & Wakefield. "But only about 10 percent of the product at 8A has ceiling heights over 32 feet." However, he pointed out that not every business needs the greatest height. "Some people don't need 32 feet," he said. Those older facilities, he said, will be leased at lesser rents than the new tall buildings can command.
Although the economics of higher stacking are generally favorable, the technique has imposed some additional demands on builders. One is for floors that are really, really flat.
Even a minor variation in floor flatness can be a problem when hoisting pallets of goods over 30 feet and trying to fit them into closely packed racks. One Prologis estimate is that one millimeter of variation at floor level can result in a load being as much as 12 inches out of line at the top shelf of a rack.
"Above 30 feet, you will have things dropping through or they simply won't go into the rack,"' said William L. Mascharka, president of Frazier Industrial Company, a major manufacturer of racks based in Long Valley, N.J.
So builders are using laser-guided devices known as screeds to produce flat, smooth floors that resemble ice skating rinks. And the concrete is compounded with a chemical additive that makes the floor smoother as it is cleaned.
In the Graybar distribution center, a line of grout patching compound runs down the center of each aisle of racks. The ground conceals a wire that sends signals to a device on a forklift truck to keep it squarely in the center of the aisle, so all the driver has to think about is forward and back and up and down motion.
Keeping the forklift in the precisely right position allows narrow aisles and the ability to pack goods in more closely. Because of the sensor system, a forklift measuring 76 inches wide operates in an aisle of just 84 inches. Because the truck cannot turn in such a narrow space, the building is equipped with forklifts whose lifting masts pivot to insert and remove pallet loads of electrical equipment.
IT costs on the order of $800,000 to $1 million to equip a 200,000-square-foot warehouse with racks, industry executives say. Narrow aisle fork trucks with pivoting masts cost approximately $50,000 apiece and a warehouse would need four to six depending on how fast goods move in and out. Several less sophisticated fork trucks to load and unload trailers at the dock would also be needed at $15,000 to $20,000 each.
Fire suppression is another issue in high-rise warehouses. In the past, most fire codes required the installation of sprinklers in the rack system itself, which was expensive to install and often had to be modified if the products being stored changed.
But in recent years the development of the early-suppression, fast-response sprinkler system has permitted the development of warehouses as high as 35 feet of clear height, without sprinklers in the racks. Instead, the sprinklers are mounted under the roof and use a high-pressure pump and more sensitive sprinkler heads to dump a large quantity of water early in the life of a fire. Sprinkler head technology currently undergoing testing may permit 40-foot clear heights in new construction.
The availability of land in the 8A area allows developers to provide accommodations for trucks, which have grown larger over recent years and have trouble turning around and maneuvering in more crowded urban areas.
"We are building larger truck courts for trucks that are 53 feet long now compared to 40 feet a few years ago," Mr. Nachamkin said. "They are taller too, at 110 inches from 96 inches."
"With these larger spaces the trucks don't have to back in nine times to get in the right position," Mr. Katz said.
Although warehouses are places to store things, many companies do not want to store them very long. With just-in-time manufacturing operations becoming common in American industry, many companies want more frequent deliveries of smaller amounts of material so it can be used as it arrives, rather than go into storage at the factory.
Companies like Prologis are constructing buildings with truck loading doors on both sides of the building, so material can flow through the building from suppliers to customer.
With two sets of doors, material can be received on one side and shipped out the other simultaneously.
The lack of a big population in much of the area off Exit 8A means that companies can operate at all hours without complaints about noise from the neighbors. "Home Depot supplies its stores overnight," said Robert Sager, a managing director at Insignia/ESG. "In an industrial park, they can operate any hours they want without getting residential complaints."
Real Estate executives say the three main towns in the area, Cranbury, South Brunswick and Monroe Township, have had varying attitudes toward development.
"At first Cranbury was against development, so the early projects were in Monroe and South Brunswick,"' Mr. Cohen said. "But then taxes in Cranbury started going through the roof, and coming out of the recession they changed their master plan and accepted development."
Mr. Tesser of Matrix Development said that "20 years ago Cranbury was the most difficult to deal with."
"Now," he said, "Cranbury has most of the available land and is into development."

HEADLINE: WEDDINGS;
Miss Herbert and Mr. Handwerger

 BODY:
Stephanie Alice Herbert, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene T. Herbert of Great Falls, Va., was married yesterday to Mark Richman Handwerger, the son of Gretchen Mann Handwerger and Joseph Handwerger, both of Washington. The Rev. William P. Billow Jr., an Episcopal priest and chaplain of the St. Albans School in Washington, performed the ceremony at the Washington National Cathedral.
Mrs. Handwerger, 30, is an associate in the Washington office of Perkins Coie, a Seattle law firm. A graduate of Tulane University, she received a law degree from Boston University and is a candidate for a master's degree in English literature at Tufts University. 
 Her father, who was from 1989 to 1994 the ombudsman of the International Monetary Fund in Washington, is now a consultant on employee-dispute resolution for corporations and organizations. Her mother, Myra Ratti Herbert, is the coordinator of social work services for the Fairfax County Public School System in Virginia.
Mr. Handwerger, 35, is the president of the Bedrock Management Company in Washington, which develops and manages billiard halls in Washington, Nashville, Philadelphia and Austin, Tex. He graduated from Swarthmore College and received an M.B.A. degree from the University of California at Los Angeles. His mother, a former deputy director of the Peace Corps, retired as the World Bank representative to the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development in Paris. His father is president of Joseph Handwerger Associates, architects in Washington.
The couple met in 1997 in Washington at a joint reunion of St. Albans, of which the bridegroom is a graduate, and the bride's alma mater, the National Cathedral School.

HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT;
For Newark Council Members, African Trip Draws Criticism

BYLINE: By STEVE STRUNSKY 

DATELINE: NEWARK

 BODY:
In a publicly financed show of sibling amity, members of the Newark City Council are planning a two-week trip to the Republic of Ghana later this month.
Several thousand Ghanaians make their home in Newark, and the city has established official ties, through Sister Cities International, a nonprofit group based in Washington, with two cities of the West African nation, Kumasi and Cape Coast. 
 Donald Tucker, Bessie Walker and Gayle Chaneyfield-Jenkins, the Council members planning to make the trip with at least three other people from May 8 to 22, will be able to speak English, Ghana's official language, while meeting with Ghanaian officials and business people and passing out T-shirts and pencils to local schoolchildren. The delegation will also attend the African-African American Summit in Accra, the country's capital, on the last week of the trip.
But official travel has become virtually synonymous with bureaucratic excess in Newark, where the Council and the Board of Education -- before a state takeover of the school district in 1995 -- have been criticized for indulging in junkets at the expense of taxpayers hard pressed to pay for basic services.
Councilman Tucker, who visited Ghana in 1995 to establish the Sister Cities link, said in a brief telephone interview that the relationship, including the May trip, afforded an opportunity for cultural, educational and business exchanges. "They sell Ghanaian products, and we buy Ghanaian products," Mr. Tucker said.
Others agreed, at least in principle. "Oftentimes, when you get the relationship, you're surprised at the kind of business opportunities you have," said Gerald Janssen, senior vice president of the New Jersey Commerce and Economic Growth Commission, who accompanied Governor Whitman and other political and business leaders on a trade mission to South America last month.
Mr. Tucker said that three Ghanaian delegations had visited Newark to promote the country's mahogany exports. But Mr. Tucker could not say whether any deals had resulted, nor could he provide specifics of any other business or cultural exchanges, and he did not return repeated follow-up calls.
Ms. Walker and Ms. Chaneyfield-Jenkins, as well as City Clerk Robert P. Morasco and staff members in his office, all failed to return calls or provide copies of an itinerary or the Council resolution authorizing the trip. A spokeswoman for the Council, Geraldine Clark, said she was not at liberty to talk about it. A spokeswoman for Mayor Sharpe James, Pam Goldstein, said the Mayor thought the trip was a waste of money, and said she had no further information.
The silence from City Hall contrasts with the clamor of criticism from other members of the Council and some Ghanaians in Newark. Cory Booker, the newest member of the Council, said he had been told that the trip would cost the city $36,000, for airfare, hotels, goodwill gifts and other costs, not including the "hundreds of hours" he said City Hall employees had put into its planning.
Mr. Booker, who joined Councilman Augusto Amador in voting against the trip, said the Sister Cities relationship may have value, but he failed to see the need for a visit by Council members, particularly when the goals of the trip were not clearly defined. "I don't know what they're expecting to come from this trip," he said.
Mr. Booker also criticized the Council's decision, which he said was proposed by Mr. Tucker, to spend $7,000 to take along Leonard Jeffries Jr., a professor at the City University of New York who stirred controversy nine years ago when he said, among other things, that Jews had dominated the slave trade. Dr. Jeffries, a native of Newark who has traveled in Ghana, did not return messages left at his office.
Newark is hardly the only city where such trips have been criticized, justly or otherwise. "There have been criticisms that Sister Cities have been a waste of municipal money," said Alexander Gorev, an official of Sister Cities International in Washington, who said he was unaware of the Newark trip. But in the vast majority of cases, Mr. Gorev said, "this is certainly a misperception."
Atta Boamah, a native of Kumasi who moved to Newark in 1988 and sits on the executive board of the Ghanaian Society of New Jersey, said Mr. Tucker was bringing Dr. Jeffries because they were personal friends and had been named honorary chiefs by villages in Ghana. But if there is to be a trip to Ghana, he said, then one of Newark's 3,000 to 4,000 Ghanaian residents should act as a guide, not Dr. Jeffries.
Mr. Boamah, a South Ward district leader and a political opponent of Mr. Tucker, said he had a theory about why he and other local Ghanaians have been excluded from any planning or information about the trip. "I believe there will be a business deal," he said. "That's why none of us were informed."
Even more fundamentally, he said, many of his fellow expatriates are unhappy about Newark's having close ties with what he considers his homeland's oppressive regime. "We're fed up with the government," he said.

HEADLINE: IN BRIEF;
New Library Chief

BYLINE: By F. ROMALL SMALLS 

 BODY:
After nearly a year's search, the Mount Vernon Public Library has hired Rolly (Rodney) J. Lee as director of the 103-year-old institution, which serves as the central library for the Westchester Library System.
Mr. Lee is the former executive director and chief executive officer of the library system in Gary, Ind., with a population of 150,000 and six branch sites with more than a million books. 
 "The library continues the educational process where the schools leave off," Mr. Lee said. "We are in an age of information. The library is the hub by which all information is assembled and disseminated under one rubric. There is no other source in society that delivers free information, regardless of one's socio-economic status."
Mr. Lee has hired an assistant director and obtained funds from state and Federal agencies, corporations and foundations to augment the library's $2.8 million budget.
He also wants to end a contract dispute between the 60 full-time and part-time employees and the library's administration and work more closely with the public schools as well as to upgrade technology in the library, which has nearly 500,000 books. It is one the largest libraries in the State. F. ROMALL SMALLS

HEADLINE: THE CULTURE OF MONEY;
Bidders Without Faces

BYLINE: By DANIEL AKST; Daniel Akst is a novelist and financial journalist. His column on the cultural dimensions of money and business appears the first Sunday of each month. E-mail: culmoney@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
THE auction, it seems, is the emblematic transaction of our time, as characteristic of fin-de-siecle America as the potlatch in some tribal societies, or imperial land grants in colonial days. As a means of exchange, it encapsulates a good deal about us, with our emphasis on individual freedom, fair markets and, lately, technology. For while many of us still imagine a fast-talking, gavel-wielding auctioneer, or perhaps the desperate shouting of traders in the commodities pits, the rise of the auction is now fueled by computers.
We are not far removed -- a couple of hundred years perhaps -- from a time when ordinary people had no practical way to sell things to anyone but their neighbors, or perhaps to a few strangers at a market fair. Now, because of the Internet, we can auction almost anything among millions of potential buyers at minimal transaction costs. Culturally, this phenomenon has implications. 
 For one thing, it means the death of the bargain. After all, bargains depend on such market imperfections as inadequate information, barriers of time and distance, and so on. Buy something in an Internet auction and you can be sure you are paying the highest possible price. Economists refer to the "winner's curse," which comes free with whatever you happen to acquire at an auction. (The curse is winning.)
Prowl Ebay for a while and you'll sometimes see people bidding as much for second-hand stuff as the same items would cost new. Sometimes, bidders even drive the price above retail.
The tendency to overpay at auction, of course, is not limited to the Internet. Auctions have changed the nature of book publishing, for example: Manuscripts or even fragments of manuscripts by top authors attract frenzied bidding from publishers chasing the next blockbuster, while piles of work by the rest of us poor hacks are left to languish unloved in mid-list hell. The same dynamic is at work in the movie business, where studio heads desperately bid huge sums to land the few hot scripts, and in pro sports, where stars with expiring contracts can weigh multiple proffered fortunes.
In retail transactions, auctions take consumers another step away from the face-to-face dealings once central to village life. On-line auctions are efficient, but how do you get one to sponsor a Little League team, or lower an awning over Main Street when it rains?
As business becomes more virtual, so do communities. The growth of auctions suggests we're becoming a nation of solitary consumers, trading electronic balances for overpriced tchotchkes without ever leaving home. Talk about home shopping networks!
While auctions do a good job of setting prices for copper and pork bellies, the Everyman sort of auction fostered by the Internet depends heavily on cultural "commodities" whose value is more subjective.
To help us arrive at a bid for pork bellies, we have information about bacon consumption, population trends, herds on hog farms and so forth. But who really knows how to value a lamp by Poul Henningsen or a painting by Irving Lehman?
The phenomenon is also at work in the astonishing run-up of Internet stocks, whose value, to the denizens of chat rooms and the world of on-line trading, is just as subjective in the absence of earnings.
HE may long for a world in which we buy staples across the counter from a kindly old fellow in an apron, yet we like auctions almost as much as we like the "category killer" superstores that have wiped out the mom-and-pop retailers of memory.
In fact, though, Internet auctions may have more in common with market day in a medieval village than with ordering from the operator at the toll-free number in Omaha. Ebay offers the opportunity to inquire about items for sale via E-mail, and, after the transaction, you can rate the person you bought from. These ratings are recorded, and anyone can look up anyone else's record before entering a transaction. In other words, J. P. Morgan has been proved right again: Character counts.
And so far, when you buy something in an on-line auction, you're not dealing with Wal-Mart or Home Depot, but rather with Joe Cyberspace in Columbus, Ohio, who happens to be parting with a pair of arts-and-crafts bookends you just can't live without. In this day of a shrinking globe and vanishing community, that's something.

HEADLINE: PRIVATE SECTOR;
When She Talks, Stocks Move

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr.

 BODY:
ACCORDING to its advertising, Dean Witter measures its success "one investor at a time." But it might also say that behind each of its 11,450 brokers is one Leah Modigliani.
Ms. Modigliani, among other things, is day-to-day manager of Morgan Stanley Dean Witter's list of 10 stocks it recommends most strongly for purchase, called its fresh-money buy list. When she makes a new choice -- on Wednesday, for example, it was the Mead Corporation -- many thousands of customers get calls from brokers suggesting they follow her lead. The chosen company's market capitalization then typically swells by hundreds of millions of dollars. Mead jumped $4.75, or 12 percent, on Wednesday. 
 But what really distinguishes Ms. Modigliani, a slight, 34-year-old roller-blade enthusiast, from most Wall Street strategists is intellectual firepower, no doubt related to one of the best economic pedigrees this side of Lawrence H. Summers, the Deputy Treasury secretary. (Both his parents are economists and two uncles, Paul A. Samuelson and Kenneth J. Arrow, are Nobel laureates in economics.)
Ms. Modigliani is the daughter of academics -- in social psychology and education -- and a distant cousin of Amedeo Modigliani, the painter and sculptor. And her grandfather is Franco Modigliani, winner of a 1985 Nobel in economics.
"My grandfather's enthusiasm for economics is absolutely contagious," she said. "But I never expected to be particularly interested in economics. It's just that it was my favorite subject at Oberlin." She is now known for developing, with her grandfather, a new way to judge the performance of mutual funds and other portfolios.
Byron R. Wien, her mentor and boss, had complained that most comparisons ignored the amount of risk that managers took. He asked that she try to figure out why. What Ms. Modigliani found was that existing methods were either not rigorous or precise enough -- she cited Morningstar's star system -- or were too difficult to understand. "I just kept thinking there's got to be a better way," she recalled in an interview in her 11th-floor office in Morgan Stanley's theater-district headquarters on Broadway.
Her solution began over the dinner table at her grandfather's house in Boston, not long after she joined the firm in 1995. He asked her what she was working on. After a brief discussion, she said, "we knew we were on the same page." Drawing on her grandfather's pioneering work on corporate leverage, she developed over the next year a measure that she called risk-adjusted performance. It soon became well known as Modigliani-Modigliani, or M-squared.
In essence, the approach first adjusts leverage artificially, to make all portfolios as risky as a benchmark, like the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index. Then it measures returns. It is the kind of challenge that taps Ms. Modigliani's intellectual heritage -- from Oberlin College and Harvard Business School as well as her ancestors -- and also earns people money.
"What I really love is combining the two -- taking the academic ideas and making them applicable," she said. "And it's about human behavior as well as finance and math."
She said she follows Mr. Wien's prescription to have fun at work, though nobody would confuse the Morgan Stanley version with, say, fraternity high jinks. "My idea of fun is choosing stocks for the portfolio," she said, and "to think about risk and talk about risk to investors."
Her style of living, which must allow for a 7:30 meeting with analysts each workday morning to discuss stocks, is anything but yuppie indulgence. Ms. Modigliani, who in June plans to marry Nicholas McGrane, a venture capitalist for Bankers Trust, lives in Manhattan's West Village, where, she says, "I hardly ever run into people on the street from work."
In fact, she is something of an activist. Last week, she was exulting because Eulia Charles, a young woman she had been mentoring for four years through a group called the Student Sponsor Partnership and whose parents never finished high school, had won a full scholarship to Fordham University. Ms. Modigliani took Ms. Charles to a family reunion of her Italian-Jewish clan -- transplanted to the United States after Italy adopted anti-Semitic laws in the 1930's -- in Boston for Passover last month.
She is also involved with Girls Inc., an after-school program that teaches girls about money, and serves on the investment committee of Oberlin's board of trustees.
Since she has had a high income for only a short time and is repaying large student loans, Ms. Modigliani's own stock portfolio is relatively modest. Still, she insists on backing her opinions with her own cash. "I can't really be advising people what stocks to buy unless I'm doing it myself," she said. "Byron, he wants me to feel the pain when the stocks go down -- and I do."
Between Oberlin and Harvard, Ms. Modigliani worked for six years at Marsoft Inc. in Boston, where she managed the production of software for economic forecasting in the bulk-shipping industry. But she went on to business school, she said, because she wanted to put her academic background to use in a practical setting.
At Morgan Stanley, she and Mr. Wien -- whose job she is likely to inherit someday -- share the view that the stock market is about 25 percent overvalued. They have been adding some cyclical stocks, like DuPont, and small-cap companies, like Cyprus Amax, a metals concern, to the firm's hypothetical model portfolio.
But Ms. Modigliani said she doesn't feel pressure to conform. "I'm allowed to have my own opinion on whatever I want," she said. "When I talk to the brokers and the clients, they know I'm saying what I really think. That intellectual freedom really is important to me."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS;
Putting a Braver Face On Japan's Bad Loans

BYLINE: By ANDREA ADELSON

DATELINE: OAKLAND, Calif.

 BODY:
"HE'S Don Quixote," said Jun Satoh, chief manager of credit policy for the Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi, motioning to his senior colleague, Eiichi Haruki. "I'm Sancho."
The two Japanese bankers came to the United States on a mission that some of their peers regard as nearly as crazy and embarrassing as tilting at windmills, though it is likely to accomplish a lot more. The quest: enticing institutional money managers, beyond a small circle of bargain-hunting specialists, to invest in Japan's mountain of defaulted bank loans. 
 Japan's banks have traditionally hated to sell nonperforming loans, because acknowledging that some or all of what was owed will never be recovered is seen as humiliating in a culture that takes humiliation hard.
When economic times were good, banks could afford to be unrealistically patient and optimistic about a few bad debts. But the bursting in 1992 of the country's "bubble economy" of soaring real estate and stock prices and the seven long years of recession that followed have left the country's banks with nonperforming loans that by some estimates total $1 trillion. By tying up capital that could otherwise be lent anew, they throttle bank earnings and starve the economy of credit.
The dead weight dragged a few weaker banks into liquidation and forced others to merge. Ultimately, it prompted the Government to design a $64 billion bailout plan, announced last October, to help the survivors cope by injecting capital into banks that took write-offs before the end of the fiscal year, on March 31.
Alone among Japan's biggest banks, though, Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi has stood aloof from the bailout and tried to solve its problems on its own. And that's where the delicate journey of Mr. Satoh and Mr. Haruki comes in.
In 1997, Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi was among the first Japanese lenders to start selling its defaulted mortgages on factories, stores and office buildings. So far it has sold loans totaling $7 billion in face value in 17 deals with Wall Street "vulture" funds and hedge funds in Britain and America.
These are the same kinds of investors who moved in early when the United States had a similar problem, the collapse of the savings-and-loan industry in the late 1980's, and who made big profits buying up dud loans at 50 cents on the dollar, restructuring them and selling them at 60 or 65 cents.
BUT the investors who wield money on the scale that Japan needs -- the big pension fund managers -- came late to the bulk auctions of S. & L. loans by the Resolution Trust Company. This time, Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi wants to lure those managers into the game earlier.
"They've taken a lead role in reaching out to nontraditional investors because it will broaden the market and speed liquidation," said Jack Rodman, a managing director of a Los Angeles accounting firm that specializes in real estate, E&Y Kenneth Leventhal, and one of Japan's leading bad-loan deal makers.
Outreach is what Mr. Satoh and Mr. Haruki were doing in California, trying to prepare the ground for future sales by preaching the general advantages of investing in dud Japanese loans on Japanese terms. They paid calls on two of the United States's largest institutional investors, the California Public Employees Retirement System, known as Calpers, and the treasurer of the University of California.
Squiring the two bankers into the offices of the fund managers was William J. Popejoy, who has experienced the pain of real-estate cycles first hand. At Federal regulators' behest, Mr. Popejoy was chosen in 1984 to try to forestall the demise of American Savings, the nation's largest S. & L., It ultimately failed despite his efforts.
"We said we aren't here to do a deal," said Mr. Popejoy, now the president of Pacific Capital Investors of Irvine, Calif. "When the Japanese came and bought assets in the U.S., they bought them the U.S. way," he said he told the portfolio managers. "We'd like you to think about buying Japanese assets the Japanese way."
Pacific Capital has already bet its own money on that kind of thinking. It recently completed a deal to buy 40 loans with a face value of $370 million from the bank, and wants to buy another package of loans five or six times that size, preferably with pension funds as partners.
Pacific Capital's deal with the bank requires it to stick to nonconfrontational tactics in trying to collect on the defaulted loans. The aim is to get partial repayment from the debtors without resorting to repossession, an intense humiliation in Japan that the bank still wants to spare its customers, even nonpaying ones.
"They're concerned with how we treat their borrowers," Mr. Popejoy said.
Institutional investors are likely to consider such a deal attractive if it includes an American partner to service the loans, said Martin J. Whitman, chairman of the Third Avenue Value fund, who has been an outspoken advocate of changes in Japanese law to ease the bad-debt problem. Spokesmen for Calpers and for the University of California treasurer would not comment on their meetings with Mr. Satoh and Mr. Haruki.
TO HELP it make its case to investors, Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi discarded its historical ways of analyzing nonperforming loans in favor of approaches drawn from the R.T.C.'s experiences, like valuing the loans based on cash flow. In the process it pioneered a secondary market that was new for Japan.
"Two years ago, you couldn't liquidate nonperforming loans," Mr. Haruki said. "This is very new. The effort was put into finding out what the investors' appetite is for." When the bank's bulk-sale plan passed muster with Japanese tax authorities, other banks followed suit.
Emboldened, the bank is considering securitizing some of the bad loans, another strategy rare in Asia but common in the United States. "In Japan, when you want to change things, it takes a long time," said Sachio Mikumo, a bank executive who accompanied them on their California trip. "There were skeptics, but not any more."
Mr. Rodman of E&Y Kenneth Leventhal estimates that $40 billion of nonperforming Japanese loans have been sold in the last three years at prices averaging 10 percent of face value, much lower than was typical in R.T.C. sales.
Buyers have included CS First Boston, Salomon Smith Barney, Lehman Brothers and Goldman Sachs. Sales should accelerate this year as once-hesitant banks, spurred by the bailout, begin writing off and selling bad loans the way Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi has, American investors say. "Everyone's waiting for the tap to open," said Thomas J. Barrack Jr., chairman of Colony Capital.
When it does, Mr. Satoh and Mr. Haruki hope that the pension funds they are evangelizing will be ready to buy in bulk -- and help buoy prices.
"This is the only way the Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi survives," Mr. Satoh said.

HEADLINE: The Nation: No Benefits, But No Jobs;
Welfare's Missing-in-Action

BYLINE: By CAREY GOLDBERG 

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
They seem, at this point, to be the disappeared, the missing, the lost in action of the new welfare era.
As more and more states track down former welfare recipients to assess how their well-being has been affected by stricter eligibility rules and more stringent work requirements, the question of those not accounted for looms ever larger. 
 The dimensions of the question are not trivial; the group of people neither working nor on welfare amounts to more than one-quarter of former recipients, state officials have said in several preliminary reports.
And in the information wars between advocates for the poor who contend that recent welfare changes are too harsh and state officials who present them as working well, the "missing" category is becoming a weapon that both sides seek to wield.
There are two kinds of the unaccounted-for: those who simply could not be found by trackers and those who have stayed off welfare but are not working. Not on welfare but not working either? What, then, are they living on? How do they survive?
When Massachusetts issued its first detailed, long-term report on how former welfare recipients seemed to be doing in mid-April, Claire McIntire, the state's commissioner of transitional assistance, immediately hailed its findings that a majority were working and about 20 percent were back on welfare as good news.
But her "very first question" to her staff, she said last week, was, "What is happening to the other 25 percent?" So she asked researchers to get back to her about how, exactly, those who were neither working nor on welfare were getting by. The answer was piecemeal. Of all the households that remained off welfare, 75 percent had an adult member working, the researchers found. The rest could be broken down like this:
* Just over 6 percent were in the process of re-applying for welfare or other assistance;
*About 2.5 percent were getting some form of Social Security payment;
* About 12 percent had been working in recent months but were not at the time of the survey;
* The remaining 5 percent or so had other explanations.
"I would not characterize them as missing," Ms. McIntire said. "We know they're still around, and they have other means by which they are supporting themselves and their families. And if they do not, we want them to come back to us and we will help them get back in the work force."
Such assertions draw vehement challenges from the advocates for the poor who see the Massachusetts report more as cause to worry than to rejoice. Unfamiliar with the official breakdown Ms. McIntire had ordered internally, they had their own ideas of what was happening with the missing 25 or 30 percent.
"My guess is that some have probably moved in with former spouses and boyfriends, of whom some are probably abusing them," said Randy Albelda, a University of Massachusetts economist, citing the high percentage of welfare recipients who have suffered domestic abuse. "Some people are probably going underground and doing illicit and illegal activities."
But basically, Ms. Albelda said, "We don't know what's happened to people, and it's going to get worse because the people who went back on welfare will have no welfare to go back to" now that time limits in Massachusetts are kicking in. "They're our missing," she said.
The advocates also point out that the people who could not be found at all for the survey, or refused to answer, are likely to be worse off than those who answered, and that respondents were likely to be less then honest because they were told that the information they provided could be forwarded to their case workers.
Around the country, there is a growing push to fill the holes in the welfare puzzle. Jack Tweedie, who tracks welfare policy for the National Conference of State Legislatures, said that, in the simplest terms, the states made changes in their welfare programs, their case loads dropped much faster than they had expected and the immediate question became, "What happened to those families?" Two key questions, he said, are, "How many are working and how many are in desperate circumstances?"
That broad picture is now emerging. State reports have tended to show that about two-thirds of former welfare recipients get jobs and about one-fifth find themselves even poorer than before.
SO now, Mr. Tweedie and others said, efforts to track the families that left welfare are getting more advanced, and officials are beginning to ask follow-up questions about how former recipients who have not found work are supporting themselves, and what exactly are the barriers that keep them from getting jobs.
In Wisconsin, said Jan Van Vleck, a state expert on post-welfare tracking, the latest survey asks the question, "If you have not identified any forms of support, could you let us know how you are living?"
One way many are likely to be living, Mr. Tweedie noted, is by depending even more on family than before. A New Jersey study of certain former recipients, he said, found that as they were leaving welfare, 38 percent said they planned to get a job; but only about half of those people actually did. And just 23 percent said they would depend on family support, but then a full 47 percent actually did.
The worry is that such family support may not be sustainable for long, he said, because the families that former recipients depend on are usually poor as well.

HEADLINE: INVESTING WITH: STEVEN A. CHAMBERLAIN;
Invesco European Fund

BYLINE: By WILLIAM R. LONG

 BODY:
A LONGTIME fan of Manchester United, the English soccer team, Steven A. Chamberlain, manager of the Invesco European fund, can do something that most other sports enthusiasts can't: control a chunk of the sports franchise he follows so passionately.
But Mr. Chamberlain's strong affection for "Man United" is not the reason he invests in it, or in the two other soccer clubs in his portfolio. 
 As an aggressive, growth-oriented manager, he is focused on the fact that soccer is the most popular sport in Britain and across Europe, and that major clubs are reaping increasing shares of television advertising revenue.
"Really, these companies are actually very good leisure plays," he said by telephone from his London office.
Soccer club shares account for just 1.75 percent of the fund's portfolio, which contains 79 stocks. The fund, with $631 million in assets, has returned 18.7 percent, annualized, for the three years ended April 23, compared with 16.8 percent for the average European stock fund, according to Morningstar Inc., the Chicago financial publisher. But there have been problems this year; the fund is down 7.2 percent, versus a decline of just 1.3 percent for the peer group.
Mr. Chamberlain attributes the recent performance to the portfolio's high-growth stocks, which carry big price-to-earnings multiples. Manchester United, with a P/E of over 50, is down 12.3 percent this year. "These companies have come in for profit-taking as investors shift to deeper cyclicals," he said, referring to oil, chemical, and some mining and steel companies. Some investors are also returning to Asian stocks, out of favor until recently.
Mr. Chamberlain, 34, grew up near Sheffield in northern England -- not far from Manchester -- and has been with the Denver-based Invesco Funds Group since 1987, working in a centuries-old complex in the City of London. He became manager of the European fund in 1990, when he was just 25.
The fund's assets are spread around Europe, mostly in large-capitalization companies. "What we really want to do is find companies that are operating in business areas that are growing, where they are well positioned to also be able to grow in that market," he said.
To zero in on stocks, he analyzes industries, visits companies and uses computer screening. He pays special attention to companies that have shown above-average return on equity over the last six years. "If they have a proven record over that sort of time period," he added, "it usually shows that they're doing something right."
But the fund, like others invested in Europe, has been hurt by slower growth in economies, by the shaky start of the euro and by negative market sentiment from the conflict in the Balkans.
One top holding is Vodafone Group of Britain, the wireless network provider. It took a big step into the American market in January, announcing its plan to buy Airtouch Communications for more than $60 billion.
"Earnings growth has been strong, but earnings are still at a low level, because the company is reinvesting lots of capital," Mr. Chamberlain said. "This is what we like. We want companies that are generating cash, hopefully sufficient amounts to be able to expand their businesses, and they're hopefully operating in markets where they have lots of room to grow."
Mr. Chamberlain said he first bought Vodafone stock in January 1997 at 2.54, it closed Friday at 11.45, and he has a target of 15.40 for 12 months.
A SMALLER company, Tomra Systems of Norway, specializes in so-called reverse vending machines. Customers return empty recyclable bottles and cans to the machines and receive tickets that can be redeemed at store checkouts. More than half of Tomra's revenues come from the United States.
"Tomra has more than 90 percent market share globally in those machines," he said. "We liked it because we thought that it had a big target market in which to grow."
He bought Tomra stock in August 1995 at about 30 Norwegian kroner. It now trades at 310 kroner, and his 12-month target price is 430.
Telepizza, the largest fast-food company in Spain, also has outlets in Portugal and other European countries. Mr. Chamberlain said Telepizza has a 60 percent share of the Spanish pizza market, "and it's a fast-growth market because fast food in Spain is underdeveloped."
In the United States, he said, an average person spends $300 a year on fast food. "In Spain, it's about $15," he added.
Telepizza delivers by moped. "The pizzas themselves are pretty good, but it's really the fact that they're very good at marketing and they offer a very good service," he said.
He started buying the stock in February 1998 at the equivalent of 4.95 euros. It now trades at 6 euros; his target is 9.18 by next April.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 4; Column 5; Money and Business/Financial Desk

LENGTH: 871 words

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW;
Out of Asia: The Move Toward Global Regulation

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
THE Asian crisis is subsiding. Even Russia is reviving a bit. But for all the relief that brings, the global financial meltdown remains a haunting memory -- not as searing as the Depression for a generation of Americans, but scary enough. And just as the Depression brought regulation to America's financial markets, the Asian and Russian crises are forcing rules on the global market.
That is a striking shift in course. The thousands of lenders and borrowers who move money among themselves in what is called the global financial market had counted on markets to heal themselves without much oversight. Many economists encouraged that view, until Asia took a dive. And now public officials with the power to regulate global markets are speaking more explicitly than ever about actually doing so. 
 They are not thumping pulpits about it. But in interviews, speeches and forum discussions at the spring meeting of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank, held here last week, some officials offered views they would not have dared to put on the record six months ago.
"There is a growing acceptance in the official international community that you tremendously increase the risk of triggering volatility and crisis if rules are not made for the proper structuring of debt," Jack Boorman, the I.M.F.'s director of policy development, said in an interview. Volatility is a euphemism for the panicky rush of foreign lenders out of Asia, then Russia, and then Brazil. Credit even dried up in the United States last fall, until a worried Federal Reserve abruptly cut rates.
While the World Bank had spoken out for global rule-making, the I.M.F. had held back, and so had the Clinton Administration. But it was clear at last week's meeting that they, too, have now come on board.
The Asian crisis has imposed on all of them a common frame of reference. It goes like this: The global capital market, like national markets, is neither self-regulating nor self-curing. Left alone, lenders and borrowers tend to operate with too much exuberance, on the one extreme, and then pull back too far in panic, on the other.
"Crises are, in a sense, accidents," said Lawrence H. Summers, the Deputy Treasury Secretary, in a speech last Sunday. "As with accidents, crises will never be eliminated, and are not amenable to silver-bullet solutions. Think of auto accidents: If one looks back at any auto accident, there are always many things that could have combined to produce greater safety."
Given that recognition, the new rule-making -- or accident prevention, as Mr. Summers put it -- is under way. It is now openly recognized that lenders must be regulated, and negotiations have begun over what strictures to impose on them. (Hapless borrowers have been lectured from all sides since the global crisis started in 1997 on how they should have behaved and must now behave.)
"There is more belief now in the necessity of controls on both the lending and the borrowing side," said Stanley Fischer, the I.M.F.'s first deputy managing director.
The lenders, after all, are part of a system that can swing too easily from optimism to pessimism. These swings are facilitated by short-term loans, which lenders prefer to long-term lending. Loans of less than a year are less expensive for lenders because banks need not keep as large a percentage of the loans' value in reserve. And short-term loans can be withdrawn quickly in a crisis, which makes the lenders whole but tends to deepen the crisis.
Borrowers are also tempted by short-term loans. They can often borrow abroad for the short term at relatively low interest rates and re-lend the borrowed money long term at home at higher rates. They gamble that the short-term loans will be renewed indefinitely, not suddenly withdrawn in panic.
One goal of the new rule-making is to discourage short-term lending in favor of long-term loans, which are less likely to finance speculation and more likely to finance factories and similar investments. Not surprisingly, this shift is turning out to be the hardest part of the new rule-making process.
LENDERS, naturally, are opposed. "Presumably the market, on its own, will find the right balance between short- and long-term credit," said James Chessen, chief economist of the American Bankers Association.
Public officials are sensitive to this resistance. Still, there is much talk of raising reserve requirements on short-term loans, and of requiring bondholders to postpone repayment in the event of a crisis.
Tougher proposals come more slowly to the table. One is the so-called Chile approach: When short-term foreign loans enter in great quantity, Chile requires the foreign lenders to deposit a percentage of each loan in a noninterest-bearing account -- a tax, in effect, that raises a loan's cost. Such a strong deterrent never entered Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin's speeches, until April 21, the eve of the meeting here.
"Some countries," he said, "may deem more comprehensive measures -- such as Chilean-style taxes on short-term capital inflows -- to be appropriate." Caveats filled the next three sentences, but no rejection. The rule makers, mindful of Asia, are clearly moving forward.
