SECTION: Section 14; Page 1; Column 3; The City Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 2780 words

HEADLINE: Life on the Edge;
How High a Fence Is the City Line?

BYLINE: By BERNARD STAMLER 

 BODY:
CHERRYL MITCHELL is a native New Yorker, born and raised in Brooklyn. But she's quick to tell you she doesn't think much of life in the city, or the "concrete forest," as she calls it.
"I left and I've never missed it or looked back," she said. "Now I hear birds and see real trees when I wake up." 
 While there are trees in Brooklyn, and birds, Ms. Mitchell lives in a 200-year-old house on two acres in Charleston, Staten Island, next to the wetlands and forest of the Clay Pit Ponds State Park. Dogs and cats roam the grounds, even a goose. The sky, unbroken by silhouettes of buildings, seems a million miles from the city.
But when turkey hawks wheel overhead, swooping for prey, it is often a pigeon they will grab for an afternoon meal. The skies are not theirs alone. Frequently, the thunder of jets flying in and out of Newark International Airport can be heard. For the earthbound, the vista includes oil refineries lining the New Jersey side of New York Harbor, and, on the way to Ms. Mitchell's house, the mountain of urban garbage that makes up the Fresh Kills dump.
With her home two miles from the Outerbridge Crossing to New Jersey and half that from the municipal boundary, Ms. Mitchell lives on a frontier. Like thousands who live on the city's margins, on Staten Island, in Queens or the Bronx, she is a New Yorker on the edge.
It is often said that New York is less an urban monolith than a collection of small towns. All over the city, there are distinct neighborhoods, many of them with a well-developed sense of community. Some are like small villages, where everyone seems to know everyone else and generations of the same families have lived and died.
In communities that touch, in some cases straddle, the city line, the border helps define the place for its residents, though the effect varies considerably. For some the boundary is a dividing line that connotes separation from the city. And there are those who think that's a good thing, like Frank Scala.
"I live in Bayside, Long Island," he says, "not Bayside, New York." A retired teacher who lives in the Queens home where he grew up and raised his own family, Mr. Scala sees Bayside as "a town or a village, like a rural part of Nassau or even Orange or Westchester County."
Well, not exactly. Although there are plenty of one-family homes nearby in the northeastern Queens communities of Bayside, Douglaston, Douglas Manor and Little Neck, some of them on wooded plots and quiet streets like those in Nassau County, there are also two- and three-family homes and apartment houses.
The area is ringed by highways, and two of the city's East River bridges, the Whitestone and Throgs Neck, provide a crossing to the Bronx. Bayside's main commercial artery, Bell Boulevard, has the same parking meters and arcane street signs that bewilder motorists in the five boroughs, and city buses rumble up and down the main streets.
Still, in eastern Queens, where there is no subway (it ends in Flushing, several miles west), a car is a must. The public schools are among the city's finest, with reading and math scores rivaling those of upscale suburban towns across the county line.
Demographically, the area is also similar to towns next door in Nassau County: more affluent, with more white people than the city as a whole. While 1997 census estimates put the white population of New York City at just over 50 percent, Bayside is 73 percent white, while in Douglaston 80 percent of residents are white. Average family income citywide is $65,777 annually. In Bayside it is $84,170 and Douglaston, $83,185.
There are other signs of suburbia. At Fort Totten, which the city will soon acquire from the Federal Government, children play soccer on windswept fields overlooking Long Island Sound and Little Neck Bay, where the boats of the United States Merchant Marine Academy at Kings Point ply the waters.
Then there are buying habits. People shop locally or, more often than not, in Nassau border communities like Great Neck and Manhasset, as well as at Long Island malls like Roosevelt Field and the Source in Westbury. A Source spokeswoman, Billie Scott, said 15 percent of its customers came from Queens. Many Nassau businesses advertise in local Queens papers, said Victoria Schneps, who publishes The Courier, a Bayside weekly.
Thus Mr. Scala, who heads the 464-family East Bayside Homeowners Association, is far from alone in thinking that he has far more in common with residents of, say, Lake Success, N.Y., than with those of Bensonhurst or Greenwich Village.
"I don't think of myself as a city person," said Geraldine Spinella, president of the Bayside Historical Association, whose family has lived in Bayside since the 1890's.
"It's a suburb within the city," agreed Tess Mittman, a 40-year resident. Councilman Michael J. Abel, a native of Bayside who represents the 19th District, which includes the northeastern part of the borough, said: "I don't live in an outer borough. I live in an inner county."
He recalled that residents deluged him with complaints when the Post Office decided to refer to the area generically as Flushing (the name of its main post office), eliminating place names like Bayside from its computers. Under pressure from residents who objected to identification with a more urban and less affluent area of Queens, the Post Office relented.
The reasons for this pervasive sense of apartness from the city are partly historical. Residents of eastern Queens didn't want to become part of New York City in the first place, voting against municipal consolidation in a referendum that preceded the creation in 1898 of Greater New York, the late 19th-century term for what is today New York City. Their distrust of the city led eastern towns to secede from Queens, thereby forming Nassau County; even among towns remaining, skepticism was high.
Today, the feeling persists along the Queens-Nassau line. Not just in Bayside and Douglaston but also in communities to the south like New Hyde Park, Floral Park and Bellerose, all bisected by the municipal border, lying partly in Nassau and partly in Queens. There, where the homes tend to be more modest than in the neighborhoods to the north, those who live on the New York City side are aggrieved by what they say is the city's outright disregard of their needs, according to Councilman Sheldon Leffler, who has represented many parts of the area for more than 20 years and whose 23d District abuts Mr. Abel's. "People think that the city doesn't give them adequate attention," he said.
Susan M. Noreika, a resident of the Queens part of New Hyde Park who has been chairwoman of Community Board 13 since 1971, said, "We've always had to fight like tigers for everything we need," like street repaving.
This disaffection has led to the formation of neighborhood groups like the Lost Community Civic Association, whose president, Oscar Berenberg, declared, "Half the people in city government probably don't even know where Queens is." It has also led residents of border communities to identify more strongly with suburban counterparts.
For example, in the area roughly bounded by 225th Street and 257th Street in Bellerose, New York State Route 25 is known as Jericho Turnpike on the southern, Nassau side, and as Jamaica Avenue on the northern, Queens side. That causes confusion, so Richard Hellenbrecht and other members of a Bellerose civic group are trying to get both sides to take the same name "as a way to help people in the community get together."
Their choice for the joint name? Jericho Turnpike. "There's no reason in the world why people in Nassau would want to name their street for Jamaica," Mr. Hellenbrecht said. But presumably every reason why those on the Queens side would want their street named for a town in Nassau.
Of course, not everyone in eastern Queens is wary or disdainful of the city. Residents note that their property taxes are generally a small fraction of what they would be in the adjoining Long Island suburbs. Thousands commute to Manhattan daily, according to the chairman of Community Board 11 in Bayside, Bernard Haber, who said that he and others "like being a part of New York City," able to take advantage of the city's cultural offerings.
As Mr. Leffler put it, "It's like a best-of- both-worlds philosophy." Such city-friendly sentiment exists, no doubt, elsewhere along the border, too. But there are also places on the edge where the city just doesn't seem to be all that important.
Take Woodlawn, a small, 40-square-block enclave of the northern Bronx just below the Westchester County line. Bordered by the Bronx River Parkway on the east, Van Cortlandt Park on the west, Woodlawn Cemetery on the south and, on the north side, by Yonkers, the inhabitants of Woodlawn are in effect geographically cut off from the rest of the Bronx. But not philosophically, according to Councilwoman June M. Eisland.
The people in the community are "proud to be Bronxites," she said, and eager to overcome "the stereotype that the Bronx is not comfortably residential." They are also "very happy to be where they are," she said, "equidistant between Manhattan and the shopping malls of Westchester."
James C. Reilly, a 15-year resident and past president of the Woodlawn Heights Taxpayers Association, agrees, but only up to a point. He says there is another kind of identity that matters far more to residents. "For most people who live here," he said, "parish boundaries are more important than municipal boundaries."
In some ways, Woodlawn is a throwback to an earlier New York, when one or two ethnic groups predominated in a neighborhood. Here, the vast majority of residents are Roman Catholic, according to the Archdiocese of New York, and their parish, St. Barnabas, which crosses the city line, includes roughly equal parts of Yonkers and of the Bronx. Most residents are at least partly of Irish descent, with citizens of Italian and German ancestry coming in second and third.
"We have always thought in terms of our parishes," said the Rev. Richard Gorman, chairman of Community Board 12, who now works for Catholic Charities but began his career at St. Barnabas. "It's part of Catholic culture."
By appearance, the Bronx and Westchester parts of the parish are hardly distinguishable: one-, two- and three-family homes, some small apartment houses. Even the street signs on both sides of the border are green and white. Residents of both parts of the community shop at the businesses that line MacLean Avenue, the main commercial street on the Yonkers side, and Katonah Avenue, in the Bronx, where there are numerous Irish bars and an Irish bakery. Their children play Little League ball together.
Social service agencies ignore the border. On the Westchester side, Sister Edna McNicholas and the Rev. Tom Flynn, both from Ireland, work at the Asiling Irish Community Center, where they assist thousands of immigrants each year, according to Sister McNicholas, many from Woodlawn. In the Bronx, the Woodlawn satellite office of the Queens-based Emerald Isle Immigration Center sees 70 to 100 people a month seeking assistance in applying for green cards or citizenship, according to Patricia Bowie, an employee. Although the center is open to everyone, she said, "every person you see is Irish or Irish-American," coming from both sides of the community.
Even the parish church, St. Barnabas, symbolically straddles the city line, half in and half out of the city. The pastor, the Rev. Francis C. Toner, said it was a deliberate choice made by the church's builders in 1910 "so that no one group could claim it for its own." So homogeneous is the neighborhood that people living on the Yonkers side will often say, when asked, that they live in Woodlawn, identifying with the city. And that's something suburban residents rarely do.
Staten Islanders have long prided themselves on their relative isolation from the rest of the city, calling theirs "the forgotten borough." And Charleston is clearly to Staten Island what the borough is to the rest of New York: if not forgotten, then certainly the last frontier.
It sits next to the narrow Arthur Kill and New Jersey, on what residents call Staten Island's South Shore, where towns seem to run into one another and boundaries are hard to draw. Charleston is generally thought to run from the Arthur Kill on the west to Bloomingdale Road on the north and east and then to Route 440 on the south. Areas nearest the shore remain the least developed; there, where equestrian and hiking trails of Clay Pit Ponds Park can be found, people still raise small farm animals and stable and ride horses.
Not that Charleston is a bucolic paradise. This is real country, where people work and live, not some picture-postcard ideal. Indeed, Charleston was once a fairly sizable industrial town, where bricks were made from the region's clay soil. The legacy of this industry, from the 1850's to the 1920's, can be seen in the historic homes and street names like Kreischer, after the brick factory's founders. It can also be seen in the detritus of an industry gone bankrupt, and in zoning that allows people to be shoehorned between industrial properties.
Owen Reiter was born in the Bronx and raised in Queens. He lived in Manhattan until 1985, when he and his wife, from Minnesota, discovered Charleston. They were taken by the open space, by the chance to raise animals and do serious gardening, he said, and by the 200-year-old home they eventually purchased, which was originally owned by one of the founding families of the area. There were also woods behind the property and, beyond them, a beach on the Arthur Kill.
The Reiters keep goldfish in outdoor ponds. They raise ducks and chickens. They once kept horses. Their home is immaculate and grounds well tended. Across the street are other neat homes. But the rest of their surroundings are something else. Deserted barges litter the beach. There are factories nearby, some abandoned, others functioning, and across the street a junkyard of garbage and cars. Fuel tanks line the horizon; the Arthur Kill State Correctional Facility is near.
In short, isolated in a part of the city as far from Manhattan as possible, the Reiters still live near some of the most unsightly things modern life can produce. Yet they still cling tenaciously to their home, and to Charleston. Why?
"There's nowhere else in New York City where I could find a similar situation for the kind of money I can afford," Mr. Reiter said. Industry or not, "there's still no other place that's still so rural." Older houses in Charleston sell for $175,000 to $200,000, depending on the condition and plot size, according to Lydia Ragucci Real Estate, with new two-family homes and semidetached one-family dwellings priced from $225,000 to $250,000.
But will the rural character last? For residents, the prospects of stopping development nearby don't look good. Already, attached homes on microscopic plots crowd once vacant land near Bloomingdale Road, just up the block from Cherryl Mitchell. There are plans for more, too, and for hundreds of other homes on the water's edge near Mr. Reiter's place, said Lorraine Sorge, president of the Staten Island Taxpayers Association and a former chairwoman of Community Board 3. The city is reviving long-dormant plans to build a shopping center on wetlands it owns next to the Clay Pit Pond Park, plans that residents have opposed for years.
"I fear for Charleston," Ms. Sorge said.
Cherryl Mitchell is also fearful. And downright angry. "I feel like the rest of Staten Island is encroaching on me," she said, pointing in the direction of newly built homes that for now are still invisible from her property.
Ms. Mitchell says she feels little, if any, kinship with those who are moving to Charleston, or even with those who live farther in on Staten Island, closer to the Staten Island Expressway and the established commercial centers. She does all her shopping in New Jersey, she says, never bothering to go to places like the Staten Island Mall, which is about the same distance away as Woodbridge Center in New Jersey. And she vows that she may move altogether if the new houses get any closer. There's simply nowhere left to go, she said, except out.
Still, she plans to stay, at least for now. It's the country, after all. Or as her friend Ms. Sorge puts it, referring to poultry some Charleston residents still slaughter for their dinners, "Where else in New York can you still see chickens running around without their heads?"
Nowhere, of course. Unless you count Manhattan during morning rush.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 5; Money and Business/Financial Desk

LENGTH: 3161 words

HEADLINE: Going For Broke

BYLINE: By MELODY PETERSEN

 BODY:
DIANNE LAWE, a private investigator, arrived early enough on an overcast morning last November to beat the garbage truck to Harry Leonhardt's home in a tranquil neighborhood north of Houston.
When she lifted the lid of the dark green trash can at the foot of Mr. Leonhardt's driveway, Ms. Lawe found just what the lawyers who had hired her said she might: a trove of financial documents, many of them emblazoned with the corporate name of the National Gypsum Company. 
 Mr. Leonhardt, a consultant and former building industry executive who had advised National Gypsum as it went through a messy bankruptcy in the early 1990's, had been ordered in a subpoena to turn over any papers he had relating to the company. The lawyers say they sent Ms. Lawe to check Mr. Leonhardt's trash the day before his scheduled deposition because they thought he might be tempted to throw away whatever documents he had; he later explained that he did not even realize he still had the papers and simply was cleaning boxes out of his closets.
Like many other companies that make construction materials, National Gypsum filed for bankruptcy to help rid itself of thousands of injury claims that were pouring in from people who had become ill -- or feared they would -- after inhaling asbestos in the manufacturers' products.
What distinguished National Gypsum's case was the outcome.
For three prominent investment firms that held most of the company's senior debt -- Fidelity Management and Research; Goldman, Sachs & Company and the Trust Company of the West, an investment firm based in Los Angeles -- gypsum turned to gold when National Gypsum went on to flourish after it emerged from bankruptcy in 1993, largely in their control. The firms doubled or even quadrupled their initial investments, making upwards of $240 million in profits.
But thousands of others had claims against National Gypsum -- asbestos-exposed workers, school districts, hospitals and universities that spent millions ripping asbestos from their ceilings and walls, investors who bought National Gypsum bonds for their retirement accounts. At best, they were left with mere fractions of what they were owed. Those creditors have been unhappy with the company almost from the day the trouble started. But now their lawyers -- the people who hired Ms. Lawe -- say they finally have proof that the resolution of the bankruptcy case was a miscarriage of justice.
The lawyers say documents they have uncovered suggest that before the bankruptcy was settled, the company and the investment firms had a secret cost-cutting plan, devised by Mr. Leonhardt, that had the potential to add millions to the company's value -- and eventually did. Though bankruptcy court judges are supposed to approve all advisers and professional fees, the court was never told that National Gypsum had hired Booz-Allen & Hamilton, the consulting firm, to flesh out the plan.
To the contrary: The company and the investment firms' experts said on the witness stand that National Gypsum's expenses had already been cut to the bone. Documents that might have painted a different story -- like those in Mr. Leonhardt's trash -- are only now making their way to the courthouse, as part of a long-running lawsuit now heading to a Texas appeals court.
The defendants in that suit -- including the three investment firms, former executives of National Gypsum, and Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, the company's financial adviser during the bankruptcy (but not Mr. Leonhardt, whose behind-the-scenes role was not initially known to the plaintiffs) -- all say there was no secret plan and no misconduct of any sort.
"It's a fantasy piece," said Bryant C. Boren Jr., a Dallas lawyer who has kept busy representing the company's former officers and directors in much of the litigation that has trailed the bankruptcy. What the creditors' lawyers call Mr. Leonhardt's secret plan, Mr. Boren added, was nothing more than his sales pitch for a role in restructuring National Gypsum.
The investment firms, meanwhile, say their gains were their rightful reward for making the risky choice to take stock in National Gypsum in exchange for their bankruptcy claims. It was an unforeseen upturn in the economy and the housing market -- not some back-room conspiracy -- that led those shares to triple soon after the company emerged from bankruptcy, they say.
"It is clear that the rise in National Gypsum's stock price subsequent to the reorganization was principally due to an upturn in the U.S. housing market generally and in gypsum prices in particular," said Scott Beyerl, a spokesman for Fidelity.
And in any event, the defendants add, the dispute has already been aired in court and resolved in their favor.
Undisputed, though, is the meager amount that National Gypsum's bankruptcy left for a long parade of creditors.
"I think I've been had," said Alfred B. Earnest, a retired human-resources manager from Houston, who invested $1,800 of his retirement money in the company's junior bonds in 1986. After years of waiting, Mr. Earnest was paid $592.65 in 1995.
Anxieties are high, too, for asbestos-exposed workers counting on payments from a trust fund established during the bankruptcy proceedings. Already, 300,000 claims have been filed, even though the first signs of lung disease often do not emerge until 30 years after the exposure. National Gypsum's fund, which has received a total of $518 million to pay claims, may run out of money as soon as 2002, according to W. Dee Hilton, its managing trustee.
"Because of the alleged fraud committed during the bankruptcy process, the trust did not get the money that it would have," Mr. Hilton said.
The three investment firms, however, received the entire value of their bonds -- and, in the end, much, much more. Lawyers for the asbestos trust, Mr. Earnest and the others who held the company's junior bonds estimate that Fidelity; Goldman, Sachs; the Trust Company of the West, and a few other senior creditors walked away with securities that, in total, were eventually worth as much as $800 million for bankruptcy claims that had a face value of only about $300 million.
Indeed, because the bankruptcy had driven down the value of National Gypsum bonds, the stakes actually cost the three investment firms only about $120 million to acquire.
Goldman, which put up $31.8 million, acknowledges that it more than doubled its money. (Those profits are atop the investment banking fees it made for advising National Gypsum to take on debt in the mid-1980's.) Trust Company of the West says it quadrupled its initial investment of $40 million or so. Fidelity has not divulged details but lawyers for the other creditors believe that it at least doubled a $30 million investment.
 
A Judge's Concern For Facts Not Known
The Federal judge who spent three years shepherding National Gypsum through bankruptcy has second thoughts about those results.
In a written opinion a year ago -- in which he was in the awkward position of arguing that his own judgment ought to be re-examined -- Judge Steven A. Felsenthal said he was concerned that the "very integrity" of the bankruptcy process might have been harmed by the possible concealment of work-force cuts intended to save $30 million a year.
Though he was "keenly sensitive" to the protection of jobs during the bankruptcy process, Judge Felsenthal wrote, "substantial work-force reductions were not presented to the court" when he was asked to confirm National Gypsum's reorganization plan.
During the bankruptcy, Judge Felsenthal had rejected arguments that the company was underestimating its value, saying there was no evidence to back up that claim. Had he known that the company would be announcing layoffs in October 1993, just three months after it emerged from his court, the case would have ended differently, Judge Felsenthal said in his January 1998 opinion.
The value of the company would have been greater, and "unpaid asbestos claimants and unpaid bondholders would have benefited," he wrote.
But Judge Felsenthal's ruling came on a narrow issue about the payment of certain legal fees. The fraud case is being argued in Texas state court, and there the disgruntled creditors' charges have been rejected. On March 1, David C. Godbey, a Texas district court judge, decided without much explanation to leave the outcome of the bankruptcy case essentially intact.
That is the decision that the asbestos trust fund and creditors who owned the junior bonds plan to appeal. They say the district court gave short shrift to evidence they discovered, largely over the last year, of a conspiracy to conceal the company's true financial value during the bankruptcy court proceedings.
"They walked away with $500 million of value that belonged to other people," said James R. Moriarty, a Houston lawyer who represents the junior bondholders. "These people have committed an outrageous fraud."
The defendants, however, argue that letting bankruptcies be reopened because events didn't turn out as some of the parties expected would destroy the system. "The consequences of permitting that second trial would indeed be devastating to the principle of finality of judgments," the lawyers wrote in their motion asking Judge Godbey to dismiss the case.
 
How Some Creditors Got Less of the Pie
It wasn't until late 1997 that the lawyers for the creditors began to piece together what they now contend took place behind the scenes of the bankruptcy case.
At a hearing before Judge Felsenthal, a lawyer for the company's former executives said the work-force reductions were not management's idea, but had come from consultants at Booz-Allen. That was the first that the plaintiffs' lawyers had heard of Booz-Allen's involvement. But with that lead, the lawyers subpoenaed Booz-Allen and obtained many key documents, including a plan prepared by Mr. Leonhardt.
When Mr. Leonhardt was confronted last fall with the discovery of the documents in his trash -- including spreadsheets that showed his estimates of the company's worth -- he said it was all an innocent mistake. He had no idea he had any relevant documents, he told the junior creditors' lawyers at his deposition; he was simply cleaning his closets, and the spreadsheets and other papers, which he did not even know he had, must have been in boxes he was tossing.
But the lawyers say they believe there are many more documents that the defendants should have turned over long ago.
"They've put up every conceivable obstacle to try to keep us from getting at the truth," Mr. Moriarty said. "Every single defendant has said they don't have the documents. It's all part of their plan."
Mr. Boren said in response, "It shouldn't surprise anybody that people who claim there's a conspiracy but can't find evidence of that then say there's a conspiracy to hide the evidence."
This is not the first time, however, that National Gypsum has been accused of being slow to produce crucial documents in a court proceeding. In June 1990, when the asbestos lawsuits hit a crescendo, the company lost a case filed by 52 Texas school districts that had bought its building products and wanted to be reimbursed for the cost of removing them.
In explaining his ruling, the Texas district court judge who decided the case said he was dismayed by evidence that National Gypsum had concealed or not produced documents that the schools had subpoenaed while preparing their case. Later, just before a subsequent trial was to begin, to decide how much money the Texas schools should get, the company filed for protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy code, stopping that trial and hundreds of similar lawsuits dead in their tracks.
By filing for bankruptcy, National Gypsum transferred the injury claims from the trial courts, where juries don't generally consider whether a company can afford to pay any damages they might award, to Federal bankruptcy court, where the priority is settling a company's debts so it can continue its operations.
At the end of the bankruptcy, a trust fund was set up to pay the asbestos claims. The company has contributed $138 million to the fund, while insurance companies have so far agreed to pay $380 million. But that money will not cover claims expected to reach $2.3 billion.
With the fund running out of money, asbestos-exposed workers who are not yet ill wonder what will be left for them.
"The doctors tell me sooner or later it's coming around," said Leroy Gilley, a retired boilermaker in Chickasaw, Ala., who spent four decades insulating boilers and has buried friends who died from lung disease. The trust fund should have money "until all the people are gone," he said.
The trust fund also was responsible for reimbursing property owners that had claims against the company. Because money is tight, that group has received less than half of the cost of their repairs. The biggest claimant, New York City's schools, sought about $44 million and have received $20 million, Mr. Hilton said.
 
A Profit Opportunity Not Widely Shared
Mr. Leonhardt has not been named as a defendant in any of the litigation, but his work is at the heart of what the angry creditors are calling fraud in the National Gypsum bankruptcy.
A consultant with more than 40 years of experience in the building and gypsum industries, he prepared an analysis -- never disclosed to Judge Felsenthal -- that concluded that National Gypsum was paying $40 million a year too much for costs associated with selling its products and operating its administrative offices.
The report by Mr. Leonhardt is significant because, while he was preparing it in 1992, the company's executives and other consultants hired by the investment firms were testifying in court that those costs could not be reduced and would instead rise with inflation by about 3 percent a year.
Days after Judge Felsenthal, relying on the testimony, approved National Gypsum's reorganization plan in April 1993, a series of private meetings about implementing a cost-cutting program began, according to documents obtained by the creditors' lawyers.
Attending the meetings were Mr. Leonhardt; Peter C. Browning, chief executive of National Gypsum, and two men whom Trust Company of the West hoped to place on National Gypsum's board: Richard Masson, a managing director of Trust Company of the West, and Vincent J. Naimoli, now an owner of baseball's Tampa Bay Devil Rays, who was then chief executive of Anchor Industries International.
According to an April 16, 1993, memo written by Mr. Browning, it was agreed on April 1 that National Gypsum would hire Booz-Allen to help determine which specific costs could be cut and which workers could be let go. On April 6, Mr. Browning wrote a memo informing employees of the company's decision to bring in the consultants.
Handwritten notes taken during the April meetings by John E. McGrath, a Booz-Allen consultant, indicate that one of the participants said the company could save as much as $40 million, or 50 percent of its selling, general and administrative costs. "30% to 50% SG&A can go!" he scribbled. His notes also say that there was an opportunity to increase the value of the company by $200 million to $600 million.
It was at this juncture, the junior creditors contend, that National Gypsum and the investment firms made a clear choice to hide their plans from the bankruptcy court. The accusers point to another passage in Mr. Browning's April 16 memo, in which he says that Booz-Allen's work needed to be delayed.
"Since it is felt by counsel that the project would require court approval at this stage," the memo says, "we have decided to postpone the initial phase" until either the company emerged from bankruptcy "or whenever we have reached a point where obtaining court approval would be more appropriate."
In a deposition, Mr. Browning testified that it was appropriate for the men -- all of whom expected to be directors of the new National Gypsum that would emerge from bankruptcy -- to begin talking about future plans for the company. But actually spending the money to hire Booz-Allen was a matter for the new company, which would not exist until July, he said.
Indeed, National Gypsum formally emerged from bankruptcy that July 1, without ever having informed the court of its dealings with Booz-Allen. The first announcement of the restructuring was made on Oct. 5, 1993, when the company announced that it was laying off 12 percent of its work force to save $30 million a year.
The news came just a month after a key legal deadline; the creditors had until Sept. 6 to ask Judge Felsenthal to revoke the company's reorganization plan if they suspected fraud.
Playing out the opportunity that the executives had envisioned, National Gypsum's cost-reduction plans delighted the stock market. In the week after the layoffs were announced, the stock rose 20 percent; by February 1994, the company's shares had hit $40 -- more than three times the $12.50 price at which they had been valued, at the urging of the company and investment funds, by the bankruptcy court. Gypsum prices were booming during the period, as well.
Lawyers for the disgruntled creditors estimate that the three investment firms would have turned their $295 million bankruptcy claim into $790 million if they held their stock until October 1995, when National Gypsum was acquired for $54 a share, or about $1.2 billion, by Delcor Inc., a private investment company led by National Gypsum's former chairman.
Not all the firms held the stock that long. The Justice Department required Goldman, Sachs to sell its 20 percent stake in November 1993 after Federal antitrust officials learned that Goldman's Water Street Fund also owned 43 percent of the USG Corporation, National Gypsum's largest competitor. Goldman made a profit of about $70 million on the deal, according to a deposition by Barry S. Volpert, who managed the National Gypsum investment for the Water Street Fund.
Lawyers for Goldman, Sachs said that because the firm sold its shares so quickly after National Gypsum emerged from bankruptcy, it could not have reaped any benefit even if there were a secret plan. They also said Goldman had intentionally taken no role in creating new business plans for National Gypsum because it knew it would have to sell its investment quickly.
Trust Company of the West held its stock longer; according to evidence obtained by the junior creditors' lawyers, the firm sold its stock and bonds, which had cost $40 million, piecemeal from 1993 to 1995 for $180 million.
Those numbers sting for people who haven't shared in the good fortune.
"The big money guys took care of themselves," said Jackie Fields, who owns a Phillips 66 distributorship in McAllen, Tex., and bought some of the company's money-losing junior bonds, "and left everybody else in the cold."

"A Building Products Bankruptcy"
National Gypsum's future has fallen and revived along with the market for its gypsum products. Here are some key points in the company's bankruptcy and its aftermath.
 
April 1986 -- National Gypsum's executives take the company private in a leveraged buyout with advice from Goldman, Sachs. The transaction increases the company's debt by hundreds of millions of dollars.
 
Oct. 29, 1990 -- National Gypsum files for bankruptcy protection as the price of gypsum falls and the company is buried in injury claims from people who have inhaled the asbestos fibers in its building products.
 
Late 1990 to 1992 -- Fidelity, Trust Company of the West and Goldman buy the company's senior debt at cheap prices and become the company's most powerful creditors.
 
Spring 1992 -- The three big investment firms decide to break away from the other creditors, hire their own lawyer and work toward getting the court to approve a reorganization plan that benefits their interests.
 
Fall 1992 -- A bankruptcy committee representing all creditors except the three investment firms says it believes that the company is intentionally understating its value in documents filed with the bankruptcy court.
 
December 1992 -- Harry J. Leonhardt, a consultant, completes a written plan that says National Gypsum is spending $40 million too much on selling and administrative costs. He gives copies to Trust Company of the West and Fidelity.
 
1993
 
March 9 -- Bankruptcy Judge Steven A. Felsenthal approves the reorganization plan presented by the company and the three investment firms.
 
April 1 -- The company's chief executive, Mr. Leonhardt and two representives of Trust Company of the West agree to hire Booz-Allen & Hamilton to implement a cost reduction plan.
 
April 14 -- Booz-Allen consultants prepare a letter stating they plan to begin work on April 19.
 
April 16 -- In a letter, Mr. Browning says that the company's lawyer believes the Booz-Allen project would need court approval and that the work therefore will be delayed.
 
July 1 -- National Gypsum emerges from bankruptcy protection.
 
Oct. 5 -- The company announces that it is cutting its workforce to save $30 million a year. Within a week, the stock rises 20 percent.
 
1995 -- Creditors file a lawsuit against the company's former executives charging that National Gypsum and its financial advisers hid the cost-cutting plan from the bankruptcy court. The investment firms later are added as defendants.
 
Jan. 21, 1998 -- In a written opinion, Judge Felsenthal says that the company's value would have been greater -- and that smaller creditors would have received more money -- had he known about the job cuts before National Gypsum left his court.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
The Perilsof Investing On Automatic Pilot

BYLINE: By GRETCHEN MORGENSON

 BODY:
WHILE stock investors applauded the Dow Jones industrial average's assault this week on another nice round number -- 11,000 -- it is likely that few of them were participating in the profits. That's because most investors have money in stocks listed not in the Dow but in the Standard & Poor's 500, which has risen only half as much as the Dow this year.
Proving that no investment trend lasts forever, the S.& P. is now the laggard after years of beating the Dow. And this is occurring just as mutual funds that mimic the S.& P.'s moves have been flooded with money. 
 The turnabout reflects a shift in sentiment among some investors that began about two weeks ago. Sensing a revival of economic growth around the world, investors plunged into stocks of industrial companies, like paper, steel, cement and chemical concerns, seeing them as likely beneficiaries of the recovery. At the same time, investors started to exit the technology and health care stocks that had made the S.& P. a star.
Unlike the Dow, which is weighted by its stocks' prices, the S.& P. 500 is weighted by its stocks' market capitalizations.
What does this mean for investors? Just as the impressive performance of the S.& P. has masked a bear market in many smaller stocks since last summer, its current malaise masks a bull market in stocks with lower market caps, which are not big contributors to it.
Stefan D. Abrams, chief investment officer of asset allocation at Trust Company of the West in New York, said investors should prepare for a stealth bull market. "The averages will be in a trading range," he said. "But within the confines of that trading range there will be wonderful moves in stocks that will not show up in the indexes."
This is already happening. Shares of Dow Chemical, for example, rose 40.8 percent in April. But because it is such a tiny component of the S.& P. -- 0.267 percent of the index's value -- its rise has had little impact on the 500. Microsoft, with a weighting of 3.77 percent, fell 9.6 percent in April, producing a significant impact.
The S.& P. is vulnerable because it is dominated by the companies investors have been selling in recent weeks. Technology and health care companies account for 19 percent and 12 percent of the index's value, respectively. In contrast, chemical companies make up 1.9 percent of the index; paper and forest products account for 0.6 percent, and aluminum concerns represent 0.3 percent. Because these stocks make tiny contributions to the S.& P., as they have surged, the index has shrugged.
It may be premature to say that the era of momentum investing is over. But buying what has been going up is no longer working. Even the Russell 2000 index of small-capitalization stocks, left for dead in recent months, was up 8.8 percent in April, versus the S.& P.'s 3.8 percent rise.
Jeffrey M. Warantz, an equity strategist at Salomon Smith Barney, reports that even the tiniest stocks have improved. While companies with less than $250 million in market value were, on average, down 6.7 percent for the year in early April, they are now down only 1.6 percent.
All of this is very positive for investors whose holdings are diversified among small stocks and large, value and growth. It is not good news for those who have placed all their eggs in the S.& P. 500 basket.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 7; Column 2; Money and Business/Financial Desk

LENGTH: 762 words

HEADLINE: New Formula Yes. But Is It Improved?

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr.

 BODY:
A LOT of diversification-minded investors are gravitating toward a group of indexed stock mutual funds that may seem a far wiser choice than the familiar version tied to the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index.
The funds, called total market funds, track several thousand stocks to mimic the spectrum of American securities, not just a chosen 500 of the biggest companies. Though the retail assets in such funds are still relatively small, at $11.1 billion versus $116.3 billion in S. & P. 500 index funds, they have grown more than 14-fold percent since 1994, when only the Vanguard Group had such an offering. 
 Some experts, in fact, see total market funds as a kind of all-in-one solution for investors' stock fund needs, giving them exposure to all kinds of equities -- large and small, value and growth. And they have rock-bottom expenses, too. But this is where investors can go wrong, because the easiest tack is not always the best.
Investors flocking to total market funds, which track the Wilshire 5000 index, may not be aware of the funds' limitations.
There is no denying the growing popularity of total market funds, helped by well-publicized endorsements of the Wilshire 5000 by the likes of John C. Bogle, senior chairman of Vanguard, and Burton G. Malkiel, the Princeton economics professor and author of "A Random Walk Down Wall Street" (W. W. Norton).
"I now believe the best general United States index to emulate is the broader Wilshire 5000-stock index -- not the S.& P. 500," Professor Malkiel said in the book.
The biggest and longest-established of this handful of funds is the Vanguard Total Stock Market Index fund, which began in 1992 and now has more than $10 billion in assets. Newer entries are Fidelity Spartan Total Market Index, the T. Rowe Price Total Equity Market Index and, since Feb. 1, Wilshire Associates' own version, the Wilshire 5000 Index Portfolio.
The appeal of such funds is based on a major failing of the S. & P. 500: that it contains only large companies and is weighted by capitalization so that the biggest stocks have undue influence.
When examined, however, the Wilshire 5000 -- now expanded to include all 7,200-plus publicly traded companies headquartered in the United States with readily available prices -- has a weight problem, too. Like the S. & P. 500, it is weighted by market capitalization, so there is not as big a difference between the two as one might expect.
In fact, as much as 80 percent of the Wilshire's value is in companies that are also part of the S. & P. 500. This striking overlap means that an investor who may think he is getting stakes in a healthy portion of small and midsize companies is actually looking at a quite meager side dish.
Today, with the price-to-earnings ratios of many big stocks in the stratosphere, risk-conscious investors may conclude that such indexing still gives them an uncomfortably large exposure to expensive stocks.
Indeed, the two kinds of index funds track each other closely: Vanguard Total Stock Market has returned 19.9 percent annually on average from its inception seven years ago through April 23, versus 21.4 percent for the Vanguard Index 500, according to Morningstar Inc., the Chicago financial publisher.
A BETTER idea may be allocating assets to put more emphasis on mid-cap and small-cap index funds, thereby balancing the risks of stocks with high P/ E ratios against those whose valuations are less exalted. That is something you cannot do in a total market fund.
Of course, an investor with a total market fund, or some combination of benchmark-linked funds, has indexed all his assets. What's wrong with that? While it is accepted that indexing makes sense for large-cap stocks, the jury is still out on indexing when it comes to smaller issues.
Consider the 18.9 percent average annual return of the S. & P. 500 for the 10 years ended March 31. That beat every category of general equity fund over the period, according to Lipper Inc., the research firm in Summit, N.J. But the average small-cap fund returned an average of 13.6 percent annually over the same period, handily beating the 9.7 percent average of the Russell 2000 index of small-cap companies.
(The average mid-cap fund returned 14.6 percent, annualized, over the 10 years, versus 17.4 percent for the S. & P. 400 index of mid-cap stocks).
The lesson: A total market index fund is a good core holding. But if you choose it as an all-in-one substitute for a genuinely diversified set of stock-market assets, you are likely to pay for the convenience.

HEADLINE: Political Muscle: The Only Good Enemy is a Strong/Weak Enemy;
Straining To See the Real Russia

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES 

DATELINE: MOSCOW

 BODY:
BELIEVE it: The Russians are hopping mad. For 8, 10 years now, they followed American advice on how to become capitalists. They swallowed American foreign-policy handouts urging that Russia be "integrated into Euro-Atlantic and global communities" and built into "a modern, market-based economy." They gave up on empire, cut up their missiles and ceded three of their clients to NATO. And for what? More than $60 billion in new debt. A beggar, rubber-ruble economy. A skeletal military. A short leash held tight by the International Monetary Fund. And now, the leveling of their one remaining friend in all Europe, Yugoslavia.
Last week Washington came back again, beseeching Moscow to help cut a deal to end the Kosovo crisis, and Russians wonder why. Most of them now believe Washington gives lip service to free markets and global partnership, but is secretly just as happy -- no, happier -- to have Ivan face-down on the floor at last, one arm behind his back. 
 Could they be right?
Well, no, not literally. It is easy to argue that America has fumbled its policy of promoting a healthy, democratic Russia, though the Russians have fumbled plenty all by themselves. Few would make the case that, in the long run, the United States would not benefit from a prosperous Russia that shares at least some of its basic values.
But there's the rub: Nobody knows what Russia will be in the long run. Russia may have lost a cold war. But as the last eight years have shown, it is no postwar Germany or Japan, no vanquished foe to be occupied and rebuilt in the American image. Quite the opposite: The Russia that re-emerged from hibernation this spring seems at times almost gleefully anti-American and, yearning for empire, is considering new unions with Belarus and Yugoslavia itself. If Russia is the country it seemed to be for 10 years after the fall of Communism -- a nation struggling to grow into a modern democracy -- then the West has a long-term stake in its success. But if the real Russia is instead the seething fury visible on the nightly news, the glory-mongering defender of murderous hypernationalism, then its success looms fearsomely as a threat.
So the United States thinks of Russia mostly in the short run. And even in the short run, it's not easy to noodle out whether America's interests are best served by a Russia that is robust, or one that is weak. For undeniably, Russia's current sallow state has given the United States license to act in ways that would have been unthinkable a decade ago, when two superpowers bestrode the world.
The steady drip-drip of bombing runs by American jets over Iraq would be far riskier were Russia able to bolster its old ally, Saddam Hussein, or wield more clout in the United Nations Security Council.
Russia's decline has shifted the balance of power further toward America in the Middle East. It has opened potentially strategic oil deposits in Russia's Caspian Sea backyard to American companies, and spawned a game of pipeline-building politics in which the effect of American policy -- and even perhaps the intent -- is to weaken Russia's influence with other members of the former Soviet Union.
Last weekend's declaration by NATO that the alliance had broadened its mission to battling proliferation and genocide outside its borders would have been impossible were Russia a force in world affairs.
Indeed, the Russians complain bitterly, they acquiesced to NATO's absorption of Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic this year only after being assured that the alliance was fundamentally defensive -- and that Russia would have a voice, if not a veto, in its policies.
Yugoslavia, of course, is the marquee example, the epitome of the American policy conundrum -- and the sum of all Russia's fears. Does a weak Russia serve American interests? Absolutely. Russians are furious over NATO's decision to intervene in what they see as a civil war. They are even more furious over Washington's turning a deaf ear to their objections -- indeed, over the decision to authorize bombing as Prime Minister Yevgeny M. Primakov was crossing the Atlantic to meet President Clinton.
But would a stronger Russia serve American interests? The United States seems to believe so; bogged down after 40 days of bombing, Washington and its NATO allies have embraced Moscow as the best hope for getting the Yugoslav strong man Slobodan Milosevic to the bargaining table.
Russians are exquisitely sensitive to the contrast. Western leaders support Russia's mediation of the crisis "for a very simple reason -- they want to convince Russia to put pressure on Milosevic to make him accept NATO's ultimatum, in order to stop the military action and say that NATO has won," Alexei G. Arbatov, the deputy chairman of the defense committee in Russia's lower house of parliament, said at a seminar last week. "This is not a request for Russia to facilitate the peace process. This is pressure on Russia."
From the American perspective, ignoring a weakened Russia now seems cost-free. Sure, Moscow still has 7,000 nuclear warheads, but nobody thinks that even the craziest Russian nationalist is about to fire them. But there's a long run in Russia, too, and a Moscow that sees the United States as its enemy can play some cards, from weapons proliferation to cozying up to China. Nor can anyone assume that Russia, with more oil than anyplace, will always be a beggar.
Dmitri K. Simes, a leading scholar of Russia who is president of the Nixon Institute, a Washington-based foreign policy research organization, says he understands why Moscow feels used. In his view, the United States sincerely wanted to enlist Russia as a strategic partner, but its decision to hang its entire policy on President Boris N. Yeltsin and his team of reformers -- even as Mr. Yeltsin became more autocratic and unpopular and the reforms were eaten away by corruption -- left precisely the opposite impression.
"And when these individuals and those policies all collapsed in August of '98," Mr. Simes said, "I think the Administration found itself without a policy -- with a lot of frustration, with an absence of new ideas and, if you wish, a perverse sense of satisfaction that if Russia didn't quite live up to the Administration's expectations, at a minimum they were in such a mess that they didn't have to take them seriously.
"I think the Russians have sensed that on a variety of issues -- Iraq, Kosovo, arms transfers, Caspian pipelines. On all those issues, the Administration is talking about partnership, but in each case its idea of partnership is that Russia would walk in lockstep with Administration policies."
Militarily and politically enfeebled, Russia has swallowed hard and accepted American policy on many of those issues -- even in Kosovo, where Russia basically supported United States positions in the United Nations. But on the other hand, Mr. Simes said, "there's a difference between impotence and acceptance of American policies."
It is with Yugoslavia that that difference, long concealed under a veneer of Russian-American cooperation, has burst into view.
"This is a clash of civilizations," Alexei Podberezkin, the deputy chairman of the foreign affairs committee of the Russian parliament's lower house, said last week. "They offer us an aggressive and virtually Protestant model of democracy -- no, they impose it on us. What is happening in Yugoslavia and what happened in Bosnia and Croatia is an attempt to impose the Western understanding of values, including democratic ones. But Russia may have other values -- cultural, historical and democratic."
Leonid N. Dobrokhotov, a former aide at the Communist Party Central Committee in the 1980's and now an adviser to the party's chairman, Gennady Zyuganov, put it more elegantly in an interview last week.
"As a result of the actions in Yugoslavia, we've again found our natural enemy," he said. "The problem isn't Milosevic. This is a geopolitical problem."
More and more Russians agree, which underscores one of the dangers of short-run policies: Strung end to end, they become the long run. Some Russians now argue -- and Mr. Simes said he fears -- that with Yugoslavia, American policy toward Russia may have crossed that divide.

HEADLINE: PERSONAL BUSINESS: DIARY;
They Might Even Meet Alan Greenspan Himself

BYLINE: By MICHAEL BRICK

 BODY:
It comes as no surprise that teen-agers would love to meet the Chicago Bulls or the Spice Girls. But how about shaking hands with members of the Federal Open Market Committee? Well, for high school students in the final rounds today and tomorrow of the Fed Challenge, a sort of monetary-policy bee for budding macroeconomists, the committee has star power.
Teams in the finals, held each year in Washington, typically portray members of the committee, which sets the nation's monetary policy in discussions of financial conditions and debates over whether to adjust interest rates. Then the teams are grilled by judges recruited by the Federal Reserve, which runs the event. 
 The students' knowledge sometimes amazes the judges. Lloyd Bromberg, director of educational programs for the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, who has been a judge for the contest in the past, recalled one contestant who quoted from an arcane report by the Fed bank in Kansas City, Mo. "The judges looked to each other and said, 'I didn't read that article,' " Mr. Bromberg said.
Now in its fifth year, the contest shows evidence of changing the way economics is taught. Several high schools around the country offer college-credit courses that prepare students for the Fed Challenge, according to Federal Reserve officials. A powerful incentive is the prize money, provided by Citigroup: a $40,000 grant for the winning school, a $10,000 scholarship for each of the five members of its team and $10,000 for their teacher.
This year's finalists will meet some members of the committee they have studied and portrayed -- and perhaps an even bigger monetary star. It's not certain yet whether the Fed chairman, Alan Greenspan, will be there this year, but Mr. Bromberg said that in 1997, the students "lit up," when Mr. Greenspan appeared to award the trophy. MICHAEL BRICK

HEADLINE: DataBank: April 26-30;
An Off-Key Finale for a Spectacular April

BYLINE: By MICKEY MEECE

 BODY:
The Dow Jones industrial average ended the last day of April with a whimper, suffering its biggest loss of the month on concerns the economy was growing too fast, threatening to hasten inflation and cause interest rates to rise.
 But over the month, the Dow did not go quietly: it rose 10 percent, crossing the 10,000 milestone; set 13 new highs, and flirted with 11,000 before closing at 10,789.04 on Friday. 
 In the first four months of the year, the Dow added 18 percent, surpassing what it gained for all of 1998.
 It has been one of the most spectacular months ever for the Dow, Scott Bleier, chief market strategist for Prime Charter Ltd., told Reuters on Friday.
 Investors jumped on inflationary fears and the month's end as reasons to take profits. When you consider the market has risen almost 1,000 points in the past four weeks, investors have a good excuse to sit back and enjoy some of their recent winnings, Charles Crane, market strategist at Key Asset Management, told The Associated Press on Friday.
 In Europe, markets ended the week higher, with a 1.93 percent rise in London and a 3.3 percent increase in Paris and Frankfurt. MICKEY MEECE

SECTION: Section 4; Page 1; Column 5; Week in Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1633 words

HEADLINE: Political Muscle: The Only Good Enemy is a Strong/Weak Enemy;
When Allies Are Fierce Competitors

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
LATE in the day on April 6, Energy Secretary Bill Richardson showed up at the White House with some bad news for President Clinton: The leakage of nuclear secrets from America's weapons labs was far worse than anyone thought. The Chinese -- whose Prime Minister was on his way to Washington -- may have obtained computer codes that are the key ingredient for simulating nuclear weapons explosions.
It was the kind of chilling discovery that would make for a good Washington thriller. But real life is more complex. In a speech the next morning, Mr. Clinton said Americans do indeed have reason to worry about China, but not only a muscular China with the latest weapons technology. Americans have as much to fear, he argued, from a weak China whose ailing banks and bankrupt enterprises could undermine the world economy. 
 "If we've learned anything in the last few years from Japan's long recession and Russia's current economic troubles, it is that the weaknesses of great nations can pose as big a challenge to America as their strengths," Mr. Clinton said. "So as we focus on the potential challenge that a strong China could present to the United States in the future, let us not forget the risk of a weak China, beset by internal conflicts, social dislocation and criminal activity, becoming a vast zone of instability in Asia."
It was the starkest moment yet in what has emerged as the central foreign policy conundrum in Washington: In an age when your military adversary can also rank among your biggest trading partners, and when your military allies double as your fiercest economic competitors, does America want weak global neighbors or strong ones?
That question is increasingly the subtext of daily debate here, fracturing the Democratic and Republican parties across unusual lines, trapping lawmakers and pundits in circular arguments about where America's true interests lie. It helps account for the crazy-quilt of American foreign policy. And the problem is made more complex by the fact that the world stage is crowded by weak states -- countries that are jockeying for global influence while struggling to keep from drowning in debt, self-doubt and rising unemployment.
The Japanese, once masters of the art of converting old-fashioned capital into political capital, have watched their global influence decline faster than the price of an office building in the Ginza. While Russia tries to flex old muscles in the Balkans, it is submitting to the humiliation of having the International Monetary Fund micro-manage its economy. (Last week, spurred by fears that Moscow is feeling dangerously alienated from the West, the I.M.F. finally committed to $4.5 billion in new loans for the nearly insolvent Government, just enough to stave off national default for another year or so.)
The Chinese spies who may be tinkering with the nuclear codes are probably thankful for the fact that, unlike millions of others who toil for the state, their jobs are going to be around for a while. And then there are the Europeans, who are slogging through a war in Yugoslavia just at the moment that their economies are slowing and their new currency, the Euro, has fallen 10 percent. This was supposed to be the year the continent focused on becoming the next great economic superpower, linked by a single currency and a huge market. Instead, one European finance minister visiting Washington last week moaned, "We're spending all our political energy on a 600-year-old problem."
"It's an extraordinary moment that perhaps we haven't seen since the '20's, or at least since the days of the Marshall Plan," said Kenneth Courtis, the chief Asian economist for Deutsche Bank. "You have the world economy flying on one engine -- the United States. And almost everyone else is dealing from a weak hand."
You would think this would leave Washington filled with joy, and often it does. After all, that single engine still has its afterburners lit: The Government reported Friday an astounding 4.5 percent annual growth rate in the first quarter, once again beating virtually every forecast. It's hard to imagine any country threatening America's sole-superpower status for decades. It's even harder to recall that only a decade ago Washington was still preoccupied with Japan's buying spree in Hollywood and on Wall Street, and wringing its hands about the successes of Asian-style capitalism. But the celebration of American supremacy sometimes obscures the far more complex risks of managing world affairs amid global economic and political fragility. And the truth is that Washington is still a lot more comfortable containing an easily identifiable enemy than managing a system where cracks on one side of the globe can radiate to the other.
Part of the problem is that weakness comes in many forms. There is Russian-style weakness, an inability of the state machinery to make the country function, to keep control. Whatever temporary pleasure Americans derived from watching the Russian military threat fall apart has been tempered by the fear that economic chaos has put its nuclear expertise up for sale. "During the cold war we knew that Russia's nukes were under strict control, but we were terrified of the people controlling them," said Michael Mandelbaum, a Johns Hopkins University professor who has written about the new challenges of managing a global system in which leaders are overwhelmed by the forces around them. "Now the fear about Russia is that nothing is under anyone's clear control -- not the taxation system and not the atomic-industrial complex."
And then there is Japanese-style weakness, a subject President Clinton will be carefully dancing around on Monday as Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi arrives for an official visit. In Tokyo the problem isn't a collapsing state; it's a chronic inability to get political consensus, whether the issue is bolstering security in Asia or remaking the world's second-largest economy.
Mr. Obuchi will be arriving with the news that the lower house of Parliament has finally passed legislation that would allow it, in theory, to act like a real ally of American forces should a military emergency break out in the Pacific. But the bill was stripped of several key elements, including one that would let Tokyo participate in enforcing international sanctions, and the Pentagon still fears that if North Korea lashes out, Japan may sit on its hands.
OF more immediate concern is whether Japan's seven-year recession is finally ending, as the Japanese insist. If not, Japan's troubles could choke off Asia's fragile recovery and force the United States to continue taking in a wildly disproportionate amount of the world's exports. Sooner or later, that will cost American jobs, which is why Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin warned again last week that America's soaring trade deficits are "not politically sustainable." But in Japan's case, as in Russia's, Washington has few levers to pull.
In fact, Washington is never quite sure with whom it should be negotiating. Mr. Obuchi has scant control over the pace of Japanese reforms. That power is in the hands of the country's scared corporate heads, its much-criticized bureaucrats and its workers, who are terrified by the rising unemployment rate and know that they have few options if they lose their job.
If Boris N. Yeltsin was once committed to reforming the Russian economy, he has given it up. It is notable that ever since Russia's currency devaluation and default on some of its debt last August, the Clinton Administration has cut back on providing free advice about the wonders of making the transition to a market economy. "It would only stoke their resentments further," one senior State Department official said. "We're wiser to shut up about reform."
But at least there is some agreement in Washington that a stronger Japan and an economically stable Russia are in the country's interests. Raise the subject of China, and it's a different story. On Capitol Hill these days, China is once again a power to be contained.
The revelations of nuclear espionage bolster the arguments of conservatives who say the Clinton Administration has been blinded by big business and big donors, and that it buried the evidence of transgressions at Los Alamos because they threatened the policy of engagement. Add their voices to those of human rights groups who are horrified by China's recent crackdowns, unions that fear trade deals, and Taiwan supporters who want more protection from the mainland's missiles.
At the other end of the spectrum are Mr. Clinton and many of America's China experts, who see 100 million jobless wandering the Chinese countryside, failing state-owned enterprises and insolvent banks that -- at the Government's insistence -- keep those enterprises afloat. And there are Russia-like symptoms: arms proliferation, the rising power of organized crime, a military in business for itself.
The theory of integrating China into the World Trade Organization -- the deal President Clinton walked away from earlier this month -- is that it would help the Chinese pull off the feat that the Russians couldn't. It would force China to deal in a Western legal system, to open up, to let a billion Web users bloom.
A nice theory, but the reality is that Washington wants China, like Russia, to be strong on Washington's terms. Washington wants to encourage Chinese economic strength and discourage military strength; it wants nations to independently find their own way to a market economy -- as long as it runs strictly according to Western rules. In short, Washington wants strong economies run by leaders who will shrink their military power and act weakly beyond their borders. But Washington is not likely to get what it wants.

LENGTH: 940 words

HEADLINE: Final Return Of the Canal Colors Vote In Panama

BYLINE: By MIREYA NAVARRO 

DATELINE: PANAMA, May 1

 BODY:
The "Trautenbels," a 484-foot cargo ship, was ushered from the Pacific Ocean into the Panama Canal by tugboats, and by two electric towing locomotives into a water lane. Steel gates snapped shut, enclosing the ship in a chamber, inside which it was lifted by rising water, a process repeated twice more at different points for a voyage up to 85 feet above sea level, across mountains now flooded by artificial lakes.
Up close, the Panama Canal is a fascinating feat of engineering, an American-made 50-mile passage that carries more than 13,000 ships and 190 million tons of cargo a year between two oceans and that, this year, the United States will relinquish to Panama -- along with about $4 billion worth of property. 
 The canal and the prospects for an economic boom based on the property Panama will inherit are by far the most important issue looming over Sunday's presidential election, a contest between the son of Gen. Omar Torrijos, who negotiated the Panama Canal Treaty with President Carter in 1977, and the widow of a President ousted by the General. The winner, whose tenure is limited to one five-year term, will preside over the Dec. 31 handover.
The canal is so hallowed that the candidates, locked in a tight race, agreed that it could not be the subject of electoral mudslinging.
But it is Panamanians' fervent desire to use the handover to help eradicate high unemployment and poverty rates and help this country of 2.8 million people toward a brighter future.
The next administration faces the challenge of disposing of the valuable real estate the United States is leaving and replacing the jobs and income earned from the American bases, which has run to as much as $350 million a year. It must also operate the canal, which brings about $545 million a year in tolls, oversee its expansion and prevent deforestation of the watershed.
Polls showed the election to be a close match. In Panama's clique-ridden politics, Martin Torrijos, a 35-year-old, is trading heavily on the memory of his father, who died in a 1981 plane crash. And his opponent, 52-year-old Mireya Moscoso, is the widow of Dr. Arnulfo Arias, who was elected President three times only to be deposed by the military each time, the last just days after taking office in 1968, in the military coup that installed Gen. Torrijos.
Although both have been active in the political scene in the 90's, each has sparse experience in government. Their political platforms have broad similarities. Both oppose privatization of certain services and promise honest government.
Mr. Torrijos has served as Deputy Minister of Government and Justice for the current President, Ernesto Perez Balladares, and is the candidate of the governing Democratic Revolutionary Party.
Both Panamanians and Americans have fears that future Governments may divert canal money for their own benefit, and Mr. Balladares did little to assuage them when he packed the Panama Canal Authority, the agency that is supposed to govern the canal's operations starting next year, with relatives and cronies. Leaders of the governing party have also been allowed to rent, with an option to buy below market value, some of the best of the reverting properties.
Public outrage over the actions was cited here among the factors leading voters last September to reject a constitutional amendment to allow him to serve a second term.
Since the Panama Canal was completed in 1914, the bulk of its revenue has usually been invested in maintenance and modernization. While the handover of the 569-square mile American canal zone has been seamless so far -- 95 percent of its more than 7,000 employees are Panamanian, working under a Panamanian administrator -- there is great uncertainty about the fate of the valuable property that comes with it.
Only about 4,000 Americans, mostly Army and Air Force personnel, remain of the 10,000 military personnel once stationed here. When they leave at the end of the year, Panama will be left with the task of somehow transforming the American military's property into the centerpiece of a longed-for bonanza.
If all goes according to the plans, or dreams, then barracks, hospitals, schools, airstrips, churches, houses, offices and manicured lawns will become private housing, hotels, a university, sports centers, and industrial parks at the center of an envisaged export boom.
Already, $1 billion has been invested by Panama and other countries, from Spain to Taiwan, mostly in tourism and maritime-related services, Panamanian officials say. The old School of the Americas, for instance, where Latin American military officers trained, is turning into a luxury hotel. Part of the Albrook Air Force Station has been sold to American former canal workers for a retirement community of 147 families.
But most of the really valuable property -- nine military bases -- will only be transferred over the next eight months. The future of that real estate hinges on the ability of Panama to attract more investors, said Nicolas Ardito Barletta, administrator of Interoceanic Region Authority, created in 1993 to manage the property reverting to Panama.
"The property is going to be worth what we make it produce," Mr. Barletta said. Some properties that have already reverted are fallow and deteriorating, even as others are being developed.
Besides the economic questions posed by the handover, some Panamanians worry about losing the American military, whose presence has served as a deterrent against incursions by Colombian guerrillas. Now, the border with Colombia will be guarded only by police, for Panama has no army.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 16; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 865 words

HEADLINE: The Logic of Kosovo

 BODY:
Slobodan Milosevic's promise yesterday to release three captive American soldiers suggests that he may now be looking to end the war in Yugoslavia. But unless a diplomatic settlement materializes quickly, the war could well extend through the spring, if not beyond. As the American people brace for a sustained military campaign, they deserve a clearer account of America's goals from President Clinton and of how the national interest would be served by achieving them. Anyone who doubts the demand for a compelling rationale for the war need look no further than the House of Representatives, which last week stunned Washington by refusing on a tie vote to support the NATO air offensive.
Though partisan maneuvering by the Republicans was partly responsible for the unfortunate outcome, the deadlocked House was a symbol of national ambivalence that Mr. Clinton cannot afford to ignore. The problem is not that Mr. Clinton has failed to outline military and political objectives for Kosovo. He has done so in some detail. But he has so far failed to connect those aims with larger American interests in a way that convinces a majority of his countrymen that war with Mr. Milosevic is warranted and may have to be waged for months. 
 After 40 days of bombing, the military and political picture in Kosovo has changed in ways that the White House and NATO did not fully anticipate. As a result, some clarification and redefinition of purpose are required.
One of the original objectives of the air war -- protecting the ethnic Albanians in Kosovo from Serbian aggression -- has proved unattainable. Each day brings a new wave of bedraggled refugees to Albania and Macedonia, and with them stories of unspeakable abuses and killing by the Serbian forces. Gen. Wesley Clark, the NATO commander, has acknowledged that alliance missiles and bombs cannot stop the bloodletting. Even if NATO wanted to send a ground force into Kosovo, which it does not, it would take two or three months to assemble the troops and weapons, more than enough time for Mr. Milosevic to finish his ethnic cleansing.
That unpleasant fact means that this war is now being fought primarily over the future of Kosovo, a cause that is harder to define and more difficult to sell to Americans than the defense of innocent civilians under brutal attack. It is also a cause that will be difficult, though not necessarily impossible, to advance with air power alone.
The goals Mr. Clinton has enunciated for Kosovo are honorable and desirable. They include the return of the refugees, the restoration of a high degree of political autonomy for Kosovo and the creation of a secure environment in which Serbian forces could no longer threaten ethnic Albanians.
To gain the support of the country, Mr. Clinton has to place those aims in a broader framework. We believe that freedom, human rights and the preservation of a civilized society are critical principles bound up in the conflict in Kosovo, and that Mr. Milosevic's effort to drive the Balkans into a new dark age must be resisted. While Serbia does not present a military threat to the rest of Europe, and unlike Iraq cannot impede the flow of oil, its genocidal assault on Kosovo cannot go unanswered.
With the cold war over, the country needs to devise a new calculus for determining when its security is threatened and the use of force is warranted. Kosovo is a test case. If the United States and its NATO allies are prepared to let a tyrant in the Balkans slaughter his countrymen and overrun his neighbors with hundreds of thousands of refugees, other combustible regions of Europe may face similar upheavals. History teaches that instability in Europe inevitably hurts the United States, and can produce larger conflicts.
Just how Washington and its allies defend these interests in the Balkans will depend on military and diplomatic developments in the weeks ahead. The application of air power, which is now crippling the Serbian economy, may be forcing Mr. Milosevic to seek peace. The bombing must be given time to work. The option of an invasion should be kept open, if only to pressure Mr. Milosevic.
Release of the prisoners to the Rev. Jesse Jackson would be a welcome gesture by Mr. Milosevic. The Clinton Administration, with the assistance of Russia, which is now trying to broker a peace deal, should look for ways to build on Belgrade's apparent interest in containing, if not ending, the conflict. While Mr. Clinton's peace terms should shape a settlement, there may be space within them to work out an accord. NATO has already offered more flexible terms for a cease-fire and Mr. Milosevic has given a little ground on allowing peacekeepers in Kosovo when the war ends. Moscow's apparent readiness to back an armed international peacekeeping force in Kosovo can help advance diplomacy, as can Mr. Milosevic's willingness to accept some kind of United Nations role in the province.
But whatever course Mr. Clinton chooses, the country must be satisfied it is worth the sacrifices that may be required. If Mr. Clinton hopes to prevail in Kosovo, he will first have to secure the support of the American people and of Congress.
