SECTION: Section 1; Page 16; Column 1; Foreign Desk 

LENGTH: 1460 words

HEADLINE: CRISIS IN THE BALKANS: THE NEIGHBORHOOD;
Front-Line Hungary Feels Anxiety

BYLINE: By JOHN TAGLIABUE 

DATELINE: BUDAPEST, May 1

 BODY:
At night, Attila Chikan's mother, a woman in her 70's whose generation recalls World War II, hears the bombers over Yugoslavia, even though, her son says, "from where she lives, it's physically impossible."
For the generation of Mr. Chikan, 55, Hungary's Economics Minister, the war over Kosovo is a sharp contrast to memories of vacations in Yugoslavia in the 1970's, when Tito's reform Communism inspired restless young Hungarian economists. 
 The minister, a professor of economics, is also in touch with students. That generation, he said, "doesn't understand the war, from the point of view of rationality."
In less than a decade, Hungary has gone from a front-line member of the old Warsaw Pact in a cold war to being a front-line state in NATO's first hot war, and the experience is straining the nation of 10 million -- politically, economically, militarily, and individually.
This week, the first NATO tankers began flying from Hungary, and attack aircraft will soon use its air bases for their sorties. A sense of anxiety hangs over Hungary, a sense of support but not enthusiasm for the war, and even that is not felt uniformly through the generations of a nation that persistently finds itself sitting astride the fault line between East and West.
The war erupted less than two weeks after Hungary, Poland and the Czech Republic joined NATO. Hungary's willingness to aid the war effort has angered Russia, its former ally. A visit to Moscow by the Hungarian Foreign Minister was canceled and Moscow recalled its Ambassador for consultations.
The war threatens the Hungarian economy, which only recently began recovering from the financial shock of last year's Russian economic meltdown and which is faced with slowing growth in western Europe, now its major trade partner.
Hungary, its people are quick to point out, is the only NATO state bordering Yugoslavia, and there are misgivings over the fate of the Hungarian minority in Serbia's Vojvodina region, north of Belgrade. Vojvodina Hungarians, some fleeing military conscription in Yugoslavia, others uncomfortable with the regime of President Slobodan Milosevic, are fleeing to Hungary.
They are joined by a wave of Serbs, not impoverished masses like many of the Albanians from Kosovo who have flooded Albania and Macedonia, but middle class people and members of the political opposition, disillusioned after years of peaceful dissent as much by NATO's bombs as by Mr. Milosevic.
Sztojan Vujicsics, a Hungarian writer of Serbian descent (in some of his writings he uses the Serbian spelling of his name, Stojan Vujicic), said Hungarians are intent on fulfilling their obligations to NATO. "But they don't want to destroy Serbian-Hungarian relations, which are very ancient," he said. "The war will end, with all its consequences. But neighbors are neighbors, and we will continue living here."
After five weeks of air strikes, with NATO appearing to stumble politically and militarily, he said, "a dilemma is arising both among intellectuals and the common people."
"There is rising anxiousness," he added.
Like many in this corner of Europe, Mr. Vujicsics' family reflects Hungary's complex historical weave. In the 17th century, his forebears fled Turkish expansion in Serbia. Ever since, his family has remained here, in the heart of a sizable Serbian community. Now he welcomes the latest wave of refugees.
Otto Horvath is the son of Hungarians from Novi Sad, in northern Yugoslavia. Shortly after the bombs began falling there, he and his wife left for Budapest, where he has family. They managed to cross the Yugoslav border on a technicality involving a German visa Mr. Horvath had obtained for academic purposes.
Although Hungarian is his mother tongue, Mr. Horvath, 32, speaks fluent Serbian. Indeed, in 1987, when he was barely 20, his first thin volume of Serbian verse was awarded Yugoslavia's most prestigious young poets' prize.
"Hungary could have been an intermediary," he said, over coffee, with bitterness.
He is no friend of Mr. Milosevic, but the bombs, he said, are destroying civil society in Yugoslavia. "The land is destroyed, there is no money, no economy," he said. He does not intend to return when the war ends.
Compared with Yugoslavia, Hungary is flourishing, and he and his wife quickly found work teaching. Like some other Yugoslavs, ethnic Hungarian and not, they have found the Hungarian Government fairly uninterested in their lack of citizenship.
Last year, growth here was 5.1 percent, and at least 4 percent is expected this year, double the rate in western Europe. The Budapest stock market, battered last summer by the Russian crisis, has sprung back.
Yet when Laszlo Koszonits, managing director of Mahart, Hungary's river shipping company, looks out over the Danube from an office a block away, he sees that it is empty of ships. Earlier this month, NATO bombs destroyed bridges over the river in Novi Sad, paralyzing traffic on one of Europe's longest inland waterways, a vital artery for the Balkans, central Europe and Germany.
"Four ships and 24 barges -- 20 percent of our total capacity -- are stranded," he said. Revenues this year are projected to be a third to a half lower than last year's $20 million.
Cruise liners no longer ply the Danube from Vienna to the Black Sea, hurting tourism. The Dunaferr steelworks, down-river at Dunaujvaros, is scrambling for alternative carriers for the iron ore it hauls up from the Black Sea and the steel rolls and sheets it ships out, said Mihaly Schneider, the marketing director, at an increased cost that make the steel less competitive.
Oddly, said Mr. Koszonits, "the West paid to destroy those bridges, and the West will have to pay to rebuild them."
Hungarian officials fear the war's effects on tourism, which accounts for 9 percent of the economy. And Moscow's anger could lead to cuts in oil and gas supplies, which come mainly from Russia, and would cost more to replace.
While NATO membership has increased Hungary's attractiveness to foreign investors, the effect could be neutralized if investors perceive the war-torn region as inherently unstable.
There are no signs this is happening yet. Nokia, the Finnish phone company, is building a big research center here, and the German car maker, Audi, plans a $335 million factory. But the longer the war lasts, the greater the risk becomes. "I think it grows exponentially, because of the increasing mistrust of this area." Mr. Chikan said.
Tamas Wachsler, the State Secretary in the Defense Ministry, said Hungary has sent a 35-member medical team to Albania, and its military planes are airlifting food and other supplies for the refugees there. But to protect its minority in Yugoslavia, Budapest has told NATO that Hungarian troops will not get directly involved in the war, and that there is no way Hungary could be used as a staging base for a NATO ground invasion of Yugoslavia.
"We would like to avoid Hungarians under the NATO flag fighting against Hungarian conscripts under the Yugoslav flag," Mr. Wachsler said.
Jozsef Kasza, the ethnic Hungarian Mayor of Subotica, the largest Hungarian city in Yugoslavia, recently warned Hungary's Prime Minister, Viktor Orban, against "toying with the fate" of the Vojvodina Hungarians.
With the expulsion of the Kosovar Albanians, said Mr. Wachsler, the Hungarians are Yugoslavia's last minority, "which is of primary concern to the Hungarian Government, obviously."
For now, at least, there are no signs that Belgrade is moving against the ethnic Hungarian minority. Indeed, Hungarian newspapers have reported promotions of ethnic Hungarian officers in the Yugoslav Army, in an apparent bid for loyalty, although Mr. Wachsler said he could not confirm this.
Surveys in Hungary show 55 percent of the people supporting the air strikes, and 75 percent backing NATO membership, up from 60 percent at the time of accession in March. Yet two-thirds back the ban on using Hungarian troops in action.
With the dismemberment of the old Hungary by the Trianon Treaty of 1920, Hungarian minorities remain not only in Yugoslavia, but also in Slovakia and Romania. Governments in both those countries now include Hungarian ministers. More than anything else, sensitivity to minority rights appears to steel Budapest's resolve in Yugoslavia.
Janos Martonyi, the Foreign Minister, said that "patience and determination" were required.
"In the end, we cannot allow it when a government decides to massacre one part of its population based on religious or ethnic issues," he said. At the end of World War II, he said, "there was fundamental agreement that that could never happen again."
"Everybody has to understand that NATO just cannot lose," he said.

SECTION: Section 1; Page 15; Column 5; Foreign Desk 

LENGTH: 992 words

HEADLINE: CRISIS IN THE BALKANS: BELGRADE;
An Ordinary Serb, Lost In Air Attack, Is Buried

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: BELGRADE, Serbia, May 1

 BODY:
In one of the ordinary epics of everyday life, they buried Tomislav Mitrovic today.
He was 60 years old, with a wife, Lila; two daughters, Ivana and Jelena; a grandson, Kosta; and an informally adopted son, Dejan, the grown child of his best friend, who had died years before. 
 Mr. Mitrovic was a program director for Radio Television Serbia, the state-run broadcaster that gives the news much as President Slobodan Milosevic wants it given. Mr. Mitrovic was on the overnight shift on April 22-23, when NATO missiles hit the station to silence what the Pentagon spokesman, Kenneth H. Bacon, had called "as much a part of Milosevic's murder machine as his military."
Mr. Mitrovic, known as Tomi, was the 11th body pulled from the rubble of the station. They found him -- or, more precisely, they were able to identify him -- on April 29, six days after the explosion. He was in the control room that night, coordinating camera positions and tape for the early morning news, roughly where the missile impacted.
Those who died in the 2:10 A.M. strike were people like Darko Stoimenovski, 26, a technician who had helped foreigners transmit their footage; Ksenija Bankovic, 28, a video mixer; Jelica Munitlak, 27, a make-up artist; Milan Joksimovic, a 46-year-old security guard, and Tomi Mitrovic. Sixteen of the 100 people in the building that night are dead or still missing.
Everyone knew the station was a likely target. But the workers had been told by their editor, Dragoljub Milanovic, who was not in the building, that for reasons of patriotism and need they would work their assigned night shifts or they could pick up their work papers and find another job, losing their pensions.
Mr. Mitrovic, well liked in the way congenial, competent people are in any technical profession, was a year away from retirement in a country deformed by years of international sanctions, economic mismanagement, ethnic hatred and civil war.
"You retire in a year, and you're told to work or leave now and lose your pension," said another employee of the station.
"It's less than $100 a month, but it's still something. And in a country broken like this one, you can't afford it."
Mr. Mitrovic was the best man at the wedding of Dejan's father, which brings with it special responsibilities here. He was the "kum" (pronounced koom) of this second family, like a godparent but more. Dejan's father, Mihajlo, had been a lawyer, a sophisticated and cosmopolitan man with important connections in Yugoslavia and big expectations for his son.
But Mr. Mitrovic was the salt of the earth, an easygoing man whose company Dejan's father cherished. And when Dejan wanted to become a journalist, and his father was horrified, it was Mr. Mitrovic who interceded, again and again, and kept a peace between the two.
"He started in television in the early '60's as the guy who delivered the mail," Dejan said. "He had no sons, but there was this little boy who was the son of his best friend." Here, hating it, Dejan's face slowly collapsed, tears surging from his eyes as if a pipe had broken.
"When I talked about journalism," Dejan finally said, "my parents were so embarrassed, but he supported me. He said, 'Do what you care about and the money will come.' "
When Dejan's father died in the hospital in early 1995 after a long illness, it was Mr. Mitrovic who went to identify the body. And it was Mr. Mitrovic who brought the family the wedding ring that he had carried to the nuptials of his best friend many years before.
"Tomi loved America," Dejan said. "He built himself an American house, and everyone joked about it, but they admired it. He built a ranch house, with three bedrooms and three bathrooms. He saw it somewhere and he liked it, so he built one."
The living room and dining room are connected; there is a nice garden and a very un-Serbian lawn: Mr. Mitrovic used to cut the grass short, American-style.
"He had a wife, two daughters, a grandchild, a couple of cats and a dog who appeared one day," Dejan said. "He was just one of the people working there. He had no influence on the programs or on Milosevic. He just switched the cameras and the programs from channel to channel. He was a professional. He worked for his salary. If the political opposition ran the station, he'd work for them, too."
He and Dejan used to talk politics, and after 30 years of being a faithful reader of Politika, then as now the mouthpiece of whatever regime rules in Belgrade, Mr. Mitrovic stopped reading the paper in the winter of 1996-1997. Then, months of pro-democracy and anti-Milosevic demonstrations roiled the country, and state television refused to cover those demonstrations for a month, as if they did not exist.
The demonstrators called the station "the Bastille," and some of the windows still covered with plastic, even after NATO's bombing, were those broken by the stones of democracy's advocates.
"But the West did nothing then," the state television journalist said. "They had a chance to push out Milosevic and did nothing." He laughed harshly. "They certainly didn't bomb."
Mr. Mitrovic became embarrassed by the station's politics. "He was no supporter of Milosevic," said Dejan, now 31. "I had these debates with him. But you know, older people have this distance. They have so much to lose."
Dejan stopped again, busied himself with a cigarette, looking away. "He told me, 'You know, at this age, what can I do?' "
Tomislav Mitrovic was mourned by hundreds today at the Topcider cemetery. He was just one out of the many dead, Albanian and Serb.
The night the missile hit, said Slobodan Novakovic, speaking today at the graveside, Mr. Mitrovic told his subordinates to go home, while he remained on duty. "He showed enormous courage," Mr. Novakovic said.
"He was an ordinary man but a special man," Dejan said, again in tears. "He was my father's best friend, and he became my friend. And he was guilty of nothing."

HEADLINE: W. S. Salant, 87, Economist From the Keynesian School

BYLINE: By MICHAEL M. WEINSTEIN 

 BODY:
Walter S. Salant, who as a graduate student in the 1930's and later as a Government and private economist helped infuse the revolutionary teachings of John Maynard Keynes into Washington policy deliberations, died on Friday at a hospice near his home in Washington. He was 87.
After graduating from Harvard University in 1933, Mr. Salant attended the lectures of Keynes at Cambridge University, two years before he published "The General Theory of Employment, Interest and Money" -- the discipline-shattering treatise that argued that industrialized economies, then mired in depression, were unlikely to recover on their own but could use Government spending and tax cuts to do so. 
 Mr. Salant returned to Harvard and joined the celebrated fiscal policy seminar run by Professors Alvin Hansen and John Williams that explored Keynes's new ideas and trained economists who went on to build a discipline forged in part on the Keynesian foundation.
"It was an economically depressed time," James Tobin, a Nobel laureate at Yale University, recalled in a recent interview. "Most older professors other than Hansen himself had no explanation or understanding of what was happening, and no solution. The idea that Keynes had an explanation and a solution that involved an intellectual revolution but not a proletarian revolution was a pretty exciting thing. Walter was part of the core Keynesian group, a major figure of what became the center of American Keynesianism."
Mr. Tobin calls a short book, "An Economic Program for American Democracy," that Mr. Salant co-wrote with a number of graduate students in 1938 a "Keynesian manifesto" -- one of the first strong polemics in the United States on behalf of more Government investment and other Keynesian ideas that were then revolutionary but would, because of the efforts of Mr. Salant and others, become mainstream.
Mr. Salant left Harvard for a series of Government positions. He served in the Treasury Department, the Securities and Exchange Commission and Commerce Department in the 1930's, and, in the 1940's, the Office of Price Administration and other agencies that designed the national strategy for wartime price controls. He was a senior staff member for international relations on the President's Council of Economic Advisers from 1946 to 1952. He later served as a consultant to NATO and in the Treasury Department in the Kennedy and Johnson Administrations. He left the Government in 1954 to become a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution in Washington, staying until 1976.
Mr. Tobin credits Mr. Salant with helping to "internationalize Keynes." "The General Theory," Mr. Tobin said, "analyzed economies that engaged in no trade. Mr. Salant applied its lessons to a world that increasingly relied on trade and foreign investment -- analyzing how trade surpluses play the same role in an economy to create employment and output as do private investment or Government spending."
Prof. Charles P. Kindleberger of M.I.T. points to an influential report that Mr. Salant prepared for the Truman Administration showing that the proposed Marshall Plan -- a massive aid program for the reconstruction of Europe -- was affordable, financially feasible and would not, as critics feared, ignite a ruinous inflation.
Mr. Kindleberger also cites Mr. Salant's contributions to analyzing America's balance-of-trade deficits, a problem so severe that a senior official in the Kennedy Administration cited it along with nuclear arms as the two biggest issues confronting Government. A report that Mr. Salant wrote with Lorie Tarshis, Emile Despres, Alice Rivlin, now vice chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, and other distinguished economists at the request of President Kennedy's Council of Economic Advisers laid out the proper economic role of the United States as the world's central bank. Just as central banks need to provide currency to their domestic economies, they said, the United States needs to supply dollars to the international economy. In a controversial article he wrote in 1966 with Mr. Kindleberger and Mr. Despres, Mr. Salant explained that a steady outflow of dollars to pay for the trade deficit was no economic catastrophe. Indeed the outflow was necessary to feed an international economy desperate for liquidity.
Ms. Rivlin says the staff of the Brookings Institution in the 1960's included many distinguished economists who, like Mr. Salant, worked on practical problems of economic policy. His colleagues included Kermit Gordon, Joseph Pechman, Herb Stein, Charles Schultze and Arthur Okun, all of whom served in the Federal budget office or on the Council of Economic Advisers. She also cites Mr. Salant's role as mentor. He was, she said, "one of those people who took you under his wing."
Mr. Salant was born in New York City in 1911 and received his Ph.D. in economics from Harvard in 1962. He served on the Board of Editors of the American Economic Review, the journal of the American Economic Association, from 1956 to 1958.
He is survived by his wife, Edna; two sons, Michael, of Washington, and Stephen, of Ann Arbor, Mich., and three grandchildren.
Referring to his decision to leave university life for Washington in the Depression, Mr. Salant wrote in a reminiscence of the New Deal that the spirit of the Roosevelt Administration brought in young people like himself, "generated ideas, fermentation, energy, a feeling that something was being done, that there was leadership when leadership was needed, that there was a relationship between the government and the people in which the government was the citizen's friend."

HEADLINE: Congress Weighs Bill to Expand the Cartel Letting Northeast Dairy Farmers Set Prices

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 1

 BODY:
In a fight pitting farmers' incomes against consumers' pocketbooks, Congress has begun a fierce debate over legislation that would allow dairy farmers in New York, New Jersey and other states to charge more for milk.
The bill would enable New York and New Jersey -- as well as Maryland, Delaware and Pennsylvania -- to join the six New England states in the Northeast Interstate Dairy Compact, a two-year-old federally sanctioned cartel that sets a minimum wholesale price for milk. 
 The legislation, which would also authorize Southern states to create their own compact, would almost certainly raise prices at the cash register by a few pennies a gallon, and perhaps much more.
With 157 sponsors in the House and 39 sponsors in the Senate, the bill is well on its way to winning the 218 House votes and 51 Senate votes it needs for passage.
But consumer groups and businesses that process milk have led a vigorous lobbying campaign against the measure, contending that it would hurt the elderly and the poor. Anti-tax groups have also opposed the bill, saying it would have the effect of imposing a milk tax.
On the other side, environmentalists have joined farmers in asserting that the measure would help small dairy farmers stay in business, keep the region's milk supply steady and prevent the sale and development of pasture land. And Southern conservatives have locked arms with Northern liberals in supporting the bill, saying that, for the dairy industry at least, government regulation might be all right after all.
"The Federal Government already sets minimum prices for fluid milk," said Representative Asa Hutchinson, an Arkansas Republican who is a lead sponsor of the bill. "I just want to improve the regulatory system."
The debate is immensely important to farmers like Tom A. Borden, a part owner of O. A. Borden & Sons Farms in Washington County, N.Y., 30 miles north of Albany. A sixth-generation dairy farmer who is distantly related to the founders of the Borden Foods Corporation, Mr. Borden, 44, said the legislation would increase his annual income by several thousand dollars, enough to cover part of his property taxes and equipment costs. Most important, he said, it would ease his anxieties about the roller-coaster milk market by guaranteeing a minimum level of revenue from his 160-cow herd.
"Anything that makes us healthier will make it more appealing for the next generation to take on the business," he said.
But Augustine Carson, 74, a retired postal worker from Harlem who tries to drink a quart of milk each day to combat her arthritis, said she feared that the legislation could end up squeezing her already tight budget. "If I had to pay more for milk, I'd have to cut down on other things," Ms. Carson said. "I know farmers work hard and have to make a little more money, but can't it come from some other source?"
The debate on Capitol Hill will be strongly colored by regional alliances, as the South and Northeast unite against the Midwest, and possibly the West, where farmers contend that dairy compacts will hurt their sales. Some urban legislators, including those from New York City, are also expected to oppose the bill.
The issue is particularly significant to New York State, the nation's third largest milk producer. Under intense pressure from the state's 8,300 dairy farmers -- down from 14,200 a decade ago -- Gov. George E. Pataki pushed a measure endorsing the compact through the Legislature last year by tying it to a pay increase for the lawmakers. Here in Washington, the state's Senators, Charles E. Schumer and Daniel Patrick Moynihan, both Democrats, support the Federal bill.
The bill would allow New York, New Jersey and Maryland -- whose legislatures have endorsed the compact -- to join the Northeast compact immediately. Delaware and Pennsylvania could also join once their legislatures approve it. And it would make the Northeast compact permanent. Because the system was controversial, the compact was devised as a test and is scheduled to go out of business on Oct. 1.
Sixteen Southern states, including Texas, Florida and Georgia, would also be authorized to create a separate regional compact.
The Federal Government has been regulating the milk market since the Depression, and continues to set wholesale prices for drinking milk in most regions. But the Government has been scaling back price supports since the 1980's, causing wholesale prices to fluctuate more. Last month, for instance, the price paid to farmers for milk in New York plummeted to 99 cents per gallon from a record high of $1.50.
Farmers say that such wild changes have made it difficult to plan or get bank loans. They also say that declining consumption, coupled with increased productivity, have kept milk prices relatively low. The compact is intended to address both problems by setting prices that are steadier, and generally higher, than the Federal price.
Under compact rules, farmers receive the higher of the two prices. When the Federal price goes above the compact price, as it did late last year, the compact price goes out of effect, until the Federal price is the lower one. The compact price is set by a 26-member commission appointed by the governors of the six New England states.
Opponents contend that in states that join the Northeast compact, milk prices will rise by 20 cents to 40 cents per gallon. Higher prices, they say, will reduce sales, causing even more small farms to go out of business. The real beneficiaries of the arrangement, they maintain, are large farms, which would receive most of the additional revenue from higher prices. Such critics say the Government should try to emphasize benefits for small farmers by using tax cuts or aid programs that could reduce their utility bills, property taxes and feed costs.
"I am all for helping small farmers in our state, but this appears to be just helping big producers," said Representative Carolyn B. Maloney, a Democrat representing Manhattan and Queens, who said she is likely to vote against the bill.
Proponents say that the Northeast compact has raised retail prices only a few cents a gallon and that increases above that have resulted from market forces. While the compact may require milk processors to pay more for milk, those increases will not necessarily be passed on to consumers, they say. And they assert that without the compact, small farms will continue to fail, causing supplies to decline and prices to rise.
"If we don't do this, many small farmers will go out of business and then milk production will be in the hands of a few," said Representative Sherwood Boehlert, a Republican from Utica who is pushing for the legislation. "And then you'll really see prices go up."
Supporters also note that the Northeast compact has exempted school lunch programs and the Women, Infants and Children nutrition program for low-income families from paying the higher milk price.
Dairy economists say both sides have been guilty of exaggeration.
Several economists say the Northeast compact has had a smaller effect on prices than the critics had predicted. Although prices in the six New England states rose sharply in the first month of the compact, July 1997, they fell back slightly and then leveled off.
Economists also question the central premise that compacts will help small farms avoid being bought out by larger ones. "This does precious little to prevent the structural change that is going on in the dairy industry," said Andrew Novakovic, director of Cornell University's dairy markets and policy program.

HEADLINE: Carolina Bank Robberies Show That Friendliness Carries a Price

BYLINE: By DAVID J. MORROW 

DATELINE: CHARLOTTE, N.C.

 BODY:
It is virtually impossible to drive past a major intersection here without seeing a bank. Some of the nation's largest banks -- including First Union and Nationsbank -- are based here, solidifying North Carolina's reputation as the banking state.
Banks are so numerous that North Carolina is one of the nation's leaders in the number of branches. 
 But if honest North Carolinians have no trouble finding a bank, neither do bank robbers. Even though bank robbery has been declining nationwide, the crime has become remarkably common here. The state's banks, credit unions and savings institutions were robbed 289 times last year, a 38 percent jump from 1997.
While numbers are not yet fully reported, North Carolina's rise in bank robberies last year appears to be near the nation's highest, according to the F.B.I. North Carolina had 38.9 for each million people last year, compared with Illinois and New Jersey, which had 21 and 11 robberies per million, respectively.
North Carolina's tally was so high that the F.B.I.'s field office in Charlotte, which covers the entire state, ranked fourth nationwide last year in the number of reported bank robberies, trailing only Los Angeles, San Francisco and Seattle.
While bank officials are concerned about the rising number of robberies in North Carolina, they have not taken harsh measures to prevent them. In fact, the banks' friendliness to customers -- revered locally as Southern hospitality -- may actually increase the frequency of robberies.
Bank executives say robberies are a hazard of the industry. No one has a good explanation as to why the number of robberies is up one year and down the next. "I don't know how you avoid them," Harold T. Keen, president of KS Bank in Kenly, N.C., said. "This is not something that happens every month. And you don't want to have so much security that you inconvenience your customers."
Long regarded as the home of Big Tobacco, North Carolina has recently acquired another reputation. With so many banks concentrated in its urban areas, North Carolina has become a modern-day version of the Wild West, where holding up stage coaches became a national pastime. The two crimes are remarkably similar, law enforcement officials say, in that they are sometimes so randomly planned that many criminals settle on a target primarily on the basis of convenience.
"Bank robbery is a crime of opportunity," said Mark Rozzi, a special agent for the Federal Bureau of Investigation's Charlotte office. "The banks in North Carolina have a lot of branches that pride themselves on being friendly."
If the trend in North Carolina illustrates anything, law enforcement officials say, it is that robbing banks has changed little since Bonnie and Clyde became household names in the 1930's. Then as now, the number of bank holdups appeared to have less correlation with the economy's health than with the personalities of the robbers themselves.
"Bank robbers are antisocial," Dr. Ken Tardiss, a specialist in violent crime and a professor of psychiatry at the Weill Medical College of Cornell University, said. "The economy may be doing well for some people but not for them. Or they may just want more money and have a feeling that they deserve it."
Once a bank robber has experienced the thrill of a holdup, it is difficult to abandon the glare of a security camera. Some 20 percent of the bank robbers who were convicted nationwide last year were repeat offenders; two of the most active were in North Carolina.
One, Mark Vernon Brindell, an unemployed landscaper from Wake Forest, was sentenced last year to five years in Federal prison for holding up seven banks near Raleigh. The other, Isaiah Belcher 3d, was sentenced to 20 years in Federal prison for robbing eight banks near Durham. Between them, Mr. Brindell and Mr. Belcher committed 5.2 percent of the state's bank robberies in 1998.
Even though Bonnie Parker and Clyde Barrow captured the American public's imagination, some law enforcement officials never regarded them as anything more than common hoodlums, too dumb to pull off more sophisticated crimes. While the F.B.I. maintains that there is no stereotypical bank robber, some crime experts insist that bank robbers are still among the dumbest thugs going. One North Carolina robber several years ago actually wrote the holdup note on the back of his deposit slip, while another tried to rob a bank's drive-through window from the back seat of a taxi.
"These people are not physicists," said Thad Woodard, president of the North Carolina Bankers Association. "A lot of times they are on drugs and need money to support their habit."
Hollywood's take on bank robbers -- including Bonnie and Clyde -- usually has them toting semiautomatic weapons and wearing tailored suits. While some robbers do wear disguises, most enter banks wearing street clothes, hand tellers written instructions and then make quiet getaways.
But there are exceptions. A masked man entered a KS Bank in October and wasted little time terrorizing the place. Hopping over the counter, he pushed the teller aside and yanked open the money drawer. As he grabbed stacks of bills, he shouted obscenities, bank officials said, until he leaped back over the counter and fled.
He has yet to be caught.
There appears to be a simplicity to the robberies. According to statistics compiled last year by the F.B.I. in North Carolina, a majority of bank robberies occurred on Fridays between 9 and 11 A.M. The F.B.I. does not dismiss the timing as happenstance.
"The reason these robberies happened when they did?" Mr. Rozzi said. "The robbers wanted money for the weekend."
Given the aptitude of the typical bank robber, it should come as no surprise that most are caught relatively quickly. The F.B.I. in North Carolina solved 70 percent of the state's bank robbery cases last year, well ahead of the 60 percent rate in the rest of the country.
"The bottom line of this is that bank robberies are just a foolish crime," Mr. Rozzi said. "There are easier ways to get more money."
What may be especially frustrating to most robbers is that few walk out with the amount of money they expected. Bank officials balk at releasing amounts taken during robberies, but crime experts insist that most of the time the loot is insubstantial.
F.B.I. statistics for North Carolina put the average take last year at $11,722, slightly above the nationwide average of $9,266, but the numbers were skewed by several vault robberies. Many robbers get only a few thousand dollars, bank officials said, since they take money primarily out of teller drawers.
Unlike most banks in the United States, branches in the Southeast seldom use common security measures like armed guards or bulletproof glass to protect tellers. Some bank officials say these measures would upset customers, who have grown accustomed to niceties like free coffee and personal greetings by branch employees.
"You have to understand that we have a different way of doing business down here," Mr. Woodard said. "Customers don't want to be frightened or overly stressed by security. Some customers feel so welcome here that they carry the teller a card or cake on her birthday."
Unfortunately, the banks were prone to a few other mishaps. Since the average teller nationwide works only six to nine months before quitting, it is difficult to provide extensive security training. All too often, law enforcement officials say, inexperienced tellers are unable to find the marked bills during a robbery or give the holdup note back when the robber did not ask for it.
"Our tellers go through extensive training," Mr. Keen said. "They are told what things to look for. But when someone sticks a gun in your face, what are you going to do?"
Concerned about the rise in robberies, several banks are experimenting with new security technology. One program that has been particularly successful is the $5,000 reward set up by the North Carolina Bankers Association for information leading to the arrest and indictment of someone who robbed any of its member banks. Association officials note that a prime source of information is the robbers' friends and family.
The new programs appear to be lowering the number of bank robberies in North Carolina, but law enforcement officials remain cautious. In a meeting last month with other agents from the F.B.I.'s office in Raleigh, one senior agent, John Werner, noted that the rising number of bank robberies in the state was finally beginning to decline.
"I may have been speaking for about half an hour," Mr. Werner said. "And by the time I had finished, two more banks had been robbed."

HEADLINE: Prosperity for All?

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Bob Herbert (column, April 29) describes the lack of public awareness of the suffering and poverty of millions of people in the United States. Indeed, despite widespread reports concerning our country's economic boom, a staggering 35 million people live in poverty. Those of us who try to draw attention to this statistic find our voices repeatedly drowned out by reports of low unemployment figures and diminishing welfare rolls. 
 Unfortunately, these numbers do not tell the whole story. A recent study by our organization found that large numbers of people leaving the welfare rolls are experiencing the effects of poor nutrition, unstable housing and inadequate health care. This is true whether or not they are able to secure jobs. Moreover, as welfare rolls were dropping, social service agencies reported a significant rise in numbers of unemployed people without government assistance.
 
KATHY THORNTON
Washington, April 29, 1999
 
The writer is national coordinator of Network, A National Catholic Social Justice Lobby.

HEADLINE: MEDIA;
As Booksellers Shuffle, Readers Depart

BYLINE: By DOREEN CARVAJAL 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, May 2

 BODY:
The reviews are in for last year's books and the reading is not pleasant. A new industry study indicates that the popular market for literature declined, with the number of purchases dropping for the first time in seven years despite the growing presence of electronic bookstores and the easy availability of titles.
The widely publicized arrival of on-line booksellers has failed so far to expand the market for popular fiction and nonfiction even as demand has fallen for mass-market paperback books and as affluent, educated readers buy fewer titles, according to the Book Industry Study Group, a trade group that tracks the reading habits of 16,000 households. 
 That conclusion may defy the conventional wisdom of some of the top publishers who gathered today at the Los Angeles Convention Center for Book Expo America, the annual and sometimes uneasy business reunion of independent booksellers and their suppliers.
A day before the release of the survey on Friday, Peter Olson, the chief executive of Random House, the unit of Bertelsmann A.G. that is the nation's largest publisher, appeared on a panel, "Bookselling in the Next Millennium." During the discussion, he insisted that book sales on line amounted to incremental growth rather than a shift of purchases from other traditional outlets.
But the new consumer-research study indicates that sales over all declined almost 3 percent, to 1.04 billion books purchased -- literary spoils that were divided among a shifting group of booksellers.
For the first time that electronic commerce was measured as a category, on-line stores captured 2 percent of the book market while independent booksellers continued to lose share, which declined less than one percentage point, to 16.6 percent. The large bookstore chains raised their part of the market slightly to 25.3 percent, reflecting their own slowing expansion of brick-and-bookshelf stores. The rest of the bookselling market includes everything from mail order companies to warehouse chains to food and drug stores.
With the widespread availability of books and the plethora of titles on the market, booksellers struggled to understand why they were not reaching more readers. The downturn in sales comes as the economy continues to thrive and the number of small independent publishers has grown in the last 10 years to more than 53,400 companies.
Many of those small publishers and large houses from New York stocked the vast convention center here with books, hoping to appeal to independent booksellers. By necessity, those booksellers are banding together to create a common electronic bookstore of their own, Book Sense, which has now signed up more than 860 members.
Avin Domnitz, the chief executive of the American Booksellers Association, said the study reflected other research the trade group had conducted to prepare for the August start of the Book Sense site on the World Wide Web.
"Young people, in particular," Mr. Domnitz said, are "so busy and so mobile that the acquisition of these things are just not on their priority list."
That group is reading, he noted -- not necessarily traditional books but perhaps information on line.
Much of the softness in the market is attributable to the falling popularity of paperbacks; those books once ushered in a revolution in popular reading because of their modest cost and easy portability. The weakness of paperback sales took their toll on used bookstores, book clubs, mail-order companies, even drugstores -- all of which experienced declines in their shares of the market.
Mass-market paperback sales sagged more than 21 percent at drugstores and 17 percent at used bookstores -- reflecting a shift in American reading habits by customers who may prefer the larger type of discounted hardcovers or more expensive trade paperbacks. Cost may also have driven away potential customers: the average price of a paperback book outpaced the rate of inflation over the last five years, rising to $4.56 from $4.12 in 1994.
To deal with the age issue, the Association of American Publishers has created a publicity campaign featuring celebrity bookworms and a slogan, "Get Caught Reading," to try to reach the young, but there is heavy work ahead. In particular, readers younger than 25 bought fewer books last year, with purchases down by 20 percent. Older customers between 55 and 64 remained loyal, the study showed, buying 15 percent more books.
Readers with annual incomes of more than $75,000 are usually big book buyers, but last year they also cut back. In general, readers bought fewer fiction titles and pared even more on nonfiction, like biographies and history, which had a 12 percent decline in sales.
The customers younger than 40 who did shift to on-line book shopping displayed rather different reading tastes from those of the general market. Popular fiction topped E-commerce sales at 33 percent, followed by 14 percent for technical and science books, 12 percent for cookbooks and crafts titles and 11 percent for psychological and recovery books. In the general market, popular fiction has a much more commanding presence -- 51 percent -- followed by religious titles at 10 percent and cookbooks at 9 percent.
The study noted that buyers of religious books did not seem to respond to electronic bookstores, but did buy enough titles in other outlets to expand the segment's share of the market by more than 1 percentage point. Over all, customers bought fewer books in every category except travel and religion.
Mr. Domnitz, whose organization helped finance the study, still said the potential exists for expanding the market.
"The problem is that about half of the population is not going to purchase books in the course of a year," he said. "And so we have to concentrate on those who do."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Thompson and Kirshenbaum Bond are forming units to focus on the entertainment industry.

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
TWO agencies are joining the growing chorus along Madison Avenue singing "That's Entertainment."
At J. Walter Thompson New York, an executive from the William Morris Agency, Marina Hahn, is arriving in the new post of executive vice president for strategy and entertainment. And Kirshenbaum Bond & Partners in New York is forming a division to specialize in film, television and theatrical accounts. The division, named KBE, opens with assignments that have billings estimated at $15 million to $20 million. 
 The moves are indicative of the increasing attempts by agencies to broaden their missions beyond conventional advertising and enter fields that are fresher and faster-growing. The enormous opportunities presented by what Michael J. Wolf, in his new book, "The Entertainment Economy," calls "the E-factor" -- the voracious appetite among Americans to be amused -- are too potentially lucrative to ignore, particularly after Hollywood talent agencies have sought to muscle in on the tasks that agencies have long performed for marketers.
"Agencies can't just develop 30-second TV spots anymore," said Bob Jeffrey, president at Thompson New York, part of the J. Walter Thompson unit of WPP Group P.L.C.
"We have this big responsibility to form marketing partnerships with clients in more aggressive ways and grow brands with the total spectrum of communications," he said. "Entertainment is global, ubiquitous, contemporary and sets trends."
Ms. Hahn, 40, had been vice president and head of the East Coast corporate advisory group at the New York office of William Morris. She has also worked for the Sony Corporation of America, the Pepsi-Cola Company unit of Pepsico Inc. and what is now DDB Worldwide in New York, a unit of Omnicom Group.
"It's all about using entertainment as a strategic tool," Ms. Hahn said, "combining the creativity and clout of the entertainment industry with the resources of corporate America and figuring out how to build brands in innovative ways."
And "it's more than creating the next sponsorship or product placement or hiring the next celebrity endorser," she added. "You have to think about the experiences, not just the brands." Among marketers praised by Ms. Hahn and Mr. Jeffrey were the Walt Disney Company; the Tommy Hilfiger Corporation; Nike Inc., for the Niketown retail stores, and the Starbucks Coffee Company.
Ms. Hahn will form and lead a group at Thompson New York that will combine what had been separate operations handling account planning and media planning with a new entertainment unit, which, like KBE, will seek clients in Hollywood, book publishing, music and theater. Another goal is to use entertainment expertise to sell the packaged goods of clients of Thompson New York and other Thompson offices.
At KBE, one initial assignment comes from a partnership between the Columbia Tristar Television Group, a division of Sony Pictures Entertainment, and Children's Television Workshop, the nonprofit company that developed "Sesame Street." KBE is working on projects for "Sesame Street" and will provide services including advertising, interactive marketing and promotions for "Dragon Tales," a new animated series aimed at preschool children that is to be broadcast by PBS in the fall.
"This is about developing a brand, not just a successful show," said Sherrie Rollins Westin, executive vice president for marketing, communications and research at the workshop in New York. "The launch of KBE speaks to bringing brand-building sensibilities to entertainment and media."
"Dragon Tales," featuring cartoon characters with names like Cassie, Ord, Quetzal and the two-headed Zak & Wheelie, is being produced by a new group at Sony Pictures Entertainment in Culver City, Calif., devoted to television shows, movies and videos for children and families.
"With the continuing fragmentation of the marketplace, producers will have to take on more responsibility to supplement the networks' efforts with their own show promotion," said Sander Schwartz, president of the new group.
"The folks at Kirshenbaum Bond have shown an ability to distinguish products of clients from the clutter and the competition," he added, referring to work for Snapple and Target. "I'm excited about them doing the same for 'Dragon Tales.' "
Another initial assignment for KBE comes from Radio City Entertainment in New York, part of the Madison Square Garden division of Cablevision Systems; Kirshenbaum Bond has handled assignments for the company's Broadway musical, "The Scarlet Pimpernel." KBE's work will include campaigns for productions of "The Wizard of Oz" and "A Christmas Carol" and a Halloween attraction with the entertaining name of Madison Scare Garden.
KBE begins with about 10 employees under the direction of Jeff Peters, 39, vice president and account director, and James Hitchcock, 35, vice president and creative director. Mr. Peters joined from (coincidentally) Thompson New York, where he had been a vice president and marketing manager. Mr. Hitchcock had been a vice president and associate creative director at Kirshenbaum Bond on accounts like Target.
Mr. Peters and Mr. Hitchcock will report to Jonathan Bond and Richard Kirshenbaum, the co-chairmen at Kirshenbaum Bond.

HEADLINE: T. Justin Moore Jr., 74, Ex-Chief Of the Virginia Power Company

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS 

 BODY:
T. Justin Moore Jr., a retired chief executive of the Virginia Power Company and a founder of an economic development group that sought to break down racial barriers in Richmond, died of cancer on April 24 at his home in Richmond, a family spokesman said. He was 74.
Mr. Moore was as well known in Richmond for his attempts to ease racial tensions in the city in the 1980's as he was for his career at the utility. He had a knack for dealing with different groups, including politicians, consumers, state agencies and his own employees. 
 He founded the development group Richmond Renaissance in 1982 along with Henry L. Marsh 3d, a Democratic state senator who also served as Mayor of Richmond.
The group, which is still active, was a biracial partnership that brought together public and private groups to spur economic development. It succeeded in attracting new business into the area.
Mr. Moore served as the first chairman of Richmond Renaissance, helping to develop the Sixth Street Marketplace, a pedestrian mall area. Acting on Mr. Moore's idea, the group built a bridge over Broad Street as a symbolic as well as practical way of bringing the black and white areas of the city together. Before it was built, Mr. Marsh said, Broad Street had separated the two communities like a Berlin wall.
Concerning the increasing demand for energy, Mr. Moore expressed faith that technology like solar power would eventually meet the challenge. "I'm a great believer that new technology is going to keep on saving our necks," he said.
Mr. Moore served as an officer in the Navy in the Pacific during World War II. After graduating from Princeton University in 1947, he attended Virginia Law School, graduating in 1950. He then joined the firm of Hunton & Williams.
He was named assistant general counsel for the Virginia Electric and Power Company in 1956 and joined the company as senior vice president and principal financial officer in 1967.
He was promoted to president in 1970 and was named chairman and chief executive in 1978. He retired from Virginia Power in 1985 but continued to serve on the board of Dominion Resources Inc., the parent company, until 1994. He also served as a director of the Philip Morris Companies, the GTE Corporation and the Conference Board.
His first wife, Mary Elizabeth Pearson Moore, died in 1983. He is survived by his wife, Jeanette Bray; a son, T. Justin Moore 3d, and a daughter, Mary Moore Wilkinson, all of Richmond.

HEADLINE: PUBLIC LIVES;
A Great Defender of the Old Social Security Battles On

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
THE conventional wisdom these days is that any major change to Social Security is unlikely before next year's elections, but Robert M. Ball remains ever vigilant. In the unending debate over the nation's pension system, Mr. Ball stands as the great defender of traditional Social Security, the genius of its basic principles, the soundness of its basic approach.
"Though I feel good about our position," he said in a lull in the struggle on a lazy spring afternoon, "people who think like I do better be very careful, and we better have good proposals and we better be alert. Or something may happen that we don't like." 
 Mr. Ball comes by his passion honestly, having been at the Social Security wars for a very long time. He went to work for Social Security in 1939, ran the program as Commissioner from 1962 to 1973, and has since played a principal role on some of the important advisory commissions. He is a regular source of advice for leading Congressional Democrats, has sent a series of memorandums on the issue to the White House over the last few years and, yes, is a Social Security beneficiary himself.
Mr. Ball, who is 85, said he had no complaints about life on the other end of the Social Security check. "They do a good job," he said, happily settled for the moment like any other cardigan-clad retiree in the living room of his ranch house in Alexandria, Va.
For many Democrats engaged in the issue, Mr. Ball is an irreplaceable link with 60 years of history. "There's a reason why the program is what it is," said Representative Earl Pomeroy of North Dakota, a Democratic point man on Social Security in the House. "And Bob Ball can explain it to you."
For the last few years, Mr. Ball's consuming cause has been beating back the forces of privatization: the notion that at least part of Social Security should be replaced with individual accounts that workers could invest as they see fit.
He sees privatization as a "slippery slope," a dangerous step away from the guaranteed benefits of Social Security. He contends that the system can be shored up for the next century by far less radical measures, like raising the maximum amount of earnings subject to Social Security taxes.
Mr. Ball acknowledges that his views are shaped by a very different world than that of the young privatizers. One of three children of a Methodist minister, he grew up in northern New Jersey and graduated from Wesleyan University with a master's degree in economics during the Depression. There were no jobs.
For help, he turned to his thesis adviser, who happened to have a friend involved in the new Social Security program. "He said, 'Well, this program is just starting up. It's going to be a big program. It's an attractive program and an important social program, and it would be a good thing if you got in on it in the beginning.' "
So Mr. Ball took the Civil Service exam during his honeymoon (he spent the rest of the time on a camping trip with his wife, Doris) and began work as a field representative in the Newark office of Social Security for $1,620 a year.
He spent his early years visiting employers, trying to straighten out wage records and, along the way, proselytizing for a program that seemed quite revolutionary at the time. On the wall of his office at home, he has a picture of that Newark field staff, earnest young foot soldiers of the New Deal.
There are other pictures on that wall: President Lyndon B. Johnson signing the law creating Medicare, which Mr. Ball helped put into effect. The Presidential commission, signed by John F. Kennedy, that named Mr. Ball head of Social Security. (Mr. Ball noted that it mentioned more than once that he served at the pleasure of the President.) A picture of the Balls with President Richard M. Nixon in 1973, when Mr. Ball was leaving office. The newspapers at the time said he was "pushed out." Mr. Ball says: "I was perfectly happy to go, but I couldn't have stayed if I wanted to. I lasted for the first term."
Along the way, the Balls brought up two children: their son is a psychotherapist; their daughter, an art therapist.
Mr. Ball acknowledges that his retirement has been less than restful. He does do a lot of reading, and not just on social insurance issues, he said a trifle defensively. Mostly novels and Romantic poetry.
BUT the care and tending of Social Security keeps pulling him back.
"There was a time when I felt a lot of pressure on the basis that there wasn't anybody else really working on it very much," he said. "Now there's a whole group. They'll carry on whether I die tomorrow and do as good or better job."
That was the idea behind the National Academy of Social Insurance, a nonprofit organization that does research on social insurance and tries to "enhance public understanding" of the issues; Mr. Ball was one of its founders 11 years ago.
Still, it is not at all clear that Mr. Ball is ready to pass the torch and enter the land of retirement he helped create.
"My wife and I had dinner with him and Doris two nights ago," said Henry Aaron, an economist at the Brookings Institution. "I don't know of any other 85-year-old who's wrestling with what he's going to do, new. But Bob is wrestling with that. I think he sees the health care issue emerging anew."

HEADLINE: Low-Wage Businesses Add to Number of Uninsured Workers

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 2

 BODY:
A long-spreading gap between the wages of undereducated workers in menial jobs and those of skilled college graduates is contributing to another gap, in workers' health benefits, a research journal reports.
Lending a new perspective on the swelling numbers of Americans without health insurance, an article to be published on Monday in the journal Health Affairs says that a phenomenon feeding the benefits gap is the proliferation of low-wage businesses, like stores and restaurants. 
 "Our findings," the authors say, "strongly suggest that low-wage families" can often protect themselves from losing health insurance "if they find work in firms where a substantial share of the employees earn more than they do."
John Gabel, the lead author, an economist and benefits specialist at the Hospital Research and Educational Trust, said in an interview, "The pattern we see is that employers that have a high-income work force offer better benefits, no matter how you choose to look at it."
The article notes that after taking inflation into account, wages for high school graduates fell 11 percent from 1973 to 1997, while those of college graduates rose 17 percent.
The journal says that the rise in the numbers of uninsured Americans, from 38 million in 1992 to 43 million in 1997, has touched most segments of the population, but the poor especially.
Over the five years, the study says, the percentage of heads of households with high school diplomas who lacked coverage rose to 28.6 percent, from 26.2 percent. But for those with college degrees, the percentage was much lower and barely budged, to 8.1 percent from 7.8 percent.
The authors looked in particular at relationships showing that low-paid employees of companies with high proportions of well-paid employees were more likely to be offered benefits, and to get more choices in coverage, with smaller deductions from their pay, than those at businesses with few well-paid employees.
The article does not identify the 2,763 private and public employers the authors examined. But the authors show that low-wage workers serving hamburgers in the cafeteria of, say, a General Motors or a Merrill Lynch, which have relatively few such workers, are more likely to have health benefits than those at McDonald's or Burger King, which have many low-wage workers.
For the article, the authors used two surveys conducted last year. One, by KPMG Peat Marwick, the consulting firm, surveyed 1,583 small and large employers. The other, by the Kaiser Family Foundation, surveyed 1,180 small businesses employing from 3 to 199 workers.
For each employer, the authors weighed the numbers of well-paid workers -- those earning more than $75,000 a year -- against those earning less than $20,000.
The authors put those employers with the highest proportion of the lowest-paid workers into a "low wage" category and those with the highest proportion of high-paid workers into a "high wage" category. Workers at the high-wage companies -- whether poorly paid or well paid themselves -- got the better deal. They paid 21 percent of the employers' premiums for individual coverage, compared with 24 percent at low-wage firms. And for family coverage, workers at high-wage firms paid 27 percent of the cost, compared with 41 percent for low-wage firms.
Among the smaller companies, the authors found that only 39 percent of the low-wage companies offered health benefits, compared with 82 percent of the high-wage firms. 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: Pataki Tests National Waters, but Barely a Ripple Is Seen

BYLINE: By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

 BODY:
Gov. George E. Pataki had just finished a 50-minute speech at Georgetown University about the Balkans when a student interposed a question that had little to do with Mr. Pataki's views on foreign policy: Why was a New York governor offering a major address in Washington on global problems in the first place? "Normally, those are handled by Presidents and Vice Presidents," Matthew Payne, a government major, observed dryly.
Mr. Pataki paused as a rustle of laughter rose from the seats. "I'm sure that we have many New Yorkers involved in the air strikes," he said. Besides, the Governor asserted, "The national policy debate -- the decisions that are made here in Washington -- have an enormous effect on New York." 
 As the question posed at Georgetown last week suggests, Mr. Pataki's campaign to establish himself as a leading influence within his party -- shaping the Republican Party's platform and earning consideration as a top-tier candidate for national office -- apparently has yet to take hold. Three months after Mr. Pataki began offering his views of the world beyond Albany with a series of speeches across the country, Republican politicians and strategists say he remains largely a New York State figure, respected for his accomplishments in that state, but still not considered among the leading forces in his party.
Mr. Pataki's signature argument that his party should turn away from such issues as abortion rights and embrace the Reagan-era platform of cutting Government spending and taxes has yet to inspire the kind of debate that the Governor might have envisioned. Even Republicans who praise his record say he is rarely mentioned in discussions these days about potential Presidential or Vice Presidential candidates.
"The truth is that he is not a serious candidate," said Mike Murphy, a Republican strategist who worked for Bob Dole's Presidential campaign in 1996. "His Presidential ambitions are writing checks that his political muscle can't cash. There is no opening for him."
Doug Bailey, a former Republican consultant who is now the publisher of a daily political digest and tip sheet, said: "I don't think he's on anybody's list. I don't think anybody seriously thinks that he's planning to run. I don't think he's a household name anywhere."
Notwithstanding his apparent lack of success to date, Mr. Pataki has a history of emerging unexpectedly at the top of the political heap. He was, after all, the little-known Republican legislator from Westchester who toppled Mario M. Cuomo, and he is nothing if not a persistent candidate.
His nomination in 1994 came after years of steady if unnoticed work in New York political circles, traveling the state and giving speeches, preparing himself should the political opportunity arise, as it did when Republican leaders recruited him to run against Mr. Cuomo. He is now executing the same kind of strategy on a national level, his aides say.
And Mr. Pataki said that he was satisfied with his success so far, asserting in an interview that his speeches on national politics and the future of the Republican Party -- in Illinois, Missouri and New Hampshire, among other places -- have drawn attention both to his record in Albany and to his views on how his party can become more competitive in national elections. "I really believe this stuff," he said. "I really believe in these principles."
"I am amazed at the level of attention," Mr. Pataki said. "When you have seven or eight candidates -- and I'm not a candidate -- to have obtained the level of attention that we've gotten is, to me, very surprising. I didn't expect it to be as widespread."
That is a view, though, that is not widely shared among Republicans these days. Several contrasted Mr. Pataki's trips with those of his predecessor: In particular, Mr. Cuomo's 1984 speech about abortion rights at the University of Notre Dame, when he was a first-term governor, which drew extensive national attention and helped stir the talk among some Democrats about Mr. Cuomo as a potential Presidential candidate.
Mr. Pataki's advisers describe what he is doing as, in effect, a should-lightning-strike strategy: establishing his credentials in case one of the Republicans more commonly mentioned for national office should falter. But that is an eventuality that even Mr. Pataki's advisers see as increasingly unlikely.
The Governor's attempt to use the 2000 Presidential campaign to raise his own profile -- following a long line of Governors from New York who have done the same thing to great success, whether Thomas E. Dewey or Mr. Cuomo -- has been, to some extent, undercut by events beyond his control.
When Mr. Pataki began earlier this year, it was far from clear who the Republican Party might nominate for President. That has changed with the rise of Gov. George W. Bush of Texas as the party's leading Presidential contender, to Mr. Pataki's clear disadvantage.
"I don't think he's actually looked at as a candidate by very many people because the movement to Bush is unabated," said Gov. John M. Engler of Michigan, an early supporter of Mr. Bush. "There is a settling in that's taking place that in all likelihood, George W. Bush is going to be our nominee."
And Mr. Pataki's hopes of being considered for Vice President are complicated by, among other things, his support of abortion rights, which will certainly be a contrary position at the next Republican convention, and the fact that he is from New York.
"The first thing Republicans are concerned about is reinforcing their base in the South and the Southwest," said Adam Goodman, a Republican consultant. "The Northeast is not at the top of the priority list."
Still, Mr. Pataki has succeeded in distinguishing himself ideologically in his party, with his emphasis on economic issues combined with his support for abortion rights and gay rights. Several advisers said that such ideological positioning could prove fortuitous in future Presidential elections if the Republican Party moves to the center. In that event, what Mr. Pataki is doing now could pay dividends in 2004 or 2008, much the same way his work in New York in 1990 paid off in 1994.
In the meantime, Mr. Pataki said he intends to continue traveling the nation, presenting himself as a noncandidate concerned about the future of the Republican Party.
"He is doing what you can do when you are the Governor of New York, which is to monkey around in the primary season," Mr. Murphy, the Republican consultant, said. "There is no such thing as too much exposure."

HEADLINE: CRISIS IN THE BALKANS: NEWS ANALYSIS;
Diplomatic Initiative Helps Strengthen Both Yeltsin and Russia

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON 

DATELINE: BRUSSELS, May 2

 BODY:
By dispatching his special envoy to Washington for talks on ending the Yugoslav conflict, President Boris N. Yeltsin has put Russia at the center of international diplomacy, reviving relations with Washington and NATO. Perhaps more to the point for Mr. Yeltsin, it also plays well at home.
The move has quieted the hard-line critics who have lamented Moscow's dwindling influence, and has even enabled the President to settle a few scores with some of his political rivals. 
 The trouble is that it remains unclear whether the Kremlin has real influence over the Yugoslav President, Slobodan Milosevic, and whether it is willing to use it.
"The Russians have been knocking at the door and demanding to be treated as an important player," said Toby T. Gati, a former senior State Department official. "Now they have got the biggest welcome they can have: the welcome at the White House. But this is a high-stakes game. The question is whether they can deliver."
An initial answer may come Monday afternoon when Viktor S. Chernomyrdin -- the former Prime Minister whom Mr. Yeltsin fired last year and then tried unsuccessfully to rehire -- meets with President Clinton. Mr. Yeltsin suggested the meeting in a 15-minute telephone call to President Clinton today.
Certainly, Mr. Yeltsin had compelling reasons to plunge into Balkan diplomacy. Since NATO's bombs first started raining down on Yugoslavia more than five weeks ago, the Kremlin has been on the political defensive.
The Communists have charged that the NATO raids show how weak and marginalized Russia has become on Mr. Yeltsin's watch. Hard-liners have demanded that the Kremlin provide military assistance to Belgrade.
Such a step would frustrate Mr. Yeltsin's longstanding policy of maintaining a good working relationship with the West, no small consideration for a nation still sorely in need of billions of dollars in credits from the International Monetary Fund.
At first, Mr. Yeltsin sought to fend off his critics by turning up the anti-NATO rhetoric. Russian officials denounced the allied air strikes in vitriolic terms, warning that the military campaign might even spark a third world war. When it came to deeds, however, the Kremlin was careful to stay clear of the conflict.
Ultimately, however, that approach merely reinforced the perception that Russia was powerless to end the fighting. Neither NATO nor Belgrade seemed to care very much what Moscow thought.
So Mr. Yeltsin switched his strategy. He appointed Mr. Chernomyrdin special envoy on the Yugoslav conflict and sent him to Belgrade in search of a settlement.
In a cut-throat world of Russian politics, the Chernomyrdin appointment also served another purpose. It enabled Mr. Yeltsin to diminish the political role of Yevgeny M. Primakov, Mr. Yeltsin's current Prime Minister and a former Foreign Minister.
Mr. Yeltsin has become increasingly unhappy with the ambitious Mr. Primakov, who has done little to pull Russia out of its economic morass while seeking to position himself as a potential successor to the ailing President.
This is not to say that Mr. Chernomyrdin's diplomacy is simply a matter of political theater. Russia has a genuine stake in brokering a settlement on Kosovo.
As NATO's air strikes have dragged on, there has been increasing talk in allied capitals of a possible land offensive. A NATO ground assault to seize Kosovo would further inflame anti-Western opinion in Moscow and renew the bitter criticism at home of Mr. Yeltsin's policies.
Brokering an agreement, however, is the hard part. As Russian officials see it, Mr. Chernomyrdin has several important strengths, including a good working relationship with Vice President Al Gore.
Negotiating a settlement might also help Mr. Chernomyrdin revive his moribund political career, though almost certainly not to the point where it would make him a plausible presidential candidate.
Still, Mr. Chernomyrdin's mission is heavy with political risks. Having claimed the world spotlight, Russia has staked its prestige on diplomacy. If it fails to make headway, Russia may soon find itself back on the sidelines.
By all accounts, the issues are still formidable. NATO and Belgrade have been far apart on the main issues, including the alliance's demand that NATO troops be deployed in Kosovo to protect ethnic Albanians and that all Serb forces be withdrawn.
Another divisive question concerns the final political status of the Kosovo region. NATO is proposing that it be an "internationally protected area" that is only nominally within Yugoslavia. Belgrade wants clearer administrative responsibility over the region.
Nor is it clear that Moscow and Washington agree on how Russia should go about its mediating role. Russia has tended to cast itself as a sort of marriage counselor that expects concessions from NATO, as well as Belgrade. The United States, however, insists that NATO's demands are firm and that it is the Milosevic regime that will have to make the major concessions.
Mr. Chernomyrdin, for his part, met on Friday with Mr. Milosevic. He left without declaring a breakthrough and was careful not to promise one today.
"We consider the situation to be far from simple," Mr. Chernomyrdin said. "But it gives us hope that efforts which Russia has taken and will take are significant."

HEADLINE: Stanley D. Canter, 75, an Adviser to Corporations

BYLINE: By DANA CANEDY 

 BODY:
Stanley D. Canter, who advised many of the world's best-known corporations on marketing and advertising matters during a career that spanned more than 40 years, died April 24 at the Jacob Perlow Hospice at Beth Israel Hospital in New York City, according to a longtime business associate. The cause was cancer. He was 75.
Until his retirement in 1989, Mr. Canter was president and treasurer of Canter Achenbaum Associates, Inc., a consulting firm that specialized in advertising and marketing. He and his partner, Alvin Achenbaum, created the agency in 1974, and it became known for being instrumental in changing the way client companies select and compensate agencies. During Mr. Canter's tenure, the firm conducted more than 40 agency searches for many of America's blue-chip manufacturers, as well as for the largest Japanese and Korean automobile companies. 
 Canter Achenbaum, now called Achenbaum Bogda Associates, was included in a recent issue of Advertising Age, the trade publication, commemorating 100 executives who had a significant impact on advertising during the last century. Mr. Canter was mentioned for his contribution along with Mr. Achenbaum for changing the relationship between clients and agencies.
While working for the Toyota Motor Company's United States division in 1974, Canter Achenbaum helped develop a systematic competitive process for choosing its advertising agency and agreeing on compensation. The approach was a departure from the industry practice in which agencies received 15 percent commissions on media billings. This helped lead to the present practice of companies' using a variety of compensation structures for agencies, including pay-for-performance fees.
Mr. Canter began his career in 1945 at Econometric Institute, a firm, now defunct, that conducted economic forecasting using statistical models. He moved into advertising two years later when he became head of the media research department and later led the marketing research division of McCann-Erickson, now part of the Interpublic Group of Companies.
In 1957, Mr. Canter joined Ogilvy & Mather as head of the research department for what was then a fledgling operation. He once said of his work there that it involved research that often employed "a statistical technique for classifying individuals into subcategories depending on their response patterns to a series of questions."
He remained at Ogilvy & Mather for 13 years, rising to senior vice president and director of marketing services. He had also been a senior account officer responsible for the Shell Oil and Sears, Roebuck accounts.
Mr. Canter left the agency in 1974 when he and Mr. Achenbaum started their business. In addition to its work in advertising agency search and compensation, the firm provided strategic marketing counsel to many marketers, including Hallmark Cards, the American Express Company and Citicorp.
In an article announcing his retirement in 1989, Mr. Cantor reflected on the industry and said that agencies were groping for a "new type of marketing specialist -- a person familiar with several different kinds of media."
Mr. Cantor was born in New York City, where he lived his entire life. He is survived by his wife, Florence Sanoff of New York City; two sons from a previous marriage, Leonard, of Redding, Conn., and Robert, of Santa Monica, Calif., and two grandchildren, both of Redding.
