HEADLINE: The Widow Of Ex-Leader Wins Race In Panama

BYLINE: By MIREYA NAVARRO 

DATELINE: PANAMA, May 2

 BODY:
Mireya Moscoso, the widow of a Panamanian President who stepped out on her own politically to become the main opposition leader here, narrowly defeated her main opponent tonight, electing her the country's first woman President.
With just 55 percent of the vote counted, official tallies showed Ms. Moscoso, 52, with 43 percent. Martin Torrijos, the 35-year-old son of the late Panamanian strongman, Gen. Omar Torrijos, followed with 38 percent. 
 Alberto Vallarino, 47, of a third political alliance, trailed with 17 percent. He conceded defeat shortly after 8 P.M. and wished Ms. Moscoso "success in leading this country in one of the periods of major challenges but also of major opportunities in our history."
About an hour later, Mr. Torrijos publicly congratulated the winner and announced to his supporters that he would seek to become secretary general of the Revolutionary Democratic Party, reorganize the party and prepare to run again in the 2004 elections "for the benefit of the motherland."
"You can be sure that we have a future and that time does not stop at this moment," he said to wild cheers.
Shortly before 10 P.M., Ms. Moscoso was welcomed by supporters at a hotel here with shouts of "Mireya! Mireya!" while caravans of honking cars could be heard around the city. She then promised to given an address from her party's headquarters later tonight.
"Today Mireya Moscoso didn't win," she said. "The Panamanian people won. We have a commitment with this country and thousands and thousands of people."
Ms. Moscoso will lead the administration that acquires the Panama Canal from the United States at the end of the year under the 1977 Canal Treaties negotiated by General Torrijos with President Carter.
The President is elected by a simple majority for a five-year term starting Sept. 1.
Panamanians also chose two Vice Presidents, 71 legislators for the unicameral Legislative Assembly and 74 mayors in tranquil elections that appeared to be the third clean vote of recent years, solidifying a break from a history of massive election fraud and political coups.
Turnout among the 1.7 million registered voters was 74 percent, and in many polling places the mood was relaxed, with little partisan euphoria evident in or outside the buildings.
Ms. Moscoso, owner of a coffee business inherited from her late husband, Dr. Arnulfo Arias, for whom the Arnulfista Party was named, ran on a populist platform that promised to end Government corruption and privatization policies that have left Panamanians grumbling about higher rates for telephone and other services. This was her second try at the presidency; she lost 1994 elections to current President Ernesto Perez Balladares.
This time, Ms. Moscoso had to overcome early polls that showed her behind, criticism over her lack of college degrees and government experience, and the ghost of General Torrijos. Memory of the general still resonates with many voters and his name was constantly invoked by her opponent. To retaliate, she often referred to Mr. Torrijos, the candidate, by the diminutive "Martincito."
Mr. Torrijos, an economist with degrees from Texas A&M University who served as Deputy Minister of Government and Justice in the Perez Balladares administration, did not differ widely with Ms. Moscoso on policy. The main thrust of his campaign was to offer a cleaner, less arrogant image for the party once led by Gen. Manuel Noriega, who was ousted in the American invasion of Panama in 1989 and is serving a prison sentence in the United States on a drug-related conviction.
In her campaign, Ms. Moscoso drew on the memory of another charismatic politician: her husband. Mr. Arias died in exile in Miami in 1988 after a long career in which he won three elections as President, but each time was removed from office by opponents, the last time in 1968 in a military coup that installed General Torrijos as ruler.
While some Panamanians quipped that the campaign was thus a race between "two corpses," many voters expressed a desire to break with the past, which Ms. Moscoso said she would offer.
"Today, the selfish leadership in the Government has appropriated the riches and national assets while the great majorities are increasingly impoverished," she said in a fiery speech at her own campaign closing rally last week. "I promise you a different Government."
With poverty and unemployment widespread, and a judicial system in need of serious reform, many Panamanians hope for a break with the Government corruption and nepotism of the past.

HEADLINE: Doctors Face the Business of Medicine

BYLINE: By ERIC NAGOURNEY 

 BODY:
No one had ever said that starting her own allergy practice would be easy, but Dr. Cheryl Lynn Walker was not prepared for the anxieties that beset her after she opened her doors to patients.
"I would get up in the morning, and I would just feel overwhelmed," she recalled. 
 The problem with the practice of medicine, she found, was not the medicine but the practice. Like many physicians, Dr. Walker, who opened her practice in Chicago in 1990, felt under siege in the changing landscape of health care, where managed care and corporate medicine now rule, and doctors often need to be as conversant in the language of business as they are in healing.
So Dr. Walker did what a growing number of doctors are doing: she went back to school -- for a master's in business degree.
Authorities say more and more doctors are doing just that, as universities add or adapt programs to meet doctors' needs. The University of Tennessee, for one, started a program last year; the Boston University School of Management is starting another one in the fall.
Meanwhile, medical schools have created programs for students who want to study for a business degree simultaneously.
The kind of doctor who seeks an M.B.A., moreover, appears to be changing. While the degree is still a pedigree for doctors who aspire to run a hospital or a health maintenance organization, where they may never lay hands on a patient, it is now increasingly attracting doctors who intend to keep practicing.
Some solo practitioners, part of a dwindling breed, also hope a business degree will give them the financial acumen to allow them to survive by teaching them how to run their practices more efficiently. But the investment is considerable, with tuition alone in the tens of thousands of dollars.
Dr. John A. Fromson, vice president of professional development for the Massachusetts Medical Society, said last week that when his organization polled its 17,000 members about whether to begin a business degree program, 10 percent expressed strong interest. The medical society, after fielding inquiries from dozens of business schools, decided to enter into a partnership with Boston University.
"The message was clear that physicians did, indeed, want some sort of business management training," Dr. Fromson said.
Doctors cite numerous reasons for the change. Where once those in small or medium-size practices spent most of their time with patients while clerical staff members handled billing and filed insurance claims, doctors now find themselves having to make business decisions on which the survival of their practices could well hinge.
They must decide, for example, which contracts to accept from managed-care companies. To determine whether the fees offered in a contract will cover their costs, doctors often must do the kind of analyses of their own practices that have more traditionally been used in business settings.
Business schools teach doctors not only the basic principles that allow them to make these calculations, but also about the overall economics of health care and how to work in teams.
Andrew McLean Thomas, an internist from Columbus, Ohio, who graduated from medical school in 1995, decided two years later to get an M.B.A. He is now enrolled at the Fisher College of Business at Ohio State University.
Dr. Thomas said patients could be better served if administrators making broad policy decisions in large health care organizations had not just business degrees but medical ones.
Dr. Thomas, who hopes to treat patients and to work as an administrator, said it was essential in the current changing medical climate for doctors in management positions to have training in business to make decisions that resulted in the best care.
"When it comes to making business decisions, the days of 'I am doctor, therefore I am right, and cost be damned' are out the window," Dr. Thomas said. "Everyone has to understand we're living in an era of constrained resources."
Still, not every doctor is enamored of the trend toward combined degrees.
Leonard Laster, chancellor emeritus of the University of Massachusetts Medical Center, expressed concern about the growing number of doctors who go back to school for business training, questioning whether practicing doctors should adopt the philosophy of business executives.
"The expectation that a single individual can espouse and live by the two incompatible creeds appears unrealistic," Dr. Laster wrote in a 1998 issue of American Medical News, published by the American Medical Association, "and I will not allow my family members to be guinea pigs for testing whether these professional polarities can be successfully used. I say let businessmen be businessmen and pursue profits, and let doctors be doctors and care for patients."
For Dr. Walker, 40, going to business school did present a kind of culture shock. She was the only doctor in the executive M.B.A. program at the University of Chicago, and she quickly had to learn a new way of thinking.
But within a year of graduating from the part-time program, she said, she had recouped the cost of the degree, about $25,000, largely through improved billing and administrative practices.
Dr. Walker says the business training has not affected how she handles her patients.
Instead, she said, by teaching her to be more efficient, the training allows her to use her time the way she wants: spending longer with patients and working two days a week in research.
Still, while she is glad she went back to school, Dr. Walker sounds anything but sanguine about the future.
"I love my small practice," she said. "And so I've decided that I'm just going to give it the best that I can, until I can't do it any longer. And then at that point I will need to join up with a larger group."

HEADLINE: A Familiar Skin Hides an Evolving Space Shuttle

BYLINE: By WARREN E. LEARY 

DATELINE: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., April 30

 BODY:
America's aging space shuttles, often criticized as monuments to 1970's technology, are slowly being replaced by much more modern spacecraft -- themselves.
With the possible exception of a few science fiction counterparts, the nation's fleet of space shuttles, which began flying humans into space 18 years ago, have become the most recognized spaceships in the world. The stubby-winged spaceplanes, with twin rocket boosters and giant fuel tanks strapped to their bellies, appear little changed since the first one flew in 1981. 
 But appearances can be deceiving. The shuttles have been steadily modified during their lifetimes, NASA engineers and managers say, and are much more modern beneath their familiar skin than most people realize.
The shuttles underwent numerous, highly publicized safety modifications after the Challenger explosion in 1986 took the lives of seven crew members. These changes, among thousands of major and minor design modifications that were made since the shuttles started flying, included redesigned solid-fuel booster rockets, more spacecraft sensors and a parachute escape system for the crew.
But later improvements that have not drawn as much attention include new main engines that engineers say are safer and more reliable because they have far fewer welded parts and operate under lower pressures; external fuel tanks made of a new, lighter aluminum-lithium alloy, providing a 7,500-pound weight reduction that translates into increased cargo capacity; improved brakes and the addition of tail parachutes for surer, shorter landings, and added protection against the impact of orbital debris to the leading edges of the wings and heat radiators inside the cargo bay doors.
To illustrate the evolving shuttle, officials at the Kennedy Space Center here showed off the shuttle Atlantis on Thursday, giving journalists unprecedented access to the orbiter, which recently completed a major upgrade. During a 10-month, $70 million overhaul, the Atlantis was taken out of flight rotation and given more than 130 major modifications while being disassembled, cleaned, tested and put back together again. Such reconditioning typically occurs every four or five years.
The 86-ton spaceplane returned to Kennedy last September from a Boeing plant in Palmdale, Calif., weighing 1,000 pounds less and full of enhancements, including a modern cockpit with digital display screens and a new navigation system and other electronics that rival the latest airliners.
"This new cockpit is a major improvement and should make the shuttle much easier and safer to fly," said Col. James D. Halsell Jr. of the Air Force, who will command the Atlantis on its first mission after the overhaul, a supply flight to the international space station tentatively set for December.
Dressed in a white "clean room" suit that includes a hood over his head to prevent stray hairs from contaminating the Atlantis's near-sterile environment, Colonel Halsell showed similarly clad visitors the shuttle's new "glass cockpit." Gone are four black-and-white cathode ray television screens and numerous mechanical instruments and gauges, replaced by an array of color active-matrix displays like those found on portable computers. The nine flat-screen displays in front of the pilots, plus two more in the rear cockpit, can be programmed to show all kinds of flight information and sensor data.
Shuttle pilots said the new displays, each with a square 6.7-inch viewing area showing better organized and color-coded data, should help them to obtain and understand information more quickly during the critical eight-and-a-half-minute trip from takeoff to orbit and subsequent landing.
"The cockpit displays are the most visible sign of changes in the shuttles, but a lot of the other modifications will be of huge benefit to the crews," said Lieut. Col. Scott J. Horowitz, who will pilot the Atlantis on its next flight. "The shuttle will be flying for a long time because nothing else can do its job. This thing will outlive my career and a lot of other people's, too."
With continued updating, officials say, these shuttles could conceivably fly for another 20 or 30 years.
Elric McHenry, the shuttle program development manager, said Congress and the Clinton Administration would soon decide what to do about a replacement for the shuttle. But whatever the decision, he said, the shuttle fleet would continue to fly for at least a decade, and probably longer, because there are no alternatives on the immediate horizon.
"It's prudent for the shuttle program to assume that for the next 10 years, we will be it," Mr. McHenry said at a news briefing, "and I personally believe we will fly much longer than that."
Other space experts agree. Dr. John M. Logsdon, director of the Space Policy Institute at George Washington University in Washington, said that the only shuttle alternatives that existed were on paper and that he believed the current spacecraft would continue flying for 15 to 20 years. "The shuttle is the only re-usable, manned spacecraft that we've got," he said.
John E. Pike, space policy expert for the Federation of American Scientists, said the shuttle could be the spacecraft equivalent of the much-modified B-52 bomber, which the Air Force recently said could remain in service more than 70 years after its introduction. "The shuttle could continue flying like the B-52, with the only limit being its airframe life," Mr. Pike said.
Daniel S. Goldin, the administrator of NASA, said the versatility of the shuttle made it difficult to find alternatives, particularly for servicing the international space station now being constructed in orbit. People have suggested alternative vehicles that would only carry crews to and from the station, or that would serve as unpiloted cargo haulers, but no proposal is up to all the shuttle's jobs, he told reporters last month.
"The shuttle is a rocket for eight-and-a-half minutes capable of carrying a crew and cargo, but the shuttle is also a spacecraft that can operate independently in space for 8 to 14 days," Mr. Goldin said. If a major problem occurred aboard the space station that required outside repairs, he said, there would be a need for a craft like the shuttle, in which crews could live and work for long periods.
Officials noted that the shuttle fleet was still less than one-fourth of the way through its design lifetime and that continued modernization was making it safer, more capable and less expensive to fly with each year. Each of the $2 billion shuttles was designed for 100 flights and the most used orbiters, the Columbia and Discovery, had so far flown 25 missions each.
While the shuttles technically could fly for 30 more years with updating, Mr. McHenry said the program probably would not last that long for economic reasons. As new technology, like different types of engines or electronics, emerges for better, cheaper spacecraft, he said, it might make more economic sense to apply it to a new vehicle rather than adapt it to the shuttles.
NASA spends about $100 million a year to develop and install modifications and upgrades for the orbiter fleet, Mr. McHenry said. For example, the agency spent about $200 million to develop the equipment and software for the new cockpit, he said, including $9 million to install it in Atlantis. It should cost slightly less to put the new flight deck into each of the other shuttles as they come up for refitting.
Mr. McHenry said NASA was considering numerous other modifications, including installing a new system of jets, using less toxic fuels, to control the shuttles in space, improving the life of the fuel cells that generate electricity on missions and developing a new front landing gear for better safety under hazardous landing conditions.
Even more radical changes have been suggested, like replacing the solid-fuel booster rockets with safer, liquid-fuel boosters designed to fly back to their launching site. But with a projected development cost of more than $5 billion, experts question whether the investment would be worth it.

The revamped Atlantis, above, has a modern cockpit with digital display screens and other electronics that rival the latest airliners. (Photographs by NASA)(pg. F2)

HEADLINE: Can Russia Be an Ally We Can Depend On?

 BODY:

To the Editor:
A May 2 Week in Review article asks whether the United States wants a strong or a weak Russia. The answer should be that we want a Russia -- weak or strong -- that will be a responsible international player. 
 NATO's war with Serbia comes at the same time as Russia's economic collapse and NATO's expansion. Thus, we must take particular care not to wind up with a new cold war. To that end we should facilitate and enhance Russia's role as a peacemaker in Kosovo. The best end would be similar to Bosnia, where Russian troops participate in a peacekeeping operation.
After Kosovo, we should strengthen Russia's ties to NATO while recognizing that our interests and Russia's will not always coincide. In the Caspian region we should include Russia in the pipeline networks, thus diminishing incentives for Moscow to destabilize other Caspian states.
 
CAROL R. SAIVETZ
Cambridge, Mass., May 2, 1999
 
The writer is a research associate at the Davis Center for Russian Studies at Harvard University.

HEADLINE: Debt Relief for Poorest

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "Poor Nations and the Debt Trap" (editorial, April 30):
Providing debt relief to the poorest countries would not only increase primary school enrollment, but it would also save lives. Fourteen percent of children in Tanzania reportedly die before age 5, and 40 percent of Tanzania's population dies by age 35, yet the country spends nine times more on foreign debt payments than on health care. 
 The debt relief bill introduced in Congress would require each country receiving debt relief to establish a human development fund to hold the debt relief savings. The use of the fund would be restricted to reducing the number of people living in poverty, expanding access to education and health care, and preventing environmental degradation. The bill excludes countries that support international terrorism or that have excessive military spending, gross violations of human rights, or drug trafficking.
 
ELLEN J. FISHER
Cedar Rapids, Iowa, May 1, 1999

HEADLINE: Several Big Auto Makers Posted Robust April Sales

BYLINE: By ROBYN MEREDITH 

DATELINE: DETROIT, May 3

 BODY:
In a further sign of consumers' willingness to keep spending in a robust economy, auto sales maintained their sizzling pace in April.
The Ford Motor Company, DaimlerChrysler A.G., Toyota, Honda and Nissan, along with a number of smaller auto makers, reported strong sales today, and the industry as a whole is on track to match or beat its vigorous sales pace of last April. 
 Ford said its sales rose 6.6 percent last month to 345,672 compared with the corresponding period a year ago. Those figures included Volvo sales, since Ford's acquisition of the Swedish car maker was completed March 31. Excluding Volvo's results, Ford's sales rose 4.1 percent, with car sales falling 1 percent and sales of sport utility vehicles, minivans and pickup trucks rising 7.8 percent.
DaimlerChrysler said sales at its American unit, Chrysler, rose 2 percent, to 225,195. Mercedes-Benz sales dropped eight-tenths of 1 percent in the United States last month. Excluding the Mercedes results, DaimlerChrysler's car sales rose 5.9 percent and its truck sales edged up four-tenths of 1 percent to record levels.
Honda sales have set records each month this year. In April, sales rose 4 percent, to 90,352. Honda's car sales fell 3.1 percent but were offset by a 52.9 percent rise in truck sales. "Confidence in the economy remains strong and continues to drive consumer demand for big-ticket items," said Dick Colliver, executive vice president for American Honda.
Toyota sales rose 9.6 percent, to 118,833. Nissan sales rose 21.5 percent, to 47,243. "There's a lot to celebrate," said David Bradley, an auto analyst at J. P. Morgan Securities Inc.
Auto stocks generally rose today. Ford was up $2.75, to $66.6875, and DaimlerChrysler increased $1.9375, to $100.125.
The General Motors Corporation is scheduled to report its April sales results Tuesday. G.M. put on hefty discounts last April, which jump-started its sluggish sales, and will have a tough time improving on its results year-over-year. Indeed, Wall Street analysts expect G.M.'s sales to drop as much as 3 percent. Mr. Bradley said that "even if the numbers are down a bit, they would still be very strong numbers." Shares rose $4.6875, to $93.75.
Month after month, this year's auto sales results have surprised even the experts: auto industry economists have repeatedly raised their industry sales forecasts.
"I've been doing it pretty much every month this year as the results kept coming in stronger and stronger," said W. Van Bussmann, corporate economist at DaimlerChrysler. In December, he predicted the industry would sell 14.8 million cars, trucks, minivans and sport utility vehicles this year. He has raised his forecast four times since then, to 15.6 million cars and trucks.
Economists at Ford and General Motors have also increased their estimates. Ford began the year predicting the industry would sell between 14.6 million and 15.1 million cars and light trucks this year. In mid-March, it added a half-million vehicles, and just a few weeks after that said sales would likely fall at the top end of the range, or 15.6 million, in line with Chrysler's predictions.
G.M.'s forecast mirrored Ford's at the beginning of the year, and economists there now expect the industry to sell between 15.3 million and 15.9 million cars and light trucks this year.
During the first quarter, sales reached an annual pace of 16.6 million, well above last year's first-quarter sales of 14.9 million. Even if the pace slows somewhat later this year, the industry could break its all-time sales record of 16 million cars and light trucks, set in 1986. "It certainly is a possibility that we'll exceed that 1986 record," said Ellen Hughes-Cromwick, a senior economist at Ford.

HEADLINE: Still Opposed, Planners Let Airport Link Go Ahead

BYLINE: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN 

 BODY:
After voicing nearly unanimous disdain for a Port Authority plan to build a rail link to Kennedy International Airport, the New York City Planning Commission authorized the city yesterday to acquire several properties that will allow the project to proceed.
The commissioners expressed many concerns about the $1.5 billion light-rail plan, including fears that it would cost too much to build and to operate. Some commissioners also said they were afraid it would not appeal to nearly as many riders as predicted, because Manhattan passengers would have to switch trains at the Long Island Rail Road station in Jamaica, Queens. The commission said the proposed $5 ticket price would also discourage use. 
 Then, speaking just as firmly as when they were stating their reservations, 12 of the 13 commissioners said that the Kennedy rail line was of critical importance to the city's future and that therefore they would not deny the city's application to acquire the several properties between the railroad station and the airport and turn them over to the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. Instead, they urged the Port Authority to rethink the plan.
The chairman, Joseph B. Rose, and other members said the panel was primarily responsible for determining whether the city was justified in seeking to acquire the properties, which left the commissioners room to approve the plan despite their serious reservations.
"This is without question the most difficult vote that I have been asked to make in my five years as a member of this commission," Mr. Rose said at the commission's meeting yesterday. "The Department of City Planning, this Planning Commission, myself personally, this administration, believe that meaningful access to our airports, especially J.F.K., is one of the most important single things that can be done for our economic future."
Mr. Rose said New York was perhaps the world's only major urban center without a direct train link to its major airports. But he added, "At the same time, this project as currently conceived is clearly not a successful project. It will not provide the level of service, it will not provide the access to the airport that this city, that this region, has a right to expect."
Explaining his reasoning for voting to let the project go ahead, he said, "We have the procedural good fortune, I think, on this commission to be asked to vote not on whether we think this project is a good project, but on whether it is appropriate for the city to convey the properties." Only one commissioner, Kathy H. Chin, voted against the plan.
The Planning Commission's vote means that the City Council can consider the rail plan, and the Council Speaker, Peter F. Vallone, said he would call it up next week.
"The massive size and scope of this project warrants our full attention and review, and its impacts must be examined and discussed openly and publicly," Mr. Vallone said in statement yesterday.
The Port Authority plan calls for a 3.4-mile rail line joining Kennedy's nine terminals to one another. A three-mile line would connect the terminals to parking lots, rental car agencies and the Howard Beach station of the A subway line.
The most controversial part of the plan is another three-mile line, elevated 55 feet and running down the center of the Van Wyck Expressway and connecting the airport with the Jamaica station, where passengers could transfer to the Long Island Rail Road, the E, J and Z subway lines and to various bus lines.
Queens civic groups are almost universally opposed, fearing noise and traffic disruptions from years of construction, but the plan has received some community support because it is to include renovation and expansion of the Jamaica station.
Neither Mr. Vallone nor his aides would speculate on what the Council will do at next week's meeting, but a Council report issued last month raised a number of concerns about the project, including the suggestion that a rail link to La Guardia Airport was needed more.
The report also concluded that the Port Authority's "assumption that the Van Wyck el would stimulate development where none had existed before is unsupported by any previous experience in New York City."

HEADLINE: 3 Sets of Data Are Positive For Economy

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 3

 BODY:
Manufacturing grew in April for the third consecutive month, and personal income and spending and construction spending all rose in March, a private industry survey and Government reports showed today.
"The economy looks like it still has lots of momentum," said Cynthia Latta, an economist at Standard & Poor's DRI in Lexington, Mass. "Manufacturing looks reasonably good. Consumer spending is rising. Housing is strong." 
 The National Association of Purchasing Management's factory index was 52.8 last month. While that was down from a March reading of 54.3, it was still the third consecutive monthly reading above 50, indicating more businesses reported improved conditions than showed declines.
Personal incomes of Americans rose four-tenths of a percent in March after rising five-tenths of a percent in February, the Commerce Department said. Personal spending also rose four-tenths of a percent in March after increasing eight-tenths of a percent in February.
In another report, the Commerce Department said construction spending rose five-tenths of a percent in March, to a record $708.1 billion at a seasonally adjusted annual rate, paced by record spending on residential and road projects.
The March rise in personal spending was restrained by a drop in demand for automobiles, while consumers bought more nondurable goods like clothing. The gain in income for the month was limited by a rise of three-tenths of a percent in wages, the smallest since September. That was partly attributable to the first drop in wages for manufacturing, mining and agriculture jobs since June 1998.
The cooling of the purchasing managers' index in April was attributed to small declines in new orders and production. Still, the decrease was the first this year and came after a nine-point increase during the first quarter. That was the largest increase since the second quarter of 1991, when the current economic expansion was just beginning.
Much of the strength of the expansion, now a record for peacetime, comes from growing consumer demand. With an abundance of jobs and rising incomes, consumers spent at the fastest pace in 11 years during the first quarter. That propelled the economy to a 4.5 percent annual growth rate in the first three months of the year after a 6 percent gain in last year's final quarter.
Still, the rebound in manufacturing in the first quarter is expected to take some time getting on its feet. Last year's slump was caused in part by a drop in exports, the first in 13 years. Recessions in Japan and elsewhere cut international demand for American-made products.
"Manufacturing was so badly beaten up last year that manufacturers aren't going to make a big commitment" to adding workers or increasing output, said Christopher Low, an economist at First Tennessee Capital Markets in New York.
On the inflation front, the purchasers association reported its index of prices paid rose to 49.9 in April from 43.2 during March, an indication that more companies reported price increases during the month.
Oil prices rose for a second month in April, topping $18 a barrel for the first time since February 1998, after petroleum exporters agreed to production cuts. In New York today, oil rose 19 cents, to $18.85 a barrel.
Rising oil prices will add to manufacturers' production costs, hurting profit margins and pushing customer prices higher, Ms. Latta said.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Succession Fight Roils World Trade Organization

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH OLSON 

DATELINE: GENEVA, May 3

 BODY:
A leadership crisis disrupted operations of the World Trade Organization today after weekend negotiations collapsed, with no breakthrough in sight.
Supporters of the New Zealand and Thai finalists for the post of director general at the 134-nation group both insisted their candidate should win. 
 Diplomats fear that the brawl at the four-year-old organization, which makes rules and arbitrates disagreements in international commerce, could stall resolution of many trade disputes and jeopardize preparations for new trade talks set for Seattle in November.
"Whether this is resolved quickly or without blood on the floor, it could impact on the climate for preparations," said Pakistan's trade envoy, Munir Akram, whose country backs the Thai candidate. Carlos Perez del Castillo, Uruguay's top trade delegate, who backs the candidate from New Zealand, said, "The W.T.O. is absolutely paralyzed."
Under the organization's rules, the term of the outgoing Director General, Renato Ruggiero of Italy, which was to expire Friday, was extended through today because a successor had not been chosen. He appointed a caretaker administrator to handle routine chores, but only a new director general can make important decisions, such as selecting arbitrators for disputes and admitting new members.
Animosity over who would replace Mr. Ruggiero first broke into the open Friday when the organization's selection committee said one candidate, Mike Moore, a former New Zealand Prime Minister, had the highest and broadest geographical support among member nations. Supporters of Mr. Moore's rival, Supachai Panitchpakdi, Thailand's Deputy Prime Minister and Commerce Minister, furiously rejected the choice, contending that the 62-to-59 vote tally among member countries was dubious and too close to declare Mr. Moore victorious.
 Groups of countries supporting each candidate caucused today, each accusing the other of hardball tactics. On Sunday, countries backing Mr. Moore urged delegates not to resort to a precedent-setting and potentially divisive vote that Mr. Supachai's supporters are demanding.
 The trade organization has sought to avoid a formal vote for fear that it could set big trading powers like the United States and the European Union against the smaller, but more numerous, developing countries, creating polarizing frictions that would undermine its legitimacy. Traditionally, the organization tries to make important decisions by consensus.
Both finalists insisted they would fight to the end, suggesting there was no room for compromise. "We are not pulling out," Mr. Supachai said. Mr. Moore, in a telephone interview from New Zealand's mission in Geneva, said: "We're stronger than before. The issue now is whether you support the rules or not."
A group of countries backing Mr. Moore, which included Uruguay, Venezuela, France, Turkey and Sweden, issued a statement urging Mr. Supachai to withdraw. "If Moore is vetoed, there is no way Supachai will be the next director general," said Mr. Perez del Castillo of Uruguay.
 Mr. Supachai's backers, led by developing countries, have become increasingly angry over what they view as a bias against him by the large trading powers, particularly the United States. Zimbabwe's envoy, T. J. B. Jokonya, complained Saturday that a "most deadly arsenic diatribe was unleashed on those who dared to oppose the wish of the anointed." He was referring to efforts by supporters of Mr. Moore to defeat Mr. Supachai..
 Many nations supporting Mr. Supachai were stunned at the choice of the selection committee because the 52-year-old Thai economist had reportedly been ahead since the process of country-by-country consultation got under way last fall. Many believed the selection was purposely delayed in order to garner more support for Mr. Moore, 50.
"The big boys thought it would all be decided behind closed doors, like last time," Mr. Akram of Pakistan said. "But the W.T.O. has evolved and it's time for a developing country choice."
 In Bangkok, politicians argued that it was time to review ties with the United States.
 Japan, an influential supporter of Mr. Supachai, was sticking by its candidate. Yoichi Suzuki, a trade diplomat from Japan, said, "We have more problems with the process than the candidate."
 Mr. Suzuki said the vote tally announced Friday "shows that it's finely balanced," adding, "You can't tell who is winning."

HEADLINE: Ernest Gross, a Key Diplomat During Cold War, Dies at 92

BYLINE: By MICHAEL T. KAUFMAN 

 BODY:
Ernest A. Gross, a diplomat and an international lawyer who was closely involved in issues of war and peace from the Korean War to decolonization and disarmament, died on Sunday at his home in New York City. He was 92.
Mr. Gross, whose life as a diplomat began in 1931, when he joined the State Department as legal adviser, went on to serve as a delegate to the United Nations during a particularly tense period in 1950. Later, he was legal counsel to Ralph Bunche, then Assistant Secretary General of the United Nations, who was called before panels investigating his loyalty during the McCarthy period, and to the United Nations Secretary General, Dag Hammarskjold. In 1948, Mr. Gross was among those who introduced a convention against genocide to the United Nations, and in the 1960's, while in private practice, he brought a suit in the World Court against the South African Government for its policies of apartheid. 
 But the most dramatic period in Mr. Gross's long public career took place soon after he was appointed by Secretary of State Dean Acheson to be America's deputy delegate to the United Nations on Oct. 11, 1949. Two months later, Warren Austin, the chief delegate, took a leave of absence and Mr. Gross, a soft-spoken and scholarly professional, took over the effort to parry Soviet attempts to transfer China's United Nations seat to the Communists, who had just won the civil war, from Chiang Kai-shek's Nationalists, who had just fled the mainland for Taiwan.
It was on Jan. 13, 1950, when Mr. Gross was attending his first meeting of the Security Council, that Jacov Malik, the Soviet delegate, walked out of a discussion over China's representation. For reasons that have generated wonder and debate ever since, Mr. Malik stayed away from the Council in protest for months. He was still absent on June 25, when North Korea invaded the South. By the end of that day, the Security Council, unrestrained by the threat of a Soviet veto, condemned the North Korean attack and called for the withdrawal of Kim Il Sung's forces.
Many years later, Mr. Gross discussed what seemed to be Mr. Malik's extraordinary blunder, which allowed the United Nations not merely to vote for a peacekeeping force, but to brand one warring party as the initiator of conflict and commit unequivocal support to the other side.
"I think the Soviets felt they had very little, if anything, to worry about," Mr. Gross said in 1975. "They did not anticipate that the Security Council would take action."
In the fall, Mr. Austin returned to take over the American delegation again and Mr. Gross resumed work as his deputy, leaving in 1953 to enter private practice as a partner in the law firm Curtis, Mallet-Prevost, Colt & Mosle. He remained affiliated with the firm until his death.
Mr. Gross was born in Brooklyn on Sept. 23, 1906. He attended De Witt Clinton High School in the Bronx and went on to Harvard College, where he graduated in 1927. After studying and rowing at Oxford University, he returned to Harvard for Law School and met Kathryn Watson, the daughter of Senator James Watson, Republican of Indiana. They were married in 1933.
That same year, Mr. Gross left the State Department and signed on as a division counsel for the National Recovery Administration, the agency coordinating President Franklin D. Roosevelt's anti-Depression strategies. A year later, Mr. Gross left Government service and served as counsel for the National Association of Manufacturers. In 1940, he returned to public life, as associate counsel for the National Labor Relations Board.
"I was the only living man who ever went from the N.A.M. to the N.L.R.B.," said Mr. Gross, speaking of the two organizations, the first of which scorned labor unions while the other empowered them.
In 1943, he was commissioned as a captain in the Army, and then promoted to lieutenant colonel when he served the chief of the economic section of the Civil Affairs Division of the War Department General Staff. With peace he returned to the State Department, serving as deputy to the Assistant Secretary of State for Occupied Areas. From 1948 until 1953, he was with the United Nations.
But some of that involvement with the world body spanned a much longer time. For example, it was Mr. Gross who, representing the United States, signed the United Nations Genocide convention in 1948. On the eve of the General Assembly vote, he had urged approval for the treaty "before the memory of recent horrifying genocidal acts has faded from the minds and conscience of man."
The vote passed but it would take another four decades years before the United States would ratify the convention. In 1985, Mr. Gross, a prolific and lifelong writer of letters to editors, felt impelled to write a letter to The New York Times rejecting the reservations to ratification that had been raised in an Op-Ed article by Senator Orrin G. Hatch. "The convention should have been ratified long ago," Mr. Gross wrote.
In addition to his wife, he is survived by three children, Suzanne Wolff of Baltimore, Peter W. Gross of San Francisco and Catherine Gross of New York, and 10 grandchildren.

HEADLINE: With Budget Cutting, Medicare Spending Fell Unexpectedly

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 3

 BODY:
New Government data show that Medicare spending actually declined in the first half of the current fiscal year.
Congress and President Clinton clamped down on Medicare spending in the Balanced Budget Act of 1997, curbing payments for many services. They expected to slow the growth of Medicare. But for the six months ended March 31, Medicare spending was in fact $2.6 billion less than the $106.5 billion spent in the similar period the previous year, according to data from the Treasury Department. 
 With cuts proving deeper than Congress intended, health care providers of all types are furiously lobbying Congress to restore money cut from their payments. They are competing with Medicare beneficiaries who want to use the same pot of money for new benefits, especially coverage of prescription drugs, now a major out-of-pocket expense for the elderly and disabled.
Medicare spending has risen continually since the program began in 1965, and Federal officials had predicted that the growth would pick up again this year after it slowed to 1.5 percent last year. But so far the predictions are wrong.
Hanns Kuttner, an expert on health policy who worked in the Bush Administration, said, "This defies the first principle of Medicare policy analysis: that Medicare costs will always rise faster than the rate of inflation."
Senator John B. Breaux, the Louisiana Democrat who headed a bipartisan commission on the future of Medicare, said, "We're now starting to feel the pinch from the Medicare cuts required in the balanced budget agreement, and I fear the worst is yet to come."
Doctors, hospitals, physical therapists, home health agencies, nursing homes and health maintenance organizations have deployed a small army of lobbyists, seeking to persuade Congress to rewrite or repeal parts of the 1997 law. Home health care and nursing homes have been hit particularly hard. As a result of the cuts, they contend, patients have less access to some types of care, like home health services in some parts of the country, and the quality of care has begun to erode.
Medicare is clearly spending less than Congress anticipated. In the spring of 1997, before passage of the Balanced Budget Act, the Congressional Budget Office predicted that Medicare would spend $1,348 billion on health care for the elderly and disabled from 1998 to 2002. About 39 million people are now enrolled in Medicare. After the law was signed, in a spirit of bipartisan celebration in August 1997, the budget office revised its estimate, predicting that Medicare spending would total $1,249 billion in that five-year period.
Now the budget office is predicting that Medicare will spend $1,146 billion in that period, a huge amount of money but much less than anticipated just two years ago.
Dr. Jordan J. Cohen, president of the Association of American Medical Colleges, said, "There was a gross underestimate of the savings from the Balanced Budget Act."
Kenneth E. Raske, president of the Greater New York Hospital Association, said, "Congress really overshot the runway when it passed the law."
Several other factors have helped stop the growth of Medicare. A Federal crackdown on fraud and abuse has made doctors, hospitals and home health agencies more cautious in the claims they submit to Medicare, so they are less likely to overcharge the Government.
In addition, Medicare and its contractors are taking more time to review and pay claims. The contractors are moving more slowly because they have adopted new safeguards to detect fraud, and because they are preoccupied with getting Medicare computers ready for the year 2000.
In the past, when Congress cut Medicare payments for one service, health care providers often responded by providing more of another service, for which money continued to flow freely. But this has become difficult because Congress in 1997 cut back Medicare payments for almost all types of health care services.
"The law had more synergy than we expected," said Gail R. Wilensky, chairwoman of the Medicare Payment Advisory Commission, an independent body that advises Congress.
Medicare spending for home health care fell nearly 15 percent last year, to $14.9 billion, and the Congressional Budget Office now says home health agencies will get a total of $79 billion from 1998 to 2002, or $48 billion less than the office predicted in January 1997.
Medicare payments to skilled nursing homes rose 8.9 percent last year, to $13.2 billion, but the budget office foresees a decline of 3.8 percent this year. The budget office now says nursing homes will get $66.7 billion from 1998 to 2002, or $16.6 billion less than the office predicted in January 1997.
Federal officials have drafted a letter to state officials saying that some nursing homes face "drastic declines in revenues" and "may suddenly close their doors, potentially placing residents at risk." Spokesmen for nursing home chains agree and are pleading with Congress for more money. But an increase for any group will be difficult.
"In a political sense, there's only a certain amount of money available for Medicare," said John C. Rother, chief lobbyist for AARP, formerly known as the American Association of Retired Persons. "To the extent it goes to providers, then it's not available for additional benefits."
Asked whether the 1997 law was squeezing Medicare payments more than expected, Dr. Wilensky said, "In the short run, the answer is definitely yes."
The Congressional Budget Office predicts that, despite "the sudden flattening of Medicare expenditures" in the last year, annual outlays will more than double in the next decade and will exceed $400 billion by 2008. By then there will be more than 44 million beneficiaries.
"The anticipated growth," it said, "reflects advances in medical technology that are expected to raise health care costs and a continued increase in the use of services by beneficiaries."

HEADLINE: TRACK AND FIELD;
Taking the Long Way

BYLINE: By JERE LONGMAN 

 BODY:
Haile Gebrselassie, the world's greatest distance runner, arrived in Manhattan yesterday after a 16-hour flight from Ethiopia and made plans for an easy jog to stretch his legs. Of course, for him, easy means an hour running the roller-coaster hills of Central Park.
"I know Central Park is where the New York Marathon ends," the 26-year-old Gebrselassie said. "I want to run the marathon here. If you win New York, it is like winning the Olympics." 
 This season, Gebrselassie will embark on an ambitious, unprecedented campaign to eventually gain world records at every distance from 3,000 meters to the marathon. Already, he has run the fastest times ever at 5,000 and 10,000 meters. By late June, he would like to add the 3,000 and two-mile records to his resume. And after the 2000 Summer Olympics in Sydney, Australia, where he figures to defend the gold medal at 10,000 meters that he won in Atlanta in 1996, Gebrselassie will turn to the event that means everything in Ethiopia -- the marathon.
Until he wins a marathon -- as Abebe Bikila did at the 1960 Rome Olympics and the 1964 Summer Games in Tokyo, as Mamo Wolde did in Mexico City in 1968, as Fatuma Roba did in the women's race in Atlanta -- Gebrselassie jokes that his countrymen will consider him a mere sprinter. "I have to run the marathon because of the people," Gebrselassie said. "That's all they think about, the marathon. They don't understand the 5,000 and 10,000. When I win, they say, 'Haile, where did you get that record in the marathon?' That is their race."
He has interrupted his training this week to promote an autobiographical movie called, "Endurance," which was made by Disney and directed by Leslie Woodhead. It opens May 14 in New York and Los Angeles under the billing of a "nonfiction feature."
The movie features not actors, but members of Gebrselassie's family, who portray their own lives or stand in for close relatives. A nephew of Gebrselassie plays him as a youngster; he plays himself as an adult. An older sister plays his late mother. His father is in the movie, along with his wife, Alem. As actors they are remarkably natural, having grown up in a culture without television. Not trained how to act like someone else, they act inconspicuously like themselves.
The film's title refers not only to the stamina of distance running but to the harsh subsistence living in one of the world's poorest countries. Athletes from developing nations now dominate everything beyond the sprints, perhaps, in part, because they are unaccustomed to affluence and willing to accommodate suffering and deprivation. The movie recounts, with spare dialogue and lush cinematography, Gebrselassie's upbringing on a peasant farm in East Africa -- running six miles to school, walking three hours round trip to find water, living in a hut made of mud and cow dung, ignoring a stern father who wanted him to be a clerk or a lawyer, losing a loving mother who died when he was a boy.
The funeral of his mother -- who was carried from home on a bed to a bus, which took her to a hospital and away from her family forever -- was so real and painful for Gebrselassie's father, that he asked that it not be included in the film.
"We still have not shown him that part," Gebrselassie said.
The movie's climax consists of suspenseful footage of Gebrselassie's victory in the 10,000 meters at the Atlanta Olympics, shot by the Olympic documentarian Bud Greenspan. The 25-lap event was ignored by NBC, which apparently doubted its audience's long-distance attention span, but on the big screen the audience is allowed to hear the runners breathe, to sense their determination and to watch the sweat-drenched strategy unfold.
The 5-foot-3-inch Gebrselassie bided his time, running on the balls of his feet, his head perfectly still, his arms carried high and pumping economically, his barrel chest extended, a fluttering lower lip the only sign of exertion. Then, on the final lap, he broke into a sprint, and a sort of death-mask smile creased his face as he neared the finish, looking repeatedly over his shoulder and realizing that his Kenyan challenger could not catch him. His feet were so blistered by the hard running surface that he took the victory stand wearing shower clogs.
This is the form that has carried him to world records in the 5,000 (12 minutes 39.36 seconds) and 10,000 (26:22.75), and that will challenge the records of Daniel Komen of Kenya, who has run the 3,000 in 7:20.67 and two miles in 7:58.61. At high altitude in Addis Ababa, the Ethiopian capital, Gebrselassie has been honing his speed work -- 3x2,000 in 5:05; 4x1,000 in 2:26; 3x800 in 1:53; 3x600 in 1:25; 3x400 in 53 seconds; 5x200 in 24 seconds.
"The two-mile is not so hard, but the 3,000 is a tough record," said Gebrselassie, whose best of 7:25.09 in the latter is nearly five seconds slower than Komen's best. "Maybe it is easier for a 1,500-meter runner moving up."
After Sydney, he said, he will dispense with the track to concentrate on the marathon. The possibilities of Gebrselassie in the marathon have the sport hyperventilating. He said he will likely run first in Rotterdam, the Netherlands, in the spring of 2001, and that he would also like to run New York, Boston, Tokyo and London. The marathon at the 2004 Olympics in Athens "will be my last competition," Gebrselassie said. "I will be 32; I will have to stop."
 There are those who believe that he can chop two minutes off the world record of 2 hours 6 minutes 5 seconds, held by Ronaldo da Costa of Brazil. Gebrselassie agrees that he will have to alter his style, that he cannot run like a sprinter, on the balls of his feet, for 26.2 miles.
"I'm sure I can change," Gebrselassie said. "When you run longer and become more tired, you use your whole foot. In my opinion, I can run a very good marathon."
He has run one before, at age 16, when he arrived in Addis Ababa from the countryside for the first time, carrying all of his belongings in a plastic bag. He struggled across the finish line in 2:48, his legs chafed and unable to carry him another step. "My coach tried to stop me during the race," Gebrselassie said. "At the end, he said, 'This is what you want. Are you crazy?' "
Acutely aware of his place in running history, he has collected film dating to the 1908 Summer Olympics. And though he has learned to drive, to keep from being mobbed on the streets in Addis Ababa, he does so sparingly. "Driving makes you lazy," Gebrselassie said. He prefers to travel by foot.
"It is important to get the records if it is possible," he said. "It means you are one of the best."

HEADLINE: De Niro and Miramax Face Problems in Film Studio Plan

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
Although Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, the actor Robert De Niro and Harvey Weinstein of Miramax Films announced a tentative agreement yesterday to build a movie studio at the Brooklyn Navy Yard, major elements of the deal to transform the cavernous shipbuilding complex into a glamorous film factory are not in place.
The proposed $150 million project would turn a 15-acre site on Wallabout Bay into 12 huge sound stages for film and television production and revive the home of Brooklyn's oldest industry, the long-closed 129-year-old Navy Yard. But the economics of such a project and the vagaries of the film industry are daunting. 
 Even as a news conference got under way yesterday near the dry docks at the Navy Yard, Mr. De Niro's company, TriBeCa Productions, and the developer for the project, Vornado Realty Trust, had not signed a letter of intent with city officials, despite repeated attempts during a series of meetings last weekend and yesterday.
Nor had Steven Roth, chairman of Vornado, been able to sign a separate agreement with the movie makers, Mr. De Niro and Mr. Weinstein, co-chairman of Miramax, that detailed the extent of their involvement in the project.
The financing is not quite in place and two men who started the project, Louis Madigan and Cary Hart, are objecting to the city's proposed deal.
That did not stop Mayor Giuliani, Mr. De Niro, Mr. Weinstein and Mr. Roth from declaring their allegiance to Brooklyn and their intentions to build a Hollywood-style studio where tens of thousands of workers once labored. The Mayor, like nearly every other executive or city official who went to the microphone, noted his birth in Brooklyn.
"This facility will allow producers to shoot an entire movie, from start to finish, right here in New York City," Mr. Giuliani said. "It will not only encourage new film production in the city; it will also help revitalize an area that has long been under-used."
Mr. De Niro, whose company produces about five films a year, was equally ebullient. "Everything we would do, we would do here," he said. "That's the whole point. Being part of this is very exciting for me and great for New York."
Sounding a little like the mobster-turned-therapy patient he played in his latest film, "Analyze This," Mr. De Niro added: "I could be wrong a little bit here and there. But you cannot fail in this."
Under the terms of the still-unsigned deal, the venture led by Vornado would invest $35 million. The Fisher real estate family, which owns Plaza Construction, would build the project and become a partner in the deal. The city, in turn, would provide a $25 million low-interest loan, while Brooklyn Navy Yard Development Corporation would put in $8 million more.
The Union Labor Life Insurance Company is considering investing and providing about $82 million in financing, although it has not yet made a commitment. Keyspan Energy, which will build the electrical system, may also invest.
A copy of the proposed letter of intent obtained by The New York Times specifies the role of the city and Vornado but says nothing about the obligations of TriBeCa Productions. Miramax, which shoots 10 to 15 films a year, is not even a signatory.
Randy L. Levine, the Deputy Mayor for economic development, acknowledged that there was still lots of work to be done, including environmental studies and other reviews. "Hopefully," he said, "we'll be back in a year to break ground."
In the last year, nearly a dozen film or television projects have been announced, but nearly all of them have foundered. Sound stages are expensive to build, but film producers, unlike office tenants, rent a studio only for several months and are not willing to pay top dollar.
City officials boast of the surging number of films and television series shot in New York in the last five years, but industry executives contend that many of the major film companies are in the midst of cutbacks. Competition with Toronto and Vancouver has only intensified.
The executives said that the Brooklyn Navy Project might work because it joins real estate executives with film makers.
"It's an expensive business to run and the profit margins are notoriously thin," said Mitchell Brill, executive vice president of the New York Production Alliance, a trade group. "That being said, there are ways to make studios lucrative."
According to executives involved in the Navy Yard project, Mr. Madigan and Mr. Hart have not come to terms with Vornado.
Two weeks ago, Mr. Madigan and Mr. Hart, who were given a 5 percent stake in the latest deal, tried to oust Vornado, which, according to city officials and executives on both sides, had offered them only $2 million. The two men have told friends that they had spent nearly $2.5 million. Last weekend, Mr. Madigan demanded at least $3 million and refused to sign the letter of intent. But a senior City Hall official said the deal would go forward with or without them.

HEADLINE: Some Companies Derail the 'Burnout' Track

BYLINE: By LESLIE KAUFMAN 

 BODY:
Two years ago, Linda Davis, the Great Lakes-area sales manager for Hewlett-Packard, realized she had a crisis on her hands. Her sales team had been chalking up impressive revenues, but the strain of long work hours was showing. There were too many broken marriages, the attrition rate had risen to 20 percent in a tight labor market, and when asked on the annual company survey if they were "experiencing excessive pressure" on the job, more than 50 percent of her workers had said yes.
So when headquarters sought volunteers for an experimental program to reduce and redesign workloads, Ms. Davis jumped. Employees are now asked to set annual goals not only for productivity but for leisure as well. They are expected to meet both, and if they fall short, their supervisors have to answer for it. At monthly meetings, team members are asked to list three business goals and three personal ones. And when a staff member achieves a milestone, such as leaving at 2 P.M. to take a daughter ice skating, co-workers are encouraged to applaud with the same gusto as they would for someone landing an order for laser printers. 
 After nearly a decade of piling on the responsibilities, a smattering of American companies like Hewlett-Packard are beginning to worry about the consequences. Concerns ranging from a lack of creativity to "burnout" -- the point at which an employee becomes too tired to work effectively, or even at all -- have emerged as among the most urgent topics at human resources forums.
The movement to do something about the problem is inchoate -- many companies are talking about it but do not know how to move from their old ways -- but some companies are experimenting with ways to alleviate workloads: everything from limiting work to 40 hours a week to discouraging employees from checking their E-mail and phone messages over the weekend.
At Hewlett-Packard, Ms. Davis acknowledges that the emphasis on leisure has had a noticeable effect on the work side of the equation. Some tasks have been reorganized so they can be shared by 9-to-5 administrative assistants. On the whole, she says, referring to how much an employee can accomplish in a day, "expectations have been lowered." Still, she says, productivity has not suffered where it counts. The Great Lakes area remains a top sales region, and out of a staff of 74, she lost only two people last year, and both of them were promoted within the company. Moreover, several staff members who received outside offers have stayed put, and one top performer who had been lured away by a start-up actually returned.
Unlike the last wave of corporate initiatives aimed at helping employees balance work with their personal lives -- flexible hours, telecommuting, and concierge services -- new programs like Hewlett-Packard's aim for more than convenience. At their most ambitious they address the fundamental problem of how much time a job demands and how to build a life beyond work.
The incidence of burnout has not been measured in any meaningful way, but since the corporate downsizing of the 80's, American workers report feeling more pressed at work. Professionals and managers said they clocked an average of 48 hours a week, according to a 1997 work force study conducted by the Families and Work Institute, a nonprofit research group in New York.
But to judge by anecdotal evidence, a significant subgroup toils upward of 55 hours a week, while part-timers often find themselves putting in more than 35 hours a week. In the automobile and communications industries, hourly wage earners have also seen their week grow as mandatory overtime has become more prevalent.
The main impetus for the current effort to re-evaluate growing workloads is the drum-tight labor market, in which unemployment is at a 30-year low. "These days," says Peter Cappelli, author of "The New Deal of Work: Managing the Market-Driven Workforce" (Harvard Business School Press, 1999), "employees are able to push back a lot more and are much less willing to work themselves to death."
Adjusting to the new environment has been especially difficult for the most demanding employers. The Big Five accounting firms, which are notorious for their grueling hours and travel schedules, have suddenly found that their young, intensively trained staff members are being snatched away. Deborah K. Holms, director of the office for retention at Ernst & Young, hopes the firm's new emphasis on "empathy and humanity" will build loyalty. Pilot programs being tested at the company include "permission" for employees not to answer their voice mail and E-mail over weekends and while on vacation, and "utilization committees" that monitor employee overtime and redistribute work when the total workload consistently registers more than 50 to 55 hours a week.
Beyond the straightforward problem of retention, corporations are motivated by a growing body of research that shows that working long hours over long periods is not necessarily cost-effective. Mindy Fried of the Center for Work and Family at Boston College has been trying to quantify how much money companies lose because of the errors and additional medical claims that result from overly long hours. "The research is pretty clear that as people work over a certain number of hours, productivity goes down, stress goes up, and work isn't as good," she says.
SAS Institute Inc. in North Carolina is a privately held software company that has experienced double-digit sales growth for two decades. It is also something of a workers' paradise, where full-time employees, starting with the chief executive officer, Jim Goodknight, clock in for just 35 hours a week. The company switchboard shuts down at 5 P.M., and the main gate is shut an hour later. Jeffrey Pfeffer, a professor at Stanford Business School, recently studied SAS, which is based in Cary, outside Raleigh. He concluded that not only did the company save tens of millions of dollars each year because its turnover rate was a fraction of the industry average, but it also gained by having more alert, less error-prone programmers.
David Russo, SAS's vice president for human resources, says that five years ago rivals considered the company's 40-hour workweek freakish and impractical, but "in the last two years, we've had 20 companies -- some really big companies -- come down and study what we're doing here."
In Silicon Valley, intense pressure to stay on the technological cutting edge and to maintain high growth rates has made 16-hour days a norm. But after years of trying to entice programmers with idiosyncratic benefits like gourmet kitchens and pet-friendly office spaces, some companies are beginning to create a work pace that is more sustainable over the long term.
John Gage, the chief engineer at Sun Microsystems, the manufacturer of work stations and compatible software, describes his programmers as "lone poets" who get so involved in their work that they often will not leave their screens until the company pries them away. To sway these workaholics, Sun, which is based in Palo Alto, Calif., has developed an informal buddy system under which programmers monitor each other. "That way, if someone disappears into his office for a few days, someone will go rescue him," Mr. Gage explains. The company has also hired a slew of what he euphemistically calls "get a life" counselors, whose job it is to coach code writers on the joys of the real world -- sunlight, bike riding, children.
Nor is the hours backlash limited to professional and managerial employees. Unions say that reducing mandatory overtime has become increasingly important to their members. The United Automobile Workers has made it one of the pillars of its official negotiating platform, proclaiming that "heavy and steady overtime work can lead to depression, fatigue and confusion."
Last year, the Communication Workers of America went on strike against US West until the telephone company agreed to a pay increase and to cut mandatory overtime in half, to a maximum of eight hours a week, by January 2001. Mike Withrow, vice president of C.W.A. Local 7777 in Englewood, Colo., said the time-and-a-half compensation did not make up for the fact that members felt "they didn't have a life."
Still, many workplace experts say they are seeing a lot more talk than action. Jeremy Rifkin, author of "The End of Work," laments, "We still have too many employers who have bought the idea that the only way you get ahead is by chaining your workers to their chairs until they drop."
Sue Meisinger, senior vice president of the Society of Human Resource Managers, says that the same tight labor market that makes companies consider reducing hours also makes them pile on the work. After all, the job has to get done somehow. "Companies see the problem, but they don't know how to fix it," she says. "There is plenty of wringing of hands, but if an employee goes on vacation and there is an emergency, you will call him." The only difference now? The company will "feel guilty" about the intrusion.

SECTION: Section A; Page 22; Column 1; National Desk 

LENGTH: 1499 words

HEADLINE: Two Parties Seek to Exploit a Relentless Boom in the Suburbs

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 3

 BODY:
Anyone perplexed by the amount of time Vice President Al Gore has recently devoted to traffic jams and suburban sprawl should consider this: Fifty years ago fewer than a quarter of Americans lived in the suburbs; now roughly half do. Every 10 years, another 10 members of Congress represent predominantly suburban districts.
As the battle for the Presidency and control of Congress gets under way, that growth is having a more profound effect than ever before on the language and policy proposals of the parties. The focus ranges from education and child rearing, central to the family life that political consultants have identified as a suburban cornerstone, to the interest in controlling sprawl and a search for ways to appeal to the high-technology workers who populate office complexes along suburban beltways. 
 So Al Gore looks at suburban land-use policies. Elizabeth Dole courts suburban women by braving jeers in New Hampshire to defend the ban on assault weapons. And Representative Thomas M. Davis 3d, the new chairman of the House Republican re-election effort, looks for candidates tailored for just such fast-growing areas as his own affluent Virginia district, the 11th, in Fairfax County.
"Clearly where the rubber is hitting the road today is the suburbs," Mr. Davis said.
To show what that could mean to Democrats, whose core voters are in the cities, Al From, president of the centrist Democratic Leadership Council, points to Illinois.
When John F. Kennedy narrowly won the state in the 1960 Presidential election, Mr. From noted in an article in the council's magazine, The New Democrat, Chicago cast 35 percent of the Illinois vote; 26 percent came from the suburbs. In 1996, when President Clinton was re-elected, the suburbs cast 40 percent of the state's vote, Chicago only 20 percent.
"The electorate of the 21st century," Mr. From told Democrats in Idaho recently, "will be more educated, more affluent, more suburban, more independent, less unionized -- unless we can turn that around -- and less urban than the electorate in the 20th century."
But the political alignment of suburban voters also seems to be shifting. Two decades ago suburbanites were considered bedrock Republicans, drawn to the party's message of lower taxes and fewer handouts. Now, as the nation's Levittowns age and events like the shootings in Littleton, Colo., demonstrate that the suburbs are not immune to violence and other problems long familiar to the cities, suburbanites have become more willing to vote Democratic. Mr. Clinton defeated President George Bush in the suburbs in 1992 and made even stronger inroads in 1996, winning crucial suburban counties all across the industrial Midwest and the Northeast.
Suburbs vary immensely, of course, ranging from older communities near the cities to the new strip malls and subdivisions rising from more distant farm fields. But politicians use the term as collective shorthand for key groups of swing voters: married couples with children, the "soccer moms" who were so sought after in the 1996 election, affluent independent voters and the high-technology employees who work miles from any city.
Linda DiVall, the pollster for Mrs. Dole, says the crucial demographic group is parents who have children under 18 living at home.
"They are a little more Republican than Democrat," Ms. DiVall said, "and the candidate that wins this group tends to win the election."
Given all this, politicians are listening closely to voters like those in Montgomery County, a Republican stronghold outside Philadelphia that is home to densely packed brick houses and the swanky Main Line as well. The county backed Mr. Clinton twice and ousted a Republican Congressman last November in favor of Joseph M. Hoeffel, a Democratic county commissioner.
Mr. Hoeffel was sounding out constituents in supermarkets the other day when Joyce Wilson confronted him by a vegetable counter to talk of the school shootings in Colorado.
"I think this country is just kind of crazy the way it is handling guns," said Ms. Wilson, a pastor's assistant. She also deplored the growth in the area's Delaware Valley. "A lot of our town commissioners," she said, "are reluctant to stand up against the builders."
At another supermarket, Lynne Hall, a 52-year-old manager for a medical office, was evidence of how precarious the Democrats' hold on voters like her might be. "I voted for you," she shouted to Mr. Hoeffel, "but I still don't like that President!"
Issues like education, transportation and health care have long been on the national agenda, of course, and have an appeal stretching beyond the suburbs. But the focus on the suburbs -- and thus broadly on middle-class families -- has subtly changed how the issues are discussed.
"It's hard to separate class from geography," said Geoffrey Garin, a Democratic pollster. "Think of where the health care debate has gone. It's not about insuring the uninsured. It's about H.M.O.'s. The debate is about how to treat people who already have insurance."
The same is true with education. Democrats once emphasized education programs for poor children, and Republicans spoke of eliminating the Education Department. Now both parties are gearing the debate toward interests of middle-class families, the Democrats stressing class size and the Republicans offering tax credits for parochial- and private-school tuition.
New this year to the national agenda are issues that appeal almost entirely to suburbanites. Mr. Gore and Democrats like Mr. Hoeffel (pronounced HUFF-uhl) are talking of suburban sprawl, traffic congestion and a need to preserve open space -- matters that are already playing prominently in state and local political races.
With the Vice President at the fore, the Clinton Administration has proposed a $10 billion "livability agenda" that would provide mass transit subsidies and tax credits to support bonding authority for protecting farmland and cleaning up abandoned industrial space.
"The livability issue is huge here," Mr. Hoeffel said, using a map of the county in his district office to point out traffic trouble spots and new development. "The suburban sprawl that we're experiencing is happening all over the country, and suburban people are up in arms."
At least one Republican strategist, Christine Matthews, thinks her party is underestimating the resonance of the issue. "You need to be empathetic to the fact that people are going a little crazy," she said. "You're going out, and all you see are these giant Wal-Marts. They are every few blocks, and it's not the kind of environment people want to live in."
For both parties, the focus on suburbanites poses challenges.
The Republicans' problem, political strategists say, is that many of these voters have been alienated by the religious right's influence on the party. It is no coincidence that a number of the leading Republican Presidential candidates are trying to keep an abortion ban far from the top of the party's 2000 agenda.
Congressman Davis said the party should reach out to the "new economy" workers through free-trade policies and legislation sought by the high-tech industry, including a bill, blocked by Senate Democrats last week, that would limit lawsuits arising from year 2000 computer breakdowns. The measure is opposed by trial lawyers, who are among the Democrats' biggest contributors.
"Instead of putting up issues like gay rights and abortion that split our constituencies," Mr. Davis said, "let's put up issues that split labor from the high-tech sector, lawyers from high tech."
The Democrats, meanwhile, are trying to emphasize their longtime issues like Social Security and Medicare. But they too are placing special emphasis on the suburbs.
"You're talking fundamentally about a suburban voter built around a family life style," said Mark Penn, the pollster for both Mr. Clinton and Mr. Gore, "because people until they have children are much more likely to live in urban areas and then resettle once they have children."
So when Mr. Gore talks of reducing traffic, he frames road congestion as a family issue, speaking of parents "on the car phone talking to their kids, explaining why they can't get home for dinner."
Democrats battled in the last Presidential campaign over whether to stress values or economic issues, and some of them want to make sure that the emphasis on suburban voters does not eclipse the party's traditional concern for the less well off.
"I think we've got a lot of good issues to go after suburban voters," said Representative David R. Obey, Democrat of Wisconsin, "and I think Gore is particularly well positioned to do that. But he ought to be able to walk and chew gum at the same time. I don't see anything that makes it a mortal sin to talk about minimum wage, to talk about health care, to talk about tax fairness, loopholes and all the rest -- the stuff we used to take for granted that Democrats believed in."
