HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Dow Crosses 11,000 Mark Just 24 Days After 10,000
The Dow Jones industrial average blew past the 11,000 mark, just 24 trading days after it topped 10,000 for the first time. The 10 percent move from March 29 was not the fastest such rise in market history, but it was the quickest jump of 10 percent to come during a period of prolonged market strength.
The Dow rose 225.65 points, or 2 percent, to 11,014.69, led by cyclical stocks. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gained 19.45 points, to 1,354.63, but the Nasdaq composite index fell 7.27 points, to 2,535.58, as money moved out of technology shares. Page A1. 

Some Companies Easing Workload
After nearly a decade of piling responsibilities on workers, a smattering of American companies are beginning to worry about the consequences, ranging from a lack of creativity to burnout. And several companies are experimenting with ways to alleviate outsized workloads, including everything from explicitly limiting work to 40 hours a week to discouraging employees from checking their E-mail and phone messages over the weekend. A1.
 
Gumbel Returning to Morning TV
Bryant Gumbel's long-anticipated return to morning television will become official today when CBS announces that he has agreed to become the anchor of a revamped "CBS This Morning" program, which will be in a new studio on Fifth Avenue in New York City at the entrance to Central Park. The new program, with Mr. Gumbel and a still-to-be-named woman co-anchor, is scheduled to start sometime in the fall. C8.
 
Clinton and Obuchi Talk Strategy
President Clinton and Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi of Japan professed to be in agreement on strategies to pull Japan out of a seven-year slump and deregulate its economy. But their meeting underscored how many of Mr. Clinton's initiatives with Tokyo have been sunk by the Japanese recession. A3.
 
Ford Gain Leads Sizzling Auto Sales
Auto sales maintained their sizzling pace in April. Ford reported a 6.6 percent rise, and gains were also reported by DaimlerChrysler, Toyota, Honda, Nissan and several smaller auto makers, putting the industry on track to match or beat its vigorous sales pace of last April. G.M. is to report today. C2.
 
Manufacturing and Income Rise
Manufacturing grew in April for the third consecutive month, and personal income and spending and construction spending all rose in March, a private industry survey and Government reports showed. Personal incomes rose four-tenths of a percent in March after rising five-tenths of a percent in February, the Commerce Department said. C6.
 
Microsoft and U.S. Name Witnesses
Microsoft and the Government released the names of the final witnesses each intends to call when the antitrust trial resumes later this month. The list indicates that the Government hopes to shore up its case, while Microsoft's goal, at least in part, is to argue that America Online's purchase of Netscape Communications undercuts the Government's case. C2.
 
Vencor Plans to Miss Debt Payment
Vencor, one of the largest operators of nursing homes, said it would not pay $14.8 million due in interest on $300 million of notes that mature in 2005, providing new fodder for investor concerns about its ability to survive. C2.
 
Nortel Seeks Improved Fiber Optics
Nortel Networks plans to announce today that it has developed a product that could increase the capacity of fiber optic communications networks. C7.

HEADLINE: Japan Recession Stifles Trade Climate, if Not Summit Talk

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 3

 BODY:
President Clinton and Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi of Japan professed fundamental agreement today on strategies to pull Japan from a seven-year slump and deregulate its economy. But their daylong meeting underscored how many of Mr. Clinton's once ambitious economic initiatives with Tokyo have been sunk by the Japanese recession.
Mr. Obuchi, the sixth Prime Minister Mr. Clinton has dealt with in six years, spent all morning at the White House, talking about the containment of North Korea, deregulation and Japanese aid to Kosovars. 
 He and the President then announced agreement on deregulating a range of Japanese industries, from telecommunications to medical equipment. For example, foreign companies will now be able to own 100 percent of cable television operations in Japan, and foreign telecommunications companies will be guaranteed more fairly priced rates to connect into Japan's domestic telephone network.
At a news conference, Mr. Clinton went out of his way to praise Mr. Obuchi while pressing him to "use all available tools to restore solid growth."
Mr. Clinton's aides said they feared that any of the benefits of Japan's Government spending program to spur the world's second-largest economy has been undercut by the unwillingness of many Japanese companies and consumers to spend. And they acknowledged that today's deregulatory accord would mean little if Japan's economy kept contracting.
In fact, the Japanese recession has changed the nature of meetings between Japan's leaders and Mr. Clinton. The President came into office promising to exert great pressure on Japan, open its markets and invoke sanctions if Japan's bureaucracy stood in the way. But that energy was spent after the United States and Japan battled over an accord on automotive trade in 1994, and it has never really recovered.
The auto agreement was the first big effort by the Clinton Administration to clear away regulatory hurdles that American manufacturers had complained about for years. But although the agreement led to some changes in Japanese regulations, the economic benefits Mr. Clinton had envisioned never materialized.
For example, under that agreement the Administration once boasted that the Big Three auto companies would be displaying their cars in more than 1,000 Japanese showrooms by this year. They are now in 193 showrooms, the United States Trade Representative's office says -- scarcely more than when the accord was signed. Sales of cars manufactured by Ford, GM and DaimlerChrysler are down by 34 percent in the first quarter of this year, compared with the same quarter in 1998. That is a far steeper falloff than the one in overall Japanese car sales -- yet President Clinton, who was briefed on the decline, never mentioned it in today's meeting, according to participants.
"There's a lot of Japan fatigue around here," one senior Administration official said today, "and it was evident in the meetings. There comes a moment when you recognize that while you've made some progress, it's hard to provide much proof that American workers or companies are going to benefit anytime soon."
In fact, the most notable shift in recent times is the absence of pressure from the business community for more openings into Japan.
American auto executives are virtually silent about Japan these days, and DaimlerChrysler walked away recently from a chance to take a big stake in the ailing Nissan Motor Corporation, the second-largest Japanese manufacturer. Estimates from private economists that Japan will be lucky to grow at 1 or 2 percent annually over the next decade have scared away many American companies, even though the cost of buying land for factories in Japan has not been this low in decades.
The result is an astounding turnaround: American companies are turning their backs on 120 million of the world's richest consumers, at the very moment that the Japanese Government says, for the first time since before World War II, that it is actively seeking American investors.
Mr. Obuchi argues that deregulation is critical to reviving Japanese industry, and many Japanese executives agree. His Economic Strategy Council -- made up of business executives, former bureaucrats and other influential Japanese -- recently circulated in Japanese and English a report detailing laws and regulations that should be swept away. They ranged from proposals to establish high-technology businesses to the development of bankruptcy laws that would allow the sell-off of assets of unsustainable businesses.
Japan experts note that similar reports have been prepared in Japan since the early 1980's -- and resisted by bureaucrats who did not want to lose control over every aspect of the economy, and by businesses that feared competition.
Administration officials acknowledge that deregulation has been extremely slow but say that each agreement maintains pressure on Japan to keep moving. And there are signs now that Japan's prolonged pain has in fact resulted in a rethinking, in which the deregulation of American industries has become a model.
As Richard Fischer, the Deputy Trade Representative, explained it, "There are a lot of Japanese firms who now realize that bringing down their costs -- their energy costs, their telecommunications costs -- is critical to their survival."
Despite the clear effort by the White House and Mr. Obuchi's handlers to portray this as a harmonious meeting, there were two areas of clear disagreement.
Mr. Clinton warned Mr. Obuchi, first in private, then more mildly in public, that he would begin a trade action against Japan if its shipments of steel to the United States did not soon return to the levels that existed before the onset of the Asian economic crisis.
A flood of low-cost foreign steel has already resulted in some job losses in the steel industry, leading to a Commerce Department action to penalize Japan and other countries for "dumping" steel at prices below the cost of production. While Japan's shipments to the United States have fallen in recent months, Mr. Clinton vowed stiffer action unless the levels declined.

HEADLINE: Woman in the News: Mireya Elisa Moscoso;
Earnest Icon For Panama

BYLINE: By MIREYA NAVARRO 

DATELINE: PANAMA, May 3

 BODY:
For more than 20 years, Mireya Elisa Moscoso lived in the shadow of a man 45 years her senior who, she says, even told her how to wear her hair. But by the side of that man, her late husband, Dr. Arnulfo Arias, three times President of Panama, she also gained a political schooling that on Sunday helped transform her into "Senora Presidenta," the first woman to become President of this country of 2.8 million people.
"The triumph of Senora Mireya is a triumph for the Panamanian woman," Dominador Kaiser Bazan, one of two Vice-Presidential candidates on the winning ticket of her Arnulfista Party, said at an impromptu victory rally on Sunday night. 
 Ms. Moscoso, 52, became one of the few female Presidents in Latin America in what many Panamanians regard as the most important election in their country's short history. Her administration will oversee the transfer of the Panama Canal from United States to Panamanian control this year under treaties signed in 1977. She will also preside over the withdrawal of American troops for the first time since Panama was carved out of Colombia in 1903 in a move engineered by the Americans to build the canal.
Ms. Moscoso said last week that her goal for the canal was to insure that "users feel that it is as well taken care of as when it was with the United States." But throughout her campaign, Ms. Moscoso said her first priority would be to work on poverty, which affects more than a third of the population, and the 12 percent unemployment rate. She also wants to slow changes like privatizing state utilities and has promised to end corruption and nepotism.
"I won't forget my roots or my commitment to fight unemployment, poverty and its consequences," she said on Sunday night, after winning with 44 percent of the vote. "I want for this country what I want for my son Ricardo, that he have the right to grow up in a democratic country, with guaranteed freedoms, with judicial stability and with social justice."
Ms. Moscoso was born on July 1, 1946, in Panama City to a rural family of six children that sank into poverty with the death of her father, a schoolteacher, when she was 10. She was 17 and working as a secretary after graduating from high school when she met Dr. Arias, at a friend's birthday party in the early 60's. Dr. Arias, 62, a widower, was a physician who had been President twice, ousted both times by political opponents.
Ms. Moscoso worked in his campaigns and in the coffee business that she has managed since Dr. Arias's death in 1988. In 1968, after Dr. Arias had been removed from the presidency the third time, in a military coup, she joined him in exile in the United States, where she married him the next year and remained until he died in Miami.
A later marriage ended in divorce after five years. She has a 7-year-old adopted son.
Ms. Moscoso said she had initially rebuffed requests to continue Dr. Arias's work. But in 1990 she coordinated the creation of the Arnulfista Party to replace her husband's old party. In 1991 she took over as party president.
By 1994, when she ran for president, coming in second, Ms. Moscoso was the main opposition leader. She took on the Revolutionary Democratic Party, which had ruled Panama with a succession of military Governments and yielded power to the Arnulfistas only from 1990 to 1994.
Some Panamanians have cited her lack of a college degree -- she studied interior design at Miami-Dade Community College -- and a possibility that she might be easily manipulated as major drawbacks. And not everyone remembers Dr. Arias with fondness. Although he created a social security system, strengthened labor laws and let women vote, his views included a curious mix of fascism, racism, mysticism and nationalism.
In her campaign, in which she defeated two other candidates, including a son of Gen. Omar Torrijos, who ruled after the coup in 1968, Ms. Moscoso said, "My biggest university was that of Dr. Arias."
She called sexism an even bigger obstacle to her political career.
"Although they say Mireya doesn't have the capacity," she shouted at the final rally, "although they say that because she is a woman she can't be president, I tell you here, I can wear pants just like the men in this country! And I know when to put on skirts and when to put on pants, too!"
Panamanians look to her to exploit fairly the the canal property, worth an estimated $4 billion. She will have to contend with a 72-seat legislature dominated by the opposition.
"She comes from way below," Ronald Luque, 25, a waiter who went to one of her rallies, said. "The hope is that someone who came from below will help more."

INTERNATIONAL A3-20
 
NATO Short-Circuits Yugoslav Power System
NATO attacked Yugoslavia's electrical system, cutting off power to millions of civilians as well as to military units in the field. Special bombs containing strands of carbon were used to short-circuit electrical transformers without destroying them. A1
 
NATO warplanes have begun flying more low-altitude bombing raids against Yugoslav forces in Kosovo, a practice that until now was ruled out as too dangerous. A19 

President Clinton, who met with the Russian envoy Viktor S. Chernomyrdin, said the bombardment of Yugoslavia would continue unabated despite the release of three American military prisoners and Russian efforts to broker a peace deal. A1
 
The Senate debated a bipartisan resolution championed by Senator John McCain, an Arizona Republican and Presidential aspirant, which would authorize President Clinton to use all means necessary to win NATO's fight over Kosovo. But the resolution appeared destined to fail because of opposition from the Senate's Republican leadership. A19

President Clinton and Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi of Japan said they were in fundamental agreement on strategies to pull Japan out of a seven-year slump and deregulate its economy. After a daylong meeting in the White House, they announced agreement on deregulating a range of Japanese industries, including telecommunications and medical equipment. A3
 
U.S. Frees Saudi's Accounts
The Treasury Department released more than $24 million in bank accounts held by Salih Idris, the Saudi owner of a Sudanese pharmaceutical plant that was destroyed last August by American cruise missiles after the terror bombings of American embassies in Kenya and Tanzania. Mr. Idris's lawyers said the action was a tacit acknowledgment that the investigation into the bombings had failed to substantiate intelligence reports that Mr. Idris was connected to the Osama bin Laden terrorist network. A8

Official Under Fire in Turkey
Turkey's chief prosecutor, Vural Savas, opened a criminal investigation into a female lawmaker's wearing of a head scarf in Parliament. Mr. Savas may charge her with violating a law that punishes anyone who "openly incites people to enmity and hatred by pointing to differences of class, race, religion or creed." A7

Deadly Tornadoes Sweep Through Central Plains
A band of tornadoes pushed across Oklahoma and into Kansas, killing at least 30 people, injuring hundreds, destroying more than 1000 homes and tearing up whole towns. HEADLINE: An Uneasy Coexistence;
Tensions Between Town and Shelter Flow Both Ways

BYLINE: By NINA BERNSTEIN 

DATELINE: CHESTER, N.Y.

 BODY:
The 13 homeless men stood apart from one another in the parking lot of the Chester Mall, afraid, one said later, of drawing hostile attention. So they tried to blend in, clutching their purchases of crackers, soda and instant soup, and anxiously scanning the horizon for the van back to Camp La Guardia, a 365-acre outpost of the New York City shelter system in Orange County.
But such men do not escape the notice of local people like Glenn Karch, of the nearby town of Warwick, who stopped at the mall to buy wine on a gray April Friday. 
 "There's like a lot of lowlifes walking the road when you come off the exit," he complained. "We moved here to get away from people like them."
Men from camp also have reasons to try to keep their distance, Mr. Karch, 44, a manager at a trucking company, acknowledged. He confirmed a complaint that local drivers sometimes swerve at homeless men hiking the three miles between the mall and camp along a shoulderless highway.
"My older daughter's friends, I've heard them talking," he said. "It's a game they play, like smash the mailboxes -- you know, bored country kids."
Tensions between camp and community gained new attention in April when Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani spoke at a Republican fund-raising dinner in Orange County and was confronted with complaints about the 1,031-bed shelter. Local officials said that men from camp frightened residents with offensive behavior and petty crime, and that some were wanted for arrest on serious offenses elsewhere.
But a closer look at the relationship between residents of the town, about 70 miles northwest of Manhattan, and the camp reveals that the fear and resentment flow both ways.
"This is a clash of cultures," said Gary Abramson, chief attorney for Legal Aid of Orange County. "You're talking about the victims of New York City's housing difficulties, mostly minority men, coming to a community of people who in many cases came to Chester to escape."
Susan McCabe, a local resident, voiced common community concerns when she told Mr. Giuliani during his visit that police sweeps to get the homeless off New York City's streets and subways were turning the camp into a dumping ground for criminals and polluting the quality of life upstate.
A county lawsuit making similar charges against the city is set for trial in June, and Mr. Giuliani -- who will need local votes if he runs for the United States Senate -- promised a crackdown.
But though the community has been subjected to some distasteful or disturbing incidents -- like the time Ms. McCabe says she caught a homeless man masturbating at the end of her driveway -- the police could recall no serious crime against a local resident by a La Guardia man.
Michael W. Farrell, who has been Police Chief in Chester for 18 years, said the sole local murder in recent years was by a prominent lawyer who shot his business partner, and the armed robbery of a gas station was also by a local fellow.
And while two shelter residents were arrested at the time Mayor Giuliani was speaking to the Orange County Republicans, Mr. Farrell said, the charge was shoplifting three packs of cigarettes.
The camp residents, however, have some factual basis to fear harm living in Chester, the police said, particularly in their need to walk to town when the shelter's 13-seat van is full. Two weeks before Mr. Giuliani's visit, a 47-year-old homeless man from camp named Boris Ivanov was run over and killed by accident as he tried to cross the highway.
And while the police recalled that at least two other camp residents died in similar circumstances in recent years, officials here denied a request by the Coalition for the Homeless to install street lights.
The relationship between shelter and town was not always so antagonistic. During the Depression, the camp was hailed for taking demoralized men and turning them into farm workers running their own enterprise for pay. Later, after wartime prosperity shrank the numbers of able-bodied homeless men and the camp became a more custodial refuge for elderly alcoholics, the community barely noticed it.
But in the 1980's, thousands of middle-class families moved from the New York City area to semirural Orange County, propelled by a growing gap between housing costs and income, deteriorating city neighborhoods and expensive suburbs. Their arrival paralleled a new wave of homelessness that engulfed city shelters by 1981, bringing to the camp younger men and more drug abusers.
For a time, the camp continued keeping a low profile by confining the men largely to the grounds. But by 1990, the city acknowledged that legally the men were free to come and go.
Some episodes that followed have had long-lasting resonance, like the "dial a drug" ring, in which local residents called orders into pay phones at the camp and had crack cocaine delivered by shelter residents on bicycles. The camp now bans bikes.
Another case involved a homeless man who allegedly strangled a family's pet rabbit in 1994. Legal Aid maintained that the rabbit was wild, and that the man killed it for food.
The men waiting for the van on this day did not fit the frightening public images. One, florid-faced with silver hair and blue eyes, said he lost his job as a doorman at a theater in Times Square that was shut down as part of the cleanup of the area. Before entering the shelter system, he said, "I was living on the street in Flushing, under a bridge."
When the van finally arrived, it brought a man who identified himself only as Ramon, 42, heading to his part-time job at the Ames store in the mall.
For six years, he said, he worked at a Pergament Home Center in Queens and lived with a cousin, but he lost both job and home because of worsening epileptic seizures.
"They say, 'Why you don't look for disability?' " he recalled, his speech slurred by a cleft palate, his right hand crippled. "No," he answered himself. "I'm still strong. I can work."
City policy holds that the homeless elderly and disabled should be moved to permanent housing, not kept in shelters, especially ones far from their medical care. But older men, seen as more benign, are the kind of shelter residents the community wants to keep, said Nancy Calhoun, a Republican Assemblywoman who has been active in local politics since 1982.
"Raising the age to 55 would do wonders," she said as she drove to the camp, hoping to give a tour to a reporter. Earlier, Ms. Calhoun had called La Guardia "the Cadillac of homeless shelters."
But Patrick Markee, a social policy analyst for the Coalition for the Homeless, disagreed. "Maybe a rusted-out 1972 Cadillac," he said, pointing to state inspection reports that repeatedly found conditions wanting.
Verifying either description proved impossible. At the camp's guardhouse, the Assemblywoman was told she could only circle the grounds on the public road until the visit was approved by the Giuliani administration, which denied the reporter's previous requests for a visit and refused permission this time, too.
On the highway, under a chill spring rain, a few homeless men were walking back to camp from a day's manual labor. Some had fortified themselves at the mall liquor store, which sells cheap pint-sized vodka its clerks call "the campee special," and 99-cent miniature bottles of brandy.
"They talk all this mess about us, but they have no trouble taking our money," said Warren Thompson, 46, a camp resident and member of its advisory council.
Local residents looking for casual labor hire "campees" for as little as $4 an hour, Mr. Thompson said. Some do demolition, work in the slaughterhouse of a nearby Hasidic community, or in the kitchens of summer camps.
Inside La Guardia, some work as orderlies in the infirmary for a stipend that amounts to 62 cents an hour. This work is considered training, and many, including Mr. Thompson, are happy to supplement a public assistance check of $22.50 every two weeks, although they point out that city employees at the camp make $11 an hour for the same work.
These days, many city employees at the camp fear losing their jobs because the city plans to privatize the camp's operation. It is in the midst of negotiating a contract with Volunteers of America, one of the nonprofit groups that now run most city shelters.
A city analysis prepared in 1995 for those interested in taking over the camp showed the population to be similar to that in the overall shelter system, though somewhat older. Of 1,552 men who passed through the camp between October 1994 and the end of March 1995, more than 534 stayed all winter, many of them sick, disabled or frail.
About a quarter reported a history of alcohol abuse, a third reported using drugs in the past, and 7 percent reported recent use. While 2 percent were on probation or parole, more than 70 percent had never had legal problems.
"My sense of the camp is that it's a lot of really down-and-out men who are not criminals, who are just really at the bottom of our economy," said Mr. Abramson of Legal Aid of Orange County.
Not all local residents condemn the camp residents. "I haven't personally had any problems, so it's hard to get on the bandwagon," said Laura Mosher, 35, of nearby Whispering Hills. "There's a level of uncomfortability because a lot of these men are a different race. It's easy to stereotype; it's hard to form a personal bond."
Over a hamburger at the local McDonald's, Mr. Thompson explained how easily homeless men can get into legal trouble.
Alcohol is forbidden in camp, so if a homeless man buys a beer in a store, he said, he risks arrest for drinking in public. Should he go into the woods to relieve himself on the long walk back, he will court community disgust, and possibly charges of trespass or indecent exposure.
A few years ago, a homeless man was even arrested in Chester under an open-container law for drinking a Sprite; he sued and won a $30,000 settlement after showing that the law was enforced only against camp residents.
Worse than arrest, however, is fear of being transferred, Mr. Thompson said, shuddering at the recollection of a Brooklyn armory shelter where another homeless man was murdered for $20 last fall.
Back on the highway, about 5 P.M., a police car let out three camp residents who had been escorted out of Chester. One, a 50-year-old African-American man in a faded N.Y.U. sweatshirt, was at a loss to explain what had happened.
"Somebody in town complained that we were laughing and making a lot of noise," he said, shaking his head. "I'm new here. I'm not saying they're not used to seeing minority people, but I guess they're not used to seeing minority people in a group."
Slowly, he added: "These people got to understand, this is not their world. We've all got to live here."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
CERIDIAN AGREES TO BUY ABR INFORMATION SERVICES

BYLINE: Bridge News 

 BODY:
The Ceridian Corporation, an information services provider, said yesterday that it would acquire ABR Information Services Inc. for $25.50 a share in cash, or about $750 million. ABR, based in Palm Harbor, Fla., provides benefits administration, payroll and human resource services. The Minneapolis-based Ceridian said the deal would slightly dilute earnings in 1999 and 2000 but was expected to increase the growth rate of Ceridian's human resources business. ABR projects revenues of around $120 million for its current fiscal year and employs some 1,500 people. Its shares soared 43 percent, or $7.50, to $25, while Ceridian slipped 50 cents, to $36.125.

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
Cuba Game Could Open Some Doors

BYLINE: By GEORGE VECSEY 

DATELINE: BALTIMORE

 BODY:
THE orange and black banners were hanging downtown, giving a festive feel to a soggy day.
Baltimore Welcomes Cuba. 
 This was not New York or Cleveland coming in for a big game. This was the national team of Cuba. Salsa music danced out of the loudspeakers, turning the arcade and the old brick factory behind right field into a Latin plaza.
When they hang out the bunting for the World Series, they don't mention the opponent. It's just generic decoration. This was different. This was one of the grand old baseball cities -- Wee Willie, The Babe, Earl, Frank and Brooks -- playing host to a baseball nation.
It's a good thing they don't have automatic relegation in baseball, the way they do in world soccer leagues, because the inept Orioles would be good candidates for demotion after last night's embarrassment, a 12-6 Cuba victory that more than made up for the taut 3-2 Orioles victory on March 28.
"I believe we all will win," said Omar Linares, the superb Cuban third baseman.
But who really wins from this strange little sequence? You could almost hear the baseball scouts salivating over the talent that Cuba saw fit to load onto the plane. They would love to pick off a few, to slip a few business cards into a few willing palms, but what does that prove? Is there some bigger picture here?
Baltimore Welcomes Cuba.
Cuban-Americans with memories of their homeland may fear that a baseball relationship will only strengthen Fidel Castro. It is easy to say that a mere game or two cannot balance out four decades of political repression in Cuba, economic sanctions that the United States has imposed on Cuba, mutual bad blood.
But there they were, big-timers with more than a bit of swagger, in glittering blue jackets, white pants and bright red caps, a trifle more solemn than visitors for a World Series.
At times, it sounded just like any other big sporting event, with American sportswriters asking Alfonso Urquiola, the roly-poly Cuban manager, why he had omitted this player or that player from the road squad.
Just the words "Los Hermanos Hernandez" -- "the Hernandez Brothers" -- conjures up the specter of defection, but Urquiola sounded like every other touchy manager when he said, "I thought I already explained that." Still, it was more than a game, it was a gesture.
Baltimore Welcomes Cuba.
There is something to be said for gestures -- the nod, the smile, the word, the phrase that just might lead to something better. There is something to be said for gestures like Preacher Jackson going into Serbia and bringing back three captured American soldiers, making sure they are safe at home, and then letting the politicians argue about who is using whom.
What is the endgame for this little home-and-home gesture? Why would Fidel Castro even permit the American professionals to play his state-supported amateurs? What could be worth the intense security, the fears of defection, even the possibility of ignominious defeat? What's in it for Fidel?
Here they were, the cream of the international circuit, big-timers who play teams from Japan, Mexico, the Dominican Republic. This summer they will go to the Pan-American Games. These guys get around.
Baltimore Welcomes Cuba.
If they were flabbergasted by the amenities of a chain hotel alongside the glitzy renovated harbor, they were not about to let on. Did they glance at the varieties and the prices of a room-service menu? On the other hand, did they catch a glimpse of America's poverty outside their bus window? They were not saying, but they did not shy away from the impulses of their baseball hearts.
"There are changes taking place," said Luis Ulacia, an outfielder with a firm jaw and an appraising glance. "We do not rule out that Cuban players will play professionally some day.
"We wish not to be forced to defect," he said, talking about joining the major leagues some day. "It would be a beautiful experience."
Asked if he would play for free, just to prove himself, Ulacia brought up the American sanctions: "Because of the blockade, I believe it would be difficult. If they gave us the opportunity to play, I believe the Treasury Department would not let us get paid."
Ulacia was making propaganda. There is plenty of that between the countries. What is needed is the next step -- a series in November, maybe, or a few Cuban players allowed to earn salaries in the majors. There is something to be said for gestures.
Baltimore Welcomes Cuba.

(G. Paul Burnett/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: List of Final Witnesses Released in Microsoft Trial

BYLINE: By JOEL BRINKLEY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 3

 BODY:
The Microsoft Corporation and the Government both released the names today of the final witnesses each intends to call when the antitrust trial resumes later this month. The list indicates that the Government hopes to shore up its case, while Microsoft's goal, at least in part, is to change the subject of discussion to one that might make the Government's case seem irrelevant.
The most surprising announcement came from Microsoft. The company is summoning David Colburn -- a senior executive for America Online and an important Government witness earlier in the trial -- to testify as a hostile witness in the final, rebuttal stage of testimony. 
 Mr. Colburn will be questioned about "the completeness and candor of prior testimony," Microsoft said, and as part of the company's effort to argue that America Online's purchase of the Netscape Communications Corporation undermines the Government's case.
"Our rebuttal witnesses will show that the $10 billion merger of AOL and Netscape completely undercuts the Government's case" by showing that "competition and innovation are stronger than ever in the software industry," said William H. Neukom, Microsoft's senior vice president for law and corporate affairs.
Microsoft will also call Gordon Eubanks, the former chairman of the Symantec Corporation, maker of the Norton Utilities programs for Windows, and Richard Schmalensee, an economist and dean of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology Sloan School of Management. Mr. Schmalensee was Microsoft's economic witness earlier in the trial.
The Justice Department is also recalling its chief economic witness, Franklin M. Fisher, another M.I.T. economist. It will also recall Edward Felten, the Princeton University computer scientist who served as a Government witness earlier in the trial, and Gary Norris, an International Business Machines Corporation executive who was for several years director of I.B.M.'s software strategy division.
Government officials said they were confident of their case and hoped their rebuttal witnesses would shore up areas of weakness exposed during the earlier part of the trial.
One witness, Mr. Felten, is being called in part to rebut any technical statements Microsoft might make that Government lawyers find questionable. He and his staff found several of the technical flaws in Microsoft's demonstration tapes played in court earlier.
The overarching goal, Government officials said, is to keep the strong legal advantage they believe they have already gained.
A senior I.B.M. executive, John Soyring, has already testified for the Government, and there is some overlap between the areas he discussed and the ones Justice Department lawyers intend to raise with Mr. Norris. But they also intend to question him about Microsoft's efforts to stop I.B.M. from offering software on its computers made by Microsoft's competitors, according to a filing with the court.
With its witnesses, Microsoft wants to open up new areas of evidence. A filing with the court shows that the company wants to use Mr. Colburn to help make the case that Netscape, America Online and the Government plotted, in effect, to hide for two months the developing deal between Netscape and America Online because they were afraid news of it would hurt the Government's case.
A Justice Department official called that "a desperate attempt to distract attention from Microsoft's illegal behavior.
"Nothing about the transaction has any relevance to the case," the official added, "and nothing about it will break Microsft's stranglehold on the operating system market."
Mr. Eubanks, now the head of Oblix, a business-directory software manufacturer, led Symantec during the years when the company sold utilities that Microsoft later incorporated into the Windows operating system. But Microsoft wants to show that Symantec then came up with new ideas, like antivirus software, to replace the lost business and continued to prosper.
Microsoft describes Mr. Eubanks as a friend and competitor. In a filing with the court today, Microsoft said Mr. Eubanks would testify about "the rapid pace of change in the software business, and the inability of anyone to predict the directions in which computer and communication technology would evolve over the last 10 years," and "the expansion of the concept of an operating system through the addition of new features and functions."
In a recent interview, Mr. Eubanks said, "Microsoft has done some bad things," but added that the company and its chairman, William H. Gates 3d, had been victims of the American tendency to tear down those who are too successful.
Both Mr. Fisher and Mr. Schmalensee will have to repair damage they did to Government and Microsoft cases during earlier cross-examination.
Mr. Fisher said he did not think Microsoft's behavior had harmed consumers, a statement he later tried to modify. And Mr. Schmalensee was shown to have offered opinions in previous years that were opposite the ones he was espousing in court, leading Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson to question his credibility.

CORRECTION-DATE: May 7, 1999, Friday

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day on Tuesday about the lists of witnesses in the Microsoft antitrust trial referred incorrectly to comments by Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson about the earlier testimony of a witness, Richard Schmalensee of the Sloan School of Management at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. The judge questioned an apparent contradiction in Mr. Schmalensee's testimony; he did not question his overall credibility.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
8 European Stock Exchanges Form Alliance

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, May 4

 BODY:
Edging closer to the vision of a unified European stock market, eight stock exchanges agreed today to develop a common trading system for stocks in Europe's biggest companies.
The eight exchanges are those of Frankfurt, London, Paris, Amsterdam, Brussels, Madrid, Zurich and Milan, Italy.
The agreement is a step toward eliminating the inefficiency of Europe's stock exchanges, which play a much smaller role in the overall economy than their counterparts in the United States. 
 But despite the allure of creating one big market and taking advantage of Europe's single currency, the euro, the exchanges are still divided by rivalries and are feuding over the kind of system to develop.
Indeed, today's agreement was an attempt to soothe the anger of France and several other countries, which were shocked last July when the London and Frankfurt stock exchanges -- the largest and second-largest in Europe by market capitalization -- announced their plan for a joint-trading system and merely "invited" others to join.
The move was particularly galling to executives at the Paris Bourse, the third-biggest exchange in Europe, who did not learn about the Frankfurt-London deal until it was publicly announced. It was also troubling that Frankfurt was teaming up with an exchange outside the 11 nations that use the euro.
Since then, the smaller exchanges have vacillated between the anxiety of being left out and the fear of being swallowed up. Today's agreement was the most concrete step toward reconciliation, but those involved offered no clues about the exchange's structure, trading hours, common rules, preferred stock index benchmark or timetable, all key issues that must be resolved.
In a brief signing ceremony in Madrid, the eight exchanges "underlined their commitment" to bring their rules into agreement and eventually develop a single electronic-trading system for stocks of Europe's largest companies.
"We are facing a complex project, but it is possible and necessary," said Antonio Zoido, chairman of the Madrid exchange.
The pact is essentially an endorsement of common goals, and it is limited to trading in a fairly small universe of Europe's biggest companies. It does not include Europe's fast-growing "new markets," the exchanges, affiliated with the older ones, that were created primarily for newer technology companies.
Meanwhile, the French, Swiss and Italian stock exchanges said they were continuing with plans for a "virtual market" that would probably compete with the Frankfurt-London alliance.

HEADLINE: Hanok Journal;
Bean Paste vs. Miniskirts: Generation Gap Grows

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF

DATELINE: HANOK, South Korea

 BODY:
A blast of steam caught Park Ki Soon in the face as she peered into the caldron of beans and began stirring, feeling ever more sorry for herself.
"When I was young I did what my mother-in-law said," Mrs. Park, 70, said morosely as she used a wooden paddle to churn the beans. "But now my daughter-in-law doesn't listen to me. 
 "So now I'm making this bean paste, and I'm feeling miserable because I'm an old woman and she's using me. I don't know why she doesn't make bean paste herself. I think she just wants to be comfortable. She never likes hard work."
The small group of women clustered around Mrs. Park, here in the village of Hanok about 30 miles northwest of Seoul, nodded their heads in agreement. Young Koreans, they concluded, are incomprehensible and insufferable.
"When I go to the cities, I look at young people, the way they dress, the way they behave, and they aren't Korean," said Choi Sam Soon, 55, who was also making bean paste. "Young people always carry credit cards, and they get money from machines! They always spend money so recklessly."
"And young people abandon things that are still usable," Mrs. Choi added, shaking her head at the idea. "Some people throw out old kettles, so I pick them up and take them home and use them."
The problem, of course, is that young people are not thrilled about having their mothers or mothers-in-law rifling through other people's garbage to rescue battered old kettles. And such skirmishes are only one facet of a generation gap that many South Koreans say is greater than almost anywhere in the world.
Korea was one of the last places to open up to Western influences, for until a century ago it was an ancient kingdom that operated on Confucian traditions and deeply regimented customs. Those customs -- especially respect for the elderly -- permeated Korean society until the last few decades.
Since the 1960's, South Korea has been one of the fastest-changing societies in the world. The economy grew at a blistering pace, the country industrialized and urbanized, a middle class emerged, and these days respect tends to go to those with money and E-mail accounts, not to the old men and women who make great bean paste.
"Generation gaps exist everywhere, but the gap is wider here, because Western culture is pouring in at an amazing speed," said Annette E. Y. Ahn, 28, a Seoul interpreter who grew up partly in the United States and Europe. "I also think it's wider here because looking back in history, we were the last country to open up to Western culture, and now the doors are open and it's pouring in."
These gaps seem to cause misunderstandings and sadness, but fewer open explosions than one might expect. Young and old alike may stew inside at the foolishness of the other, but they also describe how they go out of their way to accommodate.
"It's a constant bother to live with the old folks," said Chong Kum Sook, 38, who lives in the same house as her husband's parents. "It's very hard. It's not that they complain, but I feel the burden on myself.
"My in-laws are early risers, so I try to get up when they do. And in the summer I can't wear skimpy clothes, because I have to dress cautiously so as not to disturb them. I should be careful not to make them unhappy."
Korean women were traditionally expected to dress very primly, and indeed a young woman was arrested for indecency just four years ago when she wore a T-shirt that exposed her navel.
"When I see girls exposing themselves in short dresses, I'm shocked," said Koh Kap In, a 79-year-old matriarch who was sitting outside her house. "But I've never said a word to my granddaughters. It's the times. All the young women are in those clothes."
Most elderly Koreans say that they are often shocked privately at the laziness or immorality or extravagance of young people, but that mostly they bite their tongues.
"If I complain, would they listen?" asked Kim Hae Song, 78, a stooped woman who was outside weeding her garden. "No. That would only put them on bad terms with me. In my heart I feel upset at what goes on, but I don't say anything."
Mrs. Kim and her husband, Kwon Sang Mook, 81, are most offended at the disappearance of traditional etiquette, which young people often breach without even realizing it.
"I see young people smoking in front of their elders," Mr. Kwon said, shaking his head. "Young people say they are so smart, but what is the point of knowledge if you don't know how to behave?"
The elderly often seem particularly poignant because, mixed in with the outrage at the way their grandchildren or daughters-in-law behave there is also often pride at their education and worldliness.
Sitting in her kitchen, Lee Hee Ja, 58, a housewife, served coffee and a 40-minute denunciation of young people. She fretted that her eldest daughter-in-law will not carry on the family rituals, that her second daughter-in-law has not minded her advice to dress modestly, that neither can cook properly and that none of the young people are attentive enough to her own needs. But then Mrs. Lee paused, smiled and sighed.
"Maybe I'm wrong," she said. "Young people now are very bright. So smart! So I don't know. Maybe in the end my daughters-in-law will be better than I was."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
A Co-Finalist For Trade Post May Be Out

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH OLSON

DATELINE: GENEVA, May 4

 BODY:
The diplomatic struggle over who should be the next head of the World Trade Organization continued unabated today while most work at the global trade forum seemed to grind to a halt.
After putting off deliberations for a day, the chairman of the search team jolted delegates at a meeting today by declaring that the candidacy of Suphachai Panichpakdi of Thailand was over and that the group should consider only his rival, Michael Moore of New Zealand. 
 The announcement by Ali Mchumo, Tanzania's trade delegate, set forth vigorous protests from Mr. Suphachai's supporters, led by Asian countries, as the meeting stretched late into the evening with no final decision. Delegates will meet again, after taking "time for reflection."
In an interview today, Mr. Suphachai declared that he was "confident of the outcome" but criticized the selection process as taking too long. "I won't say that I feel cheated, but a number of countries seem to feel the whole process was not consistent," he said. In Thailand, where Mr. Suphachai is a Deputy Prime Minister, there has been an outcry against the United States, which was seen as the chief obstacle to his winning the international post.
After six months of reviewing four initial candidates, the field was winnowed to the two recent candidates. Mr. Mchumo, who heads the trade organization's decision-making General Council, announced on Friday that Mr. Moore had edged out Mr. Suphachai, by 62 votes to 59, among the members and should be nominated as the new Director General.
Meetings over the weekend, some vitriolic, among envoys of the 134-nation trade forum, failed to come up with a choice or even agree on a method of proceeding.
Mr. Mchumo urged the delegates to wrap up the selection or, he said, "we shall see the intensification of the already unhealthy divisiveness, recrimination, mistrust and erosion of friendships which has already taken its toll."
However, when he declared that the process was over for Mr. Suphachai, representatives of two dozen countries took to the floor to disagree and to argue that the race was too close to count him out. Kenya's envoy proposed that Mr. Mchumo sound out delegates on Mr. Suphachai's acceptability as the new W.T.O. chief, and Mr. Mchumo eventually agreed to consider it.
There is still the option of a vote to decide between the two candidates, although many countries oppose this as contrary to the four-year-old organization's way of doing business by consensus.
If the deadlock continues, diplomats increasingly were entertaining the possibility of jettisoning both candidates and starting over.
Soon after the meeting got under way, Renato Ruggiero, the outgoing Director General, whose selection four years ago had been marked by bitterness, officially left his post and drove off, foreclosing the option that he might stay on to tide the trade group over until it resolved its leadership crisis.

HEADLINE: Harry L. Kavetas, 61, Kodak's Finance Chief

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH

 BODY:
Harry L. Kavetas, the chief financial officer who helped lead the Eastman Kodak Company through a huge financial upheaval that involved sweeping job cuts over the last few years, died yesterday at his home in Rochester. He was 61.
The cause was an apparent heart attack, the company said. 
 Although he had been with Kodak only since 1994, Mr. Kavetas was credited with helping to engineer the strategies that helped the company dig out from under a huge debt load and stem a precipitous drop in its share of the American film market. As part of the management team of George M. C. Fisher, Kodak's chief executive, Mr. Kavetas helped the company capitalize on the growth of digital photography. He was also deeply involved in Kodak's wrenching decision, announced in 1997, to cut 19,000 jobs.
"It's terrible to lose someone of Harry's quality at a time when the company has so many balls in the air," said B. Alexander Henderson, an analyst who follows Kodak for Prudential Securities Research.
On joining Kodak, Mr. Kavetas began finding ways to pay down more than $5 billion in debt from Kodak's 1988 purchase of Sterling Drug.
He helped spearhead Kodak's decision to divest itself of huge chunks of its health business and, just this year, to sell its copier business. He was also very involved in the decision, announced in 1997, to pare as many as 19,000 jobs -- a decision that would be painful for any company but that was excruciating for Kodak, which had run so paternalistic an organization that its nickname in its home town, Rochester, was "Great Yellow Father."
Mr. Kavetas, a native of Springfield, Ill., had a bachelor's degree in finance and economics from the University of Illinois.
Before joining Kodak, he spent 32 years with the International Business Machines Corporation, rising steadily up the ranks. When he took early retirement from there in December 1993, he was chief executive of the I.B.M. Credit Corporation. Kodak hired him two months later.
Mr. Kavetas was elected a Kodak executive vice president in September 1994, just seven months after joining the company. In May 1997 he was elected to Kodak's board.
Mr. Kavetas is survived by his wife, Sue; two daughters, Betsy Kavetas and Kathy Rothchild; a son, James, and three grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Business Travel;
Drivers face a summer of rising gasoline prices
as the nation's refineries run at top capacity.

BYLINE: By Agis Salpukas

 BODY:
WITH the summer driving season approaching, the price of gasoline across the country has jumped sharply from historically low levels as major oil producing countries cut supplies of crude oil.
The supply of crude remains the most crucial factor affecting gasoline, but many experts warn that a shortage of another kind may push prices at the pump higher in the months ahead: tight supplies of refined gasoline in the United States. 
 Demand for gasoline has been increasing steadily, spurred by the economic boom of the 1990's, by the growing popularity of big sport utility vehicles that have relatively poor gas efficiency -- and by the low price of fuel. In February, at 87.8 cents a gallon for regular nationwide, gas was as low, on an inflation-adjusted basis, as it had been since the 1920's.
Even with price rises since then -- almost 29 percent, to an average of $1.13 a gallon nationwide -- energy prices remain relatively modest in most parts of the country.
Predicting oil and gas prices is an inexact science at best. During the summer, the Energy Department says, the likelihood is that gasoline will range from $1.08 to $1.18 a gallon, 9 to 10 cents higher than the unusually low prices seen last summer. Since the average motorist drives 15,000 miles a year and gets 21 miles a gallon, and would spend $821 a year on gas at $1.15 a gallon, according to AAA, such prices would not pose a huge financial burden.
But two factors may drive prices higher. The first, the supply of crude oil, has received most attention. Two announced cutbacks in production by a coalition composed of members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries and non-OPEC members like Norway, Mexico, Russia and Oman have driven prices up from a low of $10.35 a barrel in December to $18.92 a barrel yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Crude oil prices have risen in anticipation of actual production cuts. If the cutbacks do not stick, the price of oil, and of gasoline at the pump, could decline again.
But it is the declining capacity of refineries to process crude oil and convert it into gas and other products that has recently come under scrutiny on the West Coast, and is likely to become more of an issue across the country, many analysts say.
From 18 million barrels of crude oil a day in 1981, refining capacity across the country declined sharply during the next 15 years as the industry underwent a period of low profit margins, consolidation and investment in equipment to meet more stringent environmental regulations. Capacity began to rise modestly four years ago. Still, it now stands at only 16 million barrels a day and demand is growing faster than supply.
For the last three years, refineries have been running at top production levels. "Refiners have to work full blast just to keep up with demand," said Fred Leuffer, an analyst for Bear, Stearns. "There is no more room for error."
Shortfalls are being made up by imports of gasoline, which are more expensive and have been less reliable than domestically refined fuel.
Under these circumstances, when production at refineries is disrupted, as occurred recently in California, spikes in gasoline prices are likely to follow. In a case now under investigation by the California State Attorney General's office, prices jumped by more than 40 percent after two fires shut refineries there.
Meanwhile, over the next several years, new regulations by the Environmental Protection Agency to greatly lessen the amount of sulfur in gasoline would require considerable investment by refineries just to make existing quantities of gasoline environmentally acceptable. Under new rules proposed by President Clinton on Saturday the agency would require the industry to produce gasoline with no more than 30 parts per million of sulfur, about a 91 percent reduction.
All these factors are likely to put pressure on prices at the pump nationwide.
"People will still get what they want to buy," said Larry Goldstein, with the Petroleum Industry Research Foundation, a research group for the industry in Manhattan. "There will just be times when they will have to pay more for gasoline."
No one is predicting a return to the gas lines of 1973 and 1979, which were the result of big cuts in the supply of oil by OPEC. Barring unforeseen disasters, oil supplies are generally believed to be too abundant and diversified to allow critical shortages that might require rationing or long lines at gas stations.
"It's worth raising the concern," said Jeff A. Dietert, an analyst who covers refining for Simmons & Company International of Houston. "But I don't think that the world is about to come to an end."
More likely are occasional price spikes, most analysts say. In California, the refinery fires cut production by about 15 percent. Prices for regular unleaded gasoline in the state jumped from an average of $1.11 a gallon in February to nearly $1.60 in March before starting to recede in recent weeks to the current level of $1.47 a gallon. Shipments from the Gulf Coast and from as far as Korea eventually helped to ease the state's shortage.
Last Friday, some California municipalities and consumer groups urged drivers not to buy gasoline in protest.
John Gioia, a member of the Contra Costa County Board of Supervisors, which supported the boycott, said that while the effort had little economic impact it was a "symbolic statement of concern over the action of the oil companies."
California's geography and its stringent environmental regulations have made the state's gas more expensive than in the rest of the nation. Even if gasoline could be shipped from the East Coast to the West economically, it would not meet California's regulatory standards.
But across the country, demand for gasoline grew at a pace of about 3 percent last year, with another 2 percent expected this year. Refineries nationwide are expected to be hard pressed to meet demand.
"They're going to have to run harder and harder because demand is outstripping supply growth, " said Mr. Leuffer of the Bear, Stearns.
In the long run, Mr. Leuffer said, refiners and retailers will be able to impose higher prices for gasoline.
While the current tightness in refining capacity may impose burdens on motorists, it represents a welcome change for the industry. Overcapacity led to years of shrinking profits, and inefficient refineries were abandoned. From 300 refineries in the early 1980's, there are only about 160 refineries.
Last year's collapse of the price of crude oil, which cut profits of oil companies and independent refiners alike, led to belt tightening and low capital spending. For most companies, the profit decline continued into the first quarter of this year and capital spending remained low. Most companies say they are waiting to see if the crude oil price remains at current levels.
Refining capacity is due to grow at a little more than 1 percent this year and probably not much more in the next few years, industry analysts say. This compares with an increase of 2.6 percent last year and an average of 2.2 percent in the last five years.
"With capacity going up 1.8 percent and demand growing at more than 2 percent you are going to get higher prices over time," said Michael Mayer, an analyst with Schroder & Company.
Still, there is a check on the industry. Often when prices in the United States climb, refiners in Europe and Latin America, who still have extra capacity, begin to ship extra supplies. In the first quarter of this year, for example, imports of gasoline were up sharply, rising 7 percent over last year and accounting for 5.3 percent of total supply. For all of last year, imports amounted to just 3.6 percent of supply.
But the gasoline shipped here is more expensive. Transportation costs add about 3 to 4 cents a gallon. Overseas refiners tend to hold off, waiting to see whether United States shortages, and price increases here, stick. That uncertainty often causes spot prices for gasoline in the United States to run up even more in futures markets. If sustained, those increases eventually get passed on to the motorist.
"The movement across the Atlantic is fairly expensive to justify shipping a lot of gasoline," said Eric Leon, the London-based general manager for the chemical and petroleum industry for I.B.M., and a close observer of European refining.
In August 1997, the price of gasoline in the United States jumped about 10 cents a gallon when strong demand combined with problems at several American refineries. The price surge, which was ultimately alleviated by European imports, came even though crude oil prices were dropping.
Such short surges in prices, however, are not expected to cause oil companies and independent refiners to ease their purse strings.
"Brief peaks in prices will not get a lot of investment going," said John Cook, the director of the petroleum division of the Energy Information Administration, the statistical arm of the Energy Department.
The challenge is to meet new environmental standards while maintaining adequate gasoline supplies, he said. He expects that imports of gasoline are likely to play a larger role in the future.
"There is concern about making the transition," Mr. Cook added. "How do you get from here to there without disrupting the marketplace?"

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Investor Shift Is Suggested As Prices Drop For Treasuries

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Bond prices dropped sharply yesterday, pushing long-term interest rates to their highest level in nine months.
There was no significant economic news to prompt the selling, said traders and analysts, who instead cited a shift in view among bond investors. 
 The selling has pushed the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond up almost a quarter of a percentage point in just three trading days.
In late trading in the Treasury market yesterday, the price of the 30-year bond dropped 25/32 to 93 15/32; the yield, which moves in the opposite direction, jumped to 5.71 percent, from 5.65 percent on Monday.
Increasingly, investors are losing the conviction that the United States economy will slow this year, with inflation remaining in check; instead, a growing number worry that a rebound in the rest of the world will keep growth strong here and -- combined with a rise in the prices of oil and other commodities -- will nudge inflation higher.
The jump in prices should not be large -- from the 1.6 percent increase in the Consumer Price Index in 1998 to an expected rise this year of 2 percent or more. But investors appear to fear that this acceleration may still be enough to prompt the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates to slow economic growth.
"Investors are becoming increasingly aware that the global economy is improving and that the prospect for low inflation is less, while the prospect for higher inflation has increased," said Richard Berner, the chief United States economist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter.
This outlook on inflation and growth, he added, means that the Fed is likely to raise interest rates by the first quarter of next year, if not sooner.
Higher interest rates, and the fear of inflation that would cause them, are a threat to the stock market, which retreated yesterday after the Dow Jones industrial average topped 11,000 points for the first time on Monday. Yesterday, the Dow dropped 128.58 points, or 1.2 percent, to 10,886.11.
So far this year, equity investors have ignored the rise in rates, which has seen the 30-year bond yield shoot up from a low of 5.05 percent in January. But at the current level, according to the valuation model used by Byron R. Wien, the United States investment strategist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, the stock market is overvalued by 30 percent.
In a sign of concern about an impending rise in the Federal funds rate, the central bank's interest rate target, the yield on the Fed funds futures contract for December has jumped to 5 percent since Thursday. The Fed funds target is now 4.75 percent.
Thomas Connor, the head government trader at J. P. Morgan Securities, said a Morgan survey showed that money managers, who had been betting on an economic slowdown here and a bond rally, were changing their view.
Just two weeks ago, he said, 89 percent of the money managers surveyed were at or ahead of their performance benchmarks in terms of their bet on bonds -- meaning many were expecting a rally. But now the survey shows the percentage has dropped to 75 percent. Reducing bond exposure in this direction means selling.
Mr. Connor also said there was a lot of selling because investors were switching from Treasury securities to corporate and other bonds, which offer higher yields.
"It is a wake-up call for a bond manager," said N. Graham Allen, managing director of global fixed income for Wells Capital Management. He still believes that this is just a wide swing in a trading range that will see bond prices rally and yields fall again. But he acknowledged that the bond market "is a little shaky at the moment."
Stephen D. Slifer, the chief United States economist at Lehman Brothers, also argues that investors are overreacting. He said that the 1.4 percent rise in the inflation measure for the gross domestic product was overstated. It was the report of that rise on Friday, along with the news that the economy grew at 4.5 percent during the first quarter, a rate much stronger than expected, that set off the latest round of bond selling.
He also said that while some commodity prices have risen recently from their lows for the year, they have not had the kind of surge that amounts to an inflationary threat.
But he acknowledged that right now this analysis does not matter in the bond market. "While I may kiss this off," he said, "there is nothing that says that interest rates can't go up in the near term."

HEADLINE: April Auto Sales Impressive Despite LowerG.M. Results

BYLINE: By ROBYN MEREDITH

DATELINE: DETROIT, May 4

 BODY:
Car and truck buyers were out in force in April, and as a result the auto industry turned in strong sales results just as it heads into the crucial summer selling season. Sales rose 3.9 percent over all in April, and the industry sold cars, sport utility vehicles, pickup trucks and minivans at a brisk seasonally adjusted annual rate of 16.3 million.
The impressive results came despite lower-than-expected sales at the General Motors Corporation. G.M. said its sales fell 4 percent in April, with car sales falling 4.5 percent and truck sales falling 3.5 percent compared with results in the month a year earlier. Wall Street analysts cautioned that the G.M. results were not as weak as they seemed because G.M. had blockbuster results last April when it was offering particularly hefty rebates. Still, analysts expected G.M.'s sales to decline no more than 3 percent. 
 But G.M. executives were upbeat. "April was a very good month for us," said Roy S. Roberts, vice president and group executive for North America Vehicle Sales, Service and Marketing. "Our market share is north of 30 percent for the first time in seven months." G.M.'s market share in April was 30.6 percent, down from 33.2 in April of last year. Much of the decline came from G.M.'s largest division, Chevrolet, where sales dropped 10.9 percent in April.
The sales came at a price. G.M. offered hefty rebates and other incentives on many of its vehicles in April. For instance, current Cadillac owners are entitled to $1,000 off the price of any new Cadillac except the Escalade sport utility vehicle. Pontiac will lease its Grand Am sedan for $219 a month. And Buick is offering three-year, zero interest leases on four of its models, as if it were borrowing the money at Japanese interest rates and passing on the savings to its customers.
Nevertheless, with nearly a year of especially strong sales results, auto makers are considering building factories in the United States to help meet demand. G.M.'s board tentatively approved plans to build a new factory in Lansing, Mich., to produce rear-wheel-drive luxury vehicles. G.M. is still negotiating agreements with the United Automobile Workers union and state and local governments but could begin construction for the factory as early as this summer, said Kyle W. Johnson, a company spokesman.
Honda, which said on Monday that its sales rose 4 percent last month and 8.3 percent so far this year, is considering building its third American factory and is looking at sites in Alabama and Georgia. Alabama is considered the front-runner for the factory, which would build sport utility vehicles.
Wall Street analysts said the industry's strong sales reflected a buyer's market. "There are a lot of really interesting products out there for people to buy, and people are getting good prices," said Wendy Beale Needham, an auto analyst at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette.
Economists concur that the strong sales are fed by several factors: strong economic growth, a surging stock market, low interest rates, tax refunds and hefty rebates and other sales incentives. Auto executives agree but add that some of the strength in sales can be predicted by reading demographic tea leaves.
David P. Bostwick, director of corporate market research for DaimlerChrysler A.G., said auto makers were selling more cars and trucks because the leading edge of the baby boom had reached prime car-buying age. "This is basically the time when you buy more cars more often than any time of your life," Mr. Bostwick said.
Other auto makers also reported strong sales. On Monday, the Ford Motor Company said its sales rose 6.6 percent, DaimlerChrysler sales rose 3 percent, Toyota sales rose 9.6 percent and Nissan rose 21.5 percent.
Mazda sales rose 16.7 percent in April, to 21,989. Kia sales nearly doubled, to 10,606, and Hyundai sales nearly doubled, to 10,685.
Daewoo, the Korean company that began selling cars in the United States last September, sold 2,006 cars in April. Volkswagen A.G. said its April sales rose 29.5 percent. Audi said its sales rose 29.3 percent, to 5,592, because of strong sales of the Audi A4 and A6 models. Subaru sales rose 12 percent, to 12,331, because stronger sales of the Forester offset weaker sales of the Impreza. Isuzu said its sales fell 5.8 percent, to 7,011.
BMW sales rose 14.1 percent, to 14,225. Mitsubishi sales rose 21.3 percent, to 16,370, and Porsche sales rose 11 percent, to 2,198.

HEADLINE: Gore Pushes Mass Transit in the Heart of Automobile Country

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER

DATELINE: DETROIT, May 4

 BODY:
Pursuing the suburban voters who may prove crucial in next year's Presidential election, as well as traditional Democratic constituents in cities, Vice President Al Gore called today in a speech here for reviving urban centers and reducing traffic congestion.
Speaking in the heart of the nation's auto industry, Mr. Gore called not only for better schools and the redevelopment of abandoned industrial sites but also for shifting spending from highway construction to mass transit systems. 
 "If you want to build subways instead of highways, you ought to be able to make that choice," he told nearly 3,000 local politicians and community advocates from across the country.
Mr. Gore's comment's provoked scowls and whispers among the handful of auto executives in the audience, not one of whom was willing afterward to criticize the Administration. With nearly five million people, Detroit is the nation's largest metropolitan area without a subway.
Asked about the executives' skepticism, Mr. Gore replied: "That's not universally the case. They know that mass transit has a legitimate and larger role to play."
Spending on mass transit has barely kept pace with inflation in the Clinton Administration, rising to $5.39 billion this fiscal year from $4.58 billion in the 1994 fiscal year, the first for which the Administration set the budget. By comparison, Federal highway appropriations have soared to $27.37 billion now from $18.99 billion in 1994.
Transportation Secretary Rodney Slater blamed Republicans for the disparity, saying the Administration had sought higher mass transit spending only to see Congress devote more money to highway construction instead.
But even though many Republicans have been hostile to mass transit programs, which tend to benefit big, heavily Democratic cities, the Federal budget is a result of a series of compromises between Congress and the Administration in which both sides share responsibility for the final spending decisions.
The Vice President, Mr. Slater and other senior Federal officials spoke on Monday and today at an Administration conference here on ways to improve the quality of life in communities and protect the environment while still encouraging economic growth. The officials' comments, at the Town Hall Meeting for a Sustainable America, were transmitted through satellite video links to 60,000 local advocates and officials at more than 100 sites around the country.
Responding to critics who have suggested that issues like traffic congestion and suburban sprawl are not big enough to justify so much attention from a Vice President and Presidential candidate, Mr. Gore said, "I think it's good that people tune in to the fact that this is a huge issue for Americans who live in the suburbs, and at long last they're shedding this misconception that it's somehow a small issue."
Mr. Gore met with top auto executives today as part of an effort to persuade them to work with the Government on ways to improve the fuel efficiency of sport utility vehicles. The big, off-road vehicles account for a fifth of family vehicle sales and outsell cars in the luxury market for automobiles costing $28,000 or more. They are allowed a much lower Federal fuel-economy standard than cars, a legacy of the days when sport utility vehicles and other pickup truck-based vehicles were used mainly by small businesses.
Today's meeting, the latest in a series between the Administration and the auto industry, did not produce any immediate decisions. But after years of mainly studying whether batteries, natural gas and other alternative power sources may someday be used in cars, auto makers are beginning to look at whether these technologies may also have applications in sport utility vehicles.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Weakening Treasury Issues Cause Drop in Most Indexes

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Further deterioration in the bond market gave equity traders an excuse to sell stocks yesterday, and major market averages fell sharply.
One day after setting a new high, the Dow Jones industrial average recorded its sixth point decline in five weeks. Interest rate-sensitive stocks like American Express, J. P. Morgan and Citigroup were among the Dow's biggest decliners. By the close, the blue-chip index was down 128.58, or 1.17 percent, to 10,886.11. 
 Broader indexes also fared poorly.
A big selloff in popular technology stocks like Microsoft, Cisco Systems, America Online and EMC helped drag down the Standard & Poor's 500 stock index by 22.63, or 1.7 percent, to 1,332.00. The Nasdaq's composite index fell even more sharply, dropping 50.46, or 2 percent, to 2,485.12. And the Street.com's Internet stock index fell 17.84, or 2.8 percent, to 615.13.
Although few sectors of the market managed to post gains yesterday, transportation stocks were an exception. For the second straight session, the Dow Jones transportation average set a new high.
The overall market's slide yesterday was attributed not only to profit-taking after Monday's big advance, but also to recent developments in the bond market.
Long-term bond yields have risen to their highest levels in nine months, reflecting traders' fear of inflation, a result of fresh evidence of economic buoyancy. The Conference Board reported yesterday, for example, that its index of leading economic indicators rose for the sixth straight month in March, and the Government said that conditions in the housing market remained strong.
"I think the stock market is right to be worried about rising interest rates," said Hugh Johnson, chief investment officer at the First Albany Corporation.
With signs of economic improvement popping up in a number of countries and industries, fixed-income investments may again become competitive with stocks.
Responding to these changing conditions, Richard Bernstein, chief quantitative strategist at Merrill Lynch & Company, signaled a shift in his group's model portfolio yesterday to 40 percent stocks, 30 percent bonds and 30 percent cash, from 40 percent stocks, 50 percent bonds and 10 percent cash.
"This started with an equity call, where we think it is time to start rotating out of large-cap, high-quality growth stocks and move into value and small-cap stocks," he said.
"Some of our profit indicators in those areas are popping up, signalling it is time to move. But value stocks tend to rise when interest rates go up. So we shortened our bond position as well."
With the exception of Goldman, Sachs, the rise in interest rates hurt the stocks of financial service companies yesterday. Goldman, whose stock was freed to trade for the first time yesterday, saw its share price soar 17 3/8 to close at 70 3/8.
But J. P. Morgan, a rival and a Dow component, fell 4 1/16, to 133 1/2. Merrill Lynch shed 6, to 81 1/4. Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette declined 3 3/16, to 63 15/16. Charles Schwab lost 5 11/16, to 101 3/4. Citigroup fell 2 3/4, to 72 1/4.
Big technology stocks also slid broadly. Microsoft fell 1 13/16, to 78 1/16. Cisco Systems dropped 5, to 108 5/8. Lucent Technologies declined 1 5/8, to 57 7/8. EMC fell 7, to 100. And America Online lost 6 1/16, to 127 1/16.
Trading was active. On the Big Board, 933.2 million shares changed hands. Volume on the Nasdaq was 921.7 million shares.
