HEADLINE: Preserving Montenegro

 BODY:
Slobodan Milosevic is using the war in Kosovo to try to sabotage his most formidable political rival, Milo Djukanovic, the President of Montenegro. Mr. Djukanovic has brought economic reform and ethnic tolerance to his part of Yugoslavia, and calls the ethnic cleansing in Kosovo "insane." The West should do everything possible to help him.
So far, Mr. Djukanovic's popularity has discouraged Mr. Milosevic from using his Second Army, stationed in Montenegro, to attempt a coup. Instead he is trying to undermine Mr. Djukanovic by creating ethnic instability and worsening the economic crisis brought on by the war. Belgrade has driven 70,000 Kosovars into Montenegro, where they are resented by the Slavic population. It has made Montenegro into a NATO target by shooting at alliance planes from there. Although NATO has responded with restraint, each bomb undermines public support for Mr. Djukanovic. 
 Mr. Milosevic has also tried to use the army to take over Montenegro's border posts, television transmitters and its main port -- Yugoslavia's only outlet to the sea. He has replaced commanders with his loyalists, and brought in troops from Serbia. So far Mr. Djukanovic's police have kept control.
Washington has made the crucial pledge that ships carrying oil bound for Montenegro will be exempt from the planned embargo on Serbia. It has also sent Montenegro $10 million, which will help pay pensions and salaries this month. Congress should approve an additional $20 million requested by the White House, but more is urgently needed.
Montenegro also needs more aid to help the Kosovars it has taken in. It has treated them well, but some have now been killed by the Second Army. If these measures fail to keep up support for Mr. Djukanovic and the army does attempt a coup, NATO ought to retaliate from the air. NATO should do whatever it can to protect this democratic enclave from Mr. Milosevic.

HEADLINE: Milwaukee High School Team Wins Annual Test of Economic Wits

BYLINE: By JOHN FILES

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 4

 BODY:
Seated around a vast conference table in the intimidating, vaultlike chambers of the Federal Reserve's Board of Governors, tomorrow's would-be Alan Greenspans gathered this week in a battle of economic wits.
The fourth annual Fed Challenge national championship, sponsored by the Federal Reserve, required the high school students to consider a range of economic data, analyze daily financial figures and then argue for a specific American monetary policy. The nine teams of five members each were judged on their knowledge of monetary policy and the Federal Reserve and on the quality of their presentations, research and analysis. 
 The winners -- the team from the University School of Milwaukee -- will take home a total of $100,000, provided by Citibank: a $10,000 scholarship for each team member; $40,000 for their school (to develop an in-school economics lab) and $10,000 for their faculty adviser, John Stephens. Each of the other eight teams received $35,000.
Although most of the 45 students have taken economics courses, and some of their schools offer college credits for courses that prepare students for the competition, the Fed Challenge is mainly an extracurricular activity, said Lloyd Bromberg, director of educational programs for the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
In some schools, Mr. Bromberg added, the Fed Challenge is treated like an interscholastic sport, with tryouts and weekly practices or lectures.
The University School team had been preparing since February, meeting twice a week for a couple of hours and for three or four hours on weekends. The students said they relied on newspapers, 24-hour cable news and the Internet for information and up-to-date financial statistics.
"There is no opportunity like this in any other academic field," said one member of the team, Mary Broydrick, an 18-year-old senior. "The information we exchange in class, and in preparation for the competition, correspond to real life."
A member of another team, Juan Carlos Rasco, a 17-year-old senior at Belen Jesuit Preparatory High School in Miami, said the Fed Challenge "became our eighth class."
"I'm not taking an economics course right now," Mr. Rasco said. "Most of the work is done on our own -- assessing financial indicators and paying attention to the news."
Ted Hartsoe, an economics teacher who is the faculty adviser for the team from Choate Rosemary Hall, a private school in Wallingford, Conn., said he had made assignments for his team on issues of macroeconomics and the functions of the Fed. "The kids stayed committed and involved with weekly presentations," Mr. Hartsoe said.
In welcoming the students, Mr. Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, said dryly that he would wish them luck but that luck was not involved in the board's decisions. He did acknowledge that the Fed had "sneaked a look" at what the students were doing and saying over the years. And two years ago, board officials say, Mr. Greenspan went so far as to borrow an analogy -- likening higher interest rates to vaccination -- from a three-time winner of the Fed Challenge, Bryan High School in Bryan, Tex.
The program was created in 1995 by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, and became a national competition in 1996. Federal Reserve Banks conduct their own regional competitions, sending the district winners to Washington. This year more than 300 students took part around the nation, with 9 of the 12 Federal Reserve districts represented at the final competition.
Each team offered a 15-minute presentation before a three-judge panel in a mock meeting of the Federal Reserve's policy-setting body. The students analyzed current economic data and forecast trends that can be important in setting monetary policy: inflation, unemployment, trade balance and stock market fluctuation.
After the presentations, the teams faced a 10-minute question-and-answer session led by the judges: William J. McDonough, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York and vice chairman of the policy-setting Federal Open Market Committee; Edward M. Gramlich, a governor of the Federal Reserve Board, and Jack Guyan, president of the Federal Reserve Bank in Atlanta.
Of course, it did not hurt that the high school students and the central bankers were on the same wavelength. All four teams in the final round made recommendations to the Federal Reserve to maintain current policy, including leaving interest rates unchanged.
"The quality of the presentations was outstanding," Mr. McDonough said. "The students showed a remarkable ability to provide a quick and accurate assessment of the questions asked of them and thoughtful answers."

HEADLINE: CRISIS IN THE BALKANS: THE NEGOTIATORS;
Gore and Chernomyrdin, Familiar Partners in Talks, Seek Balkan Solution

BYLINE: By JOHN M. BRODER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 4

 BODY:
Viktor S. Chernomyrdin, the stolid former Russian Prime Minister, and Al Gore, the stolid American Vice President, are engaged in an intensive search for a diplomatic exit to the bloodshed in the Balkans, an effort that brings some risk to both men, but potentially large benefits.
Over the past two days, Mr. Gore and Mr. Chernomyrdin conducted a movable meeting that migrated from Mr. Gore's small quarters in the West Wing of the White House to the Oval Office to the exercise room of Mr. Gore's official residence. 
 While the sessions were "constructive," the leaders said, there has been no breakthrough. Aides said that substantive progress on the diplomatic front would not come for weeks, if ever.
But the two men, lifelong party apparatchiks and loyal lieutenants to more charismatic leaders, do not traffic in breakthroughs. Their speciality is dialogue; their advanced degrees are in "process."
The Gore-Chernomyrdin discussions may in the end yield nothing.Nevertheless, both men stand to gain from these high-profile sessions. Should their talks bear fruit, each would be seen as a peacemaker, an effective negotiator and a credible leader.
But Mr. Gore is engaging in a calculated gamble, as well. Failure in a high-profile diplomatic venture could undercut his argument that his foreign policy experience makes him uniquely qualified among all the current candidates for the White House.
Advisers to Mr. Gore said there was no conscious effort to position him as the seeker of peace in the Balkans, in contrast to President Clinton, the maker of war.
One Gore adviser said that given the hawkish sentiments in the Democratic Party today, Mr. Gore would benefit more from an aggressive pro-war position. Mr. Gore could suffer if he is associated with a Russian-brokered peace deal that comes to be seen as too easy on President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia, this adviser said.
The Gore-Chernomyrdin dialogue, first opened six years ago, has been an invaluable high-level channel for addressing issues that their bosses do not have time for and their subordinates cannot deliver on. They are able to conduct talks without the pomp of summitry or the indecision of staff-level work. And their personal connection, groomed over years in high office, creates a bond of trust unrivaled anywhere else in the American-Russia relationship.
"There's just no doubt that we have the ability to talk with one another in total candor and in total confidence that neither is trying to pull the wool over the other's eyes," Mr. Gore said in an interview today.
Mr. Gore and Mr. Chernomyrdin have been negotiating partners since early 1993, when Mr. Chernomyrdin was the newly appointed Russian Prime Minister under President Boris N. Yeltsin and Mr. Gore took office as Bill Clinton's Vice President.
In 10 formal sessions of the Gore-Chernomyrdin Commission on Economic, Security and Scientific Issues (pretentiously referred to by Roman numerals, like Super Bowls), the two leaders tackled some of the thorniest issues dividing the United States and Russia. They took on Russian missile sales to Iran, lax controls on Russian weapons-grade plutonium, competition for Russian oil and gas resources, international loan commitments, and cooperation in space between the two countries. Their discussions were technical and detailed, without much bluster, said an aide to Mr. Gore.
The formal sessions ended when Mr. Yeltsin dismissed Mr. Chernomyrdin in March of last year as the Russian economy was imploding, but Mr. Gore maintained informal contacts with his former negotiating partner.
The link was re-established this year when Mr. Yeltsin named the former premier Moscow's special envoy for the Balkans, dramatizing Russia's interest in aiding its historical ally, Serbia, and enhancing its own prestige.
Russia strongly opposed NATO's use of force against Yugoslavia when bombs started falling on March 24, provoking one of the deepest crises in Russia's relationship with the West since the collapse of the Soviet Union. Moscow has offered itself as a negotiator in hope of reasserting its influence and international relevance.
Thus it was natural to turn to one of the oldest and deepest ties in American-Russian diplomacy, the Gore-Chernomyrdin channel. Mr. Chernomyrdin was seen as an ideal interlocutor because he did not have confining governmental responsibilities, but he carried the full authority of President Yeltsin. He had also earned a reputation over the years of dealings with the Vice President as someone who backed up his promises with action.
"This is a very good, very well-established working link with a very practical side to it," said Leon Feurth, Mr. Gore's chief foreign policy adviser. "Both of the people involved are accustomed to working out problems with each other."
Administration officials who attended the Gore-Chernomyrdin meetings this week were reluctant to share details of their discussions. The Americans tried to make clear to Mr. Chernomyrdin the conditions the allies are demanding before they will consider halting hostilities against Belgrade. Mr. Chernomyrdin was relaying Mr. Milosevic's own position, which so far remains wholly unacceptable to the United States and its allies.
Do not expect miracles, American officials cautioned today. The talks remain about process, not yet about peace.
"This is very much a work in progress and very much uncertain," a senior Administration official who participated in the talks said. "We're not negotiating a peace in the Balkans with Russia. If we were, we'd be home by now. The problem is Milosevic. The Russians do not have decisive influence with him, nor do they claim a decisive influence. But they are trying to help. They are trying to end this conflict."

HEADLINE: Report Raises Concerns About Bias in Crash Inquiries

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 4

 BODY:
The Government's system for organizing crash investigations is too dependent on work from groups with direct interests in the results, including manufacturers, operators and regulators, a draft report by the Rand Corporation says.
The preliminary report, which Rand has been asked to present on Thursday at a House budget hearing, also found that lengthy investigations like those involving USAir 427, which lasted for more than four years, and Trans World Airlines 800, now two and a half years old, are becoming the norm, as fewer airplanes crash from simple causes like navigation error or parts failure. The USAir flight crashed near Pittsburgh in September 1994, killing 132 people, and the T.W.A. flight went down off Long Island in July 1996, killing 230. 
 The stakes are rising in each investigation, the report said, with higher and higher payments in civil suits brought by survivors, or settlements in suits among airlines, manufacturers and component producers. Market share and public confidence are also at stake.
"Dispassionate fact-finding becomes problematic," Rand said in notes for a briefing to National Transportation Safety Board executives last month. The board requested the study last year out of concern over public criticism of accident investigations, especially air crashes. Beyond concerns over the length of time that investigations take, families of the dead, and especially their lawyers, are seeking a greater role in the investigations.
Those investigations follow what the board calls its "party system," under which it invites those with specific expertise to help it investigate but not analyze or draw conclusions. For example, in the case of USAir 427, it had help from the airline, the pilots' union, Boeing, the company that manufactured a suspect hydraulic valve and the Federal Aviation Administration.
Cynthia C. Lebow, a Rand analyst who is leading the study, said in a interview that "the party process is essential in many respects because the safety board is never going to be an enormous agency, and it will never have the staff and the technical capability to design an aircraft or operate an airline." But of the parties, Ms. Lebow said, "you have to recognize that in this day and age, those guys are coming in with multiple agendas," including limiting their legal liability and maintaining public reputation or market share.
The study recommends that the agency add more experts to its staff, but also practice "knowledge management," knowing where to find outside expertise, from NASA, the Defense Department, national laboratories or academic institutions.
In addition, top board officials say -- and the study confirms -- that the agency lacks the resources to keep training its investigators, as the complexity of airplanes, air traffic control systems and related equipment advances year by year. In a survey, 40 percent of the investigators told Rand that they had got no training at all, the report said, and average annual training expenditure per aviation employee was $2,000, at a time when learning to fly new models of planes could cost up to $40,000.
The study found that the safety board's staff of about 400 people, of whom about half are investigators, had been "operating under continuing excessive workload." Aviation investigators told Rand researchers that they worked an average of 51 1/2 hours a week, not counting periods of intense work immediately after crashes, when they are in the field from sunup until sundown, and meet every evening to compare notes.
Board officials say that no matter the investigators' pay grade, their overtime is at the time-and-a-half rate of junior employees, which is sometimes less than their straight-time pay. Board officials say investigators for other agencies, sometimes working shoulder-to-shoulder with safety board investigators, receive traditional time-and-a-half overtime.
The study said many employees were eligible for retirement, suggesting a looming personnel crisis.
The Administration's budget request for the agency for the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1 is $57 million, which is about equal to spending in the current fiscal year, including extra money voted by Congress for the T.W.A. 800 inquiry and other special investigations. But the board wants $73 million for overtime and training in the fiscal year 2001.
"We hire smart people, and then we work them hard, and we don't train them," said Peter Goelz, the agency's managing director, in an interview. He said more money would allow the board to again finish major inquiries in 12 to 18 months.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Levitt of S.E.C. Criticizes Ads for On-Line Investing
Arthur Levitt, the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, criticized brokerage industry advertisements focusing on the get-rich aspect of on-line investing, contending they were doing more harm than good for both Wall Street and the public.
Mr. Levitt also admonished individual investors to better educate themselves about on-line trading. But he called on brokerage firms to strengthen their disclosure of the risks of trading stocks over the Internet. Page C5. 

Treasury Bond Prices Drop Sharply
Bond prices dropped sharply, pushing long-term interest rates to their highest level in nine months. The yield of the benchmark 30-year Treasury jumped to 5.71 percent. Investors are losing the conviction that the United States economy will slow this year, with inflation remaining in check; instead, a growing number worry that a rebound in the rest of the world will keep growth strong here and nudge inflation higher. C10.
 
Stocks Fall; Dow Down 129 Points
Stocks tumbled, sending the Dow Jones industrial average down 128.58 points, or 1.17 percent, to 10,886.11. The Nasdaq composite index fell 50.46 points, or 2 percent, to 2,485.12. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index declined 22.63 points, or 1.7 percent, to 1,332.00. C10.
 
Shares of Goldman Sachs Group, which was Wall Street's last big private partnership, soared on their first day of trading, rising $17.375, or 33 percent, to $70.375. C6.
 
Higher Gasoline Prices Forecast
Approaching the key summer driving season, gasoline prices are up sharply from historically low levels, a result of cuts by major oil producing countries. Now, citing tight American supplies of gasoline, experts foresee still higher prices. Travel. C8.
 
CBS Puts Pressure on Morning TV
CBS's decision to bring Bryant Gumbel back to morning television raises the ante in the competition among network morning programs, an area gaining more attention from network executives because it offers far more potential for increased profits than prime time or any other hour of the day. With Mr. Gumbel, a new program and new studio, to be built in one of the most visible sites in Manhattan, CBS is making a commitment to compete head to head with NBC's "Today" show, by far the dominant show in the morning with Katie Couric and Matt Lauer. C6.
 
Alliance Formed With Sheep Cloner
Geron, a leader in what has been called regenerative medicine, said it was forming a $20 million alliance with the Roslin Institute of Scotland, which cloned Dolly the sheep. A22.
 
Auto Sales Rose 3.9% in April
Auto sales climbed 3.9 percent in April despite lower-than-expected results at G.M. C2.
 
Senate Debates Banking Legislation
The Senate began debating a broad measure to rewrite the nation's banking laws despite deep partisan disagreements over both regulatory authority and existing requirements that banks lend to members of minority groups and others with little access to credit. C2.
 
Eisner Testifies in Katzenberg Suit
The chairman of Walt Disney, Michael D. Eisner, testifying for the first time in the lawsuit by his former studio chief, Jeffrey Katzenberg, disputed Mr. Katzenberg's contention that Disney owes him millions of dollars. C7.
 
A Key Eastman Kodak Official Dies
Eastman Kodak's chief financial officer, Harry L. Kavetas, who was an architect of the company's revival, died. C6.

HEADLINE: AT&T Is Seen Forging Link To Microsoft

BYLINE: By GERALDINE FABRIKANT and SETH SCHIESE

 BODY:
The AT&T Corporation is close to forming a wide-ranging partnership with the Microsoft Corporation as part of an intricate web of deals that also would make AT&T the winner in the battle against the Comcast Corporation for Mediaone Group Inc., the big cable television company, executives close to the negotiations said last night.
Comcast bowed out of a potential bidding war for Mediaone last night by reaching an agreement with AT&T to exchange certain cable systems. The deal would give Comcast an additional two million subscribers and AT&T up to $9.2 billion. 
 But the most intriguing and potentially important element of the numerous deals is the partnership that AT&T is negotiating with Microsoft, the No. 1 maker of personal computer software.
Under the terms of the deal being negotiated last night, Microsoft would invest about $5 billion in AT&T to acquire 2 to 3 percent of AT&T, executives close to the talks said. Microsoft would pay more than the $51.5625 closing price of AT&T shares yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, the executives said. They added that the size of the premium to be paid was one of the central sticking points in the negotiations last night.
Microsoft would get what it has long been seeking: a commitment from AT&T to use Microsoft's Windows operating system in the advanced set-top boxes that AT&T will deploy to offer bundles of digital services.
Together, AT&T and Microsoft have a market value of more than half a trillion dollars and, if linked, would form the world's leading force in technology and communications. Any AT&T-Microsoft partnership would be sure to arouse concern among politicians and regulators. Though the two companies are not now competitors, both AT&T and Microsoft are behemoths with long traditions of dominating their industries.
The prospect of an alliance is sure to seem mind-boggling to at least some powerful people in Washington.
William E. Kennard, the chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, declined to comment last night.
While AT&T does not need the money, an investment by Microsoft would buoy AT&T's shares, which may fall as the company continues its headlong deal-making.
With $22 billion in cash and no debt -- and already owning 11 percent of Comcast -- Microsoft found itself in a kingmaker role in the Mediaone bidding.
An investment in AT&T would be partly defensive for Microsoft. The company has scrambled for advantage for Windows CE -- the version of its operating system for small devices -- in the young, fast-changing market for software used in television set-top boxes. And Microsoft also wants to try to insure access to high-speed networks for its other software and Internet commerce businesses.
But Microsoft's move would also be offensive in that it could help the company as the Internet business moves toward the so-called broadband model in which households are continuously connected to high-speed data lines.
As for Comcast, whose initial $53 billion bid for Mediaone was topped by an AT&T offer of $58 billion, it would end up with as many as two million of AT&T's existing cable subscribers, mostly on the East Coast as part of the AT&T deal. It will also assume management control over an additional two million AT&T cable subscribers.
Even after selling up to two million subscribers to Comcast, AT&T, the nation's biggest telephone company, would emerge from the fray as the nation's biggest cable television company. Before agreeing to acquire Tele-Communications Inc. for about $32 billion last summer, AT&T had no presence in cable television. But C. Michael Armstrong, AT&T's chairman of 18 months, is pursuing a vision of delivering integrated packages of telephone, television and high-speed Internet access to millions of households using cable lines.
Comcast will still end up the No. 3 cable television company. The residential customers it is set to buy from AT&T will serve to solidify Comcast's dominance between Philadelphia and Washington, executives close to the talks said. AT&T and Comcast agreed to form a venture to offer telephone service over Comcast's cables.
Though Comcast has agreed to drop out of the bidding for Mediaone, it will walk away with a rich prize, analysts said yesterday. At a price of up to $9.2 billion in cash and stock for as many as two million cable subscribers, Comcast is paying roughly $4,500 a subscriber, about the industry average.
Comcast, based in Philadelphia, will swap an additional 750,000 subscribers to give it more clustered subscribers in crucial markets. Though only half of the exact locations for cable swaps and purchases had been determined late last night, a person involved in the discussions said Comcast was increasing cable subscribers in some of its main markets, including Philadelphia, Nashville and parts of Michigan, and giving up some in Chicago, Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and Sacramento, Calif.
To pay for the subscribers, Comcast will use the $1.5 billion fee that Mediaone will pay for backing out of the original deal with Comcast. Comcast is also swapping back to AT&T $1.5 billion in AT&T stock and another $1 billion in the stock of At-Home, a provider of Internet services over cable modems. Had Comcast sold that stock on the open market, it would have paid heavy capital gains taxes. Selling it back to AT&T is a tax-free transaction, people close to the company noted last night.
To pay the balance of the purchase price, Comcast will issue additional shares of its own nonvoting stock at a price based on how the stock trades over the next 50 days. A person close to the talks said that Comcast expected to add 75 million new shares to its existing base of 450 million shares.
Comcast clearly wanted Mediaone but was unable to form a bidding alliance with America Online, which was not in a position to issue more stock to pay its share because its stock price has been volatile. Microsoft, another potential ally, decided to cut a deal with AT&T, and Comcast did not have the financial muscle to buy the company on its own.
But several analysts who follow Comcast were pleased by the new deal. For one thing, Comcast will be using its deal-breakup fee of $1.5 billion, which one analyst called found money. It is also using a large slug of Comcast stock, which is trading near record prices. It closed yesterday at $64.125, down $1.8125. And for analysts who believe that size is less important than clustered systems that enable cable companies to sell local advertising and have better management control, Comcast is moving close to that model.
Continued consolidations have reassured investors that cable companies will be well run and will benefit from economies of scale.
In a related transaction, AT&T is buying the half of Lenfest Communications that it does not already own from that company's chairman, Jerry Lenfest. The price for the midsize cable company is $2 billion, or 43 million shares of AT&T stock.
Brian Roberts, Comcast's president and a member of the family that controls the company, will manage those cable systems, which are heavily weighted in New Jersey and Philadelphia, where Comcast already has cable systems.

HEADLINE: ON HOCKEY;
Series a Straight Line In Tangled Tale for Jagr

BYLINE: By Joe Lapointe

DATELINE: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.

 BODY:
Seven hours before the face-off, Jaromir Jagr kept answering the same questions the same way. What about the pressure of the seventh and deciding game against the Devils in the first round of the Stanley Cup playoffs?
Does he like pressure? someone asked Jagr. "Everybody does," Jagr said, smiling frequently. "I like the pressure." And he didn't seem too concerned about the injured groin muscle that kept him out of four games in this series and limited his effectiveness in Game 6. In that one, a Pittsburgh victory on Sunday, he scored two goals -- the tying goal late and the game winner in overtime -- and he said he was lucky to get them while skating with pain and limited range of motion. 
 Jagr spoke early, after yesterday's morning skate, a hockey ritual that is a mixture of light practice, interviews, gossip, spin and propaganda. As he walked through the door and down the corridor, he spied a TV crew interviewing Matthew Barnaby, the agitator of Pittsburgh's forward lines. Jagr sneaked behind him and began to jump up and down, hair flopping, arms waving, legs stretching, causing great laughter and a light air that contrasted with the tense Devils' mood down the hall.
Last night, when the first round was decided, Jagr had reason to jump up and down again, but he stood still, exhausted. Although his skating was even more labored than it was in the previous game, Jagr produced some brilliant moments as the Penguins won by 4-2 to win the four-of-seven-game series, four games to three. The Penguins will go on to play Toronto in the second round.
Even while injured, Jagr showed why he won the National Hockey League's scoring title this season and is the consensus favorite to win the Hart trophy as the most valuable player in the N.H.L.
"People judge you by the way you play in the playoffs," he said.
Jagr was credited with two assists, including a beauty in the final minute of the second period. On that play, he drew two Devils defensemen to him, deep in the right-wing side of the New Jersey zone, before flipping a backhanded pass to the uncovered Jan Hrdina, who scored the goal that put the Penguins up by 3-1 and caused the home fans to boo the Devils as they left the ice for intermission.
On the first goal, by German Titov, Jagr did not get credit for an assist, but he created the play by pursuing the puck deep into the Devils' end and occupying the attention of Scott Stevens, the Devils' defenseman. This cleared space and time for Martin Straka to set up Titov. On the fourth Pittsburgh goal, the one that made it 4-2 late in the third period and sealed the decision, Jagr came up with a loose puck in the neutral zone, roared in on goalie Martin Brodeur and fired. Brodeur made a save, but was vulnerable for Straka's scoring shot on the rebound.
"When I came back, it was a big lift for the whole team," Jagr said. "But I told the guys, 'Don't count on me to score three goals.' "
His Penguins were the eighth and final seeded team in the Eastern Conference; the Devils were ranked first, and that wasn't Pittsburgh's only disadvantage. Their success is coming against a backdrop of chaos. The franchise has been in bankruptcy for most of the season. A Federal judge is hearing the case. The major group bidding for the team is fronted by Mario Lemieux, the former Penguins star who is owed more than $30 million in deferred salary. When Lemieux led the team to two Stanley Cups as captain in the early 1990's, Jagr was his understudy. The letters of "Jaromir," the fans noted, could be rearranged to spell "Mario Jr." Now, Jagr is the captain.
The N.H.L. has told the court that it needs to know the fate of the team by June 1, although the judge has said it may take longer. Among the options, according to the N.H.L.: the franchise could be sold and moved or the franchise could be dissolved, with the players redistributed throughout the league via some as-yet unannounced method. Jagr, in reply to a question last night, noted that he stands to lose money because some of his past salary has been deferred.
Amid all this, Jagr is excelling. He took many hard hits from Devils checkers last night, missing one shift for medical attention, but he is a hard man to discourage. "Scary moment," he said of the missed shift. "I started to feel a little pain. I thought it was over. The pain went away."
Stevens, the Devils' captain, had hinted last week that he might not have been sidelined with an injury such as the one to Jagr. Perhaps he should have bitten his tongue. On many of their shifts they were matched against each other and Jagr was at his best.
Jagr is playing with a pair of specially made shorts to protect his injured groin. The pants, shipped from Vancouver, are made of strong stretch material, like a girdle, with a special belt system. A heating patch is sewn on the inside of the shorts to warm the groin area. Removable, figure-eight straps are used to compress and warm the thigh tissue. At times during last night's game, Jagr could be seen wincing on the Penguins' bench and reaching into his waistband to adjust the equipment.
He has his name on the Stanley Cup twice from the Lemieux era, and he won a gold medal last year with the Czech Republic in the Olympics. A nine-year veteran at age 27, he still seems youthful, with the chubby cheeks of a boy. When someone asked why so many great players, including several Penguins, come from the Czech Republic, Jagr turned serious, recalling how he grew up in what was then called Czechoslovakia. "Under Communism," he said, sports were a way out, a way to travel, to see the world. The Government sponsored the team and gave out free sticks, free uniforms, free ice time.
Now, everything is different. He is a world-class athlete, a master of his sport, working in the United States during an economic boom of capitalism for a franchise in financial free fall. And he plays in pain and deals with it, too, surviving and thriving, leading his team to who knows where. What a country, what a team, what a player.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
Accounts Moving At Mad Dogs

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott

 BODY:
Accounts are leaving and arriving at Mad Dogs and Englishmen in New York.
Mad Dogs is losing the trade advertising duties for the American account of The Economist magazine, which it had handled since 1991. The account, with billings estimated at $1 million to $2 million, is being consolidated at Weiss Stagliano Partners in New York, which has handled the corporate or consumer duties since 1997. The Economist is part of Economist Newspaper Ltd., the British company half-owned by Pearson Group P.L.C. that calls itself Economist Group. 
 More than offsetting its loss, Mad Dogs was awarded duties for three branding assignments with total billings estimated at $6 million. The Time Warner Cable Group in New York, part of Time Warner Inc., selected the agency to produce an integrated television, print and outdoor campaign to begin in the fall. Mad Dogs produced a similar campaign last year.
The Daily Deal, a financial newspaper that American Lawyer Media Inc. in New York plans to start publishing in the fall, named Mad Dogs to create a trade campaign. And Vanishing Point in New York, a beauty services retailer, selected the agency to a create a campaign to start this spring.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;
Canada's Central Bank Lowers Discount Rate

BYLINE: Agence France-Presse

 BODY:
The Bank of Canada announced a quarter-point drop in its discount rate yesterday, to 4.75 percent. Within minutes, the nation's largest commercial bank, the Royal Bank of Canada, announced that it would cut its prime rate, which it charges its best customers, by a quarter of a point, to 6.25 percent. 
 Yesterday's move was the fifth cut in the central bank's discount rate in eight months and was announced as the Canadian dollar was at a 12-month high against the United States dollar. The Canadian dollar traded yesterday at 68.68 cents (United States), compared with 69.13 cents on Monday.

HEADLINE: Commercial Real Estate;
Disney Presses Ahead With Times Sq. Restaurant

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA

 BODY:
This would not seem to be the best time to get into the theme restaurant business.
The best known of the theme operators, Planet Hollywood, is losing money and struggling to avoid bankruptcy. It is trying to sell its Official All Star Cafe chain without success. Others have cut back expansion plans and some themes have died before the first restaurant opened its doors. 
 Nevertheless, the Walt Disney Company is pressing ahead with plans to open a three-level, 42,000-square-foot sports and television theme restaurant in Times Square at the end of the summer. It will be in the new office building being completed on the east side of Broadway between 42d and 43d Streets that will be named after one of its chief tenants, the Conde Nast publishing company.
The restaurant will be called the ESPN Zone, after Disney's all-sports network. The new installation will add to the growing presence of the Disney company in the Times Square area. In addition to a retail store that has operated for several years at the southwestern corner of 42d Street and Seventh Avenue, the Disney-owned ABC network is building a broadcast studio overlooking Broadway at 44th Street.
Two musical shows based on Disney animated movies, "The Lion King" and "Beauty and the Beast," are also playing in the Times Square area, "The Lion King" in the New Amsterdam Theater on 42d Street, which the company restored and leases from New York State.
Unlike most other theme restaurants, whose economics are based on the sales of food and theme-related merchandise, ESPN Zone is designed with sports and broadcasting themes and has an added source of income: interactive games.
One ESPN Zone restaurant has operated in Baltimore for less than a year and another is scheduled to open in Chicago in July. Disney officials say the New York property will be the chain's flagship.
The restaurant will have three levels, which Disney Regional Entertainment, the division developing the restaurants, calls the Studio Grille, the Screening Room and the Sports Arena. The entrance will be on Broadway, north of 42d Street.
The Studio Grille, on the first floor, will be a dining room decorated with elements of ESPN studios, including replicas of the sets of such programs as "Sportscenter," "Baseball Tonight" and "NBA2Night." Disney officials said that some broadcasting would be done from the site.
"We are going to have a full-time radio station there and television specials," said Art Levitt, president of Disney Regional.
The next floor up is the Screening Room, which is intended for people who want to eat while watching sports. The floor will be dominated by two 16-by-13-foot screens surrounded by a dozen 37-inch monitors. In all, the restaurant will have 220 video monitors.
The dual large screens are unusual in New York, officials said, so that Giants and Jets or Yankees and Mets games can be shown simultaneously. "There are over 200 days a year when two New York sports teams are playing at the same time," said Scott Dickey, director of marketing and sales for ESPN Zone. Those wanting to watch games in other cities can also be accommodated. ESPN Zone officials say they can bring in any game being broadcast in the country.
Full food service will be available on the first two floors, with the 70-item menu devoted to what the company describes as "upscale American grill food." Alcoholic drinks will be available only on the third floor, which will stretch from 42d to 43d Street but which will have part of its glass facade obscured by the large signs expected to be mounted on the building. That floor will feature interactive games at which customers, in theory at least, can test their skills against sports stars'.
At a baseball batting cage, customers will be able to play a video of a favorite pitcher winding up and throwing a baseball. In fact, the ball will be thrown by a standard pitching machine through a hole in the screen. Other games will include simulated football and ice hockey, Mr. Dickey said.
"The concept is that you will watch a game downstairs and say, 'Ewing should have taken that shot,' " Mr. Dickey said, referring to the Knicks center. "Then you can go upstairs and take that shot yourself." Customers will pay for their play using a debit card bought in advance, with a $5 minimum purchase.
The complex will include a retail store, Zone Stuff, with a separate entrance at the corner of 42d and Broadway. The items offered for sale will include caps, T-shirts and jackets emblazoned with the ESPN logo -- what Mr. Dickey described as "high-end golf apparel."
The restaurant will seat 450 to 475 people, but since the third floor can accommodate several hundred people playing games, the total capacity may be 850 or more. About 400 people will work at the ESPN Zone.
Although no mention of the Disney ownership will be made at the ESPN Zone, the restaurant is part of a plan to offer Disney entertainment to people not inclined to make the trek to its parks in Anaheim, Calif., and Orlando, Fla.
The company is also developing Disney Quest, an interactive theme park that will cover 100,000 square feet in each location, Mr. Dickey said, and Club Disney, a suburban playground for small children and their parents.

HEADLINE: Supplies-Side Economics;
When Disaster Strikes, Someone Must Provide the Tents

BYLINE: By BARRY MEIER

 BODY:
The fax in Joe Addis's makeshift office near Skopje, Macedonia, has been whirring since the Catholic Relief Services official set up shop near a refugee camp last month. Businesses and brokers have besieged him with sales pitches for tents, toothpaste, food, vegetable oil, laundry soap, sanitary napkins and medical supplies.
Several auto dealers that have an exclusive franchise with Toyota, Ford or Nissan to sell to relief groups, have offered him all-terrain vehicles. Generic-drug wholesalers in Britain and the Netherlands that specialize in supplying field clinics with aspirin, antibiotics and antidepressants, have been in touch with him. So has a company in South Carolina that sells plastic sheeting, a Bronx company that offers blankets and one in Massachusetts that sells prefabricated warehouses. 
 In any disaster -- war, hurricane, famine -- government agencies and humanitarian organizations rush to bring aid. Standing behind them is a growing "disaster industry," a loose conglomeration of companies and middlemen for which bad times can mean boom business.
The companies include small manufacturers whose normal business does not include disasters but which are eager to seize a sudden opportunity. But for the bulk of the companies, which are largely based in Europe and employ from 10 to 500 people, sales to relief and development agencies are their main business. Some are specialized procurement brokers that for a commission of 5 to 20 percent will search for items needed by relief groups like surplus field kitchens, bulletproof vests and concertina wire.
Every year, governments and international organizations spend tens of billions of dollars on both long-term relief projects and emergencies. And large buyers like the Federal Government will buy directly from manufacturers, negotiating contracts and storing emergency supplies at warehouses worldwide.
But in a crisis like the war in Kosovo, charities, both large and small, pour hundreds of millions into a region. In these chaotic situations, they often turn to companies and brokers that are disaster specialists, which can ship goods quickly, track down hard-to-find items and even extend credit. In addition, some relief organizations do not have their own procurement offices and rely on outsiders.
Many companies employ former relief workers and say they can do well by doing good. Others see a huge aid effort as an opportunity to profiteer by selling goods at inflated prices to humanitarian groups or to donate drugs close to their expiration date rather than paying to destroy them.
With hundreds of thousands of refugees in the Balkans in need of blankets, some dealers are holding back the 5 to 10 percent discount normally given for bulk purchases, one major procurement agency said. Depending on quality and material, a blanket used in relief operations costs from $1.50 to $5.
"Where we would normally expect a bulk discount, the discount is not coming through," said Tony Urwin, a buyer with Crown Agents Ltd., a nonprofit procurement service that was part of the British Government until a few years ago. Mr. Urwin declined to identify the dealers but said he was able to find a blanket manufacturer in the United States willing to give him the discount.
Officials of International Procurement Agency, a Dutch company, said it was supplying groups in Kosovo, including World Vision International, with items it had bought from around the world. Blankets are coming from an Egyptian producer, plastic sheeting used for ground coverings is coming from a Dutch company and inexpensive pots and pans from a Czech manufacturer.
"It's a madhouse at the moment," said Bob Vliestra, the company's commercial director.
 
Size of Industry Is Hard to Estimate
Reliable estimates for the size of the industry that serves the disaster and long-term relief market do not exist. With rare exceptions, all the companies selling disaster supplies are private and do not disclose their sales. But Kim Ginnerup, the director of Mission Pharma, a Danish drug wholesaler for which relief groups account for about half of sales, estimated that for drugs alone, the relief market amounted to $1 billion a year.
He said that much of the modern industry sprang up in Europe about 25 years ago among companies focused on supplying Africa, where much relief work was then under way.
Some companies have roots in the nonprofit world. Greg Spitzfaden, an official of Tri-Med of Britain, said that company got its start when its three founders began arranging the shipment of relief items bought with the proceeds from charity rock concerts like Live Aid and Band Aid.
Later, the company branched into procurement and now has offices close to troubled regions, said Mr. Spitzfaden, who recently flew to Macedonia to visit refugee camps and work with clients, including Mr. Addis of Catholic Relief Services.
"We have 13 offices in the places in the world that are at the absolute bottom of everyone's tourist list," he said. Mr. Spitzfaden's office is in one of the world's more idyllic spots, Peterborough, N.H., and many of the European-based concerns have offices here so they can work closely with relief groups based in the United States.
While brokers like Tri-Med will seek out anything requested by a relief group, other companies specialize. Toyota Gibraltar, in the British colony, is Toyota Motor's exclusive dealer to agencies working in relief and development worldwide.
A competitor, Kjaer & Kjaer, a Danish company that holds the Nissan Motor relief distributorship, has based a salesman in Sarajevo to deal with charities and government agencies operating in Albania and Macedonia and has posted his cellular telephone number on its Internet site.
"The situation in Kosovo is deteriorating every minute," the company's site states. "We may be able to assist your efforts in the region."
Soeren Laursen, the Kjaer's marketing manager, said it had sold about 100 all-terrain and pickup vehicles in recent years to groups working in the Balkans. He said the vehicles were stripped-down models built to "Africa specifications" to endure rough conditions. Some have been modified as ambulances or fitted with armor and ballistic floor mats to protect occupants if they go over a land mine.
 
Drug Makers Try To Drum Up Sales
Some companies have just started to get a toehold in the business. Three years ago, for instance, Schein Pharmaceutical Inc., a generic-drug producer based in Florham Park, N.J., hired Allison Formal, a former official with International Services for Medical Services for Health, a relief group, to help sell drugs to humanitarian organizations.
Ms. Formal said Schein, in some cases, had given drugs at cost to relief groups to build up relationships. But typically, the company charges from 12 to 30 percent above a drug's production cost, she added. Drugs sold to commercial wholesale buyers typically cost at least twice as much.
Drug companies in the disaster market must sell products to charities at a steep discount because they are competing against United Nations agencies, which buy huge quantities directly from manufacturers and pass the savings along.
Currently, sales to humanitarian groups are about 1 percent of Schein's annual sales, or about $5 million, Ms. Formal said.
Donated medical supplies, which are desperately needed in crises like Kosovo, can cause their own problems for aid groups. A 1997 article in the New England Journal of Medicine estimated that it would cost the World Health Organization about $2,000 a ton to destroy the hundreds of tons of expired drugs and unusable medical supplies sent to Bosnia and Herzegovina during that conflict.
Normally, a pharmaceutical company must destroy expired drugs in a hazardous waste incinerator, an expensive form of disposal.
A W.H.O. guideline now calls for donated medical supplies to be no less than a year away from expiration. But Max Ziv, a pharmacist working at Genpharm Inc., a generic drug maker in Toronto, said in a telephone interview that he had been giving charities drugs with a shelf life of six months. Mr. Ziv collectes the drugs from his employer and other companies and donates them.
Both Mr. Ziv and Bruce W. Simpson, the president of Genpharm, said they were unaware of the W.H.O. guideline but defended the practice, saying the drugs were good. Genpharm is a subsidiary of Merck K.G.a.A., a German company that is not related to Merck & Company, the American drug giant.
"It is a moral issue," Mr. Ziv said. "Would you rather see people in the third world dying because they need medicines?"
Last year, however, the Vietnamese Government burned about 1,000 pounds of expired antibiotics and drugs that Mr. Ziv had collected and donated. He said the drugs were no older than six months from expiration when they reached Vietnam in March. Government officials destroyed the drugs last fall, according to news reports.
 
Trying to Unload Wrong Kind of Tent
As the Kosovo crisis continues, some sellers of tents are apparently seeking to unload products of little use to refugees. Normally, such products are made by specialized factories, said Mr. Urwin, the buyer with Crown Agents. In recent weeks, he said that some tent producers that normally did not serve the relief market tried to sell him expensive tents designed for campers. The problem: the tents are too small for people to stand inside.
"They are fine if you are looking to spend a weekend in the mountains or on the beach," Mr. Urwin said.
And even products designed for refugees are not always right for the situation. Mr. Addis, the Catholic Relief official, said that some of the tents delivered to Stankovic I, a sprawling refugee camp outside Skopje, do not have floors because they were produced for Africa, where it is hot and relatively dry. As a result, the charity has bought plastic sheeting to serve as tent bottoms.
Thus far, Mr. Addis said, his experience with companies in the disaster business had been good. Not long after surveying the needs of the 30,000 Kosovar Albanian refugees at the Stankovic camp, he decided to bring in military-style field kitchens to cook hot meals for thousands of them at a time.
But when he looked into buying that number of new kitchens, Mr. Addis said he quickly found that the cost was steep and that new kitchens would take six to eight weeks to get to Albania.
He alerted Mr. Spitzfaden of Tri-Med of the problem, and the procurement company found a surplus dealer that had 22 used NATO field kitchens. Catholic Relief Service bought the kitchens, utensils included, for $9,000 each and shipped them immediately to Albania.
Whatever Tri-Med's markup was, Mr. Addis figures he got a deal. It would have cost him $1 million, about five times what he paid, to buy 22 new kitchens.
"I feel we got a good price," he said.

HEADLINE: GAME THEORY;
New York City on Screen: Love It or Fix It

BYLINE: By J. C. Herz; E-mail address: Herz@nytimes.com

 BODY:
NEW YORK CITY begs for simulation. It has been simulated in movies, books, paintings and avant-garde classical music, not to mention prime-time television. Inevitably, it has been assembled in digital media.
But just as there are different visions of the Big Apple on celluloid, there are different visions of New York in ones and zeros. 
 One vision is Sim City 3000, the latest installment in the best-selling line of virtual metropolis construction kits. Like its predecessors, Sim City 3000 puts you in the mayor's office of an urban hub, with all the attendant responsibilities: roads, power lines, water usage, zoning, public transportation, environmental policy, education, finance, garbage disposal, traffic, unemployment, law enforcement and public approval ratings. Build wisely, and your citizens will thrive.
It's an urban planning exercise with good production values. There are multiple levels of resolution, so you can zoom into different neighborhoods and see commercial zones filled with Lilliputian business people, industrial zones speckled with hard-hat workers and tiny firefighters loitering outside their stations. Downtown you'll hear traffic. In residential neighborhoods, you may hear birds chirping and children playing.
But where previous Sim City titles simulated a generic urban environment, this one allows you to create the Sim City That Never Sleeps. Not only can you build on a ready-made terrain that mirrors the contours of Manhattan, but there are also little landmarks to plant on the map: Grand Central Terminal, Lincoln Center, the United Nations, Rockefeller Center and the Statue of Liberty.
If you want to include the Chrysler Building and the Guggenheim, you can download them from the Web site (www.simcity.com), which recently posted a "Build Manhattan" contest for Sim City users.
Would-be Donald Trumps took considerable license. There was Trihattan, a fanciful version of the city with three downtowns, and Alotta-Opolis, which incorporates artificial lakes, a wheat field and a moat surrounding the American Museum of Natural History.
One contestant asked the judges to "imagine N.Y. with San Francisco's TransAmerica tower, Houston's 700 Louisiana building, Hong Kong's Bank of China tower and the Arc de Triomphe in a relocated Central Park."
Other players used landmarks from outside New York as place holders for buildings that aren't available. "Trump Tower is represented by Columbia Seafirst Center, and the Citicorp Building is the 700 Louisiana," explained Gergory Jungenberg, a resident of Long Island City, N.Y. "Flatiron Building is the Bank of America. Riker's Island has Alcatraz representing the prison there. Everything in this city is meticulously accurate."
Of course, it isn't. There is no Times Square. The subways are wrong; they are much better than ours. There's a badly needed second line on the East Side and plenty of crosstown trains, for which we all yearn. There are also palm trees and an inexplicable geyser in Central Park.
But when you start to examine these model Manhattans block by block, as a resident, you're looking for another kind of simulation. You're not interested in the city-as-mechanism, with all moving parts in order. You want to see the city as a mirror of your memory, as a simulation of your personal experience.
For that sort of simulation, you would do better to examine City ROM, an annotated digital map of New York published by the Small Blue Planet Atlas Company. Like Sim City, City ROM allows you to zoom into an aerial view of the city. But unlike the computer game, City ROM's images are photographic, taken from satellite data. You are not able to construct and demolish generic buildings. But you are able to learn about real ones.
Map pointers correspond to images from the photo gallery, which are linked to text explanations:
"St. Paul's Chapel. Open 9 A.M.-3 P.M. Mon-Fri, 7 A.M.-3P.M. Sunday. This is where George Washington went immediately after his inauguration as the first President of the United States to kneel and pray for the union."
"Chinatown mushroom market, Grand at Elizabeth."
"Andy Warhol's loft. This loft/studio was owned for many years by Andy Warhol. Jean-Michel Basquiat, a famous 1980's painter/poet/graffiti artist and close fiend of Warhol's, rented the loft before and after Warhol's death. On Aug. 12, 1988, Basquiat was found dead inside from a drug overdose."
All these places have addresses listed. In many cases, the phone numbers are listed as well. You can print maps showing how to get there. You can print the photos. Or you can add your own photos and your own notes, which become another set of color-coded markers on the map.
Within a few months, you'll be able to swap these cartographic scrapbooks on City ROM's Web site (www.cityromatlas.com) and show the world your New York, or see the city through the lens of someone else's experience. In the real city, you can retrace someone's steps. Or know that they might be retracing yours, although there's no way to ascertain whether any route is fact or fiction. And like the eccentric tour guide in Bennett Miller's film "The Cruise," we are at liberty to use both. In the simulated city, any story is worthwhile.
Both City ROM and Sim City use overlays as a graphic device. In Sim City you can view water pipes, population density, land values, crime rates, transportation systems, flora or any combination of these elements. In City ROM, you can choose to display the map markers for museums, theaters, restaurants, libraries or your all-time greatest dates. Both sets of overlays are highly specific. But they reveal different sorts of truth: the mechanical truth of a city versus the narrative truth.
It's the difference between a model and a map. A model tells you that tab A goes into slot B. A map tells you that there be dragons here.
The former is theory. The latter is memory. Both are imperfect and incomplete, and that's why they are compelling. They beg us to tinker, to investigate or to tell stories -- even if they're not true. So that afterward we can say, "This is my city because I built it." Or, "This is my city because I've walked it." Or, "This is my city because I made it up."
When you build something, or discover something or invent something, it belongs to you. And who wouldn't lay claim to a few megabytes of the Big Apple?

HEADLINE: When Collection Software Runs, Debtors Can't Hide

BYLINE: By TINA KELLEY 

 BODY:
WITH Americans taking on more and more debt, high-tech collection tactics are making it easier to find debtors and encourage them to pay up. Or else.
Debt-collection software with names like the Sting, Optimizer and Determinator help collection agencies find elusive debtors, phone them and make a plan for them to pay off what they owe. Programs using artificial intelligence can gauge the likelihood that a debtor will pay up, and they can match debtors with collectors who fit their style. 
 "When you're talking about the customary ways of thinking about how people buy and sell things with credit, the old paradigms are being outstripped by new technology," said Ronald Griffin, a law professor who teaches a debtor-creditor relations course at Washburn University in Kansas.
As of February, American consumers had amassed $1.3 trillion in outstanding installment debt, up 7 percent from the previous year, according to the Federal Reserve. In 1997, the most recent year for which data are available, debt totaling $247.4 billion was sent to collection agencies, which recovered $32.2 billion that year, according to the American Collectors Association, a 3,600-member trade group based in Minneapolis.
Modern debt collectors look back with some nostalgia at the days when they worked from 4-by-6-inch index cards in shoeboxes. Now computers dig through proprietary databases, find and dial numbers, determine when debtors are most likely to be home, improve the efficiency of telephone collection centers, calculate how risky a holder of a credit card or mortgage is and generate letters and scripts for phone calls. With some of these applications running, you can't hide.
Debt collection agencies rely on the sale of bad debt. After a bill is overdue for a certain length of time, credit card companies and other creditors often sell the debt for pennies on the dollar to agencies, which are allowed to keep anything they can extract from the debtor. It's worth it for the creditor, which can at least collect something on debt that would have been a total loss otherwise, and it's worth it for the collection agency, which is more skilled and experienced than Visa and Chase Manhattan in the art of mining deadbeat accounts.
Sometimes the collector's first step is to find where to find the debtors -- or customers, as they are called at one agency, Exterra Private Recovery in Walnut Creek, Calif. ("We don't allow the D word here," said Barbara Price, the company's co-founder and executive vice president.) Banks and other credit providers want to keep customers by having collectors work out a payment plan -- courteously.
Computer terminals from far-flung locations can tap into the system, so some collection agents can work from home. That is a boon to at-home parents, handicapped workers and agencies hungry for skilled workers.
One star account manager, Priscilla Corley, has been with Exterra since it opened in 1997. Using databases and software made by Rothenberg Systems International, Ms. Corley finds people with bad debt by tracing them through other creditors listed in their credit reports, who might know the customers' whereabouts. The agency also uses a variety of other directories and databases.
ON a recent Wednesday, Ms. Corley was on the phone while studying her computer screen, narrowing in on a lead. She got the caretaker of the debtor's mother to give her the phone number of a close relative of the debtor. Ms. Corley, who recently won a lease for a 1999 Cadillac from Exterra for her productivity, handed the number over to her partner, Marla McCown, to follow up. Ms. McCown's wall is covered with 10 overnight mail envelopes, marked with the dollar amounts of the payments that arrived in them.
Then a manager announced the amounts collected during the morning. Everyone stood and waved plastic noisemakers that are shaped like hands, creating a clackety applause. Managers want to keep the job interesting, in a field where annual turnover rates of 40 percent to 80 percent are common. It can be frustrating for callers to find debtors and put up with verbal abuse.
Once debtors have been found, collectors try to get in touch with them by phone or through the mail or through neighbors.
Dialing software places the calls, and if a person answers, the machine passes the person along to an available collector. That saves the collector the trouble of dialing or dealing with busy signals or answering machines. The dialing software that automates this task includes programs like the Optimizer, by Centerforce Technologies.
The dialers' software is called predictive because it has a strategy. "The odds are, if you're not there Monday at 9 A.M., then you won't be on Tuesday or Wednesday at 9 so the machine will try again at noon, in the afternoon and the next day in the evening," said Jon Mazzoli, senior vice president at Outsourcing Solutions, a collection agency in Chesterfield, Mo., that tries to track down 10 million debtors a year.
Outsourcing Solutions' technology can predict when a collector will finish a call, dialing the next call so the collector can go straight to the new debtor without losing any time. (This is the same technological advance that brings you those hang-up calls at supper time from telephone solicitors.)
In half the debt-collection and sales offices with predictive dialers, collectors have been able to triple the time they spend on the phone talking to people, to 45 minutes an hour from 15 minutes, said Tom Buiel, the vice president for domestic sales at Melita International, a telecommunications software company in Norcross, Ga.
Many collectors use a computer scoring system to figure out the likelihood that a bad debt will be paid. Some programs use artificial intelligence, so they "learn" from and incorporate earlier collection results.
"We typically look at several hundred characteristics, 300 or 400 or 500 characteristics, for an individual," said Bernhard Nann, president and co-founder of Narex, in Lakewood, Colo., a company that was set up in 1995 to develop debt collection programs that use artificial intelligence. Based on information about the debtor -- like the size of the person's previous debts and how quickly they were repaid -- the company determines which kinds of letters and calls the person should receive. Or it decides that the debt is "self-curing," something that will be paid without a reminder. The results are plugged back into the system to help the software make future calculations.
The computer screens that collectors see can also help direct their work. In Sweden, one program puts a face with a smile or a frown on the account on the screen, which tells collectors what tone of voice to use with the debtor, said Susan Magrino, vice president of Rothenberg Systems International. And Magellan software provides scripts that tell collectors which questions to ask after gathering each bit of information.
"The machine does the thinking, so the agent doesn't have to," said Diane Katzaman, a senior product marketing manager at Melita, which created Magellan.
Software can also rate consumers' creditworthiness. The Fair, Isaac Company, a credit scoring company in San Rafael, Calif., that was founded in 1956, was one of the first to take many factors into account to come up with a credit score. While many consumers complain about the rigidity of such scores, some in the debt collection industry say the scores are fair because they disregard race, sex, religion and birthplace, focusing more on credit histories.
"Machines are absolutely dead fair," said Ted Crooks, executive director of the scientific staff at HNC Software, which creates debt scoring programs. "They don't know what color you are or anything about you -- they just know the data and the account history, and that people with data like yours had this kind of outcome."
Technology like this will benefit all of society, said Vijay S. Mookerjee, an associate professor of information systems at the University of Washington Business School. For small-scale lending, "it is just not cost-effective for the bank or lending agency to use human capabilities to do that when you can really boil it down and optimize the profile and do it automatically," he said.
So do all of these innovations result in the collection of more money? The results are mixed. Recovery rates at consumer collection companies reached a four-year high in 1997, according to Credit Collections News and the Credit Collections Directory, with an average recovery rate of 24.5 percent among the 300 agencies surveyed. But the American Collectors Association traced a decline in the percentage of debt that was collected by about 300 agencies, to 13 percent in 1997 from 22 percent in 1995.
Collecting debt may be easier now because the careful screening and scoring of people applying for credit means that bill payers are more likely to be reliable. The strong economy also makes it easier to collect debts. And because creditors almost always regard fresher debts as easier to collect, some creditors are placing their overdue accounts with collection agencies sooner than they used to.
But some creditors are waiting longer before turning to collection agencies. Now that more high-tech collection tools are widely available, a creditor will often try to use them first, before selling debts to an agency. Skimming the cream off their debts, many banks and credit card companies are dealing with the fresher, more easily collectible debts themselves, leaving the harder, older ones for the agencies. "They're being asked to do more and more for their clients at less and less of a rate," said Toni Nuernberg, chief operating officer of the American Collectors Association.
They're asked to be more efficient and, yes, nicer than they used to be. As Ms. McCown sifted through the form letters she can send from Exterra -- the Demand letter, the Broken Promise letter, the Broken Promise on Settlement letter -- she explained her philosophy of working with her "customers": "Just be nice, and give them the opposite from what they're giving you."
 
Zeroing In
Digital Strategy for Sorting Through Shifting Identities
ONE high-tech computer aid for tracking people down, often useful for debt collectors, is made by Infoglide, a company that has figured out ways to find some people who regularly change their identities.
"We know what clever criminals do," said Jay Valentine, chief executive of Infoglide, in Austin, Tex. "They don't choose 123-45-6789 if they're making up a Social Security number. We can find similarities with the numbers they use, subtle similarities, and can put together tremendously strong correlations to show that they're the same person, trying to get credit as a new person, even though they're a deadbeat on their other credit files. And we can create a profile, asking, Is this person likely to respond to us calling them? Or to a threat? Or a subpoena?"
Infoglide's Fraud Investigator software, which is powered by the company's Similarity Search Engine, is used by three of the largest credit bureaus in the country, the company said. It can help determine similarities in delinquent accounts under different names.
For example, if you need contact information for a debtor in a large database of accounts receivable, you can enter the person's full name into the search engine and it will present a list of possible matches, ranked according to how likely it is that the entry is for that person. The company gives on-line examples of how this works in two scenarios (www .infoglide.com/pages/thumbdemo.htm).
While the software is often used by debt collectors, it is also used by people investigating things like insurance fraud and other criminal cases. The company gives an example of what might be turned up by such an investigation: "You notice that the names seem similar. Could this be the same individual with his name accidentally mistyped or intentionally altered? You notice that the first and last names in the similar claim are switched while the middle name remains the same. Also, the address is slightly different. The street number has two transposed digits, 2506 versus 2605. There is a different apartment number and the ZIP code has 30 in one listing and 03 in the other. With these similarities in the data, you suspect that this similar claim is for the same individual."
Credit investigators can look through a variety of databases for a debtor's name or a close approximation of it, or information like a Social Security number or address. Thus records for James Stevens, Jim Stephens and JK Stevns can appear together, and if there are matches among their addresses or Social Security numbers, the likelihood that the references are all for the same person is considered high.
Infoglide was founded by David Wheeler, a computer scientist who developed the search techniques for finding criminals after the 1981 murder of his father went unsolved.
The same technology has been used to crack insurance fraud rings and to hunt down criminals on the lam. "Even a slight name change, like W. J. Davis and Billy Dhaves, will make someone invisible to most computer systems," Mr. Valentine said. "The average person who is a skipper will modify his or her name six times." TINA KELLEY

SECTION: Section E; Page 8; Column 1; The Arts/Cultural Desk

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
No Frank Capra Here, Or Jonathan Edwards

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER LEHMANN-HAUPT 

 BODY:

HOME TOWN
By Tracy Kidder
349 pages. Random House. $25.95.
At first you think that Tracy Kidder's new book, "Home Town," is going to present an idyllic profile of Northampton, Mass., one consistent with the author's opening view of it from nearby Mount Holyoke: "From the summit, the cornfields are a dream of perfect order, and the town seems entirely coherent, self-contained, a place where a person might live a whole life and consider it complete, a tiny civilization all its own. Forget the messiness of years and days -- every work of human artifice has a proper viewing distance. The town below fits in the palm of your hand. Shake it and it snows." 
 Moving closer, Mr. Kidder's focus tightens on the life of Tommy O'Connor, whose happy childhood as a Northampton townie suggests Frank Capra's film "It's a Wonderful Life," without the hero's frustration and sense of being stuck.
Tommy has grown up to fulfill his childhood dream of becoming a policeman. (On the wall inside the closet of the room he grew up in is written in crayon "Tom O'Connor September 29, 1972 / I want to be a policeman / I am in sixth grade.") The town he works in is not just the site of prestigious Smith College but also a successful experiment in urban restoration whose heart is a mix of Woodstock Nation and Main Street, where some 40 restaurants thrive and kids feel free to display their hair dyed the more unlikely colors of the rainbow.
But as Tommy drives his rounds you begin to sense an atmosphere less like a Capra film and more like something by Stephen King. Tommy knows that in the festive downtown crowds are dealers pushing crack cocaine. Crises in which he frequently has to intervene involve drunken or addicted former high school mates.
Within three chapters, Tommy is approached by a somber Rick Janacek, not only a fellow cop but also Tommy's childhood neighbor and best friend. Rick confides that as well as having a severe problem with alcohol he has been barred by his wife from contacting her or their children. The restraining order has accused Rick of sexually abusing one of his daughters.
"The only way anything could have happened with me is if I was in a blackout," Rick says, an admission that Tommy knows from experience is usually a sign of guilt. Having heard Rick confess as much, Tommy feels he will have to report the conversation to the District Attorney's office.
Rick Janacek is the first of four major close-ups of Northampton citizens that Mr. Kidder presents against the background of the town's daily life and history. The others are an odd assortment. There is Alan Scheinman, an erstwhile real estate entrepreneur who suffers so severely from obsessive-compulsive disorder that he has to keep his hands wrapped in plastic and can't remove the garbage from his apartment. There is Francisco (Frankie) Sandoval, alias Samson Rodriguez, a crack cocaine addict and dealer who works as a snitch for Tommy. Finally there is Laura Baumeister, a mother on welfare who has won a scholarship to Smith but doubts that she can handle the class work.
Even Tommy turns out not to be so pleased with his life. Although he loves his hometown and has won promotions and prizes for his superlative police work, he is frustrated by the lack of a child in his happy marriage and feels too often that his career has come to "a dead halt." What is Mr. Kidder trying to do with this gallery of misfits? For the reader their histories are a mixed experience. Sandoval's is edifying, telling you a lot about life in the underclass. Baumeister's is inspiring; she masters her class work and ends up in love with "Paradise Lost." Scheinman's is fascinating at first but gets to be a bit of a bore; he more or less cures himself of his obsessive-compulsiveness but he spews a fair amount of psychobabble in describing the process. As for Tommy, although he is no misfit, his solution to his discontents is cheering.
But what is Mr. Kidder's point in offering such a lopsided profile of Northampton? Apparently it is to illustrate how the tolerance and cohesiveness of his town embraces all extremes. After all, he reminds you in one excursion into the past, this is the town that eventually threw out Jonathan Edwards, author of the sermon "Sinners in the Hands of an Angry God" and arbiter of Northampton's morals.
Celebrating the place's diversity, Mr. Kidder writes: "The town has American Legion baseball and contra dancing, a small Buddhist church and a very active Elks club, homes that cost $400,000 and many boardinghouses and halfway houses. Somehow it works. Northampton is the kind of place where a professor, a potter, unemployed musician, former mental patient, a woman with a handsome alimony, can all be found on Sunday mornings sitting near one another at sidewalk tables outside the coffee shops. Somehow -- is it the sum of unconcerted efforts? -- a cohesive property seems to bind the place, as if it were a liquid held by surface tension." In an interview describing his experience in getting to know Northampton, Mr. Kidder has said: "The picture that I'd held in my mind began, not to fall apart, but to fragment, the way a pointillist painting turns into a bunch of small dots if you move too close to it -- except that the dots in this case were in themselves interesting, and sometimes appalling."
What his book succeeds in doing is bring the dots together again. The picture they form is far from pretty, but it certainly coheres. Shake it and it weeps.
