SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1123 words

HEADLINE: Key to Deal for Mediaone: Keeping the Losing Bidder Happy

BYLINE: By GERALDINE FABRIKANT and LAURA M. HOLSON 

 BODY:
Last Sunday afternoon, Brian Roberts, the president of Comcast, was resting at his home near Philadelphia after an exhausting week of negotiations. He had reason to be tired. After making a costly $53 billion stock bid for Mediaone Group, the nation's fourth-largest cable operator, a month earlier, Comcast found itself trumped by AT&T, which had muscled in with a $58 billion stock and cash offer.
Comcast had sought help from Microsoft the previous week, hoping the software giant would dig into its $22 billion cash coffer to aid the company in its bid. But even as Microsoft's chief financial officer, Gregory Maffei, met that week with Comcast at the offices of Sullivan & Cromwell, Microsoft's law firm, the Comcast team knew that Microsoft representatives were simultaneously meeting with its rival, AT&T, indicating that Microsoft might only be using the talks with Comcast as leverage in the AT&T negotiations. 
 Without support from Microsoft or America Online, another potential ally, Comcast had little chance of winning. But AT&T executives also knew it was wiser to strike a friendly deal with the cable operator with which it hoped to do business with in the future.
That thinking set the stage for what was to be a conciliatory call from an AT&T executive to Mr. Roberts that ultimately led to Tuesday's settlement -- widely hailed as a savvy resolution for both parties. AT&T, which already owns Tele-Communications Inc., the nation's second-largest cable company, gets Mediaone. But Comcast too walks away with a prize: it acquires two million cable subscribers outright and gets to manage franchises serving more than two million more.
Why was AT&T, eager to be the industry's Goliath, willing to give up control of more than four million subscribers? Company executives did not talk publicly yesterday, but one person involved in the talks noted that it would behoove AT&T -- which is trying to offer local telephone service through alliances with cable companies -- not to alienate Comcast. "Having Comcast, which controls six million homes, or 10 percent of the cable industry, as an avowed enemy for life was not smart," said the participant, who spoke on the condition of anonymity.
Certainly, there was still the potential for Comcast to drum up support from other quarters and escalate the bidding war. But the recent settlement puts an end to the specter of another round of bids.
AT&T is planning to offer local telephone service on Tele-Communications' cable lines and is working on a deal with Time Warner. Adding Comcast's subscribers to that overarching plan would be another coup. An agreement to offer Comcast subscribers telephone service was part of the settlement.
Referring to the role played by AT&T's chairman, C. Michael Armstrong, an investment banker involved in the negotiations who requested anonymity said: "Mike was smart enough to rise above the occasion and get the deal done in a way that everybody could go home with dignity. In a fast-changing industry, he managed to keep relationships with Comcast that insured they would work together in the future."
That is not always the case. Viacom's Sumner M. Redstone and QVC's then-chairman, Barry Diller, battled for months in 1993 over Paramount Communications. Each side continued to raise its price far beyond what then appeared economically feasible, forcing the ultimate winner, Viacom, to pay far more than Mr. Redstone had initially intended. Moreover, Mr. Redstone and Mr. Diller remained bitter to one another for at least a year after the battle ended.
And after British Telecommunications lost the battle for MCI to Worldcom, British Telecom immediately entered into a relationship with AT&T that some observers said was aimed at damaging MCI Worldcom.
One reason AT&T and Comcast may have avoided friction is that much of the negotiating was done directly between top level corporate executives who are seasoned deal makers in their own right.
On Sunday, Mr. Roberts got a call from Leo Hindery, the president and chief executive of AT&T Broadband and Internet Services, who had been a chief deal maker for Tele-Communications before it was acquired by AT&T last year. "The question he raised was how to make it a 'win win' for both sides," one person involved in the negotiations recalled. The pair talked in earnest about a plan that had actually been kicking around for a while that would let Comcast buy or gain control of more AT&T cable subscribers.
That concept had been around for weeks and last Friday, as it became clear that Mediaone was poised to accept the AT&T bid, preliminary discussions began, according to two people involved in the talks. Comcast and AT&T executives had been leery of talking directly because AT&T's offer for Mediaone dictated that neither could have discussions with any other potential bidders.
But by Friday night, according to one participant in the negotiations, a decision had been made that because Mediaone had already singed confidentiality agreements with America Online and Microsoft, the standstill provision was no longer in effect, and preliminary talks between AT&T and Comcast had started. (An AT&T representative denied that there were any settlement talks before Sunday.)
In deals, politics count. And no one wants to be rebuffed. So before Mr. Hindery actually picked up the phone to call Mr. Roberts, representatives from AT&T's banker, Goldman, Sachs, called one of Comcast's bankers, Lazard Freres. (Comcast is also represented by Salomon Smith Barney.) Lazard, in turn, called Mr. Roberts to say that Mr. Hindery would be phoning, according to people close to the negotiations.
And so the talks began. By 8 A.M. Monday both Mr. Hindery and Mr. Roberts and their teams were at the New York offices of AT&T's law firm, Wachtell Lipton Rosen & Katz, hammering out what was to become the final settlement between the warring sides. Comcast would get two million more subscribers for $9 billion, and management over two million more cable homes, helping it accomplish its initial goal of getting bigger. AT&T would acquire Mediaone. The two sides also agreed to a crucial goal of AT&T: to offer telephone service over Comcast's cable wires.
But even as Comcast was finishing up the terms of its deal with AT&T, reports that MCI Worldcom was interested in joining the battle for Mediaone began making their way on Wall Street. The news did little to sway the parties, but did quicken the pace of the discussions, one person said. Daniel Somers, chief financial officer for AT&T, in particular, did not take the MCI Worldcom threat seriously but still wanted a quick end.
"Time was ticking," said one person involved in the talks.

HEADLINE: Teaching Hospitals Battle Medicare-Money Cuts

BYLINE: By CAREY GOLDBERG 

DATELINE: BOSTON, May 5

 BODY:
Normally, the great teaching hospitals of this medical Mecca carry an air of white-coated, best-in-the-world arrogance, the kind of arrogance that comes of collecting Nobels, of snaring more Federal money for medical research than hospitals anywhere else, of attracting patients from the four corners of the earth.
But not lately. Lately, their chief executives carry an air of pleading and alarm. They tend to cross the edges of their palms in an X that symbolizes the crossing of rising costs and dropping payments, especially Medicare payments. And to say they simply cannot go on losing money this way and remain the academic cream of American medicine. 
 Dr. Mitchell T. Rabkin, chief executive emeritus of Beth Israel Hospital, says, "Everyone's in deep yogurt."
The teaching hospitals here and elsewhere have never been immune from the turbulent change sweeping American health care -- from the expansion of managed care to spiraling drug prices to the fierce fights for survival and shotgun marriages between hospitals with empty beds and flabby management.
But they are contending that suddenly, in recent weeks, a Federal cutback in Medicare spending has begun putting such a financial squeeze on them that it threatens their ability to fulfill their special missions: to handle the sickest patients, to act as incubators for new cures, to treat poor people and to train budding doctors.
The budget hemorrhaging has hit at scattered teaching hospitals across the country, from San Francisco to Philadelphia. New York's clusters of teaching hospitals are among the biggest and hardest hit, the Greater New York Hospital Association says. It predicts that Medicare cuts will cost the state's hospitals $5 billion through 2002 and force the closing of money-losing departments and whole hospitals.
Dr. Samuel O. Thier, president of the group that owns Massachusetts General Hospital, says, "We've got a problem, and you've got to nip it in the bud, or else you're going to kill off some of the premier institutions in the country."
Here in Boston, with its unusual concentration of academic medicine and its teaching hospitals affiliated with the medical schools of Harvard, Tufts and Boston Universities, the cuts are already taking a toll in hundreds of eliminated jobs and pockets of miserable morale.
Five of Boston's top eight private employers are teaching hospitals, Mayor Thomas M. Menino notes. And if five-year Medicare cuts totaling an estimated $1.7 billion for Massachusetts hospitals continue, Mayor Menino says, "We'll have to lay off thousands of people, and that's a big hit on the city of Boston."
Often, analysts say, hospital cutbacks, closings and mergers make good economic sense, and some dislocation and pain are only to be expected. Some critics also say the hospitals are partly at fault.
"A lot of teaching hospitals have engaged in what might be called self-sanctification -- 'We're the greatest hospitals in the world and no one can do it better or for less' -- and that may or may not be true," said Alan Sager, a health-care finance expert at the Boston University School of Public Health.
But the hospital chiefs argue that they have virtually no fat left to cut, and warn that their financial problems may mean that the smartest edge of American medicine will get dumbed down.
With that message, they have been lobbying Congress in recent weeks to reconsider the cuts that they say have turned their financial straits from tough to intolerable.
"Five years from now, the American people will wake up and find their clinical research is second rate because the big teaching hospitals are reeling financially," said Dr. David G. Nathan, president of the Dana-Farber Cancer Institute here.
In a half-dozen interviews, around the Boston medical-industrial complex known as the Longwood Medical Center and Academic Area and elsewhere, hospital executives who normally compete and squabble all espoused one central idea: teaching hospitals are special, and that specialness costs money.
Take the example of treating heart-disease patients, said Dr. Michael F. Collins, president and chief executive of Caritas Christi Health Care System, a seven-hospital group affiliated with Tufts.
In 1988, Dr. Collins said, it was still experimental for doctors to open blocked arteries by passing tiny balloons though them; now, they have a bouquet of expensive new options for those patients, including springlike devices called stents that cost $900 to $1,850 each; tiny rotobladers that can cost up to $1,500, and costly drugs to supplement the reaming that cost nearly $1,400 a patient.
"A lot of our scientists are doing research on which are the best catheters and which are the best stents," Dr. Collins said. "And because they're giving the papers on the drug, they're using the drug the day it's approved to be used. Right now it's costing us about $50,000 a month and we're not getting a nickel for it, because our case rates are fixed."
Hospital chiefs and doctors also argue that a teaching hospital and its affiliated university are a delicate ecosystem whose production of critical research is at risk.
"The grand institutions in Boston that are venerated are characterized by a wildflower approach to invention and the generation of new knowledge," said Dr. James Reinertsen, the chief executive of Caregroup, which owns Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center. "We don't run our institutions like agribusiness, a massively efficient operation where we direct research and harvest it. It's unplanned to a great extent, and that chaotic fermenting environment is part of what makes the academic health centers what they are."
"There wouldn't have been a plan to do what Judah Folkman has done over the last 20 years," Dr. Reinertsen said of the doctor-scientist at Children's Hospital in Boston who has developed a promising approach to curing cancer.
Federal financing for research is plentiful of late, hospital heads acknowledge. But they point out that the Government expects hospitals to subsidize 10 percent or 15 percent of that research, and that they must provide support for researchers still too junior to win grants.
A similar argument for slack in the system comes in connection with teaching. Teaching hospitals are pressing their faculties to take on more patients to bring in more money, said Dr. Daniel D. Federman, dean for medical education of Harvard Medical School. A doctor under pressure to spend time in a billable way, Dr. Federman said, has less time to spend teaching.
The Boston hospitals' plight may be partly their fault for competing so hard with each other, driving down prices, some analysts say. Though some hospitals have merged in recent years, Boston is still seen as having too many beds, and virtually all hospitals are teaching hospitals .
Whatever the causes, said Dr. Stuart Altman, professor of national health policy at Brandeis University and past chairman for 12 years of the committee that advised the Government on Medicare prices, "the concern is very real."
"What's happened to them is that all of the cards have fallen the wrong way at the same time," Dr. Altman said. "I believe their screams of woe are legitimate."
Among the cards that fell wrong, begin with managed care. Massachusetts has an unusually large quotient of patients in managed-care plans. Managed-care companies, themselves strapped, have gotten tougher about how much they will pay.
Add to the troubles some complaints that affect all hospitals: expenses to prepare their computers for 2000, problems getting insurance companies and the Government to pay up, and new efforts to defend against accusations of billing fraud.
But the back-breaking straw, hospital chiefs say, came with Medicare cuts, enacted under the 1997 balanced-budget law, that will cut more each year through 2002. The Association of American Medical Colleges estimates that by then the losses for teaching hospitals could reach $14.7 billion, and that major teaching hospitals will lose about about $150 million each. Nearly 100 teaching hospitals are expected to be running in the red by then, the association says.
For years, teaching hospitals have been more dependent than any others on Medicare. Unlike some other payers, Medicare has compensated them for their special missions -- training, sicker patients, indigent care -- by paying them extra.
For reasons yet to be determined, Dr. Altman and others say the Medicare cuts seem to be taking an even greater toll on the teaching hospitals than had been expected. Much has changed since the 1996 numbers on which the cuts are based, hospital chiefs say; and the cuts particularly singled out teaching hospitals, whose profit margins used to look fat.
Frightening the hospitals still further, President Clinton's next budget proposes even more Medicare cuts.
Not everyone sympathizes, though. Complaints from hospitals that financial pinching hurts have become familiar refrains over recent years, gaining them a reputation for crying wolf. Critics say the Boston hospitals are whining for more money when the only real fix is broad health-care reform.
Some propose that the rational solution is to analyze which aspects of the teaching hospitals' work society is willing to pay for, and then abandon the Byzantine Medicare cross-subsidies and pay for them straight out, perhaps through a new tax.
Others question the numbers.
Whenever hospitals face cuts, Alan Sager of Boston University said, "they claim it will be teaching and research and free care of the uninsured that are cut first."
If the hospitals want more money, Mr. Sager argued, they should allow in independent auditors to check their books rather than asking Congress to rely on a "scream test."
For many doctors at the teaching hospitals, however, the screaming is meant to save their institutions from becoming ordinary.
Medical care is an applied science, said Dr. Allan Ropper, chief of neurology at St. Elizabeth's Hospital, and strong teaching hospitals, with their cadres of doctors willing to spend often-unreimbursed time on teaching and research, are essential to helping move it forward.
"There's no getting away from a patient and their illness," Dr. Ropper said, "but if all you do is fix the watch, nobody ever builds a better watch. It's a very subtle thing, but precisely because it's so subtle, it's very easy to disrupt."

HEADLINE: The Big City;
How Vouchers Can Help Ease Overcrowding

BYLINE: By JOHN TIERNEY 

 BODY:
IN his self-described crusade to "rescue the children," the Rev. Jesse L. Jackson visited a public high school in Brooklyn on Tuesday and was appalled to find its 1,100 students had only 2 computers with Internet access. But he was just as appalled at the idea of letting any students escape to a better school.
"We might save some," he said in decrying Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's proposal to give students taxpayer-financed vouchers for private schools. "But what about those left behind?" 
 As it happens, this week there is a simple answer to his question: the ones left behind could finally afford computers. That sounds paradoxical, because vouchers are routinely criticized for "diverting resources" from public schools. But vouchers can free more money for the students left behind, and the computer shortage noticed by Mr. Jackson is an example of how all students could benefit from vouchers.
As of last week, New York's school officials planned to install computers and Internet connections in every classroom from fourth grade through high school. But the latest outline of the capital plan, which the Board of Education is expected to approve today, eliminates all those computers, according to Lewis H. Spence, the Deputy Chancellor for Operations.
The overcrowded system is desperate for funds to build new schools, and the elimination of the computers frees $1 billion to pay for 20,000 new seats.
Suppose, though, that the school system used a different technique to relieve overcrowding. Instead of adding 20,000 new seats, it could free up space by providing vouchers for 20,000 low-income students to attend private schools. Instead of spending some $50,000 to build each new seat, it could spend zero, and the savings in the capital budget could be used to put computers in all the existing classrooms.
Besides the savings in the capital budget, the school system would be spared the operating expenses associated with the 20,000 students. Those expenses, like teachers' salaries and building maintenance, average more than $6,000 per student. So the public system could break even by giving each student a voucher of that amount, and turn a profit if the voucher were for less.
"From an accounting standpoint, public school districts should be happy with vouchers," said Caroline Hoxby, a professor of economics at Harvard University.
"Most voucher programs tried so far give the students much less money than the public district was spending on them, so the district comes out ahead when a student leaves. The savings can be very substantial when the vouchers are used to avoid the high marginal costs of adding seats in new schools."
THESE advantages have been appreciated in a few places, including Houston, where the public school district has relieved overcrowding by paying for some students to attend private schools. But Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew is one of the many administrators opposed to even a small experiment with vouchers.
They fear all parents might eventually demand vouchers, including ones who now pay for private schools on their own. The extra burden on taxpayers, the argument goes, would impoverish public schools while subsidizing wealthy students at prep schools. But it would be simple enough to limit vouchers to families below a certain income level, and to fix the value of the vouchers so that plenty of money remained for students in the public schools.
A more challenging long-term problem would be to find enough places in private schools for all the students wanting to use vouchers. But there are already enough vacancies to start experimenting -- the parochial schools in Brooklyn and Queens have perhaps 3,000 empty seats.
Entrepreneurs have already demonstrated in other cities that private schools can be built for less than half the cost of new public schools, and without the billions in special capital subsidies now being sought by the Board of Education. As more and more students use vouchers, some private schools could buy buildings from the shrinking public system, which could use the proceeds to support the students remaining in public schools.
But no matter how much more money was available for each public school student, there would be a major political problem with a shrinking public system: fewer jobs for administrators and members of the teachers' union. Mr. Jackson said he came to rescue the children, but he probably did a lot more to help the adults.

HEADLINE: New York Hospitals Braced for Cuts

BYLINE: By RANDY KENNEDY 

 BODY:
The fiscal knife that has begun to cut into teaching hospitals in Boston and other cities has not yet had the same dire effects -- layoffs or widespread operating deficits -- in hospitals around New York State.
But hospital executives and health-care experts alike say that if the Federal cuts to Medicare are not softened, the state will lose much more than any other -- $5 billion and 23,000 medical jobs -- by 2002. And they warn that those cuts, a result of the Balanced Budget Act, pose a huge economic threat to New York, which has nation's greatest concentration of medical schools and teaching hospitals and trains about 15 percent of the nation's medical residents. 
 "The carnage which is created by the Balanced Budget Act," said Kenneth Raske, president of the Greater New York Hospital Association, a trade group of 175 hospitals and nursing homes, "will totally disrupt the health care system in New York when it's fully implemented. It goes at the heart of the infrastructure."
The cuts, now in their second year, come at the same time as sharp increases in uninsured patients and the growing dominance of managed care, which have prompted all hospitals in the New York region to brace for what they say will be one of the most difficult fiscal years ever.
But with critics complaining that New York still has too many hospital beds and administrative fat that should be trimmed, those who run the prestigious teaching hospitals in the city find it hard to make their case that the Medicare cuts put them in real peril.
"I know this sounds like wolf, wolf, wolf because of the successes generally in the health care industry," said Dr. Spencer Foreman, president of Montefiore Hospital in the Bronx, which lost $24 million in Medicare money in fiscal 1999. "But New York teaching hospitals are in trouble."
His own hospital did $750 million in business in 1993 and ended that year with a $3 million profit margin. This year, it will do $1 billion in business and end with a $6 million margin.
"Those are supermarket margins," Dr. Foreman said, adding that the hospital has "managed to keep a razor-thin margin every year by every year cutting costs and cutting again."
"But you can only cut so far before things begin to happen," he said. "The industry is touching bottom in a lot of areas, and the difference between profit and loss in this atmosphere is an eyelash. This is not the way normal billion-dollar enterprises are conducted."
Because the teaching hospitals have traditionally served a high percentage of poor patients, the threat to their future is even more important, Dr. Foreman and others said.
While he and other teaching hospital administrators avoid talking about it, the only way to keep from going into the red is to cut jobs and either shrink or close money-losing departments.
"The so-called low-hanging fruit has all been picked," said Dr. David B. Skinner, the chief executive of New York Presbyterian Hospital, where every department has been asked to cut spending by 5 percent. The Greater New York Hospital Association projects that New York Presbyterian will lose more money over the course of the Balanced Budget Act than any other American hospital -- about $320 million.
Dr. Skinner said that as the hospital plans its year 2000 budget "we're going to have to look very closely at staffing ratios."
"Something's got to give here," he said. "You then look at where can you downsize departments that are losing money. And we're looking at that now. I don't want to say which ones because I don't want to unnecessarily panic the troops."

HEADLINE: How Suburban Design Is Failing Teen-Agers

BYLINE: By WILLIAM L. HAMILTON 

 BODY:
AS quickly as the word "alienation" can be attached to the idea of youth, the image of isolation can be attached to a picture of the suburbs. Is there an unexplored relationship between them? It is a question parents and urban planners alike are raising in the aftermath of the Columbine High School shootings in Littleton, Colo.
At a time when the renegade sprawl of suburbs themselves is being intensely scrutinized, the troubling vision of a nation re-pioneered in vast tracts of disconnected communities has produced uneasy discussion about the psychological disorientation they might house. 
 Created as safe havens from the sociological ills of cities, suburbs now stand accused of creating their own environmental diseases: lack of character and the grounding principles of identity, lack of diversity or the tolerance it engenders, lack of attachment to shared, civic ideals. Increasingly, the newest, largest suburbs are being criticized as landscapes scorched by unthoughtful, repetitious building, where, it has been suggested, the isolations of larger lots and a car-based culture may lead to disassociation from the reality of contact with other people.
Designers of the newest American suburbs say they have largely ignored or avoided one volatile segment of the population -- teen-agers. In recent conversations, three dozen urban planners, architects, environmental psychologists and sociologists, and experts on adolescent development agreed that specific community planning and places for teen-agers to make their own are missing.
"They're basically an unseen population until they pierce their noses," said William Morrish, a professor of architecture and the director of the Design Center for American Urban Landscape at the University of Minnesota. "They have access to computers and weaponry. The sense of alienation that might come from isolation or neglect will have a much larger impact than it might have before. And there are no questions coming from the design community about what we can be doing about this. We don't invite them in."
Virtually every other special interest has been addressed by enlightened suburban designers -- the elderly, the disabled, families with young children. But, said Andres Duany, a planner who is a leading proponent of the "new urbanism," a model of suburban design based on principles of traditional towns, "it's the teen-agers I always bring up as a question mark." Mr. Duany said that he had only once or twice included teen-agers in the public process of planning a suburban development.
"It's a good point," he said, as though it were an unlikely idea. "I should talk to the kids."
Though teen-agers tend to resist advice and choose their own turf as a territorial issue of establishing self-identity, most experts interviewed say that design could constructively anticipate and accommodate anxieties of adolescence. They agreed that teen-agers need a place to congregate in and to call their own; it is a critical aspect of relieving the awkward loneliness of adolescence. Between home and school -- spheres compromised by the presence of parents or the pressure of performance -- places for teen-agers in the suburbs are as uncommon as sidewalks.
"It's a paradoxical situation," said Ray Suarez, host of "Talk of the Nation" on National Public Radio and author of "The Old Neighborhood" (The Free Press, 1999), a study of suburban migration . "Parents move there for their children; their children are dying to get out."
Like much of the Western United States, Denver is experiencing vertiginous suburban growth. From 1990 to 1996, the metropolitan area expanded by two-thirds, to its current size of 535 square miles.
"Typical of the Denver metro area are the new suburbs, where 'downtown' is a four-way intersection with three shopping centers and a condo development," said Charles Blosten, community services director for Littleton's city planning division. Highlands Ranch, Denver's largest suburban development, has its own ZIP code, "nothing but rooftops and miles and miles of nothing," he said of the numbing vista of houses.. "It's got to affect people."
The idea that place has an impact on adolescent development and socialization is accepted by most experts on the suburbs but is only now beginning to be studied. "A culture of impersonality has developed in the suburbs by the way they're laid out," said Jonathan Barnett, a professor of regional planning at the University of Pennsylvania and author of "The Fractured Metropolis" (HarperCollins, 1996). In the newer suburbs, "the standard of houses is high, but the standard of community isn't," he continued, adding, "It's most people's impression of modern life."
And the people it stands to impress the most are children. "They are the most vulnerable people growing up there," said Dr. Jose Szapocznik, a professor of psychiatry and behavioral sciences and director of the Center for Family Studies at the University of Miami. "As a child you're disabled by not being able to walk anywhere. Nothing is nearby."
Mr. Morrish said he thought that public transportation to metropolitan downtowns was crucial for high-school students. He said that the ability to access "the system" -- the world adults create -- was a vital form of empowerment.
"What to do after school, how to get to the city, to see other people and how to negotiate this without parents," he said, posing the issues. "Teen-agers have to have better access to the public realm and public activity." He recalled a conversation with a group of high school students who met with the Design Center, which invites teen-agers to group meetings when it is commissioned to study neighborhoods.
"One girl said, 'All I've got is the Pizza Hut,' " Mr. Morrish said. " 'You go there a lot or you go to somebody's house -- we're tired of both.' "
Between home and school, in a landscape drawn by cars and the adults who drive them, is there even a particular place that teen-agers can call their own? Peter Lang, a professor of architecture at the New Jersey Institute of Technology and an editor of "Suburban Discipline" (Princeton Architectural Press, 1997), a collection of essays, said: "In most suburbs, there's not even a decent park, because everyone has a backyard. But older kids never play in the backyard. They'll find even the crummiest piece of park."
Typically, the students at Columbine High School went to Southwest Plaza, a two-level mall that has video arcades, food courts and stores, supervised by security guards and closed by 9 P.M. "Like any suburban community, there's not a lot of places to go and hang out," Mr. Blosten said of Littleton. "I tell you this because that's where my daughter goes -- the mall."
Mr. Lang said he thought that places like malls were not adequate gathering spaces for teen-agers, calling them, like many public suburban venues, commercially and environmentally "controlled space." He added, "They are not places for free expression or hanging out."
Disagreeing that suburbs create greater alienation is Dr. Laurence Steinberg, a professor of psychology at Temple University and director of the MacArthur Foundation Research Network on Adolescent Development and Juvenile Justice. But he said that he thought recent tragedies like the incident in Littleton do "wake people up to the notion that there is parental disengagement in affluent suburbs." He added: "We did a a study on latchkey kids. The kids most likely to be left unattended for long periods were middle class, in sprawling professional suburbs. Isolated for long periods of time, there's no counterbalancing force to fantasy."
The desire for more and cheaper land that has pushed suburbs to rural exurbia may result in teen-agers who are alone for large parts of the day. Mr. Morrish pointed out that in communities like Modesto, in the San Joaquin Valley in central California, people commute to jobs in the San Francisco area, where they enroll their children in schools.
"Some people in California are taking their kids with them," he said, "making the kids commute."
The planners who have been most vocally and visibly at work on restructuring the suburban model have been "new urbanists" like Mr. Duany. Their solutions to the wheeling nebulae of tract development are based on tighter concentrations of houses, businesses and public spaces connected by townlike elements -- porches, sidewalks and parks -- that have largely disappeared from the new residential landscape.
If teen-agers find their place there, in new towns like Columbia and Kentlands in Maryland or Celebration, the Disney-built town in Florida, it is not because of any bravery on the planners' part. They often foster nostalgic views of families with young children. But like conventional suburbs, they overlook the inevitability of teen-agers in their design.
Peter Katz, who with Vincent Scully wrote "The New Urbanism: Toward an Architecture of Community" (McGraw-Hill, 1993), spoke of the importance to teen-agers of a place that existed only for them, neither hidden and ignored nor exposed and supervised -- in effect, a secret place in full view.
On a visit, Mr. Katz discovered that for Celebration's teen-agers, it was a narrow bridge, "with low railings, that goes from downtown to the health club." He continued: "They find each other. They sit on the railing. It's on the route to daily life -- not a back alley, but not the town square." Mr. Katz suggested that such a structure could become a conscious part of a community design for teen-agers.
For Diane Dorney, a mother with two teen-age children who lives in Kentlands, Md., a 10-year-old "new urban" suburb of some 1,800 people, the hallmarks of town life work well for both parents and children. Ms. Dorney and her husband, Mark, moved their family from a typical town-house development.
"We wanted to raise our kids in a place that provided more than just a house," she said. "It's a diverse community, of age and income," with older people, young couples, families. Ms. Dorneye said that she thought the gaze of the town created a sense of extended family and moral weight that were its most important success.
"Someone sneaking down the street to have a cigarette -- they don't get away with it," she said. "I don't think teen-agers should be left on their own until they're caught at the small things." She continued, "When they go into the big things, they know how big they are." She added: "And we have another way of knowing these kids, other than the bad things. They're your neighbors, too. You're always seeing them. You give them another chance."

HEADLINE: PUBLIC LIVES;
Graphic Vision: Art for People, Not Artists

BYLINE: By JOYCE WADLER 

 BODY:
THERE are a million stories in the naked city, but if they involve the night workers who clean the toilets and make the subways run on time, who cares?
The little drama of the aspiring comic book artist who works as a topless dancer and loses her wallet with the rent money: so what? 
 The subway worker who works the graveyard shift and finds solace in the company of rats: who wants to read about him?
But no! In a project called "The Invisible City," the stories of some of the night shift workers who make the city run, told in comic book panels, will be on placards throughout the subways until the end of the month.
Using their own computer program -- ZAP! or perhaps we should say, CLICK! -- which transforms photos to comic illustrations, two artists, Christopher J. Sperandio, who lives in Manhattan, and Simon Grennan, who lives in England, have made the workers comic heroes.
How did the artists get the idea?
Frame One: Mr. Sperandio, 35, sitting in the Manhattan office of the Public Art Fund, because he's self-conscious about the studio apartment he shares with his wife. Black T-shirt, black shirt, black sports jacket, buttoned up. (GADZOOKS! The sign of a fellow self-conscious about his weight??!!??) Hair a downtown mix of peroxide blond and brown. Box of Pepperidge Farm cookies, plateless, unadorned, real, furnished by artist, on the table. Artist will eat the most.
"I had been working as a graphic artist at one of those desks in a cubicle farm in a corporate office. I don't want to name them because I don't want to plug them."
Frame Two, noir office, the artist as drone:
"I was working from noon to 8, kind of a bridge person between the day people and the night people, and I realized that they were completely oblivious of one another, though they shared the same space. So in the morning, it would be: 'Why is the mouse pad over here?' The day person would be right-handed but the night person left-handed, and they would not know."
Frame Three, top of the artist's head.
"My hair? I had always wanted to dye it and now I've started losing it, so I've dyed it all these different colors in the last few months. I've been red, black, blond, now crazy, for a while Chromatique -- that's this bright, bright red."
There are artists who feel they must be true to their vision, the public be dashed. This has never been the case of Mr. Sperandio, raised in the town of Kingwood, W.Va., whose father worked as a lineman for the power company and whose mother worked in the unemployment office.
MR. SPERANDIO, who put himself through college with scholarships and construction work, and met Mr. Grennan while they were doing graduate work at the University of Illinois in Chicago, felt art should be relevant.
"Simon and I were very dissatisfied with the role of the artist," says Mr. Sperandio, who, while his heart is with the workers, talks about art theory till you turn bright, bright blue. "I had trouble reconciling my working-class background with the nature of contemporary art. Essentially, they're class issues, issues about the social role of the artist. Like, remember Tilted Arc, the Serra sculpture at Federal Plaza?"
(Comic book cue, Frame One: A 120-foot long, 12-foot high slab of curved steel, in lower Manhattan. Next Frame: Federal Plaza without the steel.)
"There was a lot of controversy," Mr. Sperandio continues, "and eventually it was removed. We found it to be a failure of the artist rather than the public. There was a gulf of understanding between what he was doing and the people who were trying to enjoy their lunch hour. It happened in '81, and had a big influence on Simon and me. It showed us how not to be."
A little smile.
"Some teachers felt we were very reactionary."
The projects of Mr. Sperandio and Mr. Grennan have included collaborating with chocolate workers on the design of a chocolate bar wrapping ("We're kind of known in the art world for that"), as well as a number of comic books, including "Life in Prison," for which Mr. Sperandio interviewed his brother after his brother had become "drunk as a skunk" and landed in the county jail. There are also a limited number of "Invisible City" comic books available, free, from the Public Art Fund, which paid for the project. The artists each got $2,000, which Mr. Sperandio estimates comes to about 25 cents an hour, though he professes not to care.
The people's art thing, again:
"Comics are good because so many people can get to the work." Final frames: The light is fading in the offices of the Public Art Fund. Mr. Sperandio, after saying that he keeps his distance from the New York art scene because it is "a perilous place," is explaining why it is so important to him to do good work.
"My father died the middle of my sophomore year in school. Lung cancer. He smoked all his life. I had the opportunity to visit him at the end, but I was getting my final portfolio together at school."
Next frame:
"I put off seeing him till Friday. He didn't make it to Friday. That's really the motivating factor for me. I owe it to him to work hard with my art work and make it mean something, because I sacrificed seeing him for it."
Last frame:
"You know?"

HEADLINE: The City Life;
Uptown, Across Town, Out of Town

BYLINE: By VERLYN KLINKENBORG 

 BODY:
On the stage, theatricality means a fullness of effect, a knowing use of all the theater's dimensions, an awareness of how the right staging can ionize the very air an audience breathes. But a city's theatricality -- who conspires to produce that? New York rises above its crowded streets, a consolidated chaos of views, and the power of its scenic accidents is so great that they look purposeful, every last one of them, until you realize that only the eye's intent unites them.
From time to time, as you cut across town on everyday business, New York's inherent theatricality seems to array itself before you with unusual economy, the grandness of the staging almost mocking the plainness of your business. You catch a morning cab to La Guardia, for instance, and instead of stiffing it out in midtown traffic, the driver bears north through Central Park on East Drive, edging upward along Madison Avenue, across 116th Street and finally onto the Triborough Bridge. In spring this is an inspired choice of routes, and the driver, gesturing at trees that will soon form a tunnel of green overhead, knows it. 
 The park, of course, is one of the places where the striving for theatricality is evident, where a single design makes the city cohere around it. After the streets of midtown, so full of ardor and self-absorption, the park feels truly public, even though most people go there to serve private ends, to walk or run or skate or perambulate the children, to lie beside a magnolia dropping its petals, to reinvigorate their sense of where they are. But the same feeling emerges in the vicinity of community gardens built on once-vacant lots in the blocks of Madison Avenue near 112th Street. Those gardens are shrines to green space, and though they organize less territory than Central Park does, they help define the theatricality of the streets that surround them, which contain so much of what is public in that neighborhood's life.
The shop windows clamor in this part of town, windows full of cakes and second-story wedding gowns, windows gilded with neon and crammed with half a store's stock, windows empty except for the relics of a former business. When the cab catches the Triborough on-ramp, the city seems to revolve beneath you until it integrates these low rooftops with the taller buildings that lie beyond them. The river runs slowly downtown past the East Side's long flank. And all this theater lies threaded along the path of a single cab ride -- the blaring chaos of midtown, the almost concupiscent pleasures of Central Park in spring, the vivid promptings and urgings of East Harlem. It seems forgivable, as you cross into Queens, to believe that it was arranged this way just for you. After all, tomorrow you will be an extra in someone else's epiphany. VERLYN KLINKENBORG

HEADLINE: Economy Gained Slightly in March and April

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 5

 BODY:
Vibrant consumer spending helped keep the nation's economy expanding moderately in March and April, with little indication of rising inflation, the Federal Reserve said today.
The Fed's latest "beige book" summary of economic conditions -- which covers the period from March 8 to April 26 and will be used when Fed policy makers consider interest-rate strategy on May 18 -- also said manufacturing was picking up in most districts. 
 Analysts were heartened by the summary's report of well-contained prices, which suggested little reason for the Fed to raise interest rates soon.
"Consumer spending remains healthy, led by strong motor vehicle sales," the Fed summary said.
The Fed's nationwide survey found some manufacturers complaining about weak foreign sales. But most said business was improving, with rising demand for goods like computers, medical and telecommunications equipment and automotive supplies.
The Fed said labor markets remained tight but that a scarcity of workers was not pushing up wage demands. It said some employers were increasing nonwage compensation, even using hiring and retention bonuses to attract and keep skilled workers.
Prices for most products continued to be stable, with the notable exceptions of oil, gas and building materials, especially sheetrock, which is used in building new homes.
"The comment that prices are generally well contained certainly bodes well for the policy meeting on May 18," said Gary Schlossberg, an economist at Wells Fargo Bank in San Francisco in an interview with Reuters Television.
 Construction industries were still running at high levels for both residential and office projects, but the pace was beginning to ease in some districts, the Fed said.
Bankers reported that business was good. "The Dallas, Atlanta and Chicago districts report that lending growth was robust," the Fed summary said, and there was no sign that credit quality -- a measure of borrowers' ability to repay their loans -- was weakening.

HEADLINE: Auto Insurance Rates Declined Last Year

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Auto insurance rates declined by 2.8 percent nationwide last year, the first drop in 25 years, and could fall further in 1999, an industry group said this week. The Insurance Information Institute said that the rate decline reflected competition among insurers, more skilled drivers on the road, safer vehicles and less tolerance for drunken driving.
The institute, based in New York, said it expected a further drop of 4.5 percent this year, adding that "motorists with good driving records may see even bigger savings." 
 Despite the decline in rates, premiums rose slightly in 1998, the institute said. Robert P. Hartwig, its chief economist, said the average amount spent on auto insurance increased five-tenths of 1 percent last year, largely because of higher vehicle prices and their premiums. "New cars are more expensive than old ones and so is the insurance," he said. He added that a larger proportion of new vehicles being sold were expensive sports utility vehicles.
The institute predicted that buyers, on average, would spend $702 in auto insurance this year, down from $709 in 1998 and $706 in 1997.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place;
Brazil's surprising rebound still has a ways to go, though things could get choppy in the near term.

BYLINE: By Jonathan Fuerbringer 

 BODY:
IT may appear to many investors that the sharp rebound in Brazilian stocks and bonds has passed them by. The stock market, in local terms, is up 71 percent this year and is almost back to its last peak in March 1998. Prices in the bond market have jumped, as the yields, which move in the opposite direction, have plunged. The yield on Brazil's benchmark long-term bond maturing in 2027 is down to 12.6 percent, from 16.9 percent just two months ago.
Analysts and money managers, though, say there is still much more to make on a investment in Brazil. 
 "You are betting on interest rates falling, the currency stabilizing and inflation not being a threat," said Jay Pelosky, the global emerging-markets strategist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, who recommended a move back into Brazil in mid-March.
He thinks the bet will prove to be a smart one. He even thinks the Brazilian economy will surprise this year by declining much less than expected. In the last few weeks, Brazilian officials have cut their forecasts of the decline to 2 percent.
Though Mr. Pelosky thinks Brazil is a good bet in the longer term, he warns that the stock market is in a pause right now. All the good news about Brazil's unexpected escape from disaster is, as they say on Wall Street, in the market. Since reaching a high for the year of 11,529.92 on April 7, the Bovespa index of 57 Brazilian stocks has settled into a narrow trading range.
"Today you need new confirmation for Brazil to go appreciably higher," he said. With good earnings news not expected for some months and the economy still declining, that confirmation may take some time.
Another problem is Brazil's congressional investigation concerning the central bank's role in the bailout of two small investment banks earlier this year. If it gets more serious, the inquiry could distract Congress from completing important structural changes that are aimed at insuring Brazil's long-term economic health.
Mr. Pelosky also cautions American investors not to bet on a rebound in the Brazilian currency, the real, to profit from an investment there. Such a bet might look attractive. While the Bovespa has surged, in dollar terms the index is still 57 percent below its March 1998 highs.
The real declined by as much as 44 percent in value after the Government abandoned foreign-exchange controls on the currency in mid-January. But since early March it has rallied by 28 percent and is now valued at 1.683 to the dollar.
Mr. Pelosky does not think that it will rally much more in the near term because several more months are needed for foreign investors to be convinced that important benchmarks, such as the size of the Government budget deficit, are moving in the right direction. Data for April, which would give three full months of performance since the devaluation, will not be available until June. Ernest W. Brown, the chief Latin American economist at Morgan Stanley, forecasts that the real will only strengthen another 3 percent by the end of the year.
Daniel Beneat, the portfolio manager of the new and tiny Dreyfus Premier Emerging Markets Fund, cut his exposure to Brazil several weeks ago because he thought that the good run since January was going to end.
"Throughout the summer we are going to have some pretty bad numbers," he said, referring to data showing that the economy is still in a decline. "The environment will not be that positive."
While he cut back in Brazil, he increased his holdings in Mexican stocks. "The earnings are very good and the valuations are very cheap there," he said. "Mexico will outperform Brazil in the coming months."
But when the economy turns, Mr. Beneat said, he will return to Brazil, picking up more of the utility and telecommunications stocks he already likes, including Tele Centro Sul Participacoes, the local telecommunications company, which has jumped 58 percent since the devaluation, and Companhia Paranaense de Energia-Copel, a large utility, which is up 32 percent.
"You have to have a view on Brazil," argued Arturo C. Porzecanski, chief economist for the Americas at ING Barings. But he thinks that the bond market, for now, may be a better bet. "If you are an equity investor you have to wait for earnings to come back" and that means waiting for the economy to recover, he said.
Bonds, he said, are more a bet "on a perception of risk." And with a further decline in interest rates, that risk will be lessening before the economy turns. Last week, the central bank made its fourth interest rate cut in five weeks. The benchmark rate was trimmed to 32 percent from 34 percent.
In addition, he said there was room for bond yields to fall further, when compared with history and the yields in the rest of Latin America.
According to a J. P. Morgan index that tracks the difference between Latin American yields and comparable United States Treasury securities, the spread for Brazilian debt is 8.82 percentage points, 5.98 percentage points for Argentina and 5.48 percentage points for Mexico. In addition, while the Brazilian spread has fallen from a 1999 high of 17.79 percentage points on Jan. 14, it is still more than the 6.08 percent on July 31 last year, just before Russia devalued its ruble and defaulted on its debt.
"We think this is the opportunity to buy," Mr. Porzecanski said. But he made sure to add the qualifier always invoked when discussing emerging markets -- "for the long-term investor."

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
A wrong turn on the road to Social Security reform.

BYLINE: By Michael M. Weinstein 

 BODY:
BIG plans to overhaul Social Security may or may not be dead in Congress this year. But regardless of what happens, Washington will eventually have to come up with a way to keep the system from running out of money when the baby boomers retire next century.
What each of the plans now on the table has in common, including the bipartisan House bill proposed yesterday, is that they all promise financial salvation through the creation of private accounts. These accounts would provide some of the retirement benefits that now come entirely from a common trust fund. Private accounts have a simple allure. Workers can expect to earn only about a 1 or 2 percent a year above inflation on the money they pay in payroll taxes to the trust fund. But they could expect to earn at least 4 percent on money they put into private accounts and invest in stocks and bonds. The difference is enough to raise retirement benefits by 50 percent. 
 It might seem obvious, then, that private accounts are stunningly better. Not so, economists say. Private accounts provide no financial benefit. Indeed, they are financial losers. There is a defense of privatization. But that defense is political.
A careful analysis by John Geanakoplos of Yale, Olivia S. Mitchell of the University of Pennsylvania and Stephen P. Zeldes of Columbia University shows that private accounts accomplish nothing on average that the trust fund couldn't accomplish more cheaply. It should be noted that Professor Mitchell comes to this result despite her outspoken advocacy of private accounts. Here's why.
Under current law, most of the money that comes into the trust fund through payroll taxes goes right back out to support current retirees. The obligation to pay current retirees continues whether or not the system is privatized. If reform did nothing more than replace a common trust fund with private accounts, there would be little financial benefit because there would be little to invest in stocks, bonds or anything else. Without new money, few dollars would ever go to the new private accounts because they would be committed to current retirees.
To make private accounts work, privatization advocates propose tapping expected Federal surpluses to pump extra money into the system. They envision 150 million workers investing the extra money in stocks and bonds yielding more than 5 percent above inflation.
But the extra money could instead be invested in the existing trust fund. Under current law, the money can only be used to buy special Government bonds that pay interest of only about 3 percent above inflation. The financial advantage of private accounts over the trust fund in the Congressional plans, then, follows from a quirk of current law, a law that could be changed to permit the trust fund to invest in a diversified portfolio of stocks and bonds. Invested similarly, private accounts are not better than the trust fund.
Indeed, they are worse. A single trust fund keeps administrative expense at a minimum. But setting up and maintaining 150 million private accounts would rack up substantial fees and commissions for Wall Street. Prof. Peter Diamond of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology estimates that the administrative costs would reduce retirement payments by at least 25 percent by the time of retirement and would cost another 5 to 10 percent to convert, as most plans require, the savings into a monthly annuity.
So if private accounts cost more to administer than does a trust fund and produce no better investment returns, why bother setting them up? The answer, proponents say, is that Government cannot be trusted to purchase shares in American companies. It would be tempted to meddle, for example by interfering with the management of tobacco companies or selling shares of companies that offer violent computer games to children. The way around that, say those who favor trust fund investments, is to legislatively put stock-picking decisions in the hands of private managers and forbid the Government to exercise voting rights.
So the debate over private accounts rests almost entirely on a political call. To supporters, they create private property that Congress could never reclaim. To opponents they represent needlessly costly and potentially pernicious reform that would undermine the current system's transfers to low-wage workers and scrape away the insulation a single investment pool provides individuals against the risk that their own stock and bond purchases go awry.
"There is a terrific economic argument for pumping more money into Social Security in order to raise national saving and investment," said Laurence S. Seidman, an economist at the University of Delaware and author of a new book on Social Security. "There is a terrific economic argument for investing at least some Social Security money in stocks because that would allow low-wage workers to reap the benefit of high-yield stocks without exposing themselves to much risk. But there is no purely economic reason why either of these reforms need to be done through private accounts."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Dow Makes a U-Turn to Finish Solidly Ahead by 69.30

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

 BODY:
Stocks rebounded from early losses yesterday to finish solidly ahead, as investors showed renewed affection for the blue-chip growth stocks they had shunned lately.
While none of the major indexes reached new peaks, all reversed course about 1 P.M. and climbed steadily to finish at their best levels. The Dow Jones industrial average was up 69.30 points to regain more than half the ground it lost Tuesday, after closing above 11,000 for the first time on Monday. It ended up 0.64 percent at 10,955.41. 
 The Nasdaq composite index did even better, surging 1.98 percent, or 49.32 points, to 2,534.44.
"The familiar growth names came back," said Timothy E. O'Grady, a portfolio manager at the First Capital Group. "Some of these stocks were in a deeply oversold condition."
Although interest rates were a bit lower throughout the session, stocks did not spring back until midday. Some analysts attributed the recovery to comments by John F. Welch Jr., the General Electric chairman, who told a Florida conference that his company, which has a market capitalization second only to Microsoft, would "at least" match Wall Street's expectations of a 14 percent earnings gain this year.
Others mentioned circulation of a Federal Reserve survey showing the economy growing at a moderate pace with prices generally still "stable." With the quarterly season for corporate earnings reports largely over, much of the attention, analysts said, has returned to the economy. On Friday, the Labor Department is to report on the April job market.
The market will also pay close attention today to a speech on the economy by Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, in Chicago.
AT&T, winner of the bidding contest for Mediaone, was a standout performer, jumping 5 3/8, to 56 15/16, on turnover of nearly 32 million shares. The other leading gains among the Dow Jones blue chips were 5 points, to 139, for J. P. Morgan; 4 1/16, to 109, for General Electric; 2 1/4, to 129 3/8, for American Express, and 1 15/16, to 72 13/16, for Merck.
Among the prominent losers were stocks sensitive to the economy that had become suddenly popular last month after long trailing the growth standbys. Alcoa, for example, slipped 7/8, to 60 3/16, after trading as high as 65 5/8 last Thursday, United Technologies 1 7/8, to 145 3/4, and Minnesota Mining 1 9/16, to 92 3/8. General Motorsfell 2 1/16, to 86 15/16, after reporting lower sales.
"Some of the move to cyclicals has been overdone," said Joseph Battipaglia, investment policy chairman at Gruntal.
Internet and other high-technology stocks joined the afternoon revival, with America Online a pivotal issue as it posted a 2 5/8-point gain, to 129 3/4, after trading as low as 115 1/2.
That kind of comeback "tends to set the tone" for the market in general, said Philip Schettewi, a managing partner at Loomis Sayles. "A lot of people get conditioned to buy the dips, which keep getting shallower," he added. Ebay ended 5 9/16 higher at 186 13/16 after trading as low as 168, Amazon.com rose 3 1/2, to 146 1/2, after having been down to 133 7/8, and Microsoft advanced 1 1/16, to 79 1/8, after trading at 76 7/16.
Among financial stocks, Chase Manhattan fell 2 1/16, to 80 3/16, in contrast to Morgan's big gain that seemed related to news of plans to enhance its Internet trading capability. Goldman Sachs, trading for the second day, eased 1 1/4, to 69 1/8; it went public at 53 on Tuesday. Charles Schwab jumped 5 3/4,to 107 1/2.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange edged down to a still-hefty 913.6 million shares, with gaining stocks holding only a slim margin over declining ones, 1,565 to 1,444. But 66 issues made new 52-week highs and only 17 new lows
The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks rose 15.31 points, or 1.15 percent, to 1,347.31.
Except for Brazil, where the Bovespa climbed 2.75 percent, foreign markets were nearly all lower by about 1.5 percent or more.

Treasury Prices Rise
 By Bloomberg News
 Bond prices rose yesterday as the highest yields in nine months attracted buyers, even as a factory report gave more evidence of a buoyant economy.
Investors are doing a "little bit of nibbling at these levels," after bond yields rose about 20 basis points over the last two weeks, said Mark Hemenetz, who helps manage $18 billion of fixed-income assets at Bank of New York.
Even so, many were reluctant to buy bonds before Mr. Greenspan's speech today, the Government's April employment report tomorrow and forthcoming sales of $30 billion of Government and corporate debt.
The price of the benchmark 30-year bond rose 2/32, to 93 17/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, fell to 5.70 percent, from 5.71 percent on Tuesday.

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
Campaign For Jackson In Full Swing

BYLINE: By IRA BERKOW 

DATELINE: CHICAGO

 BODY:
WHEN Phil Jackson was a player with the Knicks in the early 1970's, he would hear the coach, Red Holzman, and the trainer, Danny Whelan, inform the starting small forward, Bill Bradley, that when Bradley became President of the United States they wanted the jobs of checking the height of the water levels of the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans. Holzman would sit at one coast for six months and Whelan at the other, and then they would switch.
"I haven't approached Bill for that job yet," Jackson said yesterday, "although he tells people that if elected I'd be his Secretary of Dee-fense. Which is different from Secretary of De-fense." 
 Jackson, who has been unemployed since last June, has been an unpaid campaigner for Bradley, who, some 25 years after the end of his playing career, has announced that he is, indeed, seeking residence in the White House.
Last night, Jackson, at age 53 and looking fit and rested and shorn of his gray beard, was honored at halftime of the Bulls-Orlando Magic game at the United Center for his masterly contributions as coach of Bulls teams that won six National Basketball Association championships in the previous eight seasons. Among those participating in the ceremony were Senator Bill Bradley; Bill Fitch, Jackson's college coach, and Michael Jordan, who was unable to attend but sent a taped video message that was played for the near-capacity crowd.
"The spiritual aspect of team play of the Bulls spilled over into the community of Chicago, and brought us all together," Jackson said, addressing the crowd. Referring to the record of success he said, "we had a wonderful time, didn't we?"
For a combination of reasons -- the retirement of Jordan to a personality conflict with General Manager Jerry Krause, to a need to simply clear his basketball sinuses -- Jackson quit the Bulls and took a sabbatical.
In that time, he has built a house in Woodstock, N.Y., and has been giving speeches to the tune of $45,000 a talk (outside of politicking), doing some writing. He is, after all, the author of the best seller "Sacred Hoops." And he is still "looking over my shoulder at the world of basketball."
A little more than that surely. While last night was the first time this season that he has entered an N.B.A. arena, Jackson said he has checked out some games on television. But he has also been Penelope to N.B.A. suitors. He has sat and woven his thoughts quietly while his representative, the Chicago lawyer Todd Musburger, has been fielding love notes from teams desirous of Jackson's hand as coach.
"We have four offers on the table," Musburger said, "and at the end of the season we're expecting at least two or three more."
Jackson said, "I'd be interested only if the intrigue is there." And while Jackson has sometimes spoken in cryptic terms, it was clear what "intrigue" meant: money, team, control, city, and not necessarily in that order.
The teams that conceivably have been in touch with Musburger are the Lakers, the Nets and maybe Washington, Denver, Charlotte and Vancouver -- and the Knicks.
Some things Jackson said he would have to look at are the contracts of current players and where the team is in the salary cap and how flexible they would be in dumping aging veterans and getting players who appeal to him. Which conceivably would eliminate the Knicks. Jordan may become a part owner in Charlotte, but Jackson says Paul Silas has done a good job coaching the Hornets and he imagines that Jordan would be very hands-on as an owner.
Which would not be too attractive for Jackson, who would like the kind of control over decisions on players that Pat Riley and Rick Pitino have with Miami and Boston. "I want to decide the players for my coaching style."
One such player is Shaquille O'Neal, who traveled to South America with Jackson three years ago to conduct basketball clinics. Jackson, Musburger said, liked O'Neal and believes he would be great for the triangle offense that Jackson employed with the Bulls. Then there is the cash. Jackson made $6 million in his last year as the Bulls' coach. He would want more. Chuck Daly earns $5 million a year. Riley and Pitino have upper-management deals in which they earn $10 million or more.
One other factor: how Bradley is progressing as the one, "to lead us into the new millennium," as Jackson put it.
If someone who doesn't know Jackson asks what he does for a living, what does he say? "I say I'm a magician," he said with a smile.
A magician now, he was asked, or then? "Both," he said, inscrutably.

HEADLINE: SPORTS BUSINESS;
Stadium Financing? New Twist for N.F.L.

BYLINE: By RICHARD SANDOMIR 

 BODY:
Imagine if George Steinbrenner volunteered to help pay for a new downtown Montreal Expos stadium. Better yet, think of the Expos agreeing to chip in for a $1 billion Yankee Stadium for the good of baseball.
That is what the National Football League rivals of Robert K. Kraft, who owns the New England Patriots, will do if a plan to build a $250 million stadium in Foxboro, Mass., comes to fruition. 
 Last week, after the league made public its ardor to keep the Patriots from leaving Foxboro, the team dumped a proposed $374 million taxpayer-paid stadium in Hartford because there was no guarantee it would be ready by 2002.
The Foxboro financing would give the Patriots $125 million up front from the N.F.L., which would repay the loan from club-seat premium revenues the team would not have to pay visiting clubs.
If the club-seat cash falls short of paying the annual debt service, the league would use revenues from personal-seat licenses and network television.
The transaction is booked as an interest-free loan to the Patriots, who need not repay a cent unless Kraft sells or moves the team during the term of the loan. Kraft would then have to finance only $125 million for the stadium.
The Massachusetts Legislature is to vote on a $70 million subsidy for roads, exit ramps and sewers.
Still, it would never match the world-class handout Kraft left behind in Hartford.
"Mr. Kraft turned down a no-risk deal in Connecticut, with $1 billion in club-seat and luxury-suite guarantees and a $120 million capital improvement fund," said Joe Browne, an N.F.L. spokesman. "In Foxboro, he'd be taking on financing risks, and he'd be selling club seats and luxury suites."
Kraft's rivals would be making his life a lot easier by halving the borrowing he would need. But this illustrates the socialistic savvy of the N.F.L. Owners have shared revenues liberally for 40 years, and share more than teams in any other major league. In the N.F.L., the small-market Green Bay Packers can survive and thrive. In baseball, Montreal can barely do either.
Once assured that the business and political establishment in Massachusetts wanted to keep the Patriots from moving, the N.F.L. commandeered the Foxboro plan with a new version of its 12-year-old stadium-financing-aid program.
The original program, which was formalized in 1994, relieved teams from paying visiting teams 34 percent of their club-seat premium revenues if the money went to pay off loans for stadium construction or renovation.
Since 1987, 21 teams have used $400 million in this kind of financing, including the Miami Dolphins, the Tampa Bay Buccaneers and the Washington Redskins.
In March, owners changed the policy: first, they shifted the burden of club-seat financing from the team to the league, allowing teams to get upfront loans without paying interest, rather than get their own loans. Then, the league said the club-seat financing could account for 34 percent to 50 percent of a team's private contribution to a stadium, up from a maximum of 34 percent. Only projects in the largest markets would be eligible for the 50 percent treatment.
"It had a big impact on us," said Paul Kirk Jr., a lawyer who is leading the Massachusetts bid. When his group of business and civic leaders began meeting with Roger Goodell, a senior league executive, he said, "Our challenge was how to bring something new to the economics of the situation."
The league had been studying for over a year how to help finance stadiums to keep teams in large markets like Chicago, Boston and Philadelphia and to bring teams back to cities like Los Angeles.
Once the club-seat financing policy was amended, Kirk added: "It changed the dialogue here. It meant the league stepped up. The average fan senses the league is a very successful enterprise. Right or wrong, they see megabucks."
This part of the financing is a great deal for Kraft. "It's almost like free money for him," said Andrew Zimbalist, an economics professor at Smith College, in western Massachusetts. "It's very significant."
And it is also found money because it comes from the fans and corporations who buy club seats, those fancy perches with waiter service; personal-seat licenses, the upfront payments fans make to guarantee the right to buy season tickets, and the networks, which have agreed to pay the league $18.3 billion through 2005.
Naturally, the league believes its plan addresses some of the criticism that owners have extracted too much taxpayer money to build stadiums for the teams' private benefit. Senator Arlen Specter, Republican of Pennsylvania, introduced a bill on Tuesday that goes further than the N.F.L.'s financing.
"The league plan is an internal one to help owners raise their share of the private contribution to build stadiums," said John Ullyot, a spokesman for the Senator. "But it doesn't address how to relieve the taxpayer burden."
Specter's legislation would condition the continuation of the N.F.L.'s limited antitrust exemption and baseball's full exemption on their setting aside 10 percent of their television revenues to pay for half the cost of building new facilities. The bill would require the team and public to finance the remaining 50 percent, ideally for each party to put up 25 percent.
