SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1896 words

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: The Young Palestinian Giant;
Holding Company Close to Arafat Casts Widest of Nets

BYLINE: By WILLIAM A. ORME Jr. 

DATELINE: NABLUS, West Bank

 BODY:
From his hillside offices, Munib R. Masri can look down on the neighborhood where his grandfather's family founded the city's first university and survey the old town center where uncles and cousins served as mayors.
But Mr. Masri, a dapper, Texas-educated billionaire, keeps his eye on new features of the Nablus landscape, all of which he had a hand in building: a Palestinian stock exchange, a modern television assembly plant, the headquarters of Paltel, the Mideast's first privately owned phone company. 
 These are cornerstones of an emerging Palestinian economy, being built with offshore Palestinian money in expectation of statehood. And all are offshoots of the Palestinian Development and Investment Company, or Padico, a Nablus-based holding company run by the iron-willed Mr. Masri. In five years, Padico has become the biggest and most influential company in the West Bank and the Gaza Strip, with interests ranging from manufacturing and real estate to finance and power generating.
"We will do everything we can to put Palestine on the economic map of the world," said Mr. Masri, who made his fortune in Europe and the Persian Gulf during the quarter-century that Nablus was under Israeli administration.
In government circles, Padico is applauded for bringing urgently needed Palestinian capital and business skills back home. Local critics, though, contend that it rests on a foundation of cronyism, nepotism and protectionism, with troubling implications for a Palestine of the future. Some see Padico's close ties to Yasir Arafat's Palestinian Authority as a framework for further concentration of wealth in a society already riven by deep inequities.
In project after project, Padico has recruited top Palestinian managerial and engineering talent, most with advanced degrees from abroad, and assembled financial backing for critical new businesses.
"If you want to promote private investment here, one of the engines is Padico," said Mohsen Khalil, Middle East director for the International Finance Corporation, the World Bank's private investment arm. "They bring in a lot of competence, a lot of expertise and a lot of resources."
Local business rivals, however, portray Padico as an enemy of the free market and a beneficiary of political concessions. And Padico's founding investors are resented by others here for their affluence, their long absence and their Westernized ways. (Mr. Masri's wife and six adult children are American citizens, and most senior Padico employees speak fluent English.)
"During all our struggles here, during the intifada, all these millionaires were living abroad," said Hatem Abdul-Qader, a member of the Palestinian Legislative Council, referring to the uprising against Israeli military administration from 1987 to 1993. "Then these people came to harvest the fruits of our struggle."
Opposition legislators hint darkly that they have proof of payoff schemes and secret deals to restrict competition. But they have yet to produce any evidence of corruption involving Padico.
Mohammed Nashashibi, the Palestinian Authority's finance chief, dismisses the attacks. "They are pioneers," he said. "Let those who criticize them come and compete with them."
But the authority gave Padico a head start. Its subsidiaries are already busy crisscrossing Palestinian territory with fiber optic cables, erecting beach-front condominiums beside Gaza refugee camps, and spawning an array of start-up companies from plastics makers to poultry farms.
Among Padico's most prominent projects is the Palestinian Authority's showcase tourism enterprise, a $48 million Bethlehem luxury hotel being rushed through construction in hopes of receiving Pope John Paul II and others for millennial celebrations. The authority's biggest manufacturing venture, a Gaza industrial park with its own Israeli customs post, is another subsidiary. And Padico is the only private local shareholder in a new Palestinian home mortgage corporation, a $22 million partnership including the authority and a German development bank. All three projects are being developed with loans and equity from the International Finance Corporation.
"I don't know how they first received these contracts," said Husan Khader, a Nablus legislator. "But once they have the job, they do it professionally," adding that if they were responsible for all the Palestinians' economic affairs, "they would be a civilizing influence."
Mr. Masri is happy to acknowledge that he is an Arafat confidant. Now a member of the Palestinian central council, he was a Jordanian Cabinet minister when the Palestine Liberation Organization rose against King Hussein in 1970. Dispatched to the P.L.O. leader's desert hideout by Hussein, Mr. Masri forged an enduring bond with Mr. Arafat.
"Because I am so close to Arafat, some people think that Padico is part of the government," Mr. Masri said. "But it is not. It is completely private and independent."
Above all, Padico is seen here as an extension of the Masri clan, West Bank patricians who made fortunes abroad but always considered Nablus their home. The family traces its lineage back more than three centuries in this old Jordan Valley city -- which, with Padico's help, aspires to become the business capital of a future Palestinian state.
Munib Masri's second cousin, Sabih Nasri, another recently returned billionaire, runs Paltel. Almost every other Padico subsidiary has a Masri or two on its board. The Palestinian Authority's trade and industry chief is another Nablus cousin, Maher Masri.
Yet even in the family, there is dissent. "What they are really doing," said Muawia al-Masri, a distant relative who represents Nablus on the legislative council, "is imposing monopolies on services, which is hurting the Palestinian people."
Mr. Masri bridles at such comments. "We don't want to monopolize anything," he said. "There is plenty of work to do here. We need 10 Padicos to repair the damage that the Israelis have done to us."
There is no better indicator of Padico's influence, and the ingrown nature of its business ties, than its role in the nascent stock market. Started by Padico in 1997 with a charter from Mr. Arafat, the Nablus exchange is managed by a small Padico subsidiary. Suleiman Abbadi, the recently hired director, reports to the exchange chairman, Sabih Masri, who is also chairman of Paltel, the largest company traded on the exchange.
Paltel, Padico and a Padico real estate subsidiary together account for two-thirds of the market capitalization of the 28 listed companies.
Citing Padico's dual role as market player and manager, and lax local rules on financial disclosure and insider trading, some Palestinian businesses refuse to be listed on the exchange.
"How can I trust it?" asked Mazen Sinokrot, a candy maker in Ramallah, whose family business has diversified into animal feed and real estate. "You are my competitor, and you also control the stock market? You have information about my company, but I don't have information about yours?"
What most irks Mr. Sinokrot is that he and other local entrepreneurs did not have a place at the table when Mr. Arafat and Padico's founders devised their projects, like the plan for a telecommunications monopoly. "We were never given the same opportunity," he said.
Paltel's president, Hatem al-Halawani, who earlier served five years as Padico's chief executive, argues that by limiting itself to a minority holding in Paltel and selling shares to the public -- a Palestinian first -- Padico provided ample openings for local investors. "We could have taken 50 or 60 percent if we wanted to," he said.
And Padico's original mandate, notes Amin Haddad, until recently Padico's vice president and spokesman, was to create investment opportunities for expatriates.
Five years ago, with local political control about to pass to the Palestinian Authority, Mr. Masri returned here from London at Mr. Arafat's invitation, joining his first cabinet and helping to assemble Padico. With the Israeli-Palestinian peace accord just months old, it was a time of heady optimism, but also of few local institutions.
"The concept was to build the Palestinian economy," Mr. Masri said, "and to make a decent profit, but not an exorbitant profit. And what we did was clean; it was over the table."
With Mr. Arafat's endorsement, Mr. Masri and other expatriates courted Palestinian investors from Europe, the Americas and throughout the Middle East. A key recruit was the Amman-based but Palestinian-owned Arab Bank, the Arab world's fourth largest. Others followed.
"We were trying to convince people to put 3 or 4 percent of their wealth into a country where they will be able to raise their children," Mr. Masri said.
The group raised about $150 million initially and backed the new company with $1 billion. Each founding investor was limited to a 2 percent share. Last year, Padico directors made what they said was a one-time exception, accepting $10 million from Prince Walid bin Talal, the Saudi billionaire.
Today, Padico is a holding company of fairly standard design, modest dimensions and meager profits. The core company and its majority-owned subsidiaries have about 100 professional employees scattered across the West Bank and the Gaza Strip. On the Palestinian exchange, Padico's market capitalization hovers around $190 million, not all that much more than its reported $84 million in paid-in capital. Until a recent 1,000-for-1 split, Padico shares sold for $1,000 each, discouraging most local interest. Padico's 1998 report, released at its annual meeting in April, includes a summarized audit by Arthur Andersen showing net assets of just $122 million and an after-tax profit last year of $2.7 million.
"We have some unhappy investors," Mr. Haddad acknowledged.
But such figures belie Padico's true importance here. The company says it manages some $500 million in additional assets for its partners, including the Palestinian Authority. And the personal wealth of its board members is "about $20 billion," Mr. Haddad estimated.
Even allowing for exaggeration, the assets of Padico's expatriate founders loom extraordinarily large in a $3 billion economy. And some holdings give Padico significant profit potential, analysts say, pointing to its 10 percent share of a new Gaza electric company and 23 percent of Paltel.
Few foreign investors are ready to wade into the shallow and murky waters of Palestinian finance, but Padico and Paltel are considered the most viable eventual candidates for international stock portfolios.
"If you look at emerging markets, it is almost always the case at the beginning that a few companies will account for most of the capitalization," said Angus Blair, head of equity research for the Middle East at ABN Amro in London. "Invariably, telecoms and holding companies are going to be very important."
The London-based emerging markets department of Nomura, the giant Japanese brokerage house, is now preparing what Padico says will be the first thorough independent assessment of the company, in conjunction with a Jordanian investment banking firm.
But prospective investors may receive the report somewhat skeptically. The owner and managing director of Nomura's Jordanian partner, the Atlas Investment Group, is Omar Masri, Munib Masri's son.

HEADLINE: Studies Cite Lag in Year 2000 Projects

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER 

 BODY:
The prevailing optimism that Year 2000 computer problems will not seriously affect American business is premature, according to two new studies of Government filings by the nation's largest companies.
The studies focused on quarterly financial reports in which companies disclose to the Securities and Exchange Commission how much they had spent through the end of last year to deal with Year 2000 computer malfunctions. The authors of both studies concluded that although the written descriptions of the corporate Year 2000 projects were uniformly rosy, the actual spending figures suggested that many large companies had left themselves just one year to complete more than half their work. 
 The filings also showed that estimates of the total cost of dealing with the Year 2000 problem continued to rise in the last three months of last year, albeit at a slower pace.
"A significant number of companies in every industry sector started late and too much work remains for them to finish in 1999," said Steven Hock, president of Triaxsys Research, summarizing the findings of a report to be issued today on S.E.C. disclosure statements. The statements were filed from January through March by 647 of the 1,000 largest companies as listed by Fortune magazine.
"Some are just not going to make it in time and will be forced to rely heavily on contingency plans and crisis management to avoid serious business disruptions," Mr. Hock said.
Edward Yardeni, the chief economist at Deutsche Bank Securities in New York, said his analysis of the disclosure statements of 372 of the 500 companies making up the Standard & Poor's stock index, which he plans to release by the end of this week, is similarly troubling. Just 44 of the companies -- under 12 percent -- had spent as much as 75 percent of their projected budget by the end of last year, he said. "This doesn't mean that the others are not going to get the job done," said Mr. Yardeni, who has been Wall Street's most prominent pessimist on Year 2000 issues. "It does mean that they aren't leaving themselves much time."
Companies rushing to catch up are more likely to make mistakes, cut corners on testing and prepare inadequate contingency plans, Mr. Yardeni and many Year 2000 project managers said.
But Year 2000 experts caution against putting too much weight on the budget data. The Government does not audit them for accuracy. The figures can move sharply for individual companies from quarter to quarter. Sun Microsystems Inc., a company identified as a laggard by Triaxsys with just 14 percent of its Year 2000 budget having been spent through last year, jumped to 48 percent in the first three months of this year. And a conservative company like Sun, which has budgeted money to audit suppliers in the coming months, may take longer to complete its spending than a company setting aside little or nothing for such last-minute precautions.
Moreover, because the world has never experienced anything like the Year 2000 computer problem, no one can be certain whether a company leaving much of its spending for this year is running major risks. Indeed, recent Government and industry reports of tests performed on renovated systems have been so successful that confidence is growing that major disruptions are unlikely, at least in the United States.
The year 2000 problem, often known as Y2K or the millennium bug, stems from the widespread use of just two digits to represent the year in dates, such as 99 for 1999. Some computers, software and electronic machinery read 00 as 1900 instead of 2000 while others do not recognize it as a valid date. Some faulty systems freeze while others continue operating but produce erroneous data or gibberish.
Comparisons of spending figures for individual companies can be tricky because there is no national standard. Most of the figures reported to the Government involve spending to fix the software and equipment a company needs for its daily operations, but the spending at some companies may also include efforts to update computer-based products the company sells to others or help key suppliers prepare.
Conservative budgets may include substantial contingency planning. The 3Com Corporation, a computer networking company in Santa Clara, Calif., has spent just $3 million out of a potential budget of $25 million to $35 million through the first three months of this year. Judy Bruner, the company's controller, said that 3Com was on schedule to complete its major remediation programs but that the company had also included money in its budget for contingency plans if Year 2000 setbacks occurred.
But Mr. Hock and Mr. Yardeni said that while it might be mistaken to come to conclusions about any single company based on its spending reports, the collective figures underscore that so much work remains to be done that the country should guard against complacency.

HEADLINE: Pennsylvania Set to Break Taboo On Reward for Organ Donations

BYLINE: By SHERYL GAY STOLBERG 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 5

 BODY:
With demand for human organs far outstripping supply and more than 64,000 Americans waiting to receive new hearts, lungs, livers, pancreases and kidneys, Pennsylvania is taking steps to become the first state to break a long-held taboo against providing a financial reward for organ donation.
By early next year, state health officials said this week, they will begin offering a stipend of about $300 to help families of organ donors cover their funeral expenses. The stipend, authorized by a 1994 law, will not be paid directly to relatives, but rather to funeral homes under a pilot project that will be monitored for three years by a panel of medical ethicists to see if it increases organ donations. 
 Final details of the project are being worked out by a panel of advisers to Gov. Tom Ridge, a Republican. The panel is expected to issue its recommendations on June 9. A spokesman for the Governor said he knew of "no impediment" to the plan. If Mr. Ridge approves the program, the State Health Department will sign contracts with Pennsylvania's two organ procurement agencies to begin making the payments as quickly as possible.
"We are all ready to move forward," said Emilie Tierney, the state health official supervising the project. "We expect other states to be watching us."
Also watching is the Federal Government, which says the payments may violate the National Organ Transplant Act, a 1984 law that classifies human organs as a national resource and prohibits their sale. And the plan is generating intense debate among transplant surgeons, organ recipients and families of past donors.
"This is absolutely not buying and selling organs," said Howard Nathan, who serves on the Governor's advisory panel and is president of the Gift of Life Donor Program, one of two regional networks that distribute donated organs in Pennsylvania. "This is about having a voluntary death benefit for a family who gave a gift. The intent is to test it and see if it makes a difference to families."
But the Federal Health Resources and Services Administration, which oversees the nation's transplant programs, is not so certain.
"The Federal statute is fairly clear in prohibiting the exchange of organs for any kind of payment," said Jon Nelson, who directs the agency's office of special programs. "The question is whether this is in violation of the statute or not. Clearly, we have to look at it closely."
Even if the payments are legal, critics say they raise a host of thorny questions: Will the promise of a stipend, however small, induce families to lie about the medical histories of their loved ones, withholding information that could affect the health of the transplant recipient?
Will the money prompt a disproportionate increase in donation among the poor, injecting further economic imbalance into a system that is already skewed in favor of the wealthy? Will the plan backfire, hindering organ donation by offending families who believe their noble gift is tainted by payments?
And, finally, in an era when surgeons are routinely transplanting kidneys from living donors who are not related to the recipients, could the stipends mark the first step on the road toward outright sale of organs?
"I think it is very murky ground to get into when we put a monetary incentive for such an altruistic gift as organ donation," said Antonio Benedi, a liver recipient and past president of Transplant Recipients' International Organization, a nonprofit group in Washington. "Obviously there are some folks that need help as far as funerals go, but to attach it to the actual donation, I think, is very dangerous."
Some transplant surgeons echo his view.
"Society is not prepared to allow for your body to be bought and sold," said Dr. Francis L. Delmonico, director of the kidney transplant program at the Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston. Dr. Delmonico is also medical director of the New England Organ Bank, the nation's oldest organ procurement agency, and although that organization has not taken a position on the stipend, he said he felt compelled to offer his personal views.
"I don't have a fundamental objection to compensating families," Dr. Delmonico said. But, noting that organs are sold on the black market in some nations, he said he worried that "this would be a slippery slope toward the buying and selling of organs, which is Federally prohibited."
Still, transplant surgeons and organ procurement directors across the nation are watching Pennsylvania's experiment closely, and some, including those in New York, are laying plans to follow it if it proves successful in increasing donations.
In a report issued last year, the New York Task Force to Increase Organ and Tissue Donation recommended to the State Department of Health a plan for funeral expense reimbursement that "might be modeled after the Pennsylvania approach, after evaluation of Pennsylvania's experience."
The idea of paying donor families is not new; it has been debated in transplant circles for about a decade. In 1991, the National Kidney Foundation staged a series of town hall meetings to discuss the idea; the next year, the foundation paid for a telephone poll that found 48 percent of people favored some form of financial compensation to the families of organ donors, 42 percent opposed it and 10 percent were undecided.
"Our position is that this should be tested to see whether it serves a purpose," said Dolph Chianchiano, the group's director of scientific and public policy. "We are not talking about a situation where the organ goes to the highest bidder, or that there should be a market for organs. We are talking about a limited, specified amount of money paid to a third party."
Increasingly, others are adopting that view, said Dr. Charles Miller, a transplant surgeon at Mount Sinai Medical Center in Manhattan. Dr. Miller, who was the chairman of the New York task force, said the concept of payments had been so controversial that, for years, "people were scared to talk about it."
"I think times have changed," Dr. Miller said. "I think the organ donor shortage has become so public and so critical that people are beginning to rethink."
That there is a shortage at all is testimony to the success of transplant surgery. As recently as 1990, for instance, there were 50 liver transplant centers in the country; today there are 120. As more doctors learn how to transplant organs, more patients demand organ transplants. According to the Department of Health and Human Services , 56,716 people were waiting for hearts, lungs, livers, pancreases and kidneys at the end of 1997; by the end of last year, the list had grown to 64,423.
In 1994, sensing the growing crisis, lawmakers in Pennsylvania adopted Pennsylvania Act 102. It required, among other things, that hospitals notify organ procurement agencies of every death, a provision that has since been put into place nationwide through a regulation adopted by the Clinton Administration.
The Pennsylvania law also mandated public education programs to increase awareness of the organ shortage. It permitted residents to donate a small sum from their tax returns and motor vehicle registration fees to an organ donor trust fund. And it authorized the Governor to create a 15-member advisory panel to make recommendations about how the money should be spent.
Under the law, 10 percent of the fund may be used to reimburse families for medical or funeral expenses, at a maximum of $3,000 to any one family, said Ms. Tierney of the health department. But the Governor's advisory panel has determined that the reimbursements should be much less, about $300 per family, Ms. Tierney said. The trust fund now totaled about $800,000, she said, enough to start making disbursements.
Under the plan being drafted, the procurement agencies would inform families when their relatives died that they were eligible for the benefit if they donated an organ.
Experts have been trying for years to understand why people refuse to donate organs. They say that religious beliefs, the attitudes of doctors and nurses, and the sensitivity of representatives of organ procurement agencies, who put the delicate question to family members after their loved ones have died, all play a part. But nobody knows if a stipend will make a difference, because it has never been tried.

HEADLINE: CRISIS IN THE BALKANS: THE PRESIDENT;
Clinton Flies To Europe To Bolster Troop Morale

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: RAMSTEIN AIR BASE, Germany, May 5

 BODY:
Donning a brown bomber jacket in solidarity with the NATO forces in Yugoslavia, President Clinton began a two-day morale-boosting trip to Europe today that included a brief visit with the three American soldiers who were recently released from Serbian captivity.
His trip here was the closest Mr. Clinton has come to the Yugoslav theater of war since NATO began bombing Serbia on March 24. Despite a packed schedule that took him from Brussels to two air bases in Germany and will later tonight take him to Frankfurt, the visit, in a drizzly chill, was a subdued one for the weary-looking President, for whom the war presents an array of nettlesome complications. 
 To accommodate diplomatic needs, Mr. Clinton's schedule was expanded from a 24-hour visit with troops to include talks with NATO commanders in Brussels this morning and a visit with Germany's Chancellor, Gerhard Schroder, on Thursday afternoon.
The visit also included plans to meet with relief agencies handling the refugee crisis.
Mr. Clinton addressed the troops at the American air base in Spangdahlem and then here, where he locked into an earnest discussion with nine men during supper in a hangar under the propeller of a hulking C-30 transport plane.
He said later that they talked about the war as well as the military's recruitment problems and low pay and that he assured them of bipartisan support in Congress for a pay raise.
"The United States military, because of people like you, can do things for a troubled world that no one else can do," the President told the troops after supper. "And I'm profoundly grateful."
He arrived in Brussels this morning from Washington to the news that two American pilots had been killed, apparently in training accidents. They are the first American deaths of the Kosovo conflict.
Aides said that the immediate fall-out of the war -- the overwhelming difficulty of helping as many as 1.5 million refugees -- weighed heavily on Mr. Clinton, even as the United States accepted its first plane load of 453 refugees today in New Jersey.
Brian Atwood, head of the Agency for International Development, who traveled here with Mr. Clinton, said that the quandary of the refugees dominated the President's private talks today. "The international community is going to, at times in the next few weeks, appear to be very disorganized," Mr. Atwood said.
All in all, the President's public appearances today were fairly low-key. His speech in Spangdahlem was just 17 minutes, and he seemed to hasten through his stack of events, putting himself uncharacteristically ahead of schedule.
He began his day at NATO headquarters in Brussels by meeting with Secretary General Javier Solana. He was then briefed by General Wesley K. Clark, the Supreme Allied Commander. He later flew here and met privately with the three former captives and their families for about 25 minutes.
Asked why he thought Slobodan Milosevic, the Yugoslav President, had let them go, Mr. Clinton declined to speculate. "The important thing is he did let them go," he told reporters.

HEADLINE: Air War: Too Costly in Every Way

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "It Costs a Lot More to Kill Fewer People" (Week in Review, May 2): 
 An important consideration is the depreciation costs associated with the aircraft used in the Balkan conflict. These costs are not an immediate cash cost to the United States; however, they are a relevant part of the economic analysis.
In addition, considering that these aircraft are not only burning up fuel in the air but also wearing out and moving closer to needing to be replaced further highlights the question your article raises about the increasing monetary cost of the Balkan air war to the American people versus what appear to be disappointing military returns from the use of such expensive, high-tech weaponry.
 
ANTHONY H. LENESS
New York, May 2, 1999

HEADLINE: Essay;
Nudity and Energy: Qi Whiz!

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
One hundred fifty peaceful exhibitionists assembled at 6 A.M. in Manhattan's Times Square recently, stripped off all their clothes and together posed in the altogether for the photographer Spencer Tunick.
Before he could get the shot of massed nudes, the lubricious lensman was arrested for "tumultuous and violent conduct." The D.A. has charged Mr. Tunick with "promoting the exposure of a person." (What kind of crime is that? I try to do that in this space twice a week.) We libertarians view this bluenosed suppression of artistic expression as a foolish waste of the police's time. 
 Half a world away, at almost the same moment, a crowd of more than 15,000 middle-aged Chinese of the Fulan Gong sect assembled in front of the compound housing China's leadership. Fully clothed, they sat silently on the sidewalk in yoga's lotus position for 13 hours, in deep concentration.
They thereby threw a scare into the Chinese Communist Government the likes of which has not been felt since the demonstration at Tiananmen Square 10 years ago on June 4.
But this year's demonstration was not political. No signs were raised, no slogans shouted, no replicas of the Statue of Liberty held aloft that triggered a massacre. These are practitioners of qigong (pronounced chee-goong), both a martial art and a method of breathing and meditation that directs energy to improve health and spiritual awareness. Though an offshoot of Buddhism and denounced by the government-run qi establishment, it avoids condemnation as a cult by claiming not to be a religion.
Accordingly, Prime Minister Zhu Rongji rolled out no tanks. He listened to a delegation's complaint about harassment by officialdom, and offered them bus rides home. The crowd dispersed, having made its point. The official newspapers are now warning the Fulan Gong not to try that surprising stunt again.
This can be dismissed as a cult promoted by Li Hongzhi, a Chinese forced out of China and now in New York. Reported to believe in alien beings and levitation -- and selling TV cassettes of his outlook on his Web site -- Mr. Li's 5,000-year-old symbol of yin-yang means "all is well" but looks a lot like a swastika. Tibetan and Chinese friends tell me that by a Buddhist, he's no Buddhist.
But whether he's selling scary superstition or uplifting spirituality -- or the brain-body interaction that Western scientists no longer pooh-pooh -- between 40 and 70 million people are buying. The movement has about as many members in China as the Communist Party and is growing much faster. Beijing has not cracked down because it fears turning the energy of qi on itself by making martyrs.
Zhu has reason to worry. Communism is producing political suppression while its capitalist road requires economic belt-tightening and its social policy limits families to one child. With 200 million unemployed or underemployed making up 25 percent of the work force, China may be yearning for a movement offering a happier, healthier, freer life.
That's what troubles the Forbidden City. "They remember the Boxer Rebellion," says Columbia University Prof. Robert Thurman, "a popular movement to purify the corruption of the Manchus. Any nationwide reawakening of spirituality is seen as a threat to central control. They feel threatened by any organized movement, but how do you handle a nonviolent, transcendental ideology that seems so innocuous?"
In good times, Communism and Confucianism, with their common respect for authority, can easily co-exist. But when a sense of impermanence takes hold, and the mandate of Heaven comes into doubt, all in authority sense the danger of spiritual revival. Most sects die aborning, but a few, strengthened by repression, mushroom into a major challenge.
Advice to Prime Minister Zhu: Ease up. Don't turn a shrewd salesman into a mythic hero. Neither your stolen nuclear secrets nor your boughten supercomputers can smother an internal brush fire begun in spirituality and selflessness and ignited by outrage.
On a different order of magnitude, advice to the N.Y.P.D. and the Manhattan D.A.: Lighten up. If they're not blocking traffic and do nothing more violent than smiling at a camera, let the nudies shape themselves into a message and pose. Good for tourism, better for art, best for liberty. 
http://www.nytimes.com

SECTION: Section E; Part 1; Page 22; Column 5; Movies, Performing Arts/Weekend Desk

LENGTH: 2241 words

HEADLINE: MOVIE GUIDE

 BODY:

Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on page 12.
 
Now Playing
 
* "ANALYZE THIS," starring Robert De Niro and Billy Crystal. Directed by Harold Ramis (R, 110 minutes). The title, concept and teaming of these co-stars are all funny before the lights go down, so think of this comedy as an offer you can't refuse. Cast as a mobster whose confidence is shaken, Mr. De Niro is hilarious simply by playing his role halfway straight, in classic goodfella style. His mobster finds just the right comic foil in Mr. Crystal, as the psychiatrist who utters the immortal, "When I got into family therapy, this wasn't the family I had in mind." There's a lot more where that came from in this breezy comedy (Janet Maslin). 

* "CENTRAL STATION," starring Fernanda Montenegro. Directed by Walter Salles (R, 115 minutes). In this quiet, luminous Brazilian gem, a joyless older woman crosses paths with an orphaned boy. There's plenty of room for sentimentality here, but the wonder of Mr. Salles's film is all in the telling. As these characters develop a fractious bond, then embark on a road trip that takes them vividly to Brazil's hinterlands in search of the boy's father, Mr. Salles brings great tenderness and surprise to the events that punctuate their journey. Ms. Montenegro's tough bravura performance was one of last year's very best (Maslin).
 
* "COOKIE'S FORTUNE," starring Charles S. Dutton, Glenn Close, Patricia Neal and Julianne Moore. Directed by Robert Altman (PG-13, 118 minutes). What a treat. The sweet assurance and guerrilla wit of Mr. Altman's vintage ensemble films make a copacetic return with a Southern small-town black comedy. Seamlessly made and completely enveloping, it tells of the machinations set off when a wealthy old woman (Ms. Neal) outrages her diabolically genteel niece (Ms. Close) by committing suicide. As the old woman's dearest friend and the niece's unwitting nemesis, Mr. Dutton is rock solid and appealing. The entire cast works on a single wavelength as Mr. Altman makes the most of a well-woven screenplay by Anne Rapp (Maslin).
 
* "THE DREAMLIFE OF ANGELS," starring Elodie Bouchez and Natacha Regnier. Directed by Erick Zonca (R, 113 minutes; in French with English subtitles). In this very special French film about two freewheeling young women, their turbulent friendship is frayed by sexual passion and economic realities. The weaker and more head-turning of the women (Ms. Regnier) falls for the advances of a rich nightclub owner, while her fiery friend, played with unforgettable immediacy by Ms. Bouchez, rages against what she views as imminent disaster. In the process, Mr. Zonca shows astonishing acuity in observing how the women's diverging values affect every aspect of their lives. A rare and wrenching drama (Maslin).
 
* "ELECTION," starring Matthew Broderick and Reese Witherspoon. Directed by Alexander Payne (R, 105 minutes). From the acerbically funny director of "Citizen Ruth" comes this caustic satire of the American electoral process in a high school setting. Its leading candidate, Tracy Flick, played tartly by Ms. Witherspoon, has a mother who sought tactical advice for Tracy from Connie Chung and Elizabeth Dole. Mr. Broderick plays the hapless good-guy teacher who thinks this wicked little front-runner needs to be stopped. And the hunky newcomer Chris Klein plays Tracy's reluctant opponent in a style best described as early Keanu. With a lovely ear for hypocritical conversation, the screenplay specializes in keeping all the characters a few beats off of what they actually mean (Maslin).
 
"ENTRAPMENT," starring Sean Connery and Catherine Zeta-Jones. Directed by Jon Amiel (PG-13, 105 minutes). This glossy caper film summons the days when being a thief was the profession of choice among debonair movie heroes. And heroines: as the great-looking insurance investigator who is supposedly investigating Mr. Connery's glamorous super-burglar, Ms. Zeta-Jones makes a smashing gymnast and heist expert in her own right. No need to believe the outlandish details of the story; there's enough verve and charisma to the stars to make the escapade easy on the eyes. The action sequence, in which the stars hang off the side of the world's largest skyscraper, is a vertiginous show stopper. And here's a nice bonus: nobody gets killed (Maslin).
 
"EXISTENZ," starring Jennifer Jason Leigh and Jude Law. Directed by David Cronenberg (R, 90 minutes). Not for Mr. Cronenberg the sleek futuristic look of other films that play virtual reality games. This one has the insinuatingly ghoulish hallmarks of other Cronenberg fever dreams (like "The Fly," "Crash" and "Naked Lunch"). And it uses them to weirdly enveloping effect as a renowned game designer (Ms. Leigh) and her wary companion (Mr. Law) try to play the most dangerous game she has yet created. This sci-fi scheme is disturbingly effective as it plays its own mind games with the viewer, complete with a sharp final twist. The title is pronounced "eggs-is-tense" (Maslin).
 
"GO," starring Sarah Polley, Katie Holmes, Timothy Olyphant, Taye Diggs, Scott Wolf and Jay Mohr. Directed by Doug Liman (R, 100 minutes). This three-episode demimondaine comedy borrows truckloads of inspiration from "Pulp Fiction," but still has some flash and personality of its own. Mr. Liman, who shot the film as well as directed it, uses a supermarket as ground zero and sends a sullen cashier (Ms. Polley) out to make a drug deal. He embellishes this situation fully enough to send his film down the rabbit hole into neo-Tarantino adventures, some of which (guys go to Las Vegas, then get into trouble with strippers, gunplay, car theft and a brake-screeching chase) are a lot more tired than others. The ensemble cast shows cool comic flair (Maslin).
 
* "HIDEOUS KINKY," starring Kate Winslet. Directed by Gillies MacKinnon (R, 99 minutes). Ms. Winslet knew best when she took on this offbeat, richly atmospheric adventure in the wake of "Titanic." The leading role in Mr. MacKinnon's vividly colorful film offers her a field day. She plays a young hippie mother who brings her reluctant British daughters to Marrakesh, circa 1972. The film, about the mother's willfulness, the girls' reaction and the sheer headiness of their surroundings, belongs to the striking subgenre in which it is baby-boom adults, not their children, who most need to come of age (Maslin).
 
"LIFE," starring Eddie Murphy and Martin Lawrence. Directed by Ted Demme (R, 105 minutes). Though it's hard to miss the basic unfunniness of seeing two black men sentenced to life at a Mississippi state prison, this mild-mannered comedy is more likable than it sounds. If it awkwardly straddles the line between period piece (it begins during Prohibition) and comedy, it also keeps the stars kidding their way from youth to curmudgeonhood. Mr. Murphy in particular gives a more substantial performance than might be expected here. Stick around for closing outtakes that show (for instance) a cell phone ringing during a scene set in 1932 (Maslin).
 
* "LOCK, STOCK AND TWO SMOKING BARRELS," starring Jason Flemyng, Dexter Fletcher, Vinnie Jones and Nick Moran. Directed by Guy Ritchie (R, 106 minutes). Not since "The Usual Suspects" has there been such an oversupply of cool macho schemers in a single film. And they're served up with a quick, tart economy that bespeaks the filmmaker's background making videos and commercials, actually an advantage for a change. There's not much beneath the surface here. What's most entertaining is Mr. Ritchie's droll, hard-boiled storytelling and the rogue's gallery of a cast that he has assembled. All the film need do is juggle assorted miscreants and four separate gangs who, figuratively speaking, can't shoot straight (Maslin).
 
"THE MATRIX," starring Keanu Reeves and Laurence Fishburne. Directed by Andy and Larry Wachowski (R, 120 minutes). The time-traveling story steeped in virtual reality will be all but incomprehensible to nontechnofreaks. And the film borrows unapologetically from other sci-fi extravaganzas, with a big debt to "The X-Files" in the paranoia department. But the storytelling is intricately bizarre and the special effects are indeed special, notably when it comes to midair martial arts with a gravity-defying gusto. And Mr. Reeves shows that you can look like a Prada model while behaving like an action hero. One of the main stars here is Bill Pope, an inventive cinematographer. He and the Wachowskis provide a couch-potato epiphany: while the characters seem to be performing marvelous feats, they're often lying stock-still in the grip of virtual reality (Maslin).
 
"PUSHING TIN," starring John Cusack, Billy Bob Thornton, Angelina Jolie and Cate Blanchett. Directed by Mike Newell (R, 115 minutes). This story of air traffic controllers betrays its origins as a magazine article because it has more interesting data than built-in drama. But with a cast like this, and with the director of "Four Weddings and a Funeral" at the helm, the tacked-on soapy plot has plenty of sparks. Mr. Cusack and Mr. Thornton, both tersely good as professional rivals, become even more competitive once Ms. Jolie sashays into view as the latter's show-stopping biker-chick wife. Whatever possessed Ms. Blanchett to play Mr. Cusack's wife, a heavily accented Long Island housewife who talks about casseroles in the oven, she brings off the role with good humor and unexpected grace (Maslin).
 
* "SHAKESPEARE IN LOVE" (the Oscar winner for best film, best original screenplay, best art direction, best costumes and best comedy score). Starring Joseph Fiennes, Gwyneth Paltrow (the best-actress winner), Geoffrey Rush, Ben Affleck and Judi Dench (best supporting actress). Directed by John Madden (R, 113 minutes). A witty, sexy and merrily literate delight, with an exhilaratingly clever premise that only gets better as the film unfolds. The screenplay, originating as Marc Norman's brainstorm and turned by Tom Stoppard into razor-sharp dialogue reminiscent of his "Rosencrantz and Guildenstern Are Dead," dares to imagine whatever it likes about the link between Shakespeare's artistic passions and his mad yearning for a certain aristocratic beauty. Meanwhile, this tirelessly inventive comedy envisions an Elizabethan theater fraught with the same backbiting and conniving we enjoy today and has great fun presenting the creation of "Romeo and Juliet," glitches and all. Mr. Fiennes and Ms. Paltrow make a fine, tempestuous duo, and she gives the first great, fully realized starring performance of her career (Maslin).
 
* "A WALK ON THE MOON," starring Diane Lane, Viggo Mortensen, Liev Schreiber, Tovah Feldshuh and Anna Paquin. Directed by Tony Goldwyn (R, 107 minutes). This evocative 1969 period piece, set on the brink of Woodstock in a Catskills holiday camp, is as seductive as the handsome, itinerant hippie who turns its heroine's life upside down. Thoughtfully conceived and movingly acted, it sweeps a housewife and mother named Pearl Kantrowitz (Ms. Lane) into a torrid extramarital romance and then weighs the consequences. With a tenderness that is unusual for a contemporary American film, it tells an enveloping tale enhanced by artfully selected Woodstock-era music. Mr. Mortensen may strain credulity as the foxiest blouse salesman in the Catskills, but he certainly does wonders for the movie (Maslin).
 
* "THE WINSLOW BOY," starring Nigel Hawthorne, Rebecca Pidgeon and Jeremy Northam. Written and directed by David Mamet (G, 110 minutes). Terence Rattigan's play, about the 1910 schoolboy's trial that created a furor in England, has been artfully pared down to its essentials in this stately and deliberate adaptation. Played with unusually effective restraint by a fine, meticulous cast, it works as a precisely calibrated war of nerves in which the family of a cadet accused of theft is quietly staggered by the consequences of that accusation. Benoit Delhomme's cinematography is beautifully lucid and painterly. Ms. Pidgeon's defiantly arch acting style sets the film's tone and gives her suffragist character a sharp edge (Maslin).
 
Film Series
 
"A FRED ASTAIRE CENTENNIAL CELEBRATION." With 18 films, including favorites like "Top Hat," "Swing Time" and "Shall We Dance," the American Museum of the Moving Image is celebrating the centennial of the birth (May 10, 1899, in Omaha) of Fred Astaire. The elegant, sophisticated, graceful dancer, actor and choreographer will be seen in eight of his films with Ginger Rogers and two with Rita Hayworth. The festivities begin tomorrow with a 2 P.M. screening of "The Gay Divorcee" (1934), directed by Mark Sandrich, which includes "Night and Day" and "The Continental." At 4:30 P.M. the attraction is Sandrich's "Top Hat" (1935), which includes "Cheek to Cheek" and "Top Hat, White Tie and Tails." The museum is at 34-12 36th Street, at 35th Avenue, Astoria, Queens. Admission to the series, continuing through June 6, is $8.50 for adults, $5.50 for the elderly and students with identification, $4.50 for children 5 to 18 and free for children under 4. Information: (718) 784-0077 (Lawrence Van Gelder).

SECTION: Section E; Part 2; Page 30; Column 3; Leisure/Weekend Desk

LENGTH: 970 words

HEADLINE: INSIDE ART

BYLINE: By Carol Vogel

 BODY:

Lost Treasure To Be Auctioned
A haunting landscape by the Hudson River School master Frederic Edwin Church is being offered for sale at Sotheby's on May 27. The painting, which features a cross in the foreground, comes with an unusual past. 
 For years it was lost and known to Church scholars only from passing references. But in 1980 it was rediscovered hanging in the Des Moines Women's Club, where it had been since the group received it in 1952. Club members knew the painting not as "To the Memory of Cole," as the artist had named it, but as "Sunrise in the Catskills."
Two Church scholars, David C. Huntington, who died in 1990, and J. Gray Sweeney, an art history professor at Arizona State University, had spent years looking for "To the Memory of Cole," which Church painted in memory of his teacher, Thomas Cole, in April 1848, two months after Cole's death.
"I had found two references to the painting from newspaper clippings in the early 1970's," Mr. Sweeney said. "Then one day in 1979 I got a call from David Huntington, who said he had been contacted by the Des Moines Women's Club, which wanted him to look at a Church they owned. He asked me if I'd go instead."
Mr. Sweeney remembers the moment he first saw the painting. "It was like an electric charge, a powerful moment of recognition," he said. "It can only be described as a national treasure. It's an audacious, daring statement by a 22-year-old genius who is saying: 'I am a Cole student. I shall wear his mantle.' "
The painting was originally owned by George W. Austen, a New York auctioneer. The work predates Asher B. Durand's monumental "Kindred Spirits," now in the collection of the New York Public Library, which had long been considered the only painting to commemorate Cole's death.
At the time of his death, Cole was working on a series of allegorical paintings called "The Cross and the World," and they directly influenced "To the Memory of Cole."
"Church saw the cross as a symbol, or perhaps an ideal or proposed tombstone, but one never realized it was for Cole's tomb," Mr. Sweeney said. "The rays of morning light that illuminate the cross symbolize rebirth."
In an economic climate where top American paintings are hard to come by and prices keep rising, Sotheby's estimates that the painting could sell for $5 million to $8 million. The proceeds will go to create an endowment for the upkeep of the Des Moines Women's Club's 1907 building.
"I hate to see it go -- it's like my baby," said Anabelle Wonders, a former executive director of the club. The painting is in a collection of about 60 works, European and American, that the club owns and exhibits.
Ms. Wonders said the club first began talking to Sotheby's in the 1980's. At the time, she said, the members did not really want to part with it. And American paintings were not as highly valued then as they are today.
"It's an iconic painting," said Dara Mitchell, director of American paintings at Sotheby's. "Obviously, great paintings by Church rarely come on the market."
Ms. Mitchell noted that Sotheby's seems to get the chance to sell a work like this about every 10 years. In 1979 the auction house sold Church's "Iceberg," which became the first American painting to sell for more than $1 million. (It made $2.5 million.) In 1989 Sotheby's sold the artist's famous image "Home by the Lake" for $8.25 million.
"This is Church's first great statement," Mr. Sweeney said. "Today there are only about a half-dozen Church's left in private hands, and this is the best of them. It's my greatest hope that a museum will buy it so it can stay in the public eye."
 
Gift of a Rarity
"The Perfect Accord," one of the last Watteau paintings in private hands, has been given to the Los Angeles County Museum of Art by the Ahmanson Foundation, a Los Angeles-based organization that is a longtime supporter of the museum.
The painting, from around 1716, depicts five elegantly dressed people in a wooded park. A man in the center is playing the flute and a young woman beside him is singing. It was painted for the artist's friend Nicholas Henin, who oversaw architectural projects for the French court.
After changing hands several times, the painting was bought in 1892 by the Iveagh family of Britain and remained in the family until recently. One of Lord Iveagh's daughters, Lady Bridget Ness, the wife of Prince Frederic of Prussia, was the family's last owner. "She loved it so much she had a special case made and took it with her wherever she went," said Graham W. J. Beal, director of the Los Angeles County Museum. When Lady Bridget died a year ago, Simon Dickinson, who has galleries in New York and London, sold the painting to the foundation on behalf of the family trustees.
It is the first Watteau to enter the museum's collection and is on view in the Carter Gallery. This is the first time "The Perfect Accord" has been seen publicly in more than 100 years.
"Not having a Watteau has been a notable gap," Mr. Beal said. "The preparatory drawing for the work is also in Los Angeles, at the Getty."
 
To the Rescue
When the United States Pavilion at the 1999 Venice Biennale opens on June 12 with an exhibition of work by the installation and performance artist Ann Hamilton, the pavilion will get corporate sponsorship for the first time, and the sponsor is Gucci.
Gucci and its creative director, Tom Ford, have over the years financed decorative arts, photography and performing arts projects in London, Japan and New York.
The Venice installation is also receiving support from the United States Artists at International Festivals and Exhibitions, which is a partnership of the United States Information Agency, the National Endowment for the Arts, the Rockefeller Foundation and the Pew Charitable Trust.

SECTION: Section C; Page 8; Column 5; Business/Financial Desk

LENGTH: 591 words

HEADLINE: Excerpts From Speech To Bankers in Chicago

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from a speech yesterday by Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, at the 35th annual conference on Bank Structure and Competition of the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago:
Now that there are tentative signs that we may be through the worst of the crisis abroad, an issue to which I shall return shortly, it would be useful to address the benevolent, but bedeviling, question of how the American economy, at least to date, has managed to remain an oasis of prosperity, in sharp contrast to badly sagging economies in the developing world, recession in Japan and tepid growth in much of Europe. And, can we project how long our economy will be able to provide support to the rest of the world? . . . 
 I do not say we are in a new era, because I have experienced too many alleged new eras in my lifetime that have come and gone. We are far more likely, instead, to be experiencing a structural shift similar to those that have visited our economy from time to time in the past. These shifts can have profound effects, often overriding conventional economic patterns for a number of years, before those patterns begin to show through again over the longer term. . . .
In the event, the performance of the American economy over the past seven years has been truly phenomenal. The breadth of technological advance and its application has engendered a major upward revaluation of business assets, both real and intangible. That revaluation has induced a spectacular rise in equity prices that to many has reached well beyond the justifiable.
Of most concern is how long this remarkable period of prosperity can be extended. As I have said on previous occasions, there are imbalances in our expansion that, unless redressed, will bring this long run of strong growth and low inflation to a close.
Although productivity has accelerated in recent years, the impressive strength of domestic demand, in part driven by sharply rising equity prices, has meant that the substitution of capital for labor has been inadequate to prevent us from steadily depleting the pool of available workers. . . .
At some point, labor market conditions can become so tight that the rise in nominal wages will start increasingly outpacing the gains in labor productivity, and prices inevitably will then eventually begin to accelerate. . . .
For, if productivity growth should level out or actually falter because additional technology synergies fail to materialize, or because output per hour has been less tied to technology in the first place, inflationary pressures could re-emerge, possibly faster than some currently perceive feasible.
For, obviously if productivity growth slows, unit labor costs would rise, first pressuring profit margins, and then prices. Indeed, we cannot rule out such a process if labor productivity growth simply levels out. Our ability to forecast, when a diminishing pool of potential workers begins to raise costs or when productivity trends change, is limited. We do know, however, that if, and when, either materializes, inflation pressures are likely to again surface.
To return to my opening question: can we project how long the economy of the United States can act as a buffer to weakness elsewhere?
The answer: Not easily. History counsels us that sharp changes in direction are rarely, if ever, anticipated. Indeed, were these changes readily apparent, presumably, businesses would adjust to that anticipation and, hence, significantly damp the cyclical tendencies in the economy. 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: Jordan's King Heading West With a Plea on Debt

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL

DATELINE: AMMAN, Jordan, May 6

 BODY:
Since his father's death propelled him to the throne, King Abdullah of Jordan has been a man in motion. He has installed a new Government, moved to shore up his country's troubled economy and scurried around the region to patch up relations with Arab neighbors.
Now the 37-year-old ruler is embarking on another trip, this one to try to persuade Western governments to cancel $3.5 billion in Jordan's obligations, fully half the country's debt. He said today that this was necessary to help Jordan, which has proved pivotal to peace in the Middle East, become "more stable." 
 "You need Jordan to be strong so that we can shoulder our responsibilities and be able to support the countries of the region," King Abdullah said over a long lunch with foreign journalists, his first such interview since taking power.
The King's emphasis on the economy represents a shift in focus from that of his father, King Hussein, who died on Feb. 7 and whose main priority had been Middle East peace. But King Abdullah spoke with both candor and concern today in suggesting that his country needed more outside help. "We're not in a crisis period," he said, but added, "Time is short."
With just four million people and few natural resources, Jordan owes a staggering $7 billion to Western creditors, and its debt payments now consume a quarter of its budget. Unemployment has soared well into the double-digits, average incomes have plunged, and diplomats say they worry that mounting social discontent could make it difficult for Jordan to play its stabilizing role in the region.
The King said he was not worried about domestic unrest. But as he prepared to leave on Saturday on a journey that will take him to Britain, Germany, Canada and the United States, he argued that the combination of Jordan's problems and its strategic significance meant that Western leaders would be prudent to halve its debt burden.
"What I'm saying is we are keeping up our side of the bargain," he said, referring to steps that Jordan has already taken at the advice of the International Monetary Fund. "We are moving forward, we are moving according to the way you've advised to do it. Please meet us halfway and help us to continue."
King Abdullah said he was grateful for steps already taken by the Clinton Administration, which canceled hundreds of millions of Jordanian debt in 1994 after King Hussein made peace with Israel and has tripled its aid to Jordan in the last two years, to $700 million a year.
Forgiving $3.5 billion in debt would be a much bigger step, however. Most of it would have to be borne by the Europeans, who are Jordan's biggest creditors, and some have sent mixed signals. A British emissary, Derek Fatchett, said here this week that European countries were ready to help ease Jordan's debt problems, but Mr. Fatchett mentioned debt rescheduling, not debt forgiveness.
The King was asked what would happen if his request is not met. "No matter what cards are dealt," he answered, "we will persevere. But at what expense?"
Since he inherited the throne, King Abdullah has grown a beard, and he has also grown in confidence, apparently as a result of his rapid immersion in statesmanship. He was named Crown Prince in January, replacing the longtime official heir, Prince Hassan, just days before his father's death from cancer.
But he said that he had recognized that there was "no time to feel sorry for oneself" or for the "great loss of King Hussein," who died after 47 years on the throne. "We had to focus and get things together so that people could feel secure, and move forward," he said, adding, "I was always told by my father, you get knocked down, you get right back up."
Another item in his conversations with Western leaders, King Abdullah said, will be policy toward Iraq, whose citizens' suffering under the economic sanctions imposed by the United Nations after Iraq's 1990 invasion of Kuwait strikes angry nerves in Jordan.
Jordan was outspoken in calling for a change in the Iraqi Government in the mid-1990's, but it retreated from that stance under King Hussein and, if anything, King Abdullah seemed today to back further away. He said he believed that dialogue with Iraq might be more productive than continued sanctions, and he vowed that Jordan would play no role in any American-led efforts to topple the Iraqi leadership.
In the interview, King Abdullah seemed determined to dispel any impression that he has begun to turn his back on Israel. Jordan's peace with Israel remains deeply unpopular here, but the King said that, like his father, he was "absolutely committed" to it.
Still, it has been widely noticed in the Middle East that the King's first foreign visits were made to Arab countries, including Syria, Libya, Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates, which have been hostile toward Israel and have often criticized Jordan's separate peace.
"I want relationships with everybody, and I think we can do that," the King insisted. But he also said that, in reaching out to Arabs with whom relations have been cold, one of his motivations had been to "reassure our nationals, many of whom had worried that Jordan might have severed too many Arab bonds."
The King said he held out hope that Israel and the Palestinians could quickly resume negotiations after the Israeli elections on May 17. If there is momentum in those talks, he predicted, it might well produce a "cascade effect that could smooth over other differences, including those between Israel and Syria."
King Abdullah has maintained a studied neutrality on the Israeli elections. All three men seeking to become Israel's next Prime Minister have visited Amman recently, and the King has held a private meeting with each of them. But it is no secret in Amman that King Hussein had come to see Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, the Likud Party leader, as an obstacle to a broader peace, and a slip of the tongue by King Abdullah today seemed to suggest that he might prefer one of Mr. Netanyahu's two rivals.
The King said he would be optimistic about peace "if we have a new face in Israel," and then he caught himself. What he had meant to say, he insisted, was "if we have a new phase."

HEADLINE: Insurers Agree to Pay on Victims' Pre-Holocaust Policies

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL

DATELINE: LONDON, May 6

 BODY:
Several large European insurance companies agreed for the first time today to pay claims on prewar policies of Holocaust victims, under a formula that reflects present-day values. The settlement could potentially result in billions of dollars in payments.
The exact terms of the agreement, reached after two days of rancorous negotiations in London, were not released, and the insurers declined to comment on them. But the broad outlines of the agreement were announced by the World Jewish Congress, which participated in the negotiations, and Lawrence S. Eagleburger, the former Secretary of State who is chairman of the committee that has been conducting the negotiations. 
 The agreement was seen as a significant breakthrough on an issue haunting Europe more than 50 years after World War II. It is the latest unfolding of an effort that began some three years ago to secure financial reparations from Swiss banks for survivors of the Nazis.
Since then, the effort, led by American Jewish groups, senior United States officials and American lawyers, has mushroomed to encompass claims against European insurance companies and German corporations accused of employing slave labor. Just Wednesday, for example, Volkswagen was sued in the United States on behalf of former Polish and Russian slave laborers who claim their children died in a decrepit nursery run by the German auto maker during World War II.
The agreement with the insurers is significantly different from other settlements of Holocaust claims because it takes into account a half-century of inflation, interest payments and currency depreciation, which could drastically magnify the size of payouts.
The formula for determining the exact amount of payments has not been worked out yet, but estimates of the total cost of the agreement have ranged from $1 billion to $4 billion.
Mr. Eagleburger will lead a separate committee to resolve the value of the policies before negotiations resume in Jerusalem next month.
A statement on the agreement by Mr. Eagleburger did not say how claims would be verified. But it said he had instructed his staff to "establish the claims process and begin work on the outreach process necessary to inform potential insurance claimants that they can file claims."
Elan Steinberg, executive director of the World Jewish Congress, said the insurance companies agreed to make the payments only after Mr. Eagleburger threatened to publicly state that negotiations were a failure due to the insurers' intransigence. The insurance companies at the negotiations are some of the biggest in the industry: Allianz A.G. of Germany, AXA of France, Assicurazioni Generali of Italy, Winterthur of Switzerland and Anglo-Swiss Zurich Financial Services. Many other European insurance companies are not party to the deal.
At issue were thousands of life and other insurance policies -- and possibly many more -- taken out in prewar Europe by Jews who later died or suffered under the Holocaust. For decades after the war, insurance companies avoided paying out on the policies, arguing in some cases that, since their Eastern European subsidiaries had been nationalized by Communist governments in the postwar era, they were not responsible.
But, more recently, regulators in the United States, notably in California, put pressure on the European insurers. California threatened to suspend the business licenses of more than 100 European insurers unless they moved to settle with claimants.
On Wednesday night, after the first day of negotiations, Mr. Steinberg said that the talks were stalled on many issues, including the policy values and the insurance company nationalizations.
Today, after a second day of discussions, Mr. Steinberg said that "the rabbit was pulled from the hat" after Mr. Eagleburger told insurance company negotiators that he would disclose their attitude to the press.
Until all of the details are worked out, Mr. Steinberg said, the insurance companies agreed to make what he called "fast-track" payments to some of the thousands of aging people with direct claims on the policies. In addition, he said, the companies agreed to assume responsibility for policies predating the postwar nationalization of insurance subsidiaries.
Financial analysts said today's agreement was unlikely to eat significantly into the European insurance companies' huge holdings. But, some analysts said, the companies may have feared setting a precedent that would be used by American lawyers who won a $1.25 billion settlement from Swiss banks and are also pursuing class-action suits against German companies that employed slave labor.
In that case the issue of the value of wartime money translated into 1999 terms would assume significance because the German Government has already paid some claims that Jewish groups now consider to be too low.
Mr. Eagleburger is to meet Chancellor Gerhard Schroder along with Israel Singer of the World Jewish Congress next week to discuss that issue.

HEADLINE: Don't Quarantine Our Scientists

BYLINE: By Bill Richardson; Bill Richardson is the Secretary of Energy.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The evidence of Chinese espionage has cast much-needed attention on improving security at our nuclear weapons laboratories after years of security practices that have been insufficiently tough and vigilant.
But in the name of protecting our nuclear secrets, some in Congress are proposing to end scientific collaboration with some of the world's best foreign scientists. That misguided approach would actually harm our national security. 
 Cooperation with foreign scientists can be conducted safely when the classified areas of the weapons laboratories are properly secured. Since becoming Secretary of Energy in September, I have put strong measures in place to better protect nuclear secrets.
Our new policy requires background checks on all foreign visitors from sensitive countries. We have placed seasoned counterintelligence professionals, many with decades of F.B.I. experience, at the three national weapons labs to screen foreign visitors and to advise our people about what to anticipate and defend against when going abroad. We are requiring polygraph tests for employees working in the most sensitive areas. And there has been a 15-fold increase in the counterintelligence budget since 1996.
To improve computer security, I took the unprecedented step of suspending operations on all classified computers in all three weapons laboratories -- Los Alamos, Lawrence Livermore and Sandia -- for two weeks so computer security improvements could be put in place more quickly.
Science underpins all we do in maintaining our nuclear weapons. If we quarantined our scientists, isolating them from others in their fields, we would prevent them from keeping current with international research in unclassified areas like computer modeling, metallurgy and atomic physics that are essential to our ability to maintain nuclear weapons.
For example, the best atomic-physics codes -- unclassified codes about the structure of atoms -- are now written abroad. Hundreds of physicists around the world work to test and improve these codes, which scientists at our laboratories then adapt to support classified weapons work.
Ending international collaboration would make it harder to attract the most promising young scientists to this field. How could we lure talented people if they knew that they would be isolated from their foreign peers? Einstein, Teller and Fermi were all born abroad, and all of them did work that benefited the United States before they became American citizens.
Cutting off our international work would harm American security in other ways as well.
We send our workers to Russia because their expertise is needed to help secure hundreds of tons of plutonium and highly enriched uranium from theft by rogue states or terrorists. Energy Department employees are installing detection devices at Russia's airports to prevent nuclear smuggling. We are keeping former Soviet weapons scientists employed in Russia in peaceful enterprises so they aren't forced by economic hardship to accept weapons work in Iraq or other rogue nations. Our laboratory employees are also securing spent nuclear fuel in North Korea to prevent that country from restarting its weapons program.
All of that work would grind to a halt if a moratorium was imposed on contacts with foreign scientists.
Among the foreign visitors to our labs are inspectors from the International Atomic Energy Agency who are receiving unclassified training so they can monitor adherence to nuclear treaties and prevent the diversion of nuclear materials. These visits to unclassified areas of the weapons labs reduce the threat of nuclear proliferation and conflict.
We can have open science with international collaboration while protecting our national secrets. The right way to accomplish this is through strong security and counterintelligence efforts -- and we are doing that.
The wrong way would be to draw an iron curtain around the laboratories, isolating them from the world. We would pay a huge price for such isolation in a weakened defense. And in the end, we would damage the very security we seek to protect.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place;
InflationRemains a Danger, Greenspan Warns

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 6

 BODY:
Despite a remarkable run of prosperity that he credited in large part to new technology, Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, delivered his bluntest warning in months today that the economy could still be derailed by its old nemesis, inflation.
Delivering a sweeping analysis of the forces reshaping the economy at home and abroad, Mr. Greenspan said the ability of businesses to use rapid advances in computers and communications to hold down costs and produce higher-quality goods and services had helped hold down price increases, bolster the stock market and allow the economy to grow robustly. 
 But he said it would be risky to assume that technology could continue to keep the economy and Wall Street surging forever or that the business cycle and all the old economic rules had been repealed.
"As I have said on previous occasions, there are imbalances in our economy that, unless redressed, will bring this long run of strong growth and low inflation to a close," Mr. Greenspan said in remarks to bankers in Chicago. Excerpts, page C8.
At the top of his list was declining unemployment, which he said would eventually push wages and perhaps prices higher in an inflationary spiral. He added the possibility of a stock market downturn, which he said would cause consumers and businesses to cut their spending. And he said the rapidly growing trade deficit could one day become unsustainable, though it has caused no trouble so far.
Mr. Greenspan's inflation warning and his observation that many people think stocks have risen to levels "well beyond the justifiable" rattled Wall Street, sending bond prices sharply lower and equities down slightly. Page C8.
While it gave no indication that the Fed has any plans to raise interest rates, Mr. Greenspan's speech seemed intended as a cautionary flag to those investors and economists who have concluded that the United States has built a "new economy" in which inflation has been vanquished, corporate earnings will rise forever and the central bank remains on the sidelines.
Mr. Greenspan has helped drive the talk of a new economy by holding back pressure from traditionalists inside and outside the Fed for interest rate increases as steady growth has pushed unemployment down to a 29-year low of 4.2 percent without generating inflation. But Mr. Greenspan is very sensitive to any impression that he has gone soft on price stability, and today he planted one foot firmly in the inflation-hawk camp without quite removing the other from the new age camp.
"I do not say we are in a new era, because I have experienced too many alleged new eras in my lifetime that have come and gone," said Mr. Greenspan, who is 73 and has been running the Fed for almost 12 years.
"We are far more likely, instead, to be experiencing a structural shift similar to those that have visited our economy from time to time in the past," he said. "These shifts can have profound effects, often overriding conventional economic patterns for a number of years, before those patterns begin to show through again over the longer term."
Economists said they still expected the Fed to hold rates steady at its next meeting on May 18. But they said Mr. Greenspan clearly wanted to guard against complacency within the Fed and in the financial markets, especially if the unemployment rate falls again when the Labor Department releases jobs data for April on Friday morning.
"He may have felt he needed a way to get our feet back on the ground without going overboard in that direction," said L. Douglas Lee, an economist at HSBC Securities.
Indeed, Mr. Greenspan was careful to point out the economy's strong points in addition to the potential pitfalls. He noted that the worst of the global financial crisis seemed to have passed. And he devoted much of his speech to the case that technology has greatly improved the growth rate of productivity, or output per worker, the measure considered the most important in determining the economy's long-run potential.
Productivity growth, which has been sluggish for nearly three decades and which slipped below 1 percent in the early 1990's, averaged 3 percent over the most recent four quarters, Mr. Greenspan said.
The Fed chairman said the reason appeared to be the heavy investment in technology made by American business over the last five years. Computers, data bases, and faster and more reliable communication have all enabled companies to operate more efficiently by reducing their need for extra inventories of parts and extra workers, he said, since they have a much better handle on what is happening almost minute by minute in their markets and within their operations.
The consistent increases in analysts' projections for long-term corporate earnings growth, Mr. Greenspan said, suggests that companies are telling Wall Street that they expect productivity increases driven by technology to continue.
The surge in business investment in technology, Mr. Greenspan said, has not only restrained costs but also helped to expand industrial capacity faster than industrial output. The resulting excess in capacity has in turn helped keep prices down, helping offset any pressure from tight labor.
The result, Mr. Greenspan said, has been a "truly phenomenal" economic performance in recent years. But he said it was unclear how long it could continue.
If productivity growth "should level out or actually falter because additional technology synergies fail to materialize, or because output per hour has been less tied to technology in the first place, inflationary pressures could re-emerge, possibly faster than some currently perceive feasible," Mr. Greenspan said.
Beyond a slowdown in productivity, the biggest potential threat to the continuation of expansion, now in its ninth year, is from a tight labor market, the Fed chairman said.
"At some point, labor market conditions can become so tight that the rise in nominal wages will start increasingly outpacing the gains in labor productivity, and prices inevitably will then eventually begin to accelerate," Mr. Greenspan said.
Should the stock market tumble, Mr. Greenspan said, "consumer and business investment demands would doubtless weaken considerably."
A more distant concern, Mr. Greenspan said, is the mounting trade deficit.
"There is no evidence at this point that markets are disinclined to readily finance our foreign net imbalance," Mr. Greenspan said. "But the arithmetic of foreign debt accumulation and compounding interest costs does indicate somewhere in the future that, unless reversed, our growing international imbalances are apt to create significant problems for our economy."
