HEADLINE: TENNIS;
Dynamic Sisters Roll Along In Rome

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER CLAREY

DATELINE: ROME, May 6

 BODY:
The scene is the same this spring at the Foro Italico the clay just as red, the cypresses just as green -- but the women's roles are changing. The Williams sisters are walking tall and making big strides, and the vast majority of their competitors are not keeping up.
Together, which is the way they still prefer to be, Venus and her younger sibling, Serena, have already combined to win five singles titles this year: three for Venus and two for Serena. 
 And today at the Italian Open, against opponents who once gave them trouble, the sisters took turns underscoring their progress.
Serena was the first Williams to make her point by defeating Irina Spirlea, 6-2, 6-3. Then, with Serena watching from the stands, Venus handled Anna Kournikova, 6-2, 6-2.
In an earlier match, second-seeded Arantxa Sanchez-Vicario, now underpowered and still searching for good form after a hand injury, was upset in straight sets by Sylvia Plischke of Austria.
Spirlea, a tall, straight-talking Romanian, exchanged a chest bump and harsh words with Venus at the 1997 United States Open. The tension between her and America's first tennis family has since dissipated, but at last year's United States Open, Spirlea put an end to Serena's tournament when she defeated her in the third round in three sets.
Since then, Serena won her first tour event in Paris and then won again at Indian Wells in March.
"I think she's not giving you anymore the chance," Spirlea said. "She's not missing as much as she was missing."
Serena, ranked 10th, is also creeping inside the baseline with increasing regularity, hitting her ground strokes and service returns earlier and getting into the net with some frequency on a surface that is not always forgiving of net-rushers. Her body language is different, too; her movement during and between points is more economical and cocksure.
"I guess the thing that has really moved up is my mental," she said. "I know how to work the game more and play points better. It's just something that's grown. At the U.S. Open, I hadn't won a tournament, but now I know what to do playing people like her in her game."
Venus already knew what to do against Kournikova when they first played in the final in Key Biscayne, Fla., last year. She won in three sets, but at the time, it was uncertain which of the teen-agers was heading to the top the fastest.
With Williams at a career-high No. 5 in this week's ranking and Kournikova, who has yet to win a tour event, at No. 13, the sport now has the answer. And though Kournikova has split with the coach Pavel Slozil and stopped double-faulting at an embarrassing clip, she could not find a way to keep Venus from firing service winners and pulling her uncomfortably wide with big ground strokes.
In Friday's quarterfinals, Serena should have the trickier test. While Venus will face 11th-seeded Dominique Van Roost, Serena will face No. 1 Martina Hingis, the only player not named Williams who has won more tournaments than Serena this year.
Asked if that meant Hingis, Venus and Serena were now the world's top three, Serena did not hesitate. "Definitely," she said. "Of course. The statistics show it. It's just a fact for sure."
Though the WTA computer does not yet reflect it, Hingis concurs, and now she wants revenge for her 6-4, 7-6 loss to Serena in the semifinals last month in Key Biscayne.
"The difference is this is on clay, and I'm a more confident player, and I take her more seriously than last time," Hingis said tonight after her straight-set defeat of Corina Morariu. "She was kind of cocky on the court, and that kind of ticked me off in a way. But this time, it's going to be different."

HEADLINE: CRISIS IN KOSOVO: MOSCOW;
Russians Satisfied at Return To the Diplomatic Spotlight

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES

DATELINE: MOSCOW, May 6

 BODY:
President Boris N. Yeltsin's foreign-policy aides greeted the new framework for peace in Kosovo with a hint of pleasure at their return to the diplomatic spotlight and a determination that the country not appear to be merely a tool of the West.
Mr. Yeltsin's domestic advisers could not help but regard it as a small but significant victory for the President, who has struggled to control Russia's policy on Yugoslavia in the face of ever more militant -- and popular -- anti-Western oratory by Communist and nationalist forces. 
 In statements after the agreement was made public, Mr. Yeltsin's envoy to the United Nations, Sergei Lavrov, and Foreign Minister Igor Ivanov were quick to emphasize that they believed that Western intransigence remained the major roadblock to peace talks and an end to the crisis.
Mr. Lavrov said the West had only now agreed to terms for peace negotiations that Russia had been proposing for weeks. Mr. Ivanov used the announcement for renewed strenuous criticism of NATO's air war against Serbia.
"It's too early to talk about any sense of satisfaction today because unfortunately, NATO's bombing and missile attacks go on, people go on dying and the flow of refugees goes on," Mr. Ivanov, said. "After a long period, we've managed to get the settlement of this problem back to the United Nations, which alone is capable of solving this."
The statements echoed the increasingly hostile attacks on the West in general, and the United States in particular, that have come from the Kremlin in the last few weeks. Mr. Yeltsin has steadily edged Russia's policy on the Kosovo situation from moderate criticism of the West to threats of a diplomatic breach and war, as many average Russians have come to regard NATO as the agent of a new, anti-Russian Western empire.
Even today, hours before the agreement was announced, Mr. Yeltsin accused NATO of "naked aggression" against Yugoslavia and warned that "the shadow of war is hanging over Europe." His criticism was part of a statement marking the 55th anniversary of Russian liberation of the Ukrainian seaport of Sevastopol from Nazi troops.
The practical effect of the attacks has been to steal some of the thunder of the Communists and nationalists who control Russia's legislature, and who have demanded that Russia give Serbia weapons and even its own forces to battle NATO jets.
The two blocs will vote within days in the lower house of the legislature on whether to impeach Mr. Yeltsin, a move that probably would erase any political power the President has managed to retain after a year of illness and economic collapse.
 But whatever Mr. Yeltsin's oratory, Russia's actual involvement in the Kosovo situation has been directed not by hard-liners, but by former Prime Minister Viktor S. Chernomyrdin, a Yeltsin ally who is a familiar and moderate face in dealings with the United States and Europe.
Mr. Chernomyrdin's brokering of today's agreement on a framework for peace talks gives Mr. Yeltsin an increasingly rare political and diplomatic victory on the eve of the legislature's impeachment debate.
Mr. Yeltsin's critics have asserted for weeks that Mr. Chernomyrdin was destined to become a stooge for the West, delivering NATO ultimatums to Serbia rather than negotiating a peace.
The daily newspaper Izvestia suggested this week that the United States was merely paying lip service to Mr. Chernomyrdin's efforts as a cost-free way to demonstrate good will toward Moscow. In reality, the newspaper asserted, Washington was using Mr. Chernomyrdin to divide Russia and Serbia.
But parts of today's pact appeared to mirror what Mr. Chernomyrdin and other Russian officials have been publicly proposing in the last two weeks. Mr. Chernomyrdin said on Sunday, for example, that Serbia would agree to the placement of armed peacekeepers in Kosovo.
Mr. Yeltsin's Defense Minister, Igor Sergeyev, said during a visit to Norway this week that the Yugoslavia crisis could not be solved without an international military presence in Kosovo, and proposed using the armed forces of those Scandinavian countries that are not in NATO.

HEADLINE: Retail Boom Isn't Reliant Only on Rich

BYLINE: By LESLIE KAUFMAN

 BODY:
Michael Gonzales, a waiter from Los Angeles who earns about $25,000 a year, has been in a buying mood lately. "Things are going well for me these days," he reflected, while shopping at Home Depot in Los Angeles for supplies to refurbish his apartment. "It's not like I'm spending mountains of cash. Just enough for a few comforts."
Mr. Gonzales, 28, adds, "I'm older, so I can't stand living someplace that looks ratty." 
 Whether snapping up bathroom fixtures at Home Depot, shrink-wrapped T-shirts at Old Navy or wide-screen televisions at Circuit City, American consumers are on a rampage, increasing their spending even faster than they did last year. In the first four months of 1999, sales in stores open at least one year rose 6.7 percent from the corresponding period in 1998, one of the biggest jumps in years, according to the Goldman Sachs retail composite index. That increase comes on top of a dizzying 5.1 percent increase last year.
For growth in consumption to accelerate after eight years of economic expansion is a surprise -- the torrid pace had been expected to slow. Retail analysts and economists now point to several factors, including the continued rise of both the stock market and home values, to explain much of the gains. But another change is also helping: While the wealthiest consumers powered the expansion in its early stages, spending by those households in the bottom 40 percent, which is defined as people making up to $28,500 a year, has been picking up. Real growth in wages and the lowest unemployment rate in 30 years have spread the shopping spree into every corner of American society.
"Our research shows that for the first time in two and a half decades, workers' broad-based wage gains are generally driving consumption throughout the economy," said Jared Bernstein, an economist with the left-leaning Economic Policy Institute based in Washington. "It is not just the wealth bubble at the top."
During the first years of the economy's expansion, middle- and low-income Americans increased their spending, but at a much slower pace than those households making more than $47,000. Consumption by those earning less than $28,500 grew 10 percent from 1993 (a nadir in consumer spending for this group) through 1997, whereas spending by the richest fifth of Americans, those earning over $73,000, grew 25 percent, according to Edward Wolff, an economist at New York University who has analyzed the Federal Government's Consumer Expenditure Survey. Mr. Wolff projects that this will change when the Government data are made available for 1998. Spending by the group making less than $47,000 will have grown by 5 percent, he estimates, and spending by the richest by only 3 percent.
Given that the inflation-adjusted pay of the lowest wage earners has grown 5 percent to 10 percent since 1996 while their savings rate has hovered around zero, economists say it is safe to conclude that their additional earnings are going to new purchases. The earned-income tax credit (expanded in 1994) has also given them some additional buying power.
But low earners are taking on additional debt, too, as credit card companies court them and Federal programs encourage them to buy their own homes and assume mortgages.
"When we get the '98 and '99 data, it will become very clear that they are accounting for a very sizable share of the growth in consumer spending," said Mark Zandi, the chief economist for RFA, an economic consulting firm in West Chester, Pa.
All this is not to discount the spending power of the rich. As the biggest beneficiaries of sharp gains in the stock market, the wealthiest fifth of Americans are consuming as conspicuously as ever. Their intense appetite for luxury items has created a boom market for upscale cars and for homes that rival the gaudiest mansions of the Gilded Age. One sign of the giddy spending is the fierce resurgence of the ultimate income showpiece: fur. Not only are mink stoles in fashion for the fall, but designers are using fancy animal pelts for all manner of clothing from sweaters of royal blue chinchilla to skirts in shearling.
But if the rich are enjoying a sumptuous banquet, the remainder of Americans are not just scooping up table scraps, as many critics of Reaganomics argued was the case in the 1980's expansion. In everything from apparel to electronics to home furnishings, these Americans are making their mark.
Most notably, they are speeding the rise of discount stores and highlighting the growing troubles of retailers that cater to the middle market. In previous economic booms, low-income people tended to trade up to more expensive stores. This time around, they are sticking with those that offer them the best deals, and they are being joined by more affluent Americans, who are increasingly willing to shop both in boutiques and in stores that offer cut-rate prices.
In previous months, the surging buying power of lower-income earners helped move Target Stores, the Kmart Corporation and Wal-Mart Stores Inc. to the head of the retail pack. In April, sales at discount stores rose 3.8 percent from a year earlier, according to Goldman Sachs, much slower than in previous months but still impressive considering that Easter sales were recorded in March this year.
This segment is winning big because it has transformed itself from grimly pragmatic to stylish yet affordable. Target, a unit of the Dayton Hudson Corporation, is the most obvious practitioner of the strategy, but not its only one. It employs a brigade of trend hunters who bring the hippest clothing designs to the stores in a timely manner and recently unveiled a home design collection by the renowned architect Michael Graves, featuring retro-chic tea kettles and toasters.
"Four years ago there were no major brands in the discounters; then somebody finally woke up," said Adelle Kirk, director of marketing for Kurt Salmon Associates, a retail consulting firm. "These days discounters very successfully deliver fashion, terrific merchandising, and brands -- all at value prices."
Some market researchers argue that the more polished approach, in the best tradition of retail, is doing more than simply filling a need. It is also creating new desires to fuel the economy. In other words, Martha Stewart, the home-and-hearth avatar whose products are now available at Kmart stores, is making upscale design touches like 200-thread-count cotton bed sheets something that most every American can aspire to.
Jessica Clark, 21, has two jobs, one as a data entry clerk at a bank and another as a cashier at a grocery store. She says she regularly visits Target in her home town of Memphis, even on evenings when she goes out with friends.
"I always spend way too much when I come here, but I always find other things to buy," Ms. Clark laments. "Today I came to buy detergent and fabric softener, and I ended up with two plastic lawn chairs, plants, electronic games, candles, socks and a utility knife. I thought I would spend maybe $25, but I spent $106 instead. Every time I come here, I do that."
The other winners in this environment are also stores that emphasize good value. These includes Home Depot Inc. and the electronics giant Circuit City Stores Inc. Old Navy, the stylish low-cost clothing chain started by the Gap in 1994, has also repeatedly registered double-digit sales growth in the last year and reported a 7 percent increase in the latest monthly sales report.
Meanwhile, stores that cater to the middle class, like Sears, Roebuck & Company and the J. C. Penney Company, are finding it hard to get solid footing. Both stores yesterday reported slight sales declines in April from a year ago.
Jeffrey Feiner, a retail analyst with Lehman Brothers Inc., said, "The companies that are losing market share need to reposition themselves as value leaders, or they are not going to last."

HEADLINE: Panel Allows Senate Vote on Whitman's Pick for Court

BYLINE: By DAVID KOCIENIEWSKI

DATELINE: TRENTON, May 6

 BODY:
Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's nominee to the State Supreme Court cleared an important hurdle today, when the Senate Judiciary Committee moved to allow the full Senate to vote on his confirmation on Monday.
But support among Republicans for the nominee, Attorney General Peter G. Verniero, appeared to erode slightly, and it remained unclear whether the administration would hold together enough votes to win his confirmation. 
 Mr. Verniero, who endured two grueling days of confirmation hearings before the committee, retains the enthusiastic backing of the Governor. The Senate President, Donald T. DiFrancesco, who leads the Republicans' 24-to-16 majority, predicted today that Mr. Verniero would win the necessary 21 votes.
Mrs. Whitman's choice of Mr. Verniero for the court has run into unexpectedly fierce opposition over accusations that state troopers have engaged in racial profiling and over Mr. Verniero's legal experience.
In the day since the state Bar Association announced that it had studied Mr. Verniero's credentials and found him "not qualified" to sit on the high court, two Republican senators, including Robert J. Martin, a law professor at Seton Hall University, have announced that they would vote against him. Moments after the Judiciary Committee's party-line vote, Democrats announced that all 16 of their members would oppose the confirmation.
That means Mr. Verniero's fate, which has become an increasingly personal issue for Governor Whitman, may hinge on the votes of six Republicans who have yet to declare their intentions.
"I am confident that the nomination will be approved by the full Senate," the Governor said in a statement released after the committee vote.
Mr. Verniero told reporters after the vote that the testy questions and critical assessments of his credentials during the televised public hearings had been difficult for his family. Despite the political furor surrounding his nomination, Mr. Verniero said he was not daunted by the prospect that he might be approved with the backing of a single party.
"If the Senate as a whole sees fit to confirm me, I will be an associate justice for everybody," he said.
For more than two months, the nomination has consumed the political agenda in the state capital. During the hearings, Mr. Verniero received support from a procession of Republican political leaders who praised his record.
Democrats countered by saying that Mr. Verniero's resume was dominated by political appointments, and that he lacked the legal experience and intellectual independence to handle the rigors of New Jersey's high court.
Beyond Mr. Verniero's resume and performance as a Whitman appointee, however, the nomination has become intertwined in a variety of fractious issues, from charges of racial discrimination by the New Jersey State Police to the financial collapse of the New Jersey HIP Health Maintenance Organization.
The Legislature's Black and Latino Caucus, made up of 18 assemblymen and 4 senators, said that Mr. Verniero's response to the racial profiling issue was reason enough to oppose his nomination. Assemblyman Joseph Charles Jr., a Jersey City Democrat, told the committee that Mr. Verniero had subjected thousands of black and Latino drivers to discrimination by failing to react aggressively to a Gloucester County judge's 1996 ruling that troopers had illegally singled out black and Hispanic drivers for stops and searches.
Senator Martin said a combination of factors persuaded him to break ranks with Republican leadership and oppose the nomination.
"I think there are limitations in his experience," Mr. Martin said, "and while I don't think he is racially biased in any way, I think there are steps he should have taken earlier, especially given the gravity of the situation."
But Senator William Gormley, a Republican from May's Landing, said the hearings had convinced him that the breadth of Mr. Verniero's administrative experience made him qualified to sit on the court. Mr. Gormley added that the Attorney General was not alone in failing to respond quickly enough to accusations of racial discrimination by the state police.
"Profiling is not just a Peter Verniero issue," said Mr. Gormley, chairman of the Judiciary Committee. "It's something for all of us to do something about. And you can't just take one person and make him responsible."
Mr. DiFrancesco said he thought much of the opposition to Mr. Verniero was based on his lack of rapport with many lawmakers. When Mr. Verniero was Governor Whitman's chief of staff, some senators from both parties were put off by his stiff personal style and often dismissive attitude toward legislators. Mr. DiFrancesco said he hoped that senators could look beyond those personality traits to evaluate Mr. Verniero's qualifications.
Mr. DiFrancesco said he also thought Democrats were using the issue to attack Governor Whitman, who has announced her intention to run for the United States Senate in 2000.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Every U.S. Income Group Seems to Be Spending More
American consumers are spending faster than they did last year. In the first four months of this year, sales in stores open at least a year rose 6.7 percent, one of the biggest jumps in years. That came on top of a dizzying 5.1 percent increase last year. 
 Retail analysts and economists point to numerous factors, including the continued rise of both the stock market and home values, to explain much of the gains. But another change is also helping: While the wealthiest consumers powered the expansion in its early stages, spending by those in the bottom 40 percent of income has been picking up. Real growth in wages and the lowest unemployment rate in 30 years have spread the shopping spree into every corner of American society. Page A1.
 
Retail Sales Rose 3% in April
Sales at retail stores open at least a year rose 3 percent in April as shoppers snapped up spring fashions at clothing chains such as Ann Taylor and department stores. But sales at some of the biggest retailers may start to slow, analysts and investors said. That could hurt stocks like Gap and Wal-Mart that have surged. Yesterday, shares of Wal-Mart fell $2.1875, to $42.875, even though its sales met expectations. C19.
 
Insurers Agree on Holocaust Claims
Several large European insurance companies agreed for the first time to pay claims on prewar policies of Holocaust victims. The settlement could potentially result in billions of dollars in payments. A3.
 
F.C.C. Staff Questions Phone Deal
Staff investigators for the Federal Communications Commission said that the proposed $62 billion merger of SBC Communications and Ameritech should be blocked unless it is revised to encourage competition. C2.
 
Litton Offers to Buy 2 Shipbuilders
Litton Industries made unsolicited bids to buy both Newport News Shipbuilding and Avondale Industries for $1.8 billion. C2.
 
Prices of Stocks and Bonds Slide
Stocks fell after Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, said the "spectacular rise in equity prices" might be "beyond the justifiable." The Dow Jones industrial average slid 8.59 points, to 10,946.82. The Nasdaq composite index skidded 62.17 points, or 2.45 percent, to 2,472.28, and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 15.26 points, or 1.13 percent, to 1,332.05. Treasury prices tumbled, driving the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond up to 5.78 percent from 5.70 percent. C8.
 
Data-Scrambling Limits Rejected
The United States Government's restrictions on the export of data-scrambling software are unconstitutional, a Federal appeals court in California ruled. C19.
 
Televisa Gets Mexican Capital
Months of rumors that Rupert Murdoch would buy into Televisa, Mexico's largest television network, were laid to rest. Instead, the Mexican venture capital firm of Sinca Inbursa, which is part of the empire of Carlos Slim Helu, left, purchased a 24 percent stake in Grupo Televicentro, the holding company that controls Televisa. C4.
 
Board Turmoil in South Africa
Two board members of South Africa's most prominent black empowerment company, New Africa Investments, resigned in the face of outrage over a plan to award themselves and two other board members stock options worth more than $20 million. C4.

Russia and West in Accord On Need for Kosovo Force

HEADLINE: Senate Votes to Drop Barriers Between Nation's Financial Industries

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 6

 BODY:
The Senate approved legislation tonight that would overhaul the nation's financial system, removing barriers largely created during the Depression that have limited the ability of banks, insurance companies and securities firms to expand into one another's businesses.
By a 54-to-44 vote along party lines, the Senate adopted a measure sought by the three industries and written by Senator Phil Gramm, Republican of Texas and chairman of the banking committee. It would repeal the core provisions of the Glass-Steagall Act of 1933 and later laws that industry executives say have made it increasingly difficult to compete with foreign conglomerates unhindered by similar laws. 
 President Clinton has threatened to veto the Senate legislation, and his aides have expressed a decided preference for most of the provisions in a competing version that has been moving quickly through the House.
Senators will await the action in the House, where banking legislation with broad bipartisan support has been approved by the banking committee, and could be considered by the full chamber soon. Last year, the House adopted comprehensive banking legislation by the narrowest of margins, only to see it die in the Senate when it was blocked by Mr. Gramm.
Administration officials say the President would veto the Senate version because it would dilute requirements that banks make loans to minorities, farmers and others who have had little access to credit. The legislation also contains provisions that have been criticized by Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin because they reduce his department's oversight of banks.
But privately, some Democrats and Administration officials say that Mr. Clinton might agree to legislation if the objectionable provisions in the Senate measure were watered down or eliminated when the House and Senate negotiate a final bill in conference. The only Democrat voting for the bill tonight was Senator Ernest F. Hollings of South Carolina.
The legislation approved has been hailed by big banks, insurers and Wall Street investment houses as a monumental step forward because it deregulates the financial services industry for the first time in more than 60 years. Consumer groups and civil rights organizations have called it a giant step backward, rolling back protective measures adopted in the 1970's.
The Senate measure was sharply criticized tonight by the nation's top securities regulator, Arthur Levitt, the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, who said it would undermine significant protection now afforded to investors. Mr. Levitt said the legislation posed "a real danger to investors" because it violated "the principle of functional -- I call it 'consistent' -- regulation."
"This is a giant turf battle that in my opinion jeopardizes investor protection," he added.
But some Wall Street executives strongly praised the legislation and said it demonstrated how the leadership abilities of Senator Gramm had been underestimated.
"That Chairman Gramm achieved passage of this bill by holding to his ambitious schedule and not giving in on key issues bodes well for ultimate passage of modernization legislation," said Mark C. Brickell, a managing director of J. P. Morgan Securities.
Mr. Gramm called his bill "a major step toward changing the fundamental structure of financial services in America."
"It will greatly increase the kinds of services being offered to Americans," he told reporters during the final vote. "We have assured those services will not only be available, but will also be cheaper."
While the legislation would remove many obstacles now imposed on banks, insurance companies and securities houses, it would also reduce the role of the Treasury over new financial conglomerates and drastically scale back a 22-year-old law, the Community Reinvestment Act, that has encouraged billions of dollars in lending to inner cities, farmers and others.
For the last two decades, legislation to help modernize the banking system has had a perils-of-Pauline sort of story line, occasionally passing one chamber, only to fail in another, often because of the competing lobbying by the three powerful industries and struggles over authority among regulators.
While important policy issues remain to be resolved between Congress and the White House, many lobbyists predict that this will be the session when the lawmakers finally pass a more widely acceptable bill. Industries that have had many differences over the shape of the legislation are now largely in agreement.
"The industry groups have come out either supporting the bill or are neutral," Edward Yingling, chief lobbyist for the American Bankers Association, said. "We have been lobbying jointly with the insurance industry and the securities industry, often holding joint strategy sessions. That is really amazing, considering where we were a few years ago."
In part, the agreements have come because of legal loopholes and regulatory decisions that have punched wide gaps in the existing legal restrictions. Momentum for a new law has also grown as more financial conglomerates offer diversified services, from bank accounts to insurance, at separate affiliates.
In addition, the huge amount of money being raised by the interest groups for political campaigns has created a dynamic where no lawmaker wants to look like a spoiler. And the fact that the Senate and the House are moving so early in the legislative session suggests that compromises on the remaining disagreements can be reached in Congress.
Still, with no sign that either Mr. Gramm or Democrats in the House or the Administration will back down, the legislation could stall at any time.
Senate passage came after the White House, which has repeatedly been losing votes on the legislation, lost another vote today that had threatened to derail the bill. The Senate voted 53 to 46 to table an amendment endorsed by the White House and proposed by Senator Richard C. Shelby, Republican of Alabama, and by the Democratic leader, Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, that would have restored greater authority to the Treasury to regulate financial conglomerates.
The Shelby-Daschle amendment, which mirrored a provision in legislation that was passed by the House banking committee, would have permitted the new conglomerates created by the legislation to operate securities underwriting and merchant banking units as subsidiaries within the banks rather than as separate institutions under the umbrella of a bank holding company.
As such, it would have given a greater regulatory role to the Treasury, which now regulates banks with national charters, and would ultimately diminish the authority of the Federal Reserve, which has lobbied fiercely against the provision.
The Shelby-Daschle provision was at the center of a major policy debate and struggle for authority between Mr. Rubin and Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve.
Mr. Rubin has testified that the provision is essential because Treasury must have a regulatory role in order to formulate economic policy.
Mr. Greenspan has responded that by putting securities underwriting and merchant banking within a bank, large financial conglomerates would gain an unfair subsidy by having access to deposit insurance and the Federal clearinghouse system.
Seizing Mr. Greenspan's argument today, Mr. Gramm said that the Shelby-Daschle provision would politicize monetary policy.
"Do we really want a President to have the ability to use banking policy as a political tool?" he asked rhetorically. Transferring such authority to the Administration, he asserted, "would be a disaster for America."
To the consternation of many big banks and securities firms, Mr. Greenspan has also said that it would be better to have no bill than to have one that would permit banks to use operating subsidiaries to sell insurance and securities.
The Senate vote also followed the adoption of several other amendments. The Senators voted to create a law making it a crime for private investigators to call banks and pose as customers they are trying to investigate in order to get information about their accounts. They also approved a provision that would require all banks to post a schedule of fees at their automated teller machines.

SECTION: Section B; Page 1; Column 2; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 1425 words

HEADLINE: West Point Looks for Private Money to Improve Its Campus

BYLINE: By KAREN W. ARENSON

 BODY:
Forced to compete with increasingly wealthy universities while making do on a tight post-cold-war defense budget, the United States Military Academy at West Point today is announcing the first major private fund-raising campaign in the history of the service academies.
West Point, which gets nearly all its money from the Defense Department and gives full scholarships to every one of its 4,100 cadets, hopes to raise $150 million to endow professorships and to pay for amenities like improved athletic buildings and equipment. 
 "We have to make sure that West Point maintains itself as a tier one quality institution," said Lieut. Gen. Daniel W. Christman, who is West Point's Superintendent. He said that while the budget has remained roughly constant after inflation over many years, competition for the most desirable students has intensified.
"The other tier one schools we compete with are in the middle of what I describe to alumni as a war with each other -- for faculty, for modernization, for technology," he said. "We felt we could not go to Congress to ask for all of this. The reality -- and I've been around the Army 34 years -- is that we have rarely seen the fiscal constraints as tight as they have been."
The Army pays basic operating costs of about $175 million a year. But fund-raisers are quick to distinguish between "core needs," like the classes, military training and barracks essential for students working toward a bachelor's degree and military commission, and the extras that new money will pay for, like internships, expanded student recruitment and stadium viewing stands. Those extras are what General Christman and alumni leaders call "the margin of excellence."
In the two years of the quiet phase of the campaign, the period during which an institution approaches its best donors before announcing its campaign, West Point has raised nearly $100 million, including 19 gifts of $1 million or more.
In some ways, the fund-raising effort, formally named the Bicentennial Campaign because of West Point's 200th anniversary in 2002, is like any other university campaign.
It has the requisite wealthy alumni as co-chairmen, in this case Peter M. Dawkins (West Point '59), a Heisman Trophy winner and Rhodes scholar who is vice chairman of Citigroup's Travelers Insurance Company, and Dana G. Mead (West Point '57), a former White House Fellow and West Point professor who is now chairman and chief executive of Tenneco Corporation.
And it has the requisite contribution from an Internet baron: $7 million from Jim Kimsey (West Point '62), who led the first company of the 82d Airborne into the Dominican Republic in 1965 and 20 years later founded America Online.
But in critical ways, the campaign is unlike any other. For one thing, Federal employees are legally barred from asking for money from private donors, so the campaign is being run by West Point's alumni group, the Association of Graduates, with academy officials playing a supporting role.
Fund-raisers must also be cautious about corporate donations. Defense contractors would seem an obvious source of money, but alumni association officials are wary that such contributions could create a conflict of interest.
"We've always been very careful -- and the defense contractors have been very careful -- not to create a real or imagined quid pro quo, though we're not eliminating anyone," Mr. Mead said.
All contributions must be reviewed by Army lawyers at West Point or in Washington, said Lieut. Col. Michael W. Mahan, the alumni association's vice president for development. "It is sometimes an impediment to fund-raising," he added, "but the point is that there could be room for impropriety here and we have to take the time and effort to make sure that there isn't any."
Six companies, including Rockwell International, Lucent Technologies Microelectronics, and CAE Electronics, are on the preliminary list of 71 leadership donors to the campaign. Colonel Mahan said the biggest corporate gift so far is $1 million from MBNA America for a military ethics center.
The college must also be careful about how it attaches donor names to campus facilities, a standard perquisite for large contributors. "As with most public schools, we are trying to come up with tasteful naming opportunities," General Christman said. "But we do not put them in the main cadet areas so we don't modify the military ethos of the place."
The idea that West Point needs private money to supplement its public budget surprised General Christman when he signed on as Superintendent three years ago after serving as assistant to the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, General John M. Shalikashvili.
West Point, like the other service academies, has routinely accepted donations from its 45,000 alumni, but it had not cultivated them in the systematic way that other leading universities do. A good year meant about $5 million in donations, except when the alumni were raising money for a project, like a new alumni hall. Some private universities much larger than West Point take in hundreds of millions of dollars a year.
"We might have sent out a mailing once a year and had a few focused efforts to fund specific projects," Mr. Mead said.
Other service academies are either contemplating or planning similar campaigns. The Naval Academy in Annapolis, Md., said recently that it intended to begin a campaign but had not announced any specific goal of how much to raise. Richard M. Coppock, president of the alumni association at the Air Force Academy in Colorado, said yesterday that he expected it to do something similar.
West Point officials and alumni spent about a year discussing the possibility of a major fund-raising drive, how the money might be used and how much to seek. But it took time to convince alumni of the need.
"Most guys who have been to Vietnam feel, 'Hey, I gave at the office,' " said Mr. Kimsey, the America Online founder. He said he has been trying to persuade West Point friends to give. "This really is a sea change for them."
William P. McGoldrick, a former college development officer whose firm, Washburn & McGoldrick, was a consultant to West Point as it planned its campaign, said that the alumni are as passionate about their academy as those from colleges with the highest rates of giving, like Dartmouth and Williams, are about their alma maters.
The experience of attending West Point, including the first-year hazing program known as Beast Barracks, appears to have created a loyal alumni corps. In interviews with West Point alumni, Mr. McGoldrick said, many expressed strong affection for the institution. He recalled one who said, "Next to my wife, I love nothing more than West Point."
Mr. McGoldrick was also not expecting so many of the alumni to be wealthy. "In hindsight, we shouldn't have been surprised," he said, noting that although many West Point graduates stay in the military for 20 years or more, many others leave for careers in business. (In exchange for their free education, graduates must spend five years on active duty and three years in reserve.)
"Of the 52 individuals we interviewed, a third were chief executives, chief operating officers or chief financial officers at major U.S. corporations," Mr. McGoldrick said.
As in most college fund-raising, donors are giving money to projects that appeal to them. Mr. Mead, who holds a Ph.D. in political science and economics from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, said he was paying for four "Mead scholars" to work each summer in organizations like NATO, the United Nations or the Defense Department.
Mr. Dawkins, who was Captain of Cadets, senior class president and captain of the football team, is contributing $1 million toward a "vastly improved strength development center" for exercising.
"A steel bar and two coffee cans filled with cement is where I began," he said. But in his view, the academy needs the latest equipment, especially if it is to compete against heavily endowed football powerhouses.
"It is much more important for us than for a University of Michigan to have a world-class strength-development program," he said.
He and others contend that such extras are important to lure the strongest students possible.
"Many of us feel in our bones that the world is not going to get any less dangerous, and is not going to be any less in need of good leadership for the Army," Mr. Dawkins said. "So we should literally leave no stone unturned in trying to provide the very best."

LENGTH: 1613 words

HEADLINE: Looking to Prosper as a Melting Pot;
Utica, Long in Decline, Welcomes an Influx of Refugees

BYLINE: By PAUL ZIELBAUER

DATELINE: UTICA, N.Y., April 30

 BODY:
They have names like Pavel, Xuan and Fikret, and each has come here, to this defeated factory town in the heart of the Mohawk River Valley, for his or her own terrible reasons.
For Pavel Brutsky and his people, Pentecostal Christians from the former Soviet Union, it was to escape religious persecution and the plainclothes policemen who came knocking during prayer sessions in their homes. 
 For Xuan Vu, a 32-year-old Amerasian woman born in Saigon, it was to seek the freedom denied them by a country that treats the offspring of American servicemen with suffocating contempt.
And for Fikret Keserovic, an industrious chain smoker from the Bosnian town of Velika Kladusa, it was to build a life of peace and security in Utica after years of war and fear in the Balkans.
"Who is hard worker, like America," Mr. Keserovic, 47, who makes $10 an hour as a warehouse clerk, said in a rich Slavic accent, proud of the English he has learned in the two and a half years he has been here.
Taking a pull on a cigarette inside Restaurant Sani, still the only place in Utica with a Bosnia Burger, he added: "Everybody here friendly. I have new house, new truck. Why not like?"
Utica, a scrappy burg built on the sweat of Italian, Irish and Polish immigrants, is staking its future on newly arrived refugees from Bosnia, Belarus and Vietnam.
After a decadeslong drain of factory jobs and people -- the city's population, which was 125,000 in 1960, dropped to 92,000 by 1975 and is now down to 64,000 -- city officials and local business leaders believe these refugees, many of whom were skilled professionals in their native lands, are Utica's best chance for prosperity.
"I'm damn happy they're coming in," said Utica's Mayor, Edward A. Hannah, a millionaire businessman who was elected to help reinvent the city's economy. "I don't care where they come from. We've been complaining about people moving to the suburbs. Now we're getting some help."
In other parts of the country, such comments may seem off kilter, even anachronistic, as anti-immigration sentiment in Congress has cut down on the annual number of foreigners legally allowed in and street-level backlashes against immigrants have become more common.
But Utica is not the Texas Gulf Coast, where immigrant Vietnamese shrimpers have endured sabotage by their resentful American-born peers. Nor does Utica have the endemic racial tensions of South Central Los Angeles or Brooklyn, where animosity between Korean grocers and their black customers, for instance, has cost several lives.
Though racial problems exist, as black residents here grow increasingly sensitive to the perception that the refugees get preferential treatment in jobs and housing, Utica, with its 7.1 percent unemployment rate, about three points higher than the national average, could still use more immigrants.
In fact, as the specter of Kosovar Albanian refugees becomes a reality elsewhere, with thousands bound for relocation in New Jersey, Mayor Hannah sounded almost disappointed that Utica would not get a share. "I would encourage other towns in America to open your gates, open your arms," Mr. Hannah said. "We need them as much as they need us."
That notion has proven true for most of the 6,500 refugees who have settled here, giving Utica a 1-in-10 refugee population, one of the highest ratios in the United States. Most are either Bosnians who fled the ethnic Balkans war, deeply religious Belarussian Christians or Vietnamese who had spent years in squalid refugee camps in Hong Kong, Indonesia and Malaysia.
More are on the way; about 1,000 refugees a year are expected to resettle here, according to the Mohawk Valley Resource Center for Refugees, a nonprofit agency that since 1979 has been the starting point for refugees seeking homes, jobs, language and health care services.
To a city reeling from the loss of 23,000 jobs -- two General Electric plants, a Lockheed-Martin plant and Griffiss Air Force Base have all closed in recent years -- these immigrants, known for being inexpensive but tireless workers, are pillars of a new economy based on small service and manufacturing companies.
"The influx of refugees has helped those businesses grow and expand," said Bob Fowler, president of the Mohawk Valley Chamber of Commerce. "In 15 years, if this continues, this is going to be the melting pot of America."
Such a renaissance, economic and cultural, is still years away, and Utica is still a hurting city of empty storefronts. For now, the refugees remain largely unseen, living quietly on Utica's rougher east side and working mostly in low- or mid-level jobs at dozens of smaller businesses throughout the region.
"Life is better here," said Anton Brutsky, 76, a Belarussian refugee, lounging on the steps outside his two-story brick apartment building, one of several identical row houses where hundreds of Pentecostal Christians from Belarus, Russia, Latvia and other former Soviet republics now live as neighbors.
Mr. Brutsky, his wife, Yelena, and nine children arrived in Utica 10 years ago from Stolin, Belarus, after years of intimidation by the Soviet authorities. "When they caught Christians gathered together in my house, it didn't matter why," Mr. Brutsky said through an interpreter, "they would fine us $100. That's a month's salary."
In Utica, he and his countrymen worship freely and often, attending services four times a week in their own Slavic Pentecostal Church, a Russian-language church built nearby by Soviet refugees.
Utica's refugee communities rarely mix. The Vietnamese live on the outer fringe of Utica's social fabric, while the Slavic Pentecostals stick mostly to their steady diet of church, family and work. The Bosnians have become Utica's newest class of entrepreneurs and home buyers.
"The Bosnians are very Euro," said Judith H. Winfield, the director of community relations for the refugee center. "They've worked in Germany. English is not as difficult for them."
The five newest start-up businesses in Utica -- they have names like Hair Salon Goga, Disco Club Una and Restaurant Sani -- all have Bosnian refugee owners, thanks in no small part to a new microenterprise program, taught by a former Bosnian refugee from Rochester, that fosters entrepreneurial skills.
One of the program's current students, Sulejman Latic, turned an empty nail salon into the Karate Club Dragon in February. "Here in America you have many chances, you can do whatever you want," said Mr. Latic, a tall, affable black belt who spent four years in Rijeka, Croatia, after fleeing Bosnia in 1994. He now has 55 karate students.
"It's a small town," he added with a grin and an eager thumbs-up, "but I like it."
Perhaps to no one is the refugees' impact more obvious than to Joseph Carucci, the president of Prudential Carucci Real Estate, Utica's largest home-sales broker. A few years ago, after the exodus of newly unemployed residents, home values plunged, and he went begging for buyers of two- and three-bedroom Victorian-era homes, many of which sold for less than $30,000.
Then came the refugees, whose frugal ways and tireless work ethic have helped reinvigorate home sales. In February and March, for example, Utica real estate agents sold 109 homes, Mr. Carucci said, compared with 63 in the same period last year. He credits Utica's refugees for the increase, especially the Bosnians.
"These immigrants are so much more grateful to have an opportunity for ownership than our American people who take it for granted," Mr. Carucci said in an interview. "All of the values that the immigrants had 200 years ago are here."
Sanel Grozdanic, 23, the owner of Restaurant Sani, in Utica's all-but-abandoned Little Italy section, is typical of a growing number of young Bosnians here: energetic businessman, fluid in English and confident.
"Every day, another person is buying a house, every day," he said from behind his restaurant's three-stool bar, convinced that his business will take off when his liquor license arrives and his stock of imported Slovenian wine begins to flow.
Simmering most quietly in Utica's melting pot are the more than 1,000 refugees from Vietnam, mostly Amerasians and ethnic Khmers.
"Most people don't want to talk; they just want to work, want to make money," said Ms. Vu, sitting down for tea at the Hoai An cafe, which occupies the front room of the house she shares with her mother, husband and four children. She long ago gave up hope of finding her father, an American serviceman who left Saigon in 1972.
Already, there are indications that Utica's refugee communities are maturing into true ethnic enclaves. Two years ago, for example, after years of renting church space from local Methodists, the Soviet Christians built the Slavic Pentecostal Church on the city's outskirts. The church includes a private K-8 school, and there are plans to add 9th and 10th grades this fall.
The Bosnians, however, more than the other groups, have forged reputations as Utica's newest class of entrepreneurs. Slowly but steadily, Bosnians are repopulating Bleeker and Elizabeth Streets, in Utica's once buzzing Little Italy, where dozens of shuttered storefronts stand, darkened icons of a different era.
There are other, more subtle signs, too. A three-team Bosnian soccer league has sprouted on the fields of the local high school. Last September, Utica's first Miss Bosnia, Enisa Sabanajic, 18, proudly went on to the national competition in Chicago.
And just two weeks ago, three Bosnian men passed their citizenship tests, making them the first in their community to complete the full journey to become Americans.

HEADLINE: Suburbs Enter the Presidential Race

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "Two Parties Seek to Exploit a Relentless Boom in the Suburbs" (news article, May 4): The issue of sprawl doesn't concern only the growing numbers of Americans who live and work in suburbs. Sprawl should interest all who care about our country's endangered natural beauty and its shrinking economic and municipal diversity. Vice President Al Gore has the vision to see the logical outcome of today's trends: a devastating loss of open space, the hegemony of national retail franchises and the destruction of our towns and small cities by the cancerous growth of cheap and heedless roadside mall "development." 
 And Mr. Gore has had the courage to give the issue the importance it deserves, despite the self-important and self-interested sniping of those who trivialize the defense of our land.
 
JAMES C. FURLONG
Mystic, Conn., May 4, 1999

HEADLINE: Vouchers Offer a Chance

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re Bob Herbert's May 6 column criticizing Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's support of school vouchers: 
 As a graduate of New York City's schools and college systems, I know full well the benefits of what had been a quality school system. As standards declined, those New Yorkers who were financially able removed their children from public schools, either by moving to the suburbs or by sending their children to private schools. This left the city's public schools to the poor, particularly to disadvantaged minorities.
Why is it so terrible to give the parents of the poor and disadvantaged the option to have the same opportunity for their children that the more economically secure have had? Or is it better to continue to sacrifice children from poorer families to a lower quality of education because of a doctrinaire view of what public education should be -- but is not?
 
GERALD WALPIN
New York, May 6, 1999

LENGTH: 1798 words

HEADLINE: Thinkers Who Prefer to Be Free;
For Many Uneasy in Universities, Independence Is Worth the Cost

BYLINE: By JANNY SCOTT 

 BODY:
When Judith Rich Harris published an article in a scholarly journal a few years back and put the words "Middletown, New Jersey" in the space usually reserved for an author's academic affiliation, she found herself deluged with what she now calls her "who-the-hell-are-you mail."
Not only had she listed no university. She had not thanked any august-sounding grant-making agencies, either. She had simply credited half a dozen individuals, including one Charles S. Harris, who any half-alert reader might have guessed (correctly) is her husband. 
 "I got this E-mail from a professor at Cornell University," Ms. Harris recalled recently. He wanted to know: Are you an academic? A clinician? Or perhaps "an unemployed steelworker who has an interesting hobby of writing seminal scientific articles?"
None of the above.
Ms. Harris, who rocketed out of obscurity last year when she published "The Nurture Assumption" (Free Press, 1998), her joltingly unorthodox book crediting peers with greater influence than parents in a child's development, is a member of a little-known endangered subspecies of American intellectual known as the independent scholar.
In a country in which the academy has been accused of vaccuuming up all of intellectual life and processing it into something less deserving of the name, some scholars have traded the satisfactions and frustrations of colleges and universities for the mixed blessings of independence.
They are outsiders -- without titles, without tenure, without steady income. They have no letterhead, no lavish library privileges. As James Trilling, an independent scholar of Byzantine art studies and the history of ornament, said when asked about the drawbacks: "No colleagues. No students. No paycheck."
Yet they are free to think and write whatever, whenever and however they choose. They operate unencumbered by academic politics, protocol and publish-or-perish pressures. They straddle disciplines, elude specialization, follow their noses. For better or worse, their work is free to be unconventional and new.
"I had no vested interest in the status quo," Ms. Harris said of her book on child development. "Secondly, I had nobody to please. I didn't have to worry about offending the head of my department, about getting put in an office without a window, about being made to teach statistics."
"I see myself as a sort of gadfly," she said. "I think I'm in a much better position to criticize the field because I'm not a member of it."
The independents' reception by academics is not always warm.
The current issue of The New York Review of Books includes a letter signed by 29 academics complaining that the publication used Thomas Powers, best known as an author of books on politics and current affairs, to review several books about Crazy Horse, Sitting Bull and other 19th-century Plains Indians.
The New York Review's editors fire back that Mr. Powers had been studying those subjects for years. "It is hard to take seriously academics who condemn an independent scholar without making a single substantive criticism of his work," the editors retort.
One of the better-known independent scholars is Anne Hollander, an art historian whose subject is dress. She graduated from Barnard College in 1952, well before the advent of cultural studies. It was an era when the image of the clad figure was, she said recently, "not an appropriate art historical subject."
Instead of going to graduate school, she married an academic. She lived for years as an academic "fellow traveler" in places like New Haven and Cambridge, Mass., always thinking about and studying the representation of clothing in paintings and literature and cornering people at parties to talk about it.
Finally a friend persuaded her to write an article on the subject for a new journal. That led to a contract for her first book, "Seeing Through Clothes" (Viking, 1978), then a Guggenheim fellowship, a second book and her third and latest book, "Sex and Suits: The Evolution of Modern Dress" (Kodansha, 1995).
Dress is now a well-established subject for serious study. Ms. Hollander is about to publish her fourth book on the subject and is working on a fifth. She is in constant demand from journalists, who call asking questions that begin, "What does it mean that we are now wearing . . . ?"
Asked what she had forgone by not becoming an academic, she said, "What I did not have, and still feel nervous about, is an alma mater, an encompassing institution, the whole institution of the academy that supports all these guys and endorses their sorrows and their efforts and produces a network within which they can feel they have a perpetual identity that is theirs.
"I don't have a deep and abiding sense of myself as part of this dynamic organism. It means that every time I do anything I have to start from scratch. I have only my public and I have no idea who they are."
There was a time, not all that long ago, when autonomy was not odd. As Mr. Trilling points out, many of the great texts of the 19th and early 20th centuries were produced by people working outside the academy at the time, like John Ruskin, Charles Darwin and John Stuart Mill.
But as academia grew, autonomy waned. And many scholars who are unaffiliated today did not initially volunteer for the part. Some were in dual-career marriages, unable to move for a job; some came out of graduate school in the mid-1970's, just as the academic job market was crashing.
Yet many of them have one thing in common: they describe themselves as too ornery for academic life. They say their interests are too eclectic. They resist the degree of specialization they say is required of present-day professors. Some say they have no instinct for institutions.
Wendy Lesser, a critic, essayist and founding editor of the literary journal The Threepenny Review, drifted away from universities after getting a Ph.D. in English. While academia gave her her admiration for "impractical thought," she says, she would have made a poor academic.
In her new book, "The Amateur: An Independent Life of Letters" (Pantheon, 1999), she says she gradually discovered she was not much of a teacher, was "hapless" at dealing with departmental politics, made enemies left and right and wanted to kill most of her colleagues.
"Finally, if I had to give a single reason, I would say I wasn't suited to the academy because I wanted to exercise a kind of judgment that was not normal there," she writes. There seemed to be no room for the kind of "relatively untutored omnivorousness" she wanted and needed to practice.
"I didn't want to have arbitrary lines drawn between things: between old masterpieces and contemporary works, between art and the rest of the world, between criticism and conversation," she adds. "I wanted the whole terrain. And in my own tiny way, I got it."
Independence is not easy.
Ms. Lesser, who lives in Berkeley with her husband and son, rarely knows where her next year's income will come from. "The Amateur" is the first of her five books to generate more than $10,000. She has gotten fellowships ranging from $20,000 to $50,000 and does consulting and freelance writing.
Mr. Trilling, who got his Ph.D. in art history from Harvard and is the son of Lionel and Diana Trilling, gave up his job as a curator at the Textile Museum in Washington to live in Providence, R.I., with his wife, a tenured professor at Brown, who currently supports him and their two daughters.
He calls himself "the liberated parasite."
Others have day jobs. Neil Baldwin, who has published biographies of William Carlos Williams, Thomas Edison and Man Ray, spends his weeks as executive director of the National Book Foundation in New York City and his weekends working on his next book in his study at home in Montclair, N.J.
He can be found reading, say, Isaiah Berlin on an exercise bicycle at the Essex Health and Country Club in West Orange, N.J. In Worcester, Mass., Mr. Trilling, who has written books, monographs and articles on topics like the mosaic pavement of the Byzantine imperial palace in Constantinople, can be spotted in the balcony above the pool at the Y.M.C.A., scribbling notes while his daughter practices synchronized swimming.
Isolation can be a problem for many independent scholars. Mr. Trilling can go for months without speaking to a colleague. Except when he attends conferences or lectures, he is cut off from the shop talk and everyday sharing of ideas that are a feature of university life.
But the hardest part, he said, is having no students. He has far more ideas than he will ever have time to develop into articles or books, but he has no students to pass them on to. At the end of his career, he will be unable to survey the landscape and take stock of where his former students have gone.
"Students are a measure of your career," he said recently in his house in Providence, settled in the basement office he shares with a large pet snake. "That's never going to be so for me. Teachers live on through their students, as well as through their published work."
Ms. Harris, who says she was "kicked out of Harvard" as a graduate student in psychology in 1961, having been told she seemed unlikely to do important work, wrote psychology textbooks for many years, then one day hit upon the theory that became the central idea of her paper and book.
Because she suffers from a combination of autoimmune diseases, she rarely leaves her house. She has gone entire months without seeing anyone but her husband and a friend who cleans the house. She is an energetic user of E-mail, maintaining a voluminous correspondence with academics she has never met.
To keep up with developments in her field, she subscribes to journals and fires off printed postcards asking researchers for reprints of their papers. She has relied so heavily on interlibrary loans, she ended up thanking the librarians in Middletown and Red Bank, N.J., in the preface to her book.
Other independent scholars use their alumni borrowing privileges -- or their spouses' -- to get access to university libraries. Some follow a piece of advice once offered in a newsletter published by a group called the National Coalition of Independent Scholars: "Get a nonposition."
Joan Cassell, an anthropologist in St. Louis, acquired the title of "research associate" from Washington University, solving both the library problem and what she calls "the name tag problem" of people's eyes glazing over as they read her name tag at meetings and look past her for someone more important.
So, are they contented?
"Who's contented?" Ms. Lesser recalls having answered when asked about her state of mind while on a book tour recently. "You're dead if you're contented. Nothing is perfect."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Thais Angrily Blaming U.S. For Deadlock on Trade Post

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS 

DATELINE: BANGKOK, Thailand, May 7

 BODY:
Protesters shouted at the gates of the United States Embassy today, voicing a growing wave of anger here that was summed up the other day by Prime Minister Chuan Leekpai: Something fishy is going on.
Seemingly out of nowhere, a surge of anti-Americanism has gripped some Thais over the opposition by Washington to the candidacy of Supachai Panitchpakdi, a Deputy Prime Minister and Commerce Minister, to lead the World Trade Organization. 
 Public figures have been announcing that they will boycott the Fourth of July reception at the embassy. In addition, a number of leading politicians have called for a reassessment of Thailand's friendly ties with the United States.
Mr. Supachai, 52, has been on the front lines of the struggle for economic revival by Thailand, the birthplace of the Asian financial crisis nearly two years ago. He is a finalist to become the new Director General of the trade organization, the 134-nation group that makes the rules of global trade, and he is widely viewed as a voice for Asia and developing nations.
But an opposing camp, led by the United States, has formed around the candidacy of Mike Moore, the former Prime Minister of New Zealand.
Negotiations to pick one of them have been deadlocked in heated debate at the trade organization's Geneva headquarters since last Saturday, when the four-year term of the incumbent Director General, Renato Ruggiero of Italy, expired.
The absence of a leader at the organization is imperiling a new round of trade talks scheduled to start Nov. 30.
"This institution will stop," said Rita Hayes, the American representative in Geneva. "It will completely stop until we have a new Director General."
An attempt last week by Ali Mchumo, chairman of the organization's General Council, to break the impasse seems only to have inflamed Mr. Supachai's supporters.
Mr. Mchumo said he had determined that Mr. Moore had the support of 62 countries, versus 59 for Mr. Supachai, and that therefore Mr. Supachai should quit the race. Mr. Mchumo's calculation did not take into account 13 countries whose preferences were not determined.
Thai officials were outraged, and said the United States was responsible for what they called a conspiracy against their candidate. Calls for retaliation intensified.
"The lesson of the W.T.O. selection is that it's time we reviewed our foreign policy with all countries, especially the United States, which say that they are our true friends," said the Senate Speaker, Meechai Ruchupan, this week. "We have to see who are our real friends and who are our real enemies. In the present world every country must have claws of its own, and that's not just in terms of arms but also strategy."
Noppadol Pattama, a member of Parliament's foreign affairs committee, went further, saying, "We might need to turn more to the European Union, Japan and China, which will increase our balance of power."
Even Mr. Chuan alluded to a "dirty tricks" campaign against the Thai candidate and said there was "something fishy going on" in the selection process.
This was a reference to a widespread sense here that Washington had been orchestrating an undeclared backstage campaign to undermine Thai interests. Officials here say the United States, despite its denials, has exercised a "secret veto" against Mr. Supachai, whom Washington might regard as insufficiently committed to free trade.
In a front-page editorial, the English-language daily The Nation crystallized the resentment. The editorial accused the United States of "betting on Moore's candidacy to fulfill its hegemonistic aspiration after having flexed its muscles in other world organizations like the United Nations, World Bank and International Monetary Fund."
After the crash of the Thai currency, the baht, in July 1997, the I.M.F. produced a $17 billion rescue package for Thailand that like the packages for other nations has resulted in painful economic austerity. Critics here have complained that these new economic policies have sacrificed the welfare of ordinary people to that of the banks.
The critics have also complained that the United States offered only limited aid to Thailand, particularly in the early days of the crisis.
"It's different strands intertwined together," said Ji Ungpakorn, a political scientist at Chulalongkorn University. "It's the I.M.F. involvement in the economy and also the move to privatize state industries that have set off a nationalistic response. That's starting to cause a current of anti-Americanism."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Favorable Jobless News Pushes Dow to Another Record

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The Dow Jones industrial average climbed to yet another record high yesterday after the closely watched employment report for April soothed Wall Street's fears about inflation.
The Dow closed up 84.77 points, or eight-tenths of 1 percent, at 11,031.59, beating the May 3 high of 11,014.69. For the week, the Dow was up 242.55 points. 
 The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 12.95 points, or 1 percent, to 1,345.00, yesterday, and the technology-heavy Nasdaq composite index jumped 31.34 points, or 1.27 percent, to 2,503.62.
The Labor Department reported that the number of workers on the nation's payrolls outside the farm sector increased by 234,000 in April and the unemployment rate hovered at a 29-year low of 4.3 percent, providing more evidence that the nation's economy is creating jobs at a healthy pace. Wage pressures were also muted.
Analysts had expected 230,000 new jobs and an unchanged jobless rate of 4.2 percent.
The Labor Department also said average hourly earnings, a closely watched gauge of wage levels that could presage inflation pressures, increased by only 3 cents, to $13.11 in April.
Thom Brown, managing director at Rutherford, Brown & Catherwood, said the numbers "took big worries off Wall Street's back."
"The 4.3 percent rate is good news for the bond and stock market," Mr. Brown said.
On Thursday, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, Alan Greenspan, rattled financial markets after warning of inflationary pressures. Mr. Greenspan did not say the Fed would raise interest rates, but his comments put Wall Street on guard as bond yields marched higher.
"There's been a slight deterioration in psychology," Trude Latimer, an independent stockbroker in Charlottesville, Va., said. "The traders are getting nervous."
Referring to Mr. Greenspan's speech, Ms. Latimer added, "Some of the comments from the reigning geniuses are a little more cautious."
Meanwhile, gold stocks fell after the price of bullion plunged $7 an ounce after Britain announced it had decided to sell more than half its gold reserves.
South African gold companies condemned Britain's decision, calling the move "inept" and warning that it would encourage speculators and hurt producers who have struggled with dismal prices for the last 18 months.
"This is a classic bull and bear fight," Doug Myers, vice president of equity trade at Wachovia Securities, said.
"You've got a good underlying economy, but then you've got conflicting signals about valuations," he said. "You total all these things and you've got question marks and conflicting views."
Analysts said strength in the technology sector reflected relief that the jobs report did not fan inflation fears. High-growth stocks are viewed as particularly vulnerable to inflation.
"If the report had made it clear that the Fed would have to move to a higher interest rate environment, the techs would be reacting differently," Peter Coolidge, senior equity trader at Brean Murray & Company, said.
I.B.M. jumped 8, to 217 1/4. Microsoft rose 1 1/8, to 79 1/16, and Intel was up 1 1/4, to 60 15/16.
Newport News Shipbuilding rose 5 3/4, to 32 3/4, and Avondale Industries gained 4 5/16, to 36 1/16, after Litton Industries announced unsolicited bids totaling $1.8 billion for the two companies. Litton was off 1 5/8, to 63 1/8.
McDermott International gained 2 5/16, to 30 1/4, on news that it was buying all of the shares of its subsidiary, J. Ray McDermott S.A., whose stock jumped 4 3/4, to 35 1/4.

Treasury Issues Decline
 By Bloomberg News
Treasury bond prices fell as traders fretted that next week's quarterly Government debt sales will overwhelm demand.
"People don't feel a need to rush to buy," given that the Treasury will sell $27 billion of five-year and 10-year notes in coming days, said John Burgess, who oversees more than $90 billion at Bankers Trust Global Investment Management.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 11/32, to 9 24/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 5.81 percent, from 5.78 percent on Thursday.

HEADLINE: Britain Plans To Sell 58% Of Its Bullion

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL 

DATELINE: LONDON, May 7

 BODY:
Britain surprised world financial markets today by announcing it would sell more than half the country's bullion reserves, a move that further eroded the value of what was once the safest and strongest measure of wealth.
Gold prices, which have languished for years at roughly a third of their all-time high in 1980, tumbled as much as 4 percent after the British Treasury said it would sell 415 tons of its 715-ton stockpile and put the proceeds into other types of investments. Share prices in some big gold mining companies took the biggest drop in more than decade and contributed to weakness in the stock markets of South Africa and Canada, two leading gold producers. 
 The announcement was viewed as a maneuver by the British to pre-empt other big holders of gold, notably Switzerland and the International Monetary Fund, which have both indicated they will sell part of their huge gold reserves. Industry experts said the British wanted to sell their gold earlier to get the best price.
But the broader significance of Britain's announcement was that it drove a new dagger into gold's lingering status as a precious asset in an era of fast-paced economic globalization. Although gold has important industrial uses, from jewelry to air-bag seams, it is simply no longer regarded as an investment that retains underlying value.
Even the World Gold Council, a trade group that represents big mining companies, called it inevitable that Britain's announcement would be taken as "further evidence of official disenchantment with gold as a reserve asset."
In London, gold ended down $6.70 an ounce, or 2.3 percent, to $282.85, the biggest one-day decline in more than a year. In New York, gold fell $6.80, to $282.90.
For a long time, gold provided the spine of the global financial system, serving as a common measure for countries to value their currencies and the strength of their economies. At its peak, gold was the asset that backed 59 currencies, including the dollar, and the central banks of many nations hoarded stockpiles of gold. But the so-called gold standard was abandoned in the early 1970's, as national economies moved away from basing the value of their currencies on the metal.
"Ever since then, there's been a general tendency for the role of gold to be de-emphasized," said Phillip Klapwijk of Gold Fields Mineral Services, a leading industry analyst.
The end of the gold standard did not immediately hurt gold's glitter. On the contrary, it was still widely viewed as a resilient investment and a hedge against inflation, which helped to drive the price to an all-time high of $873 an ounce in 1980.
But it has basically been eroding in value ever since, and its allure as an inflation protection is now widely considered an anachronism. In some ways the dollar, as the most widely circulated currency in the world, has replaced gold as a measure of value.
Gold has notably failed to keep pace with many types of investments, notably stocks. An ounce of gold invested at its peak in the Dow Jones industrial average, for example, would now be worth $11,031.59, not including dividends. That's nearly 38 times higher than gold's present price.
Gold Fields Mineral Services forecast last month that the price could range between $265 and $305 an ounce for some time, Mr. Klapwijk said.
Britain is not the first central bank to sell gold. Indeed, one of the main pressures on gold in recent years has come from sales by other central banks, which totaled 412 tons last year, compared with 376 tons in 1997. But the timing and size of the British announcement today caught the gold market by surprise.
The British Treasury said through a spokesman that the sale would reduce Britain's stockpile from 715 tons to 300 tons over the next several years in what he termed a "measured and phased program." The proceeds will go into United States, European and Japanese bonds.
Starting July 6, Britain's gold is to be auctioned in 25-ton lots to dispose of 125 tons a year.
Even though gold's allure has diminished, there's still plenty of it around. Above-ground gold stocks total 137,400 tons -- including 31,400 tons in official reserves -- compared with annual demand largely from the jewelry trade of 4,123 tons, according to Gold Fields Mineral Services. Gary Mead, head of research at the World Gold Council, said the annual demand was 1,000 tons more than mining output.
"In terms of volume," he said, the projected British sale was not significant. "But in terms of psychology and sentiment, it's negative if it is interpreted by the market as a further indication that central banks are no longer interested in reserve assets."
The biggest uncertainty has come from Switzerland and the International Monetary Fund. Last month, Swiss voters in a referendum approved plans to end a formal, constitutional link between the Swiss franc and gold reserves, freeing the Swiss National Bank to sell up to half its 2,600-ton holdings. The I.M.F. is considering selling up to 10 percent of its gold reserves -- 322 tons -- to finance debt relief in developing countries, which would be the first gold sale by the lending agency in two decades.
One of the biggest immediate impacts of the British announcement was a plunge in the stocks of gold mining companies. In South Africa, shares of Anglogold Ltd., the world's biggest gold producer, fell 4.5 percent, and the Johannesburg stock exchange's 16-member index of gold companies fell 4.6 percent. Anglogold is a unit of the Anglo American Corporation. Shares in the Newmont Mining Corporation of Denver, the No. 2 mining company, fell 13 percent on the New York Stock Exchange. The Toronto Stock Exchange's 22-member index of gold companies fell 11 percent, its biggest one-day drop in almost 12 years.
One element in the timing of the British announcement may well have been Britain's independence from the 11 European Union nations that have been bound by their single currency, the euro, and single central bank since January.
The European Central Bank itself has not broached the idea of selling off European gold deposits for fear of weakening the euro, analysts said. "This does give an opportunity for those outside the system to make sales," Mr. Klapwijk said. British officials said the sales would not affect Britain's ability to deposit its required amount of 140 tons at the European Central Bank if it were to decide to join the euro sometime early in the next century.
