HEADLINE: Pay the Legislators

 BODY:
Few New Yorkers are shedding tears for the State Legislature, whose members have not been paid in more than a month. The lawmakers have only themselves to blame. In order to get a pay raise from $57,500 to $79,500 last December, they agreed to have their paychecks withheld in each new fiscal year until they finally passed a budget. The pay freeze, demanded by Gov. George Pataki as the price for not vetoing the pay raise, has failed to work any magic. The budget, which is supposed to be passed April 1, is late for the 15th year in a row. But the idea of withholding pay was bad in principle and should be abandoned.
No one would defend the sorry succession of budget impasses and delays that have played havoc with state finances and the finances of local governments dependent on state aid. But withholding the pay of lawmakers, and not of the Governor or any other statewide elected officials, distorts the balance between the legislative and executive branches. In any budgetary standoff the legislators will be under economic pressure to cave, whereas the Governor will not. Even though 14 Assembly Democrats who have challenged the pay freeze in a lawsuit insist they would never vote for an unpalatable budget in order to get paid, the whole purpose of the law was to coerce a budget agreement. It is not acceptable for such pressure to fall unevenly on the legislators, some of whom may face tight economic circumstances. 
 Both the Democratic-controlled Assembly and Republican-controlled Senate have passed their own versions of the budget this year. Democrats favor more spending for education and health programs than either Mr. Pataki or the Republicans in the Legislature. The impasse is as deep as anyone in Albany can remember, with some legislators fearing openly that the state might limp along without a budget for a whole year.
Since the stalemate has as much to do with political advantage as principle, it is not easy to think of incentives to force a meeting of the minds. The poisonous atmosphere in Albany in recent years has aggravated these confrontations, and everyone has been understandably searching for something, anything, that might force a compromise. But freezing the lawmakers' pay is not the answer.
Instead, the Legislature could change the law to require that no state operations can go forward without an overall budget. They could tie passage of the budget to the issuing of new debt obligations, a step that might force legislators to act. They could take some of the acrimony out of the process by opening it up, mandating committee hearings and conference committee meetings, or setting up a nonpartisan panel to make spending and revenue estimates. These steps would go a long way toward instilling a sense of responsibility in Albany. Docking legislators' pay is the wrong way to do it.

HEADLINE: Cuba Cooperating to Combat Drug Trade, U.S. Official Says

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 7

 BODY:
Cuba is not involved in drug trafficking and is cooperating with the United States in fighting the illegal trade in the Caribbean, the top American anti-drug official said today.
The White House's drug policy director, Gen. Barry McCaffrey, said Cuba, located in the middle of the drug route from South to North America, was very interested in discussing the issue with Washington, which has not had diplomatic ties with Havana since 1961. 
 "That dialogue might produce something useful, and we probably ought to be willing to encourage it," the retired general told scholars at the Woodrow Wilson Center, an international affairs institute.
"Poor Cuba. Location puts it in the path of international drug crime," he later told reporters. "But I do not see any serious evidence, current or in the last decade, of Cuban Government overt complicity with drug crime."
General McCaffrey said Cuban authorities had continued to maintain contacts with the Coast Guard and had responded positively to drug-related intelligence provided by the United States.
"I don't think they want Colombian drug criminals inside Cuba," said General McCaffrey, the former chief of the United States Southern Command.
Still, there is a lot of cocaine showing up on the island, the American anti-drug official said. Traffickers moving up the Caribbean from Colombia fly over the island and dump cocaine shipments in the sea off the north coast of Cuba for pickup by boats that smuggle the drug into the United States via the Bahamas, General McCaffrey said.
But Cuba lacks the "radar and intercept capabilities" to stop it, he said. Cuba cannot even effectively police its waters, where smugglers hide after fishing bales of cocaine from the sea, he said.
"It's a big problem and it is growing," he said.
General McCaffrey said Cuba wanted to cooperate with Washington on the drug problem as a way of opening a dialogue -- a sensitive initiative, particularly among Cuban-Americans opposed to relaxing the 37-year-old economic embargo on President Fidel Castro's Government.
But General McCaffrey said the United States must look to the future, when Cuba could become a major drug-trafficking center unless cooperation with Cuban authorities begins now.
"Cuba will not remain a collapsing Communist dictatorship with a goofy economic system much longer," he said. "Eventually it is going to be another economic center in the hemisphere, so we clearly don't want international drug crime dominating Cuba."

HEADLINE: More Groups Are Sharing In Job Growth

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR 

 BODY:
America's jobs boom is increasingly pulling many of the nation's most vulnerable citizens out of poverty and unemployment.
In April, the national economy added, on a net basis, nearly a quarter of a million new jobs despite continued losses in manufacturing and farming, the Labor Department reported yesterday. Last month's unemployment rate was 4.3 percent -- statistically indistinguishable from its 30-year low of 4.2 percent in March. (All numbers are adjusted to take account of expected seasonal ups and downs.) 
 The unemployment rate has now been at or below 4.5 percent for slightly more than a year and at or below 5 percent for a full two years.
Investors, who were a bit rattled on Thursday by a warning from the Federal Reserve's chairman, Alan Greenspan, that the tight labor market still posed an inflation threat, generally took the strong April job growth in stride. That was mostly because the report showed no signs that wages were accelerating. But after an initial gain in the bond market, prices fell, and the yield on the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond rose to 5.81 percent. Stocks gained, with the Dow industrial average up 84.77, to 11,031.59. Page B3.
The most striking feature of yesterday's report was how broadly the benefits of economic growth are being spread. Joblessness among workers who have long suffered the highest unemployment rates continued to decline.
Unemployment among blacks, already at historic lows, dropped to 7.7 percent. Teen-age unemployment declined to 14.1 percent. But joblessness among Hispanic workers -- a diverse group that spans affluent third-generation Americans as well as impoverished new immigrants -- bumped up from the record low set in March. Still, at 6.9 percent, the Hispanic rate remains lower than at almost any time in the last 25 years.
"We're seeing large gains by the most disadvantaged groups," said Rebecca Blank, a member of the White House's Council of Economic Advisers and an expert on poverty.
Today, nearly half of Americans live in cities and towns where the unemployment rate has dropped below 4 percent, according to a new study published by the National Bureau of Economic Research. In these "high pressure" local economies, the employment and incomes of the most disadvantaged -- the young, those who have only a high school degree or less, and minorities -- have jumped, said Richard Freeman at Harvard, one of the study's authors.
Growth that is shared by most Americans has not been the norm since the economic Golden Age that followed World War II from the late 1940's to the early 1970's. Back then, rapid economic growth had a powerful effect on the fortunes of America's poorest citizens, prompting Arthur M. Okun, President Lyndon B. Johnson's chief economic adviser, to assert that a rising tide lifts all boats. But that soon changed, when the Arab oil shock and the collapse of the Bretton Woods system of stable currency exchange rates ushered in an era of high inflation, widening inequality and stagnant wages.
Even in the long, strong boom of the 1980's, when 20 million new jobs were created, poverty barely fell, and many of America's working poor, particularly less-educated men, wound up becoming poorer.
But today there are a host of signs that the gains from economic growth are once again being spread around. "The 90's are starting to look a lot like the 60's," said Lawrence Katz, a labor economist at Harvard.
Investment bankers, basketball stars and computer whizzes -- those at the very top of the pay scale -- are still doing great, just as they did in the 80's. What has changed is that they are no longer alone. "Inequality hasn't necessarily diminished, but we seem to be in a world where the bottom and top are rising together," Dr. Blank said. "That's a very different world."
What makes the 90's different from the 80's? Two things, the experts say. First, the current expansion, which began with the unemployment rate slightly above 7 percent, compared with a double-digit jobless rate in the early 1980's, has lasted longer and has pushed the unemployment rate even lower than at the end of the 1980's expansion. Second, for the last three years or so, wages for workers at the bottom of the pay scale have been rising rapidly. In the 1980's, declining pay at the lower rungs of the wage scale offset the positive effects of robust job growth.
"You're not just getting more job opportunities, but rising wages," Dr. Blank said.
According to the Economic Policy Institute in Washington, a worker whose pay put him one-fifth the way up the wage-distribution ladder earned $7.11 an hour in 1986 but only $6.66 in 1996. By this spring, that figure had climbed to $7.17 an hour. (All the figures are in 1998 dollars and take inflation into account.)
Those gains have helped fuel a spree of consumer spending and borrowing in the last year or so. But in March, Americans reined in a bit, with consumer credit expanding by just $1.6 billion, well below the $8.7 billion jump in February. Credit card debt actually shrank, but borrowing to buy cars rose $3.8 billion.
To be sure, not everything is rosy on the job front. The nation's factories shed another 29,000 jobs last month, bringing the total number of manufacturing jobs lost since the beginning of the global financial crisis to 400,000. But increasingly well-paying service jobs more than made up that loss. Last month, service industries created 261,000 additional jobs. In the last year, they have added 2.8 million jobs while the number of construction jobs has grown by 300,000.
"We're not going back to the days when the economy was creating jobs that called for easily acquired, modest skills," said Kevin Murphy, a labor economist at the University of Chicago.
Still, the old relationship between economic growth and a reduction in poverty seems to have been restored -- at least for now. According to calculations by Professor Katz, between 1983 and 1990, poverty fell by just 1.7 percentage points, less than half what would have been predicted based on the pattern that existed in the 1960's and 1970's. By contrast, between 1993 and 1997 (the last year for which poverty figures are available) the percentage of households in poverty has declined by 2.6 percentage points, more than in the entire 1980's and right in line with the old pattern. (The numbers include income from the earned-income tax credit.)
Low unemployment is good for newcomers to the labor force like women and teen-agers and those at the bottom of the pay scale. When the labor market tightens, people who are out of work or are jumping in for the first time get jobs. Part-time workers get full-time jobs. And those in dead-end jobs find better ones and have a chance to acquire more experience and skills.
Most important, Professor Katz said, "a lot of people in inner cities are developing connections to the job market that had broken down." One reason is that temporary-help companies may be making it easier for the least-experienced, least-skilled workers to get experience and training. And falling unemployment also seems to be reinforcing the trend toward less criminal activity, which has long clouded the job prospects of minority youths, Professor Freeman at Harvard said.
A shift in antipoverty policies, limiting welfare and linking aid, such as the earned-income tax credit, to work, is also a factor. "Policy reinforced what was happening in the marketplace," Dr. Blank said. From 1989 to 1997, the average income of single mothers, with two children, who worked full time jumped 42 percent, to $13,956, which is 8 percent above the official poverty line.
It is too early to predict whether the benefits of the 90's boom will survive the next recession. Until then, however, America's tight labor market is creating opportunities for those who stand to benefit most.

HEADLINE: CRISIS IN THE BALKANS: THE BLOCKADE;
Among Allies, Doubts and Disagreement on Oil Embargo

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY 

DATELINE: BRUSSELS, May 7

 BODY:
The bark of NATO's planned naval blockade of oil deliveries to Yugoslavia may be worse than its bite, allied diplomats said today.
Leading the legal charge against the blockade that was wanted by NATO's American commander, France has apparently persuaded most allies that there is no basis in international law for allied warships to challenge ships of countries that have not declared war against Yugoslavia. 
 Further, the French argue, there is no United Nations embargo against Yugoslavia barring fuel shipments. They have rejected American arguments that a ban on importing war materials provides justification enough.
As a result, allied political authorities sent instructions today to their military colleagues at NATO headquarters to devise a different kind of "visit and search" system, one that would use psychology rather than force to dissuade merchant ships from trying to run oil, gasoline, and other fuels into Bar, the main Yugoslav port in Montenegro.
Montenegro, which with Serbia is a constituent part of Yugoslavia, has opposed President Slobodan Milosevic's operations against Albanian civilians in Kosovo.
This week, officials in Bar said Mr. Milosevic had ordered the navy to block shipping into the port.
But allied commanders say ships flying flags of opportunity occasionally do make runs into Bar, so the NATO commander, Gen. Wesley K. Clark, wanted a full-fledged blockade. Instead, the French suggest, NATO ships should be empowered to board ships of allied and European countries that have declared a ban on fuel shipments into Yugoslavia, just to check that any vessels heading into Bar are carrying no fuel.
"The Americans argued that this was ridiculous, because we'd only be checking on shipping that had already agreed not to bring in fuel," one European diplomat reported.
But the French contend that a voluntary or cooperative blockade is better than none at all and that getting an allied naval inspection system up and running could scare or shame would-be violators out of trying to run the blockade.
Jamie P. Shea, the NATO spokesman, said today that the 15-nation European Union had proposed that ships flying its flags could agree to be boarded by naval inspectors from fellow European countries. Other countries that had decided to stop oil shipments would be invited to do so as well, he said.
"Our intention is to have an effective, comprehensive visit and search regime," he said. "We're off to a good start."
Greece was insisting, one allied diplomat in Brussels said today, that none of its merchant ships could be boarded by Turkish naval inspectors. Greece and Turkey are united both by membership in NATO and by a cordial dislike of one another.
Allied diplomats said today they expected that the new system, if approved, could go into effect as early as next week.

HEADLINE: Democrats Try to Turn Focus Toward New Jersey Assembly Campaigns

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: ATLANTIC CITY, May 7

 BODY:
The prevailing message of the New Jersey Democratic Party's annual conference in this fog-blanketed casino town today was conveyed succinctly in the blue-and-red stickers that almost everyone seemed to be wearing: "It's the Assembly, stupid!"
In a year when many of the state's political leaders are already focusing n the United States Senate race in 2000 and the gubernatorial campaign of 2001, a growing number of Democrats are worried that 1999's state Assembly races are getting lost in the shuffle. 
 Many party leaders say that this year may offer Democrats their best opportunity to retake the Assembly since the Republicans gained the majority in 1991. Needing to pick up nine seats to win control of the 80-member lower house, the Democrats assert that issues like racial profiling by the state police as well as high property taxes and automobile insurance rates are severely undermining the Republicans' support.
But intraparty squabbling over picking a Senate candidate and jockeying over the governor's race, combined with news media attention to both, are making it difficult for Democrats to raise money, organize support and attract publicity for Assembly candidates, several party leaders said today.
"From my point of view, I couldn't care about the Senate candidates," said Assemblyman Joseph V. Doria Jr., the Democratic minority leader. "The whole thing is creating a distraction. And by discussing the Senate race all the time, we're not getting the attention for candidates who would not have an easy time getting attention to begin with."
Representative William J. Pascrell Jr., a Democrat from Paterson, said, "Until we can shift back to 1999, and out of this time warp of 2000 and 2001, we won't do well this year."
Thomas P. Giblin, the state party chairman, said it has become difficult to raise money for Assembly candidates because Vice President Al Gore and former Senator Bill Bradley are both raising money aggressively in New Jersey for their presidential campaigns, while Representative Frank Pallone Jr. of Long Branch and former Gov. Jim Florio are appealing to Democratic donors for next year's Senate race.
Amid such concerns, the state party structured much of this two-day conference around spotlighting its Assembly candidates, featuring them on panels, introducing many of them at today's luncheon and festooning the Trump Plaza banquet hall with "Assembly 1999" banners.
But it was still impossible to escape the noise of the Senate race, as three potential candidates to replace Senator Frank R. Lautenberg, the three-term Democrat who is retiring next year, used today's event as a coming-out party of sorts.
At the local Planet Hollywood, Mr. Pallone was the host of a party for the conventioneers that cost $15,000. Mr. Florio took a suite in the Trump Plaza, where he met with county leaders, fund-raisers and reporters throughout the day.
And Jon S. Corzine, a Summit resident and the former chairman of Goldman, Sachs & Company, contributed $3,000 to the convention and spent much of the evening shaking hands and introducing himself to rank-and-file party members, the vast majority of whom have only the faintest idea of who he is.
Even Mr. Bradley got into the act, joking during his keynote speech, "I'm one of the few speakers here at the conference who is not running for the United States Senate."
Mr. Florio was perhaps the most visible of the Senate candidates, working the crowd vigorously and giving interviews to reporters in which he blasted Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's fiscal policies and handling of the racial profiling issue.
Mrs. Whitman, who unseated Mr. Florio in a close 1993 election, has said she plans to seek the Republican nomination for Senate next year.
Defending his decision as Governor to raise taxes, Mr. Florio attacked Mrs. Whitman for allowing the state debt to increase despite the strong economy, saying: "I did what came naturally -- I went and paid the bills. I contrast that with what has happened over the last five years, in which she has not been paying any bills."
But paradoxically, many Assembly Democrats blame Mr. Florio's tax increase for putting them in the minority in 1991. So while the former Governor enjoys strong support in some Democratic circles, there was also grumbling today that his candidacy could weaken the party's chances of retaking the Assembly this year.
Mr. Florio said such concerns were unfounded, adding that the only thing that would keep him from running in the Senate primary would be a heart attack.
In New Jersey politics, all races seem interconnected, and many Democrats argued today that picking up Assembly seats this year, as well as taking the Senate race next year, are essential to winning the big prize: the governor's seat in 2001.
"We need a sense of immediacy," said Mayor James E. McGreevey of Woodbridge, who came within 27,000 votes of unseating Mrs. Whitman in 1997 and is considered the party's front-runner for governor in 2001. "Increasing our Assembly seats gives us the structure to get out the party's message on education, auto insurance and property taxes."

HEADLINE: Head of City Development Agency Resigns to Work for Prudential

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
Charles Millard, a top adviser to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani who has been president of the city's Economic Development Corporation since 1995, said yesterday that he was resigning to accept a position as a managing director at Prudential Securities.
Mr. Millard, 42, a lawyer who was on the New York City Council from 1991 to 1995, and has been widely considered a contender for higher elective office, is to leave his job at City Hall on June 1. Michael Carey, first executive vice president of the Economic Development Corporation, will then become its acting president. 
 Mr. Millard, who has five children, said his move was motivated in part by the chance to make more money than his $138,000 annual city salary.
"Charlie has been part of this administration's success," said Mr. Giuliani yesterday at a press conference. He credited Mr. Millard, whose job as head of the city's principal development agency entails devising incentives to attract and retain business, with contributing to the city's strong job growth and helping retain large employers like the New York Stock Exchange.
Another of Mr. Millard's efforts at City Hall has been to foster the growth of small high-technology firms as part of Manhattan's burgeoning Silicon Alley complex.
In announcing his appointment, Prudential Securities said Mr. Millard would head a recently formed Internet Economy Group, drawing upon his experience with start-up companies.
Prudential Securities said Mr. Millard would also be responsible for developing business in real estate finance, and would retain a working relationship with City Hall.
"We look forward to adding his unique experiences and legacy of service to the New York business community to the expertise we offer our clients," said Paul V. Scura, Prudential Securities' executive vice president and chief of investment banking.
Mr. Millard, a resident of Forest Hills, Queens, would not say how much he would earn at Prudential Securities.
"It has been a great run with the city, but with five kids to take care, of an opportunity like this one at Prudential is something not to be passed up," he said.

HEADLINE: About New York;
Bronx Roots Still Nurture Career Paths

BYLINE: By DAVID GONZALEZ 

 BODY:
WHEN Louis J. Cappelli graduated from William H. Taft High School in 1949, he ended up doing what most of his buddies in the Bronx did: not much. There was a recession, and jobs were tight. He would walk from his home at Courtlandt Avenue and 160th Street, cross Park Avenue and head to their hangout on Morris Avenue and 165th Street, where the biggest attraction some days was watching the street get paved.
"None of us was working," he said. "We had a nice time hanging out on the corner, shooting pool, listening to music and going to the movies. We made a few dollars delivering orders." 
 Then came another order.
"My father said, 'Louie, get a job,' " Mr. Cappelli said. "My father only had to tell me once. So Louie dressed himself up in his high school graduation suit, bought The New York Times and looked in the classified under 'Office Boy,' because that was what I thought I was capable of doing."
One ad led him to the Standard Factors Corporation.
"I was instantly offered the job," he said. "I started the same day. And I've been here ever since."
Has he ever. Louie, the iceman's son, has gone from the street corner to a corner office as the chairman and chief executive officer of Sterling Bancorp, the successor to Standard Factors. His 50-year journey left him grateful for life's many blessings, starting with his parents' work ethic. So when he goes to his Park Avenue office, he remembers that road's northern reaches in his old neighborhood.
"I never forgot where I come from," he said. "I tell my colleagues, when you look in the mirror, don't kid yourself about who you are. Don't try to be anything else."
There was a time when others told him to forget about being much of anything. He admits to having been an average student, one who sometimes sassed the teachers. Back then, his family lived at Morris Avenue and 162d Street, near Yankee Stadium.
"We were probably the only Italian family in an island of Irish," he said. "The church was Irish. The priests were Irish. The Italians were not people they thought were of quality."
But he saw other qualities in his family. His father, Peter, who came to America as a teen-ager, made his living hauling hunks of ice. Though he was not educated, he kept track of accounts in his mind. He taught his children the value of respecting family and community. Mr. Cappelli's two brothers and sister taught him the value of education, urging him to get an academic diploma at Taft, rather than go to the vocational schools that his friends attended.
He rose through the the bank's hierarchy while earning a degree from City College at night. He studied accounting, a discipline that he speaks of reverently. The numbers on a spreadsheet, he says, tell stories of businesses and the people who work for them, including his bank. He feels a responsibility to them, he said, because at one point or another in his career, he probably had their job.
"I happen to be paternal in the way I deal with the people here, as opposed to some other organization where people are treated like numbers," he said. "I traveled through the ranks, so I know what it's like. I didn't come out of Harvard Business School and start as a vice president."
HE says that his career path is not some relic from a simpler era. He insists that just as the Italians came into their own, today's immigrants will have their shot, too.
"If you're smart enough," he said. "It's not luck. It's timing. You need to be in the station at the right time."
Or the classroom. A few years ago he was Principal for a Day at Taft High School. The place had changed, starting with the metal detector at the door. In one sophomore class, Noemi Cruz listened to his corporate success story.
"How do I get a job at your bank?" she asked, half joking.
He hired her. She began working summers, and continued after graduation. She is now an administrative assistant, working full time while going to New York University at night, courtesy of the bank.
"I want to stay right here," she said. "Hopefully, I'll get his office."
Sound familiar? Mr. Cappelli is proud of her. He knows some people are amazed at Ms. Cruz's initiative and drive. They never thought a young Bronx woman could be so poised and determined. He just smiles.
"I can relate to her," he said. He snapped his fingers. "Like that, I can relate to her."

HEADLINE: Religion Journal;
Among a Religious Electorate, Overlooked Corners

BYLINE: By GUSTAV NIEBUHR 

 BODY:
When it comes to political activity by religious believers, the nation's evangelical Protestants often seem to get most of the attention from the news media and scholars.
That would be because evangelicals, particularly the many conservatives among them, have clearly emerged as a political force over the last 20 years, aided in part by media-wise organizations like the Moral Majority and, more recently, the Christian Coalition. As a result, they have made an impact on the Republican Party, often pressing causes like efforts to restrict abortion. 
 But this circumstance should not obscure a larger picture about religion and politics or, one expert says, keep reporters and scholars from paying close attention to other Protestants -- the mainline variety, like Methodists and Presbyterians -- who could play an important role in next year's elections.
That suggestion came, in a telephone interview, from John C. Green, director of the Ray C. Bliss Institute of Applied Politics at the University of Akron, who delivered a paper last week analyzing various political data related to religious groups. (The data were drawn from the University of Michigan's National Elections Studies and a poll on "values" by The Washington Post and the Kaiser Family Foundation.)
Mr. Green's paper, presented at the Center for the Study of Religion and Public Life at Trinity College in Hartford, described the outlooks and complex voting patterns that prevailed among Protestants, Roman Catholics, Jews and unaffiliated "seculars" in the 1994, 1996 and 1998 elections.
He had enough data to divide each of the three largest groups (evangelicals, mainline Protestants and Catholics) into two general categories: the "traditionalists," meaning people who maintain a high level of religious observance and accord the Bible a high authority, and the "nontraditionalists," a varied group including theological liberals, moderates and people who say they are not highly observant.
Mr. Green found that Republican candidates had done much better than Democrats with the religious traditionalists as a whole, while Democrats had drawn most of their support from nontraditionalists, seculars, Jews, Hispanic Catholics and African-American Protestants.
Evangelical Protestants accounted for nearly one-third of Republican voters during 1994-98, Mr. Green said. During that period, Democrats' largest voting blocs were seculars, nontraditionalist Catholics and black Protestants.
As for mainline Protestants as a whole, Mr. Green found that they accounted for 16 percent of the electorate -- somewhat less than the evangelicals, who accounted for about a fifth -- with 11 percent fitting in the nontraditionalist category and 5 percent in the traditionalist.
A slight majority of mainline Protestants identify themselves as Republicans, the historic affiliation of these voters. But the nontraditionalists have lately been ticket-splitters, a majority backing President Clinton in 1996 but voting for Republicans for Congress in each of the elections from 1994 through 1998.
Mr. Green said Mr. Clinton appealed to these people with his talk of a "new covenant," of shared responsibility for society between government and citizens. As President, he renewed his appeal in 1996 by pushing government interest in school uniforms and higher academic standards, Mr. Green said.
"These folks seem to have become comfortable with a large public sector," he said. "But they don't want it to get bigger, and they want it to be efficient."
Why are they important? Mainline Protestants are especially numerous in the Upper Midwest, a broad area rich in Electoral College votes running, Mr. Green said, "from western Pennsylvania through Iowa, and you could probably include Nebraska and Kansas."
Were certain social issues to play a major role in the next election, a candidate might find it hard to appeal to those Protestants and other religious voters, too. For example, most mainline Protestants oppose school vouchers, while most evangelicals and Catholics support them, the data show.
Mr. Green's report also points to common ground: a majority of voters in all religious groups say they favor protecting homosexuals from job discrimination, although most also say they do not support gay marriage. And a majority in all groups say they believe that government should reduce poverty, one of several responses that led Mr. Green to say he saw no evidence of "culture war" among Americans over economic issues.

HEADLINE: CRISIS IN THE BALKANS: RUSSIA;
View From Moscow: Success for Its Diplomacy

BYLINE: By CELESTINE BOHLEN 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, May 7

 BODY:
While NATO leaders congratulated themselves on Thursday for nudging Russia over to their side in the search for a diplomatic settlement in Kosovo, Russian diplomats took another view, claiming a small but significant victory in their monthlong attempt to mediate a peace.
Seen from Moscow, the document signed in Bonn on Thursday by the foreign ministers of Russia and the Group of Seven industrial countries had the ring of a compromise, a classic example of diplomatic give and take. 
 In the view of some Russian analysts, the give came mostly from the six NATO partners who for the first time opened the door to a settlement brokered by the United Nations Security Council, where Russia holds the power to veto. In Moscow's view, the Council should play the leading role in solving the Kosovo crisis.
"You can speak about quite a substantial success for Russian diplomacy," said Sergei Rogov, director of Moscow's U.S.A. and Canada Institute. "We were alone against seven Western countries."
No one here was touting the Bonn agreement as a breakthrough. Foreign Minister Igor S. Ivanov called it "a step in the right direction." Viktor S. Chernomyrdin, Russia's special Balkans envoy, who is to set off Saturday on his third mission to Belgrade and other capitals, talked only of "progress."
But for Russia, the significance of the agreement lay in the fact that for the first time since NATO began its bombing of Yugoslavia, Moscow's place at the head table of the world's leading powers has been reaffirmed.
"If you look at this whole story as an effort by NATO to establish itself as the dominant player, deciding questions of war and peace, and deciding them without Russia, we can already conclude that this effort has failed," Mr. Rogov said.
When NATO launched its first attack against Yugoslavia on March 24, Prime Minister Yevgeny M. Primakov, then en route to Washington, turned his plane around over the Atlantic in a move that signaled the depth of Russian fury at being ignored and shut out.
Pressed by a domestic public opinion that is united against the air raids on a traditional Russian ally, and by a Communist-led opposition that blames the West for Russia's weakness, President Boris N. Yeltsin has had little room for diplomatic maneuver.
But even against a backdrop of saber-rattling by its top military leaders, Russia began revving up its diplomatic efforts in early April, first at a meeting in Oslo between Mr. Ivanov and Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright and then with Mr. Chernomydin's shuttle diplomacy.
Today, the leader of the Communist Party, Gennadi A. Zyuganov, criticized the Government's diplomatic overtures in the Balkans. He accused Mr. Yeltsin and Mr. Chernomyrdin of "silently betraying and selling Yugoslavia the way they sold and betrayed the united country, the Russian economy, friends, history, culture and traditions."
By putting his signature on the Bonn document, Mr. Ivanov -- once one of the loudest voices in the Moscow chorus condemning NATO as a criminal aggressor -- signaled Russia's determination to be part of the solution to a crisis that had thrown its relations with the West into a freeze almost reminiscent of the cold war.
The agreement signed on Thursday will dash any hopes that Belgrade may have had of drawing Russia into its war with NATO, commentators here agreed. But some argued that by drawing the United Nations into any future peace settlement, Moscow has helped give President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia a way out of the conflict, if he chooses to accept it.
"In the final analysis, this is not our war," noted Maksim A. Yusin, a Balkans expert at the newspaper Izvestia, "and the peace will be decided between NATO and the Serbs."
With its broadly stated goals, and flimsily worded proposals, the Bonn document raises more problems than it solves. Its success will lie in details that have yet to be hammered out, probably in a Security Council resolution that promises to be the focus of the next round of intense international diplomacy.
Moscow's chief concession -- first touted by President Clinton -- lay in its agreement to join in an international peacekeeping presence in Kosovo. But as several analysts noted, Russia had already dropped broad hints of its willingness to allow and to take part in such a force under United Nations auspices with Yugoslavia's consent.
"An international presence in Kosovo is out of the question without the consent of Yugoslav leaders," Mr. Chernomyrdin said flatly today.
In the Russian view, the West's concessions came in the agreement's acceptance of a United Nations framework for both the peacekeeping force and for an "interim administration" for Kosovo. "The four-letter word NATO is not even mentioned," Mr. Rogov said.
That NATO will insist on playing a key role in keeping the peace is accepted here as one of many issues still to be negotiated. One option that some here think might be accepted by Belgrade would involve troops from NATO countries that have not taken part in the bombing.
The Russians have already signaled their intention to step up the pace of negotiations, seeking out new partners in the search for a settlement, including perhaps Ibrahim Rugova, the Kosovar Albanian leader now in Rome. Deputy Secretary of State Strobe Talbott, who came from Washington last month for talks on Kosovo, is to return here next week.

INTERNATIONAL A3-9
 
NATO Bombs in Belgrade Hit the Chinese Embassy
NATO forces bombing the center of Yugoslavia's capital struck the Chinese Embassy, in an attack that knocked out electricity across much of Yugoslavia. China reported two people were killed; Yugoslav officials reported injuries inside and outside the Embassy. China denounced the attack and called an emergency meeting of the United Nations Security Council, which convened just before midnight. NATO said it had not meant to hit the Embassy. A1 

President Clinton described the peacekeeping operation in Bosnia as a model for the force that is envisioned to protect ethnic Albanian refugees returning to Kosovo; it would include American soldiers working under the direction of NATO with United Nations approval. A1
 
NATO's planned naval blockade of oil deliveries to Yugoslavia may be blocked. France has apparently convinced most of the allies that there is no basis in international law for allied warships to challenge ships of other countries in the Adriatic because they have not formally declared war against Yugoslavia. NATO closed its posts along the Macedonian border after three American soldiers on patrol there were ambushed and captured six weeks ago, the Army commander of the soldiers said. He also described their capture and captivity. A7

HEADLINE: Why Bankruptcy Became So Popular

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Regarding your article about legislation passed by the House of Representatives to make bankruptcy rules more stringent for consumers (news article, May 6): 
 A more equitable way to help consumers alleviate their debt would be to bring back the tax deduction for interest paid on credit cards. After all, it's taxpayers who subsidize the tax breaks given to banks. Why not give consumers a tax break and an incentive for their part in growing the economy?
 
ROGER SEGUIN
Chicago, May 6, 1999

SECTION: Section A; Page 14; Column 6; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 160 words

HEADLINE: Why Bankruptcy Became So Popular

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Klaus Friedrich sheds much-needed light in his May 4 Op-Ed article. Stock market gains can indeed be considered savings, and so can proceeds from many other facets of American life. Most middle-class people put a substantial amount of money into their houses. Thus, they accumulate wealth over the life of the mortgage. This is a major effort at saving for many people but not considered so by economists. 
 The Social Security deduction from one's salary, when combined with the employer's contribution, amounts to about 15 percent for an average income. While economists do not consider this to be savings, workers certainly do.
If all methods of accumulating wealth were accounted for, Americans would have the highest savings rate in the world. The charge that Americans do not save is simply an economic miscalculation, and certainly no one can fault the savers.
 
JOHN SHAW
Basking Ridge, N.J., May 4, 1999

HEADLINE: Heir to a Fortune, and to Tragedy;
Suicide Ends the Life of a Wealthy, and Haunted, Man

BYLINE: By JIM YARDLEY 

 BODY:
William Woodward 3d was born to a family with few peers in New York society. The Woodwards had old money and blue blood, but they also had a penchant for self-destruction that inspired novels by Truman Capote and Dominick Dunne, and landed them in the headlines of newspapers around the world.
William was only 11 years old in 1955 when his mother shot and killed his father, mistaking him for a prowler at their weekend estate. The crack of the shotgun did not wake young Woody, but the shooting echoed throughout his life: His mother, Ann, was exonerated, but she committed suicide in 1975 after Capote depicted her as a murderous vamp. His younger brother, Jimmy, dabbled in drugs and spent time in mental institutions before he jumped to his death from a hotel window. 
 But William Woodward 3d persevered, eager to become more than another poor little rich boy. He became a journalist in the late 1960's and later ran for public office. He served as New York State's Deputy Superintendent of Banks. Later, he married and had a daughter and lived, for a time, a quiet life. And then last Sunday, at age 54, he jumped through the kitchen window of his East Side apartment, the police said, falling 14 stories to his death.
"It's a terrible tragedy," said Lionel Larner, a friend who attended Mr. Woodward's funeral on Thursday. "His desire was to give something back, to try to do good. But there was always a shadow of sadness. It seemed to emanate from him. He wanted very much to be happy."
The shadows in Mr. Woodward's life had become darker in recent years. Friends say he suffered periods of severe depression and had been under psychiatric care. He and his wife, Lisa, had been waging a divorce and custody fight since 1996. In his eulogy at the funeral, Parkman Shaw, a longtime friend, said Mr. Woodward called him two weeks ago, fearful that he had fallen into a depression without bottom.
Another friend who gave a eulogy, Jonathan Morse, said Mr. Woodward suffered from manic depression. "The guy had a tragic life," Mr. Morse said in a telephone interview last night. "He came from a difficult family background, and he just tragically got off the track."
His closest friends, a few of whom regularly telephoned him in recent years to "check up," gathered at a small, private reception after the funeral. In later interviews, several friends described a man of vivid contrasts: He was charming and bright, a patrician with liberal politics, a doting father, someone determined to make his mark. He was also very private, sometimes guarded and subject to increasingly unpredictable behavior.
His death, a close friend said, was "on one level shocking, but on another level it was not."
He added, "I think mental illness is so terrible and insidious."
The skyline of wealth in New York City is ever changing, with new families rising and old ones falling, but the Woodwards ranked at the summit for much of the century.
William Woodward was a chairman of Central-Hanover Bank and a sportsman who purchased the famous Belair Stud, the Maryland thoroughbred farm that produced three Kentucky Derby winners. His wife, Elsie, became a grande dame of high society and a leading philanthropist. Their son, William Woodward Jr., known as Billy, was an international sportsman, most famous for his thoroughbred, Nashua, winner of two-thirds of racing's triple crown. He married Ann Crowell, a woman of ordinary lineage but of extraordinary beauty. She was a Powers model, and became a radio personality known, somewhat oddly, as "the most beautiful girl in radio."
They had two sons, William 3d and James, and if they were born as princes of the realm, they ultimately became victims in a chain of family destruction that seems almost Gothic.
On the night of Oct. 30, 1955, Billy and Ann Woodward had returned to their weekend estate in Oyster Bay on Long Island, after attending a dinner party honoring the Duchess of Windsor. There had been reports of a prowler, and the couple retired to separate bedrooms armed with loaded weapons. Awakened by what she later described as the sound of an intruder, Mrs. Woodward grabbed her gun and fired at a shadow in her doorway. It was her husband. The two boys, asleep elsewhere in the house, did not wake up.
The shooting became front-page news. Life magazine dubbed it "The Shooting of the Century." Distraught and visibly anguished, Mrs. Woodward eventually appeared before a Nassau County grand jury, which deemed the shooting an accident. But the family would never recover.
Mrs. Woodward was ostracized socially and hounded by whispers. The whispers eventually reached Truman Capote, whose unfinished, but published, novel, "Answered Prayers," included a thinly veiled fictional account of the Woodward shooting. He depicted Mrs. Woodward as Ann Cutler, a harlot and a gold digger who killed her husband because he had discovered she was a bigamist.
In 1975, Esquire published an excerpt from the novel, and Ann Woodward was soon found dead in her Fifth Avenue apartment from suicide. Susan Braudy, whose 1992 book, "This Crazy Thing Called Love," documented the shooting, said New York society quickly accepted Capote's fictional account as fact.
"Well, that's that," Elsie Woodward, then in her 90's, said six weeks after Ann's death, according to Ms. Braudy's book. "She shot my son, and Truman just murdered her, and so now I suppose we don't have to worry about that anymore."
But after eight years of research, Ms. Braudy concluded that the shooting, in fact, had been an accident. The police had arrested a prowler who admitted to being at the Woodward estate. Ms. Braudy also discovered that Capote's story about her background was pure fabrication, despite the whispers to the contrary.
"There was an awful lot of gossip about it among their friends taking sides and wondering if it was an accident," said Anne Slater, a friend of the Woodward family. "The boys were at an age where they couldn't miss it."
The youngest, Jimmy, died first. A handsome Vietnam veteran, he quickly fell into the drug culture of the early 1970's, according to Ms. Braudy. He bent heirloom silver spoons to heat heroin, and one night in 1972, high on drugs, he jumped out of a fourth floor window but survived.
Released from a mental institution, Jimmy befriended Xaviera Hollander, the self-proclaimed madam and author of "The Happy Hooker." In one of her later books, she had a chapter, "Jimmy, Don't Jump Again."
He did. Less than a year after his mother's suicide, Jimmy jumped out of a window of a hotel on Central Park South and died.
Woody Woodward was the last of his family, and for years he struggled to make a name for himself. He had attended an exclusive Swiss boarding school and graduated from Harvard College. In 1968, he became a reporter at The New York Post, and if newspapering seemed an unlikely career for a multimillionaire, he embraced it. He paid his own way to cover the Vietnam War, riding around the war on a motorcycle. In New York, he represented the Newspaper Guild in contract negotiations with management, another unlikely role for the heir to a banking fortune.
In 1971, two journalists, Richard Pollak and J. Anthony Lukas, were searching for investors to underwrite a new magazine of media criticism called More. Mr. Woodward signed on, becoming the publisher, and More became acclaimed as an influential, liberal critical voice.
Mr. Woodward eventually left the magazine to attend Harvard Business School and ultimately he turned to politics. He served Gov. Hugh L. Carey in the banking job and worked for Mayor Edward I. Koch in economic development. In 1978, he lost a State Senate race on the East Side.
In 1981, he ran for an at-large seat in the City Council, but the courts abolished those seats before the election. And then Mr. Woodward essentially dropped out of the public eye.
The family saga resurfaced when another fictional account of the shooting, "The Two Mrs. Grenvilles" by Mr. Dunne, was published in 1985 and later was produced as a television movie. Mr. Dunne said this week that Mr. Woodward had called him before publication to ask that he not mention the Woodward name while publicizing the book. Mr. Dunne said he obliged him.
As "The Two Mrs. Grenvilles" reached the best-seller lists, Mr. Woodward and his wife, Lisa, married Sept. 28, 1985, in Paris. They had each attended the same Swiss private school, Le Rosey, then reconnected later in life. Friends and Mrs. Woodward's lawyer, Jerome Tarnoff, say that for several years the couple lived a life of comfort, sailing their boat in the Mediterranean and spending time in apartments in London, Paris and New York.
But Mr. Tarnoff said the marriage began to unravel in 1994. He said Mr. Woodward spent much of the year traveling the world, calling from train stations in Europe. In 1996, Mrs. Woodward filed for divorce, and the couple began a custody battle over their daughter, now 7 years old.
Mr. Woodward's lawyer, Steven E. Lewis, did not return telephone calls left at his office, but Mr. Tarnoff said Mrs. Woodward had temporary custody during the divorce proceedings. He said Mr. Woodward was allowed to see their daughter "40 percent of the time," and that he took her on trips to Colorado and Rhode Island.
"He was a very good father," Mr. Tarnoff said. "He loved that child more than life."
But friends said Mr. Woodward slid into another depression late last year. Mr. Pollak, who had not spoken to Mr. Woodward since they worked together at More, said they exchanged letters last year.
"It was a very unhappy letter," Mr. Pollak said of the note from Mr. Woodward. "He talked about how his marriage was breaking up, and how he was not getting to see his child as much as he liked."
For Mr. Woodward's friends, this final image of a despondent man is not how they wish to remember him. Instead, friends recalled his sensitive nature and his unique style.
"He wore clothes differently," said Ms. Braudy, who became friends with Mr. Woodward during the 70's, before she wrote her book. "He had the manners of a European prince. He was a very attractive personality, but he was vulnerability transcended in a way."
Another friend said simply, almost wishfully, upon receiving a call from a reporter, "Everybody is tired of this story, right? It's tragic and awful and it's over, I hope."

HEADLINE: CRISIS IN THE BALKANS: DIPLOMACY;
Chinese Embassy Bombing May Hurt Bid to Win Support for Peacekeepers

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 7

 BODY:
The bombing of the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade is expected to complicate, and could even undermine, efforts by the United States and other NATO members to win United Nations endorsement of an international peacekeeping force for Kosovo, Administration officials acknowledged tonight.
China, which has a veto in the United Nations Security Council, has steadfastly opposed the NATO bombing campaign in Yugoslavia and has made clear its suspicion about the motives of the Western alliance. 
 Still, Administration officials said they believed that if NATO was able to come up with a Russian-endorsed peace plan that ends the bombing, China would be unlikely to veto a Security Council resolution sanctioning a peacekeeping force, despite the attack.
Operating on little beyond television news accounts of the bombing, White House and State Department officials said they immediately telephoned senior diplomats at the Chinese Embassy in Washington tonight to express their concern.
In Beijing, the American Ambassador, James Sasser, was alerted by the White House by phone to the developments in Belgrade and asked to meet with senior Chinese officials to offer condolences.
News of the bombing was immediately relayed to President Clinton and to Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright shortly after she met with the United Nations Secretary General, Kofi Annan, officials said.
Mr. Annan said in a statement issued after the meeting that he was "shocked and distressed to learn that NATO air strikes" apparently hit the embassy and a civilian hospital in the city of Nis. "He reiterates his conviction that an urgent political solution must be found to the present crisis in the region," said his spokesman, Fred Eckhard.
While consultations with the Chinese have seemed almost a second thought to the Clinton Administration during the air war, China has the power through its Security Council veto to defeat any United Nations resolution endorsing an international peacekeeping force in Kosovo.
Under a peace plan approved this week by the Group of Seven most industrialized nations and Russia, any peacekeeping force in Kosovo must be "endorsed and adopted by the United Nations." That wording was apparently intended to satisfy Russia and to make it possible for it to take part on a peacekeeping force.
In recent days, American and European leaders had begun to court China more aggressively for its support for -- or more likely, its lack of opposition to -- a Security Council resolution. Chancellor Gerhard Schroder of Germany had been expected to travel to Beijing next month for talks.
China has opposed the air campaign against Yugoslavia from the start, consistent with its fiercely held position that a group of countries cannot interfere in the internal affairs of others. The Chinese may well see a parallel between Kosovo and Tibet or Taiwan.
"We are firmly opposed to any attempt to impose a solution on the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia," Ambassador Qin Huasun of China said earlier this week at the United Nations. "NATO must cease its military action immediately."
In February, the Chinese vetoed a separate Security Council resolution to extend the mandate for a United Nations peacekeeping operation in Macedonia, across the border from Yugoslavia. The veto was apparently a demonstration of China's fury over Macedonia's diplomatic recognition of Taiwan this year.
Administration officials insisted tonight that they had no confirmation that NATO was responsible for the bombing of the Chinese Embassy. "One of the things we've learned during the last 45 days is to be careful of what what we say before we know anything," a senior official said.
Another senior official said he believed that whether or not NATO proved to be responsible for the attack, the Chinese were not likely to veto an international peacekeeping force. "If we did indeed hit the Chinese Embassy by accident, we would express our regret to them," the official said. "There would be discussions and regret.
"But China has made very clear that it is opposed to the use of force. And if every other member of the Security Council believed that a peaceful solution was possible, China does not have a history of standing in the way. It would be hard to envision them justifying that."
During the cold war, China had close relations with Yugoslavia, largely because the the Government in Belgrade, while Communist, held to a policy of fierce nonalignment and was seen as a foil in Europe to the power of the Soviet Union. The relationship has remained close.
The Yugoslav President, Slobodan Milosevic, visited China after the 1995 peace agreement in Bosnia and received all the trappings of a formal state visit. His wife, Mirjana Markovic, has been to China on several occasions. and has praised the Chinese Government for its ability to adapt Communism to the post-Cold War era.
Two years ago, Ms. Markovic unveiled plans to build a Chinatown in Belgrade, but a shortage of funds apparently killed the project. Her only complaint about the Beijing Government is that it has adopted an economy that is too capitalistic. China was delivering oil to Serbia until several days ago, but stopped deliveries for reasons that appeared to be entirely capitalistic: Beijing was not being paid for the fuel.

And Bear in Mind
(Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)
 
Alexander Hamilton, American, by Richard Brookhiser. (Free Press, $25.) A dramatic, compact biography that argues for virtues not always attributed to Hamilton, like intelligence, idealism, character and vision.
 
Anglomania: A European Love Affair, by Ian Buruma. (Random House, $25.95.) In a work that is part intellectual history and part family memoir, the author investigates the exquisite blend of elitism and tolerance, vulgarity and gentility, that makes Britain Britain.
 
Bone By Bone, by Peter Matthiessen. (Random House, $26.95.) The last of three novels inhabited and propelled by Edgar J. Watson, a cane planter, developer and murderer whose conquest of Florida's Gulf Coast marches with the imperialist impulses of the young United States.
 
Breath and Shadows, by Ella Leffland. (Morrow, $24.) Suffused with a moonlit melancholy, this novel braids together three generations of a Danish family to pose a haunting question: What do we leave behind to prove we have ever existed?
 
A Dangerous Friend, by Ward Just. (Peter Davison/Houghton Mifflin, $23.) As its well-meaning civilian hero attempts to find an American officer captured in Vietnam, this novel emerges as an allegory for our country's place in the increasingly deranged world of the mid-1960's.
 
For the Relief of Unbearable Urges, by Nathan Englander. (Knopf, $22.) Ambitious short stories by a 29-year-old former yeshiva student from New York, now living in secular Israel; his characters are able to flourish in a borderland between the author's old world and that new one.
 
Lords of the Horizons: A History of the Ottoman Empire, by Jason Goodwin. (John Macrae/Holt, $32.50.) A journalist and travel writer illuminates the history and culture of a former seat of imperial splendor, from its humble origins to glittering eminence to lumbering decline.
 
The Meme Machine, by Susan Blackmore. (Oxford University, $25.) An informed effort to popularize the theory that cultures are controlled by replicating units (memes) analogous to the genes of biological theory, and that their operations drive cultural evolution.
 
A Prayer for the Dying, by Stewart O'Nan. (Holt, $22.) In a novel that explores both the nature of evil and the limits of human endurance, a Civil War veteran must save a small Midwestern town beset by fire and plague -- catastrophes with mutually exclusive solutions -- or go mad trying.
 
Vera: (Mrs. Vladimir Nabokov), by Stacy Schiff. (Random House, $27.95.) A thoughtful biography of Nabokov's wife, protector, dogsbody and perfect reader that opens up a 52-year marriage without pretending to explain every enigma.

HEADLINE: Beautiful Losers

BYLINE: By John Sutherland; John Sutherland is the Lord Northcliffe Professor of Modern English Literature at University College, London.

 BODY:

IN PRAISE OF ANTIHEROES
 Figures and Themes in Modern
 European Literature, 1830-1980.
 By Victor Brombert.
 168 pp. Chicago:
 The University of Chicago Press. $29. 
 Ask literary scholars old enough to have received a proper education (I'm being deliberately provocative) what they think is the most heroic work of criticism ever and, chances are, they will reply Erich Auerbach's "Mimesis." That panoramic survey of "the representation of reality in Western literature" (3,000 years of it, from Homer to Virginia Woolf) was written during World War II in Istanbul, where the author, a German exile, had found refuge, and where he wrote it without the aid of libraries or research materials. Like the outcasts in Ray Bradbury's "Fahrenheit 451," he could cite from Petronius, Chretien de Troyes, Dante, Boccaccio, Rabelais, Montaigne, Stendhal, because he had, in a sense, become their books. Auerbach was high European culture, at a time when the Nazis were devoting their hideous energies to destroying it.
"Mimesis" is also, for such a humblingly learned enterprise, engagingly accessible ("Readers of the 'Odyssey' will remember the well-prepared and touching scene in Book 19," it opens; would that I did). In the largest sense Auerbach vindicates comparative literature, that most demanding of academic disciplines. To do it well, the scholar needs many languages and must master libraries of complex literary works. Expertise comes late in life, if, by good luck, life lasts long enough ("Had we but world enough, and time . . ." is Auerbach's epigraph).
Victor Brombert's latest book, though slim, recalls Auerbach's polyglot omnicompetence. It follows the antihero topos over 150 years, across five languages (excluding English) and through works by Bchner, Gogol, Dostoyevsky, Flaubert, Svevo, Hasek, Max Frisch, Camus and Primo Levi. "The writers discussed in this study belong to several distinct cultural and linguistic traditions," Brombert notes; "in all cases, I have based my analyses on close readings in the original language." Brombert's head must buzz like a translating room at the United Nations. With an eye to his readers, however, he restricts his discussions to translated and well-known works. The 10 chapters look like a well-planned semester-length course for a class of handpicked graduates (Brombert is a professor of Romance and comparative literatures at Princeton).
In a brisk opening chapter he states the thesis: Although Dostoyevsky gave the term currency in his "Notes From Underground" ("A novel needs a hero, and all the traits of an antihero are expressly gathered together here"), Brombert locates the seed of antiheroism 30 years earlier, in Bchner's "Woyzeck" (a "loser"). The antihero emerges as "a perturber and a disturber," a "subverter" of things as they are. The type evolves into "heroes of inaction such as Proust's Swann and Joyce's Leopold Bloom." Above all, the antihero, as formulated by the seditious genius of literature, forces readers to question the ideology that drives their society ("Unhappy the country that needs heroes," as Brecht, a mass-producer of antiheroism, declared). The extreme of the subversive type is Hasek's good (i.e., bad) soldier Schweik, "an unheroic yet rebellious survival artist in a jingoistic world gone mad."
The chapters of "In Praise of Antiheroes" are self-contained and arranged chronologically. Each offers a lucid and economical explication de texte. There is little "theory" and much good sense. Some chapters work better than others. Particularly effective is the analysis of "The Overcoat." Gogol's story has as its antihero the St. Petersburg clerk Akaky Akakyevich (Brombert courteously explains the hilarious implications of the name, for those of us who do not have Russian). By dint of enormous sacrifice, Akaky acquires a new overcoat, only to have it stolen by street thugs the next day. Gogol's narrative, Brombert notes, has been subjected to "orgies of interpretations." His own interpretation, pointing to the story's "conflicting and enigmatic signals," is subtle and convincing.
The most effective chapter in the book is on Primo Levi. The text in question is "If This Is a Man" ("Se Questo un Uomo," in America banally entitled "Survival in Auschwitz"). Unlike Brombert's other texts, this is not a work of fiction. Levi describes how he was approached by a fellow camp inmate, a young Alsatian called "Pikkolo" (later identified as Jean Samuel), who asked to be taught Italian. Levi, "without first understanding why," conjured up lines from Dante, the 26th canto of the "Inferno," the "Canto of Ulysses," as the starting point of their lessons.
Levi admired Homer. Not the war-loving poet of the "Iliad," whose "orgy of battles, wounds and corpses" he found "almost intolerable." He preferred the "Odyssey," with its cunning, ingeniously antiheroic hero, Ulysses -- scheming, cheating and miraculously surviving. In Dante's "Inferno," Ulysses instructs his men as they suffer together in the circles of hell. So too does Levi instruct Pikkolo. In the squalor and degradation of Auschwitz the lessons create cultural resistance. Levi recalls that, starving as he was, he would gladly have "given today's soup" to have known how to connect two isolated lines of Dante's poem. But, like Auerbach in Istanbul (at almost the same time), he did not have access to the necessary libraries. Brombert points out that the thrust of Levi's Ulysses chapter "is of a spiritual nature. . . . The recourse to Dante's poetry, in order to teach Italian to an Alsatian fellow inmate in a German camp deep inside Poland, where Yiddish is the common tongue, becomes a symbol of universality and of the possible survival of meaning."
As Brombert glosses it, the Homer-Dante-Levi episode forms something more than an act of literary explication. One can read it as an apologia for comparative literature. Auerbach, writing his chapter on the 10th canto of the "Inferno," found in it a new "image of man" -- an image so glorious that it "eclipses the image of God." In that way Dante (partly, at least) redeems the inhumanity of the Holocaust for Levi.
Brombert's praise for antiheroes offers an oblique riposte to George Steiner -- a scholar and critic as polymathic, brilliant and effortlessly polyglot as Auerbach, but much more pessimistic. Steiner observes, "We do not know -- and surely there is something rather terrible in our doubt -- whether the study and delight a man takes in Shakespeare make him any less capable of organizing a concentration camp." Touching lightly on great issues, Brombert's elegant study ventures a tentatively affirmative answer.

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY: CORRESPONDENT'S REPORT;
Sydney Sets the Stage For 2000 Olympic Games

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL 

 BODY:
EVEN as the scent of scandal pervades the Olympic Winter Games scheduled for Salt Lake City in 2002, Sydney, Australia, host of the 2000 Summer Games, is well along with its multibillion-dollar program to build and renovate athletic fields, stadiums, parks and infrastructure. In fact, some stadiums and fields are already holding events, in part to test the people-moving machinery, and tourists traveling to Sydney anytime soon might want to check them out.
The Sydney railroad station and international airport will be decked out in their latest finery to welcome the approximately 300,000 foreign visitors (and 350,000 visitors from elsewhere in Australia) expected for the Games, which will run from Sept. 15 through Oct. 1. And hotels throughout the nation are sprucing up,not only for visitors who come for the Games but also because Olympic publicity is expected to generate an additional 1.6 million foreign visitors through 2004. 
 The accuracy of those projections, by Australia's Tourism Forecasting Council, is likely to depend on several events, especially the economic health of Australia's Asian neighbors and the fallout from the Olympic bribery scandal.
Sydney did not emerge with clean hands from the recent investigations. On the contrary, an independent Australian auditor found that officials for the Sydney Organizing Committee for the Olympic Games frequently violated International Olympic Committee guidelines in outbidding Beijing for the Games (which were awarded to Sydney in 1993). And Phil Coles, a member of the Sydney organizing committee and one of two Australian members of the International Olympic Committee, was reprimanded by the I.O.C. for accepting thousands of dollars in hospitality from cities bidding for the Olympics, a charge he admitted. But the auditor's report concluded that Sydney's red carpet treatment for visiting Olympic officials did not approach Salt Lake City's transgressions, which included cash, free medical treatment, tuition and air fare for Olympic committee members and relatives.
Sandy Hollway, the chief executive of the Sydney Games, said recently, "I don't think the ongoing publicity has been helpful to our efforts." There has already been a backlash among possible sponsors, forcing the Sydney committee to cut $32 million from the Games' $1.6 billion budget in late April.
But for now tourism officials are sticking with their original projections.
The 25,000 American tourists expected for the Games will be the biggest foreign contingent, despite the cost of the six-night packages from Los Angeles that start at about $5,000 including air fare. Australian officials said they expect that Americans will spend an average of $7,000 each, including air fare, hotels, food and Olympic tickets, which range from $8 for certain preliminary events to $1,054 for the highest-price seats at the opening and closing ceremonies (time trials are free for sailing, the marathon, the triathlon and cycling).
Sydney has already benefited from the publicity. The city climbed from the world's 26th most popular convention destination in 1995 to No. 1 in 1997, according to the International Congress and Convention Association.
Meanwhile, the pre-Olympics building boom continues. In March, Sydney completed its 110,000-seat Olympic Stadium, which after the Olympics will be used for Australian football games, cricket and concerts; its tennis center, with 16 courts and 10,000 permanent seats, is only a few months from completion. Seating capacity in the aquatic center is being increased to 15,000 from 4,400, hockey and archery centers are being upgraded, and an arena for basketball and gymnastics is being built. The new Athletes' Village will house about 15,300, eventually becoming part of the new suburb of Newington.
With so much at stake, Australia is leaving little to chance. Australian officials met in February with Louis Freeh, the director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, to discuss security arrangements. Among other things, video surveillance cameras will be deployed at railroad stations, airports, hotels and other sites. And Australian delegations traveled to Atlanta three times: in 1995, to assess the impact of the Games on tourism; in 1996, to focus on working with the news organizations; and in 1997, to talk with industry leaders about what they would have done differently, or not at all.
Those visits appear to have been productive, because Mr. Hollway of the Sydney Olympic committee recently said that the organizers had developed so much information that they are considering selling it to other cities thinking about bidding for the Games. And in a moneymaking tradition dating back at least as far as Waldi, the dachshund mascot of the 1972 Munich Games, sales of mascot merchandise are expected to reach $500 million.
The Sydney mascots are Syd the platypus, Olly the kookaburra and Millie the echidna (a spiny anteater). It is not likely to hurt sales that there are three mascots instead of the usual one, nor will it hurt that the the array of souvenirs bearing their likenesses have been on sale since 1997.
