HEADLINE: The Great Ape Massacre

BYLINE: By Donald G. McNeil Jr.; Donald G. McNeil Jr. is a correspondent for The Times based in Johannesburg.

 BODY:
Dieu-Donne Bima Bima is a nice young man with a gentle manner. With becoming modesty, he describes how the chopped-up bodies of three gorillas have come to be smoking over a fire outside his hut.
"I shot the big male as it charged me. The baby was on the mother's back, and when she turned around to look at me the baby did, too." He does an imitation of a tiny scrunched face peering at him. 
 "I shot her in the face, and the bullet went through it, too -- bouf! One bullet, two gorillas!" he concludes triumphantly.
As a horrified listener clutches his chest, he laughs. "Why do you want to protect gorillas? They're just animals."
Deep in Central Africa, the great humanlike apes -- gorillas and chimpanzees -- are rapidly being wiped out by hunters. Bima Bima will make about $60 for each adult gorilla, and would get nearly as much for a full-grown chimpanzee. Chimps with their heads and hands removed are sold as gorilla meat.
Much as that distresses conservationists, the need to stop the hunting has suddenly taken on more urgency in the West. In January, scientists announced that H.I.V.-1, the most common AIDS virus, came from the subspecies of chimpanzee found here, Pan troglodytes troglodytes. They believe it passed into humans when hunters nicked themselves butchering their kill or ate raw meat. Since the chimps don't seem to get sick from it, they may be the key to a cure. It's crucial that they be kept alive and are studied -- but that's not the fate they're headed for now.
Until recently, the great rain forest stretching from Nigeria to Rwanda belonged largely to Pygmies hunting with poisoned arrows. Nibbling at the forest's edges, they posed no more threat to the species within than the plains Indians did to the vast American bison herds.
But logging roads, shotguns and trucks are doing what the horse, Winchester and railroad did to the buffalo. As loggers extend a spider web of roads into the rain forest, hunters are moving down them, snaring or shooting anything that moves. There may be fewer than 120,000 troglodytes chimpanzees left, and thousands are killed each year. They reproduce more slowly than humans, one baby every four years.
Dr. Beatrice H. Hahn led a team from the University of Alabama at Birmingham that proved the link between AIDS and chimps.
Research has established that the pandemic form of H.I.V.-1 probably began to spread in humans in the early 1940's. Hahn showed that it came from the simian immunode-ficiency virus in troglodytes chimps.
What researchers most want to know is why the simian virus doesn't kill the host apes. To that end, they need to know how widespread infection is in the wild, which they might be able to determine from stool samples gathered from the forest floor. And they need blood samples drawn from wild animals. "These chimps are information we need," says Hahn, who has become an antihunting campaigner. "Killing them for the pot is like burning a library full of books you haven't read yet."
Environmentalists once thought most apes were killed in attempts to steal their babies for the illegal pet trade. But that's wrong -- surviving babies are just extra cash for hunters supplying the growing fad for "bush meat" on the tables of the elite in Cameroon, Gabon, the Congo, the Central African Republic and other countries.
Hunting endangered species is illegal, of course, but the law is rarely enforced here. The bush-meat market in Yaounde, Cameroon's capital, is no secret. It's a 500-foot stretch of sidewalk only a few blocks from the presidential offices and the $200-a-night Hilton Hotel. Vendors desultorily wave whisks over tables piled high with smoked and fresh monkeys, duikers (tiny antelopes), bush pigs and skinned snakes. Just behind them, watched over by rough-looking men, are piles from which long arm bones protrude, obviously those of chimpanzees and gorillas. At the fetish stalls, you can buy chimpanzee hands, gorilla skulls, round slices of elephant trunk or the bright red tails of endangered gray parrots.
"If your child is weak and you want to make him big and strong, you feed him gorilla meat," says Elie Bayoi, a vendor. "Or you can scrape the shoulder bone into water and bathe him in that. If you have a broken bone, you heat a chimpanzee skull and press it against the break." Chimpanzee hands cure stomach pains, he adds. Elephant skin repels garden pests.
The market isn't hidden, but the vendors are touchy. Even the chatty Bayoi refuses to let his stall be photographed; other vendors have mobbed photographers.
Karl Ammann is a Swiss hotelier who fell in love with the apes he photographed while running luxury camps in Africa. He has since become the chief nemesis of the bush- meat trade, and persona non grata to Governments whose indifference he exposes. He has spent years photographing the trade, sometimes with concealed cameras.
"The big conservation groups say only poor Pygmies eat bush meat, but look at these customers," he says on a walk through the market. "Look how they're dressed -- they're middle class. People don't want beef or chicken anymore -- they call it 'white man's meat.' I know a woman who has to take chimpanzee meat to her family whenever she goes home. You can order a gorilla for Christmas the same way I'd order a turkey."
To prove the point to a German television crew, he recently bought two heads: a chimp's and a pig's. The chimp was $8, the bigger, meatier pig only $5. Two gorilla arms cost $10, an equal weight of beef less than $4.
Ammann has a teen-age chimp at his Kenya home, and even on a visit to the tiny Yaounde zoo, it's clear that he is drawn to apes. He makes ooh-ooh noises and puts his head in the hands they stretch through the bars to groom him. "They have feelings and emotions," he says afterward, turning angry. "A wounded chimp will beg for its life. They're like retarded children, and we don't eat them. Where do we draw the line?"
The DNA of chimpanzees is 98.5 percent the same as that of humans, and Ammann calls eating them "98.5 percent cannibalism."
More mainstream conservationists have asked him to temper his language, saying it smacks of "cultural imperialism." One is Steve Gartlan, head of the World Wide Fund for Nature's Cameroon office. Vivid photographs of dead apes and reminders of their human qualities are "emotionally understandable but biologically unsound" since whole ecosystems need protection, he argued in a long critique of one of Ammann's articles. He also expressed sympathy for the hunters, saying, "We share an even larger percentage of our genes -- 100 percent -- with the rural poor."
At the urging of the fund, Cameroon has designated three new parks, though Ammann dismisses them as mere "lines on paper." According to a report provided on condition of anonymity by a scientist working in the 3,300-square-mile Dja Reserve in southwest Cameroon, about 100 hunters are camped inside. "Despite the European conservation money poured into the region," it says, "unique species are being wiped out at an alarming rate."
The explosion in bush-meat hunting is being propelled by two converging forces: logging and corruption. As prices for coffee, cocoa and oil have fallen, timber exports have soared. The roads bulldozed to reach the 800-year-old hardwoods are wider and smoother than the dirt national highways.
Rather than pay to ship beef or pork to the jungle dormitory towns where their workers live, the logging companies encourage hunting. The hundreds of log trucks headed for the coast become a bush-meat caravan. Bleeding bags of meat can be spotted behind the cabs; the drivers get a cut.
The political will to stop the hunting simply does not exist. Hunters rent their guns from army and police officers; there are roadblocks everywhere where police could seize the meat, but they let anyone through for a $2 bribe; Government officials serve bush meat at banquets. Transparency International, a not-for-profit corruption-fighting group, recently rated Cameroon the most corrupt country of the 85 it surveyed. Next-door, Nigeria, famous for corruption, was only No. 81.
Cameroonians say the problem is just getting worse. "When I came here in 1988, it was forbidden to kill animals," says Ndzana Ndzana, an environmental official whose territory includes the Gabon camp. "But we had guns then. We had vehicles. We had bullets. Now, with the economic crisis, the central Government gives us nothing. We can't do our jobs."
Bima Bima, the hunter, has agreed to join a project that Ammann wants to start. They hope to find a group of gorillas they can protect and habituate to humans, so they can prove that "gorilla tourism," like that which existed in Uganda until recently, is profitable.
Joseph Melloh, the first hunter Ammann converted to his cause, will be in charge. For him, it's business. "A gorilla is still meat -- it has no soul," he says. "But now I know that if you kill a gorilla, you use it once. But if you keep it for 30 years, and bring people to see it, you get more money. And you don't have to carry the firewood to smoke it."
Changing Africans' feelings about eating apes will be hard, Hahn says. "But it can be done," she says confidently. "The Japanese like to eat whales, but whales were being exterminated, so their behavior is changing. And conserving chimpanzees might turn out to be even more important than conserving whales or elephants or rhinos."
There's no guarantee that simian studies will reveal a cure or vaccine for AIDS. But the extinction of vital chimpanzee species surely guarantees that they won't.

HEADLINE: Al Gore's Money Problem

BYLINE: By Jill Abramson; Jill Abramson is Washington editor of The Times.

 BODY:
The Vice President stood before 40 wealthy Democrats in the Fifth Avenue palazzo of the Lazard Fr<heart>res executive Steven Rattner, a stunning place with marble columns and a view over the Metropolitan Museum. The guests, bathed in candlelight, nibbled at apple crisp and whipped cream. To be here, each had promised to raise at least $35,000 for Al Gore's Presidential quest.
Gore began by recognizing some of the more luminous luminaries in the room -- Eugene Ludwig, the former Comptroller of the Currency; Richard Gardner, former Ambassador to Spain and Italy; and a raft of Wall Street heavyweights. Then it was time for a joke: the one Gore tells at every fund-raiser, about an 8-year-old boy in Minnesota who wrote Gore a sort of fan letter that called him "the greatest Vice President of my time." There was a polite titter. As Gore moved on to his studiously rehearsed vision for the 21st century, the overwhelming impression was of a marble candidate in a marble setting. 
 So far in this young campaign, the issues that Gore loves -- from his "practical idealism" to his "electronic-privacy bill of rights" -- have lacked a certain electricity. But that is not to say that the Gore 2000 effort is a listless one. To the contrary, the candidate may still seem like the robot caricature of a thousand late-night monologues, but his campaign's fund-raising calls to mind a dizzyingly effective machine. In the first three months of 1999 alone, Gore fund-raisers piled up $8.9million in contributions -- easily a record, and a sum that has scared off all challengers for the Democratic nomination except Bill Bradley.
Between now and the Democratic convention in Los Angeles in August 2000, Gore intends to raise a staggering $55 million. The soul of this fund-raising machine is the candidate himself, with his vast and assiduously built network of supporters stretching from his native Tennessee to Wall Street and west to Silicon Valley and Hollywood, his reputation as an outstanding bottom-line salesman and his plain old tirelessness. Gore will spend countless hours on the free-range-chicken-and-Chardonnay circuit in the months ahead, rolling out a green carpet leading (he hopes) straight to the Democratic nomination. A massive early war chest is more important in this election than ever before, because New York and California, both key, expensive states, now have early primaries. Gore's facility with total-immersion fund-raising, then, may be his greatest strength.
Yet it may also prove to be his greatest vulnerability. There is the danger that Gore will ultimately focus too much on fund-raising, because he's simply so good at it, instead of solving his campaign's weaknesses -- like finding the issues and the message that broad swaths of voters can really get excited about. If he does not do this, and thus move the story of his campaign away from fund-raising, the defining impression left in the minds of the electorate could simply be his ability to charm the deep-pockets crowd; that could be disastrous at a moment when his standing in the polls is anemic and campaign-finance reform is popular.
Gore's opponents are no doubt aware of this potential weakness. Before it's all over, there will almost certainly be attack ads from foes recalling his role in the 1996 election as the Democratic Party's "solicitor in chief," cold-calling donors for cash, not to mention his star turn with a chorus line of Buddhist nuns in saffron robes. "Political money is the wrong game to monopolize in the year 2000," says Fred Wertheimer, a campaign-finance-reform advocate. "That's particularly true for Gore," Wertheimer adds, because of the 1996 scandals. "By raising so much money, Gore has become emblematic of the Washington money culture that the American people find repugnant," Wertheimer continues. "It's a high-risk strategy."
Even so, for Gore or any other candidate these days, fund-raising remains a necessity, not an option. Gore declined to speak with me on the record about fund-raising, but did allow me, as his campaign kicked into high gear, to tag along and get a firsthand look at events that are generally off-limits to the press. The day that ended chez Rattner was a typical jumble of official appearances sandwiched between unofficial schmooze sessions with fat cats. It began in the Bronx at the Helen Keller Elementary School in the heart of the Co-op City housing development, where Gore read aloud to a second-grader dressed in a neat uniform, who confided that she wants his job someday.
Then the motorcade rushed him to a private dining room at the Four Seasons, where he joined rich Manhattan executives for a feast of black bass with squid-ink risotto. In the afternoon, there were private chats with other prominent New York Democrats. For cocktails, Gore met with a group of African-American business leaders who have each pledged to raise $5,000 for the campaign, at an apartment on upper Park Avenue. Dinner, with a $10,000-a-head bounty, was with a group of executives from the communications industry at the trendy East Side restaurant Daniel. And finally, dessert at Rattner's.
The day's take: an impressive $1.5 million.
David Geffen, sitting in a large leather chair in one of the immense rooms in his $47.5million, nine-acre Beverly Hills estate, tells me that he finds fund-raising "time-consuming and irritating." But he intends to spend a lot of time doing it for Al Gore. "I view this as an important election," says the Hollywood mogul, clad in a white polo shirt, jeans and white sneakers. "We're going to work very hard to elect Gore and replace the most radical House and Senate in history."
Seated next to Geffen, in another sumptuous leather chair, is Andy Spahn, formerly Gary Hart's national finance director and now a fund-raising and political adviser to Geffen and his Dreamworks partners, Steven Spielberg and Jeffrey Katzenberg. Geffen and Spahn say they will very likely hold a dinner for Gore later in the campaign, much like the intimate 1996 meals Clinton shared with Geffen and 15 or so Hollywood execs, where $2 million was raised.
"My biggest worry about the Vice President between now and the election is that he become the best communicator he can be," Geffen says. He worries that Gore does not have the sparkle that his boss transmits so effortlessly. "Clinton recalls the meal you ate together and what you left on the plate." Some of Gore's other Hollywood supporters voice the same concern. Famous directors like Spielberg and Rob Reiner are eager to race to Washington to give their man some emergency speech coaching. "He's really funny, but he has a hard time letting his natural personality emerge," frets Reiner, whose film "An American President," about a picture-perfect commander in chief, was made with research help from Gore's staff.
The key to fund-raising is one-to-one networking, and Gore has proven extremely effective at tapping connections from every phase of his life. In Hollywood, for example, his longtime ambassador is John Cooke, a Disney executive, who expects Gore's California effort to raise millions. While Bill Bradley has longstanding friendships in Hollywood and is close to the Disney chairman, Michael Eisner, as well as to Barry Diller, Gore has sewn up the team from Dreamworks.
Farther up the coast are the executives in the high-tech industry who have dubbed themselves the Gore Techs. During the second Clinton-Gore inauguration, the Vice President set aside two hours to meet with a dozen executives from Silicon Valley. The group, which included the high-tech venture capitalist John Doerr, the Intuit chairman Scott Cook and the Marimba software founder Kim Polese, were wowed by Gore's fluency with the New Economy. "He really gets it," says Joe Kraus, the co-founder of Excite, who has attended several Gore Tech meetings and has kicked in $1,000 to Gore.
The candidate has since met with the Gore Techs, who now number more than two dozen, 17 more times. At a Gore fund-raiser last month at the Woodside, Calif., mansion of Janina Pawlowski, co-founder of E-Loan, his Silicon Valley supporters raised $400,000 for their candidate. Besides the nice turnout and breathtaking view, Gore had a rare loose public moment. He and Tipper bopped with a band that included two former members of the Grateful Dead; Tipper even played the bongos. Then they repaired to dinner at Doerr's house with 30 Democratic donors, who raised $10,000 apiece.
John Tyson, an international business investor, is even raising money from Gore's class at Harvard, where he was one of the future Vice President's roommates. He recalls long discussions with Gore about Vietnam and civil rights as they lay in their bunk beds. "I always knew he'd be President," Tyson says. "He does well in an environment where there is a lot of pressure." At a recent gala in Washington, Tyson solicited $20,000 from the class of '69, and is now expanding his efforts to other classes.
Gore's prowess at the money game is one of the things that attracted Bill Clinton in 1992. As magnetic as Clinton was on the fund-raising circuit, he always hated actually asking for money. Gore, in contrast, is known as the best "closer" in the business, someone who can get contributors to commit to a specific amount and write their checks on the spot. When he was a Senator, his family kept an apartment on Capitol Hill that he used as a fund-raising safe house, where he could make calls between votes. And he did not disappoint Clinton, helping raise millions after he joined the ticket in 1992 and a staggering $40 million for the party in 1996.
Add to the Gore network, then, some of Clinton's cash constituencies. One is Wall Street, although there is some lingering doubt over the Vice President's environmentalism, which some deem as antibusiness. Gore has strategically set his sights on some of the party's younger financial powers -- like his recent host, Steve Rattner. During the 1996 campaign, he orchestrated a seat next to Rattner at a fund-raising reception and subseqently called him to seek his counsel on economic issues. When it came time to gear up the 2000 fund-raising effort, Rattner signed on to play his part in a process that even he concedes "could not possibly be what Jefferson had in mind."
The engine of the Gore fund-raising machine is just up K Street from the White House, in a spartan campaign headquarters that hasn't been painted and lacks enough desks for the burgeoning staff. Here Johnny Hayes, a portly 58-year-old with glasses, presides as the campaign's finance chairman, watching over the responses to the 1.5 million direct-mail solicitations the campaign has already sent out. Until January, when he resigned to raise money full time for Gore, Hayes was a director of the Tennessee Valley Authority, a cushy job that he landed with Gore's help.
Their relationship goes back to 1976, when Gore, then a 29-year-old running for Congress for the first time, dropped by Hayes's insurance office in Hendersonville, Tenn., to ask for his support. Hayes knew Gore's father, the Tennessee Senator, and decided to help. The pair traveled the state raising money and asking for votes in a '62 Ford pickup with no air-conditioning. When Gore ran for the Presidency in 1988, Hayes raised $3 million from Tennessee and has tended the green turf of their home state ever since.
A few blocks down K Street is the law firm Wunder, Knight, Levine, Thelen & Forscey. Peter Knight worked on Gore's Congressional staff for 13 years and helped run his Presidential campaign in 1988, then managed the 1996 Clinton-Gore campaign. These days the boyish-looking Knight spends much of his time talking to members of Gore's national fund-raising committee -- The Solicitors," as they're known within the campaign. Each promised to raise $50,000 during the first three months of 1999, and almost all reached their quotas. Knight likens raising so much money in such a short time to "jump-starting a small cap company." But it's more than that, he insists: "Fund-raising is a real reflection of your political support. The Vice President enjoys a great deal of political support."
Another key member of the team is Terry McAuliffe, the Democratic fund-raising Wunderkind who between April and November 1995 raised $27 million for Clinton-Gore -- a record that stands to this day," he notes. In the winter of 1997, Gore flew through the snow to make it to McAuliffe's 40th-birthday bash at the Mayflower Hotel.
Like their candidate, McAuliffe and Knight pay lip service to the need for Congress to pass campaign-finance reform. But the bottom line is that in the absence of such reforms, they will play by the rules of the game as they exist, and play with a vengeance. Skyrocketing campaign costs have sparked the fund-raising equivalent of a nuclear arms race, and the 2000 election will be the most money-infused in history. George W. Bush raised $7.6 million in the first three months of 1999, while Bradley managed to pull in a respectable $4.3 million.
Post-Watergate election-law reforms aside, the campaign-finance system has become shot through with loopholes. Laws limiting individuals to giving $1,000 during the primaries simply mean an emphasis on rounding up donors who have lots of friends who can also write $1,000 checks. Candidates who accept Federal matching funds must limit their spending to $33.5 million in the primaries, but there are legal ways to skirt the rules. Money spent on fund-raising and on legal and accounting costs does not count toward the limit, and candidates are allowed to establish separate funds for complying with the arcane and complex Federal election laws.
In the general election, there is a much bigger loophole to exploit. Although the nominees don't raise any more private money and receive $70 million in public funds for the general election, parties can raise "soft money" -- unrestricted donations from unions, wealthy individuals and corporations -- to help elect their candidates. The two parties combined raised more than $250 million in such contributions in 1996 -- and it was in the soft-money arena that most of the campaign fund-raising abuses occurred.
The ghosts of past scandals loom over Gore's current efforts more than anyone else's. "There will be heightened scrutiny after 1996," says Lyn Utrecht, outside counsel to the Gore campaign. So the Vice President's finance and legal advisers have created an unusually onerous set of fund-raising rules. First and foremost, Gore will not personally solicit donors with telephone calls, a practice he stopped in 1997. He has also vowed not to use his official residence for ticketed fund-raising events. Campaign lawyers have held more than 300 briefings on election law for volunteer solicitors, and the campaign is scrutinizing the backgrounds of all solicitors and any checks drawn on foreign bank accounts. Campaign workers are told to follow even the smallest rules, right down to making sure all solicitation letters go out on campaign stationery.
Still, concedes Gore's campaign manager, Craig Smith, "No system is going to be perfect." In fact, there have already been a few glitches. Some suspicious donations that came in money orders may be returned. And the 850,000 pieces of direct mail sent out by the campaign in February went to some donors whose checks the campaign would not want. Among the receipients: Johnny Chung, the California donor who recently told Federal investigators that some of the $400,000 he had contributed to Democrats (since returned) came from the Chinese military.
Some of Gore's longtime fund-raisers are clearly irritated with the "by the book" mentality. A Miami solicitor complained that he had to get the text of his thank-you notes to donors approved by Washington. A solicitor in Los Angeles griped about being inactive while a background check was run: "I could have raised $100,000 in those two weeks."
Just forty-five minutes away from Geffen's estate, Maria Hsia sits in her cramped, smoke-filled office in a tiny strip mall in San Merino, a small Valley town with a large Asian population. These days Hsia still ekes out a living as an immigration consultant, but in light of last year's indictment, her career as a Democratic Party activist is over. Hsia first met Al Gore back in 1988 at the home of Pamela Harriman, the late doyenne of Democratic Party fund-raising. When Hsia and John Huang were seeking influential lawmakers to join them on a trip to Taiwan the next year, Gore was their only taker. Later, she helped raise $30,000 for Gore's 1990 Senate re-election and was there with financial and political help again in 1996. "I've met dozens of politicians," Hsia says. "The others came saying, 'Money, money.' By comparison, he is very genuine and caring."
Hsia's indictment stems from her involvement in the now infamous 1996 luncheon for Gore at the Hsi Lai Temple in nearby Hacienda Heights, where monks and nuns who had taken a vow of poverty donated $65,000 to the Democratic Party. It was illegal for the temple, a tax-exempt religious institution, to play host to a political fund-raiser, and some of the funds were allegedly "conduit contributions" -- money given through the donating worshipers, who were later reimbursed. Eventually, the Democratic Party returned the funds, and Hsia insists the case against her was baseless. (All but one of the six charges against Hsia have been thrown out; the Justice Department is appealing.)
Nevertheless, the incident was a major embarrassment. When he was first questioned, Gore insisted that it was just a "community outreach" event. Later, he conceded that his staff knew in advance that it was "finance related." Moreover, Hsia is one of a half-dozen Gore fund-raisers and supporters who have been investigated by the Congress and Justice Department and one of three who were indicted because of alleged 1996 fund-raising abuses. Another is Howard Glicken, a Miami businessman who raised $2million for the D.N.C. in 1996, visited the White House 70 times, festooned his two Jaguars with vanity license plates that read "Gore 1" and "Gore 2" -- and pleaded guilty last year to election-law violations.
So while the Gore loyalists McAuliffe and Knight are the reigning kings of Democratic fund-raising, that is something of a dubious distinction these days, and both men know it. Last year, Republicans on the House Commerce Committee questioned the legality of large lobbying fees Knight's firm has received from Democratic donors close to Gore. Ultimately, Knight and Gore were spared an independent-counsel investigation, and Knight (who says he will sever ties to his firm when he joins the campaign full time later this year) dismisses the Republican grumbling as both partisan and wrong.
But along with Gore's tortured defense of his fund-raising phone calls -- there was "no controlling legal authority" outlawing them -- this stream of allegations makes great fodder for his opponents. Already, the Republican Presidential aspirant John McCain has sniped: "The American people deserve a controlling ethical authority, as well as a controlling legal authority."
While Gore's fat war chest succeeded in driving off all Democrats but Bradley, that leaves only one credible alternative if Gore stumbles early in the primaries. Donors now have only two candidates competing for their money, and Bradley has recently been poaching on Gore territory, raising millions in San Francisco, Los Angeles and New York. "Our strategy of raising so much money so early may have succeeded too well," says one Gore adviser.
Finally, and perhaps most critically, there is the danger that Gore, to maintain his front-runner status, will concentrate too much on fund-raising. That's what Gary Koops thinks is happening, and his opinion is worth a listen: Now a Washington public relations consultant, Koops was an adviser to Senator Phil Gramm in 1996 -- when Gramm raised $8 million in the first three months of 1995, setting a record that Gore has just beaten. Gramm, too, was a powerful fund-raiser, and he didn't even make it to the primaries. As Koops puts it: "We've got the money' isn't a good campaign message."
Air Force II is on its way to sunny Palm Beach, and Al Gore is in an upbeat mood. He comes back to chat with the three reporters in his entourage. We all have copies of George Stephanopoulos's book, hot off the presses. Gore grabs one, looks in the index for his citations and glances at a few. As Gore well knows, almost everyone in the Clinton White House is furious over the book and the former adviser's disloyalty. But it seems the book has mainly nice things to say about the Vice President. "Looks O.K. to me," Gore jokes.
There is no question that the Vice President connects well in this sort of setting. But this setting is not what campaigns, in the end, are made of. Perhaps Gore's Hollywood friends are right to worry whether their candidate is a strong enough communicator -- a communicator of ideas, of charisma, of confidence, all the things that must be in place to deliver votes on a massive scale. Yet there won't be much time for such grandiose issues when Gore hits the ground in Florida today.
Gore's entourage races to a $1,000-a-head fund-raising luncheon at the Four Seasons. Then the Vice President dashes off to a lumber yard in an economically distressed section of Miami called Allapattah, where he gulps a Cuban coffee, gives a short speech and announces $25 million in Federal aid for the state's citrus industry. After that it's back-to-back fund-raisers at the Sheraton Bal Harbour.
Along the way, there is chicken breast and Chardonnay. There is the candidate at the podium, recognizing local officials. There is the joke about the 8-year-old boy in Minnesota. And when it's all over, there is another day's final tally: another $700,000 for Gore 2000.

HEADLINE: What's Doing In;
Los Angeles

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM; TODD S. PURDUM is chief of the Los Angeles bureau of The Times.

 BODY:
The early 1990's were the plague years in Los Angeles, as wildfires, riots, a devastating earthquake and the worst recession since the Great Depression left Southern California badly shaken and tourists scared away. Many of the problems underlying that social unrest remain, but the decade is nevertheless ending on a triumphant note, with the local economy booming, good news abounding and civic boosterism in full flower.
The city recently won the right to put its new face forward to the world at the Democratic National Convention, which will be held in August 2000 at the soon-to-be-finished Staples Arena downtown. It may also be on the verge of winning a National Football League expansion team that would play nearby at a newly refurbished Coliseum. 
 The new California Science Center in Exposition Park adjoining the Coliseum is drawing thousands of visitors to its interactive exhibits and IMAX movie screen, and several new restaurants have sprung up downtown as part of a fledgling effort to revitalize a neighborhood that has long tended to be deserted after dark. And fund-raising has been completed for the new Frank Gehry-designed Disney Concert Hall, to be built across from the Dorothy Chandler Pavilion downtown.
At the same time, Los Angeles is enjoying an unusually concentrated burst of high-profile theater productions, featuring big-name movie and television stars, while the streets of old Hollywood, the long-declining neighborhood where the movie industry began, are struggling toward a major revival. And the enduring pleasures of the broad strip of public beach in Santa Monica remain undiminished.
 
Events
The city's leading nonprofit theater, the Mark Taper Forum, on Grand Street between First and Temple, will stage two star attractions this spring and summer. First is "Enigma Variations," the American premiere of a work by the French playwright Eric-Emmanuel Schmitt. It stars Donald Sutherland as a reclusive Nobel Prize-winning novelist and Jamey Sheridan as a journalist sent to interview him, through June 13. On June 20, previews begin for a production of Eugene O'Neill's "Hughie," starring and directed by Al Pacino in a repeat of his 1996 run in New York. This character study of a Broadway gambler and a hotel night clerk also stars Paul Benedict. June 27 to July 25; $25 for previews, $29 to $40 for regular performances. Call (213) 628-2772.
Next door at the Los Angeles Music Center, the Ahmanson Theater will play host to a Shakespeare double bill directed by Sir Peter Hall. "Measure for Measure" and "A Midsummer Night's Dream" will be in repertory from June 6 through Aug. 1. Kelly McGillis will star in "A Midsummer Night's Dream"; Richard Thomas, in both plays. Tickets: $15 to $52.50; (213) 628-2772.
The Los Angeles County Museum of Art, 5905 Wilshire Boulevard, (323) 857-6000, whose blockbuster van Gogh exhibit closes May 16, follows that up with "Diego Rivera: Art and Revolution," which it bills as the first major retrospective of the master Mexican muralist in the United States in 13 years, from May 30 to Aug. 16. The exhibition features about 100 paintings, prints and drawings from Rivera's student years through his late Surrealist-influenced landscapes and portraits. Hours: Monday, Tuesday and Thursday noon to 8 P.M., Friday to 9 P.M., weekends 11 A.M. to 8 P.M. $7.
The Hollywood Bowl, the outdoor summer home of the Los Angeles Philharmonic, begins its season with "Brazil Nights" June 26 and 27, featuring Carlinhos Brown, Sergio Santos and Viver Brasil, a 20-member dance troupe. There is no better place for a picnic, especially with fireworks at the three-night Fourth of July spectacular featuring Peter, Paul and Mary on July 2, 3 and 4. Most performances at 7:30 P.M. Tickets $5 to $70; (323) 850-2000.
 
Sightseeing
One of the most popular new attractions in town is the California Science Center in Exposition Park, 700 State Drive, near the University of Southern California campus. This sprawling collection of interactive exhibits is a wonderful place for children of all ages. Even the escalators have see-through panels so you can watch the innards work. The Digestion Diner lets you roll a 20-foot digestive tract out of a cut-out waitress, and the High Wire Bicycle suspended 42 feet above the lobby lets the bold experience the pull of gravity (with a safety net just in case). The museum is overrun with schoolchildren on weekday mornings, but quieter after 1 P.M. Open daily, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. Free admission but $5 parking, and $3 to ride the High Wire Bicycle; (323) 724-3623. Adjoining the museum is the IMAX Theater, currently featuring, among its four films, "Everest," about an expedition to the world's highest mountaintop. Tickets $6.50; $3.75 for children, plus $1 more for movies in 3-D. Show times vary; call (213) 744-2014.
Hollywood Boulevard is the hoariest cliche of Tinseltown, with its Walk of Fame pink-terrazzo stars embedded in the sidewalk. This once sadly scarred strip has managed something of a rebound, with a new subway stop scheduled to open this summer and the corner of Hollywood and Highland now a giant construction site for the theater that will house the Academy Awards ceremony beginning in 2001. One of the most interesting new developments is the restored Egyptian Theater, a 1920's movie palace at 6712 Hollywood Boulevard, now the home of the American Cinematheque, a film and video exhibition organization that sponsors screenings of classic, revival and new films. For prices and program, call (323) 466-3456.
For another kind of movie palace experience, try the Million Dollar Theater at 307 South Broadway downtown. One of the grandest of the city's old silent-movie stalwarts, built in 1918, it is reminiscent of a Spanish cathedral, with carved wooden motifs and towering corinthian columns. The theater began a second life in the 1950's as a venue for Mexican movies featuring the comedian Cantinflas and live stage shows of Latin music. It has recently reopened on a limited basis after several dark years, and again promises weekend bills of Latin music.Information: (213) 473-0720; best to call weekends or check local listings.
 
Where to Stay
Its renovation was not scheduled to be finished until this week, but already, the Avalon, 9400 West Olympic Boulevard, has been drawing would-be hipsters. With 87 rooms in three motel-style buildings on the southern fringe of Beverly Hills, the former Beverly Carlton has been reimagined as a retro-chic retreat in soft green shades. It features modern conveniences, like CD stereos, laptop hookups and fax machines, and funky offerings, like Tarot readings, and has positioned itself as a low-cost alternative for those who can't yet afford the Mondrian. Rates from $150, to $250 for the penthouse; (800) 535-4715 or (310) 277-5221, fax (310) 277-4928.
The Beverly Plaza, 8384 West Third Street, near the Beverly Center mall on the edge of West Hollywood, is a reliable spot in a neighborhood where walking is possible, even a pleasure. This hotel houses a day spa, small outdoor pool and two saunas. Cava, a lively tapas restaurant, is just off the lobby. The 98 rooms are done in a Spanish Mediterranean style. Rates: $179 to $228, often lower depending on availability; (800) 624-6835, fax (323) 653-3464.
Budget: The Hotel del Capri, 10587 Wilshire Boulevard, is a simple motel-style spot along a strip of high-rise luxury apartment buildings in Westwood, near U.C.L.A. This is a good value, near many attractions, from shopping in Century City and Beverly Hills to the Getty Museum a couple of miles west. Some of the 78 rooms are efficiencies, and back rooms are quieter. Rates from $105 to $150. Heated outdoor pool, free parking and a free shuttle that, if available, can take guests to destinations within three miles of the hotel; (800) 444-6835, fax (310) 470-9999.
Luxury: On a hill less than a block from the beach, the Loews Santa Monica Beach Hotel, 1700 Ocean Avenue, Santa Monica, is a grand redoubt and also family friendly. Its airy, galleria-style lobby opens out to the ocean, and a pool deck has wonderful views. A first-class gym and an excellent new Provencal restaurant, Lavande, make this one of the most relaxing hotels in Los Angeles, and though nearby construction makes beach access less convenient at the moment, nothing can really spoil this spot. There are 345 rooms and 25 suites, all with contemporary decor; rates from $235 for nonocean view rooms to $325 for full ocean view, with partial views at $275; (800) 223-0888, fax (310) 458-6761.
L'Ermitage, at 9291 Burton Way, a broad boulevard in a residential part of Beverly Hills, has recently been renovated, and its contemporary-style rooms in soft tones attract the likes of Isabella Rossellini and Whitney Houston. Gardenlike atmosphere with rooftop pool and 124 rooms, 8 of them suites. Doubles: $295 to $448, depending on availability; (800) 800-2113, fax (310) 278-8247.
 
Where to Eat
If any cuisine is hot in Los Angeles these days, it is the broad family of country French, and no place is hotter than Lucques (pronounced Luke), a cozy spot within the bare brick walls of the onetime carriage house of Harold Lloyd at 8474 Melrose Avenue in West Hollywood. Homey specialties like beef short ribs with mashed potatoes and horseradish cream share space with lamb, fish and game in grilled, baked and roasted Mediterranean preparations. A bar menu is served until midnight. Delicious desserts and a fairly priced wine list with many French and Italian selections. Dinner for two with wine, $150. Reservations (essential): (323) 655-6277.
For a parade of Pan-American dishes in a sleek, humming setting, head for Ciudad, in the newly happening downtown at 445 South Figueroa Street, the latest venture of the Two Hot Tamales team of Mary Milliken and Susan Feniger. The ingredients, not to mention the exotic house cocktails, may be unfamiliar, but plunge into the mixed Spanish antipasto plate of aged manchego cheese, marinated olives and peppers, tomato croutons, chorizo and spiced almonds and you'll never look back. Entrees like tamarind-glazed salmon go beautifully with first courses like plaintain gnocchi in tomatillo cream. Try the coconut cream cake with pineapple granita for dessert. Dinner for two with tropical cocktails and a modest Spanish wine, $100; there is a $36 pretheater menu; (213) 486-5171.
For after-theater chow, no place is more venerable than the Pacific Dining Car, an old-fashioned red-leather institution at 1310 West Sixth Street near downtown, open 24 hours a day. It serves not only giant steaks, but such late-night reliables as smoked salmon and homemade roast beef hash, plus a perfect martini in an elegant trumpet-shaped glass. Not cheap, a bit musty, but the real thing. Dinner for two with drinks, $85; less for eggs and such; (213) 483-6000.
Scores of barbecue restaurants coexist in the city's thriving Koreatown. One of the best is Chung KiWa, 3545 West Olympic Boulevard, a tidy, crowded place where gas braziers are built into wood tables; you can grill your own marinated short ribs, pork, shrimp, rib eye and so on, to be wrapped in a leaf of romaine like a taco. A platter of accompaniments, including the fiery kim-chi, rounds out the meal. Dinner for two: $60 with beer and sake; (323) 737-0809.
For a true cross-cultural immersion, try another Koreatown spot, Guelaguetza, 3337 1/2 West Eighth Street, this one offering Mexican specialties from Oaxaca. Try the black mole tamales in banana leaf, and the tlayudas, pizza-like giant flour tortillas smeared with mashed beans, dried meats, tomatoes and cheese. Dinner for two, $25 (bring your own wine or beer); (213) 427-0601.

HEADLINE: ART/ARCHITECTURE;
Monuments of Stone, Testaments to an Island

BYLINE: By KATHRYN SHATTUCK 

 BODY:
TODAY the residents of Vinalhaven Island, Me., nestled in Penobscot Bay some 15 miles off Rockland, boast of their lobstering industry and an aversion to tourists. But nearly a century ago, the tiny island, roughly nine miles long and five miles wide, had another source of pride: its cliffs and knolls provided the granite for some of the nation's most imposing structures, among them the Brooklyn Bridge, the United States Custom House and the Cathedral of St. John the Divine in New York.
The history of the island's quarries, and specifically the erection of eight monumental columns in the cathedral's sanctuary, are the subject of an exhibition lining the cathedral's photography wall. "The Eight Columns of Worship: A Tribute to Human Ingenuity and Faith" tells the story behind the buildings that stand as a testament to the majesty and endurance of Vinalhaven granite. And though the photographs and artifacts are on view only through next Sunday, the structures themselves will live on as a kind of three-dimensional exhibit -- one that is being documented anew by Chester Higgins Jr., a photographer for The New York Times and an occasional visitor to the island. 
 "My love for stone comes from my love for ancient Egyptian architecture," Mr. Higgins said. "While visiting the island I heard that they had these quarries, and through my research I discovered that so much of the stuff that came from the island landed in New York. I was fascinated."
He set out to photograph the stone monuments whose impact on society transcended time but whose architectural style fell out of favor after only a few decades.
"The use of steel and reinforced concrete replaced the massive granite buildings," said Roy Heisler of the Vinalhaven Historical Society, where the exhibition originated. "The importance is the legacy of the stones, and the great buildings that were produced with them."
Settled by fishermen in the late 18th century, Vinalhaven reached its population peak (2,855) in 1880, when the quarries employed some 1,500 men from New England, Canada and Britain.
What made Vinalhaven granite unique was not only its superb quality and color -- a warm pinkish-gray -- but the ease with which it could be transported off the island. By the 1850's, the Bodwell & Webster quarry (later the Bodwell Granite Company) had received a number of Federal contracts for reinforcements at forts along the Atlantic and gulf coasts. But the demand for granite escalated enormously after the Civil War, when a trend toward European grandeur in American architecture sent the Government scurrying for an economical but beautiful stone to use in custom houses, post offices, dams, bridges and banks as far west as St. Louis. The stones used in the Pennsylvania Railroad Station in Philadelphia, the Chicago Board of Trade Building, the Executive Office Building and part of the Washington Monument were culled from the Vinalhaven quarries.
At the same time, the architect George Heins had set out in search of the stone for the cathedral's eight columns. He ultimately chose Bodwell's Wharff Quarry. With its 100-foot-tall ridge of nearly flawless virgin granite, the quarry could easily accommodate the columns' dimensions: 54 feet long and 6 feet in diameter.
The first block of granite, extracted in August 1899, was some 64 feet long and 8 1/2 feet wide and weighed about 300 tons. After being cut from the bed, each block was hewn with hand tools to within 3 inches of a column's finished dimension. In order to turn and polish the columns, the quarry commissioned the world's largest lathe, a behemoth weighing 135 tons that became an overnight media sensation.
But disaster struck. As it neared completion, the first column suddenly snapped in the lathe. The second and third columns soon followed suit. By August 1901, the architects had determined that a single block of such proportions could not withstand the pressure of the turning on the lathe. They decided to build the columns in two pieces: a 90-ton, 36-foot-long lower monolith and a 40-ton, 18-foot-long upper portion that could be reattached so as not to be noticeable.
On July 2, 1903, the first two columns and their bases were loaded for the trip to New York aboard a specially designed barge. After being pulled through the Atlantic, into Long Island Sound and up the Hudson River, the barge arrived at the West 134th Street pier eight days later.
The moving and erecting of the columns is widely considered among the world's most remarkable engineering feats. When the tide was right, the columns were rolled off the barge using its huge derrick, a timber hitch and an inclined plane. A truck with wooden wheels, pulled ahead by a powerful winch some 300 feet at a time, then carried the column pieces through the streets of New York to 112th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, a journey of about two miles. It took 19 days.
Finally, a derrick made of two 96-foot lengths of Oregon pine and powered by three steam engines was constructed to swing the columns into place atop the bases. By Nov. 25, 1904, all eight columns were in position, waiting for the walls to be built around them.
The onset of modern construction techniques put an end to major quarrying in 1918, but paving blocks continued to be exported until 1939. Aside from a smattering of rusty pieces of machinery, the only existing evidence of Vinalhaven's legacy is a single column.
"It's a flawed column, remaining right on the shore," Mr. Heisler said. "It's overgrown, but its meaning is fairly evident."

SECTION: Section 2; Page 48; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk

HEADLINE: ART / ARCHITECTURE;
Unshackled to Capture Their Country Again

BYLINE: By LYLE REXER; Lyle Rexer, an art critic, is writing a book on old-process photography.

 BODY:
AT the turn of the century, Hungary was the most photo-obsessed country in the world. Princes and princesses of the Austro-Hungarian Empire frequented photo exhibitions and proudly displayed their own prints. From a nation the size of Indiana emerged many of the leading names of modern photography, including Andre Kertesz, Brassai, Laszlo Moholy-Nagy and Robert Capa. But four decades of Communist rule isolated Hungarian photography from this artistic heritage, from the outside world and from many of its subjects.
Now, at the turn of a new century, Hungarian photographers are struggling to rebuild that tradition. Free at last to point the camera where they please, they are creating an idiosyncratic amalgam of imagination and international styles dimly glimpsed. This combination may be the perfect vehicle to express their ambivalence about the world after Communism. 
 "We have been forced to make up our history as we go along," said Sandor Szilagyi, who has organized a series of exhibitions of Hungarian photography at the Hungarian Consulate on East 52d Street in New York. "There are masters but no movements, personalities but no trends." Two current exhibitions of contemporary Hungarian photography display the diversity of this improvised avant-garde: "Kind of Blue: Six Documentary Photographers" (organized by Mr. Szilagyi at the Consulate) and "Hungary Today: Five Contemporary Photographers" (at the Sarah Morthland Gallery in Chelsea). A self-taught quality pervades this work. Wheels are reinvented and continents discovered. But if this made-up modernism sometimes looks almost familiar, it is just as often unpredictable and daring.
It is ironic that this generation of photographers should have to reinvent photography, because Hungarian photography once ruled the world. In the 1920's, Moholy-Nagy defined the Bauhaus photographic style with compositions that featured bold, abstract geometries. Kertesz melded a sense of visual form and an instinctive feel for the meaningful instant.
Brassai, whose Paris years are now the subject of a major exhibition at the Getty Museum in Los Angeles, helped forge the myth of modern Paris as a place of hedonism and creativity. Capa, the prototype of the photojournalist, provided the 20th century some of its most dramatic images of war. His brother, Cornell, went on to found the International Center for Photography in New York. In documentary and art photography, these expatriates bequeathed a many-dimensioned visual idiom we think of not as Hungarian but as modern.
The current generation of Hungarians never had a chance to claim that inheritance. The upheavals of right-wing authoritarian rule, World War II and 40 years of Communism narrowed the scope of photography. The door to the West slammed shut, and official policy transformed pictorial realism into soft-focus folk cliches. Photographers could not view original prints by the great expatriate Hungarians, who remained largely just names. Other native experimental work was almost as inaccessible. One of Hungary's largest photo collections -- nearly 400,000 images -- was tucked away in a private apartment. Artists worked alone and met informally, sharing unsanctioned innovations.
Photography deemed "conceptual" or "formalist" was taken off gallery walls, pulled from exhibitions and confiscated from private homes. The knowledge of basic photographic processes eroded.
In this climate, today's photographers used whatever inspiration they could find to reinvent photographic tradition. In their work, opportunism constantly triumphs over orthodoxy. Jozsef Hajdu, represented in last year's Consulate group, taught himself about the history of the medium by working as an archivist of the photographs collected by the old Imperial Post Office in Budapest. Mr. Hadju's roots are grittily documentary, influenced by the routines of factory life near his home. But he has read other lessons in the images he studies, and his black-and-white photos of his own grimy teacup transform a proletarian realism into a lyrical play of abstract forms and liquid textures.
Gabor Kerekes has taken the most extreme steps to reclaim photography as a medium of individual expression. Mr. Kerekes, now in his late 50's, had been the premier Hungarian photojournalist of the 70's. His dispassionate, even icy style enabled him to convey in the image of an empty factory, for example, a guarded pessimism that was difficult for the Communists to censor and impossible to conscript into any campaign for a brighter future. His was a highly influential vocabulary of constraint. In 1982, he abandoned his career. "I had grown tired of making images ordered by someone else," he said during a visit to New York last year. He could have been speaking for his entire generation. He destroyed all but 20 or so of his images, which he donated to the Hungarian Museum, and turned inward. "I couldn't see in the real world what I sought emotionally and spiritually," he added.
For eight years, Mr. Kerekes immersed himself in the study of, among other subjects, philosophy, natural history and alchemy. Just as Hungary emerged from Communism, he emerged from artistic hibernation with a repertory of disturbing visions and an intense interest in old photographic techniques.
His pictures, often salt or albumen prints, are richly toned nightmares: a truncated elephant's foot, antique and sinister scientific equipment, a murky, apocalyptic sunset, body parts. His closest counterpart in the West is probably Joel Peter Witkin. His work has inspired an old-process movement in Hungary. In part, the movement tries to make a virtue of necessity, compensating for a lack of money to invest in exotic digital technology. For Mr. Kerekes, however, repossessing the past and reinventing the present go hand in hand.
Yet the work of Zsolt Peter Barta, a protege of Mr. Kerekes, suggests that in the country of "masters but no movements," a movement may be taking shape. Unlike earlier avant-gardes, its members share no style but rather an attitude. They face the world after Communism with deep ambivalence. Mr. Barta's series of close-up black-and-white photos of preserved human cadavers, for example, can be seen, once the shock wears off, as an attempt to come to terms with the continuing impact of the political past. Free to depict any subject, he is drawn to those that suggest a perpetual inhumanity, preserved in the formaldehyde of memory.
The ambivalence is most obvious in the work of the documentary photographers, who, perhaps even more than art photographers, feel compelled to make up a new tradition. So Imre Benko has developed a monumental style to counter the heroic nationalism that was Hungary's cold war staple. His new Hungary is a series of incongruities. In one image, an impromptu barbecue takes place outside an enormous housing project. In another, a worker in a steel town looks up at the towering remnants of a dead industry that has just barely failed to squeeze the life out of him. Like so many Hungarians, Mr. Benko seems suspicious of every political gesture, refraining from criticism and celebration.
MORE partisan are Judit M. Horvath and Gyorgy Stalter, who are doing for Hungary's Gypsy minority what the Farm Services Administration photographers did for the rural poor in the United States: asserting their dignity and calling attention to their economic condition. Renouncing official folk images of Gypsy life, Ms. Horvath and Mr. Stalter have forged a documentary style that imports the grandeur and drama of the Magnum photojournalists, typified by Robert Capa.
The desperate search for a method has left its mark on all the photographers who came of age under Communism, but a younger generation doesn't feel the need to shoulder the burden of starting from scratch. To artists like Lenke Szilagyi, the past and the world are available. Although farthest removed from the legacy of Kertesz and least concerned about recovering it, she may be closest to it in spirit. In her black-and-white images of difficult rural lives lived in an unlovely Hungary, she orients herself toward a living presence, however minimized or despairing. She seems to say there will always be a need for the eye that can divine the essential moments of our humanity.
In March, Hungary dedicated the House of Culture for Photography, in the renovated Budapest mansion and studio of the former Austro-Hungarian court photographer Mano Mai. It is modeled on New York's International Center for Photography. With a new museum and an international outlook, with the Internet and travel to Paris and New York, some Hungarian artists are beginning to wonder what will sustain their work when it leaves the shadows for the global glare, when idiosyncrasy gives way to international influence and the masters join movements. After his initial enthusiasm at visiting the Museum of Modern Art, Mr. Barta wondered if he had lost his innocence. "We need a context for our work, yes," he said, "but we also need to think we are inventing something new."

HEADLINE: Commercial Property;
In New Orleans, Developers Rush to Add Hotels

BYLINE: By SHAWN G. KENNEDY 

DATELINE: NEW ORLEANS

 BODY:
THE enduring allure of the French Quarter coupled with the city's role as host to such spirited street parties as Mardi Gras and the annual New Orleans Jazz and Heritage Festival have secured its place as a top vacation spot. But increasingly travelers are in town on business -- at least for part of their stay.
The result has been a strong demand for hotel rooms by travelers to conventions and trade shows. To meet that demand, 13 hotel projects are in various stages of construction, 10 of them new hotels and the rest expansions of existing hotels. Half a dozen additional projects are in the preconstruction development phase. All this activity follows the opening of a dozen new hotels over the last three years. 
 The New Orleans Metropolitan Convention and Visitors Bureau puts the annual average occupancy rate at 75 percent, compared with 73 percent five years ago. In that time, 7,000 hotel rooms have been added for a total of 28,000.
"People think of New Orleans as a tourist town," said John Keeling, a hotel specialist in the Houston office of PKF Consulting, a real estate consulting company. "But now, first and foremost, it is a convention town."
The new hotels include the independently owned and operated International House and the St. James Hotel and franchise operations -- Holiday Inn, Sheraton, Marriott, and Promus Hotel Corporation, whose brands in New Orleans are Hampton Inn and Embassy Suites.
A major catalyst for the sustained growth, hotel operators and developers say, has been the 360,000-square-foot expansion of the city's riverfront convention center. The third phase of the Ernest N. Morial Convention Center, completed earlier this year, brought its space to 1.1 million square feet. Built on the riverfront more than 15 years ago as the Lousiana State Pavilion for the 1984 World's Fair, which rose in what is now the Warehouse District, the center has been host to more than one million out-of-town people each year.
As an event the World's Fair did not draw as many visitors as the city had hoped, said William Langkopp, executive vice president of the Louisiana Hotel and Motel Association. But it did open up the riverfront and drew people into the warehouse area, which had never been considered for hotels, restaurants and shops.
The recent hotel development trend here has been different from development in other prominent convention destinations, such as Las Vegas, Nev., or Orlando, Fla. With few exceptions, the new hotels are opening in the central business district or in the warehouse area. Both neighborhoods are within walking distance of the French Quarter and the riverfront.
MOREOVER, a majority of the new hotels are small to mid-sized projects -- 150 to 350 rooms. Statistics gathered by the New Orleans Metropolitan Visitors and Convention Bureau show that over the next two years about 2,350 rooms will be added to the present inventory.
The lodgings are usually five to 15 stories high, a modest scale dictated almost entirely by city policies that have simultaneously limited the number of available sites for new construction and spurred the redevelopment of underutilized properties that the city has deemed worth saving.
"The city realized that there were many neighborhoods and buildings worth preserving beyond those in our traditional historic areas like the French Quarter and the Garden District," said John Williams, an architect who has been involved in the designs of several gut-renovation projects, including the Ritz-Carlton Hotel. "So you have projects like the Queen & Crescent hotel, which preserves the city's first high rise and gives the business district a new hotel."
The City Council reviews every demolition petition in historic districts, which now include most of the warehouse and central business districts. Most buildings 50 years or older qualify for protection. But to encourage development in these areas, the city provides a restoration tax abatement that freezes the assessment to the predevelopment level for at least five years.
Potentially of even more value to developers taking on gut renovations of these properties is the Federal historic rehabilitation tax credit, which allows developers of qualified properties to recover up to 20 percent of the redevelopment costs.
Marriott International's recent expansion in New Orleans illustrates some aspects of the current hotel development trend. Until 1997 the only hotel in the central part of the city operated by Marriott was the 54-story, 1,290-room Marriott New Orleans, a convention hotel on Canal Street. But changes in the city's guest profile encouraged Marriott to expand its presence here.
WITH New Orleans-based TVG Group, whose partners are Steve Manshel and Henry O'Connor, serving as the builder and owner, Marriott has opened two Courtyards in the last two years. A Residence Inn by Marriott, an extended-stay hotel, opened in 1997 and a Marriott Renaissance, a moderate-rate hotel, is scheduled to open in the middle of 2001.
"Our Courtyard product has been a successful suburban hotel concept," said Craig E. Lambert, senior vice president for moderate and economy brands for the Marriott Corporation, based in Bethesda, Md. "But we discovered that in New Orleans people wanted the Courtyard brand in the urban area where there are exciting and fun things going on."
The Marriott Courtyard that opened last December went into a building that included the gut renovation of a molasses factory and a newly built section. The new 202-room Courtyard is on Julia Street in the heart of the Warehouse District.
Mr. Lambert said that it was usually difficult to justify the cost of a newly built Courtyard in urban areas. The tax incentives offer a way of doing it in New Orleans at the price point people will pay, he said.
In New Orleans Marriott Courtyard nightly room rates range from $100 to $150 depending on the season, which is well below the rate range for the company's full-service hotel on Canal Street where rooms range between $180 and $225.
By far the largest and most ambitious of the gut-renovation projects is on Canal Street, where the landmarked Maison Blanche department store is being transformed into a Ritz-Carlton hotel. The $200-million project, which will include the renovation of the adjacent Kress building and Maison Blanche annex, is being developed by White House L.L.C., based in Baton Rouge, which owns the buildings. The development partnership includes Bernard Mason, William Hindman and Stewart Juneau, who is the managing partner.
In recent years the 530,000-square-foot building has been less and less profitable as a department store. But Mr. Juneau was convinced of its potential as a luxury hotel because of its location on the western boundary of the French Quarter and because of the city's strong hotel market.
"Occupancy is improving and room rates are rising," said Mr. Juneau. But historic rehabilitation tax credits were an essential component of this project.
The hotel, scheduled to open next fall, will have 452 rooms, 25,000 square feet of meeting space, including a 10,000-square-foot column free ballroom; a mezzanine level spa and street level shopping arcade. Room rates will range from $305 to $335, said Mr. Mason, one of the developers.
The project will also include an all-suite hotel, to be known as the Quarter Suites, also managed by the Ritz-Carlton. Room rates have yet to be set.
Despite the pace of hotel development, industry analysts do not see a potential glut of rooms in the foreseeable future. The main reason is a shortage of available sites or redevelopable buildings in the areas where hotel operators need to be.
While the national chains have entered the New Orleans market, there are limits, Mr. Keeling believes, to their willingness to expand. "This will help bring about an equilibrium," he said. "And the shortage of rooms may continue for an extended period."

HEADLINE: In the Region /New Jersey;
As Available Sites Dwindle, Housing Prices Rise

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
WHEN Alexandra M. Sirio sold her two-bedroom town-house unit in Mahwah last month, it fetched more than $10,000 above the $176,000 she paid for it two years ago. But she did not realize that trading up to a single-family detached house elsewhere in Bergen County would be fraught with frustration.
Ms. Sirio, a legal secretary who is in her 30's, lost three houses because other buyers snapped them up before she made an offer or made higher bids than she was willing to pay. Even the three-bedroom colonial in Westwood she will close on next month drew multiple offers over the list price price of $299,900 -- including her successful bid in "the low $300,000 range." 
 "I'm not overjoyed," she said, "and a little discouraged by the state of the market and that I had to fight for the house."
Nunzio and Theresa Guarnieri, empty-nesters in their 50's, knew they were ready to trade the ranch they have lived in for 20 years in Hillsdale for a maintenance-free condominium town house when they found an enclave of 43 such homes going up in nearby Westwood. The couple, who have two grown children, have contracted to buy one of the three-bedroom houses, priced in the $300,000 range, and will put their three-bedroom ranch on the market this week.
"We really only looked at this house and think we're getting our money's worth," said Mr. Guarnieri, who manages technology for call centers for a national bank. Mrs. Guarnieri is a homemaker. "We also feel our house will sell in the hot market," he added. Buying one house and selling the other "will be a net-net for us," Mr. Guarnieri said, noting that the monthly cost of carrying the new home -- in the $1,000 range -- will be equal to what they pay on their existing house.
Both experiences suggest the myriad sides of the state's housing market, which has steadily strengthened over the last two and a half years and now is reaching what some industry professionals call a frenzied pace. The frenzy comes from too many buyers chasing too few houses, which is pushing up prices, they add.
All segments of the market, from the entry level to luxury housing and from town houses to one-family detached houses are moving, said Hal Maxwell, senior vice president of New York operations for Coldwell Banker, a residential brokerage in Short Hills. Mr. Maxwell, who covers Bergen and Hudson Counties, added: "Jersey City and Saddle River are feeling the same pressures."
The pressures extend, in varying degrees, across the state. Buyers, confident of a vibrant economy, are eager to make down payments, said Gloria Woodward, president of the New Jersey Association of Realtors, adding that "the issue is the lack of inventory."
While it's a seller's market, added Jacelyn Botti, regional vice president at Weichert Realtors in Morris Plains, potential sellers "are not listing their properties, because they are afraid when it comes to their purchase there will be nowhere to go."
As for new homes, 30,000 housing permits were issued in the state last year, lifting the production level out of the recessionary doldrums of the early 90's, said Patrick O'Keefe, chief executive of the New Jersey Builders Association in Plainsboro. But, he added, that is "the end of the good news" because with "the inventory of approved land dwindling rapidly and little land in the approval process" there will be a logjam in production.
The Otteau Appraisal Group, based in East Brunswick, reported that while statewide sales activity in the first quarter of this year rose 5 to 10 percent from last year, the inventory of homes was down 30 percent. The activity in Monmouth County reflects the trend, data from the group showed.
IN that time contracts were signed for 2,541 homes in the county, up from 1,977, or 29 percent, from 1998. Meanwhile, there were 3,430 homes available for sale, downfrom 4,382, or 22 percent, from a year earlier.
Jeffrey G. Otteau, the firm's president, said that homes were often selling within days, rather than months, which was the case last year. Residential brokers say buyers are now anxious to get pre-approved for mortgages and even, in some cases, forgoing home inspections.
The average statewide sale price for existing homes in the fourth quarter of 1998, the latest figures available, was $190,400, up about 3 percent from the same time the year before, according to the realtors association. For new homes the average price was $254,296, up an average of about 12 percent from a year earlier, data from the New Jersey Builders Association show.
David J. Schoner vice president of the new homes division at Coldwell Banker, likened the home-buying activity in the state to "a gold rush of sorts." He said his company had closed 1,892 homes in 1998, 400 more than the year before.
Industry professionals agreed that along with the supply-demand imbalance factors stoking the activity include low mortgage interest rates -- which have inched up, but are still more than reasonable by historic standards -- and the state's economy and job market.
The economy is now in its 84th month of recovery, surpassing by one month the boom of the 1980's, said James W. Hughes, dean of the Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers University, noting that since 1992 the state had gained 400,000 new jobs. "The economy and jobs define the locomotive engine of housing demand," Dr. Hughes said, adding that the state should be "recession free until the next millennium."
Concerns remain, particularly about further price jumps and bidding wars, which do not happen in all sales, but are on the rise, brokers said. "It's not a pleasant market for buyers," said Ms. Woodward of the Realtors Association. "I just hope prices don't become so inflated that potential buyers will leave the market."
Added Mr. O'Keefe of the New Jersey Builders Association: "First-time buyers looking for new homes in New Jersey are an endangered species."
Mr. Otteau of the appraisal firm said though the average price increase of 10 percent since the last quarter of 1998 will grow to 15 percent by mid-summer, the price jumps are "not anywhere near the 30 percent increases" of the mid-80's.
By July higher prices and mortgage rates will lead "to a temporary pause and a slackening in demand," he projected, and the market, because of the healthy economy, will rebound by mid-September. He added that prices would continue their rise, but at a slower pace. "Buyers today will not aggressively chase prices as they did in the 80's," he added.
The challenges to builders, said John G. Udell, president of Weichert New Homes and Land Company, are rising land and construction costs, a lengthy approval process and competition from conservationists -- and the state -- for land. It takes much longer to build a home and "it's only getting worse," making a weak production level even weaker, he said.
Mr. O'Keefe predicted that "construction will slow later this year and into 2000" as the inventory of land for which construction approvals have been received dwindles.
Though there may be a production gap, Mr. Otteau said, some developers have been building inventories of unapproved land to counter the situation.
Westminster Communities, a division of the Kushner Companies of Florham Park, for example, has about 9,000 units in the pipeline it will build on land it purchased or is under contract to purchase and will take through the approval process. "You can buy land, but the prices are high, and sometimes so prohibitive that a project doesn't economically work," said Charles Kushner, president of Kushner Companies.
Meanwhile, the developer expects to produce 400 one-family attached and detached houses this year, up from 340 last year and 300 in 1997. Among them is the Enclave at Westwood, where the Guarnieris intend to live. It is rising on a site on Third Avenue, once occupied by a school, that the town rezoned for its current use and auctioned off. Mr. Kushner said his company was willing to pay $3 million for the site because it was in Bergen County where available land is scarce and it had been approved for housing, removing the risk.
The 43 houses, with 2,000 to 2,200 square feet of space, are selling for $320,000 on average, up from $265,000 since sales began last October. So far contracts have been signed or are pending on 23 homes. "It's a stable investment," Mr. Guarnieri said "We're not looking for phenomenal appreciation, we're looking for it to be steady."
