HEADLINE: There Is No Joy, But Wait a Year

BYLINE: By JOHN RATHER 

DATELINE: CENTRAL ISLIP

 BODY:
THERE will be no professional baseball on Long Island again this season, no pop-ups rising impossibly high into the night sky, no diving catches in center or close plays at the plate, no rhubarbs or homers or scoreboard pyrotechnics. But wait until next year.
In April 2000, a Wall Street investment banker and former high school catcher, Frank Boulton of Brightwaters, together with a former New York Mets shortstop and manager, Bud Harrelson of Hauppauge, plans to field a new minor league team called the Long Island Ducks. 
 When the Ducks take the home field for the first time, trotting from the dugout of a brand-new 6,000-seat, $18.9 million ball park now in the early stages of construction here, all the goose eggs posted in previous efforts to bring pro baseball to sports-minded Long Island will fall away, its promoters say.
Years and even decades after minor league baseball arrived in Connecticut, New Jersey and cities up and down the Eastern Seaboard, the 2.6 million people on Long Island will at last have a club of their own.
Politicians and promoters who attended groundbreaking ceremonies here last month said this would be a game with no losers.
Long Island, they said, will get professional-caliber baseball featuring players who were once in the major leagues or came close. Suffolk County hopes to recover a $4.5 million investment in the ball park, which it will own, at a rate of $460,755 a year in rent, ticket surcharges and other revenue. The Ducks will lease the park and remain there by contract until at least 2010.
Most important, Long Island fans will pay $4 to $9 for seats that are all close to the field -- there will be no bleachers -- in a state-of-the-art park where a hot dog and a soda won't cost an arm and a leg. There will be 42 concession and souvenir windows, and 20 sky boxes. About 3,000 season tickets are now being sold, but at each game, another 3,000 will be available at the gate.
"The whole mission here is affordable family sports entertainment," Mr. Boulton said.
The ball park has too few seats to be called a stadium, Mr. Boulton said, but the field will have major league dimensions: the fence in dead center will be 400 feet from home plate, and the right and left field lines will be 325 feet. The field will be grass, and bats will be wood, not aluminum. "Aluminum bats are dangerous," said Mr. Harrelson, who is co-owner and manager of the Ducks.
Suffolk County paid the state slightly more than $2 million last year to acquire 11.3 acres of what used to be the grounds of the Central Islip Psychiatric Center. State Senator Owen H. Johnson, a Republican of Babylon, obtained a $14.4 million grant from the Empire State Development Corporation, a state agency, for the bulk of the financing, officials said. Mr. Boulton said that together, he and Mr. Harrelson invested "north of a million," but declined to be more specific.
George Gatta, the deputy Suffolk County executive for economic development and planning, said the county would get additional revenue by charging a fee for a sponsor to name the park. He said the county was soliciting proposals.
Mr. Gatta said the park would also benefit from $10 million in road improvements made in recent years to ease access and add parking for adjacent buildings, including the county's Cohalan Court Complex and a Federal courthouse now under construction. He said a 2,000-car parking lot for the courts would be available to ball park patrons at night, when all weekday games will be played. The park will also have a new 223-space lot closer to the field.
The Ducks will play a 140-game season as one of eight teams in the Atlantic League, an independent minor league -- not affiliated with Major League Baseball -- founded by Mr. Boulton three years ago.
Other Atlantic League teams, most of which are also playing in new parks, include the Bridgeport Bluefish in Connecticut, the Newark Bears and the Somerset Patriots in New Jersey, the Lehigh Valley Black Diamonds in Pennsylvania and the Nashua Pride in New Hampshire. Two more teams will be added by next year, Mr. Boulton said.
He said Ducks players would range from veterans with major league experience to younger prospects moving up through the minors. Players, he said, will be able to showcase their talents for all major league clubs simultaneously, giving them greater flexibility than those in major league farm systems, who are tied to one big-league club.
But some Ducks, Mr. Harrelson said, will play for the love of the game, with little hope of making the majors. "No one ever wants to quit," said Mr. Harrelson, whose big-league playing career spanned more than a decade. "It's just such a great game, and you feel so good about yourself when you're playing."
The Ducks certainly won't be playing just for the money. Mr. Boulton said the average salary would be about $2,500 a month, more than the $800 some minor leaguers earn but a long way from the $200,000-a-season minimum paid in the majors.
Mr. Harrelson said players would come from the more than 300 cut from spring training each year by major league teams and their farm clubs. "We are really looking for people with previous experience in professional baseball," he said.
Mr. Harrelson, who came up through the minors to join the Mets in 1965, was a member of the Miracle Mets, the world champions in 1969. He is remembered for a bench-clearing brawl that broke out during the 1973 playoff series between the Mets and the Cincinnati Reds, when Pete Rose barreled into him as he covered second during a double play.
For the last 30 years, Mr. Harrelson said, he has been one of only a handful of big leaguers -- and the only Met -- living in Suffolk County. Mr. Harrelson said his Hauppauge home is less than 10 miles from the new ball park. "Utmost for me," he said, "is that I will be doing something for the county and really for all of Long Island."
The Ducks' principal owner, Mr. Boulton, who was born and raised in the Brightwaters area, has operated minor league franchises in Albany, Wilmington, Del., and Prince William, Va.
In 1992, the Mets opposed his plan to move the Albany Yankees, a farm team for the New York Yankees, to a 6,000-seat stadium to be built with $7.5 million from Suffolk County at the county's community college in Brentwood. The Mets objected that a Long Island team would infringe on territorial rights they shared with the New York Yankees, hurting ticket sales. The objection was upheld by a panel of major and minor league representatives.
David C. Howard, the Mets' senior vice president for business and legal affairs, said last week that because the Ducks were not affiliated with Major League Baseball, the team and the Atlantic League were exempt from the territorial rule.
Mr. Howard said the Mets didn't believe the Ducks would draw away fans. "The quality of play is so very different," he said. "By definition, they are players who for whatever reason haven't attracted the interest of the major league programs."
The Ducks got off to a shaky start. In November, the Suffolk County Legislature rejected a $4.5 million bond issue to help pay for the ball park, despite strong support from County Executive Robert J. Gaffney and other top county officials.
Opponents of the bond said backers of the park had concealed the true cost of the project two weeks earlier, when the legislature had accepted the $14.4 million state grant they said was supposed to cover project costs. "I just thought it was bait and switch," said Steve Levy, a Democratic legislator from Holbrook.
The legislators approved the county bond in December.
Mr. Levy, a former Little League shortstop and an avid Mets fan since childhood, said he expected that Long Island would embrace the Ducks.
"It's inexpensive to go to a game, and you can have your kids back in bed by 11," he said. "The players are accessible and don't have attitudes like a lot of those millionaires you'll find in the big leagues. Little kids can go right up and touch them."

LENGTH: 1812 words

HEADLINE: In New London, Creating Jobs, Building a Buzz For Revival

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON 

 BODY:
THE stately homes along the Thames River in New London testify to an era of extravagance, a time when waterborne commerce and whaling brought wealth to the city.
Many decades have passed since its economic peak. Most of the city's factories began to head South in the 1960's, employment declined as the submarine maker Electric Boat scaled back, and large sections of downtown were ripped up for redevelopment projects that never happened. But over the past year there has been a revitalization buzz in the city, most notably because of the announcement a year ago that the pharmaceutical giant Pfizer would build a $250 million research complex employing 2,100. In addition, the long-dormant New London Development Corporation, a private economic development group working closely with state and local government agencies, has targeted six downtown sites for development. It has also prepared a plan for the reuse of the former Naval Undersea Warfare Center, which left 30 acres of waterfront commercial property vacant when it pulled out of town two years ago. 
 The corporation is considering how to make the best use of a rebuilt deep-water pier, an unused foreign trade zone that offers benefits to importers, and a little-used downtown enterprise zone that offers tax breaks and other incentives to employers. There are also public improvements planned, the most ambitious a $15 million waterfront park that the city hopes to have in place for the arrival of Opsail 2000, a visit by a group of tall ships next year.
"There are a whole lot of different, remarkable ideas out there for New London," said John C. Markowicz, executive director of the Southeastern Connecticut Enterprise Region, a regional economic development group. "There's a lot of energy in the New London Development Corporation, and now some of the other towns in the area are talking about setting up their own programs. There's a sense of excitement that's been building ever since the Pfizer announcement."
David M. Goebel, a retired Navy rear admiral who is the chief operating officer of the corporation, said the city would also benefit from a decision to make New London one of a few stops on a high-speed rail corridor between Boston and Washington, D.C. New London, he said, "has an obligation to make itself the kind of place where people might want to stop for the day."
People could wander up from the train station, stop in the shops, see museums like the Hempsted Houses and Shaw Mansion, and watch a play at the Garde Theater. Also, with the rail service, New London could become a commuter city for Boston or New York, which would be only an hour away. "All of a sudden, New York and Boston are very close," Mr. Goebel said. "You've just got to start taking a different view of what all this can mean to the community."
Dr. Claire L. Gaudiani, the president of Connecticut College in New London, who last year revived the development group at the request of state officials, has long written about how social justice requires opportunity for all. New London has become a sort of laboratory for her theories.
"It's hard for anybody to believe this is going to be good for everybody," Dr. Gaudiani said, "because we're all so used to situations where somebody gets hurt, but there are such a diverse group of projects and we're thinking of everybody: Will this build the tax base? Will this create jobs? Will this help people in the lower income brackets?"
She added that it has been "a great chance to see a diverse group of citizens work together to make social justice and economic development two sides of the same coin."
Susan Howard, a real estate broker with U.S. Properties in New London, said the Pfizer announcement last year, followed by the development corporation's efforts, have already started to have an impact. A vacant warehouse on Washington Street that was listed for three years, for example, garnered three offers in one week late last year, then sold for $350,000.
In the last year, office space prices have risen by more than 20 percent. "And even at the increased prices, there's very little left," Ms. Howard said.
A large office complex called Shaw's Cove is almost 100 percent full, "and that had a vacancy rate of almost 50 percent for a long time," Ms. Howard said. She went on: "Last year I closed 50 commercial deals, almost one a week, about half of them sales. That's a lot. The year before I did probably 30, and of the 30, most of them were leases rather than sales.
"It used to be you couldn't get people to even look at property in New London. Now buildings on Bank Street, people are bidding for them. If something becomes available, at least three people are looking at it."
The New London City Manager, Richard M. Brown, said that while it seems the activity has developed very quickly, it has been building since as early as 1971, when an urban development plan was created. For instance, the city prepared the New London Mills site, a former linoleum factory. for a new developer -- so when Pfizer needed land for expansion, it was available.
"I don't think you can ever look at anything as an overnight success," Mr. Brown said. "There may be individuals or organizations that can serve as catalysts, but the basic structure has got to be there. We've been devoting a lot of attention to downtown, we have a program to eliminate housing blight, we're bringing properties back on tax rolls and encouraging home ownership. All of the things happening now are taking place within a much larger context that has been taking form over many years."
One criticism of the plan has been that the corporation is trying to accomplish too much, too fast. Mr. Goebel dismisses those concerns. "Our goal, really, is to bring it all up at once," he said. "If you don't do that, what you do is you put a Band-Aid on a serious problem, and the city has had experience with that approach in the past."
Clearly, the catalyst for the current interest in New London was the plan by Pfizer, long one of the dominant employers in the region with a large research operation in Groton, right across the Thames River, to build a new campus in New London.
George M. Milne Jr., a Pfizer vice president, said the contractors would start driving piles for the buildings soon, start erecting steel in June, and have it ready for occupancy by late next year. Why New London?
"Part of it is the area got lucky," Dr. Milne acknowledged. "We started in Groton after the war because the plant was here, and it was the investment in the land that was around the plant in the late 1940's and early 1950's that gave us a place to start our research division, and since then it has just continued to grow. So we got here sort of as a consequence of decisions that were made a long time ago." "But this area is on the threshold of becoming a much more attractive area," Dr. Milne continued. "There's a unique opportunity we enjoy here in southeastern Connecticut to really lead the world in biotechnology and medicine. With four major companies already in the state, and the beginnings of a biotechnology industry, we'd like to work very hard to attract more of that business into southeastern Connecticut."
The New London Development Corporation quickly moved in to take advantage of the attention that the Pfizer announcement brought to New London, creating a plan for several key but deteriorated downtown properties.
* At the Crocker House, an old building at State and Union streets, ground-floor retail space and 40 apartments on the top floor will be developed.
* At Union and Pearl streets, an enclave of residential units will be created.
* The Parade, an area on State Street not far from Union Station, will be restored with mixed-use retail and entertainment businesses that will capitalize on the estimated one million commuters and tourists who pass through annually.
* A new residential building of 62 units on Eugene O'Neill Drive is to be built where there is now a parking lot.
* The Bacon and Cronin buildings on State Street are to be rehabilitated to create 25 units of housing and 15,000 square feet of ground-floor retail space.
At the same time, at the former Navy research laboratory at the south end of the city, where the state already plans a park around the Civil War-era Fort Trumbull, the group has proposed a mixed-use development that would include a 200- to 250-room hotel, health club, office space, marina and retail shops, as well as 80 townhouse units, at a cost of $50 million to $84 million.
"This brings the opportunity to repopulate portions of New London and restore the middle-class balance," Mr. Goebel said. "The philosophy is to create anchors in the community and spread out from there, creating more housing, improving transportation. It all becomes possible after the base is established."
The corporation is working to reduce negative impact on existing businesses and residences. At the Crocker House, for example, residents qualified for almost $2,800 in relocation benefits.
And commercial tenants in the area have few complaints. "It allowed me to move into a larger facility at a time when I was ready to expand my business anyway," said Joshua A. Friedman, who owned a custom furniture and cabinetry business in New London on Pequot Avenue, on land needed by the Pfizer development. The development corporation helped him find new, larger quarters on Jay Street, helped him get a loan for the expansion, and paid his moving expenses.
The corporation has had to deal with a setback for one of its earliest efforts, a proposal to bring in a private company to run the city-owned Ocean Beach and invest $7 million for a water park. Residents rejected the plan in January because it would have brought an estimated 2,500 cars a day into one of the most heavily-populated residential areas of the city.
"If we're going to be able to do good planning, we have to be able to hear 'yes' from citizens, but we also have to be able to hear 'no'," Dr. Gaudiani said. "There was no ugliness at the meeting. People were grateful to the work N.L.D.C. had done, but they looked at the number of cars that would be coming in and said 'no.' I don't want a city where people are going to roll over and let just anything happen."
Mr. Goebel said city residents have been discouraged by the number of false starts in revitalization over the years, but the ideas are still generating excitement.
"There are more and more people saying it really could happen this time, it's got the right team, the right state interest and support, the right leadership, and the right City Council to drive it all through," Mr. Goebel said. "New London recognizes that this is its chance, this is its opportunity. And I think there's a realization that this could be the last opportunity to pull it off."

HEADLINE: Q&A/Linda C. Fentiman;
Call to Monitor Long-Distance Health Care

BYLINE: By DONNA GREENE 

 BODY:
TELE-MEDICINE is a field where law and ethics are lagging far behind what is going on, said Linda C. Fentiman, director of the Health Law and Policy Program at Pace University School of Law in White Plains. It is a trend that not only has the potential to expand access dramatically to quality health care, she said, but also to make it more impersonal, to reduce health-care costs -- or even increase them -- and to destroy a patient's right to privacy. And, she asks, Who should be regulating such practitioners?
Tele-medicine is medicine at a distance. It may mean a local doctor consults a colleague at a teaching hospital by means of a teleconference, and perhaps the patient's X-rays are shared by modem and other high-tech equipment. It also encompasses tele-pharmacy, where medicines are sold on the Internet, and tele-health, where health information, not all of it reliable, is shared on Internet home pages. 
 Ms. Fentiman, who lives in Manhattan, was a criminal defense lawyer in California in the 1970's. She was drawn to health law after representing clients who used mental-state defenses, and that interest spilled over to the bio-ethics law field and then the business aspects of health care law. Here are excerpts from a recent conversation with her:
Q. What is the negative side of tele-medicine?
A. There are several negatives and a lot of uncertainty. The real potential negative is that it may change the physician-patient relationship. Now, even in the managed-care era, we are accustomed to having a physician whom we consult on a regular basis, who knows us. With tele-medicine we're more likely to have a more complicated relationship with both our local physician and another physician at a distant location. There are questions about what are the ethical obligations the tele-physician owes a distant patient.
There may be concern about patient privacy and confidentiality. When a patient is in a physician's office, she knows that the physician is examining her, but there is no one else there to see her. If it's a tele-mediated consultation, then not only will a physician and other health-care professionals at a distance "see" her but so also may technical people, video support people. So she may not be aware how much her personal privacy might be compromised. And there is the possibility that lots of her data may be sent over the Internet in order to do an effective tele-diagnosis.
Q. What are the issues involved in the purchase of prescription drugs on the Internet?
A. People have long been able to mail away a prescription to sort of a wholesaler and get their drugs in that way, and no one saw any problems. Now, there is no reason your local doctor couldn't order a prescription and you could order it over the Internet. The interesting new thing is how many of these Internet pharmacies have pharmacists who are answering questions as well as filling orders that are placed over the Internet. Virtually every state, including New York, requires that a pharmacist be licensed in the state in which he is prescribing medication. There seems to be a potential problem if a pharmacist in, say, Chicago is answering questions for a patient in New York and if that pharmacist is not licensed to practice pharmacy in New York. So there are questions about whether the New York oversight board can effectively limit or regulate or scrutinize what the tele-pharmacist is doing and is he or she practicing pharmacy in New York without a license?
Q. The answer is unclear at this time?
A. Right. It hasn't been litigated. The on-line pharmacist has only been on line for under six months.
Q. What do you think of reports of doctors on the Internet prescribing without face-to-face consultation?
A. That seems very scary. Clearly, that physician doesn't have any personal observation of the patient, and the heart of the physician-patient relationship is face-to-face contact -- looking and touching. And also being able to pick up nuances in how a patient is telling about his symptoms. All that is missed when practicing via the Internet.
There is a trade-off, perhaps, in the traditional tele-medicine setting between intimate contact and observation with a more accurate diagnosis. What you're getting through tele-medicine is often a high-tech second opinion. Often that is worthwhile for a patient who can't come to a major academic setting -- either it's too far or too expensive or the patient can't take time off from work. That patient can save a great deal of resources by having a tele-medicine consultation, but then the patient is relying on his local physician to fill in the gaps, to consult with the tele-doctor.
Q. For decades there have been people who looked to other countries for certain drugs they could not obtain here. Doesn't the Internet pull those barriers down further?
A. Yes, and that can be the plus of tele-medicine -- that it helps pull down barriers to access and quality of health care. And it puts the patient potentially more in charge of his own medicine treatment. But at the same time we don't have the paternalistic state medical board or paternalistic Food and Drug Administration protecting the patient from his own folly.
The Food and Drug Administration has erred on the side of patient protection, generally speaking, screening out drugs if it's not absolutely certain that they're safe and effective. Now sometimes that is bad because patients sometimes don't get access to drugs that other countries think are effective. But sometimes it is good. The F.D.A. prevented the use of thalidomide in this country precisely because there was a very zealous F.D.A. scientist who said, "I see this causes birth defects in armadillos, and I'm not going to let it in this country." It was available in other countries. So the Internet makes medicine much harder to control. One of the issues is: if a person, say, in New York was practicing tele-medicine on a patient in California, whose laws would govern?
Q. Where do you see this going in the way of regulation?
A. Different states, through their legislatures, have adopted varying approaches. California is very liberal in allowing it as long as the patient signs an informed consent form that says, I know I'm being diagnosed via tele-medicine. Georgia and Oklahoma, for example, have taken very protective stances. In Georgia you cannot practice tele-medicine in most cases unless you're doing it for free or you're doing it through the University of Georgia. New York's position is that you can't practice tele-medicine on a patient in New York unless you're licensed to practice medicine in New York. And a lot of it is kind of turf protection.
Now the interesting thing about this is: generally, medicine in the United States has become much more national, so every physician in the United States goes to a medical school approved by the A.M.A. Data about malpractice and other negative information about a physician goes to the national health care practitioner data bank. It is kind of ironic that at a time that we're recognizing that medicine is national in scope, states are digging in their heels and saying, Only our doctors within our borders can treat our patients. It's really an economic issue rather than a patient-protection issue.
Q. How is the Federal Government supposed to deal with the confidentiality issues?
A. Congress is required by the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act of 1996, which it passed, to act by this August to issue national confidentiality regulations. So far, there has been no action. But what has also happened is that New York did a big study of patient confidentiality issues and decided that it would wait until after the Federal Government acted. So right now the law is very outdated because it assumes that all these medical records are on paper. The ongoing debate is: how protective should we be?
Q. This is quite an emerging field, isn't it, where law and ethics are not resolved at all?
A. Right. It has the promise to improve the quality of care, but if private insurers and Medicare and Medicaid won't pay for these services, then that becomes an issue. And if it becomes the norm that you always have to have a high-tech second opinion, that will drive up the cost of health care. And there is another area, the question of tele-health -- people who get information over the Internet. This affects the whole patient-physician relationship. It used to be patients relied on physicians to give them information -- now you have patients who can surf the net. But there is no control on the Internet in terms of the accuracy of information.

HEADLINE: Town Houses May Rise Where Indians Once Made Their Homes;
Adult Bookstores, Condos And Traffic Congestion Find Fierce Resistance

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

DATELINE: DOBBS FERRY

 BODY:
FOR more than a decade, no issue in this village of 1.5 square miles has generated so much passion as the future of a lazy creek and picturesque ravine leading to the banks of the Hudson River.
Debate over the creek and related land-use issues has forged an unlikely and diverse ad hoc alliance. It includes those who wear suits to work and those who do not own one, bankers and blue-collar workers, entrepreneurs and educators. 
 And while the 50 members of the group rarely mix at the same cocktail parties in this leafy suburban community, they meld when it comes to keeping development from one of the village's last open-space areas, a former Indian gathering site.
"In this respect, we share a common goal," said Shiraz Shakarchy, a 30-year-old adjunct college professor and a member of the Friends of Wickers Creek Archeological Site, or Fowcas.
Like Fowcas, other ad hoc citizen groups throughout the county have united against perceived common foes. Last year, in Mount Vernon, for example, a citizens' effort limited adult bookstores and topless bars to a small section of the city. In the last decade in Hastings-on-Hudson, citizens have successfully fought off a variety of projects, including a proposed widening of the Saw Mill River Parkway where it runs through the village. In Port Chester, an ad hoc organization continues to oppose a Home Depot, saying unmanageable traffic congestion would result. In Peekskill, a group is opposing the installation of video surveillance cameras in public areas. In Dobbs Ferry, where the Village Trustees see tax dollars, the members of the citizens group envision a verdant expanse of open space, Ms. Shakarchy said. And where the developer, Louis R. Cappelli, pictures 104 high-priced town houses, the members imagine a meeting place of the Lenape Indians restored to its former glory.
In the last 11 years, two separate proposals to build town houses just above the ravine have met with fierce resistance from the ad hoc organization, whose members have attended local government meetings and filed lawsuits against the developer.
But two weeks ago, the group suffered a serious setback. Judge Peter M. Leavitt of State Supreme Court in White Plains brushed aside its lawsuit, saying that the developer should not be prevented from moving ahead. Although the organization claimed the village failed to conduct an adequate environmental review of the project, Judge Leavitt thought otherwise.
Now members are making plans to appeal. Those with young children, like Mrs. Shakarchy, will persist because they want them to have something other than concrete playgrounds. Others like 65-year-old John Culhane, a journalist who lives in an apartment overlooking Wicker's Creek and the Hudson River, said an appeal was important to him because he fears the developer will "turn a Garden of Eden into a noisy hell" of tractors and construction equipment.
Mr. Culhane, who considers Rachel Carson a heroine, said members were also troubled by the potential effect of contaminants buried under a capped landfill on the site, although an environmental study of the property completed for the village concluded that it posed no serious danger to humans.
For Thomas Morrison, president of the group n for the last six years, saving Wickers Creek has become almost a religious calling. Mr. Morrison, 57, has a master's of divinity degree and cut his teeth as a fighter for civil rights in Charlotte, N.C.
"Now Wickers Creek," he said, "has tapped a deep passion in me."
This most recent cause has disrupted his household and "not quite threatened my marriage," he said. "It's one of those things that I thought would last a couple of months, and then one thing led to another. The issue has taken on a life of its own." Mr. Morrison said he spends at least three hours a day for the past 11 years working on Wickers Creek projects.
Still, Mr. Morrison said he was hardly ready to give up.
Although Cappelli Enterprises has granted a conservation easement on the property to the village, that has not satisfied Mr. Morrison and the other members of Fowcas. The easement allows the public to view the property only from outside its borders, and does not provide access to it.
Peggy Blizard, a painter who owns an art gallery in the village, said, "We want the property for a park, for everyone, not just for the people who can afford the town houses."
Another member of the organization, Donna LoPinto, who owns a T-shirt printing business in the village, said that although environmental concerns were the most obvious aspect of the group's focus, it was not the only issue for members.
"We're not just tree huggers or sandal wearers or all of one kind," Ms. LoPinto, 35, who grew up in Dobbs Ferry, said.
Her frustration is also political, she said, explaining that the Village Board of Trustees had approved the project despite the wishes of many Dobbs Ferry residents. "They are not listening to us," she said.
Another member, Kenneth Barton, a retired headmaster of a private school, worried that the project would bring in too many cars and people to a village that was straining at the seams. "We're already too crowded," he said.
The members said the group was also concerned with civil rights and cultural issues, including the preservation of a Native American site.
Prehistoric archeological artifacts dating from the fourth and third millenniums B.C. and belonging to hunter and gatherer societies of coastal New York have been found at the site. Members of the Weckquaesgeck tribe, ancestors of the Lenape Indians, were the first settlers of Westchester, and shells from oysters and other mollusks, which once abounded in the river and were a key source of food for the Indians, can still be found in the soil. Until 1644, when the Indians were massacred by Dutch settlers, members of the tribe spent the warmer months along Wickers Creek.
There are, however, conflicting opinions about the site's archeological value. The land has been given legal and environmental clearance as a building site from the village, and three years ago the State Historic Preservation Office gave Cappelli Enterprises permission to build, asserting that years of looting by amateur archeologists had destroyed the site's historic value.
Members of the citizens group believe otherwise, and their lawyer, Samara Swanston, said that even if the site did not have strict archeological value, what remains of it should be preserved.
"We've already left many attached town houses for future generations to see, but there are not too many like this Indian site," she said.
Ms. Swanston works for Minority Environmental Lawyers, which provides pro bono legal services for what they call righteous causes, she said. "We're a bunch of activist lawyers of color working for environmental justice issues."
Fowcas also tried to save the property for open space by nominating it in 1992 for the National Register of Historic Sites. The state and National Park Service deemed the site eligible, Mr. Morrison said, but it has not been placed on the list because the property owners do not want it listed.
As Marge Schneider, a partner in Summit Landing, the proposed development, explained then: "I could come in and nominate a neighbor's home for the National Register. That doesn't mean my neighbor needs to agree to it."
Ms. Schneider said the two- and three-bedroom town houses would sell for about $375,000 to $500,500 and would appeal to people without children, like young adults and couples whose children have grown.
The land was once owned by Mount Mercy Associates of Castleton, N.Y., which paid $9 million for the property in 1995 and proposed to build four-level town houses, some overlooking the 50-foot ravine, with elevators and up to 4,000 square feet of space. The project would have included a private park, a beach, a pool and tennis courts, but the developer walked away from the project during the economic difficulties of the late 1980's.
Cappelli Enterprises acquired the property in 1995 from the Resolution Trust Company, the Federal agency handling properties in default during the savings-and-loan crisis.
Mr. Morrison, frustrated by the inability of his small group to succeed in fighting for preservation of a section of the Hudson River, said, "There are a lot of stinking things to this."
He said he wondered, for example, why Gov. George E. Pataki, who promoted preservation of the Hudson River waterfront during his most recent campaign, has largely ignored his group's efforts. The Friends of Wickers Creek Archeological Site sent a series of letters to the Governor from 1996 to 1998, requesting his assistance in the matter, he said.
Mr. Morrison questioned whether Mr. Pataki was influenced by the fact that Mr. Cappelli, who is one of the leading builders in Westchester County, is also a large contributor to Republican politicians, most prominently the Governor.
Michael McKeon, a spokesman for the Governor, called Mr. Morrison's remarks "offensive and completely political" and added, "What can the Governor do?" He also said that at the Governor's request the State Department of Environmental Conservation approached the property owners last year to see if they were willing to sell, and Cappelli Enterprises said no.
Meanwhile, the Village Board of Trustees would like to realize more tax ratables in a municipality where about one-third of the property (schools, a college, a children's rehabilitation center, for example) is not on the tax rolls. The board approved the development proposal last year.
But Mayor Brian Monahan, who as a Trustee 10 years ago supported more development for Dobbs Ferry, now claims that the cost to the village in terms of new schools and services to support the town houses would outweigh any gains.
"I've been persuaded that it would be good if the property were not developed," he said.
The developer, however, would sue if the Trustees reneged on their approval, he added.
Ms. Schneider confirmed the Mayor's statement.
Meanwhile, the Friends of Wickers Creek Archeological Site said it hopes someone or something will allow the property to be saved from development. "A miracle from God could help," Ms. Blizard said. "Governor Pataki could intervene. We're just normal everyday people who have come together to save the land because we want to be able to walk there, too. Hopefully, a way will be found."

Gutierrez for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Q&A/Cynthia Winer;
Homeless Children Find an Advocate

BYLINE: By NANCY POLK 

 BODY:
MORE than 600 students in the Hartford Public School system are homeless. "These are the ones I know about," said Cynthia Winer, coordinator of Homeless Education in the Hartford Public School system.
Ms. Winer gets referrals from city shelters, other school social workers, the Department of Social Services and the Fire Department. She then contacts the students' former schools for records, including special education records and she then places the students in school. 
 She is an advocate for these children. "It's not the fault of theirs that they were burned out or their mother was arrested for the umpteenth time for prostitution. They shouldn't have to pay the price," Ms. Winer said, "We have to be more understanding."
Recently Ms. Winer, in her office at Hartford High School, discussed the issues that homeless children face. Following are excerpts from that conversation:
Q. Where do homeless students live?
A. They live with friends, on the street, with relatives and at shelters.
Q. Why are these children homeless?
A. It could be because of a fire. It could be their parents have been evicted because the housing was not suitable or because of nonpayment of rent. Earlier this year a whole building was closed down. It had 10 families with many kids. It was shut down because of drugs and unsuitable conditions.
No one helps to meet the continued needs these people. The Red Cross only deals with emergencies. If it's a fire, I call the Fire Department to find out who they are and what schools they attend so that when they return to school on Monday they will have transportation to get there. D.S.S. (Department of Social Services) gives them a certificate that directs them to bad hotels and bad housing. If they are not on state assistance they are on their own.
Mainly they are directed to shelters. Hartford has 11 shelters. The biggest shortage of beds in the city is for men with children. There is only one shelter in the City of Hartford for men with children. There are only about 10 beds for them and they are always full.
Q. How old are these homeless children?
A. They range from preschool to age 21. (The state is required to provide services for special education students up to age 21.) There are lots of preschoolers.
I had a lady come in who was frightened. She knew she didn't have a lot and she was afraid that D.C.F. (Department of Children and Families) could take her child away. But she needed housing so she came here as a leap of faith. I referred her child to a preschool. I thought the little girl looked like she had lead poisoning so I sent her for testing. Her lead level was too low to qualify for help with housing so I tried to get housing for them. I tried to get her food, clothing.
Q. Are these children are on their own or with families?
A. Both. Children can live alone in a shelter under the guardianship of D.C.F. Children can live alone in a shelter for years. Kids as young as age 12 are living on their own in shelters. They must follow very stringent rules and regulations of the shelter. If they don't, they can be evicted to another shelter. Then I get another referral.
Q. Are all these Hartford children?
A. We've had kids from Terryville, Avon, Simsbury, Bristol, Farmington, New Britain, Glastonbury. That's why Hartford has so many, because we get other districts' kids. This is not just a Hartford problem. This is society's problem.
Q. How do you protect abuse victims confidential location?
A. I would guess about 20 percent of the children are homeless because of domestic violence. They could come from anywhere throughout the U.S. They come through the underground network of domestic violence shelters. I would never give up their confidentiality. Say I have a child from California. I'll call and request the records if the mother didn't bring them with her. I will ask them not to record my call because if a man is the father of that child, he has the right to those phone records.
Many change their identities. They are able to change their names and social security records.
Q. Are some of the teens you work with mothers themselves?
A. I went to a shelter to give a presentation on AIDS. There were 10 girls there and all 10 had babies. One was only 14. I've had a 12-year-old mother. She lived sometimes with the father and sometimes with the grandmother.
Q. Can homeless students stay in school to do their homework?
A. Sometimes. The structure of the shelter is very strict. Some of them go for therapy after school. I try to get them into summer camp. Some of them try to get jobs. They only get $200 twice a year for clothes.
They do homework at the shelters. They also have programs for them. For teen-age girls, it's how not to get pregnant again. They have programs on self esteem, getting along with others, conflict resolution.
Q. Do their classmates know they are homeless?
A. Sometimes they don't. Some of the kids in Hartford High, you would never know. They are so neat.
Q. With all these problems it must be difficult to stay in school.
A. Some are determined to stay in school. We have a 14-day rule. After 14 absent days, you get no credit for the grade. They shouldn't have to pay the price of not going on to the next grade.
I don't know how many graduate but I do know they all come with dreams. We have had some of these kids go on to college. D.C.F. pays tuition for these kids to go to college. I think that's the best way my tax dollars can be spent.
Q. Do you focus on other areas besides schooling?
A. You can't just do school because they have to have clothes to go to school. They have to have a home to go to school. They have to have food to go to school. I have kids in school who have no food. They get free breakfast if the school bus is on time. They are entitled to free lunch.
One thing I do is offer some kids hope, at least listen to them, show that someone cares about them, give them a pair of jeans when they need them, listen to their pain when they have to share it and hug them when they need it.
Q. How do you keep from getting discouraged?
A. My dream is to have a Covenant House-type shelter. Some place that would be good, a safe place. There's a building right on the corner of Farmington and Marshall, it's abandoned. It would be great. It would be great to have that kind of facility for the kids. I wish Hartford would put up matching funds so we could accept corporate gifts.
I wish we could have education on the needs of homeless children for D.C.F., the police, the Fire Department. I would like to do outreach work with other agencies.
I think the Federal government and the State of Connecticut truly need to invest in programs that follow the letter of the law. There needs to be more compliance review. We need to be doing networking with everyone in the business of working with homeless families and streamline policies.
Q. In this booming economy do you anticipate the numbers of homeless children will decline?
A. No. I think the problem will grow larger. I think the richest state, Connecticut, has put a cramp in welfare reform. I think that many people, because they haven't been compliant with the rules of the welfare system, are going to be off welfare and their children pay the price. They have to pay the price and fend for themselves because Mom can't support them. It's going to lead homelessness and it's going to lead to crime. I used to run the work fare program in Middletown so I certainly understand the need of welfare and welfare reform but I can't see that innocent children should have to pay the price of adults' mistakes. They have scars for a lifetime.

HEADLINE: Is This Wash Brushless? Yes, and Topless, Too

BYLINE: By DAN NEIL 

DATELINE: GREENSBORO, N.C.

 BODY:
IN an economy as polymorphously diverse as America's, it seems unlikely that Harper's II Exotic Car Wash is the only one of its kind. But it could be. "It's the only one I'm aware of," said Eddie Collins, who owns both the car wash and a nearby strip club.
Seven years ago, Mr. Collins, who drives a blue Corvette convertible and is partial to gold jewelry, was "looking to make money during the day" at his club. He considered selling used cars or getting a U-Haul franchise. Then the detailer who had worked on his own cars quit. A neon light bulb came on over his head: Why not open a topless car wash? 
 City officals resisted at first, but Mr. Collins took steps to preserve public decorum. A privacy fence eight feet high surrounds the entrance to the metal building behind the club, where women in G-strings wash the cars.
Business has been brisk, he said, averaging 25 cars a day -- more during the Greater Greensboro Open golf tournament or the A.C.C. basketball championships. The wash is open year-round; there are heaters in the building for the comfort of workers, who do not dress warmly.
Washes are $15 a car, competitive with other hand washes in the area. The workers receive only tips, plus what they make from table and couch dances in the car wash area -- $10 and $20, respectively. In a corner of the shed, "V.I.P. areas" are set aside for private dancing.
"I like the hours," said Tammy, 24, who declined to give her last name. "It's more laid back, and you get tan." In the summer, cars are often washed outdoors.
Usually, the car washers do not work after hours at the club, and vice versa. "It's hard to find enough pretty girls who want to do the work," Mr. Collins said. Sometimes, however, he will punish a club dancer by sending her to the car wash -- "especially those prima donnas who think they are too good to wash cars."
And the cars do come clean, to the surprise of a first-time customer. After he parked his green Saturn and took a seat nearby, two attendants, Ariel and Tiara, untrussed themselves and began hosing the car with warm water. They used lamb's-wool mitts to lather up the car, raising the windshield wipers and paying close attention to the wheels. After rinsing, they dried the car with a hand chamois. Given that Ariel managed these feats in thigh-high, patent leather, stiletto-heeled boots, a $5 tip did not seem extravagant. DAN NEIL

HEADLINE: The Very Model Of a Modern Major Museum;
The Old Masters Still Have Their Place, But Today's Curators and Educators Promote New Ways of Seeing and Doing

BYLINE: By DIANE NOTTLE 

 BODY:
NOT so long ago, museums were like temples -- temples dedicated to Art. Big, imposing and often neo-classical outside, they were quiet, often darkened places inside, where people went to look reverently at inanimate paintings and sculptures by dead white males, familiar mainly from textbooks. Sometimes they would take their children, who would be hushed into a similar state of intimidation under the eye of uniformed guards. Hardly anyone went to a museum for fun.
The facades may not have changed much, but the museums certainly have. Flashing lights and funhouse mirrors entice visitors away from the greatest visual hits of the 1690's and into multimedia celebrations of the 1960's at the Newark Museum. Brightly colored balls bounce around miniature golf courses that bear no resemblance to the ones at the shore, thanks to artist-designed holes like the nine in last year's "Strokes of Genius" at the Montclair Art Museum. This summer, the Morris Museum in Morristown will be "Talkin' Baseball" with an exhibition on New Jersey's minor-league heritage, inviting visitors to call the play-by-play on a videotaped game or even play a game of wiffle ball. Suddenly, going to a museum is fun. 
 Every other sentence coming out of the mouths of museum directors or curators these days seems to include at least one word starting with "inter-" -- Latin for between. Their mission, to establish relationships between themselves and the public, now extends far beyond preserving and displaying works of art or collections of natural history. Increasingly, they use words like interactive, interdisciplinary and intergenerational.
"Museums are not built for eternity," said Karen Cummins, curator of education at the New Jersey State Museum in Trenton. They change, she said, with "the pace of science, the pace of everything."
Interaction may be high-tech or low. At the National Gallery of Art in Washington, visitors who had just left the acclaimed exhibition of Japanese Edo-period art last winter clustered around computer stations related to the show, gazing into the screens with rapt concentration that quite possibly surpassed the attention they had given any of the actual objects in the galleries. New Jersey's museums may not have the resources of the National Gallery, but the same principles apply.
But interaction means more than a click on an icon. It may mean touching a fossil, or turning a plastic owl's head to see how far it will go. It may mean a field trip from an elementary school, with an impromptu art class inside the galleries, or from a retirement home. It may mean contributing a piece to an installation in progress, or taking home a book of artists' instructions meant to nudge you toward your own art projects, as in the recent "Do It" series at five museums throughout the state. It may mean a social encounter, or even a children's birthday party, in the museum cafe.
As museums' missions have changed, so have their operations and strategies, with education and marketing departments receiving attention and deference once reserved for curators. Yet the core remains the art and the ways it can, and does, touch lives. Museumgoing, said Mary Sue Sweeney Price, the director of the Newark Museum, is "not just immersion in a fantasy experience, but being put in touch with real objects of value."
 
NEWARK MUSEUM
A City's Diversity Reflected in Galleries
Pop and populism mingle comfortably at the Newark Museum, now celebrating its 90th anniversary. The Pop has been especially visible since February as a labyrinth of galleries covering 5,000 square feet of the normally rather staid museum have been given over to "Off Limits: Rutgers University and the Avant-Garde 1957-1963," which closes next Sunday. The show, tracing the birth of Pop art and the era of happenings, has a high interactivity quotient: visitors are invited to listen through earphones to John Cage's late-1950's composition class at the New School for Social Research in Manhattan; have their pictures taken in photo booths and post them outside, or "create your own event" at a drawing board.
Lest anyone think art was (or is) divorced from real life, the displays are accompanied by pages from popular magazines like Life, particularly advertising that pointed the way toward the American Dream the artists were rebelling against. "Putting the art in context is a very broad concept," said Mrs. Price, the museum's director. "What was happening then? Why was the artist making this art?"
Long before multiculturalism became a buzzword, the museum was practicing it, to the extent that one side of the contribution box in the entrance foyer says "Donate today" in the Portuguese of the city's Ironbound section. "From the founding, we've welcomed those groups," Mrs. Price said, "from the German-American focus of the jewelry show, to the Jews before and after the war, to the African-Americans who came largely from the South." So the museum has mounted shows like "The Glitter and the Gold: Fashioning America's Jewelry" in 1997, "Ancient Land, New Style: Jewish Arts and Crafts From Jerusalem" in 1998, and last year's "Wrapped in Pride," an exhibition of kente cloth from Ghana, as well as prominently displaying pieces by black American folk artists.
The museum has permanent galleries of African and American Indian art, as well as the largest collection of Tibetan art in the Western Hemisphere, with a major exhibition "From the Sacred Realm," opening in October.
Last year, "Crowning Glory: Images of the Virgin in the Arts of Portugal" drew 3,000 visitors from the Ironbound on one Sunday alone, Mrs. Price said. "There were grandmothers who spoke only Portuguese, the kids who spoke English, and the mother in between, interpreting," she said. "One woman said, 'I never thought I'd see my hometown on a museum wall.' "
Like many regional museums, the Newark Museum covers both art and science. The state's first planetarium opened there in 1952, and its collection of 70,000 natural history specimens includes snakes, tamarin monkeys and other inhabitants of a mini-zoo in the Junior Gallery.
The museum ranks 11th in the country in education spending and second in proportion of education dollars to the total budget, according to the Association of Art Museum Directors. The education department has two primary functions: instructional services, working directly with educators on incorporating the arts into the core curriculum -- "teaching teachers how to use art objects," Mrs. Price said -- and youth and family services, offering classes and workshops, and programs for school vacation periods.
On weekends, the museum offers family time with an emphasis on intergenerational activities. "In the past, parents would deposit their kids at an activity and go sit and read," she said. "Now, they'll do the activity together." Older generations add an extra dimension. "So many of the grandparents in the region have historical ties to Newark," she said. "When the grandchildren come to visit, this is one of the first places they come." Last weekend, when the museum celebrated its 90th anniversary with a ball on Saturday night, Family Day followed on Sunday, drawing 3,000 visitors to the same tent on the museum grounds.
If all the bells and whistles of modern-day museumgoing prove too stimulating, you can always duck into the galleries of 18th- and 19th-century American art designed by the Princeton architect Michael Graves. But even there, watch out. "A Closer Look," a prototype gallery for a permanent reinstallation designed to tell American history through the decorative and fine arts, asks visitors admiring "Portrait of the Children of William Rankin Sr." (1838), by Oliver Tarbell Eddy, Yes, even a two-dimensional painting hanging unobtrusively on the wall can provide an interactive experience.
 
STATE MUSEUM
You Can Look, And Sometimes Touch
It's definitely field-trip season in the state capital. Big yellow buses from Toms River and Freehold lined State Street and snaked around the corner the other week. A dozen or so children climbed "Hineni," a large sculpture in white oak by Harry Gordon, on the plaza outside the State Museum; others examined a brightly painted welded-steel sculpture by Alexander Calder nearby while their schoolmates, all fully clothed, enacted their own brown-bag version of Manet's "Luncheon on the Grass."
As New Jersey's official repository and showcase, the State Museum has a strongly educational mission ranging far beyond fine art. The floor-by-floor directory testifies to the museum's scope, listing not only the current retrospective of paintings by Alma W. Thomas and the women's art show, but also "Baskets and Brooms: Delaware Adaptations to European Contact"; "Paul Weingarten," paintings by the Montclair artist; "New Jersey Amber," and "Ceramics and Glass." Stuffed bears and jaguars inhabit dioramas of North American wildlife. In halls containing exhibitions on New Jersey's Native American archeological record, some of the print on the text panels have been rubbed faint by the arms of children leaning on them.
Clearly, this museum is not venerated, but used. "This has never been a temple in the park," said its director, Leah Phyfer Sloshberg. "I came in 1964, and I can't remember its ever being that way. We were founded in 1895, and from the very beginning we've had a strong educational mission." In fact, she said, she has met people in their 60's who remember vivid details of their own class trips to the museum when it was still in the State House Annex.
For every exhibition, "we try to come up with an educational component to go with it," said Karen Cummins, curator of education. And for every exhibition, the staff makes a point of defining its potential audience. "There are the hard-core museum people who go and look at every show we do," Ms. Sloshberg said. "But for every exhibition, there's a special audience."
Those audiences come from "truly the region -- Bucks County, Montgomery County and Delaware -- and literally from all of New Jersey," Ms. Sloshberg said. How does she know? For one thing, "when our calendars are wrong, we hear from the people who've driven here," she said with a laugh.
And what do audiences want? "More blockbusters," Ms. Sloshberg said.
So the museum is planning its first official blockbuster, "Unseen Treasure: Imperial Russia and the New World," to open in September. "It's a story of exploration," Ms. Sloshberg said, from a meeting between William Penn (one of 12 partners who purchased East Jersey in 1681) and Czar Peter the Great in England in 1698, to the Alaska Purchase two centuries later. Organized by the American-Russian Cultural Cooperation Foundation in Washington, the exhibition comes to Trenton from the Russian State Historical Museum on Red Square.
After the blockbuster brings people through the door, the museum will do its best to expose them to other forms of art. "We want the people who come to 'Unseen Treasures' to see what wonderful collections we have," Ms. Sloshberg said.
As for interactive exhibits, "we've had high-tech and low-tech, and the low-tech works best, in my opinion," Ms. Sloshberg said, noting that "there's nothing more frustrating" than confronting a computer that doesn't work.
When the museum had its popular "Dinamation" show of animated dinosaur models in 1996 and 1997, one of the activities was "Design a Dinosaur," which invited visitors to mix and match foam models of heads, tails and bodies from various species. Also popular are the working scientists in a glassed-in mini-lab in the natural history galleries. "Rather than have the researchers working in an office, they do it in public," Ms. Cummins said.
Most effective of all, she said, is giving visitors contact with the objects themselves whenever possible -- what she calls "hands-on experiences in a hands-off institution." School groups may pass around fossils or rocks. "We have a category designated as the educational collection," Ms. Cummins said. "They might be fossils with an iffy provenance, of marginal value for research, but they're real things that a child can experience."
"The world is so full of simulations," she added. "Our strength is the real."
 
ZIMMERLI
Turning Abroad For a Home Advantage
The Jane Voorhees Zimmerli Art Museum has all the "inters" of the other museums, plus a fourth: international. At the moment, most of the gallery space is given over to Russian art, the museum's specialty even when it is not mounting a show like "Defining Russian Graphic Arts: From Diaghilev to Stalin, 1898-1934." Since 1995, the Zimmerli, on the Rutgers University campus in New Brunswick, has been the repository of the Norton and Nancy Dodge Collection of Nonconformist Art From the Soviet Union, and it also houses the George Riabov Collection of Russian Art. On the lower level is the Kusakabe-Griffis Gallery, honoring a connection between New Brunswick and Japan dating back more than 100 years and currently devoted to Japonisme. And the children's corner is presenting "Maples in the Mist," watercolors illustrating 16 Chinese poems from the Tang Dynasty.
The international emphasis arrived at the Zimmerli 29 years ago with its director, Philip Dennis Cate. "I was given a charge: 'Do what you want to make a museum,' " Mr. Cate recalled. "It was very exciting because it's not often that a museum director is given an opportunity to start from scratch and build up a collection. The metropolitan area is so congested with art and culture. I wanted to do something that didn't compete, but complemented. I tried not to build a comprehensive collection, like the Princeton Art Museum or the Metropolitan; it was too late for that. So I began concentrating on specific areas that I felt we could handle economically."
When he took charge, the University Art Gallery, the oldest space in the present-day museum, now the David LLoyd Kreeger Gallery, had just over 3,000 square feet for a collection of 2,500 art objects. When its current expansion is finished a year from now, the museum is expected to have 45,000 square feet of exhibition space, and the collection has grown to more than 60,000 works.
The Russian emphasis is a happy accident. In 1989, Mr. Cate was approached for advice by George Riabov, a Rutgers alumnus who is a Russian-American consultant on languages and art, who had been asked to lend some of his Russian art collection for exhibition in the Soviet Union. "I advised him not to send it to over there," Mr. Cate said, and he began negotiating a gift to the Zimmerli. Mr. Riabov introduced him to the Dodges, whose collection had been smuggled out of the Soviet Union, piece by piece, in dozens of trips over 30 years. By spring 1991, Mr. Cate had won the two collections.
The Zimmerli recently lost its education director and is in the process of hiring another, but its public education and outreach programs programs go on, from an all-day symposium on the Russian graphics last month to calligraphy classes to concerts of chamber music and jazz.
Interactive elements are present in forms both low-tech ("Make Your Own Mark" clipboards at "Maples in the Mist," encouraging children to design their version of traditional Chinese seals) and high- (menu-driven interactive video programs, in your choice of English or Japanese, accompanying the Japonisme show). There are also tried-and-true devices like time lines with the Russian and Japanese exhibitions that help put the art in social and historical context.
"That effort is much more deliberate than it used to be," Mr. Cate said, "because a university museum feels a need to be didactic and because we're dealing with a culture that is not that well known. For people to start to understand why this art was created, you have to put it in context. There's an intellectual part to enjoying art, as much as the visual enjoyment."
The blending of those components will no doubt continue to put the Zimmerli on the map, at home and abroad. "If you have an all-encompassing collection, it's automatically international," Mr. Cate said. "I decided when I first came in that I didn't want us to be just a regional museum. I've always worked toward things that took us out beyond the state of New Jersey, and brought in something it didn't have."

HEADLINE: ON POLITICS;
Florio's (Land Use) Plan For Taking On Whitman

BYLINE: By Iver Peterson; Iver Peterson writes from New Jersey for The New York Times.

DATELINE: PISCATAWAY

 BODY:
It has been called sustainable development and balanced growth and now smart growth. But the concept of controlling suburban growth has never yet been called a political winning hand. Until now.
Vice President Al Gore is leading the Clinton Administration's $10 billion "livability program" of subsidies for mass transit and farmland preservation, and both political parties are talking about the suburbanization of American voters, with their concerns about disappearing open space and traffic congestion. 
 So maybe it is no surprise that one of the people sitting unobtrusively through seminars like "The Regional Y2K Initiative" and "The MTA Capital Program: A Year of Decision" at the recent Regional Plan Association meeting in Manhattan was none other than James J. Florio, past governor and current Senate hopeful.
To be fair, Mr. Florio is on the board of the Plan Association, the tri-state clearinghouse for development and transportation issues in the New York Metropolitan area. But is it not also fair to believe that that the successful lawyer, who is said to be much more interested in policy matters than in mere wealth, was also there because growth issues might soon stop being abstractions and start comprising ideas that voters listen to?
It is.
"I've been talking about development issues for a long time," Mr. Florio said in an interview last week. "I signed the state plan into law, and some of the folks from New Jersey at the meeting were lamenting the fact that the executive order I signed while I was in office is being ignored." Ignored, that is, by Governor Whitman, the likely Republican nominee for next year's Senate race.
"The order said that state officers in charge of infrastructure funding and allocation were charged with not approving any such money for water and sewers and transportation that were not in accordance with the plan," Mr. Florio went on. "That means that if you wanted to put a sewer in the middle of nowhere, you would be precluded from that."
That means that the Whitman Administration would not be trying to extend a sewer from Trenton to the particular middle of nowhere along Scotch Road in Hopewell Township, outside Trenton, where Merrill Lynch wants to build an enormous office park on what was once open farmland. The project has already produced enough of a grass-roots revolt in Hopewell to oust the old Republican majority on the town board and to elect a new Democratic leadership. But that was a very specific example of outrage, where residents could come face to face with the destruction of open space.
However, Mr. Florio acknowledged that it will considerably more difficult to go from a specific situation like that to linking the aggravation of rush-hour traffic in one county to unplanned sprawl and development two counties away.
"We are still in the early stages of starting to understand the nature of the problem and I'm not overly troubled by that because it takes a while to these ideas across to people," the former governor said. "But people are now starting to understand that there are problems associated with their long commutes. They are spending two hours a day going to and from work, and one alternative to that is building a better transportation system."
Of course, talking about building anything in a time when voters are used to being told that government should spend less may not be an easy sell. Not surprisingly, then, Mr. Florio is locked and loaded when he is asked to speak in more general terms about a campaign he would run against Mrs. Whitman.
"A contest between Governor Whitman and myself, if it comes down to that, will be between two different personalities, two different governing styles, two different backgrounds and two different sets of values," he said. "It will be two clear choices, which is different from what people have been getting in recent years, which have been all about blurring the differences between points of view."
Yes, he said "different backgrounds," with its whiff of populist fervor: the country club girl against the boy from the Brooklyn shipyards, translated into a modern morality play about fiscal policy.
Mr. Florio got the boot for raising taxes to pay state expenses, and now he will try to defeat Mrs. Whitman by accusing her of running up the state debt instead of using the budget surplus to pay it off.
"My value system comes from a family that said, 'You pay your bills,' " Mr. Florio said. "My father came home on Friday night with his pay from the shipyard and the first thing my mother did was take the money for the rent and put it in the Chase & Sanborn coffee can we kept on the shelf. Because first, you take care of your expenses, and then you think about spending your money."

HEADLINE: At a Carwash Convention, Soft Soap Meets the Hard Sell

BYLINE: By DAN NEIL 

DATELINE: NASHVILLE

 BODY:
A HYPNOTIC fugue has fallen over the crowd watching the Mac Neil RW-102's. The powerful water sprayers gyrate frantically inside a stainless-steel cuff. Nearby, attached to an overhead arch like you might see at a carwash, the nozzles stop and turn, flip and churn, like choreographed stage lights at a Broadway musical. People wobble their heads unconsciously as they watch the water cannons dance.
No running water has been supplied to the floor of the 1999 International Carwash Association's convention at the Opryland Hotel here, but there is plenty of soft soap. 
 Tearing his gaze from the Mac Neil device, Andy Malecha, a representative of the Broadway Equipment Company in Minneapolis, said: "These things don't work any better than some guy with a hose. But let's face it, car washing is subtle. We have to use a little showmanship so people feel like they are getting their money's worth."
"Subtle" was definitely not on the list of adjectives describing the convention floor here late last month, crowded with more than 300 exhibitors hawking everything from hand-cranked coin sorters to barn-size bus-washing robots. Because of a chronic shortage of labor in the $3 billion-a-year carwash business, the industry relies heavily on automation. Dozens of automatic carwash devices -- those familiar, antenna-eating machines with the spinning brushes -- are deployed on the floor.
Some are simple, bare-metal machines moving with the clumsy kinetics of the elves in Saks's Christmas window displays, their felt curtain "mitters" sloshing to and fro. Others look like escaped set pieces from "Starlight Express": huge chrome and glass naves with blinking neon signs and scrolling L.E.D. readouts above the bill changers that take customers' money.
Some machines are specialized, glumly slaving away at their appointed tasks: dressing tires, for instance. Others roam from bumper to bumper, their thick drum brushes whirling like Champions on Ice.
Econocraft Worldwide Manufacturing Inc. of the Bronx has brought its "Pizazz" floor model, a 100-foot-long, $135,000 apparatus whose mirrored chrome and candy-colored lights seem inspired by somebody's favorite pachinko game.
"The idea is to spice it up, make it glitzy and glamorous," said Tim Hiller, the company's well-dressed representative. "The customer deserves it. He's paying $12 to $14 for a carwash. He wants to see more than a little soap and water."
Why not charge less and offer a simpler machine? He acts as if he has seen a gazelle run down the aisle. "Why would we want to do that?" he asked. "A wise old man told me never to leave any money on the table."
A good carwash machine offers evidence of things unseen. Many of the contraptions use flashing neon signs to indicate, for instance, when the liquid called "rust inhibitor" -- its specific ingredients are carefully guarded -- is applied. "Otherwise, who would know what it was?" asked Steve Chase of Aurora, Colo., an inventor whose tri-color washing and waxing agents are staples at many automated washes.
At the Turtle Wax booth, Mr. Chase watches as a Saab 9-3 is enveloped in rainbow ribbons of goopy spray. The stuff melts together like the walls in a particularly lurid passage by William Burroughs. In a touch of synesthesia, the area around the booth is suffused with an intense berry fragrance. "It's nice," he said, "and it will keep customers in the carwash longer."
That's the idea. Carwashes are expensive operations -- a top-of-the-line machine can cost $165,000; the average investment per bay in a conveyor carwash is about $1 million. Also, the industry's effluent is federally regulated, requiring either a separate sewer system for new carwashes, or water reclamation equipment.
To increase revenue, the industry has made an art form of "extra services," code for any frill that adds to the cost of a visit. These can range from the reasonable (Armor-All tire treatment makes the rubber look nice and shiny) to the ridiculous (a lemon-scented sealer wax that would be worthwhile only if passengers rode outside your car). In truth, consumers could probably skip the premium-priced car vacuum, its festively colored "fragrance enhancers" bubbling up inside.
Another source of money is what falls under the rubric of "profit centers." These can include everything from quick oil changes and gasoline sales to car detailing and gift shops. Dozens of vendors at the convention represent these peripheral retail services.
"The more convenience we can give to the customer, the better he likes it," said Guy W. Goddard, of Park City, Utah, the president of the International Carwash Association. "What we are looking at is a transition from 'carwash' to 'car care.' "
In fact, next year's convention in Las Vegas will be grandly called the Car Care World Expo 2000.
Mr. Goddard, who with his cowboy boots and long hair looks right at home in Opryland, says the business will inevitably reach into other services that busy people crave: dry cleaning, gourmet food and coffee, insurance services, shoe repair, even massage therapists -- "duly licensed and registered," he said.
As promising as the future looks -- the industry is growing 7 percent annually -- the business does have its problems: the rift between "friction" and "touch-free" washes, for instance. Friction washes put brushes or pads on cars. These can be worrisome because the new clear-coat compounds applied over new cars' paint can be easily marred by brushes, leaving telltale whorls.
Touch-free carwashes use high-pressure sprays, but they are less effective. To be competitive, some touch-free operators use pre-soak solutions of hydrofluoric acid, a highly toxic material, to loosen clay, brake dust and asphaltic hydrocarbons, otherwise known as road tar.
"We want the industry to take the moral high ground," Mr. Goddard said. "We hope our membership avoids the stuff."
As in all things, the moral high ground is slippery. Mr. Goddard said the industry's single greatest problem was that more than half of all drivers still washed their own cars. These driveway washers -- perhaps a million of them on a summer weekend day, by some estimates -- send their waste water into the gutter, where it makes its way into lakes and rivers. "They can do with their waste water what we can't," he said.
But the association's opposition to driveway washing -- which is both green and self-serving -- means that it opposes charity washes for churches and schools. "We have been developing a voucher system that charities can sell, rather than wash cars in parking lots," Mr. Goddard said.
Such controversies notwithstanding, the entrepreneurs of the carwash industry seem an untroubled and gregarious lot. As they trundled away from Nashville, they seemed to want nothing more than to love the next big, noisy, soap-spitting machine.

At right, Guy W. Goddard of Utah, the group's president, had a brush with some new equipment. (Chris Berkey for The New York Times)
