LENGTH: 2768 words

HEADLINE: Choosing the House Over the Address

BYLINE: By LISA PREVOST 

 BODY:
BRENTLY L. FREY made the usual Westchester and Connecticut stop-offs when he began looking for a home with a feeling of history two years ago. He toured houses in Danbury, Ridgefield, Yorktown Heights and Bronxville, but nothing fit his criteria.
Mr. Frey, a marketing consultant who works at home, wanted a property that was truly distinct. And while he could have spent well over $400,000, the house had to be priced low enough to give him the option of renovating the interior in his own style. 
 Flipping through real estate magazines, he noticed a number of interesting homes for sale in a place he hadn't previously considered -- Mount Vernon, the city separating the Bronx from Bronxville. More urban melting pot than sheltered suburbia, what Mount Vernon lacked in exclusivity it made up for in proximity to the city (25 minutes by train) and competitive housing prices.
It was in the city's Fleetwood section, a neighborhood of closely spaced houses and tree-lined streets butting up against the border of high-priced Bronxville, that Mr. Frey found his home -- a 1920's brick colonial with a grand center hall, French doors, Palladian windows and a tiled solarium with the original wall fountain. He closed on the house last May at a price that he said was "between $350,000 and $400,000."
"Like many old gems, this one needed to be dusted off," said the 35-year-old Mr. Frey. "It's like a diamond in the rough. For me, where I live is not an issue of prestige. It's an issue of my house, and I want my house to be what I want."
While so many home buyers studiously heed the cardinal rule of real estate and elevate location above all other considerations, Mr. Frey represents a different breed of buyer, one for whom house matters much more than address.
These are the people who are either unwilling or unable to pay the price for their ideal house in the most sought-after ZIP codes, and so happily drift across the borders of prime neighborhoods to lay claim to similar properties in less lofty surroundings. Some purposely seek out these border communities because they tend to offer more diversity.
As home prices have soared in the last few years, these buyers have become all the more evident as they fuel demand in less prestigious neighborhoods bordering communities where similar homes carry significantly higher price tags. Some examples of such communities in Westchester are Fleetwood and the Armour Villa, Lawrence Park West, Beech Hill, Cedar Knolls and Park Hill neighborhoods of Yonkers.
In Connecticut, the Black Rock and Brooklawn neighborhoods of Bridgeport, bordering Fairfield, offer good value for prime properties. In Norwalk, price differentials still exist in the Cranbury and Wolfpit neighborhoods of the city along the Westport border, but the price gap between Norwalk and surrounding towns has closed considerably, brokers say.
The same is also true on the North Shore of Long Island, where one-time factory towns like Glen Cove used to offer waterfront properties at prices much lower than the more exclusive areas, said Lee E. Koppelman, executive director of the Center for Regional Policy Studies at the State University of New York at Stony Brook. The tight real estate market has narrowed price differentials in Nassau County considerably as "the areas that would have served as a contrast have been gentrified," he said.
In New Jersey, South Orange, adjacent to Short Hills, offers some "wonderful old housing stock," as does the Sleepy Hollow section of Plainfield, bordering Edison Township, according to James Hughes, dean of the Rutgers University School of Planning and Public Policy. In addition, the Montclair Heights neighborhood of Clifton is an increasingly popular alternative for buyers attracted to higher-priced Montclair, said Ken Hauser, a sales associate with Weichert Realtors in Clifton.
In many of these areas, historic or architecturally detailed homes can cost hundreds of thousands less than their counterparts just blocks away across community borders. And property taxes, too, can be thousands of dollars lower. The trade-off for a smaller mortgage and lower property taxes, however, is often a school district that compares unfavorably with adjoining towns and perhaps a higher crime rate.
One factor motivating some of the more venturesome buyers in these areas, said Dr. Hughes, may be that thanks to the stock market runup of recent years, the role of the house as the dominant investment has diminished for more families. "Their stock holdings could potentially dwarf their house," he said. "These areas may appeal to people who aren't so housing-dependent for their nest egg."
And it's possible that once the real-estate market slows again, some who invested heavily in improving homes in secondaryareas may find it difficult to get their money out, noted Julie Garton-Good, a real estate lecturer and author of "The Frugal Homeowner's Guide to Buying, Selling and Improving Your Home" (Dearborn, 1999). "There's nothing wrong with people going in and losing money on a house," she said. "But they need to be aware of it ahead of time."
Then again, observed John Clapp, a professor of finance and real estate at the University of Connecticut's Center for Real Estate in Storrs, a less predictable degree of risk can also lead to a higher return. Over the last five years in Norwalk, for example, condominium prices appreciated an average of 9.2 percent annually, while condominium prices in Stamford, a lower-risk market than Norwalk by Professor Clapp's measurements, appreciated an average 3.5 percent annually, he said.
 Even if buyers consider their house less of an investment than simply a home, they should still sit down and weigh other considerations before they begin looking, advises Martin Shenkman, a New York City real estate lawyer.
"Private or public schools, commute time -- whatever the most important amenities -- all those things have to be thought through," Mr. Shenkman said. "People have to sit down and rank their priorities before they fall all over a house. Then whatever they decide is fine, once they've made that personal choice."
MR. Frey has long since stopped worrying about how much money he's spending on his house. He is having his prominent corner lot landscaped, a project that includes adding a garden off the solarium. He has also paid for installation of a central air-conditioning system, restoration of some of the French doors, interior repainting and refinishing of the oak floors.
"I have a lot of friends who are real estate agents and, in the beginning when I was making renovations, I was always asking them, 'Am I spending too much?'," he said. "And they would say, 'You can't put a dollar value on it. It's not a dollar value, it's a love value.' "
The average sale price of a house in the Fleetwood area last year was about one-third of that in Bronxville, said Elizabeth Lindsey, owner of Lindsey Real Estate in Mount Vernon. For many buyers who wind up in Fleetwood the cost of renovating a house there still puts them ahead of what their neighbors in Bronxville are paying.
"But you can stand in one of our houses and it looks the same, the air smells the same," she said. "And the termites don't stop at the Bronxville border."
Sabina Grochowski, 39, and her husband Peter Wyrwinski, 37, both physicians, scouted out Bronxville, Mamaroneck, Scarsdale, Larchmont and New Rochelle before friends convinced them to look in Mount Vernon. Ready to move out of their co-op in Woodmere on Long Island, they wanted an impressive historic home in good repair with high ceilings and at least four bedrooms.
They came close to buying a $699,000 Tudor on a tiny lot in Larchmont. But last December, they found a 1913 Mediterranean-style home on an acre on Gramatan Avenue in Fleetwood with such lavish details as stained-glass windows, relief ceilings, mahogany paneling and an elaborately carved central staircase. They snatched it up for $648,000.
"We think Mount Vernon is one of the few underrated spots in Westchester," Dr. Grochowski said.
At about $18,000 a year, the taxes on the property are about the same as those on other houses they considered, Dr. Grochowski said. But the price is considerably better, she added, even after figuring in the $40,000 they spent on renovations before moving in last month. And since the couple have no children, schools were not a consideration, she said.
As a rule, lower housing prices are partly a reflection of the perceived quality of the community's schools. Several economic studies have tried to measure just how much a good school is worth on the real estate market.
In a summary of those studies published last fall in a report titled, "House Prices and the Quality of Public Schools," in Business Review, a Federal Reserve publication, Theodore Crone, head of the regional economics section of the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia, noted that because housing prices were affected by so many other neighborhood characteristics, it's difficult to separate out the absolute value of a school district. But such a "school premium" clearly exists, Mr. Crone said, and is often linked to districts with higher per-pupil expenditures and higher test scores.
In a 1997 study titled "Do Better Schools Matter?", Sandra E. Black, an economist with the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, found that even when parents were already paying for a better school district in the Boston suburbs, they would pay an additional 2.5 percent for a house linked to an elementary school that had test scores just 5 percent above the others in that district.
Parents who can afford to pay this housing premium, but choose not to do so, generally make the choice quite consciously. "A number of people don't even ask about schools anymore because they've done the research and they know what they're doing with their kids," said Jane McAfee, a Yonkers sales agent for Prudential Ragette.
In Yonkers, residents may choose from a variety of magnet schools in the public school system, or send their children to one of the many nearby parochial and private schools. Some even pay to have their children attend public schools in Pelham or Ardsley. The Beech Hill neighborhood near Scarsdale and the Armour Villa and Lawrence Park neighborhoods bordering Bronxville have long been popular with buyers wanting large homes at lower prices. And they both offer the added bonus of a Scarsdale or Bronxville ZIP code.
"The people I deal with certainly have looked around and they know the prices of houses in Scarsdale," said Kathleen Kuhnel, an associate broker at Cardinal Realty in Ardsley. "Some of them have kids in private schools anyway, so they figure, 'Why pay those taxes?' "
The differences can be dramatic: A five-bedroom colonial in the Beech Hill neighborhood with a Scarsdale ZIP code was recently listed at $385,000 with taxes of $7,700 while in Scarsdale a colonial of the same size and age was priced at $675,000 with taxes of almost $14,000.
Prices are even higher in Bronxville, where a 50-year-old, four-bedroom colonial was recently listed at $699,000 with taxes of more than $17,000. Just over the border in the Cedar Knolls neighborhood of Yonkers a similar colonial was listed at $399,000 with taxes of $6,100.
The Yonkers neighborhood of Park Hill, though not on the border of Bronxville or Scarsdale, has also caught on in the last few years. One of the first planned residential suburbs around New York, Park Hill is a mix of about 200 19th- and early 20th-century homes on a 300-foot plateau overlooking the Hudson River.
Though the neighborhood has long been popular with artists and entertainers, its proximity to blighted areas had previously made it a hard sell with less venturesome spirits. Now, Ms. McAfee has a list of 25 buyers waiting for houses in Park Hill, where homeowners say they are united in their determination to restore the neighborhood to its former glory.
"I was invited to a party by a neighbor before I even moved in," said Mary Jerome, 54, chairwoman of the English as a second language program for international students at Columbia University. "People have asked me over to dinner. I've been asked to join the Park Hill Conservancy. It's really a nice mix of people -- kind people."
IN January, Ms. Jerome moved into a 100-year-old, 7,000-square-foot Georgian with a view of the Hudson and space for a garden, exactly the kind of magnificent home she had long dreamed of owning. Having lived in Manhattan for 27 years, she knew little about Westchester and nothing of Park Hill when she began looking at houses. She estimates that the $780,000 sale price on the house would undoubtedly have been double in Hastings-on-Hudson or Bronxville, the other communities she had looked into.
"I never even considered whether I'd be able to get my money out because I knew this was it," she said. "My daughter's grown, and this is where I'll stay. Just this morning I went outside and looked at all the stupid little things I planted, which are just pathetic. But I love having the green space."
Empty-nesters are, of course, among the buyers most likely to trade off a prime address for lower taxes and a better deal. In Connecticut, for example, Wendy Tremaglio and her husband, Ralph, a golf pro, opted for Norwalk about two years ago as a money-wise alternative to Westport, where they raised their daughter. As they shopped around for a house, their biggest priority was one-level living to make it easier for their two aging bichon frises to get around.
By crossing the Westport border into Norwalk's quiet Cranbury neighborhood the couple were able to get a large two-bedroom ranch with an attached garage on a third of an acre for just under $190,000. Taxes are $3,400 a year. They spent about $30,000 on renovations, including redoing the kitchen.
"But this house in Westport would have probably been about $400,000 or $500,000," said Mrs. Tremaglio, 44. And it's still only minutes away from her two places of employment -- her family's store, Dining In, in Norwalk and Riverside-Shavell Realty in Westport.
More up-and-coming is the Black Rock neighborhood of Bridgeport, a waterfront community along Black Rock Harbor. "I've heard of three or four instances now where people have sold their homes in Westport and moved to Black Rock," said Ken Scala, owner of Century 21 Scala and Clark in Bridgeport. "This is a trend now, it's really happening."
While Black Rock has most of Bridgeport's highest-priced homes, prices are still significantly less than the beach neighborhoods of Fairfield and Westport. For example, a four-bedroom, 1920's Cape Cod with a view of Long Island Sound recently sold in Black Rock for $211,500, with estimated taxes of $3,478. A similar-sized 1920's colonial on a slightly smaller lot in the beach area of Fairfield recently sold for $400,000, with estimated taxes of $3,500.
LAST summer, Nikita and Maiko Cheremeteff moved to Black Rock after 23 years in Westport. Mr. Cheremeteff, 66, had just retired as vice president for manufacturing at Loctite Corporation in Hartford, a chemical company, and the couple's four children were all living on their own. So the Cheremeteffs settled into a five-bedroom 1920's colonial in Black Rock on a hill overlooking the Sound. They paid $370,000.
"We wanted to move to a cheaper house, but a better house, a nicer house," Mr. Cheremeteff said. "And we wanted to be on the Metro-North line, so the children could come visit easily. We still do all of our shopping in Westport -- it's only seven minutes away. There are a lot of people around us who have moved here from Westport, basically for the same reason.
"Twenty years ago, we would have stayed in Westport because the school system is much better. But now, school is no longer a problem."
Buyer interest in Black Rock is such that prices have appreciated more there in the last 12 months than in any other area of Bridgeport, said Mr. Scala, the brokerage owner. "There's a real sense of community there," he said. "Neighbors gather at the Harbor View Market -- it's kind of the local meeting place."
To a great extent, the empty-nesters moving downmarket are encouraged to to so by a strong market and a seemingly endless supply of another breed of buyers, those willing to pay top dollar for the most desirable addresses. Indeed, it was a developer who bought the Cheremeteffs' 1970's split-level on two acres in Westport. He promptly razed the house to make way for a $2.6 million mansion.

LENGTH: 471 words

HEADLINE: One Museum That's Happy Just to Be Its Tranquil Self

BYLINE: By BILL KENT

 BODY:
THE sign for the Noyes Museum of Art points east off Route 9 in Oceanville, but the entrance to Lily Lake Road is easy to miss. You'll know you've gone too far north if you pass the cluster of restored 19th-century buildings called the Historic Towne of Smithville. And if you hit Atlantic City, you will have gone far too south.
Both Atlantic City and Smithville are the reason New Jersey's most beautifully situated museum exists. Fred and Ethel Noyes made their fortune with the Ram's Head Inn in Absecon, a dress-up surf-and-turf house catering to Atlantic City's visitors before the casino era, and the Smithville Inn, a Colonial-era stagecoach stop. The Noyeses became avid collectors of regional folk art, amassing one of the world's largest collections of antique waterfowl decoys, made by Atlantic City hotel workers unemployed during the winter, and sold to hunters for little more than $1. 
 In 1983, the couple spent $9 million to build a museum for their collections. They wanted the museum to link the Jersey Shore Pinelands environment with the art it inspired. Mrs. Noyes died shortly after the museum opened; Mr. Noyes left a foundation to perpetuate the museum when he died in 1987.
A central gallery displays some of Mr. Noyes's waterfowl decoys. A decoy carver is usually on site once a week to explain how they are made and why they have become so highly prized.
Two other galleries, as well as portions of the foyer, house 10 to 12 exhibitions of regional fine and folk art each year. At the moment, you can see family photographs by Rita Bernstein and "Brushes With Spirituality: Ethereal Paintings," a group show.
But the museum's most dramatic feature, one that easily attracts more attention than the art, is the view of Lily Lake from the lowest terrace. No matter what the season, the lush vista of the Forsythe Wildlife Refuge view evokes contemplation.
"A peaceful haven is not quite the image we want to project," said Jane Epstein, the museum's executive director. "Yes, it can get pretty quiet on the weekdays, and some people do visit for just that reason, but we've been taking great pains to establish the museum as a meeting ground between fine art and folk art, especially outsider art, the objects produced by artists who have not been professionally trained." A show of work by the reclusive self-taught painter Justin McCarthy opens on June 20.
Not counting the decoys, the museum has 300 artworks in its permanent collection. It shows work mostly from artists who live or have worked in the Northeast. The Noyes has benefited from state and private grants, some of them from casino companies, although the only exhibition that directly referred to Atlantic City was a somewhat satirical assembly of paintings and sculpture relating to the Miss America Pageant in 1997.

HEADLINE: IN PERSON: A Cloud Over the G.O.P.'s Silver Lining in Essex County;
After a Troubled Murder Investigation in Orange, James W. Treffinger Tangles With a Protege

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS 

DATELINE: NEWARK

 BODY:
JAMES W. TREFFINGER'S wife, Janet, has a name for it. She calls the decision five years ago -- when her husband chucked his lucrative partnership at a Wall Street law firm to become the first Republican county executive in Essex County in 35 years -- his "midlife crisis."
It wasn't the textbook case, a time of searching, redefinition and renewal, Mr. Treffinger said one day last week. But his wife's label was, he conceded, an accurate one nonetheless. 
 "I was Mayor of Verona and looking at the corrupt bloated county government," he said, noting that the county executive at the time, Thomas J. D'Alessio, a Democrat, was about to be convicted for money laundering, fraud and extortion. "It was my Moby Dick and I was Ahab. I jumped into the race and I enjoyed it and I redefined myself as a political reformer."
Today, as the 49-year-old official heads into his fifth year and his second term in office, he can boast of five consecutive county budgets in which he did not propose a tax increase. And in all but one of those years, his no-tax budgets survived. In 1998, under what he consider election-year pressure to tarnish his record, the eight-to-one Democratic majority on the Board of Freeholders overrode his budget proposal and increased taxes by $10 million.
Over that time he managed to mix cutbacks to a score of favored programs and sacred cows, passed along several county functions to the state, auctioned off some county assets to private industry, corralled support for these steps among leading Democrats -- all while cadging considerable assistance from Governor Whitman. In all, despite inflation and normal growth pressures, he cut county budgets from $530 million in 1994 to $506 million with his latest proposal that includes no tax increases.
With the completion of some important negotiations in recent weeks and an infusion of state money, Mr. Treffinger seems poised for yet another victory as the Freeholders begin their consideration of his budget.
But there is a cloud hovering as well.
He is engaged in a very public dispute with the Essex County Prosecutor, Patricia A. Hurt, his former deputy county executive and the woman whom he vigorously backed in 1997 to become the first black female prosecutor in the county and only the second in the state.
Ms. Hurt's office was already reeling from widespread criticism of its handling of the investigation into the shooting of a police officer in Orange and facing several state and Federal investigations of her office's actions. On April 8, a police woman was killed, and for six days she held a man who had a strong alibi, who passed a polygraph test and who later was cleared.
She suffered another blow when when Mr. Treffinger publicly charged her with extravagant spending that added to her troubles by leading to an audit by the State Attorney General's office.
The two have been locked in a dispute in which Ms. Hurt has seeking a budget increase for her office -- the busiest in the state -- to $29 million from $23.4 million last year. But Mr. Treffinger, alleging misuse of funds, has tried to hold her to last year's initial proposal of $22 million.
Ms. Hurt has fought back, charging that Mr. Treffinger's much-touted budget magic over the last five years has essentially been accomplished with smoke and mirrors. Contrary to cutting the budget and deficits of the past, she said, pointing to her role as advisor and confidant during the time, he left the county with a real deficit of $30 million. As the charges have gone back and forth over the last week, the words have grown angry and vituperative.
In his office last week, Mr. Treffinger said that the whole dispute had saddened him and made him wonder about what has happened to the idea of political loyalty.
"Like honor, it is a virtue, and I'm saddened that our friendship is damaged," he said. "This was someone I was fond of, my running mate when she ran for county registrar in 1994. But I deserve to take some of the responsibility for her because I was unabashed in my support for her to the Governor when she was appointed prosecutor. She was my idea."
Some suggest that Mr. Treffinger is being disingenuous in so lamenting the current dispute. They contend that he has abandoned Ms. Hurt at a time when she is besieged and weakened and has shown himself to have his own problem with loyalty. His support of her appointment reportedly aided his ability to attract black support during his re-election bid last year in a county where Democratic registration outstrips Republican by three to one and where the black population is more than 40 percent. That support could be jeopardized, some suggested, should Mr. Treffinger's attacks on Ms. Hurt further weaken her standing with Governor Whitman.
The Rev. Reginald T. Jackson, executive director of the influential Black Ministers Conference of New Jersey, said there was such concern about the split between the two officials that individual ministers had sought to meet with them separately to try to heal the rift. He said that there would be other efforts in the coming week to "try to bring them together".
"The ministers pushed for Ms. Hurt's appointment and some of them supported Mr. Treffinger's re-election last year," Mr. Jackson said. "It's important for us to not have the prosecutor under attack, but also important to have as prosecutor someone we can defend."
Mr. Treffinger insists that he did not set out to see that a black was appointed county prosecutor, but that he was, nevertheless, proud of that fact.
"I happen to believe in making the Republican Party as inclusive as possible and here was this person who was my friend and who I felt was qualified and I was glad that she was an African-American," he said. "Yes, I was proud of it and I talked about it."
Born James Padalino in Newark, Mr. Treffinger was adopted when he was 4 years old. He was raised in Maplewood and graduated from St. Benedict Prep School in Newark. He graduated from Seton Hall University magna cum laude and as a Fulbright scholar studied in Germany. He went on to receive a law degree at Rutgers University.
Practicing corporate law, he eventually became a partner in the firm of Hughes Hubbard & Reed. He began his political career as a member of the township council in Verona, where he eventually served a total of 13 years, rising to deputy mayor and then mayor and county freeholder simultaneously. A Democrat when he entered politics, Mr. Treffinger switched in midstream to the Republican Party in 1986 when he was mayor of Verona out of disappointment with soaring taxes and increasing burdens on local governments when the county was controlled by Democrats.
In 1994, when Democrats were split racially over the county executive race and reeling from the corruption convictions of many of its leaders, Mr. Treffinger squeaked into office by 2,400 votes. What he found were drawers still crammed with unpaid bills, a previously hidden budget deficit of $161 million and the imminent downgrading of the county's bonds to something just below junk bonds. He set out to improve things and won re-election by 7,000 votes last November on the strength of his fiscal stewardship and his political canniness in leveraging state help and cultivating Democratic allies.
While still mayor and well before moving into the county executive's office, Mr. Treffinger, by his own admission, became "obsessed" with the county machinations surrounding the future of 365 acres of densely wooded land, bordered by abandoned county medical buildings and straddling the communities of Verona, Cedar Grove and North Caldwell. He vigorously fought early proposals to sell it to private developers for construction of offices and a hotel and supported creating a park on the property called Hilltop.
In 1991, the county's Democratric administration was implicated in the illegal dumping of construction debris and hazardous waste on the property. Mr. Treffinger, who had helped uncover what was happening by making late-night visits to the county reservation to witness and document the illegal dumping, said that he became the administration's "implacable foe" and set out to come up with a plan to protect the area from further misuse and locally unwanted development.
"We wanted to make it idiot-proof by getting it out of county hands so they couldn't do anything worse with it, while at the same time creating some green space," he said.
Initially he had won approval to sell the land to the Essex County Improvement Authority, which issued bonds backed by the county, for a net gain of $32 million. That money was used to help reduce the deficit that Mr. Treffinger faced upon entering office and the plan was to sell off some of the land to developers to get the money to repay the bonds.
Last week, the county freeholders unanimously approved the final piece of Mr. Treffinger's plan. Several acres will be sold to private interests to be developed as single-family housing while privately developed senior citizen housing will be built on another portion of land surrounding the wooded Hilltop area. In addition, private developers will be sought out to construct a 350-bed center and a 1,000-bed nursing home and assisted-care facility.
And with the help of a grant from the state, 227 acres at the very top will be preserved as a county-state passive park where the most intensive activity will be hiking on a few trails. It is the combination of the money from the state purchase of the land and the proposed sale of other parcels to private developers that will wipe out the debt and prevent any new costs that could increased county spending and taxes.
"It was the dumping on Hilltop that really got me angry at a time when my only political ambition was to perhaps run for State Assembly," he said. "It got me back involved with the county and I started tilting at windmills and suddenly they were toppling over. The Hilltop plan is something that I will be very proud of when one day I take my grandchildren there."

HEADLINE: PERSONAL BUSINESS;
Not Doing What the Romans Do

BYLINE: By CAROL STEINBERG 

 BODY:
WHEN Kay Ainsley of Detroit traveled to Saudi Arabia several years ago to sell the rights to open Domino's Pizza shops there, she felt the full force of being a woman in a man's land.
Her business visa was rejected twice before the intervention of the Saudi businessman with whom she planned to negotiate. Then she arrived at their meeting room in Jidda to find that employees nearby had been cleared away because of her presence. 
 Dressed in a business suit, she was later asked to cover herself with an abaya, or traditional long black robe, for lunch at the businessman's home. In scouting the competition, Ms. Ainsley, then Domino's director of international development, found that a local sandwich shop didn't allow women, so she had to peer into a window and have male colleagues fetch take-out.
In a global economy, American business people are learning how to grin and bear overseas cultural challenges. Women, however, often face added obstacles.
Recent research suggests that only about one of every 8 or 10 managers assigned abroad by American corporations is a woman. But as more companies and more female executives see other women succeeding overseas and recognize that such jobs can speed advancement, more women are likely to go.
"Businesses in the U.S. have wrestled with their desire, honestly, to assign women who are otherwise qualified to work overseas," said Bill Carmell of Winston & Strawn in New York, a labor lawyer for management. "Part of the problem, though, for them has been the acceptance of that in some countries."
Darlene Orlov, a work-force consultant in New York specializing in sexual harassment, said some employers were quietly allowing potential cultural clashes to influence their choices for foreign jobs. "We all know it's illegal to allow your customer's preference for gender or race to determine who will be assigned to that business," she said of United States companies. "However, people still consider, 'Can we send a person into an environment where the customer might not be responsive?' "
RELOCATION experts say France, Italy, Spain and Eastern Europe are among the places where women are recognized first as business people and then as women. But they regard Japan, Australia, Saudi Arabia and much of Latin America as among the toughest places for an American woman to do business.
Ms. Ainsley, now a franchise consultant with Michael H. Seid & Associates of West Hartford, Conn., said she would go back to Saudi Arabia. But even she would advise clients otherwise. All things being equal, she said, "I'd probably assign a project to a male -- it would be easier for them to get business done."
The biggest challenge is to be sensitive to a culture, but not mimic it, said Nancy Adler, a professor of international management at McGill University in Montreal: " 'When in Rome do as the Romans do' is not particularly good advice, and it's horrible advice for women in many cultures."
When abroad, American businesswomen can circumvent some local customs by making it clear they are different from local women. A Japanese-American in Japan should clarify up front that she was born, say, in Kansas.
Women often must strive to be taken seriously. Sue Roll of Gaston, Ore., a human resources manager at the Intel Corporation, was ignored for 45 minutes while meeting with an employee training agency in Shanghai. Only after her male peers repeatedly turned to her and said, "Sue, you're in charge," was her authority acknowledged.
Women coach female colleagues to signal their importance by displaying their knowledge and having top executives send introductory letters, make calls and accompany them to meet clients. For small companies, an American consulate or industry group can open doors. Women are sometimes advised to travel in business class and stay in good hotels as symbols of their status.
As for building relationships, "the biggest mistake made by women is assuming they have to act identically to males," Ms. Adler said. Referring to foreign habits of heavy after-hours drinking, she said, "We have a quiet joke that it's possible to be highly successful as a woman in Asia without losing your liver."
That wasn't immediately apparent to Edith Parham Melton, who, as a customer-service executive for Lucent Technologies, covered Asia from Hong Kong until recently. She was included in dinners in Japan, but then male colleagues, Japanese and American, would drop her off at her hotel and go drinking. Rather than protest such exclusion, she continued to develop rapport through lunches and dinners. "It didn't impede the business relationship, but it took longer," she said.
Women have also found that even a casual comment can be misinterpreted. At a dinner in Japan, a male client told Jane Echols, who has a public relations firm in San Francisco, that her children must miss her when she travels. When she replied that her husband stayed home with them, "he was dumbfounded," she said, adding, "His image of me became someone who could overpower men."
There are ways to cope with, but still respect, foreign customs. In Pakistan, it is possible to evade the taboo against meeting with a man behind closed doors by keeping the door open or meeting as a group.
Although Ms. Ainsley completed her Saudi deal, she kept silent when she was banned from the contract signing at a palace in Riyadh; her boss, a man, signed instead. "I wasn't there to revolutionize their culture," she said.

HEADLINE: Janel Plank, Craig Peters

 BODY:
Janel Katherine Plank, the daughter of Peggy and Christopher Plank of Lake Placid, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Craig Tillman Peters, the son of Nancy and Merz Peters of New York. The Rev. Mark Demers, a United Methodist minister, performed the ceremony at the Adirondack Community Church.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS;
Insurers and Uninsured Put Hospitals in a Squeeze

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM 

 BODY:
AFTER a run of profitable years, hospitals across the country face cash-flow problems -- squeezed, officials say, by slow-paying managed-care companies, cutbacks in government programs and rapidly growing numbers of uninsured patients. Pressured by rising costs, hospitals are aggressively trying to collect mountains of overdue bills for patient care.
According to the hospitals, managed-care companies are routinely delaying payments by three or four months, even in states where delays that long are illegal, often by reporting that they have lost track of bills, including those transmitted electronically. 
 Adding to their problems, hospitals are feeling the effects of changes enacted in 1997 to the Medicare program, which covers elderly and disabled Americans and supplies more than half the revenue at many hospitals. The changes have reduced the hospitals' share of growth in program payments by billions of dollars.
Across the board, payments for patients plummeted 20 percent last year at the nation's most efficiently managed hospitals, according to preliminary findings by HCIA Inc., a Baltimore company that studies health care trends. By another widely used industry measure, HCIA said that the 100 best-managed hospitals had to wait 64 days last year, on average, to be paid, or five more days than in 1997.
The payment delays, along with rising costs for employees and prescription drugs, are pushing hospitals to seek new price increases, which would add to medical inflation, said John F. Hindelong, a health care analyst at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette.
But before raising rates, hospitals are trying new ways to collect money. They are hiring drivers to take uninsured low-income patients to Medicaid offices to sign up for benefits, combing through Medicare documents seeking overlooked payments, prodding managed-care insurers to pay more promptly and experimenting with ways to collect from patients more efficiently.
"We look under every rock to find money," said John Lavan, executive vice president and chief financial officer of New York Presbyterian Hospital, where almost one-third of the unpaid bills are more than four months old.
It is illegal in 21 states for insurers to delay payments to hospitals by more than 30 to 60 days, but it is not uncommon for such laws to be routinely flouted. The pain is especially sharp in New York, where the legal limit is 45 days but managed-care companies typically take three to four months to pay, according to Patricia Wang, a senior vice president of the Greater New York Hospital Association.
Enforcement is spotty and the penalties for late filing have so far been minor; state regulators fined 14 insurers for late payments last month. The biggest penalty so far this year was $91,900 in two fines assessed against Oxford Health Plans, hardly a heavy burden for a company with $4 billion in annual revenue. But Leslie Moran, a spokeswoman for the New York State Health Plans Association, said the fines were based on a "miniscule" number of claims among millions handled each month. She said most delays were caused by hospital billing errors.
Whatever their cause, the late payments are tying up working capital and will push more hospitals into operating losses if the money is not collected, Ms. Wang said.
The outlook is almost as dreary elsewhere. The Massachusetts Hospital Association said recently that its members were owed $163 million by health maintenance organizations, of which $122 million was for bills that were 90 or more days old. In Los Angeles, Cedars-Sinai Medical Center has more than $270 million in unpaid bills, and it takes 68 or 69 days, on average, to collect, said Bernadette Lodge-Lemon, the director of patient financial services.
Some hospitals have looked for ways to get faster payment on the portion of hospital bills that patients pay themselves. In some cases, they are urging patients to use major credit cards. Visa reported 14.5 percent growth in hospital-bill charges to its cards last year, which accounted for $665 million of its $12.1 billion in health care charges; Mastercard said its hospital charges were up 10 percent.
But hospital officials say many patients are reluctant to use their credit cards this way. Patients shy away from adding a big, open-ended charge -- the total owed may not be known until weeks after the patient goes home -- to cards that may already be near their credit limits.
Patients are in no big hurry to pay, either. "The consumer doesn't feel guilty about not paying the hospital, feeling it has gotten paid sufficiently by the insurer," said Dan Cain, a health care investment banker based in New York. And until recently, hospitals, especially nonprofits, have been timid about collecting from patients. "They are very concerned about their public relations," said Ted Smith, a vice president of the American Collectors Association, a Minneapolis-based trade group of credit officers, banks and card companies.
When all else fails, hospitals turn to collection agencies and sometimes sell receivables at discounts to financial firms that are more willing to pursue debtors.
To keep matters from reaching that point, several dozen medical centers have introduced credit cards just for hospital bills. Last fall, the Atlantic Health System in New Jersey started offering such a card, managed by Health Charge, a privately held finance company in Chevy Chase, Md.
With the card, patients of the system's four hospitals get 60 days to pay without owing interest; thereafter, they are charged the prime rate plus six percentage points, or 13.75 percent as of Friday, a moderate rate by credit card standards. The management company advances the hospital 50 percent of the total bill up front and keeps 5 percent of patients' principal and all interest paid. If the patient does not begin paying in 90 or 120 days, the hospital must return the advance. "It works pretty smoothly, especially for patients that don't have any insurance," said Diane Robinson, who tracks payments for Atlantic Health.
So far, only a small minority of patients are using the cards. Atlantic Health has issued cards to just 150 patients; nationwide, Health Charge has 8,000 card holders at 40 hospitals, according to Paul Devereaux, the company's general manager.
Still, health care is "a huge market that needs capital," said Robert Napoli, a financial services analyst in Chicago with ABN Amro, a Dutch bank. Banks, he added, are "not very good at understanding" health care, creating opportunities for niche players like Health Charge.

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW;
3 Ways a Frail Global Rally Could Come Again to Tears

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
WHEW. Glad that crisis is over.
From Bangkok to Berlin, people are celebrating the end of the global turmoil that started in Asia nearly two years ago -- investors, that is, not the unemployed of Indonesia, Thailand and South Korea, who are wondering what all the excitement is about. 
 While real economies languish, stock markets are surging. Thailand was up 10 percent on Wednesday. The South Koreans fret that their currency may be getting too strong. Hong Kong just witnessed its own Internet frenzy. Even Russia's market is rising, now that the International Monetary Fund has agreed to make believe the country can pay its debts.
Nonetheless, this is a pretty nervous group of partygoers. Catch a finance minister or central banker in a moment of candor, and you discover someone surveying the land for signs of imminent eruptions.
Here are a few of the favorite worst-case scenarios kicking around:
The fate of the world economy rests on the performance of Yahoo and a handful of other American stocks. If they buckle, kiss the rest of the world's markets goodbye.
Overly simplistic it may be, but this thinking has a certain gut appeal. American consumers are on a spending spree, egged on by a wealth effect based on how much a rising market has added to their net worth. Sung Won Sohn of Wells Fargo Economics notes that housing and traditional consumer spending equaled 119 percent of the amount by which the economy grew in the first quarter, meaning consumers more than compensated for a sharp fall in exports.
The stock market's rise, in turn, is built on a strikingly small galaxy of star stocks, though the galaxy has grown a bit lately.
So the theory goes that if those stocks crack, consumer spending cracks, too, ravaging the rest of the market. And as America stops sucking in the world's exports, countries and regions that depend on American demand -- Japan, Latin America, Europe, Southeast Asia -- also go over a cliff.
This theory is widely discussed in the upper reaches of the Clinton Adminstration, but never in public. "Too radioactive," one of the President's economic advisers says. "Too ugly to think about."
The fate of the world economy has less to do with Yahoo than with a bunch of yahoos in the Japanese parliament.
Washington politicians like this one more because it places the blame on the world's second-largest economy. All hands nodded politely as Japan's Prime Minister, Keizo Obuchi, explained last week that the country's worst troubles were behind it, that the recovery was in sight, that after seven years of fumbling the Government had figured out what to do. And as soon as Mr. Obuchi was out of earshot, most of Mr. Clinton's advisers had the same reaction: Yeah, right.
Here's the fear: The Japanese Government is spending roughly 8 percent of gross national product on a stimulus package to reflate the economy andis predicting a growth rate of 0.5 percent this year. Everyone else thinks the economy will go on shrinking. Even the International Monetary Fund, which hates to offend its members, downgraded its 1999 projection to a 1.4 percent decline in G.N.P.
Despite the Government's huge spending spree, Japanese companies say they are still cutting back on capital investment in new plants and technology. And that's where the disaster scenarios start.
The Government can't keep spending like that. "They are pretty much out at the limit now," says Edward Lincoln, a Brookings Institution economist who once worked as special adviser to Walter F. Mondale when he was Ambassador to Japan. And if the tap runs dry, Japan's slow retreat could turn to a rout -- a highly contagious one.
Yet Japanese legislators visiting Washington in recent weeks acknowledged that they had no plan for speeding the restructuring of Japanese industry, because that would mean more unemployment. Instead, they talk about "job preservation" and steer the conversation away from the Internet and toward the travails of rice farming.
Shades of 10 years ago, or 20. It suggests that Japan's political system is still unable to come to terms with how its economy must be transformed.
Forget Yahoo and the Japanese yahoos. The real trouble is a counterattack on a fellow named Zhu.
That would be Zhu Rongji, China's Prime Minister. No sooner did he arrive back from his trip to the United States than Chinese businesses began assailing him for the concessions he made in trying to gain membership for China in the World Trade Organzation.
The telecommunications minister reportedly threatened to quit. The Government began hinting that some of the offers were coming off the table and then ordered the removal of some foreign-origin programs from satellite television systems -- not exactly an embrace of the global economy.
China, of course, is still an economy unto itself. So even if Mr. Zhu were to lose his war to modernize the economy, or China's insolvent banks were to acknowledge their insolvency and go over the edge, it might not matter much in the rest of the world.
On the other hand, it's a bigger country than Thailand. And look what happened after a little problem there.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BOERUM HILL;
Magazine Revises Its Span

BYLINE: By COREY KILGANNON 

 BODY:
Brooklyn Bridge may not be falling down, but the magazine can no longer afford to be published monthly, its owner and editor in chief, Melissa Ennen, said last week.
Three of the five news staff members were laid off on April 30, and the magazine will now be put together by freelance editors and writers and published every other month, Ms. Ennen said. The production and sales staff will remain, she said. 
In August 1995, Ms. Ennen, a North Carolina native with no journalism experience, used family money to start Brooklyn Bridge, whose offices are in an old machine factory on Atlantic Avenue in Boerum Hill.
Ms. Ennen, 46, who also lives in the neighborhood, said she had invested $5.3 million into the magazine, which has not made a profit. "I could have retired on the French Riviera five years ago," she said. "Instead I started the magazine, not to make a killing, but so Brooklyn would have something to read."
She blamed herself for mistakes in hiring and said the magazine had problems deciding what kinds of articles and covers would attract readers. There were also difficulties in getting the magazine to Manhattan newsstands, she said.
Circulation, which Ms. Ennen said is not audited, has remained steady around 35,000, she said, 31,000 by subscription. She said the annual subscription price for new subscribers will be $12 a year for six copies. (Current subscribers paid $18.) And the $2.75 newsstand price will go up 25 cents, to $3.
Martin S. Walker, chairman of Walker Communications, a magazine consulting firm, said the decision to publish less frequently "sounds like a last gasp."
"What they're saying is, 'We can get the same number of ads in 6 months as we did in 12, and only pay half the printing and distribution costs,' " Mr. Walker said. Brooklyn's diverse ethnic communities and its neighborhoods with disparate economic conditions make it hard to gain a readership base and attract national advertisers, he said.
Ms. Ennen called this her "fundamental challenge," but said that her magazine has a diverse readership. "Most people think we're a Slopey, Heightsy magazine, but half our readers don't even live in brownstone Brooklyn," she said. The goal, she said, is to publish "something for everyone."
"It feels drastic, but Brooklyn Bridge will be fine," she said. COREY KILGANNON

HEADLINE: INVESTING WITH: BERNICE S. BEHAR;
John Hancock Emerging Growth Fund

BYLINE: By CAROLE GOULD 

 BODY:
PORTFOLIO managers who limit themselves to small-capitalization stocks face a recurring quandary: Their best performers grow into mid- and large-cap stocks, forcing them to sell.
Bernice S. Behar, lead portfolio manager of the $650 million John Hancock Emerging Growth fund, understands the problem -- and welcomes it. "Our goal is to buy companies that graduate out of the fund, like Starbucks and E*Trade," she said, referring to two previous stock picks. (Actually, the fund still holds a small amount of Starbucks shares.) 
 Ms. Behar succeeds by identifying stocks that benefit from economic, demographic or industry trends like outsourcing and Internet growth. "The linchpin for us is finding companies that are exploiting a change," she said from her Boston office, overlooking the Charles River.
In a period when many small-company stock funds have struggled, Emerging Growth has turned in a solid performance. It returned 12.8 percent, annualized, for the three years ended April 30, versus 5.6 percent for the average small growth fund, according to Morningstar Inc., the Chicago financial publisher. And for the 12 months ended April 30, the fund returned 5.9 percent, versus a loss of 4.9 percent for the peer group.
Ms. Behar, 38, came to money management via Tokyo, where she studied at International Christian University. Her fluency in Japanese helped lead to a job at Sanyo Securities America in New York, as an analyst focusing on Japanese stocks. She moved to Boston in 1990 to work as an analyst on John Hancock's Pacific Basin fund, and soon began focusing on small-cap United States stocks in a variety of positions.
She looks for companies with revenue and earnings growth of at least 20 percent a year. But she said she shuns using computer screens to find them: "We take a bottom-up, analytic approach," she said.
Ms. Behar personally covers retail, consumer-product and business-services stocks. One other portfolio manager who works with her focuses on technology, another on health care, while an assistant portfolio manager covers media, entertainment and education. Their industry expertise helps pinpoint companies that offer both outstanding growth potential and top-flight executives. "Management takes on a heightened importance in small companies," she said, "because they need not only a vision of where their market is but how the company will grow to serve the market."
Ms. Behar considers unloading stocks that lag behind the Russell 2000 Growth index or their industry groups for a year from the time they are bought.
Small-cap growth stocks, of course, are an especially risky lot. "These stocks can be quite volatile, because of the lack of liquidity," she said, "and the companies themselves are volatile because they're in their early stages of development."
Diversification helps to lower the fund's risks. The fund owns 180 companies, each accounting for just 0.4 percent to 1.4 percent of assets.
But Ms. Behar doesn't buy the tiniest companies -- or stocks with little liquidity. She looks for those with market capitalizations of at least $100 million and a 10-day average daily trading volume of at least 100,000 shares.
IN February, she bought shares of Pacific Sunwear of California, a retailer with 350 stores nationwide, for $27.54 a share. The company sells casual clothing for teen-age boys, a fast-growing group, Ms. Behar said. She said the company's management is adept in a fickle business, shifting rapidly as fashion trends change. The company, based in Anaheim, Calif., is introducing a line of clothes geared toward older customers -- in their early 20's.
She expects Pacific Sunwear to earn $1.50 a share this year, and she sees annualized earnings growth of 30 percent over the next three years. The stock closed on Friday at $34.125.
Another favorite is Getty Images of Seattle, which provides images to advertising companies, magazines and newspapers and which last week agreed to buy Art.com, a Chicago-based seller of art images, for up to $202 million in cash and stock. Getty has a library of 30 million images; customers use them in lieu of hiring photographers. The company recently signed an agreement with Amazon.com to supply photographs for its on-line greeting cards.
Ms. Behar first bought Getty Images shares in January 1998 at $19.29. She expects the company, which lost $36.4 million last year, to post a 28 percent increase in after-tax cash flow in 1999 and to become profitable in 2001. The stock closed on Friday at $27.875.
A third holding is Exodus Communications of Santa Clara, Calif., a company that develops and maintains Web sites. Clients include Yahoo, Ebay and Lycos. One positive for the stock, of course, is the growth of the Internet, she said, "but it's also an outsourcing play, because it costs companies six times as much to develop and run their Web site themselves than to have Exodus do it."
The fund first bought Exodus stock in March 1998, at $15. The company lost $66.4 million in 1998, but she figures that its gross revenues will grow 70 percent a year, on average, over the next two years, and that it will be profitable by the fourth quarter of 2000. The stock closed on Friday at $80.50.

HEADLINE: PERSONAL BUSINESS;
How Much Protection For Bank Customers?

BYLINE: By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

 BODY:
YOUR bank can collect details about your spending habits, like how much you charged last year at lingerie, liquor and lawn-and-garden stores, and then sell that information to companies that market bras, booze and bug killers.
And your bank is not required to tell you if it does. Nor can you do anything about it, except maybe pay for everything with cash (in which case your bank can collect and sell data on your A.T.M. use patterns). 
 Last week, President Clinton pressed for tougher laws to curb or at least improve disclosure of what he called banking industry abuses like these. Consumer advocates say, however, that with the Government unlikely to afford adequate protections, bank customers must be wary.
The President wants to have banks improve disclosure of fees, charges and interest rates. Consumer groups say that bank customers shouldn't have to be corporate lawyers or accountants to comprehend what their banks are offering.
"Many people in this country are essentially math-illiterate, and they need information disclosed in terms that they can understand but that Congress is not requiring," said Gary Klein of the Consumer Law Center in Boston.
Mr. Clinton wants credit card issuers who lure customers with low teaser rates to state prominently how much they charge after the introductory periods -- in some cases, more than 2 percent a month. For now, customers should concentrate not on the initial rates, often promoted even on the envelopes containing these offers, but on the regular rates, sometimes disclosed in small print and sometimes not at all.
Automated teller machines present special challenges. People who use A.T.M.'s operated by banks where they do not have accounts often have to go through several steps to learn whether and what they will be charged. Last week, the Senate approved a requirement that banks post charges on the machines.
Several of the President's proposals are meant to protect customers' privacy. Mary Griffin, a lawyer for Consumers Union, the nonprofit publisher of Consumer Reports magazine, wants Congress, at a minimum, to require full disclosure in plain English when banks sell information about their customers and their spending habits. Better yet, she said, customers should be able to block the sharing or sale of this information, as President Clinton has proposed.
But in the Senate, which last week passed a bill to repeal the core laws that have governed the banking industry since the Depression, the focus was much less on protecting consumers than on letting banks, insurers and securities firms enter one another's businesses.
The President says that as banks expand their domains, there is greater need for new restrictions and privacy protections. When one company can own a bank, an insurance company and a brokerage firm, he said last week, "you should not have to worry that the results of your latest physical will be used to deny your application for a mortgage or a credit card."
Consumer advocates also want Congress to prohibit banks from pitching insurance and investment products to people with pending loan applications, a practice they regard as coercive. Banks aren't allowed to turn down loan applicants for refusing to buy other products, but those seeking loans often have the opposite impression. Consumer advocates advise applicants to get their loans first, then choose insurance and investments separately and free from untoward pressure.
THE consumer groups say the President should have tried to give customers who buy securities from banks at least as many rights as those who buy from brokers. Most important, they say, are protections against being steered into unsuitable investments, like an especially volatile mutual fund or Internet stocks for an elderly widower with only modest savings.
Also missing from the President's proposals are limits on the rates banks can charge on loans or credit cards, consumer groups say. States used to set limits, but Congress, with the backing of the Supreme Court, has asserted its dominance.
Banks say the loosening of restrictions benefits many customers, because interest rates can be set according to each borrower's credit risk. While some people pay higher rates because of poor credit histories, the banks say, others now borrow at lower rates.
But with credit card lenders having to write off only 1 percent of the money owed them, Mr. Klein said, punitive rates are not justified.
While the President is threatening to veto the Senate bill for weakening regulations aimed at making sure banks lend in the inner cities, he has not listed the other consumer issues as veto bait.
Banking trade groups say that issues as complex as privacy and disclosure should be dealt with separately, rather than having them jeopardize legislation needed now. "These consumer protection issues," said Ed Yingling, chief lobbyist for the American Bankers Association, "are not germaine to the bill."
But Stephen Brobeck, executive director of the Consumer Federation of America, said that the longer the delays, the greater the need to police bank practices. "Banks are pushing the envelope in every direction, testing consumers and regulators," he said. "And why? Because their consumer business is far and away their most profitable business."

HEADLINE: PORTFOLIOS, ETC.;
Industrial Metals: The Tea Leaf Commodities

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
THE price of copper has jumped 15.4 percent since its low this year, to 70.78 cents a pound. The price of tin is up 12 percent from its 1999 low; nickel, 41.3 percent; lead, 11.8 percent, and aluminum, 17.1 percent.
So what? 
 The price of spot copper is still 17.3 percent below its 1998 high. Aluminum is down 13 percent; tin, 10.4 percent; lead, 10.2 percent, and nickel, 6 percent. The prices of these metals, all traded on the London Metal Exchange, are even further below their highs of the last big commodity rally, which reached its peaks in 1995 and 1996. (And at the same time, agricultural commodities, except for hogs, are still declining.)
For for all kinds of investors, there are reasons to be concerned. But there is one issue -- inflation -- that is not worth worrying about yet.
The recent rise in industrial commodity prices is important because it could help lead to rising wages and, therefore, more inflationary pressures.
One of the recent surprises for economists has been the slowdown in the rate of wage increases, despite a drop in unemployment. The April employment data released on Friday showed that the increase in average hourly earnings had slowed to 3.4 percent in the last year, below the 3.8 percent for the 12 months ended in December.
One theory to explain it is that the sharp decline in the inflation rate in 1998 tempered wage demands. The Consumer Price Index rose just 1.6 percent last year.
Ian Shepherdson, chief United States economist at High Frequency Economics in Valhalla, N.Y., thinks the C.P.I. will end the year up about 2 percent. That is not a major increase. But he thinks that the jump in oil and gasoline prices will temporarily push the annual rate of increase in the C.P.I. to 2.5 percent. And that headline, he said, "will not play well in Peoria, and it could well affect pay negotiations later this year."
The price increases in metals could also signal that the global economy is turning around, a fact that would make a slowdown here less likely and a rate increase by the Federal Reserve, to put a drag on growth, more likely.
What is happening globally is one of the most important questions for investors over the next several months. The selloff last week in the bond market, which pushed the yield on the 30-year bond up to 5.81 percent, the highest in almost a year, was prompted in part by the fear that a rebound in Asia and Europe would make a slowdown here almost impossible.
Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, compounded that concern by saying on Thursday that the global financial crisis appears to have passed. He said the threat was now that low employment would drive wages -- and inflation -- higher.
If commodity prices are accelerating, Mr. Shepherdson said, "it is more likely that the world economy is turning around."
Mr. Shepherdson and other economists caution that, as of now, this is the likely, but not the certain, outcome. There are not enough data yet to prove that the global economy has turned around. While South Korea and some other Asian countries are showing signs of revival, Japan is still a big question mark. And Europe is sluggish despite the surprising interest-rate cut last month by the European Central Bank.
William O'Neill, director of futures research at Merrill Lynch, said: "It is premature to say that commodities are telling us that we are heading to a new global economic boom. But the worst may be over."
What is not to worry about is that inflation is going to shoot dangerously higher. "We're not set for a big commodity or inflation boom," Mr. O'Neill said.
A main reason is that commodities constitute such a small part of American products, making up less than 10 percent of the total cost, according to Mr. Shepherdson. And companies can offset the higher costs. So outside of oil and gasoline, it is very difficult to predict what portion of commodity price increases will reach the consumer.

PUB-DATE: May 9, 1999,

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 4; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 2342 words

HEADLINE: A Capitalist Hero Keeps On Pitching;
The Corny Charm of Buffettpalooza

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA 

DATELINE: OMAHA

 BODY:
IF there's one thing that the thousands of pilgrims who made their way here last weekend would be loath to say about Warren E. Buffett, it's that he's shameless.
But it's true. No other American chief executive may be so plain-spoken or so masterful an investor. Nor does any other American chief executive do so many hokey things. 
 In the course of the annual, three-day gathering of investors in his company, Berkshire Hathaway -- a get-together that he has called the capitalists' Woodstock -- Mr. Buffett could be seen all over town. He donned an old-time baseball uniform to throw out the first pitch at a minor league game, to Hall of Famer Ernie Banks. (Mr. Buffett's number: 1/16, in homage to Wall Street and its stock fractions.) He also signed autographs outside Gorat's, his favorite steakhouse. He played bridge, "the official game of Berkshire Hathaway," at a local mall -- against a former world champion.
And during Berkshire's six-hour annual meeting here in Berkshire Hathaway's hometown last Monday, a session generally regarded as one of the best financial seminars conducted anywhere each year, Mr. Buffett ritualistically swigged Cherry Cokes and nibbled at See's candies and Dairy Queen ice cream bars -- all products of Berkshire holdings, all demonstrations of his penchant for concrete investments in things you can use every day.
Hucksterism? Of course. Mr. Buffett, 68, a kind of Will Rogers character with John D. Rockefeller's bank account, has mastered the art. But Berkshire Hathaway shareholders don't care. Like teen-agers at a marathon rock concert -- or, perhaps, religious devotees at a revival meeting -- some 15,000 of them came here to soak up his every word and gesture.
They waited in long lines wherever he went, simply to get their hero's signature on old photographs, annual reports he had written, ticket stubs, baseball caps, dollar bills or books. They shopped at Borsheim's jewelry store and the Nebraska Furniture Mart, Omaha businesses he bought for Berkshire because he thought their owners were brilliant merchants; they drove by the modest house that Mr. Buffett bought for $32,000 in 1958 and still calls home.
One visitor said he'd rather be in Omaha than at the Super Bowl. Another shareholder, Laurence Day of St. Louis, said he told his wife he preferred Omaha to Paris this time of year. And Richard Dejonckheere, a sports trainer from Belgium, remarked: "Like every good Moslem goes to Mecca, I come here. Every shareholder or capitalist should go one time to Omaha."
It is like this here every spring around the first Monday in May -- even in years, including this one, when Berkshire Hathaway stock is lagging behind the broader market and the investing world has been agog over technology companies instead of Mr. Buffett's favored consumer brands. After more than 30 years of whipping the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, his followers happily make allowances for Mr. Buffett's minor miscues.
"I'm not worried," said Frank Booker, an investor who came from St. Simons Island, Ga. "We've been through this before. And I don't know anyone else I'd rather have as the captain of my capital."
Partly, maybe mostly, such affection is fueled by the love of money. The faithful know that Mr. Buffett's investing catechism has generated astonishing returns. They can cite the figures by heart: a $10,000 investment in Berkshire in 1965 would be worth about $65 million today. Though the class A shares are up less than 10 percent this year, about half as much as the Dow Jones industrials, this follows a 50 percent increase for the shares in 1998.
But more is at work here. The pilgrims flock to Omaha because the huckster seems so sincere.
With his focus on the long term and his antipathy for the trendy, Mr. Buffett may be out of step with Wall Street and much of corporate America, they say. But he represents something they find wholesome, true and uniquely American. By all accounts he lives simply, well below his means and with few of the trappings of wealth. And in a marketplace crowded with whispering insiders, accountants' obfuscations and boosters happy to promote stocks at almost any price, he speaks directly to his shareholders, in language they can understand and with the kind of wit and wisdom they can appreciate.
In short, shareholders say they come each year because Mr. Buffett and Berkshire embody not just value investing but values. Study hard, he says. Search out sound advice. Know your limitations. And ask the right questions.
"It's a philosophy of investing and a philosophy of life," said Jeffrey Crohn, who came here from Mount Kisco, N.Y., for the Berkshire meeting with his wife, Kathleen, and left with a new bedroom set, television cabinet and patio furniture from the Nebraska Furniture Mart.
The Crohns, who say they have seven shares of Berkshire's class B stock -- the version that now sells for about $2,500 a share, versus the $77,000 price tag that keeps the original class A shares beyond the reach of most investors -- are now passing on those lessons to their children. "Buffett takes a very common-sense approach to life," Mr. Crohn said. "You achieve what you achieve through hard work and sound management."
 
Getting With the Program
There are moments during the Berkshire weekend when the Warren worship seems to get out of hand.
When Mr. Buffett stopped at Borsheim's, which was opened on Sunday just for shareholders, the store was mobbed, with shoppers spilling into the common area of the Regency Mall. Eager to record the moment, one woman yelled, "Honey, hurry up and take the picture!" as Mr. Buffett passed through. Later that evening, when he downed his trademark T-bone steak with a double order of hash browns at a shareholders' dinner at Gorat's, 200 others, lemming-like, ordered the identical meal, the manager said.
Even the news media grew idolatrous. During a two-hour news conference in which Mr. Buffett and Berkshire's vice chairman, Charles T. Munger, waxed poetic about investing, one reporter interrupted to say: "Mr. Buffett, I want to go to a warm and fuzzy place. I'm very taken with the fact that your shareholders are very taken with you." As the session ended, the gathered reporters broke, uncharacteristically, into applause.
Not long after, Marc Norton of The Louisville Courier-Journal, who had posed a serious question during the news conference, nabbed Mr. Buffett in the parking lot and asked him to pose for a picture.
"Here, I'll whisper a stock tip in your ear," Mr. Buffett said, and he jokingly pretended to do so just as the picture was snapped. "What did he say?" another reporter begged to know as Mr. Buffett disappeared.
Mr. Buffett has taken note of the frenzied rise of his profile. "There's no question the celebrity aspect has gotten played up," he told the reporters. "But Berkshire shareholders know what they own."
Besides the little companies he hawks so unabashedly, they own a huge insurance business, made up largely of Geico, which sells auto and other insurance directly to consumers, and General Re, a reinsurer that Mr. Buffett bought last year. And they share in Berkshire's storied portfolio of stocks: By investing in companies with rich consumer franchises like Coca-Cola, Gillette, Walt Disney, Washington Post and American Express, Mr. Buffett has made Berkshire -- a small company of which he gained control in 1965 -- into a company now worth $116 billion.
"This is a unique person in the history of capitalism," said Stevin R. Hoover, a money manager from Boston who has been a Berkshire shareholder since 1982 and was on his 10th trip to Omaha. "He's made most of us a lot of money."
Mr. Buffett's style of value investing, however, is largely out of fashion these days. And that has made Omaha -- and the figurative Omaha that exists wherever Berkshire shareholders reside -- a peculiar outpost in a financial world enamored of momentum trading, the latest hot new offering and Internet stocks valued at multiples of their losses, not their earnings.
But Mr. Buffett remains the world's second-richest man -- after only his friend William H. Gates, the co-founder of Microsoft -- and is the architect of countless Berkshire fortunes. In fact, many people travel to Omaha simply to thank him for setting them on the road to riches -- riches that they also tend not to flaunt.
"We're millionaires, but who would know?" said Ernest Arvesen, 61, a retired banker from Atlanta. "Not our neighbors."
Not, that is, unless they looked in the closets and medicine cabinets of Mr. Buffett's devotees.
Mr. Day, the St. Louis investor, had his epiphany in 1982, when he was sitting on a beach in northern Michigan with a pile of Berkshire Hathaway annual reports. "I read them and I was totally absorbed," he recalled. "I said, My God, this is it." Now Mr. Day, 65, arranges his everyday life around Mr. Buffett's favorite stocks, living by the theory that the investor's sidekick, Mr. Munger, likes to call "eating your own cooking."
"I buy every one of Berkshire's products," Mr. Day said. "Gillette razors. Coke. And now I have Geico insurance." He recently was married -- and naturally, his wedding ring was bought at Borsheim's.
 
The Oracle Speaks
Most shareholders, however, say they come to Omaha not to buy Berkshire goods but to listen to Mr. Buffett's lengthy question-and-answer session at the annual meeting -- the formal raison d'etre for the weekend hoopla.
This year, they lined up as early as 4:30 A.M. outside the Aksarben (that's Nebraska, spelled backwards) Auditorium, which seats 14,000. And when the doors opened two and a half hours later, Mr. Buffett was there to greet those who rushed through the turnstiles.
The billionaire then hopped into his Lincoln Town Car and drove out through the parking lot, waving to a long line of shareholders waiting to enter the arena.
When everyone was in place, Mr. Buffett and Mr. Munger entered the packed auditorium to a standing ovation, in what shareholders describe as a kind of parting of the waters as the two made their way toward the stage.
The two men quickly ran through the official business of the company. And then -- when most annual meetings would abruptly be adjourned -- they opened the floor to questions, which they answered patiently, often with a good deal of wit, until 3:30 P.M.
(Actually, Mr. Buffett answered most of the questions, with occasional philosophical musings from the generally silent, seemingly lifeless Mr. Munger, whom Mr. Buffett introduced this way: "If you haven't figured it out, this hyperkinetic bundle of energy on my left is Charlie Munger.")
The shareholders asked about everything -- Mr. Buffett's investment philosophy, of course, and what the company would look like after his death. (He has already named successors, he said -- without naming names -- and "they'd be ready to take over tomorrow.")
They asked the personal, too. Was he interested in a career in music? (No, though he sang "Tomorrow" at a benefit performance of the musical "Annie" last year.)
What books would he recommend? "Personal History" (Knopf, 1997), the autobiography of Katharine Graham, the former publisher of The Washington Post, and "Common Sense on Mutual Funds" (Wiley, 1999), by John C. Bogle, senior chairman and founder of the Vanguard Group.
Shareholders also posed pointed queries about specific investing decisions, including why Mr. Buffett chose to sell a large number of shares in McDonald's last year -- shares that later skyrocketed.
"It was a mistake," he said, repeating what he told shareholders in this year's annual report: "Over all, you would have been better off last year if I had regularly snuck off to the movies during market hours."
And they asked about the prospects for core Berkshire holdings like Coca-Cola, Gillette and Disney, whose chief executive, Michael D. Eisner, took a break on Monday from the ugly trial over his feud with a former company executive to visit the Main Street U.S.A. of Mr. Buffett's annual meeting.
All those stocks have badly trailed the market lately, but Mr. Buffett gave no hint of souring on any of them. About Coca-Cola, in which Berkshire had an 8 percent stake at the end of last year, he said, "Through the next 20 years, preference for Coke will do nothing but grow."
He steered away from stock recommendations or predications, however, though shareholders repeatedly encouraged a leak. Despite his occasional big bet on macroeconomic trends -- he bought 111 million ounces of silver in 1997, for example, expecting the price to soar with growing demand -- he declined to forecast interest rates or discuss the big economic picture. Mr. Buffett may sometimes seem like a hayseed, but he is not about to show other market players his hand.
Again and again, Mr. Buffett said that he doesn't pay attention to the everyday swings in the market: "We don't worry about the performance of the stock; we worry about the performance of the company." True to his habit of talking down Berkshire's prospects, he acknowledged difficulty in finding good values in a highly valued market, and the near impossibility of keeping a $100 billion company's value growing at 20 percent or more a year, as his investors have come to expect.
Some shareholders, nervously challenging their guru, asked why he didn't embrace the technology stocks that so many other investors look to for growth. Mr. Buffett said that while the technology revolution has changed the economic landscape, he doesn't know how to evaluate the long-term prospects of such stocks -- and that the values assigned many of them by the market indicate that other investors don't, either.
Taking bites from a Dairy Queen ice cream bar, Mr. Buffett said he simply buys what he knows, then offered a judgment he has no doubt debated over many bridge games with his friend Mr. Gates. "The Dilly Bar," he said with a smile, "is more certain to be around in 10 years than any single software application."
